This works well for my wife's Fitbit Flex, the Flex sits in a little pocket under the bracelet and after a couple months of use it is still together and working without a problem.The quality is good for what you pay so I would recommend this if you are in the market for jewelery to hide you flex...Just my thoughts,AK

Full disclosure this was sent to me specifically so I could review it.  But I am giving my honest opinion of the product.Update:**After using it for a couple weeks I noticed it has become harder to swivel when containers have things in them.  This is not something I would expect even at this price point so I have -1 star for that...  I think this is due to the plastic warping a but under the weight of full containers of things like sugar.  I moved the heaviest (not very heavy) to the bottom and lighter up top and this has solved this for the time being**This is an interesting concept for a spice container.  I am using it for some of the things I use a lot of.  Sugar, bullion cubes, powdered creamer so far. I haven't decided what to put in the other 2 compartments yet...That said this is a plastic item, not glass and metal.  Also it is worth noting this does not contain "bottles" they are cups that rotate around a central core and they do not seal closed (Implied by the wording bottle)But I feel the price point reflects that which is why I left the rating at 5 stars.  If they made a glass and metal version that seals in this style this I would definitely get it.It took some thought of what to put into the compartments since it isn't quite big enough for bulk items you might use like flour and the compartments don't seal shut so keep that in mind.Overall I am pleasantly surprised by this spice organizer.  I had thought about using it for medications, but the pill bottles my pharmacy gives out are too large and I don't like the idea of having unsecured medications in the house, but that is a thought...  Also it does come apart easily for quick cleaning.My Rating:Price for what it is: 5 StarsNot Sealing containers: -1 StarComes with spoons: +.5 StarEase of cleaning: +.5 StarOverall 5 Star RatingJust my Thoughts,AK

I tried, I really wanted this to work and despite some of the reviews I bought the shine. For 2 weeks it worked great, then for the last 3 days it will not sync, no matter what I do.  It was always slow to sync up,  usually taking a couple tries but for 45 minutes I tried to get this thing to work, and I'm done.  I contacted misfit support 72 hours ago and haven't heard a word. (I have been trying to sync for the last 72 his as well)  I never even tried out the waterproofing it claims to have.I rate this 2 stars only because it's good looking and is supposed to be waterproof.5 stars-1 star for it stopping syncing after 2 weeks.-2 stars for absolutely no customer service support.To sum up,  spend a little more and get a fitbit or similar.  Apparently when it comes to fitness trackers you really do get what you pay for...Just my thoughts,AK

Excellent companion app to Blue Iris software.  I run 8 IP cameras on the Blue Iris Desktop software and this app picks everything up without any issues.

Solid Wireless Mouse.At first I had issues where I was bumping the DPI button on the top of the mouse (My old one was single DPI) so I would be cruising along and my mouse would either slow or jump depending on what was happening. But after about a week that issue went away as I got used tot the feel of a new mouse.  and now after a month of use I am happy with it and have not yet had to change batteries or do anything with it.  I only do light gaming but it works great for that and for everyday use...I had never heard of this brand before but after using it I would recommend it for daily use...Just my thoughts,AK

I bought this to connect up a home network with at least 1 Cat6 line in every room.  So far 6 months in I have had 0 issues and this switch even with all 16 ports in use has not choked on the traffic...  It may not fit in a rack without some form of adapter as it's not a full size switch, but sitting on my shelf it is perfectly happy, never gets hot and has never failed to operate or been the cause of any failures.No software needed, no real experience needed.  This switch is simply plug and play.  (Most are plug and play now, but I thought it was worth mentioning)I would absolutely recommend this if you are looking for a 16 port switch and the price is right for you.Just my thoughts.AK

Excellent Cable, No signal issues over the 50 foot.  I am running a Gigabit AP powered by PoE on this cable and it is working without a problem.  The cable is well packaged and solid quality.  I like Cable Matters Cat6 cables, I have bought over 100 in the last few years for varous projects and I have has none that failed either the speed or quality tests I do...I would recommend this cable if the length and price are right for you.Just my thoughts,AK

Good single cable HDMI-Ehternet-HDMI adapter.  The picture is as good ad just on HDMI even over a 75 foot cable and I have seen no stutter or quality issues with it.BUT I only gave it 4 stars because the Ethernet connection on the receiver side of the system doesn't want to stay tight.  But I fixed that by using a bit of electrical tape to hold the cable in the plug (Not a huge issue, but could speak to a design flaw)So I would recommend this if you need a 1 way HDMI cable (This does NOT do 2 way HDMI)Just my Thoughts,AK

I bought these for install in my parents house to (Pardon the pun) unify their WiFi network which had been handled by 3 typical routers, 2 of which were in AP mode.  In my case the wires were already mostly in place, I just had to move them from the wall into the ceiling as indoor UniFi APs all like to be ceiling mounted for best coverage (Outdoor ones are a but different).  All 3 hooked in and powered on without a problem.  I paired them with the UniFi Security Gateway and Controller software v4+.They now give double the coverage range of the Amped Wireless high power Routers they replaced and with Zero hand-off enabled they can move around the house without losing signal or connection for even a second.  The 3 APs now give their entire house signal (3500SQ Foot) and full coverage in their front and back yards. The Amped routers covered the house with only a couple dead zones and barely reached the gardens at all.Install was dead simple if you know anything about running Ethernet cable and the software walkes you though setup even with the most basic knowledge of networking.Just my Thoughts,AK

I had high hopes but this one fell apart within 3 weeks of purchase. (Never being removed from the device after install)Ok, so I bought this for my daughter's iPod touch...  I installed it and it immediately worked without a single issue.  But 3 weeks later she started complaining it wasn't charging right.  So I checked and everything seemed fine, the cable wasn't cut, it hadn't been disturbed in any way (the adapter was in a case the entire time) When I pulled it out to inspect the connections I found that the glue that holds the plastic piece on the charging end had come unglued.  Simply from the heat of the iPod itself (Which rarely gets warm to the touch)  I tried to reglue it and in 1 week it failed again....So I cannot recommend this charging adapter as it does not seem to be made to last at all.Just my Thoughts,AK

We bought this to simulate the high gluten flour common in Sweden.  Their four has a much higher protein content than US flour does which makes it hard to make real Swedish baked goods that actually turn out right.I am giving this 5 Stars as our Swedish Exchange student has said "These look and taste just like their supposed to, they aren't flat and tasteless like the regular four ones" when she does her baking.So that being said if you need a Higher gluten (Protein) concentrated flour this one will work very well!Just my Thoughts.AK

So far so good.I am currently using this on a network now almost exclusively of UniFi products.  (3 UniFi AC APs 3 Trendnet 5 Port Switches and a BlueTech 24 Port Switch all running full gigabit)The box itself looks like nothing special, 4 ports, Lan, Wan, management and VOIP.  If you are used to a traditional router with WiFi and 4 Lan ports this will probably seem a bit weird but it isn't at all.  In my opinion moving to just a router, and just APs makes good sense becasue you can upgrade either without having to upgrade everything.  But anyway, back to my review.I am tech savvy but I am no trained network specialist.  That said I had this set up on my network within 10 minutes (including upgrading to the Version 4+ controller software.  The controller recognized it right away and it connected without a problem.  (I already had the 3 UniFi AC APs up and running (using the V3 software)  I have now had 30 Days since install with 0 downtime due to the gateway (I have Time Warner so they drop signal at least 2 times a week no matter what)This is on a home network and I have 12 wired devices and 18 wireless ones on my network at any given time and the only choke point is my internet connection.  The router handles all the incoming/outgoing traffic without missing a beat. (Firmware v4.2.4.4733350)So far it's been a set and forget gateway and I couldn't be happier with it.  If something changes I will update this review, but as of right now I am definitely willing to recommend this gateway to anyone who is building a UniFi products based network.Just my Thoughts,AK

As of this review I have bought 5 of these 10 packs.  All 50 cables have worked without a catch and all hold true gigabit speeds on every network I've had them on.If the size is right I would absolutely recommend these cables for use in just about any Cat6 application.One thing to note: the black plastic tab covering the clip connector is pretty stiff so if you have a deep socket or very narrow space this may cause you issues.  on the 3 places I ran into this issue I simply trimmed that tab off and it worked without an issue.

It's just a 3 slot pill box.That means there's not a whole lot to review, but it is a pretty good pill case...My family is hard on pill cases...  We use 4 cases a day every day...This 3 pill was bought to replace a weekend trip case that fell apart on us.  The plastic is solid and the connections are fairly sturdy.  I would guess We'll get 6 months out of the lids before they fall off and for the price that is a good deal for us.If you are looking for a basic pill case I would recommend this one to you.Just my Thoughts,AK

Sorry for the bad pun but I couldn't help myself!Ok, I ordered these in February and they arrived completely intact without any melting (I mention this because there seems to have been some issues with melted eggs.)  I could be that in warmer climates than February in Ohio these will melt in transit, but I had no issues.They are the genuine Reese Eggs.My wife Loves these as a snack and when I saw I could get 48 eggs for less than $1 each shipped I couldn't resist...  I was concerned with the melting others noted but like I said earlier I didn't have any.They are comparable price to in store ones at least this far from Easter but I am really satisfied with them and I might even buy them again, but I will make sure to do it in cooler weather so I don't risk having melting problems...Just my Thoughts,AK

DOA, not once but twice....  Plus I honestly think the "signal booster" is blocking the signal....This was bought to run from a Receiver to projector (front to back of room) and I specifically purchased it because of the signal booster.  Well you live and learn.  Despite being connected properly (Input at receiver and output at projector) it does not function.  it simply gives no signal, I even tried it on various HDMI devices and none would get a signal to the projector or any of 3 HDTVs.This is really disappointing as I previously used a super cheap low end 75 foot HDMI 1.0 cable that functioned flawlessly....  But I wanted to upgrade to newer spec as I was remodeling...This was really disappointing and with 2 failures in a row I cannot recommend this cable to anyone....  I ended up getting a refund and buying another cable...Just my thoughts,AK

Love it!I put it in mostly to give auto off capabilities in my daughter's bathroom (They leave the fan on 24/7 because hitting a button is so hard)  And it exceeded my expectations.Now they don't even have to touch it.  IT comes on shortly after the shower turns on and back off within 45 or so minutes of them being done.  and if they turn it on by hand then it shuts off within 30 minutes!  I love it!It swapped into the old switches position without any hassle and it can be done by anyone who has some knowledge about changing a light switch.It has been operating for about 4 months now and I couldn't be happier.I am trying to list a con but honestly there are none that I have found but I will update this review if my experience changes.Just my thoughts,AK

This chord works perfectly for my Christmas lights.  My front porch has 5 columns spaced about 5 feet apart and I needed a cord or cords to get power from one to the next for my Christmas lights.  This worked absolutely perfectly...  the length was almost perfect for 5 foot spacing and 5 columns.  It also ran about 1000 regular (non-led) christmas lights without any issues.  It is now packed up and waiting until the next time I will need it but I would absolutely recommend this to you if the style fits your needs.Just My thoughts,AK

I really like this trash can.  We use it in our home as a "party" trash can that we bring out whenever we have a lot of guests over.  The size is great and fits 32/33 gallon trash bags perfectly.  the bag holder is pretty good and does it's job pretty well but I did notice that if you try to compact the trash it does tend to pull out of the holder.  (Which is just a couple pieces of flexible plastic on a hinge).It is very narrow for what it is and sits against the wall out of the way quite nicely.  It is fairly heavy compared to many other cans (and I think that's a good thing.)I would absolutely recommend this is you are looking for a nice quality and nice looking can in the 30 gallon size range...Just my thoughts,AK

I will be uploading a video review of this IP cam in the next few days so please watch out for that.The GW Security IP Cameras are good basic cameras.  They work generally well only requiring about 1 reboot per week to function without issues (I have 4 and I find them going out (No signal, no web interface access) about once a week.  They give good picture in both low and normal/bright conditions and faces at about 15 feet away are plenty clear.I have an NVR but I use Blue Iris 4 and record all my footage to a cloud storage drive.  They seem to send a signal without any issues and other than the reboot issues I am happy with this model camera.  They look nice, not super sleek but higher end than the price they sell for.I will note you need to have some understanding of how a LAN works as it comes preset with an uncommon IP address that may require you to change your computers IP address in order to do the initial setup.  I wouldn't call these plug and play cameras but they are not overly complicated either. I ended up buying these from another retailer because I didn't search Amazon long enough to see these....Pros:Good picture at 1080p ~30FPShas the possibility to update firmwareworks with any IP capable recorder or built in softwarePlenty of optionsEasy to accessCons:Frequent Reboots requiredCan't find anywhere to provide a firmware updateOn-Camera Zoom/Focus only (Not PTZ capable)Just my thoughts,AK

Extremely happy with the numbers, They look great on the house!  The installation was pretty simple, They send a Template along with the full order of numbers.  I ended up having to cut up the template since I was doing a vertical numbers install instead of horizontal, but no complaints, I centered them, leveled them and drilled my pilot holes.  The numbers were up and mounted in less than 15 minutes.The dimensions are accurate and they are a nice brushed finish, one thing I would recommend, use a rubber mallet or put a cloth over the number when hammering into place, otherwise you risk damaging the finish.  It is tough but steel hammering on aluminum the aluminum will lose that battle.See my pictures to see how they look on the house, I would absolutely recommend these numbers, they are solid aluminum, almost a half inch thick and should last for years...Just my thoughts,AK

It's no "Red Swingline", but it does the job....Small compact and accepts standard size staples.  This works great as a portable stapler.  I use it almost daily and even though it's plastic it does seem like it will hold up for quite some time...I would recommend this for anyone looking for a compact stapler that uses standard size staples...Just my Thoughts,AK

There isn't much to say about this wall plate, but here goes...It fits flush on a standard 2 gang box, the keystones have no issues being added or removed from the plate, and the screws do hold it in place well.With all that said I can recommend this if you are in need of a 12 keystone double gang wall plate...Just my thoughts,AK

We bought these to add to thank you cards, they worked great and added a nice personalized touch to otherwise generic cards.  If you need lots of ways to stick thank you on something these will do the job!Just my thoughts,AK

Broke within 2 days...  So I got a replacement and it broke within a week.It did do as it said when it worked, but I cannot recommend this to you since the quality seems really poor.It's too bad to because I had really high hopes for this to make my wood floors easier to get picked up....

I had several holes to drill through 18 inches of concrete and brick.  This did the job.  I can't speak to how long the bit will last but I needed it for a very specific job and it worked without a problem in my cordless drill.  It seemed like it worked just as well drilling the first hole as it did drilling the 8th...I have it in my tool chest in case I need it again... I'm no contractor but I would recommend this bit for anyone who needs the size and length it provides.Just my Thoughts,AK

These are just OK, I ran them nightly for 2 weeks.  By the end of the 1st week 1 bulb was out and by the end of week 2 another had gone out.They flicker nicely and do add interest but I do not like the low reliability.  These will not be used in my Halloween display next year.The price is high given the poor quality of the bulbs, so I can't give you a definite buy recommendation, but they are not super expensive so I won't tell you to run the other way either.  Just know that of you buy these you may be disappointed in how long they last.Just my Thoughts,AK

I would recommend this for anyone looking for a durable novelty mat for Halloween.  It is solid rubber so all the moisture just runs off and it held its color for the entire month we used it.  It will come back out next Halloween.The description is accurate and I would recommend it if the design is something you like.  It looked just like the picture.Just my Thoughts,AK

Really there isn't much to be said about extension cords....But here goes...They are 8 feet from tip to tip, fit well into my sockets without having to force them and they aren't loose.  I had them powering Halloween decorations every night for 3 weeks and had no issues.  The price is pretty good so I'd say if you are looking for a good outdoor extension cord that is 8 feet these will do nicely.Just my 2 Cents,AK

This Replacement power cord for Toshiba Laptops is very good.  It is a direct fit replacement and it has been working without an issue for a week in my old laptop...  BUT Before you put it in MAKE SURE that the black and red wires are in the right place!!!  I can't stress that enough!!!I have an L655-S5150 and this cord fit perfectly but my 2 red and 2 black wires were reversed on the connector...  Before you remove your old one take pictures, make sure they are right.  If you get one that is reversed you can simply pull the wires out of the connector and reposition them (This is what I had to do) then reconnect.That said if you are not comfortable doing this yourself take your computer to someone who is, connecting this wrong can fry your motherboard and ruin the laptop...This is an issue for most versions of this replacement DC jack for Toshiba laptops so no matter which one you choose make sure the wires match your configuration!!If you are comfortable taking apart the laptop and making sure the wire colors match then this is a good choice for a DC jack replacement and I would recommend it.Just my 2 cents,AK

2:41 MinsAfter receiving these I promptly put the first battery on the charger, waited about a 2hours then noticed it was charged, so I swapped it out with my Samsung Battery and tried some tests.** I will be updating this review over the next few weeks as I use them more often.****Update 1: The company contacted me regarding this review, they seemed unhappy that I pointed out that this product charges phones using the USB slower than dedicated bricks do and not giving a 5 star rating.  I applaud them for being proactive and I feel this shows a very high willingness to put out a quality product and honestly my opinion of the company is quite high.  That being said I stand by my rating of 4.5 Stars, It is an excellent product, and it is significantly cheaper than OEM batteries and some alternatives that exist as well. But slower USB charging of devices needs to be pointed out as a small subset of users may find this to be an issue.  It makes little impact on the day to day performance, but the fact is that this is the case.  So in conclusion, I really like this product and feel it is a top notch value for the price point. With a few minor tweaks in future versions this could go from a 4.5 Star product to 5 Stars...**-Battery Drain seems on par with the Samsung battery-NFC works, no noticeable difference in NFC even with Wireless charging cover on the phone.-Charger does charge OEM Samsung batteries.-USB port on charger does charge devices but I did notice that it took about an hour longer to charge my phone from 10% to full than when using the standard cable and brick sent by Samsung.All in all I am happy with these batteries and charger and will use them as needed, I feel the price for what you get is excellent, the company seems genuinely interested in making sure you are completely satisfied so I would recommend this product if you are looking for spare/replacement batteries for your Galaxy S5...A Feature I thought would be awesome, but not required, would be the ability to use the USB port to charge a device when not plugged in to the wall (I.E. Using those extra batteries like a portable charger)  Like I said neat but not needed...So to sum it up:5 Stars to start-.5 Star for slower USB port charging (An issue that some people may care about while others will not)So 4.5 Stars overall, But since we Can't do half stars I rounded down to 4 in the interest of being fair and honest.Just my thoughts,AKFull Disclosure:This was sent to me specifically for me to review.

Laura Nyro's double album "Live at the Bottom Line" is an exquisite live set. Released on Cypress Records, Nyro shines in the looser live format with the her band, particularly Frank Pagano on drums, giving a punch to the recording as we hear the interplay between Nyro and the band. Nydia Mata gives delightful percussive touches throughout. "Roll of the Ocean" in particular works well with this live energy. Many of Nyro's songwriting hits like "Wedding Bell Blues," "Stoned Soul Picnic" (recorded by The Fifth Dimension) and "And When I Die" (recorded by Blood, Sweat & Tears") shine as well as some of the lesser known songs in her canon like "Women of the One World" and "Sohphia/My Innocence" that dazzle. "The Wild World," written as an advocacy song for the treatment and respect of animals, fares well with guitars and other instruments imitating elephant sounds, etc. I have this release on both CD & vinyl; and the vinyl shines superbly with the depth and quality of the recording. Enjoy!

Maia Sharp's "The Dash Between the Dates" is another strong set from this delightful singer/songwriter.  The set opens with the catchy "Nothing But the Radio" with its romantically playful lyric, "Take off your shirt and don't stop until there's nothing but the radio on."  "Real Love" (not the Beatles' single) is a strong track with Maia's vocals wistfully expressive and then full and resonate on the chorus, "You don't have to be anybody but the somebody you really are; Give me that sweet laugh with the crooked grin."  "You Know Where I'll Be" is another gem that has me reaching for the repeat button with Lizz Wright joining on background vocals that makes the recording take flight, "I'm falling further than I ever dared to; It doesn't even throw me that I don't know where you stand."  Other tracks like "Little Bottles," "Phoenix" & "Poison the Well" are also standouts.  Sharp shines on this lovely set.  Enjoy!

Rhodes' "Wishes" is expansive orchestral pop that highlights his melodic songwriting and strong vocal presence.  "Close Your Eyes" builds and soars in the chorus, "I'm just the same as you & it's alright; Just stay by my side."  "Let It All Go" which brings in Birdy on vocals, is a gem with the sonic expanse, "I don't know why we need to break so hard."  "Wishes," the last track on the regular CD, builds its romantic angst beautifully with piano, "Remember the white knight stare; Didn't I show I care?  I do, I do."  Of the six extra tracks on the deluxe edition, "Glow" [track 13] sparkles with strong vocals and Rhodes' expansive vocals exploding into stars, "There a man in me; and he's always careful.  There's a light in me; and it's all I care for."  "Run," [track 15], also rivets the listener with romantic desperation.  "Wishes" is an excellent set by this strong new artist.  Enjoy!

"Light Up the Dark" is my introduction to Gabrielle Aplin.  The opening title track bursts out of the speakers like an unexpected storm, "And when the flood is over and the love starts pouring out, I wanna be the one."  "Sweet Nothing" is another good track, with her voice given a chance to sell the melody, "I feel your arms around me; You say you feel the love, but oh, I feel alone."  "Anybody Out There" is another gem with a pounding rock beat and background vocals that howl like the wind, "There's always silence in the void; and I kind of miss the noise of having you round."  While the CD doesn't have the attraction of a set by Adele, it does boast much good work.  If there are weaknesses, some of the material seems faceless and the production submerges the young singer's expressive vocals.  That said, this is a very promising set, well worth your listening time.  Enjoy!

I spotted John Mark Nelson's "I'm Not Afraid" in new releases and flipped to watch some video performance.  He's got a great expressive voice; so I flipped for the CD.  Now that it's been spinning in my changer, I'm totally flipping for the music!  This disc is a great discovery.  There is no such thing as weak tracks on the disc.  His music is melodic pop.  The set opens with party sounds on "After All I've Done," a sparkling joyful pop gem, and breaks into a gorgeous chorus, "This is where I long to know you and everything you've created."  "I'll Give You More" also sparkles with its beat like a stalker sneaking up on you, "Growing older is a fragile game, ever onward, ever turning."  "Broken" jumps out of the speaker with originality and verve, the catchy melody juxtaposed to a contemplative lyric, "If the worst is really over, why do I still feel the same?"  Other tracks like "Holes in Our Skin!," the title track and "Control" are also great.  Enjoy!

Rob Thomas' "The Great Unknown" may be his best solo set ever.  "I Think We'd Feel Good Together" blasts the set off with a throbbing quasi-rap chorus, "Maybe you can stay one night or stay forever."  The single "Trust You" follows with another pulsing beat and ends with what sounds like a child's voice echoing the title, "I trust you!"  "Wind It Up" continues the pop ambrosia with Victor Indrizzo's pounding drum sounding somewhere between ecstasy and the resulting headache.  "One Shot" follows with high energy pop-rock, "Everybody want to get high again and play it all night long; Everybody get a little wild and then they turn and go back home."  "Absence of Affection" is the romantic polar opposite of the opening track with its breakup lyric laced over classic rock rhythms, "In the absence of affection, you'll take anything and call it love."  "NLYTM" (Not Like You Told Me) has one of those catchy melodies that gets stuck in your head -- Boom Boom Boom!  "Heaven Help Me" is another track that has me reaching for the repeat button the changer, a bit more melodic, totally catchy.  "Lie to Me" is a strong track casting Thomas as the guy desperately in love, "Just tell me anything; Girl, you can lie to me; I want to hear you sing or scream and cry to me."  This is Thomas' best since his 2005 "Something To Be" solo shot.  Don't miss it!  Enjoy!

I found a copy of this instrumental album from 1959 on Liberty Records at a used book shop.  Without knowing much about it but seeing that Si Waronker (the first owner of the label) produced it, I thought I'd give it a try.  Boy, was this worth my dollar!  I cranked this sucker up on my new stereo and was in my bliss.  It is a wild romp with the percussive elements going snap, crackle & pop out of the speakers.  I thought I might be getting some schlock, but was thrilled by the quality of musicianship and the care with the production and arrangement.  Having the cover and vinyl in great shape made me feel like I was in a time machine back to when I was seven!  "Quiet Village" which was a #4 hit and originally released on 1957 LP "Exotica" ends the album.  "Firecracker" which I subsequently read was covered by the 1990's band The Cocktails is a gem.  This is a sweet set, well worth discovery for fans of instrumental music.  Enjoy!

Lesley Gore's "Someplace Else Now" is the missing link for me.  I had not heard this album when it was released in 1972.  Quite frankly, I wasn't into Lesley Gore at that time.  With hindsight as the perfect eyepiece, I can see how this set would have raised hopes that Gore could transition into the singer-songwriter era.  Gore's 2005 CD  "Ever Since" knocked me out completely!  It seemed to come out of nowhere.  Her voice had deepened to where at times she made me flash on Nina Simone.  I saw her on the tour to promote that CD and realized how great her classic canon was.  [Note: I remember her saying in the concert that she didn't call them "oldies"!]  This CD is kind of missing link between that great CD and her Mercury-era hits.This music is different.  So it does not have the girl group harmonies and hand clap percussion.  What we have is a mature singer at the top of her craft.  "The Road I Walk" is a beautiful song that Gore wrote with a strong melody and Gore's vocals full and impassioned, "What price must we pay for love; What price must we pay for glory; Tell me God, it there's one above, must I live the same sad story?"  "Mine" is another strong song.  I don't know a lot about Gore's biography, but I did read that she was a lesbian, which makes me wonder if that realization might have impacted this strong song, "I can feel the tears run down my face and hear my voice so low; You wonder is it really mine; You question all the me's I've let you meet; and soon you'll know that's the one I never show."  "No Sad Songs" also plays well for me with its lyric trying to be cheerful juxtaposed to a moody melody, "I've said it before, but I was never so sure before."  "Someplace Else Now" is essential listening for those who revere Lesley Gore's craft.  She is a Master Musician.  She will be missed.  Enjoy!

This Ace release of Lesley Gore's third album "Girl Talk" is well done.  I bought a vinyl copy that turned out to be in such sad shape it was not playable.  I heard enough to know that this was a release I wanted to add to my collection, some 50+ years later.  While I think I am turning into one of those audiophiles who prefer the warmer, more resonant sound of vinyl to digital, Ace does a very good job with bringing back this music to great form.  "Hey Now," which was a single that didn't do well, sounds good to me with its girl group vocals and handclap percussion, "I can't waste my time just waiting on the line when I can find another guy."  "Maybe I Know" is another pop gem with horns punching the strong melody, "Maybe I know that he's been cheating; Maybe I know that he's been untrue, but what can I do?"  One of the songs that has gotten stuck in my head is "Wonder Boy" with its great sing-along chorus, "If you're so smart, how come you don't know I adore you?  If you're so smart, you ought to know I love you."  From the extra tracks that were not on the original LP, the Jeff Barry/Ellie Greenwich song "What's A Girl Supposed to Do?" pops out of the speakers with its strong background vocals, a great delight!  I also really like the Mike Post song "No Matter What You Do" that opens with some punchy electric guitar and some beautiful percussion.  It's a shame that Gore passed away February 16, 2015; what a loss!  "Girl Talk" is essential Gore listening.  Enjoy!

Jeff Oster's "Next" is a delightful sonic splash that is cheer for the ear.  One great strength is the pristine engineering that makes his horn pop out of the speakers like he's playing right in your living room.  The title track is an exquisite opener with its lovely melody & Chuck Rainey's subtle but powerful bass giving pulse to the arrangement over which Oster's flugelhorn glides.  This little gem is definitely headed for my personal top ten!  The other star of the set for me, perhaps because it is so familiar and much loved as Bonnie Raitt's hit, is "I Can't Make You Love Me" where Oster counterpoints his horn to Philip Aaberg's piano.  Other tracks that stand out for me are the lovely "Ibiza Sunrise" that paints a gorgeous picture of the island off Spain's eastern coast.  "Avenue D" has a great urban sound with some tasty guitar by Todd Boston.  I kind of wish they'd let the drummer go crazy or mixed the drums more prominently since the beat is so attractive.  "Heroes" is another strong track like a soundtrack to triumphant quest with Jeff Taboloff's sax mixing well with Oster's flugelhorn.  One of the great things about "Next" is that its many moods take you so many different places, but the set has a great unity; the music fits together really well.  I admire Jeff's passion for his music and recommend this set for those who love instrumental music.  Enjoy!

Rod Taylor's self-titled album from 1972 has long been one of my very favorites, one I pull out regularly and spin.  When David Geffen started Asylum records in the early 1970's, he hand-picked the acts he wanted on his label with amazing taste.  While most know his more successful finds like Jackson Browne, the already-popular Joni Mitchell and the Eagles, there was a whole sub-tier of acts who put out quality music but didn't quite break such as Essra Mohawk, Judee Sill, David Blue and Karen Alexander.  Rod Taylor is one of these.  After the failure of this disc, Taylor morphed into Roderick Falconer and put out a series of glam-rock albums.  But this country-flavored set is exquisite.  So God bless the Japanese for this CD reissue, a first on CD as far as I know -- and I've been looking regularly and periodically for a long time.  Anyone who follows Japanese releases of American artists, knows that the Japanese do their best with the song lyrics, but frequently make mistakes.  For example, on the gorgeous second track, "Crossroads of the World," the Japanese booklet quotes the lyrics, "Dreaming had time might unfurl" rather than "Dreaming how time might unfurl."  But while it's true that most audiophiles will prefer the vinyl over the CD because it has a deeper, more resonant sound, the CD which I played back to back with the vinyl is still a good technical reproduction.  Bonnie Bramlett wails on the background vocals on Crossroads, sheer delight.  "Double Life" is a classic track with Jim Horn's searing saxophone solo, "I got a right side & I've got a wrong; This double living's going to tear me apart before too long, from living a double life, and I guess I know which one is me."  "Making A Way" has a great background vocal by label-mate Joni Mitchell on the stately piano-based melody, "There comes a time riding in the tide, when a man you'll have to choose; Remember then that this fisherman, he's got blood on his shoes."  "Livin' Dangerous Blues" has such an explosive guitar juxtaposed to the feisty piano on this edgy track, "And the lightning of a woman's heart that's what keeps me on the run."  The Japanese are again creative with "Arthur Mandias" replacing Taylor's reference to the classic Shelley poem, "Ozymandias was a king of kings, had a hundred women, armies and things; But he's dead and gone, no fire is on his lips; In the ruins we're going to waltz; so come on, give me a kiss."  "Lost Iron Man" is such a pretty country ballad.  Rod Taylor's self-titled album is a great record.  Seek & you shall find!  Enjoy!

"Back to Birth" is a strong release by Jackie Greene.  Somehow, he's got put into a niche as "Americana," but his melodic songwriting shines through.  On this release, I can't find any songwriter credits, but I assume these are all Greene originals.  Coming off his great association with Joan Osborne in the band Trigger Hippy, it's nice to have some of his recent solo work.  The opener "Silver Lining" has a pretty midtempo melody with Jackie's vocals expressive and clear, "Don't think that the life we're living is easy; We travel around; Our feet don't touch the ground."  The second track, "Now I Can See for Miles" may be the best on the set with its catchy hook and Reinhardt Weis's drums punching through between guitar jabs, "Like telescopes in search of hope, I was mystified by the way she spoke."  "Trust Somebody" is also a stellar Greene classic with a touch of country swagger mixed with tangy blues and Jackie's piano building up to the addictive chorus, "When you're out of your mind, broken & blind, look at yourself; Do you like what you see? If you want something else, you better trust somebody."  "Light Up Your Window" & "You Can't Have Bad Luck All the Time" are also gems.  Enjoy!

Tobias Jesso Jr.'s debut CD "Goon" has some strong moments.  "How Could You Babe" has a catchy hook on this midtempo track's chorus that makes it spark with Tobias' vocals alternately hushed and soaring, "When I found out you'd gone & met a new man, I felt so lonely that I cried; How could you baby?"  It's a great tear-in-your beer closer tailor-made for a last-call juke box.  "Without You" is also a lovely heartbreak ballad with Jesso's airy vocals and plodding piano drawing us into a new empty routine, "I can hardly breathe without you; There is no future I want to see without you; I just don't know who I could be without you."  While the CD suffers from a lack of variety of tempos and instrumentation, "Hollywood," "Crocodile Tears" and "Leaving Los Angeles" are also strong.  This is a promising freshman set from this young singer-songwriter.  Enjoy!

"Romances Latinos" by Rusty Crutcher is a delightful gem.  The opener, "All or Nothing (Todo y Nada)" is an incredible track that recalls the moment I heard Gato Barbieri's soundtrack for "Last Tango In Paris," a set that opened up a whole new genre and culture of music for me.  Crutcher's tenor saxophone oozes emotion into each bar with a seductive cosmopolitan sound.  Mexican musician and composer Armando Manzanero wrote "I Miss You" with Crutcher's sax blasting with passion, flavored with lament.  It stops the show for me.  The rest of the set is solid with "What A Difference A Day Made" bringing to mind my favorite recording of the tune by Dinah Washington.  This music is at times gentle, bursting with melody and above all, fired by passion.  It's jaw-dropping good.  Enjoy!

After first listening, I was deeply impressed with Groban's song selection for "Stages."  Show music seems to fit him like a glass slipper.  "Les Temps des Cathedrales" from "Notre Dame de Paris" reflects some of Groban's early work with soaring vocals, orchestral arrangement, and foreign language lyrics sung impeccably; this one in French.  "Old Devil Moon" starts with Chris Botti's gorgeous trumpet bookending the piece.  "Gold Can Turn to Sand" is a lovely tune with Groban's vocals engaged and expressive on Grammy winner Tim Rice's lyric, "From a well that was poison, he drank water; and he died where he fell, a beast to slaughter; As his eyes slowly faded, here's a watchband from his hand, Oh Kristina, gold can turn to sand.*"  Epic!  Other tracks like "All I Ask of You," "If I Loved You" and "Children Will Listen/Not While I'm Around" are glorious.  This was a set that I had to listen to a number of times before I really warmed to it; so it is not one where I recommend a snap decision.  Let it grow on you.  It's powerful stuff, as usual from this Master Musician.  Enjoy!*Note: Lyrics according to my ear.

Wouter Kellerman's "Love Language" is a blockbuster disc of mostly instrumental music that bursts forth from the speakers, vibrant and alive.  "Si Do Mhaimeo" rocks joyfully with Wouter's flute-centered arrangement of this traditional Irish song on a par with much of Tim Weisberg's classic flute work.  "To Tango (Tis Nefelis)" written by Loreena McKennit & Greek singer Xaris Alexiou, sparkles with Kellerman's flute slinking up and down the scales like a snake and Taryn Louch's vocals exquisitely expressive.  "Ek Verlang Na Jou" has a lovely ambling beat on a tune that was a hit in South Africa when Wouter was a child and is delivered here beautifully with Anna Davel on vocals.  "Zininzi," "Notre Futur" & "Love Gets Old" are also gems.  This is a delightful disc that I hope many will discover!  Enjoy!

James Taylor's "Before This World" is a strong set and return to form.  "Angels of Fenway" is an instant classic baseball song that speaks to the woes of the Boston Red Sox.  "Stretch of Highway" is a delightful road song with a grooving soul beat, "Just for example, look ye yonder over there; Chicago's got the finest high-test first-class poontang anywhere."  The ballad "Montana" is one of Taylor's finest with its sweet melody, "Who can imagine the scale of the forces that pushed this old mountain range up in the sky?  Tectonic creation, erosion, mutation, something to pleasure God's eye."  "Watchin' Over Me," Taylor's homage to Toronto "Snowtime" and "You & I Again" are delightful.  This is welcome return from one of our Master Musicians.  Enjoy!

Nancy Huston's "Black Dance" was a complete chore to read.  How I labored through this book!  On a return flight from St. Louis, the book fell out of my luggage with my boarding pass for the connecting flight.  I was much more concerned about the lost boarding pass than the lost book.  I did, however, BUY this sucker for a penny and finished the whole thing.  It does not get much better.  The writer seemed much more intent on showing what a wonderful writer she is rather than telling a story.  This is one of the most confusing novels I've ever read.  It changes locations from Ireland to Brazil to Quebec.  At one point a woman says, "We will speak French in this family!"  I did a double-take because I thought they were in Ireland. I had to re-read the dust jacket to realize that they must have shifted to French-speaking Quebec.  It also shifts between the screenplay written about Milo's life to Milo's actual life, often making it impossible to figure out which is real.  In addition to those shifts, we move back and forth in time during the 20th Century.  Literally, this book is all over the map.  From there is the final realization that no one in the book is the protagonist in the sense that we feel any sympathy or bond with them.  Finally, what's with the title?  Is this a racial slur?  "Capoeira" is defined as "a Brazilian dance of African origin..."  With all of the rape, drugs and brutality in the novel, it's hard to imagine "Black Dance" as anything at all positive.  This novel is a complete mess.  Taxi!

I picked up a vinyl copy of Dee Dee Sharp's Cameo Records release from 1962, "It's Mashed Potato Time."  The liner notes tell the story of how Dee Dee was booked on a singer on a Chubby Checker record.  Chubby didn't want a girl singing on his record; so he gave her the cold shoulder when he entered the session.  Then when she started to sing, he went, "Wow!"  After the session, the producer told Dee Dee to go home, eat and rest and come back to the studio that night because they were going to cut her first record, thus was "Mashed Potato Time" born.  The album is a great early rock record, rock and roll with no apology.  Bobby Darin's hit "Splish Splash" and Gene McDaniel's hit "A Hundred Pounds of Clay" are modified to include due homage to Chubby Checker.  Dee Dee is in great voice on "Gee" and "Gravy."  This is a sweet blast from the past that is sure to put a smile on your face.  If you're like me, you'll have to jump out of your chair and start dancing!  Enjoy!

"Men Against Mountains" is my introduction to The Revivalists.  The set explodes with much the same force as Alabama Shakes' first CD, packing a wallop in the early tracks and remaining strong throughout the set.  The opener "Keep Going" has a pumping blue-eyed soul arrangement complete with horns and David Shaw's swagger on lead vocals, "The less I know, the more I learn how much love means to me."  Track 2 follows with the blockbuster "Wish I Knew You" with a pulsing beat enhanced by Michael Girardot's glittering keyboards, "So Friday night, holy ghost take me to your level, show me the one I need the most."  "Monster" has a lovely hook-filled melodic sheen that softens the darker lyrics about a guy who is a romantic predator, "I'm sleeping with a snake tonight & nowadays what's wrong feels right; I was a bastard of the worse kind; I looked you in the eyes, still told you a lie."  "Stand Up" totally rocks the room with its shout-sing chorus and David Shaw's virile vocals, "I'm a tax-paying fool."  "Amber" is another super-strong song.  "Man Against Mountains" is such a strong set that it'll send you scrambling to find copies of the band's earlier work.  Enjoy!

Shelby Lynne's "I Can't Imagine" is a very strong set in her growing canon of recordings.  The opener, "Paper Van Gogh" is a midtempo charmer with Dusty Springfield's influence loud and clear in the lingering notes and the slow-burn of passion in Shelby's vocals, "Watercolor art, I play my feelings on my origami harp."  "Sold the Devil (Sunshine)" also appeals to me with that smoky midtempo groove and Shelby's croon achingly powerful, "We all on this plant, arm and arm as we touch, sister, brother, and our earth mother."  "Down Here" rides on a blues riff, "I love you like I'm not thinking 'bout it; It's a natural thing."  The rest of the set is strong, particular the title track that closes the set.  This is a sweet return to form from one of our master musicians.  Bravo!

When I popped Jesse Malin's "New York Before the War" in the changer on a long drive home, it popped out of the speakers.  In the weeks since then, each time I spin the disc I have the same thought, "This is REALLY GOOD!!!"  I've enjoyed Malin's solo releases.  For me, he pulls it all together on this CD.  On "Addicted," Malin rocks with apparently unrelated images of wrongs spit out like bullets from a shotgun and then he smokes a classic line, "I'm addicted to the glory of a broken heart."  "Turn Up the Mains" thunders with arena-sized rock and Malin's incendiary lyrical twist blows up, "The place is packed & the kids are jacked on those anti-social songs; You swing low like a like a halo & you're wishing you were never born."  What is my favorite track at present, "Freeway," starts with a throbbing guitar part like a pounding headache and the spends his lyrics like a fatal disease, "And I sprayed my love with the vultures and the crows with a lust for glory and a poison rose."  I also like "Bent Up" that slows the pace to midtempo and sounds like rocking music hall fare.  The slow weeper "She Don't Love Me Now" is a delightful tear-in-your-beer last-call tune that could blare out of a juke box at an all-night dive, "I know we had so many nights down there in the village, dressed up like each other's dreams; we were kind of killers."  "New York Before the War" is a gritty in-your-face rock record with Malin's intelligence and lyrical wit whipping the mix into a sheer delight!  Bravo!

Buffy Sainte-Marie's new set is an utter delight!  Weaving past and present on the disc, Buffy opens with a punchy new version of the title song from her first album, "It's My Way," "I've got my own world; I've got my own life; I've got my own strife."  "We Are Circling" is an old campfire song with a pounding beat and a melody that is infectious, "We are ripening, ripening together, babies, elders, bozos and angels."  Buffy's update of "Not the Lovin' Kind" burns and smokes, "I think I've learned your secret to keep from getting burned; Love for you is a matter of no-deposit, no-return."  The new recording of "Generation" from her 1974 "Buffy" album is sheer delight with that lyric that's rattled around in my head for decades,  "Me I don't want to go to the moon, I want to leave that moon alone, I just want to dance with the Rosebud Sioux this summer."  "Sing Our Own Song" that Buffy adapted from UB40 has a delightful American Indian flare with Buffy's astounding background vocals and the upbeat lyrics, "We will stand for the right to be free; and we will rebuild a just society."  When Buffy sang "Look At the Facts" on her "Sweet America" album, I kept lifting the needle and replaying the track.  Here the song is updated lyrically and is sung as "Carry It On."  Buffy burns on this new set and the fire will warm your heart.  Bravo!

Rachel Seiffert's "The Walk Home" might have been re-titled "The Very Very Long Walk Home."  It two me almost two months to trudge through this book, although it's only 291 pages long.  It's one that I'm really glad I can put in the past.  In a year, I will have to reread my review here to have a recollection of the book.  What Seiffert does well is place her characters in the historical context of the Irish troubles.  The story takes place after the bombs have exploded, but much of the bitterness remains.  This doesn't lead to an action-packed story, but a character driven one.  Unfortunately, the characters are barely sympathetic.  Probably the best written character is Lindsay, who leaves Ireland and an abusive father and latches onto a Protestant Irish lad named Graham.  Unfortunately for the novel, she departs before the tale is concluded to who knows where.  We build the context with Lindsay's new mother-in-law Brenda, who is an industrious cleaning woman.  Graham's father Malky plays a minor part; and I never quite retained who Malky Jr. was.  Brenda's brother Eric draws incessantly, never happy with his work.  His rift with the family and his late father Robert was because he married a Catholic girl, Franny.  Onto this pile of characters comes Stevie, Lindsay's and Graham's child.  When Graham refuses to move into a nicer flat, Lindsay blows a gasket and the two inexplicably separate.  Graham likes to play drums in the Orangewalk, a Protestant politically charged band, which also serves to fracture the relationship.  Eric is off in his head with Bible stories; and everyone tries hard to help him after the death of his wife.  Seiffert even more complicates the reading experience by splitting it into past and present, as we see Stevie working as an older teen on construction sites in London with a group of Polish workers.  The plot is awkward and we never get inside Stevie's head, although he is the central character and his is the very very long walk home.  While I appreciated the Irish flavor, this is not a tale well told.  Taxi!

I started watching this movie, turned it off after a few minutes, and then went back and finished it when I was in more of a mood to be depressed.  It is not a film I enjoyed.  For me, the problem with the film is the writing.  Rachel Weisz was nominated for a Golden Globe for playing Hester Collyer, and she is woefully depressed throughout the film, but inexplicably witless.  The problem for me is that you sit through the whole thing and the character never changes; there's no arc to the character.  She starts depressed and she ends depressed; and everything between is also depressing.  The performance that most touched me was Simon Russell Beale as the cuckold husband Sir William Collyer.  He is so pathetically in love with his young wife who understandably has no passion for the geezer that it breaks your heart to see him so unappreciated by his wife and makes one wonder why they ever married.  Ann Mitchell as the landlady also has a number of nice scenes.  Tom Hiddleston as Freddie Page has a sexy creepiness about him, not as pronouncedly weird as Loki in "Thor," but still volatile.  He is the one source of energy in an otherwise bland sea of British blokes.  Samuel Barber who died in 1981 is credited with the music, which is cloying and over-the-top dramatic.  During the opening sequences, we have not yet connected with Hester's character, but yet the music lushly plays as if we're watching the suicide with any significance or attachment.  The choice of this score for the piece made an already difficult movie even sappier.  If they'd selected some boppy jazz from the era, it would have juxtaposed the lively music with the lifeless suicide.  Taking nothing away from the fine actress that Rachel Weisz is, this movie did not work for me.  Taxi!

I enjoyed the DVD of "Susie's Hope" very much.  The film originally aired on UP TV cable.  I found the story to be very touching.  Donna Lawrence is played by Emmanuel Vaugier who has done many Lifetime movies.  Her husband Roy is played by Burgess Jenkins.  I felt compelled to review the film since so many of the reviews here speak to the issue of the movie, more than to the film itself.  The story sets up Donna as an animal lover who is expecting a child.  Her husband Roy is a good-looking construction company owner, who doesn't always understand where Donna is coming from, but clearly loves her to pieces.  I think it is this relationship which speaks to me so strongly and holds the film together.  Donna gets attacked when trying to help an abused dog and miscarries.  The intense sadness of a couple facing a childless future breaks your heart.  Andrea Powell from Twilight: Breaking Dawn Part 2 & Enders Game plays Donna's best friend Ramona.  No matter what happens to Donna, husband Roy seems to find a way to blame the neighbor, even for the event when Ramona for all practical purposes saves his wife's life.  We wish Roy's emotional clockworks weren't wound quite so tightly, but cheer when he realizes his error.  Willette Thompson plays the owner of the animal shelter and has a number of great compassionate scenes in the film.  Jon Provost who many will remember as a child actor as Timmy on the series "Lassie" does a nice job of being the politician on the side of Susie's cause.At this point I should disclose that I am an actor who appeared in the film as the Public Defender of the guy who hurt Susie.  I did buy my own copy of the DVD; so I am an actual customer; and I am also not receiving residuals from the film -- unfortunately!  For my own experience, it was the first time that I'd worked with a number of extras behind me, and proved a wonderful experience.  That said, I really enjoyed working with Cranston Johnson who plays Shawn Griffin, the bad guy.  He has a smoldering intensity which comes across well on screen, even though his is not a character that as an audience we like.  Dave Blamy who played the Lawrence's attorney Chris Parish does a very nice job in his part.  Director Jerry Rees was a joy to work with on set; and I think delivered an excellent film that not only highlights the important issue of animal abuse, but humanly touches us as we become part of the Lawrence's lives.  This is a film with which I'm proud to have been associated.  I hope dog lovers everywhere will get a chance to see it.  Enjoy!

"Darling Arithmetic" is my introduction to the Villagers.  The set is folk-oriented low-fi.  The opening track "Courage" is my favorite with its sweet vocals by Irish singer Connor O'Brien and a lovely melody, "I took a lover but then we parted; It took a little time to get over this; and from time to time I get heavy-hearted thinking of how we used to kiss."  "Hot Scary Summer" builds melodically to the chorus that has O'Brien going high into his register, "Remember kissing on the cobblestone in the heat of the night and all the pretty young homophobes looking out for a fight."  The song fades with sounds of birds.  The rest of the CD is also strong and grows with repeated spins.  Songs like "Soul Serene," "Little Bigot" & "No One to Blame" contain superb moments.  "Darling Arithmetic" is a strong set that makes me want to discover the band's earlier sets.  Enjoy!

"Diamantes" was released by UK's Proper Records.  There is no date references on the liner notes for the tracks; but I did find information on Joan's website which describes this set:  Proper Records announced the general release of Diamantes in the European markets on March 9, 2015. Diamantes was originally created for Joan's tour of South America in 2014. This special CD combines Spanish language songs culled from the 1988 recording of Diamonds and Rust in the Bullring with some in concert favorites and two newly recorded versions of the Portuguese songs "O'Cangaceiro" and "Ate Amanha/Te Ador."Joan's voice is in fine form from these recordings.  On the two Portuguese recordings "Ate Amanha/Te Ador" that was recorded in Brazil and the live "O Cangaceiro" which seem to be the most newly recorded, her voice is in fine form.  The tracks are midtempo songs with simple percussion.  Mercedes Sosa's vocals compliment Joan's on the delightful "Gracias a la Vida."  Joan's rapport with the crowd on the closing track "No Nos Moveran" is a sheer delight.Of my two favorite English-language tracks, the Steve Earle cover from his "I'll Never Get Out of This World Alive" CD (2011) opens the set in live performance.  With Joan's masterful touch, it is a stately homage to belief, "I believe in miracles, something sacred burning in every bush & tree; And we can all learn to sing the songs the angels sing."  Her take on the classic Paul Simon penned Simon & Garfunkel classic "The Boxer" is delightful with the ironic twist of a woman singing the lyric, "When I left my home and my family, I was no more than a boy."  It's lovely.  "Diamantes" is a bit of a patchwork release from different timeframes in Joan's career, but achieves unity by her masterful performance.  Enjoy!

"Beside Still Waters" grew on me.  The frenetic opening titles had me blinking with images that flashed on screen momentarily between credits.  The center of the film is Daniel played by Ryan Eggold who has wowed fans of TV's "The Blacklist" as Tom Keen.  Daniel is under stress with the death of his parents, which has resulted in foreclosure on their resort home.  He invites his close high school friends for one last remembrance weekend.  The scene where Daniel tearfully rebukes all of his friends who failed to support him at his parents' funeral is a very powerful scene.  Into the mix we get Brett Dalton who plays James, a reality TV star in an awful series, who has an affair with his long-time friend Tom, played by Beck Bennett. Beck broke out as an actor in the AT&T commercials where he sits deadpan and interviews groups of children.  James then refuses to acknowledge his sexual attraction to Tom.  There is a great shot as James denies the encounter to his friends while Tom sits stoically in the foreground until a huge tear runs down his face.  Mesmerizing!  Britt Lower plays Brittany, an old flame of Daniel's, who brings her fiancée Henry unannounced to the party, played by Reid Scott.  Erin Darke (Still Alice) plays a professional woman whose unemployed husband Martin played by Will Brill seems to drive her up the wall.  Jessy Hodges plays Charley, a somewhat emotionally unstable woman, who falls apart when she discovers James, who she has a crush on, making love to Tom.  There is some nudity in the film as everyone goes skinny-dipping.  This was the directing debut for Chris Lowell (actor in TV's Veronica Mars).  While the pacing seems a bit uneven in the first third of the film, it soon grips the viewer as we see deep emotions bubble to the surface among these old friends.  Enjoy!

I heard of Sharon Goldman in an email blast by Sloan Wainwright when the two shared a concert billing and decided to check out the artist's music.  Sharon's "Sleepless Lullaby" EP is an 8-track offering of mostly acoustic often country-flavored songs.  She's got a nice voice, very melodic.  All of the songs are lovely, but the vocals seem maybe a bit too clinically sung, too perfect, perhaps not quite letting the artist's personality fully inhabit the songs.  Of Sharon's original songs, "Winter's Come Around Again," "Letters," and the very sweet "Weekend Afternoon" resonate.  She sings songwriter Rich Dean's "House of Stone" which may be the most engaging track on the set.  Her cover of Simon & Garfunkel's "A Hazy Shade of Winter" slows the track to a piano backing, minus the distinctive percussion that made the original jab at the listener's ear.  It's beautiful; but I'm still getting used to it.  While the set doesn't grab you by the collar & demand listening, it is very pleasant and sweet.  Enjoy!

Matt the Electrician's "It's A Beacon; It's A Bell" is another melodic mostly-acoustic folk offering by Matthew Sever.  The title track is the catchiest with Matt's gentle vocals sweet and reassuring, "Was exactly at the right time, all the angels telling me to pay attention; And all the numbers were standing in line, was the easiest of days."  "Arkansas" is a lovely tune with Dana Falconberry on duet vocals.  "The Family Grave" has a happy catchy tune juxtaposed by a somber lyric about dying surrounded by family.  "Pioneer Bride" is a sweet acoustic tune with Matt's gentle vocals, "It rained & rained all the clouds could contain; And the sound was thunder inside me; And I held my ground while the sky fell down."  "Under the Wire" plucks and strums, delightfully offbeat, "I'm a ridiculous American sitting in a Burger King on the side of the highway in another country; It is actually beautiful; It is actually Denmark; I am a reading a novel by Junichiro Tanizaki."  Matt the Electrician flies under the radar screen for most, but always makes lovely, sweetly felt music.  Enjoy!

Beth Hart's "Better Than Home" is a strong CD.  It will gather criticism from some long-time fans for slowing the pace & simplifying the arrangements.  The most effective of these slower tracks is the lovely "Tell 'Em to Hold On" where Beth's vocals throb with emotion & sincerity, "Everyone's looking for something to hold; some kind of savior; They need to be told to hold on."  The title track is also a gem with a peppier midtempo melody, "I have found the place where hunger meets the edge & now I'm facing God."  Other tracks like "The Mood I'm In" & "Mechanical Heart" are also grand.  Enjoy!

"The Longest Ride" soundtrack CD has some delightful gems.  The opening track "Wildfire" by Seafret is a sweet midtempo rocker that sounds vaguely Celtic with the catchy chorus, "We are bound to each other's hearts; called, torn and pulled apart."*  It's a great addictive track.  Middle Brother's 2011 self-titled CD was a favorite of mine; and "Blue Eyes" from that CD shines on this set.  (Middle Brother is a "super-group" effort from singers from the bands Deer Tick, Delta Spirit & Dawes.)  "Backwoods Company" is the leadoff track from The Wild Feathers' 2013 self-titled CD.  It blasts out of the speakers with loud electric rock and such a great bass line, "Lay me down by the old oak tree; Cut my hair when they bury me."  "Oh, Tonight" by Josh Abbott Band featuring Kasey Musgraves comes from the band's 2010 CD "She's Like Texas" and rocks pure country, "Oh, tonight we're gonna set the world on fire; & I'm gonna set aside my pride; Not gonna be the one to say goodbye."  Sweet!  Black Pistol Fire's "Show Pony" is a blasting rocker that zaps you with its swagger, "Getting kind of cozy with a loaded gun."  Adan Jadorowsky's "Dancing to the Radio" is hook-filled with a catchy chorus.  Kodaline's 2012 CD "In a Perfect World" is the source for their gorgeous "Love Like This."  Other tracks like Pistol Annie's "I Feel A Sin Comin' On" & Ryan Adams' "Desire" make this a very strong soundtrack with no clinkers.  Enjoy!*Note: Lyrics according to my ear!

Fred Eaglesmith's "Tambourine" is a great addition to this masterful singer's long catalog.  The opening track "What It Takes" delivers a strong vocal performance with Fred's voice urgent to the point of desperation plus a lovely melody and lyric, "I'll face the wind; I'll fight the rain just to hold you in my arms again; I'll run against the sky until it breaks."  "Can't Dance" has a retro feel with a bass line not too far off from "Secret Agent Man" and Fred's vocals celebrating the joy of performance, "I love my electric guitar; I love when I play it way too loud."  "Nobody Gets Everything" rocks to a midtempo beat with Scott Merritt's keyboards deliciously framing the melody, "Nobody gets everything; and I guess I don't get you."  "Sally Green" slowly burns about a guy in love with an unfaithful girl.  "Tambourine" is a strong set by one of Canada's best.  Enjoy!

"Lesser Oceans" by Fences is a strong set on the classic Elektra Records label.  There are no weak tracks on the set, but there are a couple cuts with which I particularly connect after a half dozen spins.  "Arrows" pops out of the speakers with driving energy and an internal rap segment.  Listening in the car, I thought he was singing "Dead Roses Are Falling" instead of "Arrows"; "My old man, he kicked me out when I told him that I live this way; He doesn't own me; Just escape."  The track sparkles.  "Dusty Beds" is another track that I really like with a midtempo beat and lyrics that seem mundane like signing a check on the refrigerator, but Chris Mansfield's vocals give life to the lyric, "Roll over & touch me angel; Nothing ever happens on dusty beds."  The opening track "Songs About Angels" and the title track are also incredibly strong.  While this is my introduction to this band, it's strong enough to make me want to check out their past work and to hear more.  Enjoy!

The Lone Bellow's first CD was excellent.  I think "Then Came the Morning," their second, nudges it, and is even better.  There are more strong songs and the set doesn't ever drop out, even on the slower tracks.  The title track has an exquisite lyric and an inventive orchestral touch in the arrangement that gives the track depth.  The "joy comes in the morning" lyric mirrors Psalm 30 from the Bible, "weeping may endure for a night, but joy comes in the morning," one of my favorite Bible quotes.  "Marietta" is another superb track with a midtempo beat and a plodding melody that marches through a range of emotions, "The worry for what couldn't be, the love for the lust of your name, of losing, of winning, of striving, of leaving and stealing and breaking and shame."  Its marriage of lyric and melody is exquisite.  "Take My Love" sounds quite radio-friendly with its hook on the chorus and the full background vocals, "You're no broken record turning; you're a wild melody."  "If You Don't Love Me" is another exceptional track with its pounding beat and lyric, "Leave me or let me go."  "Cold As It Is" addicts the listener with its catchy hook and the Zach Williams' vocals that trail off into the upper register, "I wouldn't leave."  There are so many great tracks on this disc that it is essential listening, one of the best of 2015.  Enjoy!

Carole King's 2014 single release is a sweet positive thinking anthem with Carole's midtempo slightly offbeat melody resonating well with her expressive vocals, "Come what may, this heart of mine will stay forever true."  The CD release is bare bones with no record label, liner notes or musician credits listed.  While I'm sure all of her fans would more than welcome a full-length CD, this one-track disc is a welcome addition to my song rotation.  Enjoy!

This is another amazing disc by Ace Records that highlights the songwriting of Carole King and Gerry Goffin.  The engineering & sound reproduction make this set sound fresh.  The Righteous Brothers' title track is an epic recording arranged by Jack Nitzsche and produced by Phil Spector with his "wall of sound" trademark. Bill Medley's deep voice throbs, "Though I'm not free to fall in love with you, oh baby, why did I have to get so hung on you?"  The Clovers' "The Sheik" has a vaguely Middle Eastern flavor, but is a lot of fun with the tabla percussion and the sassy sax, "If you got a date, you better not be late; If you make your baby wait, you'll find that the sheik is straight."  Henry Alston's "So Many Lonely People" is an exquisite record that has a Drifters' sound and Alston's tenor voice soulful and expressive, "But baby don't you see we don't have to share their company, we've got this chance to make our love last."  This set has great liner notes and many of the tracks wear well half a century later.  Enjoy!

Glen Phillips' "Coyote Sessions" looks like a very indie release in appearance from this fine artist, kind of "Glen Phillips Unplugged."  There are no lyrics, no record label mentioned, no copyright date, no songwriting credits, just the 10 song titles listed.  "Everything Matters" is a classic Phillips track with him attacking the rhythm guitar with a vibrant strum on the lovely track, "Every word is a seed that you scatter."  This is the first time that I'm aware that Glen has recorded "No Blue Sky," although it appeared on The Thorns' self-titled 2003 CD.  I love the chorus where Glen's voice rises into the upper register on the chorus, "If you want me, you know where I will be; I don't get out much anymore."  Glen turns in a fine rendition of Paul Simon's lovely "American Tune" that appeared on Simon's "There Goes Rhymin' Simon" 1973 album.  "Green Zoller" was on Glen's "Live @ Largo" 2003 set, but everything else here is new, as far as I can tell.  "The Song Is Still Here" is an addictive Phillips' hook-filled melody with a strong lyric, "He didn't want to be no one-hit wonder; Lightning strikes quick, you can hear the thunder for miles and miles, it echoes across the East, The fire is gone, but the spark is still here."  "The Coyote Sessions" is a welcome addition to Phillips' music.  He's grown into one of my very favorite artists for whom I race to get each release.  This does not disappoint.  Enjoy!

"Medicine" is my introduction to Drew Holcomb & the Neighbors.  It's a strong set.  "Tightrope" charms with its midtempo beat, its lovely melody and Drew's vocals embracing the longing in the lyric, "I want to go wherever you go, through the night where the storms roll, till the rising sun meets the morning; Want to go wherever you go."  It's a beautiful love song.  "Even when the rain pours down, even when the light seems like it's fading, even when your heart aches, feels like it's gonna break, that's when you sing out loud," Drew sings on "Shine Like Lightning," a midtempo rocker with a with a great bass guitar underpinning the verse until the song explodes on the chorus.  "I've Got You" has a whistling chorus that makes it sound like a hiking song to me, "I've got a dream over my shoulder; I've got love tied around my waist; I've got a big imagination; I've got the world & I've got you."  While these are my favorites on the set, there are no weak tracks.  This is a very strong set that makes me want to hear more from this band.  Enjoy!

Nick Nolan's "Wide Asleep" is an interesting book with several different threads.  Crime, romance, and the paranormal intertwine.  Arthur Blauefee and Jeremy Tyler's romance reignites after a four-year hiatus.  This rescues Jeremy from a self-destructive spiral of drugs, alcohol and casual sex.  Jeremy's financial state is at a low point as his former lover Lazzaro has set him up to assume a huge debt on a house.  Arthur also is struggling with a health crisis.  Jeremy begins past life regression with Dr. Studski that puts him in touch with his former self from Greece and the Civil War.  Jeremy also seems to have hallucinations that may be paranormal.  Nolan brings up the subject of reincarnation, which you must buy to take the plot seriously.  He goes a bit overboard with having people not only have past lives, but having them look like they do in the present life.  So if you want to get a good picture of Jeremy Tyler, search for Antinous, his Greek counterpart.  The secondary characters are bit thin for me.  Carmella seems like such an evil woman that it doesn't quite work when we find there are layers to her persona.  Carlos is so very sweet.  But if you buy the reincarnation aspect, then these blemishes may be overlooked too.  I did really like the dogs.  The conclusion crashes together like a Perry Mason plot with the surprise conclusion.  Mostly, I did like the book.  Jeremy and Arthur seemed like people who really cared about each other, which was sweet.  Enjoy!

"They Want My Soul" by Spoon is a strong set.  "Rent I Pay" has a strong beat and great vocals by Britt Daniels, "Out amongst the stars and the stones; Every kinda fortune gets old."  "Let Me Be Mine" also catches my ear with its rhythm guitar and thumping bass, "You're gonna take another chunk of me with you when you go."  Other tracks like "Knock, Knock, Knock," "Outliner" & "New York Kiss" are also strong.  I've had friends who've told me I would like this band for awhile now, but this is actually my introduction to their music.  Sweet!  Enjoy!

Mary Lambert's 1st full-length set sparkles.  Where there are some flags to wave whose causes may endear the disc to some such as lesbian issues and heavyset body images, ultimately it is the music and Mary's passionate singing that sell this.  "Secrets" opens the disc with a rap-like laundry list of self-examined issues and blooms into a chorus of carefree bliss, "So-oh-oh-oh what?"  Mary's cover of the Rick Springfield hit "Jessie's Girl" grabs your attention as she takes the rocker and transforms it into a piano ballad, "Where can I find a woman like that?"  "Monochromatic" is a powerful ballad that starts simply and then adds instruments to make it an aching anthem, "My heart's too big for this city; My heart's too big for my own body; My heart's too big for you to understand me."  "Sum of Our Parts" concludes the set with a lovely original melody.  Mary is from Seattle and studied classical music before moving into pop.  This is a delightful freshman set.  Enjoy!

The self-titled CD by the Australian band 5 Seconds of Summer rocks out with a joyful spirit.  "Kiss Me Kiss Me" thunders at full volume, "Let's make tonight the best of our lives."  "18" is catchy with about every obstacle to young love referenced, "She told me to meet her there, but I can't afford bus fare."  "Long Way Home" has a melody that sets it apart, "We're hiding out in a dream; Catching fire like kerosene."  The set closer "Amnesia" appeals to me with some acoustic guitar and a brokenhearted melody, "I remember the day you told me you were leaving; I remember the makeup running down your face."  While some of the tracks have a similar sound, there are enough great tracks here to endear the disc to your ear.  Enjoy!

Melissa Manchester's new set is a strong return to form for this talented singer.  Besides looking ageless in the great cover photography, she's lost none of her steam or talent since her stunning 2004 set "When I Look Down That Road."  The opening title track "You Gotta Love the Life" sparkles with a punchy arrangement and Manchester's vocals spot on, "You gotta learn to fall every time you hit the wall; Baby, you've got the right to give it another try."  Keb' Mo' joins Melissa on guitar on the delightful blues-tinged "Feelin' for You" that slinks and smokes with desire, "You got your mojo workin', dancing your crazy voodoo; Quick, take this kiss off my lips."  "Open My Heart to Your Love" is another track that resonates with me with its lovely melody and upbeat lyric with Stephan Oberhoff's accordion giving a New Orleans flavor to the arrangement.  Many of the other tracks are also gems like "Big Light," "Claudia" & "I Know Who I Am."  Welcome back, Melissa.  We've missed you!  Enjoy!

Imaginary Friend is a duo composed of Neal Leatherman and Jeff Carroll.  This independent release from 2007 brims over with retro charm.  The two-disc set is composed of the music on the first disc and then a second disc with the guys listening to the music in the background and commenting on the songs.  "Her" is one of my favorites with its prominent guitar line and retro harmonies that ironically the lads disparage on the commentary portion, "One night it's a blur; And your speech is slurred; You've been out drinking, thinking that you're sinking without her."  "(Not Your) #6" is a direct homage to the 60s hit "Secret Agent Man" by Johnny Rivers and serves up retro-ambrosia.  "Cut of Attention" is a decidedly retro with snarling drone vocals juxtaposed to the guitar line, "She pours like the moonlight falling on the shore; And she roars like a fire churning at its core; She pours like red wine staining the floor."  "Drug Perfect" unleashes some searing electric guitar with Imaginary harmonies.  "Mangos & Peaches" has tight harmonies that are oh-so-60s except for an F bomb casually dropped in the lyric.  Imaginary Friend's CD was recorded independently in a basement over years.  It is a labor of love that sparkles for all lovers of 60s music.  Enjoy!

Walk the Moon's sophomore set blasts out of the speakers with great dance-rock grooves that grab you by the ear and don't let go until you're shaking your stuff wherever the music has found you.  "Sidekick" throbs and shakes relentlessly, "Something in the air is giving me bad ideas."  "Shut Up & Dance" is one of the most addictive tracks playing on the radio, "A backless dress & some beat-up sneaks, my discotheque Juliet, teenage dream."  "Up 2 U" pumps vibrantly until synthesizer explodes with keyboards, "It's hard enough just making money; It's hard enough just trying to feel alive."  "We Are the Kids" is another blazing track that pops and sparkles, "We are the kids that you never can kill."  "Talking Is Hard" is an amazing sophomore set building on their outstanding self-titled debut set.  Enjoy!

Casey Neill & the Norway Rats' "All You Pretty Vandals" is another excellent chapter in Casey's excellent recorded work.  Recorded in Portland, Oregon, the disc offers a number of great gems.
