The opening track "Hollow Bones" is a slow ballad with Casey's restless spirit bubbling over in the vocals, "If I had feathered wings; If I had hollow bones; I'd span these lonely seas; and I'd make you my home."  It's a beautiful song.  The title track pumps up the volume with a polka-rock beat and Casey's caustic vocals dripping with disdain, "Have you come to wreck the place and leave?"  "She Came Alive" gets its drive with excellent drums by John Moen and a musical rave-up at which Neill excels, "Came alive in a blinding flash; came alive in a culture clash."  "No Earthly Pleasure" is another favorite with its pumping beat and Casey's vocals as foil to his electric guitar seemingly at cross-purposes as his voice soothes and the guitar jabs like a poke in the chest, "I swam in the wells of sadness; Locked myself in the halls of madness; Travelled to the distant mountains and across the Bridge of Sighs."  The rest of the set is also strong.  Another wildly entertaining set from this master musician.  Enjoy!

Dulcie Taylor's new set "Only Worn One Time" offers some delights.  The opening track "On A Rainy Day" is a ballad with a touch of blues and Dulcie's vocals sad and aching, "Let the tears of heaven hide my pain away; I wait to cry on a rainy day."  "Take A Chance" has a catchy melody set to a midtempo beat,  "Remember when you were little & somebody begged you to do something that scared you?"  Many of the other tracks also shine.  Less to my liking are the four tracks where Dulcie lets male vocals predominate and moves to the background.  Quite simply, they're not as good singers as she.  That aside, there's enough here to more than recommend this set.  Enjoy!

Emily Dieffenbach's EP is a strong country set from this young artist.  I read a description of this set that described this as "a mix of pop and blues originals."  Make no mistake, while she certainly writes and sings her own material, this disc was recorded in Nashville and has mainstream country written all over it.  Each of the five tracks is strong.  My favorite track is the catchy midtempo "It's You" with Emily's vocals achingly passionate, "It's not you, it's me; How good can those words really be when they're not true? Yeah, it's not me; it's you."  The set closer "Wipe Your Own Tears" rocks out with the bite of breakup, "Are you satisfied with your life the way it is now?  Did all those happy years disappear cause you didn't feel like having me around?"  The other tracks like the melodic opener "Kiss Me," the very lovely "Drive," and the title track are all strong.  This is an excellent intro set by the developing artist who is super strong as both singer and songwriter.  Enjoy!

I just finished reading this book. . . and I was all ready to give it 5-stars. . . . until I got to the end. . . . and that’s when it all came crashing down.From the beginning, the story rolls along well.  It keeps you turning the pages to see what’s going to happen next.  I like the different characters.  It’s a very fun read.But I didn’t really like the ending.  Actually, it doesn’t “end”.  It just “stops”.  I hadn’t noticed, before reading, that this was going to be a “series”.  I don’t know how many books are going to be written in the series.  But unlike some other books of a series which tie everything up neatly at the end . .  . but leaves you knowing that there’s going another book to follow. . . . This one really feels like you got to the end of the chapter. . . and you should turn the page and the next chapter should be right there and follow.  But it doesn’t.  There are just blank pages.  I don’t know how long it will be until the next book is out. Again, I don’t know how many books will be in the series.  But because of the way that this one ended. . . . And assuming that the next book will pick-up right where this one leaves off. . . . I’d rather wait until they are all out and just read them in order one-after-the-other.In upcoming books I would hope and assume two things would happen:#1.  Find out more about Yude.#2.  Incorporate Cheng and Ramona into the “adventure”.Finally. . . I know that there are names which are “gender neutral”.  .. but. . . . “Pam” is not one of them. I have NO Idea why the author chose “Pam” to be the name of a male character.  Perhaps there is a reason for that, and it will come out in future books.  But if not, that’s just crazy to me.

This is a cute book FILLED with homophones.  They are one right after the other.  For young readers, I think this is the type of book that’s going to have to be read either with an adult. .  . .or perhaps even better in a school setting. . . where each of the homophones can be examined, reviewed and explained.  I think that homophones can be fun for kids, and this book helps to show that.I really like the artwork.  It’s very colorful and inviting.“Tank” is the female dog, and honestly, I think a better, more feminine name could have been chosen.Overall, I like the book.

This listing is for several different cases.  The case I am reviewing is the Meta II Rose Gold.I call this a “fashion case”.  It’s not really for protection, other than for scratches from the back and sides.Though it’s plastic, it has a look and feel of brushed metal.  It has a matte finish.  It’s not really textured, so it’s still quite slick.This case is Made in Korea.  At the current price, I think it’s very expensive for a piece of plastic.  Having said that, it does look quite nice, and if you’re not looking for a case for protection, then this is not bad.

I really hate the word “hoody”. . . but that’s indeed what this item is.  The listing shows, and the label shows, that this is 80% cotton and 20% polyester.  It certainly doesn’t feel like it.  It feels more like the reverse.  There is a bit of “stretch” to it.This is Made in Pakistan.  The quality is really not bad at all.  The material is not too thin and not too thick.  I don’t personally find either of these color combinations particularly attractive, but that’s simply a personal preference.I'm surprised that there is no drawstring around the hood.At the current price for Made in Pakistan, I think it’s a little expensive, but not to the level of “crazy expensive”.STX is a “generic” clothing brand from a company by the name of “Stretch-O-Rama, Inc.” out of New York. They have several “generic” brands such as this.

These shorts are what you generally think of as basketball shorts.  They are mesh, but also have a very thin lining inside all the way down the legs.  They have an elastic waist with no drawstring.  No pockets.They are Made in Egypt, and I’m actually quite impressed with the quality, especially for the price.  They look gook. . . Very stylish. . . . comfortable. . . tiny hold make them “breathable”.At the current price, especially on the “low-end” I think they are a really great buy.STX is a “generic” clothing brand from a company by the name of “Stretch-O-Rama, Inc.” out of New York. They have several “generic” brands such as this.

The shorts I have are a size 14.  The waist is right at 28.5”, which is about 1.5” too much.  So they run large.These are made in Bangladesh, which is known for cheap quality.  The material is quite thin / lightweight, but that works for hot Summer months.  They are 100% cotton, and for them to look their best, you’re going to have to iron them.At the current price, I think they are much too high.  Nonetheless, I don’t think they reach the level of “crazy expensive”.American Hawk is a “generic” clothing brand from a company by the name of “Stretch-O-Rama, Inc.” out of New York. They have several “generic” brands such as this.

These are very lightweight / thin. . . 100% polyester. . . . “slick”..  . .dress pants.  Honestly, I’m not a huge fan of this type of pants.  Having said that, if you like this type of pant, then these are not bad.There is elastic in the waist so that they are “forgiving” if you’ve gained a little weight, or have a big meal.One thing I don’t really care for is the three-step closure.  There is one button on the inside. . . There is a hook on the outside. . . and there is another button on the outside.  Then, of course, there is the zipper.  WAY too much work to put on a pair of pants!

The shorts I have are a size 12.  The waist is right at 26”, which is fine.  But the inseam is way too long and they are “baggy” overall.  So they are kind of an “odd” fit.These are made in Bangladesh, which is known for cheap quality.  The material is quite thin, but that works for hot Summer months.  They are 100% cotton, and for them to look their best, you’re going to have to iron them.At the current price, I think they are much too high.  Nonetheless, I don’t think they reach the level of “crazy expensive”.American Hawk is a “generic” clothing brand from a company by the name of “Stretch-O-Rama, Inc.” out of New York. They have several “generic” brands such as this.

The main thing you’re supposed to be able to do with a watch is tell time.  But that’s nearly impossible with this watch.  The display isn’t even close to as bright as it shows on the picture.  It’s simply not easy to read.  There is an option of pressing a light, which will illuminate things for three-seconds but #1, you shouldn’t have to do that.  #2, it will run the battery down much quicker.  If it was not for this one “issue”. . . . but it’s a HUGE “issue” then I would like the watch.The watch I have looks much darker than the one in the picture.  Almost black.  But I don’t mind that.  It looks good either way.If you don’t mind not being able to tell the time. . . or anything else on the screen.  .. . then this might work for you.  Otherwise, I would HIGHLY recommend you keep looking.

The jeans that I received are a size 8.  The waist is 24.5”.  These are supposed to be “skinny fit” which would mean that instead of 24.5.  .they should be 22.  So they run large.You will want to wash them separate due to the dye.  You may also wish to use some salt to set the color.The quality of the denim is ok.  Kind of what you expect from Made in China.  But where these jeans “shine” is in all the little “embellishments” which have been added like on the back pockets, the metal hawks, creases, etc.“American Hawk” is kind of a “generic” brand owned by a company called Stretch-O-Rama Inc. out of New York.

This is a very nice case overall, especially for the price.  It has a nice looking matte finish and it’s not slick, which I like.  A slick case is really useless.I have to say that though they call this a “heavy duty” case. . . It’s certainly not as “heavy duty” as some other name-brand cases.  But in this case, the price is really right, and it’s certainly good enough for my needs.  It took a little work to get it on, but it fits snug, and I don’t plan on having to remove it.

Note that DII makes a number of different sizes. . . shapes. . . and colors of bathmats.  Not all of them are under the same listing, so you have to look around.You will want to make sure that you clean your shower or tub thoroughly first.  You’ll also want to wash the mat first as well.  It comes tightly rolled.  If you place it upside-down in a tub and fill the tub to cover the mat with hot water. . . and let it sit for a bit. . . it will “uncurl”.Overall it’s a nice mat.  It’s Made in China, but not “crazy expensive”.  The only thing I don’t care so much about are the “dimples” which are slick.  Because a bath mat is supposed to help you not to fall, I wish the “dimples” were not slick.

This is a pet food company I really love.  . . and I don’t say that about many pet food companies.  First and foremost, NONE of their ingredients come from China.  You have to be VERY careful when purchasing pet food.  Even if the package shows that it’s “Made in the USA”. . . that does NOT mean that the ingredients are not sourced from other countries. .  .especially from China.  If you’re not familiar with “issues” with pet food ingredients coming from China, then I highly recommend you research.Here’s where Solid Gold sources their ingredients for different products:  Venison from Australia; Lamb from New Zealand; Quail, Duck and Rabbit from France; Taurine (amino acid) from Japan.  The rest comes from The United States and Canada.This particular product, Furrever Young, is specifically for mature / senior cats.  Depending upon your pet, some of the other Solid Gold varieties also work well for senior cats.

I don’t know where these are made.  I know that the company shows to be in New Jersey, but I can’t find any information on the box, inside insert or individual packaging as to where they are made.I’m always “uncomfortable” when I find something written incorrectly on packaging such as this.  I know it’s something small, but if someone is not checking the instructions, then what else are they not checking.The information on the individual package. .  .which is VERY hard to read because it’s tiny and white lettering on green shows:3.  Hold tube the vertically. . …. . .Again. . I know it’s something small. . but. . . “hold tube the”???  The instructions on the included insert are much easier to read and much more detailed.I am not 100% sure that this product works, because I have no way of checking it.  But I will say that the colors have been what I expected for the times that I’ve tried it.  But this is not cheap.  So it depends upon how often you check as to if these are worth it or not.  Other, less expensive options, are available.  .again. . . depending upon how often you are checking.

This company makes a few of these “books” (which are not really books at all) with this one being the “Colors & Shapes” edition.  I’m not really a big fan of these for a few reasons.First, this is not a book.  You open it up and there are four panels on each side of the “strip”.The “sound” button you press goes in an order.  Unless an adult is there to make sure the child is looking at the proper color/shape, then there is really no way for a child to learn the colors and shapes.  They would simply hear noises and be confused.  You might even want to cut the sound device off so that the child can simply look at and play with the soft fabric.Finally.  .. . for Made in China. . . this item is WAY overpriced.

Note that these are LATEX gloves.  Latex does not work with oil / grease as they will disintegrate.  If you are going to be working with oil / grease then you will probably want nitrile gloves.These gloves are nice “overall” gloves which, even though they are not that thick, they are quite strong.  They work well for foodservice, general cleaning, etc.Ammex makes a lot of different gloves under several different names.  Their gloves are very good quality, and very reasonably priced.

This is one of those “here today. . . gone tomorrow” books.  Yes, it’s all about online blah.  . blah. . blah. . . but it’s boring!  I didn’t find Scarlett herself to be a very likeable person, which made it a challenge to read.  More stereotypical, and not in a good way.  It comes across as a bad TV show written in book form.I’m sure there are kids out there like Scarlett. . . . and I really feel for them.  Because they could really be doing something productive with their lives.

This is the first book of the series.  I’m interested in seeing how things go from here.  Though most adults are probably familiar with the Pied Piper story, some children may not be.  But that won’t stop young readers from enjoying this book.  It’s a nice mystery with just enough suspense to keep things interesting, but not really scary.  There are a variety of “creatures” to keep things fun as well.Overall I really enjoyed the book and think kids will like it as well.  I think that 3rd graders might be  little young, but of course it all depends upon the reader.  Looking forward to the 2nd book.

This is a tall fescue seed, with a smidgen of Kentucky Bluegrass (10%) added so they can call it a “blue mix”.  Scotts makes a mix with a higher percentage of Kentucky Bluegrass as well.Results will always be based upon the amount of effort you put into it.  This seed will not do much better than any other less expensive seed if you don’t do the prep work of your yard and watering.  But if you indeed make the effort, then you’ll have good results with this seed.I really like the fact that there are virtually no weeds in the seed.  That’s a really big problem with a lot of “cheap seed” that you can buy.  So in the end, this is worth the money simply not to have weeds.

This is a really nice tower ceramic heater.  It’s just under 2’ tall.  It puts out a nice amount of heat.  Two of my favorite things about it is the remote and that it oscillates.  To see all of the information, you have to be at the unit and looking at the top.  But being able to turn it on/off from across the room is really nice.  Of course all of the safety features are great also.  The motion sensor is especially nice if you have kids and/or pets.  This is one of the nicest heaters I’ve had, especially for the price, and I’ve had several.

First of all. . . “one-size-fits-most” must be for China, where this is made, but if you’re over say 170#, then this is not going to work.This material is very loose / thin.  It is soft, but if you are familiar with “microfiber” it has a certain “feel” to it.  Personally, I’m not fond of the feel, but many don’t mind it.  I like microfiber for cleaning. .  .but not “clothing”.For Made in China, this item is WAY too expensive at the current price.

This listing is for different colors.  The color that I have is Navy.I’ve received a few similar shirts lately, and I have to say that this is a favorite.  It’s so much better than the others, and the price is right.  The picot stitching around the collar is nicely done.  The little flower buttons add that little extra touch.Please Note:  I see that this listing shows that the shirt is 100% cotton.  The shirt which I received is 60% cotton and 40% polyester.  But it’s very . . . very soft.This shirt is Made in Bangladesh, which is not known for high-quality clothing, but I have to say that this is shirt is quite nice, especially at the current listed price. . . .and especially if you can get it in the size/color you need on the “lower-end” of the price scale.

This listing is for different colors.  The color that I have is Navy.This long-sleeve shirt is certainly not for warmth.  The material is quite thin.  But it’s really soft.  Being that it’s a 60/40 blend, it should wash quite well.Though the listing shows that this item is Made in Bangladesh, the shirt I received shows Made in India.  Both countries are not known for high-quality clothing, but this particular shirt is quite nice, but again, a bit thin.  It’s certainly worth the money, especially on the low-end of the current price range.

This listing is for different colors.  The color that I have is Navy.  Having said that, the color, at least on my computer, looks almost teal in the pictures above.  But indeed the shirt I received is a nice dark navy.The material is very soft.  It’s a 60/40 blend, which means it should wash quite well.  The material is quite thin though.As for the “picot edging”. .  .It’s not at all like it is in the pictures.  It’s almost “nonexistent”.  You really wouldn’t even notice it.  It simply looks like someone sewed an extra piece of thread around the edge of the sleeve and around the collar for some “odd” reason.  But it certainly doesn’t add anything to the shirt.This listing shows that the shirt is Made in China.  The shirt I received is actually Made in India, so I can only assume they are sourcing in different places.If you can get this shirt on the “low-end” of the current price range, it’s not bad.  But I certainly can’t see paying more than five bucks for it.

I almost find it hard to believe that there is any cotton in these pants at all.  They are VERY “hard”.  They don’t really get any softer after washing as well.I don’t have any problems with the craftsmanship, which is a little unusual for me for an item Made in Bangladesh.  But these are fine.  I must admit I wish they had a button closure, inside of hook-and-eye.The waist is slightly adjustable inside the waist.But again. . . I go back to how “hard” they are.  I can’t believe that a child is going to want to wear them very often. . . . though they are not a bad price, on the low-end of the current price scale.

I have to say that these pants look better in person than they do on the pictures above.  They are indeed khaki in color, and not “cream” which is how they appear on my computer.The belt which came with the pants is not the same as in the picture above, so I have added a picture.  The belt I received is navy in color.  I think it works really well with the pants, depending upon what type / color shirt you’re wearing with the slacks.  Of course you can always use a different belt.  There is also adjustable elastic in the inside waist of the pants.The 60/40 blend means that they wash well.  They are made in Bangladesh, which is known for inexpensive / not high-quality clothing.  Nonetheless, I think these are fairly well made.  If you can get them on the “lower-end” of the currently listed price, they are a good buy.

I have to say that these pants look better in person than they do on the pictures above.  They are indeed khaki in color, and not “cream” which is how they appear on my computer.The belt which came with the pants is not the same as in the picture above, so I have added a picture.  Personally, I like the belt that came with the pants I received a little better, but either would work fine.The 60/40 blend means that they wash well. . .  though I have to say some of the stitching is a bit “loose”.  They are made in Bangladesh, which is known for inexpensive / not high-quality clothing.  Nonetheless, if you can get them for the “lower-end” of the current price range, they are a good buy.  Again, for the price, I like them.

This listing is for two different color combinations.  The glove that I have is the Black/Orange.The pictures on Amazon look a bit “washed-out”, so I’m uploading one, in hopes that you will be able to see the vibrant colors of the glove.  It’s indeed bright orange.One of the reasons that this glove is “RTP” (ready-to-play) is the material.  The outer part is mostly cloth.  The inside is “pleather” (faux leather).  But this is not an expensive glove, and unlike an adult glove, it’s not going to be used for years and years by the same person.  So overall, I think it’s a great glove at a reasonable price.

Not only are some people allergic to latex. .  . . Latex will also disintegrate when exposed to oil / grease.  That’s why I love nitrile gloves.These particular gloves are not for heavy-duty use.  I would say they are “medium” use gloves.  They will certainly work for most “normal” use types of things.  But they do come a bit thicker, if you’re doing “heavy duty” work.  These are certainly priced right for a box of 100. Worth giving a try.This company makes a TON of different gloves in different colors. . . different thicknesses. . . and under different brand names.

It’s kind of “odd” that the box and information shows that no combing is required. . . but then a comb is included.  That’s because combing IS required.  I would also recommend a better comb.  This product works, but I HIGHLY recommend you leave the treatment in overnight.  Depending upon the infestation, you will probably want to treat twice.Of course the other thing you have to do to get rid of lice is to clean. . . clean. .  .clean. . . and clean some more.

These are Latex gloves. ..  .So they do NOT work with oil / grease and such.  They will disintegrate if when they come into contact with such items.  If you’re going to be working with those items, then you will need nitrile gloves.Otherwise, these are nice heavy duty latex gloves.  They fit reasonably well.  The price is reasonable as well for 100.  If you don’t need “heavy duty” you can get them slightly lower, but these work quite well and are worth it in the end.

The material is quite thin.  It would work better in warmer weather.  It’s 60% cotton and 40% Polyester.  So it’s not as soft as all cotton.  It’s Made in China, hence the quality and the price.  It just doesn’t feel like the type of material that’s going to last.  But for the price, it’s not bad either.I would prefer that it didn’t have a “yak” on the left.  I have no idea why this company decided to use a yak for their logo / emblem.  Just about anything other than a yak would have been preferred.

This listing is for different aprons.  The one I have, and am reviewing, is “Blue Daisy”.First of all. . . Unless you’re rather petit and not too tall, then you’ll probably want to keep looking.The fabric is very thin.  This is the type of apron one would use for entertaining, after they have already cooked everything (in a different apron) . . . and are just finishing-up and serving.  It’s certainly not the type of apron one would use for “real” cooking.  Having said that, it is prettyThe current price is a bit much for thin material Made in India. . . but if the pattern / colors / size works for you. . . then great.This company makes a LOT of different aprons, so be sure and have a good look around.

This is a nice “starter” type / size football for young people to begin with.  It’s “squishy”.The one “funny” thing is the “hype” about the “Spacelace lacing system”.  The ball that I have doesn’t look like the picture at all.  I would call mine “Goop lacing system”.  See picture.  I can certainly say that “Spacelace lacing system” is quite bogus.This football is Made in China.  At the current price it’s overpriced, but not crazy overpriced.  Personally, I prefer the Wilson Junior Footballs.

This item is nice for both boys and girls.  Overall it’s more like five teething items.  I’m not sure that the “blanket” is even necessary.  They are all cute and colorful.  Nice sizes as well.  The box it comes in makes it easy to wrap and give as a gift.  For Made in China, I think the current price is quite high, but not to the level of “crazy expensive”.  This item is especially nice for travel to keep baby entertained.

These cargo shorts look really great.  They are made in Bangladesh, which  is not known for high-quality clothing, but these shorts certainly look better than a lot of other items I’ve seen.  They are 60 cotton / 40 polyester, which means that they will wash well.  They are somewhat adjustable using a strap in the waist.  The “cargo pockets” are Velcro closures.  The only thing that I really don’t care for is the metal hook on the waist instead of a button.  A button would have been much better.The current price range is really huge.  If you can get these at the lower end in the color and size that you need, I think that they are a great buy.

Though these pants are made in Bangladesh (not known for high quality clothing) these are certainly made better than some other “off-brand” slacks that I’ve tried, which were also made in Bangladesh.  The 5% spandex means that they will stretch ever so slightly.  The 95% cotton feels good.  Nice and smooth fabric.  These pants taper quite a bit down the leg.  More so than what it shows in the picture.  At least on my screen, the online picture looks more “charcoal”, but the pants are indeed black.  Overall, they are very nice. . . especially if you can get them at the lower-end of the current price range.

This is a very “basic” little sweater.  It’s quite thin and 100% acrylic.  Overall it’s fine, though nothing special.  Being that it’s made in Bangladesh, I think the price is a bit high, even on the low end of the scale.  But it’s not crazy expensive.  If you can get it on the lower end of the price range, then it’s not too bad.  FYI. . . This is a girl’s sweater.  You can tell by the way it buttons.

Please Note:  The shirt that I have is white.  This is a very “generic” shirt.  It’s very thin, and though it’s long sleeve, it’s not the kind of shirt that’s going to keep you warm.  It’s Made in China, hence the cheap price.  The material is so thin that you can see the inside label from the back of the shirt.  The cost is based upon the size and color.  If you can get them for the “low end” of the price range (under five bucks) then it can still be worth it.  It’s almost “disposable” at that cost, should it be stained.  But it’s certainly not worth the “high-end” of the price range.

These are what I would call “generic” pants.  They are not especially well made, but then they are not priced like “name brand” either.  The 55/45 blend means that they wash well, and you shouldn’t have to iron them, as long as they remove them from the dryer immediately.The label shows “Relax Fix”.  So they are going to run a little large.  They are somewhat adjustable inside the waist.The current price is certainly right, especially if you can get them at the “lower end” of the scale.  They should work well as school pants.

This is a fairly well made toy.  Nice size and gear.  It’s a little on the “pricey” side for Made in China, but you’re paying for the name, of course.  I must say that this particular figure does not look like The Rock much at all.  Some of the other figures look a little more like who they are supposed to.  The packaging is nice, just in case you’re giving it as a gift.  The different body parts are removable.  I’m not exactly sure why that’s a “good thing” but just in case you want to pretend he loses a leg. . . you can.

This is a fairly well made toy.  Nice size and gear.  It’s a little on the “pricey” side for Made in China, but you’re paying for the name, of course.  This particular one also looks a little more who it is supposed to than some of the others.  The packaging is nice also, just in case you’re giving it as a gift.  The different body parts are removable.  I’m not exactly sure why that’s a “good thing” but just in case you want to pretend he loses a leg. . . you can.

This is a crazy expensive, Made in China plastic item that is really not worth the money and not all that useful.  The screen is not that clear and it feels “tacky”.  I have to remove my phone to actually use the phone, and that is not that easy, when you’re in a hurry.  The only real “perk” to this device is the tether.  If you have more than one device. . . and one of those devices is the one that your child uses. . . then perhaps this can work for you.

These are affordable undies that “breath”.  They have tiny holes in them, which you can see if you zoom in on the picture at the top of the listing.  Though they are 94% polyester, they are so thin that they are still quite comfortable.  The colors are quite “neutral”, which I like.  But they also come in other more “exotic” colors and patterns under different listings.  Due to how thin they are, I think washing on the gentle cycle is best.

This is a great “generic” GoPro tripod mount. . . .especially for the price.  It works just as it should.  Attaches to my tripod without a problem.  Honestly, I wish they had not written “amazonbasics” but you might be able to cover that up with some paint, though I don’t know if that would make it look better or worse.  But again, for the price, I’m very pleased with it.AmazonBasics also makes some other nice items for GoPro like the small carrying case.AmazonBasics Carrying Case for GoPro - Small

This listing is for multiple covers.  My review is for the 10.1-inch Camellia / Cherry Blossom.I like the look.  The colors are bright.  The actual case itself I’m not quite as fond of.  I’ve used other Belkin cases that I like better for different devices.  This particular case is trying to be “all things to all tablets” and might . . . but might not work for your device.I wish there was a pocket on the inside.  I wish there was a stylus holder.  I wish there were more ways to set it up to view.  In the end. ..  this is just an “ok” case.The “worst” part about this case is the current cost.  At forty bucks, it’s WAY overpriced for a Made in China product.

First. . . I might be the only person in the world who has never seen a “clasp mechanism” like this. . . but it’s “odd” and not in a good way.  There are no instructions on how to open / close it.  You either have to really pull on the “buckle” part. . . or. .  I would recommend you use something to press underneath on the two center squares to pop it out from there.  If you pull too hard on the top, it could easily break.  The “buckle” itself, which has the “rod” which goes into one of the holes on the band. . . Hold it with the “LP” facing you.  Then pull-up on the top to pop it open so that you can thread the band through. .  find the hole that works for you. . insert the rod. . . and press down on the top to close it.  I find this to be a VERY unusual way to do things.  I’d would MUCH rather just thread the band through a “regular” buckle. . .and be done with it.  On top of this, I don’t know the “right” way to open it, once you have it on.  The way that I’ve been doing it is to pull-up on the band, which will “pop” the clasp open so you can take it off.  The only way I would ever use this watch on a regular basis would be to remove the current clasp. . . and put a “regular” buckle on the end.  The leather band is really not bad. . . It’s just the clasp which I really do not care for.  Instead of having a video which simply shows the watch. . . They should have a video which shows how to open-and-close the clasp.  If you too are not fond of the clasp, then I’m almost certain that a jeweler can remove the current clasp and put a standard type buckle on it.The watch itself is pretty.  In the picture on the listing the rose gold tone case looks like it has a matte finish. . . it doesn’t. . . It’s glossy.  The hands are fairly easy to read.  It’s a nice size and the white leather band works well.  If it had a standard clasp, I would give it four stars . . . but as it is, I can only give it three.The “list prices” are just crazy.  These are cheap watches Made in China.  They certainly are on the “low-end” of watches.  Another thing they do that I don’t care for. . . They put paper instructions on how to set the watch inside. . . but for several different types of watches.  It’s a piece of paper.  They could easily just print what you need for this watch, but they want to save themselves time / money by printing instructions for multiple watches and letting you “find” yours.  Again, instruction for opening the clasp are not given, and should have been.Finally. . . It’s the box which impresses me most.  The box looks like it costs almost as much as the watch!

Please Note: You’ll need two AA batteries each for the tall “pillar” candles.  So six total.  The smaller candles already have batteries, but the larger “pillar” candles do not.If you’re not familiar with “flameless” candles, this is a very nice assortment.  The lights inside “flicker” to give them a more realistic look.  When they are off, they are off-white in color.  When they are illuminated, they are “golden” just like it shows in the picture.One thing that the pictures do not show is that in the top of the pillar and votive candles is a black “wick” to make it look more realistic, especially then they are not illuminated.  Of course when you have them on, and they are glowing, the wick is obviously not burning.One thing I’m not hugely fond of, but it’s not a “deal breaker” by any means is the fact that the light that glows in the pillar candles is somehow “hanging” inside.  You can see the shadow and hear it rattle if you shake the candle.  But it’s not centered, so there is a “bright spot” on one side of the candle.  Depending upon your preference, and also where you’re using them, you may want to turn it to the front.. or the back. . .The “pillars” have kind of a cool timer.  The way it works is. . . . At the time you want the candle to turn-on each day you press the switch on the bottom over to “timer”. The candle will be on for 5-hours, and then turn-off.  It will continue to turn-on at the same time each day for 5-hours.  You can reset it simply by turning the candle off and the switching it over to “timer” at the exact new time you want it to turn-on each day.Because they are wax, the pillar and votive candles are certainly “realistic”.  But also, because they are was, you will want to be careful and not put them next to something hot, like a fireplace.

FINALLY a dog treat that is not only made in. . . but sourced in. . . the USA!  I’m a Happy Camper!. . . for the most part. ;-)I like that they are grain-free. . . no fillers. .  and so on.  They are a bit soft, but that’s not always a bad thing, depending upon your dog.  If you’re dog is not chewing them enough, then you might need to cut them into pieces.There are certainly less expensive treats on the market. . .but I’m not buying Made in China treats.  Again, I LOVE the fact that these are made and sourced in the USA.

95% cotton is great.  It’s soft. . . .Comfortable. . . Washes well.  Not really a fan of the colors.  But other options are offered in different listings.Depending upon your size / shape, these can fit a bit like “granny panties”.  The current pricing varies greatly by size.  If you can get them at the low end of the scale in your size, then they are not bad.  But at the “high-end” they are a little too expensive.

This biography tells the story of Billy Fiske, and to a lesser extent, three other bobsledding pioneers (Jay O'Brien, Clifford "Tippy" Gray, and Eddie Eagan) who made up the team that won the gold medal at the 1932 Winter Olympics held in Lake Placid despite initially being the underdog.The stories go into how the four of them met one another during the 1920's and 1930's; their individual backgrounds; how they overcame the odds placed against them at the Olympics; and what happened to them after their Olympics win, especially during and after the World War II years.At age 16, Billy Fiske won his first bobsledding gold at the 1928 Winter Olympics despite having had no previous experience or training at bobsledding, just like the much older Jay O'Brien and Tippy Gray, who were two of his team mates at the event. Not many people knew that Billy was only 16 at the time because he showed a lot of maturity and leadership qualities that made him a lot of friends.At the problem-ridden 1932 Winter Olympics, Jay O'Brien butted heads with the games organizer, Godfrey Dewey, whose selfish agenda would have proved detrimental to the eventual champions had he prevailed.  Which was why Billy Fiske and team felt vindicated when they did win against all odds.The 1936 Winter Olympics was held in Germany.  Despite Germany's anti-Jew policies, the then American Olympics Committee did not support boycotting the games.  Even though Billy was initially invited to participate, he ended up not being a part of the games for various reasons covered in the book.Then came World War II.  Despite being an American, Billy volunteered to join England's Royal Air Force to specifically serve with the 601 Squadron at a time when the United States was still a neutral country.  The book goes over Billy's reasons for doing this and recounts his heroism.Overall, I thought this book is well researched and written.  It actually covers more than just the risks and thrills and technicalities of the bobsledding sports to bring to light the humanity -- the best and the lesser aspects of it -- of the various people whose paths crossed during the decades covered in this book. While Billy Fiske's courage and heroism are this book's central focus, the story of Eddie Eagan is quite interesting as well.  The only aspect of the book that I did not enjoy as much was the sometimes extended excursions into the Olympians' Hollywood adventures and connections.

These Hefty Ultimate Easy Plastic Cups can hold up to 18 oz of liquid.  They are reusable and feel sturdy but are thinner than expected.  The middle section contains the textured diamond pattern that helps make a cup easy to grip and slip-resistant, but that section indents easily with just a little pressure.

The 39 short stories contained in this collection explore a wide range of themes and human experiences, including racial conflict, effects of wars here at home, the immigrant experience, and homelessness.  Presented chronologically, the introductory notes for each time period provide helpful highlights on sea changes in topical interests and the publishing industry due to the impact of various technological, economic, socio-political, and historical events, and the mini author bios preceding each short story provide informative tidbits regarding the kind of themes a given author's writing tended to revolve around.  Within this wonderfully curated collection readers will find one work each of writers such as Ernest Hemingway, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Philip Roth, Joyce Carol Oates, Grace Paley, Alice Munro, Jhumpa Lahiri, and Tobias Wolff.

This Eucerin In-Shower Body Lotion is fragrance-free and effective.  After rinsing off from your normal shower, apply this lotion to your still wet body while in the shower, then rinse off again.  You can feel the product on your skin as you're toweling off from the shower, and you'll feel the protection a little while longer after that.  Having used this product for several days now, I can say it works well. Remember, however, that because you're applying the lotion while you're still in the tub, you need to clean off any residue that may remain in the tub with hot water in order to avoid slipping.

In the study of evolution, the concepts of competition and "survival of the fittest" have been front and center. Recently, however, proponents of an endosymbiotic theory of evolution have been calling attention to the importance and/or pervasiveness of symbiotic or more cooperative processes in evolution.In this book, Dr. Graffin delves into the presence of such symbiotic processes and the evidence for them from various microscopic as well as more macroscopic investigations of interacting organisms.  He then discusses the implications of these findings and possible takeaways for systems-level thinking about how we should behave towards one another and towards the environment if our goal is for humans to survive for as long as possible.The discussions employ several technical terms and concepts utilized by biological and evolution scientists, but they are explained reasonably well for a lay audience.  There were times, however, when I wished the discussions could have moved along more quickly by perhaps leaving out some of the less pertinent minutiae.The overwhelming message that I got from this book is that our evolution is not and should not be driven by the competition imperative -- an abstraction that, according to Dr. Graffin, has been used to justify untrue beliefs and unkind acts against society's less fortunates, etc. There's plenty of scientific evidence for the symbiosis imperative as well.  In fact, symbiosis may be more key to human survival than competition.

I received a single one-pound bag of this Zatarain's Extra Long Grain Parboiled Rice for testing.  Using the cooking instructions printed on the bag, I was happy that the cooked rice turned out to have good texture and taste, and the grains stayed separate.  Because parboiled rice tends to be more nutritious than basic white rice, this product is worth considering if you like your rice nonsticky as well.

According to the author, many people with stress-related health problems are reluctant to seek help because of pride or shame.  In explaining how stress affects us psychologically and physiologically in terms that are understandable to a lay person, he seeks to destigmatize stress-related health problems, stating at the end of the book: 'Ultimately, psychological problems reflect "a flaw in brain circuitry and not a flaw in character." p. 268'The broad range of topics covered includes several rudimentary chapters on stress-related health problems and what are currently known about their underlying biochemical processes.  The book ends with discussions of available approaches to stress reduction, including relaxation training, psychotherapy, and drug treatments.The depth of the discussions is appropriate for a lay audience. Some of the suggestions and information are familiar and may also be considered common sensical by some readers, but the author writes very well and knows how to use humor to keep readers engaged.

This book is organized into three parts. Part One looks into the vulnerability of our power grids to a catastrophic cyberattack.  While a few in the power industry still think our power grids are resilient and well protected, a majority of the experts interviewed by the author concede that someone who has the right skills and knowledge can indeed cause damage to our power grids such that multiple states and their millions of residents can be simultaneously knocked off from the grid for a very long time (a year or longer is possible, depending on, say, how quickly replacements for damaged grid components can be manufactured, etc.).Part Two poses the following question (my wording, not the author's): What has our government been doing to deal with this possibility of a catastrophic cyberattack on our power grids? Unfortunately, the answer seems to be "Not enough."  To be fair, some in the government do know what some of the challenges are, but to date, there is no known coherent "big picture" plan.Part Three examines the efforts of some communities at becoming self-reliant when it comes to disaster preparedness, the limits of such efforts, and possible takeaways for our government and the rest of the nation.  The Mormon community's organizational capability is described in good detail, and there is passing mention of other religious organizations having a similar capability but no additional detail.Overall, this book is well written and does a good job describing the nature of the problems we have and why we need to push our government to do more sooner.

This well-written book discusses the different ways in which our country's moneyed elite have been able -- and continue -- to "rig" the system to their advantage; the damaging effects of these "riggings" on competition and innovation, consumers, and ordinary wage earners; why a shrinking middle class is not good for anyone, including the moneyed elite; what reforms are needed to counter the ever growing economic and political powers of the moneyed elite; and why such reforms can only have a chance to come to fruition if enough of the disadvantaged unite to make their outcry heard.The proposed reforms themselves are reasonably sounding and well-considered.  They include new ideas from both conservative and liberal thought leaders, and also ideas that have been implemented and seem to be working quite well in countries such as France and Australia.  One proposal that, in my opinion, requires a lot more thinking is the idea "to provide all Americans, beginning the month they turn eighteen and continuing each month thereafter, a basic minimum income that enables them to be economically independent and self-sufficient. (p. 218)"Overall, I thought this book is very readable, and explains vety well the kinds of problems we're wrestling against. Although optimistic (because in our country's history, we've seen instances where public outcries have yielded appropriate results), Mr. Reich admits the struggle will not be easy.

As recounted in this book, President Johnson's nomination of Thurgood Marshall to the Supreme Court was a surprise to the Senate's Judiciary Committee.  There had really been no vacancy in the Supreme Court, but because President Johnson was intent on getting an African American seated in the Supreme Court in 1967, he engineered a couple of clever behind-the-scenes dance steps to induce such a vacancy.  When the vacancy materialized, Johnson moved swiftly to nominate the then Solicitor General Thurgood Marshall to fill the vacancy.Senior and conservative members of the Senate's Judiciary Committee, many of whom were from the then very racist South, were displeased with, and vowed to defeat, the nomination.  This book recounts the drama that unfolded during the prolonged hearings, cutting away every now and then to harrowing tales of past lynchings of African Americans, as well as current racial riots occurring in different parts of the country outside of the Senate hearing room, to put into context what were at stake with the nomination fight.The author also provides just enough biographical information about each of the major players in the nomination fight to help readers understand how the life experiences of those individuals affected them, and whether they were able to rise above or shape those experiences into something constructive.Some of the side commentaries pertaining to actions ascribed to Theodore Roosevelt, Woodrow Wilson, and John F Kennedy that African Americans have historically viewed as having impacted their civil rights negatively may also be of interest to some readers.Overall, I thought this book is well written and researched.  It's not as interesting to me as a detailed biography of Thurgood Marshall would have been, but it's informative enough to help me appreciate why the man was held in such high regard by many.

The Neo-Nazi skinhead that lawyer Daniel Duckelman reluctantly agreed to represent was a 20-something high-school dropout.  This film explores the reasons why Duckelman decided not only to stay on as the skinhead's court-appointed lawyer but also actually poured a lot of time and energy into helping him, despite protestations from his wife and brother. The writing and acting are both powerful, but I didn't like that part of the ending involving the TV interview of the skinhead several months after the conclusion of the court trial.  I thought that part was too manipulative and that the writer should have had more faith in the audience's ability to reach their own conclusions about the events that transpired.

Frankie is 28 year old Lizzie's almost 10 year old deaf but very well-adjusted and smart son.  At the film's opening, Lizzie and Frankie are packing for a move.  Viewers learn very quickly that Lizzie and Frankie have been moving a lot, for a reason that Lizzie has been trying to keep Frankie from knowing for as long as she can.Lizzie encourages Frankie to write letters to his absentee father, who's supposedly a sailor traveling around the world.  Frankie doesn't know that Lizzie intercepts those letters so she can write back to him posing as his father.The fiction that Lizzie's been trying to keep alive runs into a problem when Frankie learns that a Navy ship is stopping over at his town and Frankie can't stop wishing his father would be in it so father and son can finally meet.  Not wanting to let Frankie feel unloved by his father, Lizzie decides to hire someone to pose as Frankie's father for a day, over the objection of Frankie's grandmother, who's been urging Lizzie to come "clean."How well would Lizzie's latest plan work? What is she really trying to hide from Frankie and does it really justify the "lies" she has had to tell Frankie?  Would she ever come "clean" to Frankie?The only thing I would venture to say is that this film / story does have a good ending. The acting is very good and Lizzie's and Frankie's responses to their plights will make many viewers tear up a little bit, but in a good way.

One of the things that I think sets this well-crafted sci-fi thriller apart from the herd is the relatively successful integration of a wide range of behavioral, political, physical, and genetic science-related topics or discussions into the novel.  These "science-y" discussions are not difficult for lay readers to follow, but they do tend to slow things down a little bit sometimes.  The notes after the end of the novel provide information regarding what is fact and fiction in those "science-y" discussions.The major characters are all interesting and fleshed out reasonably well, with the possible exception of the main villain, who tended to be somewhat one-dimensional.The well-crafted plot is the best thing about this novel. Its effectiveness (sorry I have to be vague here so as not to risk revealing any spoiler) makes up for the thriller's relative dearth of action scenes, and it does completely resolve the questions and doubts that were accumulating in my mind while following the sometimes twisty plot developments.

You could say this film is about two writers and how they tried to live with the mistakes they made.  The film is well-acted and the story has substance.  Even if you're not a writer, this film may still speak to you if you've ever had to face questions regarding what determines your identity.  At some level, we all probably know that words matter a lot to writers, but I think this film attempts to take our level of understanding a step deeper by making concrete the particular importance of words and the writing process to the two writers studied in this film.

Each of these Purell Hand Sanitizing Wipes is about 7.5" x 5.5" in size.  They're thick enough you don't have to worry they'll fall apart easily.  My hands and face do feel clean and refresh after each use.The variety pack that I received includes 1 Clean Refreshing Scent, 1 Citrus Scent, and 1 Fragrance Free canister containing 40 wipes each, and each of the canisters is small enough to fit into the globe compartment of my car.

This apocalyptic tale has a literary, even theatrical, feel to it. If it were staged as a play, members of the "chorus" would have pithy lines to deliver.The story, however, is nothing special. All of the characters are "lost" in some ways, and most of them have a dark side. When things start unraveling, the crazies predictably become unhinged. Yes, the way they become unhinged is "staged" dramatically, but it also felt contrived (e.g., the abandoned opera house scene).We get to know the characters largely through their silent musings or passively told back stories, so the characters often have a "remote" quality to them. The plot does not unfold in a strictly linear fashion; at inflection points where a new character needs to first be introduced or a returning character resurfaces, the clock is briefly turned back to give readers pertinent background information about the new or returning character(s) so readers can get all caught up with them before the storytelling thread picks up where things were previously left off.Overall, the story did not live up to its initial build-up, straying instead into a different direction, which while still unsettling, was nowhere near the spectacular ending "promised."

This collection of essays by Professor Habermas contains the author's reflections on (a) the European Union and (b) the lives and works of major European philosophers and intellectuals.  The former (a) constitutes the initial two thirds of the book, and the latter (b), the remaining third.Most of the essays would probably not be accessible to readers unfamiliar with the works of the European intellectuals referenced in the essays.  Of the essays that are more accessible, the one entitled "Democracy or Capitalism" also captures the professor's thoughts on challenges facing the European Union (EU) best.  In that essay, the professor revisits the events that led to the last Eurozone financial crisis, and his views on why the incrementalist approach to managing the crisis has been inadequate, and what Eurozone politicians and citizens must find the courage to do in order to make the monetary union work on a more sustainable basis.Professor Habermas' views on why the EuroZone countries need to move towards full political union are not very different from those already expressed by others, so readers who are already familiar with the arguments for or against such full political union won't find anything new in the essays included in this collection.

If you're traveling to the Mediterranean on a cruise ship, you may find the logistics information in this guide on how to get from a port of call to attractions within a coastal city handy.The guide provides good but not in-depth information on several of the more popular coastal cities, beginning with Spain's Barcelona, Malaga & Granada, Valencia, and the Balearic Islands; the French Riviera and Provence Region's Marseille and Provence, Cannes and St-Tropez, Nice, and the city-state of Monaco; Italy's Genoa, Florence, Pisa, Rome, Naples, Capri, Sicily, Malta, Puglia, and Venice; Croatia's  Split and Dubrovnik; Greece's Athens; and Turkey's Istanbul.For each region and / or city, you'll get capsule information of the place's history, culture, and anything noteworthy about the cuisine or attractions, in addition to the usual color-coded maps, pictures of select attractions, and information on lodging and restaurants.Both the general (e.g., dress codes are more conservative the farther south you go and in most rural areas, and especially in Turkey; few public buildings have restrooms, pp. 272-273) and insider (e.g., what attractions may require advance ticket purchases; Granada is one of the best cities in Spain for free tapas, etc.) tips are very helpful.

Peter Caswell is an assassin sent over to a planet that his handler has dubbed "Duplo" because of its similarities to Earth in terms of physical characteristics and use of "English" as a generally spoken language. Traveling in a spaceship with pre-programmed destination and return routes, Caswell only knows what his handler thinks he needs to know to carry out his super-secret mission: who the target is and a general statement of what the stakes and potential challenges are.Like the advanced spaceship that's transporting him to "Duplo" through a little known "wormhole," Caswell's body has also been enhanced with a few highly sophisticated technological devices -- implants that could temporarily increase his hearing and fighting capabilities, and also make him forget anything connected to a recently concluded mission, including anything unpleasant that may have transpired, such as the number of people he may have had to kill.In a first encounter with his target, Caswell also meets a native "Duplo" woman named Melni, who's actually a spy who's been tracking Caswell's target for about two years.  These two central characters will learn different things about each other that will make them wary of but also concerned for the other.  The knowledge they acquire about interesting similarities and differences between Earth and "Duplo" not only helps drive the pretty good world building that unfolds in this novel, but also introduces a major twist to the plot when they discover that many of those similarities and differences were not coincidental.The novel is reasonably fast-paced and packed with plenty of gory action scenes, a few of which may be needlessly over the top in terms of the degree of spectacularness or violence. Character development is focused mainly on the two central characters. And finally, there are a few surprises that propel the plot in new directions that may not please some readers.

This review is for the Pre de Provence Aromatic, Warm and Spicy, No. 63 Men's (Hair and Body Wash) Shower Gel.This two-in-one hair and body wash lathers well and has a nice scent that lingers on ever so slightly and only for a short while after showering.  I would describe the scent as "woody" and "masculine." My hair and body feel clean after each use.

The silicone kitchen utensils that I received included the following four items:  a "classic" spoon, a slotted spoon, a slotted turner, and a spaghetti spoon. All of them have a sturdy metal core but the exterior is all silicone that is heat-resistant up to 480 degrees fahrenheit.  The "classic" and  slotted spoons are bendable, which can come in handy when you need to scoop things up from a corner. The spaghetti spoon works really well.  My favorite is the slotted turner, which I find to be a lot sturdier than the one I've been using; it is the firmest and least bendable of the four utensils in this set, which is as it should be.The tools are a bit smaller than similar tools I have and my preference, but they are all very good quality.  They are easy to hand-wash, safe for use with non-stick and ceramic cookware, and have the additional convenience of being top-rack dishwasher-safe.

This Ahava mineral hand cream comes in a small, travel-sized package.  The cream has a nice consistency -- not too thick, not watery.  It works quickly but felt a bit greasy.  It has a moderate scent that was not offputting to me, but the scent is not a light one.

This book tells the story of how the CIA's Moscow Station got off to a rocky start and for many years did not even dare recruit any Soviet citizen living in Moscow to spy for it because of the extreme danger involved for both the recruit and the agency with the city under heavy surveillance by the KGB whose headquarters was only a few miles away.That was why when Muscovite Adolf Tolkachev first started making overtures to the Americans, intimating he had military secrets to share, the latter did not "bite" immediately because the overture could have been a trap.  After Tolkachev provided details about himself and what secret information he had access to, however, the CIA changed its stance and made a calculated risk to get engaged, and, boy, were they glad they did.The information that Tolkachev was able to provide to the CIA over several years of espionage -- from 1979 through 1985 --represented a windfall to the CIA's military clients who thought the information was easily worth over a billion of research and development dollars that did not have to be spent.  What was really amazing about this feat was that secrets were being pilfered and Tolkachev was having face to face meetings and exchanging notes and packages with his CIA handlers right where KGB surveillance was supposed to be really tight, and the lack of detection could have continued had the unanticipated events detailed in the book not occurred.The book delves into Tolkachev's self-proclaimed motivation for volunteering to be a spy for the CIA and the attributes that won him the respect of his CIA handlers.  There are detailed accounts of the challenges Tolkachev and his CIA handlers had to overcome, and the changing nature of spycraft during the Cold War years. The book is well written and documented, and reads like a good spy thriller.

All of us have stories to tell, some more interesting than others, and there's also an art to effective storytelling.  In this book on how to produce engaging narrative radiocasts, the creative minds behind seven popular narrative radio shows share their views on how to sift through story ideas, pick ones with interesting possibilities, gather the bits for developing a story, arrange and re-arrange those bits into a desired structure, chisel away most of those bits to retain only the most compelling ones, and add narrative bridges or overlays such as sounds or music to enhance the emotional tone of a radiocast in appropriate places.The information is presented in a comic book format which has advantages (e.g., very suitable for visually depicting some aspects of the creative process such as multiple people providing feedback or editing advice to a writer concurrently) and disadvantages (e.g., a storyboard panel can get crowded with not-so-easy-to-read small texts).  Contentwise, however, the book is well thought out and packed with good tips and helpful examples.

One way to describe this thrilling, mystery-laden fantasy novel is to characterize it as an action-packed tale of aristocratic lunacies that manages to lightly touch upon serious topics such as the unjustness of women's lower standing relative to men's in a patriarchal society, the cruel treatment of the poor by the rich, and the tensions between scientific and faith-based reasoning, while still keeping it a relatively fun read for young adults.The novel's setting is an alternate 19th-century Ireland where the existence of non-procreating machine-animal breeds known as "engimals" are the subject of intense curiosity as mysterious examples of life forms that Darwin's newly expounded theory of evolution cannot account for. Somehow, these "engimals" have some sort of linkage to the Wildensterns whose ancestry goes several centuries back.Gifted with an ability to live very long lives and a physiology that helps them heal quickly, the Wildensterns are obscenely wealthy and powerful, owning properties and businesses in Ireland, Britain, and America.  Edgar, the current patriarch, has three sons designated to succeed him in the following order: Marcus, Roberto, and Nate.  As part of their upbringing, Edgar's heirs have all been taught, before the age of 16, the art of assassination and how to live by the eight "Rules of Ascension" which, aiming to encourage ambition and aggression, two qualities thought critical to the bloodline's continued success, make it perfectly honorable for an heir, 16 years or older, to murder a higher-ranking heir for the sole purpose of advancing one's own ranking.The kind of lunacy this can lead to should be predictable.  In fact, shortly after the novel's opening, readers learn that Marcus has been found dead.  Many suspect that Edgar's youngest son, Nate, having the most to gain from his eldest brother's death, may have assassinated Marcus. Just to make things even more mysterious, when centuries old Wildenstern ancestors suddenly rise from the dead, everyone is suddenly asking: Should Edgar welcome these resurrected ancestors back into the fold, and for what reasons?The tale initially develops at a leisurely pace in the first half of the novel, but the pace picks up significantly after that, with quite a few interesting twists and turns.  The main characters are well-drawn and memorable, and some of the dialogs are witty.  There is some violence, a bit of religious talk, and a brief scene involving a homosexual kiss. If none of these is a big concern, you may want to give this action-packed, well written young adult novel your consideration.

The XSories Camera Mounting System that I received includes the following four items:  * U-Shot orange-colored Telescopic Monopod / Pole that, when fully extended, is about 19 inches long  * small tiltee  * magnetic mount attachment (for stainless steel surfaces)  * suction cup mount attachment (for smooth surfaces, such as glass)(No manuals are included, but how-to instructions and graphic illustrations are printed on the container box.)Both the magnetic and suction cup mount attachments can each support up to about 6 lbs when attached to the types of surfaces they are meant for (indicated in the bullet list above) and the surfaces have to be sufficiently large to provide a stable base for the mounts to "grab" or hold on to.Either the telescopic pole or small tiltee can be screwed to the magnetic or suction cup mount attachments. For maximum flexibility in camera angle positioning, however, you can first screw the small tiltee to the magnetic or suction cup mount attachment, then screw the telescopic pole to the small tiltee (are screws are of the 1/4" universal screw type, and both the telescopic pole and small tiltee have aluminum ball-heads).I used a lightweight compact digital camera to test all mounting set up combinations.  For the magnetic mount attachment, I used the stainless steel lid of my washing machine (A) and the stainless steel edge of a table (B) as my test surfaces.  For the suction cup mount attachment, the test surface was my patio's glass door (C).  All mounting set up combinations were stable and worked excellently with (A) and (C) but not (B), the latter due to the fact that the test surface was not big enough (the magnetic mount attachment by itself attached stably to the test surface, but with the telescopic pole screwed to it, the entire set up did not stay attached to the "smallish" test surface as expected).

The Geoffrey Beene Mens Silk Boxer Short that I received fits me just right.  It is very well constructed and all the stitchings are clean.  The exterior is shinier and softer than the interior. It is also a bit thin, but boy, does it feel comfy and good! Care instructions recommend you hand wash and air dry them.

The DII Home Essentials Reversible Throw Blanket I received has the vibrantly colored Union Jack pattern on one side, and is creamy white on the other side. It is warm, cozy, and soft but not as thick as comparable throws I've owned.  The outer edge stitchings could have been better and "cleaner."

For several years now, the United States of America has been successfully using robotic soldiers, also known as "Tin Men" to police the world's troublespots.  Some countries support this interventionist policy, even contributing financially to it, but many others have come to resent it.Robotic soldiers give the U.S. military several advantages over other countries' militaries.  They are built to have better vision, strength, and speed than their human counterparts, and can survive many forms of attack.  While their synthetic brains do need to be "mapped" to and controlled by the corresponding brain of a trained flesh and blood soldier, the "mapping" process is done through satellite transmissions, so that the flesh and blood soldiers can carry out their missions from fortified remote locations, physically away from the troublespots themselves.  This does not mean that no harm will ever befall the human controllers, however, as members of Platoon A, animating the robotic soldiers patrolling Damascus, Syria from Wiesbaden, Germany, would soon find out.Anarchists who are opposed to America's interventionist policies and want to level the playing field have been gathering information on how to defeat such robotic soldiers and also bring down the human operators linked to them.  When they carry out their plan on the occasion of a summit gathering of G20 heads of states in Athens, Greece, large swaths of the world apparently suddenly go dark, and the U.S. President and Platoon A -- both the robotic and human contingents in Damascus and Wiesbaden, respectively -- find themselves under siege and cut off from all forms of electronic communications.Both the U.S. President and Platoon A have to figure out quickly what's going on in order to respond to the crisis appropriately, and -- more importantly -- to survive.The storytelling seamlessly weaves together how the crisis unfolds in Damascus, Wiesbaden, and Athens. There are "light-touch" subplots involving the romantic feelings of two Platoon A members for each other, two pairs of father and daughter trying to do better by the other, betrayals, and breakdowns.  Some dialogs and plot elements felt very contrived, and despite the author's attempts to humanize as many of the characters as possible, those efforts fell a little bit short relative to the greater focus given to narrating the combat actions and maneuverings. But overall, I still thought the action-packed novel was a good read.

Fast CPU, sensitive full HD touchscreen, good touchpad and backlit keyboard, unusual keys layout, WiFi but no Ethernet, only 2 USBsS7-393 vs. S7-392  The 5th generation Intel (Broadwell) CPU in the S7-393 offers incremental improvements over the S7-392's 4th Generation Intel (Haskell) CPU that should translate to 5-15% faster processing speed and slightly longer battery life.  The S7-393 also has an upgraded Wi-Fi Module that's also incrementally better than the one that's in the S7-392.  Other than these two primary improvements, most everything else in the S7-393 have not really changed all that much compared to the corresponding parts or features in the S7-392.WHAT YOU GET OUT OF THE BOX  For those not familiar with the S7 series at all, the contents include: the ultrabook, a power adaptor, a nice looking sleeve for the ultrabook, and a hardcopy of the  Quick Start Guide, International Travel Warranty Program Guide, and One-Year Limited Warranty agreement / description. (A pdf version of the User Manual must be downloaded from Acer's website if you need it.)  The ultrabook connects you to the internet thru the embedded Wi-Fi module only.  Ethernet dongles or accessories are a separate purchase.  The ultrabook comes with a high-resolution full HD (1920 x 1080) display, multi-touch screen, decent keyboard and touchpad, decent webcam, 8 GB RAM (not expandable to a greater maximum capacity), two mSATA 128 GB SSDs (Solid State Drives) configured into a RAID-0 arrangement so you can only use them as an integrated single drive rather two separate drives (but with the Windows 8.1 OS + other pre-installed software, only about 189 GBs remain free for user use), only two USB 3.0 ports, a Secure Digital (SD) card reader, DC-in jack, headset / speaker jack, one HDMI port, two stereo microphones at the front, two side-speakers, and a proprietary Acer Converter Port that, with the appropriate cable / accessory (apparently, many kinds are available), will allow for easy connection to a LAN, an external display, and / or an additional USB device.  Like most other ultrabooks, this one has no CD / DVD / optical drives.DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION  The S7-393 has the same sleek look as its predecessors. Aluminum is used for the frame and chassis, as well as the entire interior and the screen’s hinges. The lid is covered in a layer of Gorilla Glass, doubled by another one on the other side, on-top of the display. The bottom and the back are made from plastic though.  The ultrabook sits well on the desk, despite resting on tiny rubber feet. One can lift the ultrabook's lid with a single hand to about 90 degrees, but beyond that the hinge stiffens and you’ll need both hands to push the screen further back.  The hinge is designed and constructed to provide steadiness to the computer, so that when the screen is at 90 degrees, you can interact with the touchscreen actively without fear of wobbly unsteadiness that could topple the ultrabook over. The screen can go 180 degrees all the way back, so the entire ultrabook can lie flat against a surface or on your lap.  Once you lift the screen, you’ll notice that there is plenty of space for the keyboard and trackpad, plus a fairly-roomy palm-rest area.  The space above the keyboard all the way through the venting area close to the hinges is kept clear to help with keeping the ultrabook cool.  There is explicit mention in the Quick Start Guide and User Manual not to use a keyboard protector as "the keyboard includes ventilation intakes for cooling," but if you think a keyboard protector may help guard against spills and such, you might want to research this matter further or consult with Acer before purchasing a keyboard protector.  The cooling fans do a very good job without being noisy at all.  The ultrabook does get warm but I've not experienced it getting hot.TOUCHSCREEN, TOUCHPAD, KEYBOARD, and LITHIUM BATTERY  The sensitive touch screen works well, offers full HD (1920 x 1080) display resolution, and supports multi-finger touch [though I have yet to use more than two fingers. :-) ]  The touchpad has been reported to have problems in older S7 iterations, but the S7-393 touchpad has worked relatively well for me.  The Quick Start Guide contains basic information on how to simulate left- and right-mouse clicks as well as how to drag screen objects using the touchpad, while the User Manual provides fuller details regarding all the things you can do with or on the touchpad.  Included in the pre-installed software is an Acer app called "Acer Touch Tool" which you might want to check out. The tool came in handy for me when I needed to do some things such as having to interact with small user interfaces, such as having to check or uncheck a really small checkbox, etc.  The keyboard is light-sensitive (it does this with the help of a sensor).  When room illumination goes down, the individual keys light up.  There are only five rows of keys in the keyboard -- the function keys are not on a row by themselves, and there is no separate numeric key pad; instead the numbers and function keys are combined together, and to get access to a particular function, you need to simultaneously press a combination sequence (for example, the "Fn" key + the "F2" key to get to the BIOS Setting Utility Screen).  There are also some other unusual key placements, like the ~ placed just near the CapsLock key or the Del placed on the bottom row near the Right Alt. There’s also no right CTRL key.  So there's definitely a learning curve involved to get used to the unusual keyboard layout, but otherwise, the keys themselves have a good tactile feel to them.  Most users would not be able to easily replace or change the lithium battery themselves.  Depending on display brightness and task intensiveness, I've been able to get 6-7 hours of continuous work done from a single full battery charge (Acer rates battery life to be up to 10 hours, but I haven't had a chance to do that kind of very long test yet).PERFORMANCE  The S7-393's 5th Generation Intel (Broadwell) CPU is rated 5-15% more efficient than the S7-392's Fourth Generation Intel (Haskell) CPU. The use of SSD as the storage device enables fast boot ups.  Upon opening the ultrabook's lid just after shutting down the ultrabook and closing down the lid, the computer starts up again really fast (within 3-5 seconds).  The S7-393 makes use of sensors to constantly check for start up signals, but you can turn off this "Fast Startup" setting if you wish to save battery life a little bit (instructions are in the User Manual, but essentially you go to Control Panel's Power Options >> Choose What the Power Buttons Do >> Change settings that are currently unavailable >> Scroll down and disable the Turn on Fast Startup option checkbox.)  Even after disabling "Turn on Fast Startup," the computer still starts up relatively fast (within 10 seconds).  The Broadwell CPU includes improved integrated graphics processing, so graphics applications work just fine.  The two stereo microphones and side speakers work very well.  You get very good sound quality.SOFTWARE  The S7-393 ships with Windows 8.1 and other pre-installed software, leaving just about 189GB of SSD space available for user use.  Windows "legacy" or "accessory" software such as Notepad, Paint, and Windows Media Player are included, but none of the Microsoft Office apps are (there's a utility screen to request trial versions but I didn't make such a request).  There is a little bit of "bloatware" but not much, and most of them are either cloud-centric apps (such as abDocs, abFile) or utilily apps from Acer.  Because I don't have a need for AcerCloud, I deleted the cloud-centric apps but not the utility apps.  Four of the Acer Utility apps are potentially useful.  They are: Acer Touch Tool (already mentioned above), Acer Screen Capture / Grasp Tool, Energy Management Tool, and Acer Quick Access Tool.  The Acer Screen Capture / Grasp Tool lets you capture a full screen or portions of it to the clip board, Acer Scrapbook (not installed, but free download), or well-known media-sharing sites.  The tool also lets you edit the captured images in basic ways before sharing them.  The Acer Energy Management Tool tells you which running apps seem to be draining battery life most.  The Acer Quick Access Tool provides conveniences such as turning Wi-Fi on or off, specifying whether start up should go to Desktop or Apps mode, etc.
