A stabbing pain jolting her awake, the novel's narrator discovers she's trapped inside a coffin, with curved bars restraining her wrists, ankles, and hips.  One of the first thoughts that comes to her is that she should not be waking up like this on her 12th birthday. She screams for help but no one comes. After several struggles, she frees herself. Climbing out of her coffin, she finds the clothes she's wearing much too tight for her body, making her question whether they are hers. Looking around, she finds there are other coffins in the room.  Then she hears a cry.  Locating the coffin where the cry is coming from, she helps get the lid off the coffin.  The newly freed stands taller than her, looks like a beautiful adult female, but like her, is only twelve. Others they help free from their coffins have the same strange story to tell:  They don't know who or where they are, other than they're all celebrating their twelfth birthdays.  They all look like they have the body of an adult though, and they are all strangely beautiful.The narrator speculates that the names etched on their coffins must be their names.  She takes on "M. Savage" as her name, and by virtue of the fact that she was the first to wake up and help free the others from their coffins, she is made de facto leader.  Her first decision is to get everyone out of the creepy room they're in, always going straight and upward, reasoning that always going straight will make retracing their way back easier than if they include turns, and going upward is more likely to lead to a place where there is light than going downward, which could also be an endless descent.Every decision she makes will have consequences, some greater than she would immediately know.  There will be dissents and challenges to her leadership, but the more these arise, the more she grows determined to hold on to her decision-making role because she can't seem to see any better alternative to her.The pacing of the plot is slower in the initial two-thirds than the last third of the novel. Whereas the first two-thirds of the novel delves a little bit into the world-building and some needed character development, the last third of the novel takes the world-building into an entirely different direction by crystallizing the overwhelming odds against M. Savage and her ilk.  Suddenly, we get explanations for many of the strangeness regarding M. Savage and her ilk, but as soon as these revelations are made, we find them in a desperate do-or-die situation.The first installment in a planned trilogy, this novel builds a good foundation for the subsequent installments, which I think have the potential to be even more interesting than this first one, because many possibilities have suddenly opened up. Even though the characters in this installment share some similarities, they are reasonably distinct and interesting in their own rights.  The M. Savage character is reasonably fleshed out in this novel, but there is more to learn about her as well as those other characters who are close to her.  The world-building and the plotting are all just fine, so overall, this planned trilogy is off to a good start.

This Logitech Conference Cam is easy to setup and use.  All I had to do was turn on the cam device and connect it to my Windows 8.1 computer via the included USB cable.  Once plugged in to my computer, any required device drivers are automatically downloaded and installed.I used Skype to test videoconferencing.  As long as the lighting level is good, the video quality will be good.  Four to six people sitting in a small table can all be readily seen and heard clearly on the other end.  The camera has pan/tilt and zoom in/out capabilities, and the controls for those are in the camera itself, as well as the remote control which also doubles as a cover for the camera to help keep dust away when the device is not in use.The two microphones built into the device can pick up sound 360 degrees within a diameter range up to 12 feet, so there's no need to huddle close to the device in order to be heard clearly.You can pair a bluetooth-enabled music player to the device to play music through the device.If you have an HDMI cable to connect the cam device to a TV or display, you can put the cam device into a "screen mirroring" mode.  In such a mode, you can connect a Miracast-enabled smartphone to the cam device, and whatever is showing on your smartphone display will also be mirrored in the bigger display connected to the cam device.  Not all smartphones are Miracast-enabled, however, so if this "screen-mirroring" capability is really important to you, check first if you have a Miracast-enabled smartphone that can be used with this cam device.

In the process of narrating Taylor Wilson's journey from shy precocious child determined to build a portable nuclear fusion reactor in his grandma's garage before reaching the age of 15, to self-confident, gregarious, and award-winning young scientist whose practical but very useful nuclear device inventions have been winning him admirers worldwide young and old, Mr. Clynes manages to not only get us to cheer for young Taylor's successes, but also to help us comprehend at a layperson's level the science behind Mr. Wilson's inventions, as well as the challenges faced by young Taylor's parents, Tiffany (who's a yoga instructor) and Kenneth (who owns and runs a soft drink bottling company), in deciding how to support Taylor's interests while remaining mindful that they don't have the scientific background to properly vet safety concerns related to the projects Taylor was pursuing.Comparing and contrasting the decisions made by Kenneth and Tiffany with those made by the parents of David Hahn, another teenager who also wanted to build a nuclear reactor, Mr. Clynes observed that Hahn's scientist parents' fear for his safety led them to forbid the youngster from pursuing that interest, but that decision only pushed him to pursue his interests clandestinely; whereas the Wilsons' support for their first born involved finding mentors for Taylor, who eventually thrived, the Hahns' fear-based decision led to some unfortunate results.According to Mr. Clynes, research has shown that after parental support, a child's early school environment is the next most critical in a gifted child's development.  Mr. Clynes laments that, despite the common knowledge that children don't learn at the same pace, our educational system is mostly a one-size-fits-all system, where most schools are not finding creative ways to help gifted children reach their potential, unlike the special schools that the Wilsons were able to find for Taylor, and his younger brother Joey, who's exceptional at mathematics.Mr. Clynes asserts that while it is true that schools would need additional funding to find creative ways to help gifted children grow to their potential, there is also an economic cost -- perhaps an even greater one -- if we fail to develop talents to stay competitive in a post-industrial global stage.  Furthermore, for gifted children programs to really succeed, they must not neglect the child's social and emotional development, and there must be a concerted outreach to economically disadvantaged families who may lack the resources that wealthier families have to advocate effectively for their gifted offsprings.

A lot of work and thought went into the presentation of information in this book, which gives a very good overview of and explains business concepts and processes in easy to digest nuggets, and keeps discussions interesting with the help of real-life examples and very good graphics and visualizations.The topics discussed include: forming a company, raising capital, product development and marketing, management strategies, tracking revenue, financial reporting, and legal, social, and environmental responsibilities.

Most of the short stories in this fine collection are either love stories of sorts or tales of World War II experiences, especially of Hungarian Jews'.  The latter include tales of dissident musicians, and a few are inspired by the author's own family history, in which the grandmother or grandfather in the story is memorialized with fondness.Quite a few of the stories have quirky characters.  My favorite is the one telling the story of how a much younger Cristophe Chapman -- who's found fame as a photographer punching famous artists in the face with one hand while capturing their reactions with a camera held in the other hand -- came into 50 year old artist Francisco Ling's life at the height of the AIDS Crisis in the 1980s just when the latter really needed someone.  Although Francisco's friends worried that Chapman may only be using Ling to further his own career, it was actually Ling who pulled a surprise on everyone, and Chapman's response to that surprise is both poignant and impactful.The stories in this collection are all very well written but some may be easier to relate to than others.

I tested this Life N Soul BM101 IPX4-rated Water Resistant Bluetooth Speaker by pairing it to my bluetooth-equipped computer, which succeeded easily.  I then played some music and was pleased that even though this is a compact pocket-sized speaker, the sound / audio quality is quite good and I can crank up the volume such that I can hear the music well in the next room. The only problem I've experienced is that the music occasionally skips.  When fully charged, the rechargeable built-in lithium battery can provide up to approximately 2.5 hours of continuous operation.

This well written book provides a broad examination of different areas in which our justice system can be improved to make it more "just," including:* Initial assessment of whether a crime has occurred where focusing on the wrong things could lead first responders to jump to erroneous conclusions* the undue weight that could be given to confessions extracted possibly with the use of questionable techniques* the use of eyewitness testimony that psychologists have found to be vulnerable to many kinds of problems* the emphasis on "winning" rather than the "search for truth" in our adversarial legal system that could incentivize the prosecution team to not share information with the defense team that could benefit the latter's client(s)* the focus on "punitiveness" rather than "rehabilitation" in our prison systemUsing different sources of information such as psychological studies of eyewitness testimony reliability, or look-backs into cases where convictions were overturned due to the more recent use of DNA evidence on appeals or reopened trials to learn how the justice system failed the innocent people in question (many of whom tended to have mental disorders or low levels of education), the author helps readers understand where, how, and why miscarriages of justice could occur.Many of the author's proposals on what we can do to make our justice system more "just" sound reasonable. Examples:  Why not digitize all case information and documents and store them in a repository that would be accessible to anyone working on a given case, including staff from both the prosecution and defense teams? Why not use video footages instead of relying on eyewitness testimonies whenever possible?Comparing and contrasting how our legal and prison systems work relative to other, mostly European, countries' systems, the author also highlights how those countries' emphasis on prosecution and defense teams partnering together to better understand what really transpired in a given situation lays a better foundation for focusing on how to help with the rehabilitation of non-violent offenders than our adversarial legal and punitive prison systems, and the lower rates of recidivism in those countries seem to provide evidence that their approaches seem to be working better than ours and might be worth adapting or at least studying further.

This novel tells the story of three young men -- Wintric Ellis, Armando Torres, and Big Dax -- who joined the military very early on in their lives because of a perceived lack of attractive good choices available to them, only to return home in much worse shape because of the tragic events that occurred while they were serving in Afghanistan.The novel opens with the more experienced Dax and Torres helping new recruit Ellis get through his nervousness while watching over local Afghans streaming into a makeshift clinic for medical attention and being on guard against suspicious behaviors.  This opening chapter is ominously entitled "Be Polite but Have a Plan to Kill Everyone You Meet."The chapter is then followed by flashbacks into the men's teenage years delving into the kind of rut they were all in before they signed up to join the military. Those chapters are a bit too long but they do show what kind of a support system they had prior to joining the military.The third person narration then switches back to Afghanistan and the tragic events that they get ensnared in and would weigh on their mind for many, many years, which the remainder of the novel delves into.In my opinion, of the three characters, Dax is the least fleshed out one; Torres has the most interesting backstory; and Ellis experiences the most difficulty coming to terms with what happened in Afghanistan. What makes these three men's stories especially poignant is that, despite finding strong and supportive wives, all three of them could not completely open up to their wives regarding what happened in Afghanistan.  Experiencing new misfortunes, they sink deeper in despair. Fortunately, hope comes to at least one of them.The storytelling drags on a little bit, but the writing is fine otherwise.

This novel is the first installment in an epic fantasy series inspired by real figures and events that played important parts in the rise of the Han Empire in Chinese history.  The reimagined story is infused with mythology, and takes place in the Islands of Dara, which were created from the solidified lava tears of Goddess Daramea as she gave birth to eight children, who would later stake claims to different parts of the islands. Ever since then, the fates of the islands' inhabitants became inextricably bound with the doings and undoings of the goddess' deity children.For centuries, back before the so-called Xana Conquest, the various island states vied for dominance. They were in a constant state of war and shifting alliances. When King Reon of Xana came to power and defeated all of his rivals, he ruled the unified islands with an iron fist as Emperor Mapidere.  Although his rule brought about some good changes to his subjects' lives, many more of his and his minions' actions and decisions caused deaths and sufferings, and in time, some of his subjects would find the courage to rise up against him.The two subjects who would find the most success at opposing Mapidere are Kuni Garu, a commoner who is street-smart, kind-hearted, and can seemingly talk his way out of any predicament but who has also displeased his family for seemingly throwing his life away preferring to live as a drifter rather than finishing his education or working for his older brother, and Mata Zyndu, the last descendant of a noble unjustly murdered by Mapidere and Kuni Garu's polar opposite: tall, brawny and skilled in martial arts, with very rigid notions of what constitutes bravery, loyalty, justice, and honor.When Kuni and Mata first meet, they take to each other immediately, calling each other "brother." Fighting Mapidere's men together initially, they enjoy many successes. Then a misunderstanding happens and drives a wedge between them.  They drift apart, and eventually, their differing temperaments and ideologies lead them to become rivals, attracting different kinds of recruits to their respective causes.  More heterogeneous and inclusive than Mata's recruits, Kuni's recruits include bandits, women, and former soldiers with different kinds of disabilities. With Daramea's deity children also taking sides, Kuni's and Mata's power struggles take many twists and turns.The storytelling delves into the various strategies and tactics employed by Kuni and / or Mata, which include the use of: brute force, deception, psychological warfare, sci-fi type of airships and weapons, majestic whales, Trojan-Horse-type of contraptions for surprise attacks, etc.The world-building is excellent. The prose includes some beautiful sayings and constructions.  The cast of characters is huge and reasonably interesting, with new characters getting introduced (then sometimes getting killed immediately) even up to the last quarter of the novel, but only few of the many characters that have significant screen time are fleshed out.  The ending is conclusive, and doesn't really leave any loose ends, except for the questions of how the surviving characters would further evolve or devolve, and what further adventures or misadventures await them.

The DII Oceanique Shower Curtain and Bathroom Rug set that I received have a pink color that is not the most neutral color to have for a bathroom, but they look and feel just fine for a starter set.  The shower curtain's chevron design is tasteful, and while the button holes do not have grommet rings, they are, nevertheless, reinforced well. The included 12 color-coordinated shower hooks are rust proof and hold the 72" x 72" curtain well. The 16" x 24" bathroom mat has a non-skid backing and the design looks fine.  Both shower curtain and bathroom rug appear well made (i.e., stitchings are clean, etc.) and they are machine washable. Liner for the shower curtain is not included.

This history book provides detailed behind-the-scene accounts of what was happening in Russia in the years leading up to and immediately after World War I, including:*  Russia's humiliating defeat by Japan in the 1904 to 1905 Russo-Japanese War;*  How the shock of that defeat contributed to the Russian Revolution of 1905, which in turn caused Tsar Nicholas II to issue the October Manifesto promising limited government reforms but in fact failed to address the social problems that years later would boil up again;*  How the same defeat spurred Tsar Nicholas II to pour money into reforming and rebuilding the military at the expense of other domestic programs;*  How Russia's military buildup did not sit well with Germany and Austria especially when viewed in light of their rivalry for control of the Balkan states and other Eastern European concerns; and*  How war between Russia and the German-Austrian alliance came about in 1914 and why the costs to Russia included the downfall of the monarchy that ended the Romanov Dynasty and also opened the door to Bolshevik rule of Russia.In addition to providing insights into the conflicting personalities and ideologies of factional leaders with influence in the conduct of government and foreign relation affairs, the author also makes interesting comparisons and contrasts of military and citizen support for the Russian state during the Napoleonic Wars and World Wars I and II, and discusses the lessons learned.  The author's musings regarding several what-if scenarios are also interesting.Some of the details shared felt like minutiae that when edited out could have made the book less dry and easier to read, but otherwise, the analyses and insights provided are valuable.

These Medline VEN6025 blue latex gloves are fairly thick and big.  They're rated "one size fits most" but, in my opinion, they'll fit bigger hands better than smaller hands.  The extra long cuff provides protection against splashes or things like garden soil getting down into the glove.  The textured fingers make it easier to grip objects.  The strength and thickness of these gloves make them suitable for heavy duty use, but if you tend to use them only for, say, gardening or cleaning dishes or bathrooms, these gloves -- which come 30 in a box -- can definitely be used more than once.

This well made and constructed DII Insulated Casserole Carrier can be used for transporting casseroles up to 15" x 3" x 9.75" (approximate WxHxD) in size.  The heavy duty canvas polyester appears durable, but the insulation is a bit thinner than I would have liked.  For both hot and cold items, the holding time is only about 60-90 minutes.

These freeze-dried apple slices have only three listed ingredients: apple, ground cinnamon, and citric acid.Each 6 ounce can contains about six servings, with each serving consisting of about 35 slices.  The slices can be eaten right out of the can without additional preparation, but if you rehydrate them, you can use them to make an apple crisp or pie.  I helped myself to several pieces after opening the can with a can opener, and I wasn't disappointed.  The slices were crunchy, sweet, and tasty.  Each one ounce or 28 gram serving contains about 20g of sugar, so that might be a concern to some, but each serving also gives you about 3g of dietary fiber, 1 g of protein, and small amounts of Vitamins A and C, calcium, and iron.Mountain House food products are shelf-stable.  The can I received had a Best Used By Date of October 2039.  Once open, however, the can's contents are best consumed immediately.  The instructions do mention, however, that if you reseal the can with the included plastic lid and refrigerate the food product, the contents should be in acceptable condition for up to one week after opening.

My overall rating for this product is 4.5 stars (loads of really nice features, few limitations but many can be fixed with firmware updates)This Sony FDR X1000V action cam is palm-sized and weighs only about 4 ounces (with the included NP-BX1 battery installed). It comes housed in a 33'-rated underwater casing that is easy to unlock, but even without this casing, the camera is rated IPX4 splash-proof, water- and dust-resistant. The rest of the base product bundle includes: a flat and a curved adhesive mount, a 23" micro-to-standard-USB cable for connecting the camera to a computer (and also in-camera battery charging), a Startup Guide, and a Reference / Specification Guide.  At the time of this review, there was only an online version of the Help or User Guide (not even a downloadable PDF).This action cam can be used to take videos or photos.  The f/2.8 lens is located on the narrow side of the camera, so when shooting something in front of you, the long side of the camera's body will most likely have to be oriented perpendicular to you, with the lens facing what you're trying to capture.  The camera's base contains a standard tripod / monopod mount, and a stereo microphone sits below the camera's lens.Menu navigation is done via pressing the "PREV" or "NEXT" button in combination with the "REC/ENTER" button. The LED Display located on one of the camera's long sides (same side as the "PREV" and "NEXT" buttons) is for displaying current mode or settings information only.  There is no View Finder, but with an Android or iPhone version of Sony's PlayMemories Mobile [PMM] app installed on your smartphone or tablet, you can use the latter device(s) as some sort of a view finder as well as to remotely control the action cam, including changing camera modes and settings (you can also purchase the more expensive product bundle that includes Sony's Live View Remote, or purchase just the latter separately;  but since I don't have the Live View Remote, I can't comment on it further except to say that I don't have a need for it currently, because I'm able to do everything I want to do just using my Android and the PMM app.)The X1000V lets you select recording movies in either XAVC S (Sony's efficient codec) or MP4 formats. 4K recording is offered a resolution of 3,840x2,160 and only in XAVC S; selectable frame rates are 30/24p at 100Mbps or 24p at 60Mbps.XAVC S recording is also available at bitrates of:* 50Mbps (1080/60/30/24p)* 60Mbps (1080/120p or 720/240p)* 100Mbps (1080/120p or 720/240p)MP4 recording is available at:* 1080/60/30p* 720/30/120p* 480/240p4K recording at 100Mbps requires at least a 64GB microSDXC card with a UHS-I U3 or better rating, such as Sony 64GB microSDXC High Speed Memory Card (ASIN: B00ND1LN7M).Electronic image stabilization, which compensates for camera shake, is a built-in feature of the X1000V that's lacking in the GoPro.  However, this feature does not yet work with 4K recording mode, and with image stabilization turned on, the camera's field angle can only be at 120 degrees (with image stabilization turned off, the field angle can be as wide as 170 degrees).With an aperture of f/2.8, the camera's ZEISS lens works very well in low light situations.The built-in stereo mic comes with a wind noise reduction capability that's settable from the menu.The camera's loop recording feature lets you record video continuously, preserving the last 5, 20, 60, or 120 minutes of footage - depending on setting. As soon as something important happens, you can commit the duration of the loop permanently to memory and continue recording seamlessly. There is an "Unlimited" mode that will fill up the remaining free space on the memory card. During loop recording, any previously recorded material never gets overwritten.Manual settings on the FDR-X1000V include:* Auto Exposure Control: 2.0, 1.7, 1.3, 1.0, 0.7, 0.3, 0.0* White Balance: Auto, Color-Temp (2500 to 9900K selectable), One PushYou can take pictures leisurely one picture at a time, or shoot multiple pictures using interval recording or burst shooting modes.While video quality can be excellent, still image / photo quality tends to be just very good.Sony rates the battery life at 115 minutes with continuous recording for 1080p, and 50 minutes for 4K, which jibe with my experience.While in-camera menu navigation and setting / configuration tweaking can require quite a few frustrating button presses stepping through unrelated menu items in order to get to the relevant ones, the use of the above-mentioned PlayMemories Mobile app with a mobile device can not only make setting / configuration tweaking easier, but also provides the following additional conveniences: navigate to the online Help Guide for the X1000V if the web is available, and switch to the included Highlight Movie Maker software to create highlight clips for web sharing, perform basic editing, and view and / or delete the saved media files.

The Soybu Levity Short Sleeve Shirt that I received appears to be made of quality material and is very well made. The stitchings are very clean and the neckline does not contain anything such as a tag that can be bothersome to some.The shirt is made of lightweight fabric that is 91% Polyester and 9% Spandex.  The spandex gives the shirt a stretchiness that supports freer arm movements and makes the shirt comfortable to wear, and the fabric's moisture wicking capability can help keep perspiration or sweat away from your body.The manufacturer recommends washing the shirt in cold temperature and low-temperature drying.

In addition to learning many fascinating things about hummingbirds, including their amazing capabilities and a few urban myths about them, I also enjoyed reading the various little stories surrounding each rescued hummingbird -- where and how they were found, who the rescuer(s) were (which included compassionate cats and kids), and the unselfishness of some of the more "heroic" rescuers who were willing to go the few extra figurative and / or literal miles to get the birds to the author for rehab help.Readers get to find out how the author got started as a volunteer hummingbird rehabilitator, the hard work involved in being one, the many times the author had to play "psychotherapist" to both distraught and frightened rescuers and birds, and the attributes and personalities of the birds she had christened "Gabriel," "Pepper," "Chucky," "Brad," and "Iris" that made them unforgettable to her and taught her different things about the caring of injured hummingbirds.The book is very well written. The author's and some of the rescuers' slightly whacky but endearing personalities come through very clearly.  Not all of the rescued hummingbirds can be nursed back to health, but every time one of them complete rehab, which takes -- on average -- about two months of tender loving care, and soars to the air after being released back to the wild, you can't help but cheer not just for the nursed-back-to-good-health hummingbird but also the author and the people who worked with her to make it happen: seemingly ordinary people performing out-of-the-ordinary acts of kindness.

This book delves into the personality and ideological clashes between two political figures, Jawaharlal Nehru and Mohammad Ali Jinnah, who later became the political leader of post-World War II India and Pakistan, respectively, and how their lack of trust and respect for each other drove them to make costly mistakes, with consequences that still reverberate today, and pit the two neighboring countries against each other, with no end in sight to their enmity.This well written book will help readers understand the historical roots of the enmity between India and Pakistan, the depth of this enmity and why it has not subsided, why Kashmir is still a disputed region, the role played by Pakistan in the rise of the Talibans in Afghanistan, and how Pakistan became a U.S. foreign aid recipient.The book contains many graphic accounts of Muslims killing Hindus and Sikhs, and Hindus and Sikhs killing Muslims solely because of fear and hatred, or for vengeance.  Except for a brief mention in the epilogue of a potential way to resolve the Kashmir dispute between the two countries, the book does not really address how the now nuclear powers can rise above the deadly legacy of India's partition into predominantly Muslim Pakistan and predominantly Hindu India.

The main takeaway from this short but well-written book is that if your organization is not constantly looking to recognize emerging new realities in order position itself to benefit from them, then your organization risks losing out to more agile and proactive competitors who are able to scale up on the new endeavor very quickly and may leave your organization in the dust.Being left in the dust is what the author calls a "structural" risk that organizations can attempt to address by cultivating leaders who can develop their:* Perceptual acuity, or ability to pick up "bend in the road" signals* Mind set to see opportunity in uncertainty* Ability to see a new path forward and commit to it* Adeptness in managing the transition to the new path* Skill in making the organization steerable and agileCase studies of organizations with leaders who succeeded or failed to step up their game with respect to the five bulleted points above are provided, along with the appropriate post-mortems or lessons learned.Readers familiar with the SWOT (Strengths-Weaknesses-Opportunities-Threats) analytical method would recognize some of the author's recommendations on how organizations can stay on top on their game (e.g., the first three bullet points above involve the analyses of opportunities and threats, while the last three involve a commitment to recalibrating an organization's strengths and weaknesses as needed), but some of the recommendations do go beyond the analysis of SWOT, making the discourse in this book a good and welcomed contribution.

The All Clad 100% Cotton Kitchen Towel that I received has a creamy color, and is large, attractive, well-made, and very absorbent.  It looks and feels plush, and the cross-hatch pattern and creamy color are neutral enough that it should easily find a place in any kitchen.

Vansky Pets Ultra Violet Urine Detector Dog/Cat Stain Remover Fluorescent Whitening Agents Detector, UV Blacklight Flashlight, Find Dry Stains on Carpets, Rugs, Curtains & Fabrics. 3 x AAA Batteries Included & InsertedReview from Jeannie’s Product Reviews This has batteries included – a real bonus, as its awful getting something new and then having to hunt round or “steal” batteries from another device! works best in the dark and made me feel I was back in the 70’s where every disco/live band venue has these lights. We girls all learned not to wear white bras unless we wanted lots of attention! and the poor guys with dandruff.....Still, how well does it work? We haven’t any pets now ( except Muska the horse and she doesn’t come indoors, much though she’s love to. If she did we wouldn’t need a urine detector – they pee pints and it would be pretty obvious!) However my daughters two dogs are here frequently though, and Flash has just stayed a few days with Him Indoors while we all went to Center Parcs. He didn’t think Flash had peed, we couldn’t smell anything but it was good to have it confirmed. What I did discover though was that though I thought the bathroom was clean – I was playing around with the torch and decided to check – it’s got a horrible amount of stains I didn’t see. I know they aren’t pee stains as they were round the bath and shower, and the sink and back spalsh, we’d need to be acrobats to pee up there! Clearly it picks up soap scum and lime scale or something too, but I was so shocked that our bathroom looked liked something off Grime busters! In normal light it looks fine, and I do clean it but I guess its time to get the steamer out again....didn’t dare try the kitchen surfaces, I’ll do that After the steamer has been round.If you’ve a house proud and supercilious relative or acquaintance you want to put down then visit with one of these! Or of course if you simply want to root out pet pee stains and target the neutraliser....If it doesn't seem to work then check the batteries are in correctly. I put them in without checking and  one was wrong way round...I guess it's that usually its 2 or 4 and I automatically put the next in the other way up without thinking, and of course three means two adjacent ones same way round.Stars: Five, but remember it shows up other stains too, not just pee, before you get a heart attack at what's revealed.Product supplied for review  If you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why so I can improve the usefulness of future reviews.

Erofa 48 Color Art Colour Pencils Drawing Pencils, for Secret Garden Pencil Pouch colored pencil Artist Sketch SetReview from Jeannie’s Product Reviews As an artist I’m always interesting in art equipment so was delighted to get these for review. There’s been a recognition recently that adults find colouring relaxing and there are several books aimed at adults with beautiful complex images ready to colour. These would work perfectly with one of those for a gift for a stressed adult for xmas! They look elegant in a simple silver colour with hexagonal design, and I feel that makes them easier to grip than round pencils. They are easy to sharpen and have an anti break formula. That’s good, sharpening a pencil only to find it snaps two minutes later is very frustrating! I like too that they are “Professional crafted with recycled wood, which is environmentally friendly and non- toxic”.  Anything that helps the environment is a bonus IMO.  There’s a huge range of colours and of course by using techniques such as blending and crosshatching you can create an infinite numbers of variables. As well as the pencils, this set includes a great carry case, in a sturdy soft fabric with elasticated inserts for each pencil and a couple of spares for an eraser of ruler maybe? Makes them perfect for taking out of the home for outside sketching, for school and college.  I found them easy to use creating both sharp edge effects and sideways for large cover. I’ve shown in a diagram below a quick ad hoc  experiments I did with a  couple of these.Stars: Five, terrific gift for others or yourself!Product supplied for review

On Our Own Terms  Adelaide HipwellReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance,I like second chance romance and rock band romance so this was a no brainer, and I expected to enjoy it. And I did, but it didn’t quite have that magic spark I was hoping for that makes a five star read for me. Its a well deserved Four though and a story I was drawn into.One of the things I really liked was that Harriet wasn’t some poor downtrodden waitress/bar tender/shopworker living in squalid conditions etc. waiting to be rescued by the Hero, (they have their place of course but sometimes its good to read about other types). Nope, she was incredibly clever, and had made millions through the sale of her apps technology. Money doesn’t bring happiness though and poor Harriet was devastated, gutted, had all her confidence sapped when her long time boyfriend and business partner is caught cheating...She leaves Australia and goes to stay for a while in LA with her sister and family, the adorable twins, lovely husband and Bitch Face and Sour Puss the pets. Their next door neighbour is none other than grown up teen boy band sensation Ned.I loved Ned, he was such a gorgeous man, very natural and down to earth.  He was tired of all the promo stuff they went through, tired of the hype and the pressure that led to one of the band members to attempt suicide and his feelings of guilt for not doing more. The guys from 4G are still close friends though, and we see all of them here in this book, see them grown up, pursuing other things but those teen pressures still affect them all. Ned’s attracted to Harriet instantly ( I LOVED their meeting where one of the twins was...well, read it!!), but oddly though they are both successful people they each think they’re not good enough for the other – its that old thing that haunts many of us, confidence, do we have what’s needed, can that special someone really want to be with us, when they are surrounded by people more successful, more intelligent, more handsome/beautiful, thinner/better body....nearly everyone has hang-ups about themselves somewhere, and sometimes they play on our minds too much.They spend more and more time together, we see more of Harriet’s and her sister’s friends and the rest of 4G, and its a fun read. Usual spats with the media – they so annoy me the way they haunt celebrities, intrude on their privacy, but sadly those images sell and that’s why people suffer – why do people want to see private pictures, believe all the lies....? Still, it provides some great plots for the book, and adds that touch of realism that I so need. I really liked Ned and Harriet, thought they were perfect for each other, but they seemed to have not only their own inner voices to overcome but outside pressures too. Its a story I really enjoyed, and I loved the way the band used their celebrity and the things that had happened to them to support a much needed cause. I spoke about realism earlier – that part felt very genuine, and sadly I can imagine just that happening today. I feel for some of the young celebrities around, surrounded by those who just want to make money from them and aren’t at all concerned about them as people, about their welfare or health. This part of the plot was all too real but Adelaide turns it to the good in the end. Overall there’s a fabulous blend of romance and humour here with some wonderful one liners and snark, and I really want to read more from Adelaide. Its an excellent start for her writing career with this first novel.  Stars: Four, a terrific first book.ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Breaking Hearts, Full Hearts book 4,   by M.J.SummersReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, I liked the little we saw of Trey in an earlier book, and of course that bombshell, that he was the father of Gabriella’s baby! Now circumstances have changed, and he needs to bring his son home. Out in Brazil he finds its not so easy, he’s no money, no job and the Brazilians want to see proof he can support toddler Tomas before they’ll give permission for him to leave.Alessandra has been looking after Tomas while completing her Law studies, and agrees to continue to help Trey with him. She knows Tomas will leave soon and wants to spend as much time as she can with him, she’s been his main caregiver and loves the little boy.Its a great story potentially but somehow it didn’t live up to the promise for me. Its well written, had good plots that expand the main story and yet ...I just felt kind of underwhelmed, a bit bored at times, wanting to get to the end and find out what happens rather than enjoying the journey there :-( Trey and Alessandra were a great couple, but at times both seemed so juvenile, so young and stubborn. It wasn’t hard to see what was going to happen and I need to be taken by surprise, not see what’s coming a mile off. Its a good read, just for me not a great one.Stars: Three, a good read but nothing to get excited about for me. ...ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

I Do, A.J. PineReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, New AdultWell this is part of a series, but each book is complete and can be read as a stand alone. Having said that I’d not read the earlier ones and I think I’d have got more from this if I had. There is brief backstory info given where needed but I just didn’t really get a sense of the people they were and what was important to them as individuals. Clearly they’ve had some issues but are a close group of friends.Its told from multiple points of view ( seven!) – I like that, but it did mean a lot of jumping from person to person in quite a short novel ( 2330 kindle locations) so there’s no space for really getting into anything in real depth.What appeals to me about the New Adult genre is the drama and emotion  books usually have but its all very surface based light and fluffy here...and I missed the angst, the sadness, the drama that makes the happy parts all the sweeter.It’s a fun read though, with a HEA for everyone and some great characters. If you want short, light and fun this is perfect.Stars: Three, a good read if you’ve followed the series and want a perfect ending for the couples. ...ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Tell Me You Need Me,  Joya Ryan Review from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, I've loved some of Joya's novels but this one just didn't work for me. Having an ARC of this info re length wasn't available and I didn't know that it's a novella at just under 2200 kindle locations. Sadly for me novella's rarely work. If I know in advance I try to avoid them but this time I didn't :-( Chloe came over as a bit brash and in-your-face to me. I've no issues about someone knowing what they want and going for it, but her reasons for avoiding romance seemed just weird, and I didn't really understand them. Likewise her compulsion to make her mum's cafe/restaurant a sucess as it was when mum ran it - why? Maybe if the book had been longer I'd have more background and understood her and her motives better. I felt the same about Gage - his intransigence about his job, his refusal to consider that maybe if he could persuade Chloe into a romance, a relationship - which was what he wanted, she'd want more than to be just waiting around for when he decided to return, and be happy when he was off for weeks at a time again was to me just plain selfish. When they are together there are some very erotically charged sex scenes, but to me that's it, just lust, and I never felt more emotionally between them. Sex is fine in a story - in fact in a good romance I enjoy it, but here I felt it was All the story, that for me there was little else except some hot and sensual sex scenes, and I need a solid story backing them up to enjoy them. I actually skipped many of them, looking for more between Chloe and Gage, looking for some kind of connection, some indications of more. Its a short novel anyway, timewise as well as length, only covering a few weeks so I guess that's again why I didn't really have the chance to get to know them and what made them the characters they are. Sadly its a book that's a pass for me, will still look out for more of Joya's excellent stories but this one hasn't hit the spot. Stars: Two, hot sex but not much else for me.  ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Eggsnow Travel Backpack Daypack, Lightweight, Ultra-Large Capacity, Waterproof Packable Backpacks, Perfect for Camping, Hiking, Climbing and TravelReview from Jeannie’s Product ReviewsThe UK have just introduced a bag charge (which I think is great, save all that plastic in landfill) so this backpack is a great buy. Its waterproof, folds into a tiny pouch with a zip that can be easily tucked in a pocket, and is perfect for carrying around so you’ve always somewhere to put purchases. It’s got a large central capacity with an inset pouch for purse or phone, with an outer zipped pocket and two mesh side pockets – perfect for drinks bottles for hikers or students. Its incredibly lightweight but very strong too, so will take groceries, heavy books, packed lunches easily. There are a couple of reflective tabs just above the mesh pouter pockets that are useful for dark nights or gloomy mornings. Every little bit of safety equipment aiding visibility helps, and these type of reflectors are very good at catching the light.Stars: Five. Great for students, shoppers and leisure activities.If you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why so I can improve the usefulness of future reviews.

Dearborn, (Woodland Creek),  Jenni Moen.Review from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, Sci-fi and FantasyWhat a fabulous concept, 30 books by different authors centred around the same small village. I’ve looked and – hurrah - some are on Kindle Unlimited, so I’m planning ( when time allows!!) to read more from this collection. I’d not read anything by Jenni Moen before but this sounded such an interesting plot I wanted to try this one. I did find it slow to start and in that way, the writing style and the way it unfolds it reminds me very much of Charlaine Harris Midnight Crossroads, though the only murders here are the Cluedo variety! Its a gentle story, full of tiny mysteries and hints about what's coming, so that when things are revealed we’ve an idea what’s going to happen. And then I got surprised when it didn’t work out the way I’d thought :-) but that’s fine, I love the unpredictability of when that happens. I loved Willow right from the start. She’s got a kind heart and that comes through, where even though she can feel other people’s emotion she still tried to think the best of them. I loved her plans for the house and when it was complete I could visualise those rooms – I’d love to stay there. Quinn too, a lovely man but so traumatised by his experiences he’s in a way scared and yet something draws him to Willow, they complement each other really well. Ryan her diner colleague was a great guy too and had some good lines. Its a very gentle story, no heart stopping romances and dramas, no edge of seat suspense, but a plot that gradually reveals more and more about the people in the village. I savoured the story, its not one to rush through or you miss the tiny elements that add so much to it. I don’t think its one I’d reread though, but the description of the village and its heritage made me want to read more in the series.Stars: Four, a tender, mellow story.ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Ice Moon,  Lisa KesslerReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, Sci-fi and Fantasy.I’ve loved this series but did feel the last book felt a little slow, but for me this is back on track. Doc Jason’s twin Jared is the subject here, and when he meets Taryn Goldstone about a new contract, some decking at her house he realises she’s his Mate. Taryn has issues though, as a Psychic with fire-starting talents she’s scared of hurting people so closes herself off. She adores her young son Charlie, but never touches him, never hugs him for fear of burning him. Her talent seems to be allied with strong emotion and she doesn’t have control, so avoids letting her emotions out. That’s why she gets nicknamed The Ice Queen.  As we get to know more of her and Charlie we can see she’s just in the right place, just where she needs to be, guided there by an unexpected source. The shocks and connections keep getting stronger, and I can see how the Pack is amassing people with the skills they’ll need if and when there’s a final head to head with Nero. As well as keeping her Pyro-kinesis a secret Taryn knows nothing of werewolves, so Jared has a hard task in front of him. He learns about her problems by accident and of course then he’s waiting for the right moment to tell her about himself. Its not only him he needs to tell her about too....Of course as always Nero are looking out for those with skills they can utilise, and they don’t ask politely but will use anything to force people to them. Jared needs to protect her and Charlie but how to protect someone when you can’t tell them everything yet, as they’ll think you need locking up. He has a plan to show her its all real but until then his family agree to keep it secret. What happens with those though? Yes, they always get released at just the wrong time!There’s love and heated (!) emotions here, dangers once more from Nero, problems to overcome for not just Taryn but Jared too, and a wonderful boy, Charlie, to protect! Its a great read and one I really enjoyed, kept me gripped right through..Stars: Five, a great instalment to the series. ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Christian, Book 10 of The Vampires in America Series,  D. B. ReynoldsReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, Sci-fi and FantasyThis is one of my favourite Vampire series. Each book is almost a stand alone in that its a complete story, but there are threads of the battle to come, the European vampires that want to take over America, that weave through all the books. Slowly the parameters are set, the lines are being drawn and Allies forming, masterminded by the clever and intriguing Raphael ( books one and two). This time we meet Christian, child of Mathilde. She was killed in the last book after using some devious means to try to get to Raphael, and Christian refused to support her.Debbie’s vampires are tough, very Alpha, and hold their territories by power alone. Anthony holds the South after a battle there but isn’t strong enough to hold it himself, and has been supported by Raphael as a strategic move. It was actually Cynthia, Raphael's human mate, that killed the former Lord but of course that can’t get out – they have some very strong and traditional laws, and a human killing a vampire lord wouldn't be seen kindly. For that reason even though many suspect the truth its seen as Raphael that defeated him, but with his own territory to run he’s delegated Anthony. Now that support is being withdrawn, he’s helped with the set up and Anthony should have been able to manage, but he’s proved not to be up to it. He’s resigned, something unheard of, usually territories are gained by formal challenges or a battle to the death. Anthony is secretly working away underhandedly in the background though to keep himself in power in an area that suits him. He certainly doesn’t want Christian to be the next Lord, he’s far too strong to allow Anthony's plans to come to fruition. Then there’s Natalie. She’s been working for Anthony for the past two years, he has her family in a stranglehold and she’s had to fall in with him. So far he’s kept it all circumspect and allowed her to do her job without any interference in her personal life, but as things heat up and he’s preparing his next move he has plans for her too, regardless of what she wants. Its another torrid, fast moving, sensual read with action and drama throughout, interspersed with some searingly hot vampire sex. Those guys certainly know how to show a lady a good time....As always there are things from previous books that creep in, scenes that were set much earlier and that’s why I’d recommend reading the previous books to fully enjoy this one, even though its complete in itself. As with past books I loved it and it will join my keepers file. I find with Debbie’s books each time I re-read I find little things I missed first time round, little references to past events and clues for future ones. Some series get a bit tired after this many book but this is as fresh still as the first few books and I’m happy for it to continue. I look forward to more – looks like Sophia, the only female vampire Lord, is set to feature largely in the next book. Although she’s the only one in America at the moment there are some strong female characters placed throughout the series, both vampire and human, no simpering milksops here. They all have to be tough to survive the events that surround them.  Stars: Five, another fantastic instalment.ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

The Alpha's Temporary Mate,  Victoria DaviesReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, Sci-fi and Fantasy.I really enjoyed this – I loved the first two novels, and its one of those easy to read, fun series that you can just relax with. This time it’s Chloe who’s the main subject, put in a difficult position by Alpha werewolf Kieran. He wants a temporary girlfriend, one that will fool his pack and get them off his back about settling down. That’s something he’s not prepared to do. Chloe needs this to go right, he’s offering big money and if she can land him she’s promised the office managers job, as her boss will use his funds to open the next Fated Match. They don’t do temporary though, they’re all about finding Mates, but the money he’s offering persuades Chloe's boss to do this as a one off, so long as the other person involved is clear its not permanent too. So far though all the people Chloe comes up with get rejected by him, while his wolf is telling him Chloe would be good. She reluctantly agrees to do it – its only a few weeks but involves living with him, and going on the annual pack retreat. She’s a witch, so that would be the perfect breakup reason for the pack, in fact it’s a win win – or is it?I love the way it played out, how we learned more about both Kieran and Chloe, how we met briefly the characters from earlier books, and how the friends on both sides needed them to be very convincing to pull it off. As Kieran says though she can’t flinch when he kisses her in public, so they need to practice...and that turns out to be the catalyst for much more emotion than either of them bargained for.Its a cute story, with some smouldering sensual scenes and some great humour. I did hope for a bit more jealousy from the pack females, who naturally would resent Chloe but what there was worked well. When it all fell apart I was so upset for Chloe – and I need that, need the sad bit.  Its another good addition to the series, and one to read when you want a light novel to relax with and entertain you, not a deep dark drama that needs all your attention and concentration. There’s a place for both in my reading lists, it depends on my mood what I want to read. Stars: Five, a great addition to the series. ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Semlos Romantic Bedroom Ocean Projector LampRelaxing Blue Night Light Projector Music Projection with 3.5mm built-in Speaker(Powered by USB Cable Included)Review from Jeannie’s Product Reviews This arrived well packed along with some other items in a secure box. Its a strange looking device but once working it transforms a room into something magical. Its easy to use and can be run from the mains or battery powered. That’s  useful if you want to use it in bathrooms where mains electric isn’t available or safe. I use it with a power bank. I love those and they  make electric devices so much more portable. It means this could also be used outdoors too, something I’ve not tried yet but which I think would be lovely in full dark.This projector really comes into its own when used in the dark, sending beautiful and relaxing shimmering waves to ceilings and walls. It can be used with or without music, and automatically switches off after an hour, making it perfect for a gentle descent into sleep at bedtime. I’ve not seen these before but have had great fun with this, and think they are perfect for atmosphere setting, for romantic evenings and for those who find sleeping difficult and the gentle waves projected feel so relaxing. Combined with one of those natural sounds CD’s ( I have one and they work really well) you’ll soon be nodding off....Its in shades of  gentle blues, but I think you could use other transparent plastics in different colours taped over the top to add variety if wanted. Personally I love the blues, but a red transparent sheet would make ( I think – light may not be like paint)  purples or a yellow one to change it to greens....fun to try anyway and something I will be doing sometime.Product supplied for reviewStars: Five. Perfect for those who have sleep issues and for mood setting.  If you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why so I can improve the usefulness of future reviews.

Rare Form, Descended of Dragons: Book 1, Jen CraneReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, Sci-fi and fantasy.Well, this sounded great fun – and it was. Its something different from the norm, shape shifters, but in a kind of parallel dimension, and with others magics being used too. Its the first book in a new series and that’s always a difficult job, delivering a good story while introducing the reader to a new world and the people within it, and its a hard balance to get right. I felt the world setting here was great and its certainly one I want to read more of, but the actual storyline of this first part was a little simplistic for me. It had a very YA/NA feel to it; that’s not a bad thing, I enjoy a well written YA/NA at times but it did present a few frustrations for me as someone long past the YA range!! The storyline is really just one plot, about Stella’s heritage and I would have liked a bit deeper plot, or some sub plots working alongside it. For someone introduced to such a fantastical new world Stella is incredibly accepting. I know she felt a little “out” in her life and how she fitted in, but she had very few questions about something that surely must have gobsmacked her totally. Would she really have thrown everything up just like that without a few more questions? Maybe, maybe not?  The romance part too frustrated me, Stella seemed quite in-your-face to Rowan while he seemed to jump from hot to cold to hot again. I was disappointed in Livia (La-VEE-Yah) I had such hopes she was going to live up to the fantastic bit ch person she first presented, but somehow that never quite worked out – next book maybe? I hope so, I do so like a good “bad” person and she sounded perfect for the role, being involved with Rowan and clearly jealous of and disliking Stella already.It sounds like it’s all criticisms from me, and it’s not. There were some great characters, a good mix of the loyal, the conceited and the friendly types. I loved the way the people had evolved, with many showing parts of their magical heritage in their human appearance and natures. I loved the  Radix Citadel, the fabulous descriptions ( I could mentally picture the place), the magic involved, the premise of Stella learning about her history which served to make us readers aware of the background story too. I could feel the connection between Rowan and Stella right from the start, just wished they’d been more consistent. Somehow their relationship felt neither one thing or another. I note some reviews have remarked on the  dichotomy of the YA feel and the language and sexual implications. There is some bad language and sexual connotations here but I don't feel its really an issue, I still feel it fits well in the YA/NA range. It's one that’s deemed suitable for the upper end of the YA grouping, not the early teens ( though I wouldn’t worry about my 14 year old granddaughter reading this, there’s far more sexuality and bad language on TV daily!)Its a fun read, in a fresh new world and one I want to read more of. I see book two is out already, and am hoping that means Jen is one of those writers who turn out novels quickly, not keep us waiting months/years for more. This doesn't end on a cliff-hanger thank goodness, but at a natural break point leading the way into the next book. .As one who hates cliff-hangers a huge thanks to Jen for that!!Stars: Four, a fresh and interesting new world and a promising start to the series.  ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Rock Me Two Timesby Dawn RyderReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, First in Dawn Ryder’s sizzling new Rock Band series.  I really enjoyed it and will be keen to read more. I really enjoy the Band/Film star trope so seeing this I was keen to read and it was well worth the time. Syon is a real jerk at first, and I just couldn’t feel I was going to like him – and that’s a big issue for me....but as I continued and got to know him better I could see why he acted this way. Part is just going with the flow, rock star expectations and availability of limitless sex, and part seems to be a defence almost like doing something before he’s accused, and never getting involved more than the minimum needed for sex means he keeps himself closed off to emotions. He knows the groupies don’t want him, the real man, but the rock star persona that is a facade. Of course when he sees Kate and wants her he’s shocked at first that she doesn’t give in the ways the groupies always do, but there’s something between them and somehow he just can’t give in. The moves he makes to get her shock himself, and he questions his feelings and actions but he just can’t let her go.  Kate’s been disappointed by the fame thing before, when an ex found fame and treated her badly. Now she has her rules, no married men, no drugs, no rock/film stars. She’s firmly set on growing her business with her partner, the adorable Percy, who’s got a huge crush on Syon ( and the rest of the band it seems) and is strongly encouraging her to have a fling with him. Syon opens up a travelling costumer position for Kate - the band all wear leather, wear it hard and their wardrobe is in sad need of renovation. Its not just a sop position – image is all and they’re a very keen and ambitious group so sub par clothing isn’t acceptable to them. Kate is the best, and they want the best. She’s not keen on spending time in such close proximity but she can’t turn it down, it’ll be the making of her company, offering opportunities not to be missed, giving unparalleled publicity to it and designer rights after the tour and her job finishes. Its a shock to both of them how strong their feelings are, and they both fight making it more than just sex. Kate can’t deal with the insecurity of groupies and all that would bring, Syon can’t give up what he thinks makes him the person he is. Nevertheless he finds his attraction to others has waned, Kate is all he wants.  Its a fun read with some underlying plots involving other band members and people involved in the tour. Its quite a light read, not hard to follow and I’d guessed one of the main issues, but its still a fun read with some very sensual sex scenes. I really want to know more about Taz and his ex girlfriend – maybe he’s book two? I hope so ;- ) One thing: Spotted Dick. Its an old English dish, currants in a steamed suet pastry, origins from the 1800’s. Its not Custard, though its usually served with custard. To be honest it’s rarely seen on menus unless its a wartime or historical special. Calling it Custard is like calling a Big Mac a pickle..... and though we have lots of pub quizzes it’d be a pretty unusual prize!!Stars: Four and a half, not quite a five, a bit light for that but a really fun read, that I’d happily reread and look forward to more.ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishers If you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, in case I've inadvertently added a spoiler and need to edit.

Untamed, (Thoughtless 4) S.C. StephensReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, N/AThoughtless and the follow ups were among the first NA reads I found, and I loved them. Now its Griffins turn to show his story, and this book is written from his POV. That gave me  problems and to be honest I was getting really tired of reading just how Awesome he thought he was. I struggled though first half, got so fed up of Griffin, I don't remember him being that selfish and plain rude/obnoxious. I remember him as being arrogant, crude and overly sexual but devoted to the band, always making jokes, even if they were crude ones, and being a loud, larger than life but at heart good guy. Griffin here doesn’t seem to have any of those features apart from that he adores Anna and Gibson. He’s simply so rude, so selfish and self obsessed that I found the first 40% of the book really hard going, and has to restart several times where usually i read right through a book, time permitting of course. Then it started to pick up. It was clear he was frustrated and I did feel for him when he kept getting a flat No from the band, when they just wouldn’t even consider any of his suggestions – Ok, most of them were puerile but he could have been encouraged to take a larger role, to practise, to have lead for one song once he was good enough....but all he got was a No, so I understood when he felt he’d got as far as he could if they’d never consider him for more. His actions though – typical Griffin OTT, and even in the way he did it. From then on I got much more into the story and the last 30% was heart breaking, incredibly emotional and made the book for me. It had all the angst and emotion that make NA reads so gripping. I loved seeing how he changed, and how the others reacted to him. Anna was an absolute star here, and the ending was very surprising, satisfying but didn't take the safe, predictable route that would have been easier, instead we got more heartbreak and a chance for Griffin to finally show everyone the man he is, the man that's been hidden for so long, and that only Anna could see was waiting to come out. If only the start had been better it would have been a five star – as it is its a 2 for the fist part and a solid five for the last with a kind of 4 in the middle. .Stars: Its a 3.5 – 4. such a shame about that start IMO – still, it’ll work for many. I’m just disappointed that it didn’t for me. The last 40% was a very well deserved five. ...ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

His Kind of Trouble, Terri AustinReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  romance,I loved Terri's first in this series, His Every Need, and at the end there was a sample of this one and I was keen to read. we see Monica a bit in the first book, now in this one we meet a different version of her, a more subdued, watered down Monica. what’s made her like this? Cal can’t believe how much she’s changed and he doesn’t feel its for the better. He thinks she’s existing now whereas the Monica he met was living life to the full.Cal is a great lead, hot and so full of life. He’s had his own issues though and reminds Monica too much of the bad boys she’s sworn off. Still, he’s hard to resist and eventually she gives in to his persistence, telling herself its just lust, sex and she’ll stop before getting hurt or letting her emotions get involved. Cal’s OK with that, he doesn’t do love, doesn’t do relationships and all the responsibility that comes with him. he likes his life as it is, with his business restoring old classic cars in the UK and his trust fund allowing him to take off anywhere in the world at whim. So, there they are, both really enjoying the very steamy and sensual sex, and kidding themselves that’s all it is...then life steps in, things go wrong and they’re forced to reassess. Monica in the first book was a happy, no holds barred, full on fun girl and she’s so changed. I wanted to know what happened and when it was revealed I felt so sorry for her. she’s forced herself into the mould of a person she really wasn’t, at the cost of her own happiness. Cal seems very “playboy” lightweight, and its how his family regard him, and yet as we get to know him he’s so much more and I really really wanted him and Monica to work things out. They were perfect for each other.There’s some snippets with Allie and Trevor in, and it was good to catch up with them. Its put me in the mood for a re read of their story. The books really complement each other, and as there’s a third sister, Brynn, I’m hoping she gets a story too – there’s a hint, I think anyway – of who might drop in to her life ;- )Its a fun read, hot and sexy, easy to follow, with some great characters and some very sensual and erotic sex scenes. the drama part was good too, nicely balanced with all the fun and happy parts. I need that contrast, the “down” part and find it makes the good parts even better. Without the balance for me its not a good read.Stars: Five, a sensual story without going OTT on the sex scenes. Its a great blend of sex and story, with neither dominating and that’s exactly what I need.ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishers If you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, in case I've inadvertently added a spoiler and need to edit.

A Fortunate Blizzard,  L.C. ChaseReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, LBGTQIA.I’ve enjoyed a few novels from L.C.Chase before so know I enjoy her writing style and this one sounded interesting.Its an unusual scenario with Trevor facing end stage kidney disease. Making a romance with someone terminally ill is tough, but LC does it and doesn’t go the obvious route either. Its touched on, but would have been just too cheesy, too unbelievable if that had worked out , so I’m glad she chose a different solution. That made the story better too because it drew in how Marc had been living, how he’d been letting his past issues with his mother dominate his life, and brought forward some other characters into the story. As Trevor says – and of course means – Life is for Living. When I was diagnosed with cancer, and told the outlook wasn’t good it made me think.  I saw and talked to other patients  for whom that phrase took on a new meaning, and it made me too look to what my priorities were in life. 20 years on I’ve relaxed a bit but still keep in mind how short life can be.  Its so easy to do as Marc was, work all hours, promising that “one day “ we’ll have time to do XYZ. That time isn’t always there, each hour, each day, each week that passes can’t be got back and given a do over, and so many discover like Trevor that the time they thought they still had could be severely reduced.The story is  a beautiful and  tender romance, and so realistic. Trevor is in a place so many others are ( and as an AB neg blood group I hope I’m never in his type of need) and meeting Marc seemed like a cruel twist of fate at first. Slowly though things fall into place, and even though we’re dealing with a sad issue there’s moments of lightness in it, snippets of beauty and a real feeling of satisfaction when I reached the ending. Its not a long read at 175 pages but one to savour and enjoy.  Stars: five, a great read, and a tender romance.ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishers If you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, in case I've inadvertently added a spoiler and need to edit.

Learning to Speak American,  Colette DartfordReview from Jeannie Zelos book reviewsGenre:  Romance, Women’s FictionWell, for a debut novel this is simply incredible. It kept me hooked to the page right to the end. It’s packed full of emotion and so, so realistic.To start with I felt so sorry for Duncan, he was trying so hard to help Lola with her depression since their young daughter died, but she was in a grey fog, drifting aimlessly, and not even trying. Then on a morning out while on holiday they come across a derelict property for sale. She’s enthused about it, it pulls to something in her and Duncan is so pleased he arranges to buy it. From there my opinions began to change, we leant more about them and see from the outside that each are dealing – or not dealing – in their own way. Duncan is buttoned up, refuses to talk about their daughter and throwing himself into getting Lola better. Hobbies, counselling, anything but letting her talk to him about her. Lola just wants to talk, not treat their daughter as if she didn’t exist, and over the two years since the accident they’ve drifted. I felt she was so cold to Duncan when he was trying so hard, I didn’t like her but as I knew more of her I saw another side. They’re still on holiday when the cottage purchase starts to bring her forward, and she responds to Duncan as she hasn’t in a long while. Their love life had fizzled out, Lola just wasn’t interested for so long and now it looks to be sparking alive again.Duncan’s having work issues too though, but he doesn't talk to Lola about them, and that harks back to his upbringing and the Stiff Upper Lip British way of men coping.  He’s very traditional, he spends long hours at work, never really switches off, he deals with money and bills, and Lola runs the home and her livery yard, which he treats as a kind of hobby. They live outside London and he has a long journey into work each day, and often stays over when work ends late. Things get worse for him at work when he loses an important contract, and the stress pushes him further into actions he rationalises as OK.Lola gets more and more involved in the new property and the people there. We can see slowly how what was supposed to bring them back together is having the opposite effect. I was really annoyed at Duncan, didn’t understand how he could reconcile his actions, how he could justify himself like that. Of course he’s doing what most people do, thinking up reasons to rationalise and excuse what we know isn’t right but what we want to do. He’s human not a saint! I felt for him even when I was angry at him. I felt for Lola finally coming out of her depression just as things as going so badly for Duncan and he’s keeping her in the dark about it all. He’s very old fashioned and the age difference between them leads him to treat her as if she’s a child in a way. If they’d just talked she could have helped...but then we wouldn’t have this fabulous story.Its a story that could happen to anyone, and so full of emotion. I so felt for both of them, was desperate for things to change for the better, for them to be happy. The death of a child is something no parent should have to deal with. I loved Treetops, the people around and involved in it. They felt so real, were so warm and welcoming even when they’d had their own issues. There’s some shocks here, things come out that no-one expects, and its a wonderful read. I’m a true romantic at heart, I want happy endings for everyone and here I got it. I finished it feeling very satisfied at the way things worked out, but it wasn’t at all as I’d thought it would be when I began reading....Stars: Five, an emotional journey and fabulous début book. . ARC supplied by Netgalley and publishersIf you enjoyed my review I'd love it if you would please click “Like” and if you didn't I'd love to know why, so I can make future reviews more helpful.

Mudder Carbon Monoxide Alarm DetectorReview from Jeannie’s Product Reviews There’s not too much to say about this, its a standard Carbon Monoxide alarm, and has a good loud noise to it. It doesn’t come with batteries so order those too so that soon as it arrives you can install it. It has good instructions for use, and has indicators to show low battery or – very important – if its malfunctioning. That's not something you want to find out too late! Pay attention to installation recommendations to get it in the appropriate place. No use having one if its blocked by curtains or sited by an air vent preventing it picking up dangerous gas levels. Our current device  is a free standing one in the kitchen, same as the gas boiler, and is on top of a tall fridge on the opposite side of room as advised by the Engineer. I’m going to use this one in the living room where we now have a wood burner.Carbon Monoxide is a silent killer. I’ve had an alarm  in the kitchen for years. Our boiler is there and when servicing it the Gas Engineer recommended  one a few years back. I mentioned we had of those visible ones but as he said, if its in the night you won’t be looking and do you check it daily? It a small price to pay for safety. A friend some time back had been suffering from headaches and discovered, in time fortunately, that it was due to carbon monoxide from an appliance that wasn’t working correctly. If you’re going abroad why not take one with you – we’ve all seen those tragic reports of kids and families dying because safety isn’t always as good as it could when it comes to servicing appliances. I’ve copied the below info from the B&Q website – its simple practical advice.What is carbon monoxide (CO)?Carbon Monoxide (CO) is a colourless, tasteless and odourless gas that can cause harmful and potentially fatal effects.Carbon monoxide is produced by the incomplete burning of fossil fuels, such as gas. This can occur in inadequately maintained or badly fitted domestic heating appliances, such as boilers and gas fires. If your flue or chimney is blocked, CO will be unable to escape your home if produce, allowing a dangerous concentration to quickly build up.If carbon monoxide escapes into your home it will cause symptoms that include headaches, breathlessness, drowsiness, vomiting, chest pains, dizziness, vision problems and eventually collapse and loss of consciousness – which can easily be confused with, or misdiagnosed as, flu, fatigue or food poisoning. Be aware of the symptoms and be prepared to react if you recognise them in yourself or others.Reducing the riskWhen was the last time your boiler was serviced?
