An alternative method for this is to use an ordinary Bible with a devotional book side by side. That is not the intent of the publisher of this Bible which is to let the devotional supplement the Bible passages. Perhaps, this is a matter of personal preference. Thus, this devotional Bible format may work for some but not others.One critique I have for this Bible is the color of the font. I would prefer the texts to be a black rather than brown, for black would have provided a better contrast for the eye.Father's Day may have been over, but it is still not too late to get a devotional Bible. While theme-based bibles may not exactly reflect the real intent of the Bible itself, from the perspective of a Bible literacy promotion standpoint, anything that encourages one to read the Bible a little more regularly will tilt my recommendation to YES. Another positive feature in this Bible is the actual title. In the family home,anyone finding the Bible anywhere in the house, the kitchen table, the living room, the study, the bedroom, or in any other room, would straightaway know: "Hey, this is dad's Bible!"Rating: 4.5 stars of 5.conradeThis book is provided to me courtesy of BookLookBloggers program in exchange for an honest review. All opinions offered above are mine unless otherwise stated or implied.

Conflict is inevitable. Sooner or later, even the most cordial of relationships will encounter rough patches. The fact is that conflicts in themselves are not necessarily bad, especially when we can learn to respond constructively when they occur. In Dr Linda Mintle's words, it is simply summarized in four words: "We Need to Talk," which is exactly the title and the central theme of the book. Called a "relationship doctor," Mintle is a popular speaker, a licensed marriage counselor and family therapist, and also chair of the Division of Behavioral Health at the College of Osteopathic Medicine at Liberty University in Lynchburg, VA. She deals with the topic of conflict sensitively but with firmness. Her three basic assumptions are:1) Conflicts are part and parcel of any close relationships;2) Under the right conditions, conflicts can help grow relationships;3) In unhappy relationships, conflicts can escalate and one needs to learn how to deal with them.Conflicts always involve a power struggle and the key is to manage power imbalances as best as possible to balance between emotional needs, personal integrity, people's well-being, and the stress of life. In order to resolve any conflict, trust must be cultivated. Keeping secrets, being unreliable, history of betrayal, are all examples of how trust can be eroded. In order to build trust, show grace with providing second chances on the one hand and to draw boundaries on the other. Learn of Jesus' humility. Cherish differences without having to pander to every wish and fancy. Beware of the four horsemen of the relationship apocalypse: 1) Criticism; 2) Defensiveness; 3) Contempt; 4) Stonewalling. Anticipate a clash of styles and to learn strategies on how to deal with each. Be realistic with what is solvable and what is not. Like a family, one can disagree but still remember that we are all family. Families must learn to fight fair and to deal justly. There are also gender differences to be aware of. Distinguish the needs behind the desire for sex. One popular belief is that men and women have opposite views of sex and affection. Men puts sex before affection while women sees otherwise. Rather than focusing on these two, Mintle suggests both genders find ways to get validation and love in order to meet both of these needs. Mintle also gives 20 guidelines with regards to social media usage and sex.Conflict styles also vary. Mintle pays special attention to difficult people that provokes high conflict levels. "High conflict" personalities tend to be too emotional about issues and often see things in black and white. Due to their rigid mental styles, they can become manipulative when they do not get things their way. They tend to yell and lose their tempers. They need help in controlling their anger and enabling lots of forgiveness. Use the serenity prayer as a guide.With lots of practical tips, this book essentially helps us to clear the decks without dismissing the most difficult players. We learn to recognize the different kinds of styles and the various approaches to deal with conflicts. Sometimes it is good to minimize conflicts. Other times, it is best to deal with the situation at hand. With a positive outlook, confidence and humility need to be used simultaneously. The chapter on "Dealing with Difficult People" alone is worth the price of the book. Mintle has given us a powerful resource on how to live together with well-being of all in mind. Perhaps, for those of us who want to do something about everyday conflicts but don't know how, we need to pick up this book, learn from it, and to be equipped on how best to calm down and to promote a constructive dialogue. For Jesus' sake.Rating: 4.25 stars of 5.conradeThis book is provided to me courtesy of Baker Books and Graf-Martin Communications in exchange for an honest review. All opinions offered above are mine unless otherwise stated or implied.

The word "community" has been thrown around quite a lot by many institutions, social help groups, corporate environments, as well as non-profits throughout the world. While trumpeting the merits of working together, the fact is that as people rush from place to place, and to work from dawn to dusk, tempers can easily flare when things do not meet our expectations. From rude behaviours in the workplace to aggressive drivers at the highways, all it often take is an unexpected event that can easily lit our fuses. For those with short fuses, the result is a terrible emotional outburst that can do a lot of damage. There are road rages and boardroom battles. There are even angry exchanges on social media that if picked up by the mainstream media, turn a petty dispute into an all-out war of words. This is what makes this book an extremely practical one. It is the author's contention that just by giving up our right to be angry is a significant change that can enable us to live better. On the area of "righteous anger," Hansen maintains that it is not supported in Scripture. He writes: "We humans are experts at casting ourselves as victims and rewriting narratives that put us in the center of injustices. (More on this in a bit.) And we can repaint our anger or hatred of someone—say, anyone who threatens us—into a righteous-looking work of art." On and on, Hansen advocates peaceful speech, gracious behavior, and a sustained emphasis on self-control, self-restraint, and self-denial. Using examples and teachings from peace rights activists like Dr Martin Luther King Jr, theologians like CS Lewis and Dietrich Bonhoeffer, pastors like Tim Keller, and popular writers like Philip Yancey and Henri Nouwen, Hansen makes his case that there is really nothing for one to lose but everything to gain as far as not being easily offended is concerned.He deals with the important subject of injustice, while affirming the fact of injustices happening, he advocates that the way ahead is to let our actions be motivated by love. Whether it is tough love or otherwise, it is critical not to let anger have its way, or to let our human emotions take control. Rather, it is to let God work through us by stepping out of inner anger toward fighting injustice not with fighting, but with firm loving. The motives matter a lot. If it is simply a reaction, it may become a wrong trying to correct another wrong, which is wrong in itself. Readers are reminded that behind many angry acts is actually a person whose pride has been hurt.Being angry is a choice. We can either choose to give in easily to anger to allow it to fly beyond rage, or to exercise self-control by giving up our right to be angry. This is the key message of Christian radio host and author, Brant Hansen. This one change of perspective is the rudder that turns the ship of uncontrolled anger and cultivates an unoffendable spirit. Very readable and tremendously applicable to modern day living, this book speaks about anger from a Christian perspective. In the Bible, we learn "in your anger, do not sin," which means that behind every anger moment is an opportunity for sin to grow. Believers must learn to look beyond the offending event and remember that the person who had hurt us is not the enemy. The enemy is somewhere else trying to make us sin against that brother or a sister, or that person that Jesus had died for. When we gain the bigger perspective of God's love for the world, we will learn to see from God's point of view and to live according to the teachings of Christ. Love your enemies. Pray for them. Love them the way Christ had loved them.Rating: 4.25 stars of 5.conradeThis book is provided to me courtesy of W Publishing Group, Thomas Nelson, and NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. All opinions offered above are mine unless otherwise stated or implied.

This is the ninth volume in the "Exegetical Commentary on the New Testament" series (ZECNT) from Zondervan. The earlier versions cover the gospels of Matthew and Luke, the book of Acts, the Pauline epistles to the Galatians, the Ephesians, the Colossians, Philemon, 1 and 2 Thessalonians, and the letter to James. What makes this series useful are the:-  More extensive Greek exegesis which is particularly helpful for those who have studied Greek-  Helpful main ideas with each pericope-  Graphical layouts and tables-  Contextual connections throughout-  Exegeting and explanation of the texts-  Application IdeasMost unique of all is the reminder throughout that exegesis must come before interpretation. This makes the commentary a very helpful reminder in itself to avoid putting the cart of interpretation/application before the horse of understanding what the text says originally. In this volume, Karen H Jobes, Professor of New Testament at Wheaton College helps us to exegete and understand the Greek texts and apply them to practical living. On the one hand, pastors and teachers would like to have a more in-depth treatment of the Bible. There are some commentaries that seem more ready to comment and talk rather than to wait and ponder over the meaning of the text, to let the text speak for itself.  This is no easy task.Thankfully, with Jobes's experience, expertise, and enthusiasm, we have this volume that looks at the three letters of John in a non-redactional way. It is less of the reading into the text and more of reading out of what the text is saying. She notes that the three letters need to be read in conjunction with the gospel of John. After listing the various existentialist and evangelical approaches, Jobes settles on an approach that lets the gospel of John and the letters inform each other. Rather than to limit the polemics in John to forms of Gnosticism or Christological heresies, Jobes prefer to expand it to a "variety of false beliefs." This allows one to have a broader picture of the challenges and the relevance of 1, 2, 3 John today.The epistles of John are particularly important because it stresses the importance of knowing God. Jesus is relevant today as well as tomorrow. In Jesus, we have a cornerstone that will stand the test of time. In a world of conflicting ideologies and pluralistic philosophies, the letters form a spiritual anchor for faith. There are major themes emphasized like our attitude toward sin, love as the glue of interpersonal relationships, and other non-polemical views like shepherding believers, and arguing for a correction to what faith in Jesus means. Jobes compares the gospel and the letters frequently, showing us of a common authorship as well as major themes that are repeated. Not only that, the letters project a certain circular or spiral movement, where themes are never forgotten as John moves from one point to another. It is not a step-wise flow of sequential thought but a series of repetition to ensure that readers get the key points. That makes outlining the letters quite a challenging one. The big idea is essentially knowing God via the Word incarnated; knowing God via symbols and metaphors; knowing what God delights and what God hates; knowing the interconnection between knowing and loving; knowing God in relationships; knowing God through right teachings; knowing God through the expression of love for one another; knowing God as God is revealed as Father, Son, and Holy Spirit.Each carefully selected passage opens with a "Literary Context" that introduces the location and contexts of the text. It is then followed by a "Main Idea" to declare to the reader where the commentator is at. The "Translation" portion itself is worth the price of the book as Jobes diligently structures the texts according to literary patterns, chiastic arrangements, and key words. The Explanation of the Text offers lots of fodder for thought and analysis. Readers are encouraged to engage the author as much as possible by asking why certain Greek words in that passage were selected in the first place. Reading it reminds me of my Greek teacher who had helped me move the texts from exegesis to devotion. Other highlights include the "In Depth" boxes that offer supplementary material and the "Theology in Application" which is one of my favourites. This commentary is the best one I have found on the epistles of John. It has the scholarship depth and the theological faithfulness. It is readable and practical. I would strongly recommend this as the key commentary to use for any preaching and teaching of the epistles of John.Rating: 5 stars of 5.conradeThis book is provided to me courtesy of Zondervan Academic and NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. All opinions offered above are mine unless otherwise stated or implied.

Must the opposite of violence be a violent counter strike? Is war necessarily a tit-for-tat exchange of bullets and missiles? Can alternative methods like peaceful response be feasible, even possible in the first place? These questions are answered with pacifist conviction by renowned author and professor, Ron Sider, whose previous book, "Rich Christians in an Age of Hunger" had gripped the hearts of evangelicals many years ago. What that book had done to many Christians in terms of their wealth and giving responsibilities, this latest book will push the limits with regards to peaceful offerings and intentional "nonviolent action." Underlying any "just war" or "pacifist" theory is a philosophy of justification whether war is the key response in the first place. What about peace as the underlying action? For any entrance into war does not mean the consequences are limited on a military scale. There are other damages inflicted on all sides, morally financially, ethically, physically, mentally, and many more as the years go by. Soldiers who survived the wars may end up having scars for life. Unable to get back to the normal life, many become marginalized in society. Such effects must not be underestimated. Rather than to a backward thrust, like the consequences of war as a main justification, Sider in this book leads from the front. He issues a clarion call for all to use nonviolence as THE way forward. Our vocabulary for action must extend beyond war and weapons, violence and vehemence.He begins with well-known examples of nonviolent actions through the centuries. During the time of Pharaoh, the Hebrew midwives responded to violence through civil disobedience, which saved the life of Moses. Pope Leo I responded to the vicious acts of Attila the Hun with a cross and a papal crown. In central America, peasants and common people overcame the violence of dictators through general strikes. India's Mahatma Gandhi led peaceful protests that rallied millions of citizens to do the same.  America's Martin Luther King Jr did the same with peaceful rallies against racism in the 50-60s. Philippines' "People Power" movement toppled the Marcos regime not with tanks but with people, not with violence but with peace. From America to Asia, Africa to Central America, Europe to the Middle East, examples abound with regards to the practice of nonviolent action that deserves to be taken more seriously. With stories after stories of how peaceful actions lead to the bloodless overthrow of regimes, changes of political forces, and new waves of hope, Sider consistently asserts that there is a better way instead of physical violence and military options. He proposes peacemaker teams that comprise representatives from all sectors. He admonishes the Christian public, especially the "just war" proponents for forgetting that war must always be a last resort. For peaceful actions are more successful than many had thought. Giving statistics and stories to back up his arguments for peace, the next step is to increase the common space for all to work with together. It there is ever to be a war, it must be a war against war.Peace is a given. Christians are called to be peacemakers in the first place. In fact, the biggest tragedy for many policy makers is not to give peace a bigger piece of the pie. It is the lack of willingness to persevere in non-violent actions that has led to an ease in pushing the war option. Contrary to what some readers may think, Sider is not some hermit calling for people to retreat back into their caves. Rather, he is calling people to arm themselves with determination to fight, with the weapons of love, the passion for peace. He wants more Christians to fight fear with faith, war with peace, and hatred with love. For most of the decisions to go to war, the problem is not only in the decision, but the lack of will in pursuing the peace option. Negotiations can be very complicated. What about violent terrorists that refuse to listen to rationale arguments? What about fanatics who have abandoned reason altogether? What about the warped and wanton evil that are happening around the world that demand a strong response? Will peace be the answer for that?Personally, I believe Sider's point is not perfect. For there will be cases that war and violence may be the only way to end wars, like the Atomic bomb that accelerated the end of WWII in the Asia Pacific. Ethical problems will continue to rear their heads with regards to some violence in order to bring about peace. While peace should be the primary "weapon" of choice, to abandon the military option would be foolhardy, in an increasingly dangerous and violent world. Like the case of a lion. Without teeth, the lion is easy prey for hyenas.Rating: 4.5 stars of 5.conradeThis book is provided to me courtesy of Brazos Press and Graf-Martin Communications in exchange for an honest review. All opinions offered above are mine unless otherwise stated or implied.

Many Christians believe in the importance of studying the Word of God. They love and revere the Bible. They spend hours studying it and do devotions with it. They organize Bible studies to understand more about God. Sometimes, there is a danger of being too subjective by letting our own philosophies and feelings dominate what the biblical texts say and mean. What are the interpretive principles behind understanding and applying the Word of God?This is an abridged version of an earlier book entitled, "Introduction to Biblical Interpretation." In a nutshell, the authors had earlier proposed a hermeneutical triad that comprises of historical contexts, literary genres, and theological implications (I call it HLT) in their nearly 900 pages length original. This edition is not only simplified but the contents reduced by 50% in order to cater for a less academic audience. From exegetical examples to bibliographical listing, advanced material to technical content, the authors are hoping that the book will benefit more lay readers and general audiences, especially the more eager learner of interpretive methods. With clear outlines and suggestions for learning, each chapter is refreshed to be more reader friendly and easier to reference. At the same time, all biblical interpreters are charged with this one single task: Interpret the sacred text with reverence and accuracy.I like the way the authors begin with the need for humility. This is so important as having knowledge can puff up rather than edify the body. It means learning as being equipped to do good work. It means listening to the text and sharpening our spiritual perception. It also means that we are changed from the inside out. The Hermeneutical Triad is the author's way of helping us submit humbly to God by being respectful of the historical contexts; being sensitive to the literary genres, and being actively engaged with the theological implications of whatever passages we are studying. Each chapter comprises key guidelines for interpretation, key words to notice, and assignments to put what we read into practice. The entry outline helps readers to keep track of where they are going in this abridged but still sizeable volume. I like the simplified description and the brevity of each section. The supporting tables and illustrations drive home the pointers the authors try to make. I appreciate the conclusions accompanying each chapter because it is good pedagogy to summarize and to repeat important points. Overall, this follows the general teaching paradigm:- First, I tell you what I am going to say- Second, I say it.- Third, I summarize what I have said.There are less distractions and more focus on putting the HLT interpretive model to practice. This helps any student, layperson, reader, or Bible study leader tremendously in putting limited efforts into maximum effect. For seminarians, professors, preachers, and teachers, this edition is a good introduction for a general audience, but needs to be used in conjunction with the original unabridged version for maximum benefit. That said, the usefulness of this book should not be underestimated. For the HLT interpretive model is a very practical one and should appeal to a wide array of Bible study enthusiasts. One more thing. I love the title. For it is the very reason why we study the Bible and learn from books about Bible interpretation in the first place.Rating: 4.75 stars of 5.conradeThis book is provided to me courtesy of Kregel Academic in exchange for an honest review. All opinions offered above are mine unless otherwise stated or implied.

I am a fan of and own many solar lights - each has a specific purpose aroud the outside of the house. I ordered this particular one to light a flag mounted on the deck-railings (horizontally) and mounted the light to the beams that protrude below the floor of the deck, outside the railings.In a word, magnificent!I have never used a light with this type of battery (LiFePO4) so cannot speak to comparisons of that - but as compared to the many rechargeable lights I have with L-Ion 18650 batteries, it is incredibly bright and lasted nearly 12 hours! Professional battery evaluators say that this type of battery has a longer life-span than even the L-Ion ones.. Time will tell.The light is bright and constant and the larger-than-usual solar panel seems to charge it nicely even on cloudy days.Presuming it continues to work as it has for the first couple of days, I have no trouble recommending this light!

I have never seen anything quite like this bowl before ... and I am nearly 70 years old. It is elegant to look at and impressive to hold and feel. The glass is as smooth as anything could be - about 1/4" thick all around. I can't decide whether to display it as decor, or to put something in it - perhaps crystals or sea shells. Certainly, anything that goes into it ought be equally note-worthy.The fact that it has been hand-made and that no two pieces are identical adds yet another element of specialness to this lovely piece of crafter glass. It is, at once, elegant, unique and substantial. While each person might decide to use and/or display it in a different way, it is hard to believe that anyone would not appreciate and immediately love this bowl.

Earbuds come in every imaginable color and style. It is widely assumed that the more they cost - the better they are. While this may be the case in some situations, it is really NOT the case with these B10s from SoundPEATS.Comfortable and light-weight, these earbuds do an outstanding job of capturing not only the main/dominant sounds of music, but also a level of subtlety and auditory innuendo usually found only in much more costly sets. Yes, they are wired. While I am a fan of Bluetooth devices, I have come to appreciate that when the wired connection is eliminated, the quality of the sound is often reduced at the same time.I have worn these while running and they stay firmly in place. Sitting still with them on, I can almost forget that they are there! No mic, so no phone answering capacity - just darned good earbuds and an outstanding price!

This is a very good quality bristle dartboard. For the cost, I think it is the best in its range.  The board is tightly wound and just the right degree of smoothness. The markings are clear and though there is some unavoidable bounce-back whenever metal wiring is used on the board (as it neary always is,) it is no worse than the Unicorn HD board I have been using that costs about twice as much.The included darts are on the light side, but are certainly adequate for all but the most devout players who (like myself!) have several sets of favorites that we have deliberately chosen and prefer.I think that the criticism of the size of the score-board is silly. Most of us simply put a plain chalk-board up next to the dartboard, draw a line down the middle and start shooting! It is my opinion that even if this board came alone - no darts and no scoreboard, it would be an excellent value.

The President's Birth Certificate was publically released toward the tail end of the second round of these inane allegations - I have a copy and Mr. Corsi probably has one, too. Besides Donald Trump and too many mindless Americans who might actually vote for him, no one believes this tripe. The title, alone, keeps me from enriching this clown buy purchasing his book.(I have heard that Mr. Corsi, himself, was created in a DNA laboratory in Somalia and tossed out with all of the other failed experiments attempting to create a sentient human being from scratch.)

For some years, we have been using a pepper grinder/ salt shaker one-piece combo on our dining table. The notion of shifting to a grinder (to use Sea Salt) has been something we had been thinking about. Coming across this nice set of grinders from Silva put us over-the-top. We simply love them!What's not to like?They are reasonably priced, attractive, easy to fill, maintain and adjust. I was able to try out several pepper grind sizes by a couple of twists onto a sheet of white paper - until the grind looked like the way we like it. With the salt, it required no trial as we know that we like our salt (which we use less and less of over the years) is very finely ground.I suppose that the logo on the metal top is a bit more pronounced than fashion would find necessary, but that's no big deal. Nice grinders...REALLY nice grinders!

For casual listening (music for ambient sound or when exercising,) I have long been a fan of Bluetooth devices and have come to appreciate the cord-free freedom-of-movement experience they offer. But, for sitting still, where listening to music is the primary activity, I have come to prefer earphones that are wired as the sound production seems and sounds truer – especially with a quality set of headphones. I have found this HM9 set from Brainwavz to give me an completely satisfying wired listening experience with a level of quality at least equal to many wired headphone sets costing 3-5 times as much.They have some ‘standard’ features, such as an In-Line microphone, cushioned headband and hinged/folding ear pieces. The nicely cushioned pads are removable and replaceable and the heads/ear pad holders pivot easily to help secure that ‘perfect’ fit.Additionally, these HM9s come with three interchangeable cables. These include  1) a 1.2 meter – about 4 ½ feet – flat cable, 2) a 3 meter (about 10 feet) – flat cable , and 3) a 1.2 meter cable with a microphone and control switch that worked perfectly with my iPhone. Flat cables are becoming increasingly popular as they are able to resist getting tangled or knotted up. The set also comes with a ¼” adapter that I was able to plug into my guitar amp to use the HM9’s as studio monitor headphones. A hard carrying case is also included.When it comes to the quality of the sound, they are hard to beat. For those to whom technical details are important: The drivers are dynamic, 40mm; Rated impedance is 40 ohms; Frequency range is a respectable 10 Hz to 24 kHz; Sensitivity is rated at 104 dB at 1 mW; and the Maximum input power is 1000 mW. For most of us, the technical stats matter less than the actual performance – i.e., How do they sound? The answer is simple: Superb!Listening to hard rock, classical, folk or jazz, the sound is ‘real life’ rich, smooth and complete. As an amp-connected studio monitor, you can hear your own instrument pretty much precisely as those listening would hear it – exactly what monitor headphones are for. The HM9’s are quite comfortable and light enough to be worn for extended periods of time while, at the same time, being substantive enough to support a nice sense of using a headset of real substance.There will always be a place for wireless devices, but for serious listening to a serious music experience, this wired HM9 set from Brainwavz is truly top notch.Disclosure:This item was provided to me at no or greatly reduced cost in exchange for an honest review. There you have it!

I was excited to find this cover was large enough to fit over a large outdoor table and six chairs. The tie-downs at the bottom seemed secure. What I did not anticipate was it's reaction to strong winds. The cover became a sail - sending the table and chairs blowing all over our newly built deck - doing quite a bit of damage to it. Also, the force of the wind (not extraordinary - 20-30 mph during some of the more billowy winter days. I sent it back and my payment was refunded.The furniture was placed in the most protected corner of the deck and yet, the cover became an uncontrollable sail.To be avoided anywhere that has substantial wind!

In my home, we use quite a bit of vanilla - both as a liquid extract and as beans. Really good vanilla beans are often a challenge to find. Those sold in supermarkets are often dried out and impossibly expensive. Given the invitation to try these Tahitian beans from Sigmeau, I jumped at the opportunity. I was not disappointed.Vacuum-sealed in clear plastic, these beans are still moist and conspicuously fresh - though appropriately aged. Their flavor is rich and sweet - and I have used them (in small pieces) in home-made vanilla ice cream as well as adding a small piece to our sugar bowl! The fact that Tahiti is suggested makes them taste even ...well... exotic!I do not believe it is possible to get real quality vanilla beans at a bargain price - On the other hand, most of my uses require only small pieces of the beans - so I expect these to last quite a while (stored in an air-tight container after opening the original plastic packaging.)These vanilla beans are absolutely succulent!

I am a fan of and use many motion-activated and light-up-when-dark solar lights around the house. This is the first one I have tried which offers the right options! (1. Lights when dark at 50% of the maximum lumens, 2. As #1, but comes to full power when motion is detected close by, and 3, Remains dark at night until motion is detected, then glows at full power.) It is absolutely the brightest and most versatile solar lamp I have found!The power source are two (included) 2200mAh batteries (18650.) They arrived about 1/2 charged and because the standards for 18560 rechargeable batteries are not firmly established around the world, other brands than those included may be either too long or too short to work with this lamp. I tried to use 2600 mAh Foxnovos - to hold additional storage power, but they were about 1/4" too long too long to fit the lamp.The back of the lamp opens ( a screwdriver is included!) to a compartment housing both the batteries and the function-selection switch. I advise leaving it open while you try the several functions before screwing the cover back on and mounting the light. Mounting screws and a mounting screw-template are also included. The unit is waterproof-rated at IP65 and should do OK during our rainy season.Although the lumen capacity is listed as 400, it actually generates 550 lumens. The 32 LEDs create, without a doubt, the brightest solar light I have used and I am delighted with it. At this price point, I do not believe there is one better out there - and I have looked!A really great light!Disclosure: This product was provided to me at no/significantly discounted cost in exchange for an honest review. There you have it.

This is a satisfyingly well-bound book, printed on (increasingly rare) premium paper that presents information often only suggested in brief paragraphs in the Sunday newspaper magazine supplement.I have always had an interest in strange things - people and places alike. In this Atlas of Cursed Places, Olivier Le Carrer has compiled a well-researched, appropriately illustrated with maps (as one would expect to find in an "atlas') and somewhat over-written accounts of 32 locales all over the world, of which I had previous awareness of only seven! I learned quite a lot in reading it.Each of the 32 places described in this volume have been  (and currently are) regarded as being 'cursed' by sometimes large groups of people. Some are well-known (the seven I was familiar with :-) and others, not so; at least as much by most North Americans who have never indulged in a study of the subject. The scope is world-wide and as most of us tend to be rather provincial in our scope of knowledge, there are many interesting surprises in this book.This is NOT a 'leave-it-on-the-coffee-table' for people to notice decoration. It is a well-researched and fascinating catalogue of some unusual places with unusual and sometimes unlikely 'histories' - and mythologies. They are all interesting stories.  This book is not a light-read and requires some sustained attention, tolerance for some arguably excessive verbiage as well as a reasonably literate vocabulary to really enjoy.Having just finished it, I must say that I learned quite a lot and found that new learning satisfying. Subtracting 'recreational' reading, learning is the object of spending time with a book in my opinion. In that way, I can recommend this guide. If you are looking for a one-over-lightly treatment of the subject of "cursed' places, this is not the right book for you.One star deducted for sometimes numbing over-writing, I can honestly recommend this book to anyone interested in the subject who has the time and ability to sustain focus enough to absorb some genuinely fascinating information.

I wear graduated prescription glasses. The upper part of the lens improves my distance vision, the middle is for computer distances and the lowwer part is for reading. I like them, but there are times when the thing I need to read or do is not made clear enough. At those times, I need more magnification and while my iPhone has a magnification APP, it is not always handy. This magnifying glass from Aoneky really does the trick.I have used it to read tiny print, dismantle small electric devices and examine the fine markings on old coins. The possible uses for a good magnifying glass are limitless - and this IS a good one. No distortion.  Held at the correct position between the object to be magnified and the user's eyes (a quick process that involves moving the glass closer and further away until the optimal clarity is achieved) the well-crafted solid glass lens, held firmly in a nice metal frame with an attractive wooden handle, does the job easily and reliably.Of course, it is not a prescription lens, so - for best results - if you wear prescription glasses, try keeping them on while you use this magnifying glass.Nicely constructed, clear lens and attractive in-and-of itself. A million possible uses!

Made of a single-layer of VERY soft cotton/poly blend, this hoodie is exactly what I was hoping it would be. Out of the washer and into the dryer - no wrinkles. Soft to the touch - no appreciable bulk to it at all. The front pockets do not zip, but are deep enough to use for most purposes.This hoodie is very comfortable, easy to care for and appears well stitched. The zipper functions smoothly and easily. It is not what you are looking for if you want something heavy for colder weather. I find that this hoodie works really well as a wind-breaker on a breezy, cool-but-not-cold day and/or as a casual top over a tee shirt.I stand 5'10" and generally wear the large size on most tops  With my 34" waist and 40" chest, the Large fits me perfectly.I find nothing to not like about this hoodie from Oxford NY and am pleased to be able to recommend it to any man looking for a comfortable, light-weight easy-care hoodie.

I have been a fan and frequent drinker of Pur Protein Shakes for several years now - they are great! But, sometimes, a solid energy-boost protein-laden snack is a lot more convenient - especially when there is no refrigeration! Given the opportunity to try and to review these bars from Pure Protein, I jumped at the opportunity. Although they have less protein per serving than do the shakes 20 vs. 35g, they taste quite good and fill the gap between meals nicely for me.The pack I received came with three flavors. Chocolate Deluxe, Chewy Chocolate Chip and Chocolate Peanut Butter. The nutritional differences among the three bar flavors are significant negligible - the taste is the different and they all taste just fine to me. I note that they do have significantly more carbs than the shakes do, but for someone wanting some extra energy to run on, carbs are a good thing (in moderation, of course.) When you get right down to it, the name Pure Protein is actually more appropriate for the shakes than it is for these bars.What they are called notwithstanding, they taste good, have a very palatable texture and provide some  protein boost with minimal sodium and sugars. I have less concern about the "Alcohol Sugars" than some other reviewers have as the amount is small and my research on the subject did not throw any red-flags for me. The substance is, actually, neither alcohol nor sugar but rather a standard thickening substance used in many foods.Yes, you can get more protein in other products - or more fiber or more carbs... but, for a great tasting snack that is NOT a meal but is a 'between meal' boost and treat, these Protein Bars have earned my top rating.
Light-weight, soft fleecy feeling - just right for a walk on a cool Fall morning! Mediums fit perfectly (my waist is 34, leg is 29/30.) A great value at this price!

I confess to being a BRAINWAVZ fan. I have used several of their products and have found them all to be reliable, well made and even the lower-end ones produce better than adequate sound. In this new S3 IEM set, they have outdone themselves. At a price that may seem kind of high to people accustomed to low-end earphones, they have produced what I feel is their 'top-of-the-line' set. These earphones include an in-line microphone and control and function as factory-made Apple headsets do with my iPhone.The flat cables are less readily tangled and render the entire set less bulky. The included hard-case makes storage a piece of cake. The range of ear-adapters included will allow these S3s to fit just about any imaginable human ear perfectly, and the sound ... well, I hesitate to offer a direct comparison, but suffice it to say that using the same pieces of HD recorded music, they performed at least as well as earphones I have that listed at 3-4 times their price. The overall harmonics sound true at all ranges and hold that clarity up to and including play at the highest possible volume. Outstanding!Although a relatively small component of these earphones, the microphone deserves some special mention as well.  Most of us know that in-line microphones are, at best, somewhat adequate. None deliver the 'hand-held-on-a-hard-line' sound that we really wish for. The microphone on these S3s come a lot closer to really good voice pick-up that any headphones (including those provided by Apple with my iPhone and iPad.) This was completely unexpected and turn out to be a significant issue for those of us who routinely use the phone between listening to music through the earphones.Structurally, there are no fancy earpieces that need to be figured out (an annoying recently popular design in may earphones.) These Brainwavz earphones simply plug into your ears - and fitted with the correct ear tips, they stay right there until you remove them.By design and by performance, these S3 earpohones are among the very best I have used - at any price!

The idea of combining a moisturizing/'plumping' product with good sunscreen protection is certainly an appealing one. Vitamin C, Hyaluronic acid,  Mannose and Neurosensine are found in many wrinkle 'removers' but rarely in combination with decent sun protection. Redermic C UV Moisturizer tries to do both. I got fair results with it - Fair in that the moisturizing/plumping ingredients DO (temporarily) make age wrinkles less conspicuous and the SPF-25 is generally adequate as far as it goes, but contains no active sun'block' ingredients, like Zinc Oxide. Anyone really concerned with sun protection - like myself as a melanoma survivor - would not rely on simple sunscreens any longer. Complete sun protection requires the addition of a compound that physically blocks the sun in addition to the more common ones, such as those found in this product, that offer essentially chemical protection. Sunscreen and sunblock are NOT the same thing.The product is easily applied and is less obvious than many other products. It does, however, dry into an almost solid, but thin, mask that is not particularly comfortable on the skin. The cost is significantly higher that using other skin plumping moisturizers and sunblock purchased separately but, for the sake of convenience, this is a handy product.For those who can afford it and are not satisfied with the results they are getting from other products, this Redermic C UV Moisurizer is definitely worth a try.

As an aging man with hair thinning on the back/top and along my forehead, my vanity was triggered and I decided, after reading many reviews, to give this Pura d'or shampoo a try. I use it in the shower every day and, as directed, leave it in my hair for a few minutes while I was the rest of my body. I was not expecting much. Even prescription Rogaine has limited results for most people. So, I was very surprised that after a few weeks, I could actually feel and SEE the difference.ould see the back/top of my head using mirrors and thought it looked less 'balding' but suspected I was kidding myself. So, I approached the truly objective and always truthful evaluator I live with - my wife - and asked her to honestly tell me if she could see any difference. AMAZING! She confirmed that my hair looked fuller and thicker - that there was a visible increase in hair on both areas where it had been conspicuous thinning. I am delighted and see no reason to discontinue using this Pura d'or shampoo.I am not an expert about these things - and certainly cannot guarantee that everyone who tries it will have the same results - but I can (and just have) shared my own experience.

I have tried a good many photo editing programs over the years. Everything from the ridiculously (and, for my purposes, unnecessarily) complex Adobe Photoshop programs to the simple, intuitive and free Picasa from GOOGLE. Being an impatient sort, I have would up continually returning to Picasa because of its ease-of-use. Finally, though, I began to get frustrated with the gap between what I really wanted to do with photos and the limitations of that free program. Years ago, I tried an earlier version of Paint Shop Pro but was overwhelmed by what it was and what it could do. I guess I have outgrown that impatience as I have begun to take my photography more seriously.I have loaded and am using this new PaintShop Pro X8 Ultimate - and, though there IS a learning curve and I realize that I will not be facile with all of its features and capabilities for quite a while, I am invested in devoting myself to using and learning it. I am encouraged by the fact that I have been able to begin with very simple actions and edits and can 'grow into' the impressive range of editing features this program offers as I either need or want to learn them.The details of this program's features have already been detailed in other reviews so I shall not reiterate them here. Suffice it to say that, overall, this PaintShop Pro compares quite favorably with Adobe's Photoshop Elements and actually has more features.A note about 'intuitive' software:Unless a person is a highly skilled photographer and photo editor, ANY program beyond the most basic is not going to be experienced as being 'intuitive.' This program, like other more advanced editing suites, is technologically complex - and, speaking for myself, none of it is truly automatic, or 'intuitive' to me. To use this program, if it is a step up for you, will demand a commitment of time and attention IF you hope to make good use of the multiplicity of editing options it offers. If there are 100 steps to learn the entire program, I write this review from step 5 or 6. I am not discouraged - On the contrary, I am challenged and excited to produce photos close to the way I can imagine them.

With this new "Crafter" Beard Boss kit from Remington (PG 6170), the standard Remington trimmer (the one sold as MB404 and the MB4045, which adds a pop-up trimmer to essentially the same device), some substantial improvements have been introduced. Both the 4040 and 4045 are very good trimmers - but there is always room for improvement and the Craftsman trimmer has done so. The shape of the trimmer is different - narrower near the head and, thus, a bit easier to aim with precision and the battery life is 3X as long as it is with the two other trimmers I have mentioned.  With 180 minutes of real use-time on a full charge, I can go for months of 1X week use without needing to recharge it.Also, the Crafter kit is simply loaded with accessories/attachments. Though many of them are geared, specifically, to use with longer beards, the range of possibilities the attachments provide is truly impressive. In addition to the more usual one or two length guide-combs, the Crafter sports six of them. Also included are two attachments I have never seen on a trimmer before _ a nose and ear hair trimmer AND a small ('mini') foil shaver! The pop-up trimmer on the back-side of the 4045 (which seems convenient but is quite awkward to position and use) has been replaced with a more useful and ergonomically facile detail trimmer blade head that can simply pop on to the handle just like the other blade does.I believe Remington's claim that this trimmer is waterproof and safe to use in the shower - but I will not be the one to test that particular feature as I find that I do a better job trimming my hair and beard if I do it in front of a large mirror without water falling all around me at the time :-)Together with the Titanium blades, Remington has produced a solid and versatile hair and beard trimmer. For the do-it-yourself groomer, it is an unarguably complete set of tools. I love it.

There are literally thousands of USB-Lightning cables available these days. What differentiates them? Function, of course. In the early days of Apple's switch over from the 30-pin to the Lightning (8-pin) connector, there were many after-market accessories and cables that were bogus and simply did not work. These days, most do work and the key variable, once functionality is established, is simply price.At this price point, I don't think you can go wrong with four of these cables from Kash Technologies.As soon as mine arrived, I tried out all four of them - each on two different devices - an iPhone5 and an iPad Air 2. In each instance, the cables worked exactly as well as those that came with the devices directly from Apple. No warnings about not compliant - no loose connections.An Apple user really cannot have too many charging and data-transfer cables. You never know where and when you might want/need one. THis four-pack is welcome.As to those who have had problems with me - perhaps the issues have been resolved by Kash - and since they offer a 100% guarantee (Lifetime) it is in their interests to get it right the first time; or, perhaps there are compatibility issues with specific devices and software (iOS) versions. I cannot say. What I CAN say, in all honesty, is that these worked just fine for me and I am glad to have them.Disclosure:These cables were provided to me at no cost in exchange for an honest review. There you have it!

This is an accurate, attractive and easy-to-read scale that sits quite low to the floor and requires no 'tap-first' action. By contrast, our previous scale looks rather bulky and rather difficult to read.There are not many things to evaluate about a scale. In fact, there are only two: Design and function.Design:The clear glass top of this Taylor Digital Bath Scale covers a marble-appearing application. It is noted that same reviewers have found the brand name, which is also printed on that marbled layer, a flaw in the design. I had no such reaction as pretty much ALL consumer products bear the name of the manufacturer. Would a Hamilton Beach blender only be appropriate for someone named Hamilton Beach? Silly. The surface is smooth and larger that we are accustomed to - but that is a good thing for those of us with larger feet!The grey marble appearance is, I thought, both neutral and attractive. It is hard to imagine a bathroom design with which it might 'clash.'Function:One simply steps on it and after a couple of seconds, the weight appears. It will read out in either pounds or kilograms - Mine arrived with the default setting on pounds, but that can be easily changed. Our previous scale had been professionally calibrated and this one gives the precise same readings, so its accuracy seems true.It is low to the ground so there is a very minimal 'step-on' to the scale and it requires no tapping to activate as many other scales do.The digital read-out is quite large and I can easily read it without glasses.It is powered by two (quite common and inexpensive) CR2032 batteries.In Summary:I honestly have nothing critical to say about this scale. I find it to be both attractive and accurate. I cannot comment on the durability of the glass top. Someone will have to drop it (or something on it) to est that out. I can only hope that will not be me!

Make no mistake. THis shirt looks well made and the fabric feels soft and smooth - BUT - if you are not a VERY slender man, don't bother - you will wind up returning it.I wear a L-XL shirt. I ordered the XXL based on the cautions from other reviewers. It fit my mid-section like a girdle - not comfortable at all. Skinny clothes for skinny people!

Inexpensive solar lights are a real boon to those of us who want some outdoor lighting - automatically at night only. I use them on the deck and they do a great job of keeping the nocturnal critters (raccoons and skunks) off the deck that adjoins our bedroom at night! These little lamps (little in size, but quite bright!) from InaRock are just right!Although both pieces of the lamps are plastic, they are easy to mount and seem adequately sturdy. They come with some screw-mounting hardware. I used velcro to mount them to vinyl posts on the deck. The 6 LED lights in each lamp create far more light than the size of the lamps would suggest and they are far brighter than others of this size that I have used.I did make and do recommend one adjustment before turning them on. They come with reasonably low power (600mAh) batteries - each unit uses only one of them. They are expected, with these batteries, to provide between 6 - 8 hours of lighting. I like mine to glow all night - from sunset to dawn. This was easily achieved by upgrading the batteries to 1500mAh ones that I keep a fully charged supply of. After a 10 hour night, they were still glowing just before the sun came up!All-in-all,these lights are a good deal. Simply constructed of adequately durable plastic and powered by a single 1.2V Li-ion battery, they have a decent waterproof rating and should last for a good many years. I am glad to be able to recommend them!

Black & Decker has been an important and reliable manufacturer of power tools and small appliances for many years. Unfortunately, their strength as drill and taster-oven makers are not apparent in this particular product. The 3W LED light, itself, is nice and does provide clear and adequate lighting for general lighting a desk space or for reading.The issues are with the reality of the lamp’s design and structure.As were others, I was surprised to find a plastic lamp at this price point. It IS heavy and feels solid for its size but is smooth, black plastic and shows each and every touch and smudge, The power and brightness level-setting button works sometimes – and sometimes it does not. The greatest frustration, design-wise, is the inability to rotate the light from the top joint. There is no rotational capacity whatever so to adjust the angle of the light, the entire lamp must be moved. I see that this is the case on at least one other LED lamp that B&D makes and I suspect that their lamps are designed by people who may not actually use them.The bottom line is this:It is difficult to recommend what appears to be an over-priced, inadequately designed lamp. So … I won’t. Black & Decker can and should be expected to do better. It would never have earned the good reputation it has producing things like this lamp.

I am a fan of magnetic cellphone holders in cars. UNlike the 'clamp' variety, one hand does the trick and there are no moving parts to get stuck or break. Until Vafee introduced this magnetic mount, the others I have known and tried have 'arms' on them that allow for the phone (or other device) to be mounted 2-4" away from the base. Also, the bases tend to be much larger than the rather petite stick-on base on this holder. I wondered what difference these two differences would make and was enthusiastic about trying this new holder from Vafee out.Also, this magnetic mount is smaller and, as a consequence, less obvious than any other I have ever seen. This is a plus that may also be a minus.I discovered the following:Because the mounting base is so small, it works perfectly for phones alone or with light-weight snap-on cases. With a heavier case (Otter, etc.) I do not think that the base would safely support the combined weight over time. The lack of an 'arm' means that the choices about where the magnet holder can be attached are limited. It works best, I found, on a fully vertical or near-vertical surface where there is room to maneuver the phone with the (very nice) rotating ball feature that allows for easy angular adjustment. Side window mounting is out as is any position requiring the phone to be even an inch or two above or below the base of the mount.The magnet, itself, is quite string and allows for the disks that we attach to our devices/cases to be significantly thinner than most other magnetic mounts require. This is a real bonus in that the disks are so slim that they can be easily mounted inside a phone case with no noticeable bulge in the case or problem with the case's correct fit on your phone.Bottom line:There are some placement limitations because of the lack or an arm that are compensated for by the smooth rotation capacity and sheer power of the battery itself. (I note that ALL car-mount holders have placement limitations that vary according to their design.)This is a very strong magnet with good adjustment/rotation capacity that works best with lighter-weight devices. As a fan of the lighter-weight snap-on type cases for my iPhone, this works quite well for me. If you have the right kind of dash and a reasonably light-weight device, this magnetic mount from Vafee will not disappoint. THis mount is small,strong and subtle and, with the right kind of mounting surface, angle and weight of device, works impeccably.

Hummingbirds where we live (in a superb north of San Francisco) are plentiful in some years and seem to have moved elsewhere during others. We keep a feeder out, even in slow years, just in case they care to stop by and visit outside our dining room window. In this drought year, when few hummers have come by, we decided to hang this truly stylish feeder and the accompanying spinner out. Three days later, they were back - as usual, in couples! Maybe it is "magical thinking," but this feeder and spinner seem to have been taken as a hearty welcome home to the hummingbirds!The feeder is truly lovely.  Heavy, antique-like glass, fashioned with true sturdiness. Once filled, there are two pieces that screw on which, once inverted, provide the feeding station. The bottle hangs from an attached metal loop which can be a tad awkward until you get use to hanging it by a hook from your favorite tree.The spinner gave me some pause, as I wondered if the 'glitteriness' of it might cause some shy hummers to fly off. I need not have been worried. Unlike some others, I chose to not hang the spinner to or along the same axis as the feeder - Rather, I hung it a couple of feet away. The fifth neighbor who stopped by to comment on the eset and ask where I got them came by just this morning.The feeder may be a bit unusual in that there is no 'perch' for the birds to sit on, but hummers feed perfectly nicely while in flight so there is no need for one. This is a fine set - Distinctive and attractive to both humans and hummers.

What I received was NOT an EPSON product, but an aftermarket piece intended to be identical to the one made by the manufacturer. It IS the same size and fits into the assigned position. However, the cotton-batten that is packed into the bottom does not lay flat inside it. I was unable to straighten it manually. As the original one lasted over a year and the indicator said it was full, I decided to replace it with this one anyway.One month later:No problems - but as is the case with after-market ink cartridges, I/we are taking some degree of risk using non-OEM products.

Now in my late 60s, many things about my body have changed. One of the more annoying of them is the ease with which I bruise - from what-were-once mild bangs and bumps to getting stuck bu a thorn on a rose bush while pruning - dark purple splotches now appear and take weeks to fade. Looking at these spots on my arms and the backs of my hands makes me feel that I am no longer getting older, but that I am, in fact, old. I hate that feeling! I had been searching for a product that might help and have tried many (vitamin E and C preparations, various ointments and creams, etc.) None of them did much. Until this Dermend Cream.With two applications a day (after an AM shower and before bed) to my hands and arms, substantially fewer of those purple bruises develop and those that do are gone within a few days. I am wearing short-sleeve shirts again! Nothing to hide.

Lovely fingerpicking here. Sometimes, I prefer instrumental music that is not burdened with the often not-so-musical sounds of a human voice - especially for relaxing. I am glad that Helen does not sing here - as it is hard to imagine a voice (excepting, perhaps, Joan Baez in her 20s) that would be good enough.Her version of Gershwin's "Rhapsody In Blue" is jaw-dropping magnificant and the traditional jigs are a delight.There is no substitute for real talent, and, in this CD, Helen Avakian certainly demonstrates that she has it!

This is a great watch for a great deal, but man it is huge.  Honestly, it's too big for my wrists (which are on the smaller side of medium).  Part of the size is the diameter (which is quite big), but also the sheer height of the watch.  The thickness from the back of the watch where the battery goes to the top of the bezel is, no kidding, as thick as my thumb is wide.  It stands up off the wrist over half an inch, maybe three-quarters of an inch.  But it looks really nice and would be a real head-turner if you can pull off big watches.  The colors (gold band around outside) and numbers are, if anything, even more striking in real life.  It has a nice turning bezel.  The band is super hefty and stout and actually pretty comfortable -- seems very well made.  The watch has quartz movement.In sum, I would highly recommend this watch (especially for the great price), but only if you are looking for a very big watch and can pull it off.

This is a really outstanding watch for what I think is a great deal.  It's a wonderful size (medium-ish for a woman, not too big but not too small), and has lovely rose gold highlights and nice white rubber band.  All the parts and hardware seem to be excellent.  It has Swiss quartz movement (hard to believe at this price!).  The appearance and finish is top notch all around, as seen in the photos I uploaded (one of them shows the face with the film cover still on it -- oops, didn't notice until I uploaded photo).  The outer edge of the face has a nice mother-of-pearl, which you can see in the light.  Really nice touch.  Overall this is a wonderful watch.  I'm beaming over the idea of giving it to my wife for Christmas!  Would definitely recommend.  One of those rare Amazon finds that is better in person than in the photos.

What can I say, this is a really nice little toy for my daughter.  She loves it and will sit and place the blocks for hours.  Now, the age says 4+ because you're supposed to use it for games that involve formulating sentences and telling stories, but my daughter is 2 1/2 and she loves it, too.  We'll use it for the intended purpose when she's a bit older.  But even now the pictures are so pretty, the blocks are so nice, and the little box they fit in works so well that she just loves it.  Best of all for Mom and Dad, the toy is fairly small, is easy to store, and seems to be made up to quality and safety standards.  Happy with this product and would recommend to others, especially as a nice small gift.

I really like this case and it's exactly what I was looking for.  I have tried and tested a lot of different phone cases and have not found many that really suited my tastes.  I like thin as possible, but also want protection.  This case basically provides that at the quality we have come to expect from OtterBox.  It is a pretty sleek case with a nice clear back.  The rubber edge is actually pretty thick to protect from falls, and the beveled edge helps protect the screen.  The quality really stands out in the button covers: they give a nice, firm, easy click (in contrast to cheap cases, which usually mess up the button covers).  As stated in my title, though, only two real complaints...  The first is that the case is very expensive at currently $40.  Much of the competition runs in the range of $15-30.  Second, despite costing so much, the case does not include a screen cover.  Ideally, I think, this case should come with a nice impact-resistant glass cover of high quality.  It's not hard to buy one aftermarket, but it would be a nice touch.Other than that, I can highly recommend this case.  Perfect for someone who wants some solid protection without the usual bulk.

I'm generally a positive reviewer on Amazon.  I get asked to review lots of items (in exchange for a complimentary product), and generally I pick things I like and want, and this results in positive reviews.  Sometimes, however, I'm very disappointed by a product and I say so honestly.  This is one of those times.  I have a bulky "protective" case on my phone and was hoping to get a sleek, slim thing in this Ozaki case.  Unfortunately, the whole product was very disappointing.  It's not *all* bad, some might like it, but this case did not work for me at all.The "backing" of the case is a really thin, cheap plastic.  I was expecting a rubbery type of quality plastic, but the backing of this case felt more like the *packaging* of a screwdriver you get at Home Depot.  It is a hard plastic (no rubbery texture to it at all), with a little flex -- but the flex comes from the fact that the plastic is so thin and cheap.  The backing did fit nicely on my phone -- I will give it that.  In fact, once I slipped the backing on, I temporarily thought this case could work out anyway.  Then I got out the plastic front piece.  It's a single piece of plastic that lays down over the face of the phone.  To their credit, they supplied an alcohol wipe pad and a soft cloth -- very good touch.  I cleaned my phone thoroughly.  Then I tried to put the screen cover on.  There was no way on earth to get this thing to lay down neatly without bubbles.  I followed the instructions, I tried everything, and eventually I gave up.  Even worse, the one time I got *really close* to getting the screen cover on with no bubbles, it was just slightly crooked and the edge would catch on things and get pulled up.  Basically, the design does not work.  Either they need a screen cover that actually sticks to the phone, or they need a backing that has a lip to pull over the screen cover and hold it down.  The design of this case has neither.  To be honest, I took this case off my phone and threw it in the trash.  It was that disappointing.  I would not recommend, even though the company generously supplied me with a free item in exchange for review.

This is my first processor and, I have to say, I would recommend it to others as a first processor as well.  It's relatively affordable, offers the full gamut of features, is durable, and has plenty of power.  This is not the best processor on the market, but it's plenty good for most purposes.  I use the machine occasionally for things like slicing potatoes and other fruits and vegetables, shredding cheese for various Tex-Mex dishes, and even some "fine" shredding of oats and other things for health foods.The size of the unit is nice.  The buttons and controls are intuitive, and the snap lid is nice.  Assembly is easy.  Most of the machine is dishwasher friendly (way better than handling sharp blades by hand).  It would be nice if the unit came with a storage case.  Our kitchen is tiny and my wife hates the sharp blades anywhere our daughter could find them.  But overall I'm pleased with this product and would recommend it for casual users.

Very pleased with this dog food.  Both my spaniels did really well on it.  I have to admit that one of them seemed not to like the taste as much, but the other chowed it down like none other -- probably depends on the dog.  It's a huge plus that it's grain free.  I find the price *a little* high for a grain free bag of this size, but not too much.  It's certainly more reasonable than some others on the market.  I would buy again.

We're very pleased with this picnic blanket.  We had been using a different one that was not living up to the demands of central Texas.  We used blankets for camping, fireworks, picnics, trips to the park, and festivals.  The problem is that it gets dry in the summer and there are stickers everywhere on the ground -- either that, or wet ground.  This blanket handles it all with ease.  The backing is a rubbery type material that is very water resistant (if not waterproof).  It holds out the moisture and is smooth enough that it doesn't pick up stickers.  The same goes for the top side, the blanket side.  It's kind of a smooth fleece material that feels similar to a chamois shirt.  It's not too "furry" like most fleece, so it doesn't pick up stickers.  Still very comfortable, though.  Best of all, the whole blanket is designed in such a way that it's easy to just hose off and leave to dry, especially after camping in dusty conditions.  Very nice blanket and good selection of colors.  Would buy again.I received a complimentary product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

This lamp didn't work out for me, but it's not entirely bad.  In this review, I'll try to spell out what's good and what I didn't like.  I'm probably a tough reviewer with desk lamps because I use them constantly and am very particular about what I get, but here are my thoughts:Pros:► Looks good► Has a sturdy base to keep it from tipping►  Two different settings help produce ideal amount of light► Has a decent amount of adjustability -- enough for meCons:►  I can't stand halogen.  They burn way too hot.  Not only is the bulb itself a hazard near my toddler, but the light emits heat by my desk (already a problem in Texas summers) and use a ton of energy.  Halogen is, in my opinion, the third worst bulb option on the market.  Fluorescents now come in such a huge variety of shades and types that only the most stodgy light bulb users find anything to complain about.  And LEDs are superior in every category, while using about one-eighth the energy.► The construction is a little weak on parts of this lamp.  For example, the points where the arms link together are fixed with some fairly weak screws, and the stem at the bottom wobbles a bit.► The hood gets blazing hot.  This is connected to the halogen thing -- a problem that simply does not exist if you use LED bulbs.►  The price is, quite frankly, outrageous.  There is no way this lamp is worth $40.  I would peg it at about $10, maybe $15.

This is by far the best humidifier I have ever owned.  I have previously used (and reviewed) three other humidifiers, all at a significantly lower price point.  This PureGuardian H8000B combines all of the best qualities I have found in others and adds some excellent new features that make it well worth the price for people serious about having a good humidifier to treat their home.  Here are the highlights of what I think this product gives you over the competition:►  Among the best features is the Smart mist sensor, which automatically adjusts output to reach the desired humidity level.  This is super nice.  Over time you will develop a good sense of what humidity level is right for your house, and this helps achieve it at maximum efficiency and with little fuss.►  Like some other PureGuardian humidifiers, this one uses Silver Clean technology to ensure that it fights mold and mildew on the water tank and does not spew it into your air.► It has a variety of other features to adjust run time, speed, output, etc.  Very versatile.►  The humidifier is very quiet despite a very powerful mist output.►  The extender chimney thing is really nice, as it allows the mist to be dispersed higher above the ground into the air, both preventing moisture from accumulating on surfaces, and generally to help spread the mist throughout your house.  Also, I always find that it's good to set ceiling fans on reverse spin (sucking air up, instead of blowing down -- there's a sliding button on the side of most fans for this) to help pull the mist up into the room and circulate it.►  Finally, the humidifier looks great whether on a table or on the floor.Overall, I highly recommend this humidifier.  Although it's expensive, it does the job and does it well, and helps keep our house at a comfortable humidity level.  Essential for winter!

This is a very nice umbrella with all the features I want.  There are four main things I look for in an umbrella.  (1)  Does it open and close easily: are the mechanisms well made and easy to operate?  (2) Is is durable, well made, and does it hold water?  (3) Can it withstand wind?  (4) Is it reasonably nice looking?I'm pleased to say that this umbrella meets all those criteria.  The mechanisms are strong and so far have no issues.  It's easy to open and close.  The nylon material is nice and well-made without being too heavy.  It looks good.  And the two-tier design makes it better withstand gusts of wind.  I'm also very happy with the size.  I hate overly small umbrellas that don't provide enough coverage, but nobody wants a super giant umbrella that looks comical and makes everybody else on the street dodge and duck when you walk past.  This umbrella is large but not too big -- just the right size for me, actually.  And for $24, it's a great deal.  Highly recommended.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

I have about half a dozen of these battery packs now (in both cars, in my office, and a couple around the house), and this is my favorite one now.  First, I mainly just like the size, feel, and look of this one.  It's about iPhone size, but nice and sleek.  The capacity is fairly large so I can charge several devices with it.  And it has two USB ports (many have only one).  One of these USB ports is 2.0 amps, which is good for bigger devices like tablets, and the other port is 1.0 amp, which is good for most phones.  I actually charge my phone through the 2.0 most of the time, because I think iPhones take 1.5 amps and this makes it pull that full charge.  But the 1.0 amp works also.  The battery pack also has an on/off switch.  I saw that a few other reviews consider this a con, but not me.  It's great when, for example, you're using it in the car and want to turn off the battery pack's draw from the car.  Then just turn it back on when you get back in the car.  There is a nice indicator light to let you know approximately how much juice is left.  I can charge two iPhones from this battery pack when it's full and that's all I've ever needed.  Very pleased with the product, and the price is reasonable.  Highly recommended.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

What can I say, I love this charging cord.  There are two main things I like about it.  (1) It has both micro-USB and Apple Lightning adapters, increasing its versatility.  I use it for both all the time and it works great -- no connection problems ever.  I can charge my battery packs with the micro-USB, then plug in my iPhone to the Lightning charger.  (2)  I love the color and even the look of the cord.  My electronics drawer is stuffed with plain black and plain white cords, but I can always find this one because the bright green makes it stick out.  Plus it has a flat shape instead of round, which is unique and nice.  Everything works great, just as advertised, and the price is reasonable.  Highly recommended!I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

This is my third pair of electronic earmuffs.  Each one has different advantages and disadvantages, and that's true of these Peltor RangeGuards as well.  My other ones are the Howard Leight Impact Sport OD Electric Earmuff, Green, and the Peltor Sport Tactical 100 Electronic Hearing Protector.  I will be comparing these other models to the RangeGuards throughout this review.  I hope it doesn't get too confusing: my intention is to help people doing some serious shopping to get an idea of how different models stack up against each other.  The short version is that I think the RangeGuards are the best VALUE and better overall than the Howard Leights, but not as good as the Peltor Sport Tactical 100s (which cost $75).  Read on for detailed explanation.I assume that most people shopping on this page know what electronic earmuffs are for, but just in case here is a brief description.  They are designed to block out loud noises like gunshots while amplifying normal-volume noise like voices.  This means you can wear them at the shooting range but still hear your buddies talk without removing your ear protection.  You could also use them for the same purpose at something like NASCAR: voices amplified so you can hear your son asking for an ice cream cone, but car engines dampened by the muffs.  In both cases, it's a huge advantage.  I have found them especially useful hunting.  You can actually hear, say, doves taking off or flying in with the amplified sound, but of course your ears don't get hammered by the shotgun blasts.These RangeGuards have an array of good features for the price.  The headband folds and adjusts easily, and it's actually pretty comfortable.  The battery slots is easy to access.  There is an audio input jack for the headphones.  You could play music through it, but I think it's intended for things like bionic ears.  The on/off button works well, and there is an auto-off feature so you don't drain the battery when not in use.  I can usually feel the button even with gloves (thin gloves anyway).  The sealing pads on the RangeGuards are really well made and work effectively on a wide range of heads (as far as I can tell).  Everyone who has tried them has gotten a good seal, which is essential for them to work right.  By contrast, my Howard Leights have hard, thin sealing pads that never seem to work right.  RangeGuard wins on that count: its pads are plush and seal well.  My only complaint is that they are plastic, which can get a little sweaty (and make your ears inside rather hot).  Leather would be nice, but hey, these are only $45.So why do I say they're not as good as the Peltor Sport Tactical 100s?  Mainly I think they are built a little more lightweight.  They are smaller and more low-profile than the Sport Tacticals, and I think they might have smaller speakers and perhaps a lower-grade mic.  Granted, the difference is not THAT noticeable, just minor.  The Sport Tacticals are $75, though, and the RangeGuards are $45, so that probably indicates the difference.  I also notice that various parts on the Sport Tacticals are nicer, like a more padded headband, and apparently beefier construction of the muffs and headband.  But I still think the RangeGuards are an excellent, affordable option, and the perfect electronic earmuffs to keep on hand for guests you take with you to the range.  Highly recommended.

This is a great heat gun that comes in handy for a lot of different home improvement projects.  You can use it to remove tape or adhesives, to strip paint, to help dry paint, to dry things in general (like air-sensitive wood glue), to melt ice out of your gutters so they flow again (a big one!!!), and so on and so forth.  I just got this thing recently and haven't yet been able to apply it to all these tasks, but I have used it for two different things (both rather ingenious, I like to tell my wife).  The first is that I used it to "melt" (really to soften and bend) plastic tubing for a backyard playscape project I constructed for my daughter.  It worked wonders.  My wife was amazed and everybody asks how I did that.  I tell them brute strength.  It was the Makita.  Shhh.  I wasn't sure if it would work for the second project, but it did.  Our dishwasher quit working and I didn't want to pay the repair guy.  So, long story short, I looked up DIY online and figured out how to replace the control panel and mother board, duly ordered the parts, and went to work.  There was only one really technical aspect to the project.  You had to "solder" a piece of plastic together.  I used the heatgun, and despite a few false starts (I'm no expert), it ended up working.
