No way I could've done it otherwise.As for the product itself, it's well constructed in general and works as advertised.  The body feels solid and the handle is comfortable.  I like how the nozzle puts out air in a small area.  You can buy other nozzles (I haven't yet -- want to).  The dial is a great concept, but I found that it wiggles during use and can easily bumped off the setting.  Just be mindful, especially if you want low heat and suddenly it's blazing hot.  In short, everything worked great and I'm happy.I would really rate this 4.5 out of 5 stars, but I give it 4 for two reasons.  First, the dial wiggles a bit during use.  It needs to hold its setting a little stronger.  Second, the main one, is that I would like to see a better/stronger/more versatile stand to affix the Makita in certain positions, at various angles, so that I can use both my hands to hold whatever it is I'm putting under the heat.  Granted, it comes with some rubber feet, but I think more would help -- maybe even some kind of tripod like thing that stands upright.Other than that, this is a great product at a reasonable price.  It has all kinds of DIY home improvement uses.  Honestly, people, buy this thing if only to melt the ice in your gutters.

This is probably my fourth set of clippers and ranks toward the very top, with the benefit of probably being the best value of any clippers I own.  Below I will give you a rundown of the good features of these clippers, but first my own personal reason of why you should buy a pair of clippers at all, whether it's these or another model.  They can save you a ton of money.  I have been cutting my own hair for years (and do a very good job of it) and each time, every 3-4 weeks, this saves me about $20, maybe more, over what I would spend at the barber.  The savings are even more extreme if you factor in the cost of pet grooming.  We have two spaniels that need regular haircuts and I do both of them myself (with Wahl clippers, incidentally).  Each time, this saves us $50-75 per dog every few months.  Clippers will very rapidly pay for themselves.  Properly taken care of (oiling before, during, and after use, and keeping them clean), they will last for years.  Even the blades on our other Wahl Elites have lasted ages and shown no sign of reduced cutting ability.  Definitely buy clippers if you have any inclination to save this unnecessary expense.  You will not regret it.  OK, now the features of these particular clippers.►  I have been using the Wahl Elites in the rechargeable lithium model, which I love (I think Wahl updated the lithium version they sell, but similar thing to the one shown in the comparison chart on this page).  My review is somewhere on Amazon.  The clippers are excellent and totally reliable -- they are my regular go-to clippers, even though I own a pair of Andis clippers that cost me around $140.  I mainly like the cordless lithium design, but these Wahl Elites in the corded version are a MUCH better value and probably slightly better in terms of motor.► The Wahl elite blades are MOST EXCELLENT.  They are very sharp, produce a very even, clean cut, and last for ages.  As I mentioned, I oil these things religiously (get a big jar of clipper oil if you use them much) and that helps them last longer.  They are very high quality blades that do great on a wide variety of hair textures, both thick and fine.  To top it off, the blades have a 5 year warranty.► The motor on the corded version sold here is fairly quiet and smooth, even better than the Lithium.  They have a really solid, expensive, low rumble sound similar to my Andis.  I'm very happy.  I think the motor on this thing is probably the best of any product Wahl sells.► The cord is super long (8 feet) and that helps in all sorts of ways.  Cheap clippers give you a short little cord that always get in the way.  These clippers, for only marginally more, give you a super thick, long cord to make sure it never holds you back.► The blade guides offered by Wahl are top notch, in my opinion.  The reason is that they slide securely into place and hold their position, unlike many other cheaper offerings that clip into place and fall of at the worst moments.  This model also gives you a lot of different blade guides (14) to make sure that every length is covered.  The range of lengths is really outstanding with this model and is better than probably any other clipper at the same price point.► For fine adjustments of cutting height, there is a blade adjuster that lets you retract the cutting edge in small increments.  This is perfect to help smooth the transition between, say, 1/4" and 3/8" on the side of one's head.  Works really well.  Just practice with it and you'll figure it out.  Great feature to help get "between sizes" when you have a limited number of clipper attachments.► The motor tends to run fairly cool and I have not experienced any excessive heating with the limited usage I give it.  To keep the blades cool, I recommend some cooling spray for clippers.  I think there are a few different brands.  This stuff basically cools down the metal at the same time as it lubricates the blades.  I use it when I clip the dogs and it keeps me going for a long time without letting the blades get hot (which would damage them, since the metal gets soft at high temperatures).Well, I think that's about it.  Overall I'm very happy with these clippers and would highly recommend to anyone.  While I think my Andis clippers are higher quality, they cost like $140.  While I use my Wahl lithiums the most, the motor is not as good as these, and the model # I have cost quite a bit more.  Dollar for dollar, these Wahl Elite 79602s might be the best clippers you can buy.  Highly recommended.

I have been using aftermarket toner replacements for almost a decade now and have found most of them to be fairly reliable.  This one is no exception.  In fact, I would rank this V4INK toner toward the top of the replacement toners I have used.  Quality can vary fairly significantly.  A few toners by another brand produced very uneven ink coverage (poor contrast; white lines when pictures were printed, etc).  Another one left splotches and marks on the page.  You never quite know what you're getting, but I have still always bought replacement toners because the cost is so much better than the outrageous $45 that Brother chargers for its brandname toners.I'm happy to report that the V4INK stands up well to my tests so far.  It prints very clear, bold, high contrast text.  The blacks are super black.  There is no running or splotching on the white page.  I actually got to subject this toner to some extra serious testing because I was running my Brother laser printer on a SERIOUSLY worn out drum cartridge that had caused print quality consistently to decline.  I put in the new V4INK toner and gave it a try.  New life came out of my drum cartridge!  The blacks were actually bold and clear!  I only printed a limited number of pages this way and finally changed the drum.  The V4INK continued to perform well.  The biggest test came when I printed an old book that had been scanned into PDF form.  The pages were not only grayish from the tint of the scans (a real ink hog, but oh well), the book also contained many photographs.  In the past, printing such books has produced very uneven results, usually streaks on the photos.  But the V4INK performed very well and produced super clear, sharp photographs as well as consistently good contrast on the text.  What more can I ask for?  I doubt a Brother cartridge could top this for twice the price.Long story short, I'm happy with this toner cartridge.  It's a bit more expensive than some other offerings (which go as low as $12), but it also seems to be somewhat better quality, approaching the $45 Brother cartridge.  Since it's a TN450, it is supposed to print up to 2600 pages at 5% coverage.  I find that 1500-2000 is more common under normal usage.  Since it might take some weeks for me to print that much, I will have to report back about its longevity.  For now, I'm just happy with its performance with a variety of printing tasks.  Highly recommended.

This is a very solidly built light that does exactly what it's advertised to do.  As you probably know from the product description, this light casts an intense red light instead of white.  It does so by means of the LED bulb itself, not from a red lens, making the light truer and brighter than "filter" options for normal flashlights.  The purpose of the red light instead of white is that it is less detectable by animals whose eyes detect a narrower spectrum of light.  Red light and green light, theoretically, is invisible to animals, and therefore it is favored by hunters who either use the light for spotlighting, or who trek through the woods at night and want to do so without scaring away animals in the vicinity.►  Now a little more about the light.  The construction is very solid and the light feels very heavy duty in the hand.  The body is constructed of 6061T aluminum and is water resistant.  This does NOT feel like a cheap flashlight: it feels like a flashlight made to handle a beating.► The light is covered with nice texturing all over to aid grip under all sorts of conditions.  The twisting cap at the bottom is textured to help screw on and off for accessing the battery compartment.  The middle of the handle is textured for grip.  Even the head of the light is textured.  This not only makes it look cool, it gives the grip you need whether using with gloves or bare hands.► The light itself is good, but I say this with some reservation.  350 lumens is pretty bright compared to ordinary flashlights, but it will your effective shooting to maybe about 30 yards or so.  This is just a guess.  The light can reach farther, but I'm not sure it would illuminate the target well enough to stretch beyond about 30.  The second reservation is that the red light is fairly hard on human eyes.  "Hard" in the sense that, even though we can see it, our eyes have to strain to process this color for very long.  The light would be best for quick bursts of use when you want to shoot or whatever, but not for prolonged periods "staring into the red."► The other parts on the light work well and have caused zero problems for me.  The switch on the bottom works perfectly.  The lanyard is a nice touch.► A final word is in order about the batteries.  I think the 18650 batteries are awesome.  For those new to them, they are basically a giant, long battery unlike anything typically available in the local Home Depot.  They are specially for flashlights.  The advantage of the 18650 battery is that they last a long time, have high energy output (meaning they can power brighter lights), slow discharge in storage, little memory (meaning you can recharge at any time and not damage battery), and in general good qualities.  If you don't mind charging batteries instead of buying them, you should definitely get a flashlight that takes 18650s.  They are way better than AAs or anything of that kind.► Speaking of batteries, please note that there are two options for this light.  One, slightly cheaper, consists of the flashlight only (no batteries).  The other, slightly more expensive, includes batteries and a charger.  If you already have 18650s, you obviously can get the light alone; otherwise buy the more expensive (I think $28?) option and get the 18650 battery and charger.  It's easy to use and you will like it.  Additional batteries are available for a very low cost all over Amazon.In general, I think this is a very worthy hunting light if you want to minimize your detection by animals at night (whether for shooting or for walking), but be aware that you are getting an unusual red light.  Otherwise, highly recommended!

This squirt gun is decent enough for what you get.  The main selling point is that it sprays four streams of water instead of one, allowing for more soakage I guess.  My daughter enjoys it.  Unlike many squirt guns, however, the spray comes from the action of running the pump, not from pumping air into a tank and pulling the trigger.  This has advantages and disadvantages.  The disadvantage is (1) that it requires two hands to use; and (2) that you cannot spray a steady stream; each pump gives you a quick burst, until the next pump does it again.  The advantage is that the power of your pump determines the power of your squirt, and this often means that every squirt is pretty powerful.  By contrast, an air-tank gun does that thing where it starts out powerful until the pressure peters out.  The build construction and durability is about what you'd expect.  I actually think the pump mechanism will last longer than many tank-based squirt guns because it's not so important for the seals to hold over time.My main complaint is actually NOT the pump action design, which I kind of like.  Rather, it's that the tank is way too small to make very good use of the four barrels, which are the main selling point.  It's only 35 ounces.  You'll blaze through this in no time.  I understand they are trying to keep this light enough for kids to enjoy, but a slightly bigger tank would be a really nice touch.  Everything else could stay the same.  Otherwise, I'm happy with it.  Hard to go wrong for only $16.

We're really happy with this little LED lantern.  It's perfect for hanging in the tent (which is how we've used it), for emergency purposes, or even for a spare glovebox light.  It's small, lightweight, well built, and casts a very strong light.  The workmanship (such as the threads and aluminum body) is very good.  As far as I can tell, the cylindrical glass cover is pretty stout and should last a long time.  I tested the magnet and found the same as other reviewers did: as long as the metal surface is smooth, it sticks.  But some textured or covered surfaces (like a fridge) do not hold the light very well.My only big reason for giving it 4 stars instead of 5 is that the battery is so specific.  Now, to be fair, I have a charger for 16340 batteries, but I had to special order some ONLY for this light.  For many people, I imagine it could be hard to keep such batteries on hand and charged up.  Since it is a relatively small light anyway, it would be nice to have it offered in a AA version for people want who total versatility.  But this is a small complaint.  Newer battery sizers as well as rechargeable batteries are becoming more common, so most will be able to adjust.  Highly recommended.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

What can I say, this is an excellent cord for my Apple iPhone 6.  Everything works perfectly, exactly as advertised.  I especially love the long 6-foot length (other options available, obviously), which allows me to stretch the cord from the plugin up to my desk where my phone sits.  No more dealing with annoyingly short Apple cords.  This is a great substitute for a great price.  Highly recommended!I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

This is a very nice armband case for a truly excellent price (many competitors cost twice this much or more).  I consider this case to have all the essential features for use in such activities as running, hiking, exercising, or walking around all day (if you want your phone on your arm), but it has two shortcomings that I explain at the end.  First the good:► The case itself is a nice, flexible, durable silicone rubber that holds the phone snugly and feels comfortable on the arm.  Because it's so flexible, it's easy to get the phone in and out, but at the same time it holds it securely.  I have done a lot of running with this case, wearing it on my upper arm, and it has worked great.► The band is equally good -- and this matters just as much.  It is basically a giant strap of elastic, but the material is softish and absorbs sweat pretty well, so it stays comfortable even while exercising.  The Velcro is REALLY strong: there should be no problems with it coming unattached.  The strap also has a lot of adjustment room.  You can cinch it really tight, or you can let out a lot of strap for big arms.  Well done Mediabridge.► There is, thankfully, a headphone jack at the bottom of the case for those of us who wear headphones while exercising.Now for the two things that I think could be improved.  First, most importantly, the top of the case covers the light sensor on the phone, which in turn affects the brightness of your screen.  At first, I thought this would be a problem.  Since the case covers the sensor, the screen gets dim, but the phone is usually used on the armband when outdoors where it is bright.  To fix this problem, just go into your phone settings, click "Display and Brightness," turn off "auto brightness," and turn up the brightness manually with the sliding bar.  It's really easy.  Just have to do it real quick each time using the case.The second thing that could be improved are the button covers for volume and screen on/off (on right side).  There ARE little raised pieces of rubber to help you find the buttons, and these actually work correctly, but when running with sweaty hands or when trying to move quickly, it's kind of hard to feel where the button is through the tiny raised button covers on the case.  This is a small complaint, but more prominent, or perhaps textured, button covers would be nice.These things aside, I think this is a great case.  The quality is good, the overall design is good, and the price is amazing.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

These are very nice and useful ice cub trays that work just as advertised.  As explained in the product description, you get two trays with eight molds each, for a total of 16 cubes.  For only $11, this is a really good price.  The trays are advertised especially for whisky and other alcoholic drinks, and I use them this way myself, but they are also great for a glass of water and seem to last longer than lots of small cubes.  One other positive point about using these for whisky.  A single large cube works much better than multiple small cubes.  Why?  Because it melts slower and prevents your whisky from getting watered down too fast.The material is a flexible rubber that makes it easy to pop the ice out when it's ready.  My only complaint (and it's a small one) is that I wish there was some kind of rigid plastic frame on the bottom to keep the tray from flopping.  The same flexible rubber that makes the cubes easy to pop out also means you have to exercise a bit of care when they are full of water, or else the tray will flop and spill a little.  Just place your hands firmly underneath as you slide it into the freezer and it will be fine.  A rigid piece on the bottom might prevent this from happening while also allowing the cube molds to be soft rubber.  Other than that, I love the tray.Overall this is a very excellent product and I highly recommend.  Great for whisky, great for glasses of water, great in general.  My visitors always remark on the cool big ice cubes I serve them.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

Sugar and Slaves is a study of the English planter class in the West Indies during the seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries.  It fills a void in seventeenth-century English history that is crucial to understanding the origins of the British Empire.  The book is divided into two parts.  In the first half he deals with the establishment of the English West Indian colonies of St. Christopher (1624), Barbados (1627), Nevis (1628), Montserrat and Antigua (1630s), and Jamaica (1655).  He then discusses the subsequent histories of each island in the seventeenth century by drawing upon travelers’ accounts, demographic records, inventories, land patents, maps, and plantation records.  In the second part of the book he uses the material topically to discuss in sequence the themes of sugar, slaves, life, and death in the islands.  His purpose is to answer three complementary questions: how did English planters in the West Indies respond to the novelty of life in the tropics?  to the novelty of large-scale sugar production?  and to the novelty of slave labor?His answer to the first question is that white planters found great difficulties coping with heat, exotic flora and fauna, food and drink, disease, hurricanes, and distance from home.  On the whole the English failed to adapt their dietary habits, clothing styles, and architectural preferences to suit the tropical climate.  Mortality was thus frightfully high and by the eighteenth century most planters became absentee owners of plantations that were often dreadfully mismanaged on the ground.  The introduction of sugar production in the 1640s led to the most distinctive transformations of the West Indies.  The high demands of labor for sugar cultivation and refining meant that planters looked increasingly to African slaves rather than indentured European servants.  Barbados, the Leeward Islands, and Jamaica became the first locations of large-scale slavery.  These labor demands, Dunn argues, set the West Indies apart from the North America colonies, despite their similar origins and the similar structure of the plantation economies.  Dunn also suggests that high mortality, unfavorable climate, inappropriate housing, and unfamiliar food made living conditions particularly difficult for the English planters, despite the wealth of sugar growing, and eventually forced the institution of slave labor to develop as an alternative to European indentured servants.  The wealth of the colonies, however, created huge gaps in wealth among white workers, especially the poor, whose mortality rates and living conditions were just as bad as African slaves.Sugar and Slaves is a well written and valuable account of the English West Indies during the seventeenth century.  It is essential reading to all students interested in the origins of the British Empire and the peculiarly strong West Indies sugar lobby that would later play such a profound role in the British parliament in Westminster.

The Empire Project is a wide-ranging study of the British Empire that surveys the period from 1830 to 1970.  Darwin is widely regarded as one of the leading historians of the British Empire, and this book has been called his life's work and magnum opus.  Describing the British empire as a ‘system’, rather than an ‘empire’ in the traditional sense, allows Darwin to analyze under a single framework both formal and informal empire as well as the full range of Britain’s constitutional, diplomatic, political, commercial, and cultural relationships.  The starting date itself is highly significant and underscores Darwin’s conception of a ‘world-system’.  It is true that by beginning the book in 1830 he omits the early phases of British imperialism.  But the preceding period ‘was less the classical era of British world power than its turbulent pre-history’, Darwin writes, ‘when prevailing conditions remained very uncertain’.  Only in the 1830s and 1840s did favorable conditions converge ‘for the growth of the loose decentralized construct that sustained British world power into the 1940s’ (p.18).  The system that emerged was characterized by the interdependence of its parts, based on four pillars that upheld British power.  British naval and military preeminence held together the strategic points and ensured British access to trade and resources; British commercial strength connected overseas territories to a global trading system centered on Britain; demographic growth provided migrants to Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and South Africa and thereby strengthened Britain’s connection to its settler colonies; and a global network of communication, centered on Britain, facilitated the spread of news, information, and personnel, and allowed Britain to promote the unity of the system.  Because this system was diverse and the power exercised over it was diffuse, Darwin focuses on what he calls ‘imperial politics’ – the ‘almost continual debate over the terms of association by which the various member states (including Britain itself) were bound to the British system’ (p.8).At the heart of Darwin’s study lies a reconsideration of the global context within which the British imperial system existed in the period between 1830 and 1970.  Darwin argues that the British empire, as a global world-system, first expanded and later declined and fell according to the opportunities and challenges presented by geopolitical events occurring around the world, many outside the empire and beyond British control.  Geopolitical change determined the fate of the British world-system in part, he argues, because the empire lacked a master plan and developed instead as a haphazard collection of disparate elements, presided over by London but guided largely by the schemes devised by private enthusiasts (like Cecil Rhodes) and by ‘men on the spot’ whose ambitions for expansion sometimes complemented and sometimes flouted the policy of the British government.  ‘British expansion’, he argues, ‘was driven not by official designs but by the chaotic pluralism of British interests at home and of their agents and allies abroad’ (3).  The success of the British world-system, since it depended upon bringing together its disparate parts, thus required specific conditions – a balance in Europe, a ‘passive’ East Asia, stability in the colonies, a globally competitive British economy, and an unaggressive United States – the absence of which would cause the imperial system to break down.  ‘The key to British power’, Darwin argues, ‘lay in combining the strength of its overseas components with that of the imperial centre, and managing them – not commanding them – through the various linkages of ‘imperial politics’: some persuasive, some coercive, some official, some unofficial’ (13).The international dimension in Darwin’s study holds interest for the present discussion because it attempts to shift the geographical focus from the internal developments of Britain and the colonies – whether formal or informal – to the wider world, and particularly to the regions outside the empire whose developments impinged directly on the fate of the British world-system.  ‘British possessions,’ he writes, are only ‘parts of the larger conglomerate’ (6).  The links between colonial territories and other parts of the system, and the ‘exogenous’ forces of the global environment, exerted a constant pressure on the terms of the British connection.  ‘Their collective effect’, Darwin writes, ‘was to create an “external” arena of extraordinary turbulence before 1900, and of volcano-like chaos in the twentieth century’ (8).

I got this solar light a month or two ago and am pleased to report that it works very well.  I placed the light under a tree (but not in shade) so that the light shines upward on the trunk and underneath the tree at night.  Everything about the light was simple to use and simple to set up.  I never even opened the instructions: everything was totally intuitive.  Within five minutes I had this light up and running, and it has worked great ever since.The light consists of two parts when you get the package: the stake, and the light unit with solar panel attached.  Simply stick the stake in the ground, insert the light, adjust the angle as needed, and it's ready to go.  There are fly bolts to adjust angle of the light and solar panel.  Loosen to adjust; tighten to hold things in place.  There is an easy on-off switch and an adjuster for high or low intensity light (I chose low).  It was all super easy.The tree I placed this light under is tall and upright and therefore allows plenty of light to get to the solar panel.  I faced the panel directly south and it seems to get a very strong charge every day.  On the low intensity setting, I find the light still running in the dusk hours of morning.  The only caveat to this is that on one or two super dark, rainy days, the light seemed to get a weak charge.  Even in the early parts of the night, the light was pretty dim.  By morning, it was off.  But, on a normal day, even on a partly cloudy day, it seems to get a charge strong enough to go all night.  The high intensity setting is very bright and might not run all night.  I have avoided using it because it might bother the neighbors.Now for the rain and waterproof issue.  Let me begin by saying that this light can handle rain and keep running.  That said, for some reason, when it rains, the light turns off and usually stays off until everything is dry.  I can't tell if this is because of a tiny leak that shorts the connection, or because of an auto-off feature that turns it off in wet conditions.  At first, when this happened, I was worried that the unit couldn't handle outdoor use.  As it turned out, however, the light bounces back to full strength as soon as it is dry again.  This is good enough for me: it keeps working.  Who cares if it temporarily shuts off in wet conditions.Overall I'm very happy with this light and love the attractive glow it casts in my landscape.  It also adds a measure of security near our back gate.  The price is fair.  So far everything works as advertised.  I will report back if there are any longevity issues, but, to be honest, I don't expect it will have too many problems.  You can always replace the battery when it wears out.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

I got these lights with the intention of hanging them beneath my pergola as low-key, ambient outdoor lighting for those times when I have friends over in the evenings.  It turns out that this kind of usage is perfect.  The wires on these lights are very thin and therefore probably not the best for using as Christmas lights, since they might not stand abuse quite as well.  But to hang and use occasionally in the same place, they work very well, and the thin wires make them more discreet.  I simply hung them on hooks on the inside bottom of the pergola, ran the cord down the pole, and I can plug them in with an extension cord whenever I need to.The design and workmanship of the lights seems very good.  In any case, they are working great so far.  The color is really unique and attractive.  As seen in the picture, it's kind of an amber color, not "soft white."  It casts an orangish/yellowish glow that is very nice.  Definitely reminds me of outdoor seating at a nice pub or restaurant.  This was a welcome relief, since many LED Christmas lights are so blindingly bright that you wouldn't want them for ambient light; but these "warm white" lights are perfect.  So far my wires are holding strong.  Even though they are outdoors permanently, they are holding up.  Note well that my lights are NOT in the sun, but are shaded by vines and the pergola structure.  Can't speak to how well they would hold up if exposed to the sun all the time.Finally, I think the price is reasonable.  They cost $20 for 20 feet, but I think that's OK.  You can certainly get LED lights a bit cheaper, but these have the advantage of (1) unique color; and (2) very thin wires that look more attractive when used as decorative lighting (as opposed to Christmas-light stuff).  Even if mine only last a few years, I would still consider it a decent price.  Just think what lightbulbs cost and you can see that these are no half bad at all.Overall five stars for a great product, unique color, and reasonable price.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

Darwin is one of my favorite historians of the British Empire, and this book, one of his first, is an under-appreciated classic in the field.John Darwin’s book is a study of imperial policy in the Middle East during the four years following the end of the First World War, a period that illuminates the spirit of imperial policy over the next several decades.  The region had held fundamental strategic importance to Britain since the early nineteenth century as part of the buffer zone that protected India.  Darwin is keen to correct the once-dominant view that the First World War was a great watershed in imperial history, the prelude to an era in which the rise of colonial nationalism and the decline of economic and military strength forced a gradual retreat from Britain’s former dominance.  According to this interpretation, the weaknesses caused by the war showed themselves in the nationalist movements that Britain faced in Ireland, India, and the Middle East in the four years after 1918.  Resistance to British rule seemed evidence of a coming era of revolution, or at least of radical change, in the relations between colonial powers and indigenous peoples in Africa and Asia.  These new symptoms of imperial weakness were often attributed to the debilitating effects of the Great War on Europe, to the diffusion of the political ideas associated with Woodrow Wilson, and to the influence of revolutionary Bolshevism.Yet, as Darwin shows, there was little evidence that the British deduced from these developments that the structure of their imperial system had become unsafe.  The British Empire had, after all, survived the war with its political structure largely intact, while the same war had served as a graveyard to four rival empires.  It had weathered internal and external strains that proved too much for its competitors.  Above all, at the end of the war, the British Empire displayed a striking capacity for further expansion in Africa and the Middle East.  “In their response to the challenge of Egyptian nationalism and in their estimate of Britain’s strategic necessities in the Middle East, it is possible to see at work some of the most influential assumptions that guided British policymakers in imperial questions up until the cataclysm of the Second World War."Darwin’s discussion focuses on the official mind – the ideas, thoughts, and motivations of those in London who were charged with the administration of foreign and imperial affairs.  He argues that, after 1918, as in the two previous generations, Britain’s foreign policy was essentially defensive in character, geared not toward expansion but rather to the conservation of her trade and diplomacy that remained centered on India.  The reason for this continuity lay in the economy of effort that was expected of British administrations.  Policymakers could ill afford to ignore the dangers of allowing the burden of empire to press too heavily on the resources of the metropolis.  After 1918 the domestic constraints on British policy were joined by a new aversion to war and by a growing awareness of the fragility of Britain’s economic position in the world.  Conversely, however, ministers were equally hesitant to loosen the bonds of political control where they already existed, especially in regions of the world where British paramountcy had long been regarded as fundamental to the defense of empire.British leaders brought these concerns to their formulation of policy in the Middle East in the four years after 1918.  Disorder and a nationalist uprising in Egypt, and resistance to British rule in Turkey, Persia, and Iraq, forced the British to negotiate a new set of relationships to maintain and strengthen their rule.  The general British policy was one of making political settlements with nationalist and resistance movements for the purpose of creating regional stability, which would exclude foreign challengers and allow Britain to uphold its strategic interests.  Here lies an adaptation of the Robinson and Gallagher thesis of imperial "collaboration" with indigenous elites who could strengthen the British position in return for support from the imperial power.  The British policy in Egypt serves to illustrate how such policies were achieved in the crisis after the war.  In Egypt after March 1919, the nationalist uprising had threatened to withdraw local support for alien rule.  The British policy that eventually emerged was one of limited concession to Egyptian nationalist demands, designed to enlist Egyptian cooperation at the minimum risk to imperial interests.  As Darwin explains, “what they sanctioned was not a revolution in Anglo-Egyptian relations but an adjustment; not a general withdrawal of imperial influence but rather its rationalization: the shrugging off of commitments that had become over-extended during the war and which, as Milner had argued, were undermining the real purpose of the British presence.”  The British thus discarded those superfluous elements of their presence that would only raise the political burden of guarding their strategic interest in Egypt.  In the long run, therefore, the crisis in Anglo-Egyptian relations had less ominous consequences than many ministers had feared.  The Allenby Declaration that emerged from the crisis, and which gave greater control to Egyptians, effectively created a political stalemate between the palace and the Wafd that allowed the British both to control political fortunes as well as to exclude foreign competitors.  The essential strategic objectives of British policy were upheld; the costs of achieving them fell to levels far more acceptable to British voters after 1918.Darwin’s study is concerned above all to establish an essential continuity of British policy between the periods before and after the First World War.  Britain’s imperial strategies continued as before.  The motives remained fundamentally the same.  How then should historians interpret the seemingly contradictory policies pursued in the period between 1918 and 1922?  For Darwin the answer lies (somewhat ironically) in the war itself.  It forced Britain to interfere more widely and intensively than ever before in the society and economy of the whole region.  “This great expansion in the imperial presence provoked, after the war, local responses which varied greatly in their character and tempo.”  Simultaneously, the change of domestic British politics compelled ministers to reduce the scope of their strategic and military ambitions, and to therefore rely more greatly on local support.  In sum, as Darwin explains: "The problem that tormented the policy-makers was not, in their view at least, whether the imperial system could survive, nor even how best to prepare for its gradual enfeeblement.  It was the more immediate problem of how to contain the side-effects of the war on the internal and international security of the imperial system.  All their solutions, whether in Egypt or the Middle East, assumed the necessity of preserving the Empire."  Or, to put the matter another way, it was an attempt by policymakers to ease the costs and burdens of empire after a phase of extraordinary effort, and to give Britain more room for maneuver in its dealings with both colonial politicians and their own domestic opinion.

This is a fantastic water bottle for kids, with a slightly complicated spout/straw design.  I give it 4.5 stars overall.  The best feature is the nifty, mechanical spout, which snaps down closed and is opened with the teal button on the front.  My 21-month-old daughter loves playing with the spout and laughs every time it snaps open.  The design works well, mechanically speaking.  The only problem is that, like many Contigo products, the design is complicated and difficult to clean.  I would recommend that you use it with water only.  Milk or juice could be really hard to clean out of the crevices.The bottle itself is great quality and is BPA free.  The lid unit is fairly heavy duty.  One major difference between this bottle and, say, a Camelbak, is that the straw is hard: you don't bite down to open it, but rather suck water through it like a straw.  We love the design, too.  Overall we're very pleased with this bottle and will keep it in mind for future purchases.

This is a useful, attractive guidebook printed in all color with many attractive maps and photographs.  It basically gives an overview of the whole state, highlighting the most popular and acclaimed tourist attractions.  If you are looking for a guidebook to "secret" or hideaway places, this is not it.  This is the one-stop, single-volume guidebook for people who want to buy a single book and use it to hit the top sites in one trip.I picked up a copy to plan for an upcoming trip and have found it to be a very well-done guidebook, better than many others I have used for different places.  I have already made an extensive itinerary from this book alone.  When I showed it to my mother-in-law, who has been to Alaska multiple times, she agreed that I have been getting good advice!So how does it work?  This travel guide covers the whole of Alaska and is divided by region.  This means that no one place has lots and lots of detail, but pretty much every part of the state is covered.  For example, it has regions on "Juneau and the Southeast," the Anchorage area, Prince William Sound, Kenai Peninsula, Denali and the Interior, Arctic Alaska, and so on.  Each individual place has a number of key cities or sites -- sometimes over a dozen -- worth visiting.  This has really helped planning because it means that you can plan all the sites to visit in one place before moving to the next and repeating the process.  The sections on individual cities and places have about the right amount of detail.  They give you the essentials, recommend certain hotels/lodges, and provide a little extra detail here and there.  Some might complain that there is not enough detail.  But the nice thing about the travel guide is that, once this book has pointed you in the direction of a key site, you can look up more online.  I find it handy for this reason alone.There are also a number of other sections on other things.  For example, the book recommends the best hikes and paddles, explains other popular outdoor activities, makes recommendations for traveling with children, and even offers sample itineraries that can be modified as needed.  Along the way it throws in sections on Alaska history, brief notes on wildlife and nature, and explanations of the landscape.  Again, these sections are rather thin (they have to be to keep the book reasonably short), but they give you just enough.  There is another section that explains different ways of getting around.  Best of all, there are nice guides to budgets and costs to help you find the price range you desire.The photographs and maps are beautiful -- "luscious" is the word I told my wife.  They are rich and bold.  They make you want to go there.  Even a native would probably find this to be an attractive and useful book.One of the nice things about all Lonely Planet travel guides is that they cater to middle-class people, like me.  This is not the guidebook I would purchase if I wanted to backpack Alaska like a gypsy.  Nor is it really aimed at rich travelers.  It seems to be aimed especially at middle-class Americans who have a decent budget for their trip but who are still budget conscious.  It would be great for college kids taking a trip, honeymooners, young professionals, or even families.  The book makes efforts to show different price ranges of hotels and excursions to help you tailor the trip to your budget.  As far as I can tell, the recommendations for hotels and pricing is all pretty up-to-date and reliable.  Glad that this is a new issue for 2015.Overall, I highly recommend this guidebook and look forward to using it more during my upcoming trip!

Like other products from Winkine, I'm very happy with this backpack.  It has a cool, retro appeal, comes at a fair price, and has a style that will work for a lot of different uses and settings.  The first thing I thought when opening it is that it kind of looks and works like a rucksack.  The bag has one main pocket that's perfect for books or a laptop.  The bottom is flat, making it better able to carry papers and books without bending pages or smashing fragile items.  It also has a number of smaller pockets.  There are two smallish pockets on the sides to hold water bottles or small items, a small zippered inner pocket (perfect for phones, pens, or other small items), and mid-sized outer pocket on the front that measures about 7x10 inches.  One of the most unique features is the top flat that closes the main pocket.  As you can see in the pics, the zippers run down the sides, and the flap attaches with velcro.  I think this adds special appeal, but it also has a small downside -- namely, that you cannot fully seal the main pocket.  This is my reason for 4 stars.  It's not a bad design, necessarily, and in fact it is kind of cool, but I realize that many buyers will want a main pocket that completely seals, whereas this one has zippers that partially close and a velcro that attaches.Beyond this, the bag seems well constructed.  It is made of a fairly heavy canvas material.  The straps are simple but sturdy.  It has a funny smell when you first open it, but this fades within a few weeks.  Overall I think this is a very nice and unique bag for a good price.  Highly recommended.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review

I got this food for my English Springer Spaniel.  He always provides a litmus test for dog foods.  He has severe food allergies and gets bad reactions to (almost) any food that is not grain-free.  Even some grain-free choices have caused rashes and itching.  So far he has done very well on this food.  He also likes the taste and shows other signs of good health (although it's admittedly hard to tell much difference after one small bag).  I always stop on over to DogFoodAdvisor and see what they have to say.  This food scores pretty high, a rare 4.5 stars out of 5, putting it up there with the most expensive grain-free foods (obviously where it belongs!).  The main ingredient is lamb, followed by other high-protein ingredients.  There are very few "bad" ingredients.The only real downside to this dog food is that it costs a lot.  $67 for a mere 24 pounds puts it among the most expensive dog food I have ever fed to my dogs.  But, if you have a small pooch to feed, if your dog has special health demands, or if for any other reason this food suits your dog best, it's worth the price.  This is high quality stuff.

If you're chuckling about the title of my review and wondering why I give this ball 4 stars anyway, it's because the ball itself is pretty nice.  It's constructed of durable rubber.  The ball has a lot more soft, rubbery "give" to it than comparable products by Kong and other brands, and this makes it a better option for playing fetch, because it won't hurt the dog's teeth.  So far, neither of my spaniels have managed to damage the rubber.  That's surprising: one of them is good at picking off little bits of tough toys with her fangs.  Another advantage over traditional tennis balls is that it's rubber and therefore easy to clean compared to a cloth ball.  And the price is great, in my opinion.But yeah, the squeaker.  Man the squeaker.  It is so loud and so annoying that we couldn't stop laughing -- the kind of half-mad, half-amused laugh you only experience when something is so annoying that it's funny.  The sound was so incredible that it sounded like one squeaking rabbit was laughing about another squeaking rabbit that was dying.  Anyway, the squeaker quit working about 15 minutes after it left the packaging.  My dog is not even a strong chewer: he's kind of a pansy and takes hours to get through an edible rawhide bone.  But he destroyed the squeaker in 10 or 15 minutes.  Buy this as a nice rubber ball for a good price (not expecting a squeaker), and you'll be happy.  If you buy this for the dying-rabbit sound, sorry you wasted your time.

The Exploitation of East Africa is the third volume in Reginald Coupland’s study of East Africa in the nineteenth century.  It arose out of his earlier research, first on East Africa prior to European contact, and then on Sir John Kirk, a member of the Zambezi expedition under David Livingstone’s leadership.  This is a well-written and compelling study that still commands attention despite being seventy years old.The first part of the book deals with the ending of the slave trade in East Africa, the principal object of British policy, Coupland writes.  Here, as elsewhere, Britain worked through local rulers.  He argues that history must award the honor for the final overthrow of slavery to Livingstone, who did the most to inspire the attack on slavery, and John Kirk, who did the most to carry it through.  And a measure of credit is due also to Barghash bin-Said, the Sultan of Zanzibar, who cooperated (partly against his own wishes as well as those of his counselors) because he had no other choice but to accept British paramountcy if he wanted to retain his position.  The three men faced great obstacles in their task.  Slavery was deeply rooted in Arab culture and preeminence in Africa; the well being of Arab rulers depended on the maintenance of slavery; and ending the slave trade entailed the loss of their biggest source of revenue and, by flouting the Arab tradition in favor of slavery, it antagonized bin-Said’s subjects and united opposition against him.  But there was no alternative in the minds of British policymakers, and the Sultan accepted an extensive treaty obtained in 1873.  On the basis of these agreements, the territorial integrity of Zanzibar became the cornerstone of British policy.Behind these three men lay the power of Britain and the “will of the people of England,” which “dictates the line action.”  The long campaign against the slave trade reached a new phase when Livingstone and other explorers revealed the facts to the world during the great period of East African exploration, 1856-1873.  The British people responded and ended the slave trade -- an assessment that is putting a positive spin on a complex process.  “It was the only real service,” Coupland writes, “apart from sporadic missionary efforts on the coast, which any of the peoples of Europe, Asia and America had yet done to the people of Africa, and it was a service of immeasurable value.”  Thus, after Livingstone revealed the facts, after the British people responded, it was the task of John Kirk to present Britain’s case to the court at Zanzibar and to convince the Arab rulers there to cooperate in ending African slavery.The second part of the book deals with the International Scramble.  Coupland argues that Britain had no territorial designs for East Africa.  This was the age of laissez-faire and anti-imperialism, when few people considered colonial possessions desirable for the British government.  British policy was driven by a desire to support and strengthen the Sultan’s authority.  The difficulties of so doing, which owed partly to the Sultan’s diffuse power in the interior, led the British to contemplate different schemes for controlling the territory, but no action was taken to annex East Africa despite the manifold opportunities for doing so.  What initiatives arose were the result of fear of German encroachment.  By 1884 the last chance had been lost and Bismarck had brought Germany onto the scene.  When Bismarck took advantage of the defeat of General Gordon in the Sudan by claiming territory, Britain refused to respond for fear of provoking a quarrel with Germany over a territory of negligible significance.  Thus in the partition of Africa the larger part of East Africa went to Germany, while British policy, slowly built up over the previous decade, had collapsed entirely.This is a classic work in the history of Britain's empire in Africa.  It is written with a degree of skill and eloquence that is rarely encountered today.  Although Coupland takes a favorable, paternalistic, and forgiving view of Britain's imperial "mission," he at least makes the case with sensitivity.  In retrospect, most historians will agree that he cleared the way for much fruitful debate over the nature and causes of the events described in this book.

Malcolm Hailey, who lived 97 years from 1872 to 1969, was the greatest colonial civil servant of his generation.  He was born in Buckinghamshire, educated in London and at Oxford, and began his career in the Indian Civil Service after placing third in the examinations.  He was often remembered in later years for his role writing the famed African Survey, but the greater part of his career – indeed, the more successful part – was spent in India, where he developed conservative, paternalistic attitudes which identified with peasants and small landowners against urban-educated elites, Hindu moneylenders, and the laissez-faire judgments of English courts in enforcing land enclosures.His formative experience as a colonial servant was as the first colonization officer in Shahpur district, where he helped build several large-scale irrigation projects and caught plague in the process.  In 1907 he began working for Indian’s finance department.  “There he demonstrated the qualities that would make him a first-class administrator,” Cell writes: “an apparently unlimited appetite for work, the ability to handle massive quantities of detail without losing sight of the main points, coolness under pressure, and willingness to delegate.”  Later he wrote the main report on General Dyer’s infamous massacre in Amritsar in 1919.  In 1922 he moved to the Home Office where he held the task of responding to the challenge of Indian nationalism.  Two governorships followed.  The first was in the Punjab, until 1928, where he presided over the concluding phase of the conflict with the reformist party among the Sikhs.  In 1928 he became governor of the United Provinces, often regarded as the highest position for a civil servant in India.  Then came his Africa service, dominated by his involvement in the African Survey.  Hailey’s task of writing a report – first intended to be brief and readable, and then to be thorough and exhaustive – caused a breakdown in his health and almost killed him.  His inability to finish the project was covered up to save face, both for Hailey and the Survey, but his reputation was solidified as an expert on Africa and he was often consulted about African affairs thereafter, though he remained peripheral to official thinking.His career as a whole spanned the era of the new imperialism, and this gives him lasting importance -- indeed this is the premise of the book.  He was born the same year as Benjamin Disraeli’s Crystal Palace speech, often cited as the dawn of the new imperialism, and he died in 1969, after the empire had passed.  “By the time of his retirement from India in 1934 Hailey was regarded as the twentieth century’s most distinguished civil servant.  He was not so much a great Africanist as a great man who devoted his last quarter century to Africa.”  “His entire career,” Cell writes in the ODNB, “like that of the empire he served, can be regarded as a series of gradual and reasonably well-prepared retreats, across decades and continents, before the insurgent, ultimately irresistible force of Asian and then African nationalism.”  Ideologically he was an imperialist to the end, but in practice he served intelligently, shrewdly, rationally, and humanely (on the whole).  He was a tall, grand, austere figure with a long beaked nose and a deep bass voice: one Indian boy who saw him riding in Lahore remarked that this was a man who was born to rule.  He was, indeed, seriously, even obsessively, devoted to his work.  “He was the embodiment of the so-called Protestant work ethic.  Brilliant, quick, with a mind able to go to the heart of complex problems while keeping in touch with massive amounts of detail, as a worker he was phenomenal.  As he grew older, however, the need to work, the dread of being idle even for a minute, became truly obsessive, as though he feared that if the machine ever stopped it would fall apart completely.”The book as a whole is very good and does well in putting together his life and influence against the obstacle of his uncooperative family, which refuses to allow historians to access his personal papers.  Its only shortcoming is that it lacks a conclusion in which to bring together the various strands of his life, to provide an assessment, and to comment on his greater significance to the history of British imperialism.

Thomas Babington Macaulay, born in Leicestershire in 1800, was the greatest of all the English Whig historians.  Macaulay was the son of an anti-slavery advocate, Zachary Macaulay.  He was educated at Cambridge University, where he began in 1818, and during the course of his time there he became interested in the utilitarian philosophy being developed by such thinkers as Jeremy Bentham and Joseph Priestley.  After some early success as a writer, he was elected to Parliament in 1830.  He later served as a member of the Supreme Council of the East India Company from 1834 to 1838, during which time he reformed the educational system and, almost single-handedly, composed a legal code for the whole of India.  After returning to England he became successively Secretary of War (1839-41), Paymaster of the forces (1846-47), an again a Member of Parliament (1839-47, 1852-56).  He quickly established a reputation as a distinguished orator and formidable politician.  He was raised to the peerage in 1857 as Baron Macaulay of Rothley.During the interim, he composed his five-volume The History of England from the Accession of James the Second.  The book was an astounding achievement that secured Macaulay’s reputation as a great thinker.  It established history as a branch of great literature.  Macaulay’s principal contribution to the world of letters was to articulate the idea of progress, particularly as it pertained to England.  “The history of England,” he famously wrote, “is emphatically the history of progress.  It is the history of a constant movement of a great society.”  Or, to choose another comment he made about the outcome of the Glorious Revolution of 1688, “the history of our country… is eminently the history of physical, of moral, and of intellectual improvement.”  The book became immensely popular in both England and Europe, selling 26,000 copies in 10 weeks.  It was translated into German, Polish, Danish, Swedish, Italian, French, Dutch, Spanish, Hungarian, Russian, Bohemian, and Persian.John Clive’s contribution to scholarship on the great Whig historian is to examine Macaulay’s early life and career.  The biography, in fact, ends before the publication of The History of England and does not attempt to examine the “Eminent Victorian.”  The subject is rather, as Clive explains, “the outsider, the ‘parvenu’ (as he once called himself) – awkward, ugly, impecunious – who by sheer talent and energy won the respect of the Whigs, and a seat in the cabinet before the age of forty…  Its aim is to trace some of the forces – familial, intellectual, political, and personal – which helped to shape the man and the historian.”  This is an admirable spin on the scope of his subject, but Clive would do well to bring the story full circle.  I know many reasons desire it.Perhaps the most valuable part of Clive’s biography is the Epilogue, in which he attempts to adjudge Macaulay’s legacy.  The key to Macaulay’s thought, Clive explains, lies in his emphasis on human progress.  Macaulay believed that the science of government, like all other sciences, was in a state of progression.  The job of the historian is to chart and to explain that progress.  Yet this common view of Macaulay is not complete.  Clive explains that, for Macaulay, progress could be interrupted, sometimes for centuries.  He further contrasted the progress of the ancient philosophers (progress of the mind) with the progress of “fruit” achieved by practical men like Francis Bacon.  He was an enigma in his religious beliefs as well.  He continued to live a life of temperance long after he gave up his Christianity intellectually.  He believed in the forces of progress – the French and Industrial Revolutions – but also believed that society progressed in stages that should not be rushed or accelerated lest the country be lost to radical initiatives or violent disorder.  He was often tempestuous in public and lacked grace with his peers, far from the ideal of the Whig aristocracy that he so often touted; and the smooth eloquence of thought that he projected outward – whether in Parliament, the press, or in his monumental works – masked a deep inner struggle that was rooted in his childhood.

This book examines the work of a group of well-born women in Edwardian Britain who formed women’s societies to promote the values of imperialism.  These women founded the Girls’ Friendly Society, the Victoria League, the Primrose League, and the British Women’s Emigration Society.  At the core of the philosophy of this women’s empire league was the idea that women held a role complementary to that of men in working within the British Empire.  They were to extend the womanly role of nurturing by undertaking practical philanthropy and good works.  For this reason Edwardian women, like their more-well known male counterparts, held many assumptions about race and colonial capacities rooted in the imperial mentality.  Women’s empire leagues promoted their actions in the fields of education, emigration, and propaganda to promote imperial unity by establishing British standards of conduct in the dominions and colonies, especially in South Africa which, as Bush points out, provided one of the earliest opportunities for women to become involved in travel, propaganda, and relief work on behalf of imperial interests.  Though the leaders of women’s empire leagues were divided over issues of women’s suffrage, and while many supported traditional political concerns, they believed that imperialism transcended their differences and provided a means of involving women in the political issues of the age.The individual chapters deal with a whole range of issues in which Edwardian women became involved: the relationship between society life, upper-class feminine influence, and male politics; the association between female-led organizations and their male counterparts; the place of women’s imperial work within the already well-established networks of female philanthropy; the creation of a gendered imperial vision in which male and female roles were complementary; the relationship between the various imperialist societies and women in the empire; the centrality of education and propaganda to their missions; and the relationship between female emigration and imperial work, and contemporary debates about women’s employment, marriage, family duties, suffrage, and wider feminist politics.Participants in the women’s empire leagues also came primarily from the aristocracy and the upper middle class in Britain.  Their social rank strengthened the maternalistic impulse already evident in many of their activities.  They also shared upper-class social values, an appreciation of social rank and hierarchy, a deep belief in the privileges and responsibilities of race identity, a corresponding certitude about what other, less favored races needed, and a conviction that as women they had a special imperial contribution to make in matters of education and emigration.  The preoccupations of these elite women led them to establish large separatist associations dedicated to giving ruling-class women a platform for their talents and the means of extending and defending what they believed to be women’s special interest in the empire.The book also has a larger historiographical purpose.  Bush, who follows the lead of Antoinette Burton’s Burdens of History, contends that British social history and imperial history should not occupy separate fields of enquiry.  As such her book challenges both the lack of attention to race and imperial issues in much mainstream women’s history, as well as the masculine tendencies of imperial history, which tends to focus on policymakers, “men on the spot,” and the activities of other male agents of expansion.  In Bush’s account the empire not only provided an arena for social action – whether as travelers, philanthropists, emigrants, writers, or teachers – but also informed and gave shape to their domestic lives, including the political campaign for women’s suffrage and the understandings of womanly duty within the empire.  This book adds considerably to the effort to bring women into the mainstream of historical assessments that seek to show the role of women in building an integrated empire based on British standards and values during the Edwardian age.

I have long been a fan of Aveeno lotion.  I usually buy the "daily moisturizing" for myself, the "baby" kind for my daughter, and some fancy smelling kind for my wife.  I find that Aveeno is the best of the mass-market lotions for a reasonable price.  I decided to try this new "sheer hydration" variation of their standard lotion to see how it worked.  The bottle says it absorbs in seconds and leaves a powder-like feel.  What did I find?  The lotion itself works fantastic and is much better on the hands than most other kinds.  It also does absorb pretty quickly.  As for the powder-like feel, I would say not so much.  I was hoping for a lotion that would completely absorb and leave no residue or lotion feeling of any kind.  I typically use lotion after working in the yard and then coming back to my desk to type: I want something that will eliminate the dryness without creating a greasy mess on my keyboard.  This lotion is not *greasy* per se, but it does leave a slight lotion-y residue that takes a while to fade.  So, 4 stars out of 5.  It is still one of the best mass-market lotions available, but I'm still waiting for the perfect, completely non-greasy lotion (maybe an unrealistic expectation, but hey, I can hope!).

This book is a work of synthesis drawn from secondary sources that attempts to describe the eighteenth-century empire in the context of historical scholarship that has typically been applied to later periods.  In particular, he writes, it attempts to examine “gentlemanly capitalism” in its eighteenth-century context.  Bowen’s aim is to identify common elements in the expansion of empire by synthesizing work on North America, the Caribbean, and East Indian affairs with the metropolitan British historiography that has often neglected the role and impact of the overseas empire.  The role of British elites, both in Britain and abroad, provides the unifying theme.  “British landowners, merchants, and financiers developed colonial economic interests and a strong imperialist consciousness,” and their role was often reinforced and legitimized by adherence to a common set of cultural values and assumptions.The author identifies three main kinds of elites: a political elite dominated by the landowning classes; a mercantile elite, which supervised and directed the growth of overseas trade; and a financial elite, based in the City, which provided much of the capital and resources to support the state as well as enterprise at home and abroad.  The attitudes, decisions, and resources of these elites “played a key role in helping to define some of the main characteristics of British imperialism in the eighteenth century.”  The elites of which Bowen speaks thus appear more diverse and less unified than the “gentlemanly capitalism” thesis allows.  “The empire in its financial context,” he argues, “should not be seen as being shaped solely by the needs of the City and investors located in the south of England” (100).  Cain and Hopkins thus place too much emphasis on the metropolis, and they ignore the influence of the elites in overseas territories who often maintained strong connections with Britain.  “Very few metropolitan investors were able to, or even wanted to, exercise direct influence on the pace and direction of overseas expansion” (100).  British elites came from different backgrounds.  They lived and worked in different parts of Britain (especially in Scotland) and the empire (especially India and North America).  Their influence as elites often drew upon different sources of wealth (whether financial, commercial, or industrial), power (whether political or military), and social rank (whether from the aristocratic class or from a merchant family with the appropriate trading connections).  But they were generally united by their common interest in supporting the extension of British trade and empire overseas.Bowen’s study, as a work of synthesis, includes an astute and careful discussion of how his ideas fit within the existing historiography.  Several of the more important contributions are as follows.  First, he follows the trend of other scholars, notably Bayly and Brewer, in emphasizing the “financial revolution” of 1688 and the emergence thereafter of the administrative and military structures that characterized the centralized government of the eighteenth century.  Second, he argues that Cain and Hopkins underestimate the importance of the Industrial Revolution, which “helped to increase consumption rates of goods and this played an important part in sustaining Britain’s position in the wider world” (39).  Third, he seeks to correct the imbalance created by the tendency among historians of British North America to pursue lines of enquiry that have rarely been applied to the West Indies much less the Indian empire, which is often assumed to be an “exceptional” case.  These narrow specializations have precluded an assessment for the eighteenth century of the general causes of imperial expansion.  Even Cain and Hopkins remarked in British Imperialism that “no acceptable interpretation of eighteenth-century imperialism” exists.  Bowen seeks to correct the national and regional focuses of historians by analyzing colonial territories comparatively within the context of the British elite that benefited from, and often guided, the course of overseas expansion.  In so doing, he applies to the whole empire the ideas of transnational and comparative international history that have been developed for different parts of the empire.  Scholars of colonial North America have developed “Atlantic history” and have emphasized the cultural, economic, and even political connections between the core and the periphery.  The British equivalent, pioneered by J.A. Pocock and made popular by Linda Colley, has emphasized the role of the empire in first creating and then sustaining the connections between England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.  Bowen extends these themes to the eighteenth-century empire and seeks to analyze comparatively the role of elites as well as the expansion of empire in Britain, North America, and India.Bowen’s concluding section discusses the general crisis of empire after 1760.  He argues that an important shift occurred in which elites began to reappraise their position within the empire and thus their very loyalty to the empire itself.  This development occurred as the result of the attempt to forge a new imperial order based on greater metropolitan control.  It met with “mixed results.”  In North America it led to an ultimately successful resistance movement that cost Britain its most important colony.  In India it helped to solidify Company rule and placed British elites at the center of the revenue-collecting system that had existed under local conditions.  Nevertheless, despite the trauma of losing a colony, this imperial crisis did not lead to the emergence of radically different ideas and assumptions about empire.  “Instead,” Bowen argues, “lines of development that had become clear in the 1760s were extended and sharpened in the new conditions that prevailed during the 1780s and 1790s” (194).  The attempt to assert government authority became stronger.  This “represented one of the most important continuities during the period between 1760 and 1820,” the other being the growth and diversification of British business activity in the wider world.  The result was that the British Empire continued to expand after the loss of the American colonies, spurred by the incorporation of new groups into the ruling elite.  “Part of the empire might have collapsed, but the metropolitan elites who had established the original structure would now set about using the same foundations and many of the same basic materials to build a new and rather different imperial edifice” (196).In sum, this is a well written and generally compelling study of eighteenth century imperialism that asks important questions, and provides several provisional answers, on important issues concerning the nature and causes of Britain’s imperial expansion.

Making Peoples is a survey of New Zealand from the eleventh century to the end of the nineteenth century. It covers Polynesian settlement and its development into the Maori tribes between the eleventh and eighteenth centuries, the encounter between the Maori and Europeans from the seventeenth century, and the foundation between the 1830s and 1880s of the “Pakeha” society, the Europeans who settled in New Zealand and maintained mostly European culture and traditions. In tracing this history, Belich seeks to show that New Zealand is a “historian’s paradise: a laboratory whose isolation, size, and “recency” [sic] is an advantage, in which grand themes of world history are often played out more rapidly, more separately, and therefore more discernibly, than elsewhere.Much of the novelty of Belich’s study derives from his attempt to interpret New Zealand history as the product of two of the world’s great colonizers, the British and the Polynesians. He argues that historians of the subject have focused too much on whether a new society, like New Zealand, was shaped most by “fragment” (the time and place from which most early migrants came) or “frontier” (the new environment, rich with opportunity). Were newly settled territories shaped by the social context of the metropolitan society from which migrants came? Or by the peculiar nature of the frontier, the peoples that settlers encountered, and the particular challenges that settlers faced in building a new society? Belich argues that it is equally, perhaps more, important to consider the “ethos of expansion” – the assumptions, hopes, and fears of the colonists – which helped trigger colonization, determined its direction and form, and influenced its development in the new land.Belich discusses early Maori history in the first part of the book. He argues that European ethnography was wrong to assume that non-European people were static and un-changing. Polynesian peoples were highly diverse and very adaptable, and their expansion into the islands of New Zealand was driven by the search for resources to sustain a complex society based on hunting and “gardening.” He also argues that, around the fifteenth century, New Zealand experienced a crisis in which the extinction of big game caused a transformation of Maori society, economic, politics, and warfare. These changes created the foundations of the society that would encounter the arrival of Europeans in the eighteenth century.In the second part of the book, “Contact and Empire,” Belich describes the first encounter between the Maori and European (mostly British) settlers. He underlines Maori agency in particular. The Maori showed adaptation and resistance to a whole variety of changes created by European arrival. A Maori “state” failed to emerge, but cohesion of Maori tribes was sufficient by 1840 to preserve some measure of autonomy and tribal rights in the face of rapid European settlement. The Treaty of Waitangi, which recognized Maori land claims and conferred upon the Maori rights as British subjects, represented one of the early Maori successes in adapting within a political system dominated by British colonists. The Maori later showed adaptability in military affairs. Evidence now suggests that the Maori became the first to use trench warfare as a means of countering (and avoiding) the challenge of modern, automatic weapons. Finally, in the third part of the book, “Making Pakeha,” Belich describes the creation of New Zealand as a British settler colony with mostly British institutions, habits, customs, and culture. In short, he describes the creation of the Pakeha in much the same way as he described Maori history in earlier parts of the book – their economic activities; their class and social statuses; their ambitions and fears; their beliefs and prejudices; and much else besides. The discussion is a thorough and somewhat unique account of European colonists in New Zealand, though not, for the imperial historian, original enough to warrant any degree of special interest. Its main virtue is that, in describing the development of “British” New Zealand, Belich interweaves the role and fortunes of the Maori people who both adapted and resisted according to the needs of the time.On the whole, this book shows all the virtues and all the faults of a broad synthesis that attempts to span vast periods of time and take account of multiple interpretations about several different social groups. The discussion is too broad and general for the specialist. It is too historiographical – and, in a sense, too ideological – for the casual reader of New Zealand history. Belich’s particular conclusions will probably fail to please many Maori specialists and “Pakeha” historians of modern New Zealand, as well as some imperial historians. But the value of the book is precisely that its ambitions so grandly attempt to integrate indigenous history with the history of European colonists, and to structure both in a framework of more general imperial interactions.
