This is a good quality light.  It's housed in stout metal, has solid threads (for accessing battery compartment), and includes a charger and 3.7v battery.  Note well: this is NOT a standard flashlight.  It is a UV light and is basically useless as a normal flashlight.  Its purpose is to detect things like forged banknotes, urine stains, harmful chemicals, scorpions (exciting game that would be!), etc.  I personally got it to check for pet stains, and, fortunately, found very few!  The light is super intense.  Do NOT look at the light for long or your eyes will be feeling it seriously.  Also not safe for kids.  But, at the same time, this is a sign that the light is very powerful and therefore has great utility for its intended use.  Both the battery and the charger seem to be of good quality as well and replacement batteries can be found here on Amazon.  Overall I highly recommend this product.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

For a long time I've wanted a GPS for my bike.  For a long time I've thought it would be SO MUCH better to just use my iPhone instead.  This MountCase came along just in time to save me from wasting my money on a dedicated GPS unit when I already have a phone that does way more and can download multiple apps.  As far as concept goes, this case is fantastic.Fortunately, it's also really nice when it comes to workmanship and features.  The first thing I noticed when opening the packaging is that it appears to be designed *by* bikers, *for* bikers.  The rubbery strap that attaches to the handlebar is made of solid material and is designed like many high-end bike components.  It uses hex screws, which are standard on bikes (meaning any biker would have the tools needed) and provides a solid hold.  There is plenty of adjustability for different sizes of bars.  On top of the strap is a raised piece, about 3/4 inch thick, where the phone snaps on.  This piece has a prominent red button on the side to release the case.  Everything seems very solid on this case.  I am probably one of the few people on this page crazy enough to take my phone on a real mountain-bike trail, but the case held strong and the phone never left its place.  I'm not saying I recommend this, but it worked for me.  Best on the road, definitely, and for commuting.The phone case itself is nice as well.  It consists of two parts.  The part that covers the face of the phone is a clear, rubbery material (including screen cover) that fits snugly around the edges of the phone.  Once you slide the phone into this part of the case, you thin snap it into the black rubbery backing, which attaches straight to the mounting unit on the bike.  The snap-in design, which you attach and remove with an easy twist, is very nice.  The black part of the case has four holes: (1) camera, (2) headphones, (3) power supply, (4) speakers.  With the clear waterproof cover attached, there are two little flaps that snap closed over the headphones and power supply.  Speakers would be covered.Do I have any complaints?  Well, sort of, but they are small ones.  First, the waterproof screen protector is so thick that it's sometimes hard to use (usually not too bad, though).  Secondly, the black part of the case has a protruding bump on the back where it attaches to the connector on the bike, and this makes it bulky and awkward for normal use, so you might want to switch it in and out when you ride, depending on how much it bothers you.  I find it's pretty easy to take the phone in and out because the material is soft and rubbery enough.  I'm speaking after using with an iPhone 6.  The 6 Plus might be harder -- don't know.  Finally, the packaging was a bear to open.  It looks really pretty (hard plastic boxes hooked together -- would be great on a store shelf), but it was hard to open.  Maybe the company could offer "frustration free" packaging for online customers, and save the pretty box for bike shops?Overall I think this is a very nice phone mounting kit for the bike and would highly recommend it to friends.  I will probably buy one for my uncle (an avid cyclist) for his b-day.I received a free product in exchange for an honest and impartial review.

This is fine toothpaste.  Nothing to write home about, but comes pretty much as advertised.  The taste is good, it did not cause any sensitivity for me, and it seems to work well at strengthening enamel and whitening slightly (although that's harder to notice right away).  I always shrug about these whitening toothpastes.  With only a few exceptions, the effect is so negligible that it's almost the same as non-whitening, but I guess it doesn't hurt either.  This would be a solid go-to option for someone looking for a reliable everyday toothpaste, but probably not a top end option if you are looking for super powerful whitening effect.

I've been thinking about Chris Bayly a lot lately owing to his recent, unexpected death.  He was one of the greatest historians of his generation, able to reach across the continents intellectually as well as personally, connecting Britain, India, and beyond.  He is mostly remembered for his pioneering work on modern India, but this book on the British Empire is one of his greatest works and will be read for many years.David Fieldhouse calls Imperial Meridian “the most important and influential single book published during the last thirty or so years on this hinge between the first European empires established from the fifteenth century and those of the modern period.”  The era between 1780 and 1830 fits uneasily into existing schemes of historical interpretation.  It has often been described as a period of transition from the old mercantilist empires to Britain’s liberal paramountcy in the age of free trade.  Bayly seeks to correct the Whiggish view that the period saw the newly liberal and industrialized West achieving almost casual dominance over a decadent East.  Some decline had occurred in the Asian states, Bayly argues, but nothing significant enough alone to allow European states to overcome them.  Conversely, there was nothing new and nothing particularly liberal about European expansion before 1830.  Rather, European imperial expansion was the outcome of warfare, and of the greed and ambition of public servants and private interests, very seldom the result of economic or political liberalism, as Vincent Harlow had argued.  Bayly describes this phenomenon as a “military-fiscal” empire, made possible by the improvement in efficiency of the British state and its commitment to fighting France.Several themes unite the study.  First, the author discusses European and non-European imperialism using the same sets of concepts.  Secondly, he follows Schumpeter’s line of argument that Britain was a kind of refurbished ancient regime, dominated by a small, agrarian-based ruling class that had never abandoned its authoritarian “atavisms.”  Thirdly, after 1830, the rate of territorial expansion slowed down, financial problems mounted, and the old agrarian ideology gave way to the new forces of liberalism and science.  Bayly divides the history of imperialism into three broad categories.  The first consisted of the Iberian and Dutch conquests of Asia and America from 1520 to 1620.  The second period spans the period from 1760 to 1830, “when European empires first seized substantial territory in south and south-east Asia, raced ahead in north America and Australasia, marked out the near east and southern Africa as spheres of dominance, and brought Atlantic slave system to its peak.”  The third period involves the “new imperialism” after 1870, when most of Africa and a scattered remnant of other territories finally came under imperial rule.  He argues that the period from 1780 to 1830, the one under review in his book, is ultimately most important because it saw the sophisticated and literate cultures of Asia and the Near East fall under European control for the first time.Nevertheless, as Bayly explains, the period from 1760 to 1830 fits ill in the broader theorizing about imperialism, which has been tailored to explain the final push for empire after 1870.  He argues that the best way to understand European expansion between 1760 and 1830 is to put the story in the context of European conflict and rivalry.  The need to finance European armies and preserve fiscal stability drove European states to seek expansion overseas.  A kind of “imperialism of military fiscalism” emerges as the main cause of expansion in Bayly’s study.  He argues accordingly that historians should modify their view that this period saw the beginnings of the imperialism of free trade.  “The dominant ideologies of the imperial projects of the period were informed by its military and aristocratic character.”  The period saw the peak of slavery and slave trade, he argues, both attempts to draw revenue from overseas conquests.  “Military attitudes, military finance, intentions, and structures tied together the fabric of the European empires of this period.”  Moreover, during this period European expansion drove non-European states to create and develop their own empires – it energized local patriotism.  “Lenin and Schumpeter got it right in part.”  But their ideas should be applied to the “second British empire” between 1760 and 1830, not to the present or the future in the later-nineteenth or twentieth centuries.Bayly's study is an original and field-changing contribution and should be read by all students of Europe, Asia, and modern imperialism.

We're very happy with this dish brush.  I find it's the perfect tool for pots, pans, plates, and shallow bowls.  It's much easier to handle and use than a long bottle brush, and it works better than other brushes of a similar design.  The handle is comfortable and well shaped, the bristles are durable but also soft enough to hold soap and clean well, and the brush can even be run through the dishwasher if you want.  This is just a dish brush, and dish brushes are not a big deal in life, but this one seems to be much better than the competition and that offers a small convenience every day.  I highly recommend the brush and will buy again in the future.

Gregory Barton’s study of empire forestry argues that “imperialism and environmentalism have a shared past” that has been obscured by environmental history’s early development in the American historical context, where it was closely associated with Romanticism and the progressive conservation movement.  Many scholars have therefore considered environmental history to be in the service of the political Left, a radical and subversive field at odds with exploitative capitalism and “imperial science.”  Empire Forestry and the Origins of Environmentalism revises this view by extending the study of environmental history to the nineteenth century and by viewing it from a global perspective that goes beyond the American experience.Barton is able to make this contribution by viewing forest conservation as an early form of environmentalism.  Forest conservation was first implemented on a large scale in India.  The movement began in the first decade of the nineteenth century when British leaders demanded the protection of forests in India to preserve a ready supply of timber for the Royal Navy’s campaign in the Napoleonic Wars.  The forest committee inquiry established to investigate the availability of Indian “teak” revealed surprisingly limited supplies of timber.  The committee delivered a proclamation prohibiting all unauthorized felling of teak trees and declaring all unclaimed lands property of the Crown.  Simultaneously, the British government appointed the first conservator of forests in 1806.Forest conservation efforts lapsed for a generation after the Napoleonic Wars, but by the 1840s British leaders again pursued forest preservation to restore rapidly dwindling timber supplies in India.  The administrative and legal structures that became the Indian Forest Department began under the leadership of James Ramsay, Earl of Dalhousie, who served as governor-general from 1848 to 1856.  Under his administration, the East India Company and the British government annexed eight states – in several cases to secure access to natural resources – and extended state ownership and regulation to the whole of British India.  Among the acquisitions were the forests of northern India.  The 1855 “Charter of Indian Forestry” enacted laws to protect the forests from private exploitation by making them the property of the Government, to be properly managed by scientific forestry.  This legal precedent was refined and clarified in a succession of acts over the next half century: the Forest Act of 1865, the Hazara Rules of 1875, and the Land Revenue Settlement of 1893.To return to the connection between empire and environmentalism, it is important to note that while the imperial government often annexed forests for strategic and international reasons, the forest service, according to Barton, generally pursued its aims without regard to the imperial government’s needs for power and revenue.  One must wonder if the forest service pursued conservation for the sake of conservation, or whether forestry in India was simply working in the service of the strategic needs of the imperial government, which in the final analysis held ultimate control over reserving land and financing and staffing the forest service.  Barton’s thesis may also need revision in the light of Richard Groves’s attempt to locate the origins of environmentalism in the eighteenth century.  Despite these two issues, Barton has written an excellent and interesting (if somewhat repetitive) book.  And it is hard indeed to dispute his main point that the “monumental achievement” of forest preservation in India “captured the imagination of the period” and inspired similar conservation movements around the world.

This short book is less a survey (as the title suggests) than a limited study of how the British government of India sought to control sexual practices in India.  He argues (correctly, on the whole, in my opinion) that British attitudes to race, sex, and class reflected and sustained the structure of power in British India.  Ballhatchet's attempt to substantiate and carry through the argument takes a modest but important step toward the goal.  The core of the book deals mostly with the effort to control the access of British soldiers to Indian prostitutes.  The problem arose because common soldiers could not afford wives and, being young and healthy and of virile body, had sexual impulses that they were apt to satisfy in one way or another.  The military authorities, disturbed by the high incidence of venereal disease, sought to regulate and control prostitution to ensure the health of British soldiers and prevent sexual activities from upsetting relations with the Indian community.  The rationale given was that such policies for the official registration and medical treatment of Indian prostitutes would protect British servicemen from the ravages of uncontrolled venereal disease.  What resulted was a pitched battle over British policy toward prostitution.  Missionaries and the evangelical community opposed the Government’s wish to give license to immoral behavior.  The military authorities, for their part, not only sanctioned prostitution but sought out “attractive” prostitutes to ensure that soldiers would vent their sexual energies within the desired boundaries and thereby prevent the spread of disease and the problems associated with ill health among soldiers.  Ultimately the military prevailed.Later chapters attempt to analyze the themes of social difference and sexual regulation more broadly.  They deal with the variety of sexual encounters across racial lines outside the military.  Mix-raced Eurasians, particularly when they were doctors, must be kept away from European women.  European women must be barred from working as prostitutes or barmaids.  Lady missionaries must keep a distance from Hindu men.  Indian princes must not be allowed to spend too much time in European company or to marry a European woman, lest their familiarity and ease around the “superior” race lead them to lose respect for the ultimate authority of the white race and the Raj.  What policies and attitudes resulted tended to reflect the hardening of racial attitudes in the nineteenth century.That British rule in India was justified by the doctrine of racial superiority and based on maintaining distance between themselves and their Indian subjects has long been well understood.  Ballhatchet analyzes a number of strands of this proposition that have been generally neglected, but, as other reviewers have noted, he makes little use of theory or of other work on these issues, and his book fails to fulfill the ambitions suggested by the title.  What he writes on the hardening of racial attitudes, for example, is much less thorough and developed than even so narrow a study as Thomas Metcalf’s book, The Aftermath of Revolt, which was published sixteen years before.  On the whole, this is an interesting study with a compelling argument that nevertheless fails to live up to its large ambitions.

I recently reviewed a similar doll by the same company (the Tea Party African American doll) and I have many of the same thoughts about this one, but I'm bumping this doll one star higher because it has a few advantages that I'll spell out below.  I have a 20-month-old daughter who is crazy about her baby dolls, which she carries all over the house, sits on chairs and couches, pats and plays with, and tries to put to sleep.  This has become one of her favorites and I think the reasons are aesthetic (she loves the bow, especially, which matches the kind she always wears).  Despite the concept of this doll being great, and despite a generally good design and workmanship, there are a few shortcomings that make this doll fall short of our hopes.► First a word about the general design. This baby doll is made of hard plastic. The main design is that you can pour water into its mouth and it comes out a tiny hole between the legs, simulating a real baby wetting its diaper. My wife said she had heard that this kind of thing is often useful to help toddlers learn that diapers need to be changed when they get wet, on the road to potty training. The dress is made of a nice material and is somewhat water resistant (i.e. doesn't absorb much). The bottles have a feature that makes them turn colors (to pink) if cold water is poured in (refrigerated water works very well, but normal tap water doesn't have much effect). The general appearance and proportions are nice, except for the material (more on that later).► But there are a few shortcomings in the design. The most significant is that it comes with a disposable diaper that presumably must be replaced every time it gets wet. I'm not exactly a stingy or cheap person, but it's a real pain to think that every time my daughter indiscriminately pours a cup of water down this doll's throat, I have to dig out a new clean diaper, at a fairly high cost. If she plays with the doll for hours like I know she would, that would be a lot of diapers! Ultimately, even worse than the diapers being disposable is the fact that the fastener is complete junk. It wore out within 10 minutes of play. We were actually going to let our daughter play with the doll and its diaper without water at first because we knew she would LOVE taking the diaper on and off (which she did! Kudos to Hasbro for that!). But the fastener didn't last. A cloth diaper with a velcro fastener that survives repeated, compulsive on-and-off play by a toddler is what's needed. Change this design flaw and I would instantly raise my rating to 5 stars.  I even tried to find preemie cloth diapers to replace it, but to no avail.  I'm not dishing out fifty cents (yep, that's about what replacements cost) every time water goes down this doll's throat.► There are a few less important design issues that could use some improvement.  I had complained about the headband on the African American doll.  This one doesn't have that problem (falling off and leaving a weird groove).  The molded-on bow is very nice.  My daughter loves it.  Secondly, the cups are less than ideal. I honestly don't know exactly what design they should take, but it's awkward and a bit messy to literally have to "pour" water into the babies mouth. Perhaps just a smaller, more controlled spout would do the trick? Third, the hard plastic material makes this a little less appealing to soft young toddler arms and hands. I understand that this needs to be plastic because it is made to withstand water and so on, but I hope Hasbro can improve the design by making it some kind of softish rubber or plastic material instead of the hard stuff it's made of right now. Finally, the leg and arm movements are very stiff and a bit unnatural. The legs are clearly designed to turn up and out to the side, at an angle that facilitates diaper changing, but this also means it can't stand and has weird leg movements. My wife pointed out that any toddler being potty trained (one of the selling points) would be able to stand, but this doll cannot.In general then, we think the concept behind this doll is great and, to be fair, my daughter loves it anyway, but the bad disposable diaper situation and a few other design shortcomings left us a bit disappointed about what could have been the favorite toy in the house.

Tony Ballantyne’s book is a study of the idea of Aryanism, and of the networks and patterns of cultural exchange through which the idea was developed and disseminated.  Yet while the book is focused on Aryanism as a guiding concept, it is largely concerned with the broader theme of how to understand and conceptualize the British Empire.  Orientalism and Race is one of the first attempts to write a transnational history of the British Empire.  Ballantyne criticizes the tendency of most history “to be organized on the basis of a fixed geographical reference generally congruent with the nation-state.”  He conceives of the empire as a “bundle of relationships,” which brought disparate regions, communities, and individuals into contact through systems of mobility and exchange.  He is equally critical of the “metropolitan” focus of imperial history, as well as the tendency among scholars in Britain’s ex-colonies to write “national” stories without reference to the broader imperial context.  Most of what Ballantyne writes is, in fact, now very familiar to historians of empire.  The idea that Britain and its colonies were bound together by transnational “networks” based upon migration, family connections, trade, literature, language, and communications is now well established.Ballantyne’s principal contribution was to propose these transnational concepts by focusing on the idea of Aryanism.  Ballantyne demonstrates that the popularity of the Aryan idea arose in the British Empire in the nineteenth century as a product of the cultural authority of the Orientalism, which was produced by agents of the East India Company in India itself.  It was not a European idea: it was deeply imbedded in the Vedic tradition.  The Rig Veda, composed in 1500 BCE, first used the term to describe the incursion of tribes of pastoralists who identified themselves as ‘Arya.’  The term thereafter developed a meaning that indicated both a community and cultural sophistication.  The discovery of the idea followed the Company’s rise as a territorial power after 1765, when a new generation of Company employees first learned Sanskrit and began unlocking the mysteries of the Brahmanical tradition.  The “native learning” of such men as Sir William Jones enabled the steady flow of dictionaries, vernacular texts, and translations in European languages.  Jones himself confirmed through his study of language the genetic relationship between Greek, Latin, and Sanskrit, and thus mapped a new interpretation of global history that drew together the pasts of Europe and India.  The term “Aryan” was in turn popularized by Max Muller, whose translation of the Vedas depicted them as a foundation source for the study of “civilization.”  Thereafter the term was used to denote ethnic or racial boundaries, often within Europe more than abroad, thus fortifying both nationalistic and imperialistic ideologies.  Thus it came to be used to mark difference between “civilized” European colonizers and “primitive” native peoples, much in the way that post-colonial scholars have argued in the wake of Edward Said.How has the idea of Aryanism developed?  How did it come to play such an important role in nineteenth-century ideologies of race, particularly as they developed in Germany and culminated in the Nazi regime?  It is here that Ballantyne’s transnational arguments re-enter the story.  The concept of Aryanism, he argues, arose from various places at different times and cannot be centered in a single colony or metropolitan state.  He characterizes the empire as “a series of interwoven archives” that were “fundamentally implicated in the processes of colonialism.”  The author draws upon South Asia, Maori, and other indigenous archives to illustrate the point.  It is necessary, therefore, to conceptualize the British Empire, not as a strict binary between metropole and periphery, but as a “web” that bound together different parts of the empire in an organic whole.  The web metaphor, he writes, "underscores that the empire was a structure, a complex fabrication fashioned out of a great number of disparate parts that were brought together into a variety of new relationships… The web captures the integrative nature of… cultural traffic, the ways imperial institutions and structures connected disparate points in space into a complex mesh of networks.  Moreover, the image of the web also conveys something of the double nature of the imperial system.  Empires, like webs, were fragile (prone to crisis where important threads are broken or structural nodes destroyed), yet also dynamic, being constantly remade and reconfigured through concerted thought and effort: the image of the web reminds us that empires were not just structures, but processes as well."These forms of transmission did not merely transect the national boundaries of Britain or the individual colonies of the empire, but also reached out to other states, nations, and imperial systems, collapsing geographical and culture space.It is worth noting in conclusion that Ballantyne’s scholarship was somewhat less prescient in its assessment of the “New British History,” formulated by J.G.A. Pocock, and the “British World” scholarship, which was just gaining momentum in 2002.  Both of these subfields of British and imperial history are now important parts behind much new transnational history written on "Britain and the world."  Ballantyne writes that “Britishness itself now promises to engulf the whole empire,” and that “fundamental differences in the demographic, economic and ecological frameworks of the ‘new’ societies prevented the simple re-creation of models inherited from Britain.”  The use of “Britishness” as an organizing concept, he argues, returns to a celebration of Britishness reminiscent of Charles Dilke – an “impoverished” and “reductive” model for the history of multi-ethnic and polygot colonial societies far removed from the United Kingdom.  The imperial historian would now probably judge that Ballantyne misread the directions of historical scholarship: studying the British World is much more sophisticated now than the old ideas of Dilke and Seeley.  The broad consensus seems to be that “British” colonies of settlement could be far-flung and bear striking differences, yet still be bound by close connections and similarities in race, culture, economy, society, language, and political tradition.

Have had this on my rear window for 4 years now in all kinds of weather here in the Northeast and it still looks good and new with no wear.  Buying another for another car.  This is highly recommended.
Great for a beginner
Well written and inspirational.  Just what we need during these difficult times.  I hope some of Marks thoughts can become part of the national debates during the presidential race.
Have had this TV in one of my rooms for 5 years now and no problems whatsoever.  Great picture and sound.

I originally came across this shirt 4 or 5 years ago in a SAMs Club for 25 bucks.  I bought all they had in XXL.  And found they fit me the way I like.....with tails tucked in and sleeve length.  And this for a 6'2" 200lb 36 inch waist with athletic build.  I like room to move and I have wide shoulders.  And these fit me comfortably.  I will, more than occasionally, wear them with tails out and feel it looks just fine.  And one of my daughters, a very fashionable wealthy young lady, thinks I look great that way, at least when I was wearing the light blue color.I wear these shirts with and without a Dockers XL tall v-neck cotton Tee.  In summer without a Tee, this shirt is so very comfortable against the skin, oweing to its lightweight and nylon fabric.  But much of the time, going between cooler climates and warmer climates during travels, I'll wear Dri-Fit Tees underneath.This shirt is well made and they show no signs of wear after 4 or 5 years.  But because I have so many of them, I don't really wash them that often.  When I do, I always wash in cold water and let them hang dry at room temperature.  If I'm in a hurry I'll dry them on a very gentle cycle barely dry.  They actually feel better that way from the dryer but I'll still dry them at room temperature because I feel less heating from a dryer is better for the material.

For me, a great travel lens.  Lightweight and 'insanely' sharp.  I'd love the 2.8 but just too heavy for me to want to carry around.  And the fast-focusing of this lens is just incredible.  I find the VR fantastic as well.  I can't say anything new here but I wanted to register my deep satisfaction of this lens.  As a 68 yr old retiree, I have no trouble carrying this lens with my D810 and Nikons vertical battery grip.I use this mostly for travel and landscape.  Portaits of my younger Grandkids when I'm able to keep them reasonably still.  Or when I'm in crowds such as a parade or at county fairs,  Old Home Days.  Right now anyways, I'm flying to Texas every couple months,  and throw this setup in my travel bag with an X100t and a RX100M3 for my pocket.  Though when I'm out and about,  I'll only carry one camera or the other.  Richard.

I have both this 1.4 and the 1.8.  Though the 1.8 appears to me to be somewhat (but not by much) sharper than the 1.4, that really only applys to my D7200 (and D7100).  But the bokeh on this DX combination with the 1.8 is not nearly as good as the bokeh of the 1.4 with my D810 (a very high resolution camera).So I don't use the 1.8 on my D810.  Using the 1.4 on such a super high resolution camera like the D810, to me, makes more sense.  Otherwise what's the point of having an D810.  The bokeh is incredible.  The subject looks to me to 'pop' out of the background - to separate from the background.  And I get an ultra-sharp image on my D810.I use the 1.8 on my D7xxx DX series cameras for its sharp and lightweight near135mm focal solution.

Believe it or not, I don't think my mouse traps were working anymore.  So I stopped setting the traps and fed the rodents until they became use to feeding on the un-set traps.  Then I set the traps again and immediately caught a one or two of the pests.  But this became a cycle I soon tired of.  Now I don't seem to catch anymore on those traps even though I knew they were up there in the attic because my cat was going nuts on the second floor clawing and whining away at the attic door.Enter this electronic pest zapper.  I was offered the opportunity by the company to try it for an honest review.  Within two days I caught 2 mice.  So I'm very impressed.  And will be ordering a couple more.  These are so much better than the mouse traps I had been using and especially better than those sticky traps (the sticky traps would occasionally 'catch' birds who would haplessly fly into my garage - for which I would then have to make a trip to the veterinarian).I'm having my electrician hard -wire these to the house so I don't have to deal with batteries.  This seems to me to be a more humane way of dealing with these rodents.  And very convenient way of disposal, non-messy and clean.  So far, this is working very well for me and I'm very impressed with this rodent zapper.Customer service seems to be very helpful and concerned for the customer and seems to want to make every effort to ensure a good user experience.

I bought a couple of these batteries for two Galaxy S3's I'm still using.  And am very impressed with them.  They come packaged very well, even shrink-wrapped inside the package, 50% charged right out of the box (though I wouldn't use them until you fully charge) -  so fully charged in very little time.They perform for me, just as well as (perhaps even better than) the OEM batteries.  I like these batteries and am very happy with them and recommend these over all the other brands of batteries for the Galaxy S3.

As far as I am concerned, this lens is another marvel of engineering from Nikon. Beautifully well built solid piece of glass. I'm using it with the Nikon vertical battery grip (and an D810) for portrait stuff with its extra shutter button and additional battery capability. And to help offset the additional weight of the 900 grams of solid glass and metal. Doesn't feel so heavy with this setup, to me anyways. Because the weight seems distributed better and it does give me something more solid to hold on to - and contributes to a more steady feeling in my large hands.For what I want to shoot with this lens - portraits, still lifes - this is going to become my favorite prime. And perhaps, someday, every ones classic if it isn't already. But for sports and action, I will pass using this lens as the AF seems to me, not conducive - or just not fast enough.Because in continuous focus, the AF seems too sluggish to me.  I may try this on my 7200 which will give me a 200mm focal length but I'm not sure about that yet given 200mm is more of a sport length.  I do like the DC, though a very few find it gimmicky, in that, as their argument goes, this kind of blur can be better obtained in PP.  I don't agree, on an entirely creative level, and because I prefer as much SOOC as possible and less time on my computer.  Further - and I guess maybe because of my age - I take a lot of portraits of more mature subjects.  And the DC gives me a way to make softer images (taking away the winkles), in a subtle manner, SOOC.  Though with my grandchildren, I can just fire away at a neutral setting DC because of their winkle-free skin.So that's the way I use, and will continue to use, this lens.  Some may not like DC, or even consider it a throw-back, perhaps even a gimmick, but I like it because it's there - it's an additional tool - for my older subjects.

Just wanted to give my view as to size of watch.  I'm 6'2" 210lbs.  And watch does not appear large at all on my wrist.  It seems a perfect match.  And the curvature looks good on my wrist as well.  I picked up mine at Verizon for a bit more money than here It seems but I'm paying 5$ a month.  I love the functionality.  And if you like gadgets, you'll like this

This is a well made tough looking piece of glass.  It's my first and only piece of glass made by Tokina.  But it has received excellent reviews by those with professional portfolio and they sold me.  I use it on a D810 macro mode and a D7100 for more reach on portrait.  I'm told resolution is just as good as some big name brands.  Im not a professional so I can't tell you any better than to say it looks very very good to me.  I'm playing with macro on this now and maybe invest in other macro glass later.  But right now I'm very satisfied with this lens and what it does.

I love this lens.  A bit heavy for the camera but not to bad.  You know I have a good selection of lens for my XT1's and they do add a little bit of weight to the lightweight mirrorless cameras.  Sometimes I wonder if some of these lens defeats the purpose of the mirrorless cameras.  But I can't say this is a heavy lens.  It works perfectly on my camera body.  Balanced well especially with the metal hand grip I use.  And images are extremely sharp.  This is a beautiful lens.  And focus fast.  For me.  I'm very happy with this lens

This is better than the foam pluck stuff.  I use the foam at home and travel with these instead.  But that's just me.  I never get them plucked right and I'm always moving my gear around.  I think a lot of people recommend this over the foam stuff.

I bought this setup and bought the dividers as well, and a couple of foam pluck inserts as well.  Along with the organizer and a couple of TSA locks, nameplate too.  I've got other Pelicans as well but invested a bit more on this one because it has great utility.  If I'm flying for 3 days, I use the LOC insert.  The laptop holder fits my MacBook Pro 15" (late 2014 model) quite well but snug with no problem.  When I fly overseas, I use the inserts instead for camera gear and leave the LOC insert at home.  The utility of this thing is fantastic.  And it's built like a tank.  But to be honest, you're not going to get too many clothes in this than a 3 or 4 day stay.  I'm fortunate that I have a place stocked with everything I need at the other end of my flights.  So usually I'll just carry some odds and ends or stuff I don't have at my other place.One of the things people are concerned about with this case is ...can you carry it on the plane.  This case dimensions just makes it.  The only time I've had difficulty carry-on is when I'm not flying First Class because I have to fly a single-cabin plane.  If I don't get on early in a single cabin they generally ask me to leave it at the gate check.  Then I have to say something like let me try hon.  But flying first I never ever have a problem.  Because I'm first to board I always get this thing on.  Point is, from my experience, fly First and you don't ever have to worry.  "You gets what you pays for."  If you're flying in back or are late to the gate, good luck.

Nice sharp Nikon glass.  Lightweight.  Well-made.  I put this on my Nikon D810.  Shot an image from 35 feet away, cropped it and filled the screen with my subject and was very very sharp with no loss of resolution whatsoever...to my eyes.  I love full frame, after using DX for sometime, and having a lot of fun with my new camera and this lens.  Easy to hold my camera with this nicely made lightweight lens.  Thank you

I use this with one of those larger split curved type keyboards (Sorry. The exact name escapes me now.  Microsoft makes them or use to).  Works great and is quite stable.  I'm not a big fan of the mouse tray that fits to the side.  But it is usable.  And I do use it.  But I would prefer it to be a bit more level.  But that's probably just me.  I think they are coming out with a new design in June 2015.  I'll be looking for it.

I use this with my MacBook Pro 15" and fits perfectly for me.  The stand is quite steady and I have no issues with it.  Seems well made and I have every confidence that it will perform well for me for quite some time.  I leave it in position over night for days at a time with no problems.  The joints seem quite solid and snap into place and hold very well.  Does not wobble at all for me

These are fantastic for my large hands.  I put one on my XT1 (black) and my XT1 (Graphite-Silver).  It fits both perfectly and seamlessly.  I have been using the grip along with the thumb grip as well.  Though I don't feel it is necessary to have both.  But the combo works well for me.  I can more easily shoot with one hand if so desired.  I get a good grip on the camera with just this hand grip and feel confident that I'm not going to drop the camera.  Without the grip, for me, my hand doesn't feel like I've got a good hold on the camera.  And it doesn't add much weight to the camera as well.  By the way, I use one camera with just the 56mm Fujinon lens.  The other I use with the 18-135 Fujinon.  Waiting for the 90mm Fujinon.  Then I'll ditch the kit lens.  Point is that with these heavier lens, the metal hand grip works great and adds to a better balance for me.  Why two camera bodies?  I don't like changing lens often because I'm afraid of getting debris on the cameras sensor.  And so this just works out for me.  This metal hand grip matches perfectly with each 'color' camera body.  And I like the look.

I use only this on my Nikons and any of my other cameras when they are available for a particular camera.  I stand by this brand.  This goes on easy and stays on and yet are very easy to take off if you so decide.  They leave no sticky residue whatsoever.  And they are glass.  I don't like anything else and I certainly don't like the sticky plastic of other brands.  Don't use it.  Get this.  The price is right.  I believe if we are to spend our hard earned money on a camera, we should protect the camera with the best.I may or may not use one on my D810 (nor would I use that silly - I think 'Ken' calls it 'sissy' plastic protector Nikon provides with the 810)  because the 810 is tough gorilla glass.  But if I were to put a protector on the 810, I would use this Larmar product.  I have no affiliation with Larmor but I do like this product very much and just wish to show my appreciation.  Thank you

I've owned more expensive BT headsets in the past - actually the more distant past when they were more expensive.  But prices have come down as the technology improves.  And this device is every bit as good as the more expensive headsets I've bought in the past and it is all and everything I need in the present. And I get more use out of this BT headset than any of my other headsets.  Because this has more utility for me with its ability to use not only in my car but also next to my easy chair in the living room.  I really like the way I can pick up from the dock and it automatically connects to my phone without having to pull out my Galaxy Note 4.  And it looks good in one of my older vehicles that does not have BT.  I prefer using the headset with docking station in my living room more so than the car.The headset is very comfortable once you match the correct ear gel with your ear.  I use the larger gel because I'm a larger person.  The audio is very clear and I'm able to walk around the room away from my phone with no hissing or breaking connection.  I have also paired this with my wife's iPhone 6 very well and tried it with a Galaxy 5 with no problem.  My personal feeling is you're getting a lot for the price you pay. I was given the opportunity to try this product by the Mpow company with a free sample and I have been happy that I was chosen to review the BT headset.  The price of these products have come down in recent years and the technology has improved considerably.  You're getting so much more today at this price point that you were a couple of years ago.  In my humble opinion.  And last, but not least, this company customer service is exceptional and responds quickly and ships quite fast.  They have been very nice and cordial to me in our communications.  Sincerely, Richard.

My 12 yr old Granddaughter loves this pack.  And she is very particular about things like this.  The first thing she said to me was that it was very comfortable as well as attractive. I made her very happy when I gave it to her.  And so I was very pleased to receive this pack from the company for my review.  I don't usually write reviews unless I like the product a lot.  But it melts my heart to see my granddaughter happy when I can give her something like this.  She is a very stylish young lady at her age and I think it says a lot that she likes carrying her pack to school.

I believe that if you're looking for a device such as this that uses suction,  this will do you well and gets the job done.

I like gadgets.  So when I was offered a chance to receive and review this device, I jumped at the chance.The first thing I noticed is its size and weight.  It's small and very light....which I like.  And its surface is that black kind of matte finish with a micro kind of fibre type feel (just my description).  So it feels good to hold and  it's non-slippery.  You can fit this device anywhere.  And it takes up absolutely no space whatsoever.  I hook it up to my camera bag (with the two tiny holes on top).  So it's always with me as my camera bag is always with me.This device is very sensitive and records well 5 to 10 feet away.  I was surprised at the clarity of those recordings.  It starts to fall off a bit after 10 feet but still records well up to 15 feet away in the next room.  At about 10-15 feet away I would generally have to turn up the volume on my receiver.  But otherwise, it's ideal at 5 to 10 feet away.  In a larger room with no interference, it picks up very well at larger distances.Too me, who likes to record life around me with a camera, it just seems nice to also know that I have the ability to record audio almost instantly should I desire to do so.  And unless you tell someone you are recording (which you should do) I don't think anyone is going to notice.  What I have been doing with this is using it as a backup drive for my photos but as a recording device I know it has that extra utility for me should I need it.  And I'm all about being prepared for everything.  And this gives me that added ability because of its extra utility, both as a thumb drive and a audio recorder in a small, lightwieight and unobtrusive but very effective device in all areas.  I like this a lot.

I bought a couple of these recently instead of the WD Passport Ultras 2Tb maybe because of looks and metal enclosures as well as the price being pretty much the same.  I also have a few of the WD My Passports 2Tb (Black) (USB3) from a couple of years ago when they were much more money (about 50% more).Side by side, these slims don't seem any different in size to me except for the weight.  The slims seem heavier to me.  I was kinda surprised that the slims don't have some kind of rubber feet or something to cause them to not slip or slide on my desk top.  So they are not condusive, in my mind, to stacking them on top of each other.  It's a nit-pick I suppose but I'm going to try to find something to place on the bottom for 'feet'.The thing is I have this demonic cat that likes to climb on to my desk and knock things on to the floor or carry things off in her mouth to places hard to find.  And I had stacked these up and she knocked one on to the floor (carpeted).  But It still works just fine.Overall I like this product, and have never had any trouble with these WD portable drives and are the only ones I will ever buy.  They all (WD My Passports) seem very reliable and well made.  I could have just as easily gone with the black Ultras as well as these.  But these I'm using mainly for my photography and video camera backups.

I own this case in both 'varieties ', the wireless as well as the non-wireless charging covers.  Both are well made and stand up to a lot of abuse in my opinion.  Granted, they don't offer the same protection as an otter box but I have dropped my Note 4 in the non-wireless case from 3 feet onto a hard-wood floor with no damage (the phone landed on a corner).  The case is very attractive in the charcoal color that I have.What I particularly like about this case and one big reason I prefer it over previous Verizon cases, is not just the functionality offered by the quick access to apps when the cover is closed, but the simple fact that it doesn't turn my phone on automatically every time I remove or place it in my pocket.  Before, when I would use the Verizon case (with kick-stand) with my other Galaxy's (S3, S4, S5),  I would always inadvertently hit the home button when sliding it in my pants pockets - turning on the phone, making calls, opening apps.  And the way around that was to use the lock screen which I don't really like to do.  But with this cover, I just close it and slide it (in my pocket).  I don't know....it just works for me.The reason I have both covers is because I travel a lot and don't want to carry anything more than I have to, meaning the wireless charging device.  So when traveling I carry a spare battery with the Samsung charging case.  And I'll switch that battery once a day as I am a heavy user.  And it's very easy to switch in this case.  And the case does not degrade with that much opening and closing.I use the wireless casing when I'm not traveling (when I'm at home-base).  And for that I use a couple of Samsung wireless charging pads.  (The white pads by Samsung advertised for the Galaxy S4.  Not the mini black pad).  You just place it on the pad and it starts charging.  I didn't like the mini-pad because you had to be a little more concerned with how you placed the phone.  But the larger white pad fits the Note perfectly and I just lay the phone down square and I'm done.I hope my review was helpful to anyone interested in this case.  If it was, please check in the comments below.  Thank you.

I have the earlier model, x100s, but decided to upgrade to this newer model because of some of the upgrades, that, to my mind, make the camera just a little more enjoyable to use.I especially like the new Electronic Rangefinder Display, improving the viewfinder.  Basically this is an optical view with a magnification of the center focus frame.  It's like a little electronic picture inserted within the optical view of the magnified focus area.  This is what actually attracted me to this upgrade, making manual focusing easier for a sharper shot.Having built in Wi-Fi now is also a big plus for me.  With the ability to remotely control the camera.  The exposure compensation dial has been improved to +_3, rather than just 2 on the previous model.As a compact camera it's bigger than most.  But I enjoy using this x100 more and more because of its retro look and feel.  With the aperture ring, EV dial, and shutter dial, I feel like I always have more and immediate control of my camera.  And as long as you don't mind this particular fixed lens focal length and 'zooming' with your feet, I'm having a lot of fun with this camera.

I'm glad I had the chance to review this charger after I accepted the companys request to try it out.  Because I like gadgets, especially when they offer me such great utility as this simple but effective 3 port USB charger for my car.In fact, I didn't even know I needed it until I received it and started using it.  I'm all about being prepared for anything.  Because I travel a lot and, by necessity,  use a lot of different cars, this comes in handy and can be thrown into my travel bag.  It charges my numerous Android devices and spare batteries (like the Samsung GS4 battery charger),  as well as my Sony battery charger for my Sony RX100M3 camera.So my setup this past week for the device while in Texas was to, first, plug in to the DC (or cigarette lighter) of the car.  Then plugged in the spare GS4 Samsung battery charging case into the USB port on this charger.  And the Sony cameras USB battery charging case into the remaining USB port on this charger.  Finally I plugged my Samsung GS4 into the dedicated micro USB Android charger cable located in the center of this USB charger.  My phone was 'paired' to the cars Bluetooth so I could then use the cars phone application to make and receive phone calls.Using the Bluetooth is important in this type of application because of the tightly coiled cable of this charger does not allow one to just pick up the phone and place the phone to your ear while still attached to the charger.So, in the end, this is - pure and simple - a charger. And does what it does well.  I like it.  And its one more thing to have in your bag of gadgets when travelling.  It takes up no room.  Is lightweight.  Attractive. And functions perfectly for me.I sincerely hope this review was helpful.

First, I paid full price for this product. I bought it before I read the reviews... ..something I rarely do. But I like Logitech products, and especially the Harmony line of remotes, which I have several good years of experience with. If I had read the reviews first, I would not have bought this product. And I'm glad now that I hadn't read the reviews first.This product, since installing two days ago, has worked flawlessly for me. And so easy to program. Programming may have been made easier for me as I also currently use my trusty, tried-and-true, Harmony One which I will never give up (the activities and device settings can be copied and transferred over).To begin using the keyboard, I had to first install the Harmony app from the Play Store to my Android Samsung Galaxy S4. (I have yet to install to my iPad Air).From there, it was simply a matter of following the screen prompts.....one of which included uploading all of my current Activities and Device settings from my Harmony One account to my Harmony Smart Keyboard Hub and Android phone. And Viola! I was in business, up and running immediately! I was totally surprised at the ease and very pleased.I have continued using my Harmony One along with the keyboard and the Harmony app on my Android GS4. But I can now actually replace all my remotes. I have 8 devices connected to my Home Theater and soon to add an Xbox One or the 360. But when I added the Amazon Fire TV (a very superior product for what it does...and  Amazon  certainly got it right), I decided to get the Logitech Harmony Smart Keyboard because the Fire TV uses radio signal rather than IR which is Harmony One exclusive. And the keyboard makes editing data very easy. So I'm playing with it now and very happy with it.The keyboard is not too large and yet a good size for my extra large hands. It has a good feel to it and is built well and somewhat rugged. And it works quite fast. Very responsive. I do wish there were additional buttons on it. For instance, a eject button for my BluRay but I'm sure that can be programmed thru the Android app.I like the Android app. It's very convenient to have on my Android and I don't find it very difficult at all to program. It's very intuitive and a joy to use. If you want to control your home theater from your phone and have a keyboard to enter data and don't mind programming the keyboard thru your phone, this is a great alternative to one of the Universal Remotes. In fact I prefer this setup right now used in conjunction with my Harmony One (I've had the One for a few years now and it just keeps going and going. Though I recommend changing out the original battery as mine was found to be swelling recently and needed to be exchanged - I have a recent review of the replacement battery and how to do it).If my review was helpful, and I hope it was, please indicate by pressing the 'yes' button below. If you need any help with programming, please let me know and I'll try to help. Thank you.

I bought two of these to have a spare and because I forget to put the One on the charger.I could not get the original battery out.  It should come out easily with one finger by lifting it from the front edge and then it just pops out.But I was told the original battery swells.  Indeed it does.  If you can't get this battery out, it more than likely has swollen and I recommend definitely replacement.Have a pair of needle - nose pliers and a flat head screw driver.  Slip the flat head in the back center of the battery (there's a small opening that allows you to do this) just enough so you can lift the battery up gently.  Hold that position with the flat head by one hand.  Take the needle pliers with the other hand and insert one side of the needle next to the flat head screw driver, in the space created by the flat head screw driver.  Squeeze the pliers shut and wiggle, gently, the battery side to side while pulling the battery out.  The swollen battery will come out.  With a bit of effort.You will be surprised by the appearance of the battery.  It will be swollen on top and bottom.  The new battery will slip in nicely and will also slip out easily from then on.Though the activities and device settings were still on the One, none of the buttons worked.  The TV would not shut off or turn on for example.  I pushed the help button and  pointed the One at the TV.  That fixed the problem.  Everything worked fine from then on.  Though the day and time settings had to be set once againThe new battery was 3/4 charged when I received it.  And the operation of the new battery made the effort worth it.  The new battery looks exactly as the original.  Enjoy

I especially enjoyed the illustations as well as the authors well informed background given to Lincolns 2nd inaugural address.  Mark Levins Preface to the book was especially touching.  And have ordered the hard-covered edition as well because I think its that good.  Lincoln has always been one of my favorite subjects and this illustrative historical book makes a good addition.

I gave this Grater to my wife and she likes it very much.  It's stainless steel and appears well made and I, myself, like it better than the previous one I bought for her sometime ago.  My wife is Polish and likes to cook and this is one of those things she uses frequently in the kitchen when she makes those Polish dishes I like so much.  It's a simple tool, yet very well made and does look like it can stand up to a lot of abuse in the kitchen.  I've watched her get the job done with this Grater with little effort. I recommend this Grater over others and not just because of the great price but because it's a good product.  Its a simple thing but it makes her happy and so I'm happy.

I'm not one to spend a lot of time in the kitchen.  Primarily because I am somewhat inept in the preparation of food.  And I'm not proud of that.  But I like good, well prepared food.  Especially my Polish wifes food.So when my wife showed me how easy it was to peel potatoes with this kitchen utensil,  I was amazed.  I've never liked peeling potatoes,  ever since my Army days as a lowly Private.  But I am actually able now to peel potatoes, not only correctly but quickly.  And I love potatoes.  Now only the skin comes off and not half the potato itself when I peel like it use to.This does an excellent job of peeling potatoes.  She showed me also how to use it with other vegetables and other than peeling.  And it worked very nicely for that too.  No mess at all.  For such a small inexpensive utensil, I believe it's worth its weight in gold.  I don't mean to go overboard with my review here but for being disabled as I am, it is somewhat empowering to now beabled to help my wife in the kitchen with something so simple as peeling a potato.If my review was helpful in anyway,  and I hope it was, please choose yes in the comments section below.  Sincerely,  Richard

I absolutely enjoyed this movie (watching it on-demand Xfinity).  As spy movies go, this could be one of my favorites.  The acting from the male leads was very good.  No one was phoning it in.  Kenneth Branagh as a Russian bad guy was truly menacing and continues to be one of the great actors of our time.  Chris Pine's transformation from comfortable, but undercover, CIA analyst, too a fully 'operational' field CIA agent, was interesting.  Chris Pine has a nice screen presence that makes him an actor to watch.  Kevin Costner as an unflappable and hardened CIA agent continues to impress as a great personable actor.The movie had elements at times similar to a 'Mission Impossible' movie and at other times, to a 'Bond' movie.  There is plenty of action and it all really picks up during the second half of the movie.  It had me on the edge of my seat.  I recommend this movie to anyone liking action movies with a lot of modern spy technology and modern day spies.If my review was helpful, and I hope it was, please choose 'yes' in the helpful comments section below.  Thank you.  Richard

I gave this watch to my 10 yr old Grandson as a gift.  And he was, and still is, fascinated by the movements of the inside of the watch which are observable thru both the top and underside of the watch.  In fact I liked it as well and considered keeping it a while longer for my own observation.  I think it is unique for a boys watch.  Everything moves very smoothly and for that reason it appears to me to be worth more than it actually is.  And I liked the way the watch was already up and running upon first opening the attractive and sturdy case.  The first word from my grandson was, "wow."The watch itself has good weight to it and feels solid and 'handsome.'  I think, for the price, its a great gift to give to a young boy.  I think I would have been fascinated by this when I was a kid.  The ability to watch all of the movements in this watch is what makes the gift.  Hope you enjoyed my review, and if you did, please choose 'yes' in the helpful comments below.  Sincerely, Richard

(Update Dec 6th 2014)I highly recommend this book for the RX100M3 by Gary Friedman.  I bought it and love it (http://friedmanarchives.blogspot.com/2014/12/lots-of-announcements.html?m=1)I bought this camera because of its faster lens (f/1.8 to f2.8), which means, to me, more light entering onto the cameras sensor which, in turn, means to me slightly better images than previous models. Which translate to a shallower depth of field available. And that's exactly what I like and want in this model, and precisely why I bought it, even though I also have the previous M2 model. One thing I want to note here before I go on. The Aperture seems to move quite fast from 1.8 to 2.8 thru the smaller zoom range. In that, a case could be made that this lens is more of a steady 2.8 thru out the zoom range.So then what exactly did I get with this upgrade from my M2 to my new M3? Well, you've got the newer Bionz X processer. The new 180 degree LCD (for Selfies if you are so inclined). The pop-up EVF (which is an innovation in and of itself, and a help with image stabilization when pressed against my face). Zebra pattern and focus peaking which is available on my RX10 and now the M3.I feel the 24mm-70mm lens (though not the same reach as my previous M2 model - 28-100mm) is a good walk-around lens. And since I have been using this same zoom range for a long time on my DSLRs, I feel very comfortable with this zoom range in a very capable and now compact camera. When I use this for portraits at the long end of 70mm I expect to shoot mostly 1/2 to 3/4 body shots to full body shots. As opposed to the previous models zoom range of 28-100mm where I used it up to head and shoulder shots at the long end.This camera has the same Bionz X processor that Sony has in their A7 line of cameras (one of which, the A7R, that I have). That was another plus for me in buying this camera. As far as image stabilization, it is important to compact cameras today and thus, to me. And I find that holding the camera up to my face while using the EVF gives me the 'feel' of a more stabilized shot. And my pictures look better to me. This is important to me because now that I am in my 60's, try as I might, holding the M2 or my smartphone without an EVF - is not as steady as I'd like it to be or as I remember it was when I was younger. And I need image stabilization in lower light. And this EVF on my new compact M3 seems to provide that for me. The only 'unofficial' (perhaps non-technical) test I could do with this camera was to zoom it out to 70mm, and hold the shutter half-way to see how much 'lock' I had on the image. Then I tried it with my M2. My observation was that I did see an improved difference with the M3.There is a slight difference in camera size from the previous model (which I also have). The thickness of this model is about 2mm more. And the weight is about 8 to 9 grams more. What this also means in terms of fitting a leather case to it is that my previous models Sony leather case will not fit this camera. You're going to need the Sony LCJRXF/B Premium Jacket Case (Black). This new case will fit all previous models as well as this model. Just as the Sony LCJRXC/B Premium Jacket Case (Black) would only fit the M2 as well as the M1. Some people think that the case for the M2 will also fit the M3. It will not. I have tried it. I also recommend the custom camera grip by Richard Franiec (camera accessories by Richard Franiec). This goes for about 35$ and is worth its weight in gold - to me. It is far better than the Sony grip that I used on the M2 for 15$. Its made of metal (anodized aluminium) is sleek looking, feels good quality and solid, and gives you a good grip on the camera while still maintaining the cameras pocketability (because it doesn't protrude past the lens assembly). Of course with the camera grip added, the M3 will not fit in the Sony Leather camera case. So it is either one or the other. So to get around this I ordered another OP/TECH USA Soft Pouch Digital D-Micro (Black) for my M3 which I also have for the M2. And it fits great.If my review was any help with your decision to purchase, and I hope I was of some help, kindly choose 'Yes' in the comments section below. Thank You. Richard

I've had this printer for over a year now and its still working flawlessly for me.  And I have yet to change the ink.  Granted, I probably don't print that much (I've probably used but one package of paper so far), but have no problems with the Fax, copy, Scan or printing functions so far.  I have been able to print from my phone remotely using Google Cloud printing.  It was easy enough to setup with the Google app on my phone.Printers have always been a problem for me.  I don't know why because I seem comfortable enough with everything else, tech, but printers ....not so good.  But thisPrinter was easy right out of the box.  And the manual provided is very easy to follow along should you have any problem with any of its functions.  And it just works for me whenever I need it to.  I recommend this printer whole heartedly.If my review was helpful,  and I hope it was, please indicate yes in the helpful comments section below.  Thankyou.  Enjoy.  Richard

In my opinion,  this sign works.  I was regularly getting almost daily animal deposits in the same area of my yard.  I put this sign up and they stopped.  The sign itself is strong and looks built to last.  And it's hard to miss the meaning of this sign by dog owners.  In fact they all look at it, point at it and smile and keep right on going.  One dog even looked at it, inspected it and decided to keep right on walking which leads me to believe some dogs know better than some owners.I pounded the sign with a rubber mallet until the wing-like structures on the metal pole were just beneath the ground.  It didn't feel like it was going to go anywhere.  After which I then placed the sign on the pole.  I highly recommend this sign.If my review was helpful,  and I hope it was, kindly choose the yes button in the helpful comment section below.  Richard

I was happy to receive one of these recently and was immediately impressed with the lightweight but sturdy design of the battery case.  After using other brands, this one seems less bulky to me.  This one does not have the rubberized feel of a previous brand but neither is this slippery for me even though it has a smoother finish.  And it does seem to slide in and out of my cargo pants front pocket easily.  All in all, I do like the appearance it gives my phone and the extra grip I now have when using the phone during calls.  I feel like I'm holding something more substantial in my hand.  And it is easier to slide on and off the phone by the simple way it separates.  And once connected to the phone, it stays on, secure and tight.  It's got a good fit.Battery usage is excellent and does not disappoint.  It works as expected and gives me another day of power usage after my iPhones internal battery dies.  And I do like the use of the micro USB cord for charging (it first powers the phone before next powering the extended battery), especially since I have a lot of other devices that use the same micro USB.  Which makes for more convenient traveling, which I do a lot.  Recently flying to Dallas, I was rerouted to Houston,, needing to rent and drive a car for four hours to Dallas, and still had enough power for my phone from 7am until 4am the next morning.  So there is a certain amount of security knowing I have got plenty of power and not have to worry too much about it.I can recommend this product without any reservations.  Some have mentioned that they didn't think it offered enough protection in a fall.  It feels to me that it offers as much protection as most other battery cases.  This will protect your phone in most situations in anything but the most dire or extreme circumstances.  And all this in an attractive case.  With great utility.If this review has been of help to anyone, and I hope it has, please use the yes button below in the helpful reviews comment section.  And if you have any questions, please leave a comment and I will get back to you.  Thanks and enjoy.  Richard

He got this earlier this year and in the short time we have had to try and get a new battery and fix the screen (all without warranty). The warranty doesn't cover the LCD screen and so we had to pay for the repair ourselves, which wasn't cheap. Then the battery went on the fritz and we had a horrible time getting a replacement for it. Overall, my kid loves it, but my husband and I hate it.

I built some gear cases and wanted to protect the edges and hold the longer sides together firmly transit.  I searched long and hard to find these, actually buying smaller ones first and then ordering these.  They are very large, 1.5” inches on a side, each of the 2 sides are exactly the same.  I believe they complement both the looks and the sturdiness of the boxes.  When paired with the matching corner protectors, they create a very sturdy box solution.  These are very thick steel; they protect the box and help hold it together by binding each of the sides along the edge, helping the box hold together during rough handling.After working with some expensive commercial travel boxes, I decided to build my own.  Using these case side clamps along with corners I was able to fabricate my own boxes out of ” ply that are just as sturdy as the professionally made very expensive boxes.  Of course I added secure latches like these too Reliable Hardware Company RH-1688/0371-A Large Low Profile Butterfly Latch and Keeper, to compliment the looks of the box.  These are the pieces I used for the corners Reliable Hardware Company RH-1027-8-A Medium Size Zinc Road Case Ball Corner - Set of 8.  With the combination of the great clamps, corners and side pieces I now have a very solid case for my generator.  I added the worn look to the wood prior to staining it.  These boxes spend months in the Alaska weather and still look great.Pictures are attached to give you an idea of what these look like in use.5 stars, very solid, well designed sturdy case edge clamps.

I built some gear cases and wanted to protect the corners during transit.  I searched long and hard to find these corners, actually buying smaller ones first and then ordering these.  They are very large, nearly 2 inches on a side, each of the 3 sides are exactly the same.  I believe they complement both the looks and the sturdiness of the boxes.  When attached on all 4 corners of a box, they keep the base off of the ground by about 1/8”.  These are very thick steel; they protect the box and help hold it together by binding each of the sides at the corner, preventing the box from getting damaged.After working with some expensive commercial travel boxes, I decided to build my own.  Using these case protection corners I was able to fabricate my own boxes out of ¾” ply that are just as sturdy as the professionally made very expensive boxes.  Of course I added secure latches like these too Reliable Hardware Company RH-1688/0371-A Large Low Profile Butterfly Latch and Keeper, to compliment the looks of the box.  On sides where they were lengths that might need additional support I added these side protectors too Reliable Hardware Company RH-1707-8-A Road Case Clamp, Medium Size, 2-Hole with Rivet/Screw Protector , which hold the sides very securely just like these corners are secure.Pictures are attached to give you an idea of what these look like in use.  The pictures don’t really show the items well, so I hope these help.  This case is holding a Honda generator so it's fairly large.5 stars, very solid, well designed sturdy case corners.

I broke my last phone case (dropped it) I wanted a new one that would provide an edge around the front to allow me to lay it face down on my desk and not scratch it.  This phone provides that feature.  It also protects the glass in case of a drop onto a flat surface due to this feature.  I like that all 4 corners have the fully wrapped hard plastic shell around them to protect those too.The back, while it appears to perhaps be rubber feeling is the same plastic as the main case; it’s just colored and has a slight texture to it.  It is not as grippy has the cases with a rubber back.  I keep my phone in a pants cargo type pocket and the raised edge around this phone make it easy to get out of the pocket without the worry of dropping it.Watch out for the colors as you order. I had thought I ordered back, but received red due to the way the colors show on the main screen.  It’s still a fine color so I won’t worry but do make sure you get the color you intended.4 stars, I would have preferred a rubber type of back for a little more grip.  The case fits well, has a safe plastic feel and the fit and finish for the button covers is nicely done.

Anyone who uses a CPAP knows that the masks age, turn a little yellow and risk tearing with time.  I have an awful distaste for the way the insurance industry charges 3x what something costs so I decided to look around and find my own way to replace my mask.  I found this item, ordered one now and have been very happy with this mask.This mask is an exact factory made replacement for my ResMed Mirage FX Mask, it arrived in the factory packaging.  It is the standard size and available for much less cost than when purchasing one through my insurance provider.  Because I have an HDHP (High Deductible Health Plan) I have to pay either way so I might as well pay a third the price!When I get a replacement, I save the older one as a backup and also keep one in my travel bag.  That way if anything goes wrong, tears, gets lost in travel etc I still have one around.  I know you are supposed to replace these every 6 months, but I have used one for over a year with no problems.  It did age, get a yellow tint to it.  I try to wash them weekly and replace every 3-6 months.5 stars, an exact replacement to keep me sleeping well at night.

My state requires a minimum 3/32” of tire depth, and I like to watch my own tires to make sure I’m well in the safe zone.  This tool allows me to accurately determine the depth and it has a very nice pass, marginal and fail color coding system with green, yellow and red bands on the gauge.Simple to use, hold the depth rod over an area you want to measure and press down on the color coded section to see how far down it goes.  Then read the depth on that plastic barrel.5 stars, does the job well, for a low price, very easy to use.

For the price it’s hard to beat this flashlight holder.  No, I would not use it for an every day carry situation, or something you had to use on the job, but for keeping your flashlight in the car from scratching things up (or getting scratched) it fits the bill perfectly.This holder is made from decent material, though it’s on the thinner side.  The main thing I didn’t like about it is that the elastic on the side only covers about the middle third of the holder.  Both the top and bottom portions are open.  Since the bottom is open the flashlight can twist in the holder and then it’s not staying protected.  This is one big reason why I wouldn’t use it as a daily carry holder.4 stars, amazing value, but not the best design with the open sides.

When I bought my 2500 HD truck it came with a Class-5 hitch which is larger than the traditional Class-4 hitches most trucks have.  I didn’t realize that also meant that my safety chain hooks would be too small to fit into the holes built into the hitch.  To resolve that problem, I found that these D-rings look and work perfectly on the back of the truck.  Now I can easily and quickly install my safety chains and know they provide just as much safety as needed without modifying my truck.These are heavy duty D-rings and I’m really happy with the powder coating on them.  I’ve attached a picture to show how they look on the truck.  To be fair, these pictures were taken after a 15,000 mile trip, towing the entire way up and down the Alaska Highway!  These pictures show how little wear and how solid these D-rings are since the usage on a trip like that only consists of a few scratches.5 stars, great looking, functional and heavy duty!

When planning a multi-week trip in our trailer, I determined we would really like to have USB power inside for charging devices.  Another desire was to be able to watch the system voltage a little more closely than the 4 segmented bar system the trailer came with.  This panel was just the ticket and has accomplished everything we hoped for.The voltage is very handy for enabling me to see how the batteries were working when we were dry camping for a few days.  The USB power outlets worked out great enabling us to charge phones and tablets too.  The 12v power outlet was used for powering a portable speaker system when we wanted to crank up the tunes.  This panel worked great and is a very solid setup, though the volt meter read about .1v lower than my multi meter shows, not a biggie but nice to know for your reference.The panel was easy to install.  I found a place near my main power distribution system.  I mounted the panel facing into the hallway, not facing the bed and I’m glad I did that.  The LED lights can be bright and I didn’t want the facing me all night.  I drilled 3 holes using a 1-1/8" hole saw which is just the right size to mount the panel into.  It came with 4 wood screws that worked great to hold it nicely in place.  Before mounting I built a wiring harness so that I would only need to plug the panel into a single outlet in my distribution panel to power all 3 devices.  Now I have it installed, fused and working in the system just as if it were factory installed.5 stars, provides power, voltage and a very clean simple install.

After using my FT-8800 for a few years, the Mic started giving me trouble.  At first it was the occasional report of static, some kind of noise and other misc things you can’t ever seem to trtace down.  I would unplug it, relieve the tension and it would work better.  I also worked through my ground system to make sure it was solid and yet the problem remained.  After some time I decided to replace the Mic wires, but then found that I could buy a replacement Mic for less than just the wiring harness and avoid all that hassle.This Mic is working better than my original Mic.  It appears to be factory original, but a few things have changed, and have been improved!  The wiring is a little thicker, more robust and I hope avoids the issues my original had.
