Additionally the PTT button has a little better definition between on and off, more of a solid feel to it and I really like it.  The rest of the features, the lighting and so forth all appear to look and function exactly the same.Ad far as sound quality, I’m getting great reports and have been told many times I now sound better than I have in years.  It’s very nice to have a solid system again, especially for those nights when running a Net.5 stars, if you feel your Microphone could be having an issue, try replacing it.

This is a very solidly constructed wallet.  It’s made from thick leather, has a secure sewing thread and will last a very long time!  I like to keep the cards and money I carry around in my front pocket, and while you can do that with this one, it’s a bit thick for me.  I like it to keep my cards in, but ordered the thinner one here for daily carry [inser link].  If I need to go out and carry more than the smaller version fits I use this one and do really like it.  It’s very nicely made.The center piece of leather has the tanned smoother side on one side and the rougher finish on the other.  If you slide your folded cash into the outside pocket that is finished it’ll go in very easily.  I put credit cards and ID in the insides where they are held securely.  When I first got it, placing more than 3-4 cards in a side was tight.  Now that I’ve used it for a few months I can easily get 5-7.  I don’t like to load it up too much though or it gets too thick and I don’t like that feeling in my pocket.4 stars, while the quality is amazing, it’s thicker than desired for a daily carry in my case.

This is a very nicely constructed front pocket wallet.  It’s made from thick leather, has a secure sewing thread and will last a very long time!  I like to keep the cards and money I carry around in my front pocket for security.  I also prefer to keep the number of items low and base that on what I need for the day.  This wallet fits my needs just right.The center piece of leather has the tanned smoother side on one side and the rougher finish on the other.  If you slide your folded cash into the side that is finished it’ll go in very easily.  I put credit cards and ID on the other side and it’s a very nice system.  When I first got it, placing more than 3-4 cards in a side was tight.  Now that I’ve used it for a few months I can easily get 5-7.  I don’t like to load it up too much though or it defeats the reason I bought it.  To keep the number of items I carry down!5 stars, this is my favorite front pocket wallet and it’ll last many years!

Many flashlights have a large enough cavity for both a 18650 battery or a 3xAAA battery holder.  The 3xAAA battery holder has a larger diameter than the 18650 battery so it fits tightly in the flashlight and the single battery fits loosely.  If this is your case, then these small sleeves act as a way to hold the single battery tightly in place.These work well and trying to find tubing and my own way to resolve this just didn’t happen when visiting the big box home improvement stores.4 stars, they do what they are designed to do, but pretty pricey for just a small tube of plastic.

In the last few years I’ve bought about a dozen different flashlights trying out the options and determining features I like.  This flashlight is my favorite light of all the under $50 lights I’ve tried!  Given that you can get it for about $16 (with discount code) it’s an amazing value too.  This light is very well made, the machining is very smooth, the tail and top caps come of and go on extremely smooth and easy, and I really like the matte black finish.  The light also comes with a nice leash, the kind I like that doesn’t have any metal parts which can make noise or scratch the finish.  It also comes with 2 spare O-rings just in case you mess one of yours up.  I apply petroleum jelly to my threads to keep that from happening.This light is very bright, I estimate about 450 lumens.  I like the feel of it in my hand; it’s a very handy size.  Small and light, yet enough power to last hours and provide an amazing light.  The bulb end has a nice large reflector which has the added benefit of causing the focused beam center portion of the light to stay tighter farther away than any of my other lights.  I really like this light, without the need to have an adjustable focus it provides a very focused center and a really evenly lit surrounding fill.Here’s the best part about this light, the lowest 2 settings are nice and low, it seems too many worry about the brighter side of the range and don’t actually provide lower options.  The Low is really low and great for checking the house at night to make sure things are off but not blasting light all over the place.  The Moonlight setting is really low, you can use it to keep your night vision and yet provide a small touch of light.  This is one of my favorite settings and something I’ve only seen on $60 and higher lights.  If I could make any changes it would be to increase this moonlight setting to about 1 lumen rather than ½, but that is a very minor difference.I’ve really come to love the 18650 battery for flashlights and this particular light really shines as far as features for the size and useful lighting modes the way I use lights.  The method used to change the default lighting mode when the light is first turned on is fairly easy to use, and doesn’t get in the way of my normal use of the light.  That means I can set it to the mode I like my lights to start in (brightest) and not worry from there.  You do this by getting the light to the brightest state, turning it off and then back on in less than 2 seconds.  That sets the startup mode.  Then once the light is off for more than a few seconds it’ll start up in whatever default startup mode you had last set.5 stars, my new favorite under $50 light, I love the low lighting options when camping to assure I have light overnight if necessary.  Carefully read the text of the listing, I found a $7 off code in there that significantly lowered the purchase price of this flashlight.

I used my battery analyzer (Opus BT-C3400) and have tested this battery. It is delivering very close to what the listing claims, which is nice to see since so many batteries don’t deliver anything near what they claim.When cycling and testing the battery I received, it is right at 3475 mAh. The battery I received weighs 85.7 grams.  Knowing that these batteries deliver the power as claimed, it helps you fairly compare the price, value and performance that you need. This battery size can be harder to find, so knowing one that delivers as promised and works well is a great find.  I highly recommend that you stay away from the very poor UltraFire batteries, I have yet to see one of those deliver even half of what they claim.The batteries I received are labeled exactly as shown, they clearly state 3500mAh, so you can easily keep track of them with all your batteries.  These also have a button on the top and are labeled as made in China.I ordered mine through MXJO and it was delivered quickly.  One thing to be aware of is that this listing is for a single battery, which the title does say, but the picture shows two so it could be confusing.The only negative I have is that within the text of the listing, it claims these are the newer 4200mAh batteries and they are not.  Due to this mis-information I have to lower the rating to 4 stars.

This is a very nice light, especially at this price.  Considering the build quality and value, this is one I've now bought several of to have handy.  I really like the 18650 battery, the power and size are very convenient.  This light lasts over an hour on bright and gives a very nice light that entire time.  Take it down to low and you get several hours of a pretty bright light there too.  If I had any complaint it would be that the Medium and Low lighting levels should be much lower, so that the battery would last several days at low.To make a light useful for a tactical situation, the light MUST turn on to the brightest setting when first activated.  This light does that, there are others that don’t so look for this feature.  This light will then step through the 5 press sequence (high-med-low-strobe-SOS) by half pressing, without clicking  the power buton.  Once you turn it off for more than a few seconds, it’ll reset and come back on at the brightest level.These seem to ship with either a bright green or black button.  When I bought a single light paired with batteries (UltraFire batteries are junk, avoid them) it came with a green button.  When I bought a couple of these without batteries, they came with black buttons.  Your mileage may vary on the button color you receive?  They do stand on the button end, which I like so that a room or tent can be lit from below.This light is very bright, I estimate about 350 lumens.  I like the feel of it in my hand; it’s a very handy size.  Small and light, yet enough power to last hours and provide an amazing light.  It’s like turning in a 75 watt directed light in a room.  One thing to be careful of is the o-rings.  The first time you take it apart, use thread lube such as petroleum jelly on the threads to keep it turning easily and thus not mess with the O-ring.  I've had an o-ring get torn up already during my testing.  I was able to get a replacement at my local ACE hardware, which was very convenient.When you leave it on, it’ll warm up over time, but I;ve found that the heat varies based on the batteries used.  If I use these batteries Panasonic CGR18650CG Rechargeable 3.6V Li-ion 18650 Battery 2250mAh, package of 2, 3008x2, the light stays cool, barely warming up at all.  If I use these batteriesFlePowTM 2 Pack 18650 Lithium-ion Rechargeable Batteries (Button Top) 3.7V 2600mAh Rechargeable Li-ion Flashlight Batteries with Protected PCB Board, the light will get rather hot in my hand.  Perhaps the higher capacity batteries are flowing just a little hotter but not enough to make the light much brighter if that’s the case.  It make sense to me to get the lower power batteries and not waste the power creating heat.  I’ll have to run a duration test with both to see how it works out!5 stars, it’s a great light, for a great price.  Not the best made but the value is amazing.

I used my battery analyzer (Opus BT-C3400) and have tested these batteries.  They are delivering slightly more power than the listing claims, which is nice to see since so many batteries don’t deliver anything near what they claim.When cycling and testing both of the batteries I received, they are right at 2685 mAh and 2705mAh, very nice. Knowing that these batteries deliver the power as claimed, it helps you fairly compare the price, value and performance that you need.  These are nice batteries and I highly recommend that you stay away from the very poor UltraFire batteries, I have yet to see one of those deliver even half of what they claim.The batteries I received are labeled exactly as shown, they clearly state 2600mAh, so you can easily keep track of them with all your batteries. These also have a button on the top and are labeled as made in China.  They have worked in every flashlight I've tested, including replacing 3xAAA holders.  One additional and curious thing is that when I use these batteries in a WF-502 light, the light body where the LED is, gets very warm to the touch.  I have other batteries with slightly lower capacity where the light does not heat up at all.  These UltraFire® 2pc Ultrafire Wf502b Flashlight Cree Xm-l T6 Led 1000lm 5 Mode Torch(battery Not Included) are really nice lights for the money and work well with these batteries.I ordered these through FlePow and the order was fulfilled by Amazon as a prime order. I received them in 2 days, not weeks, they were from US based inventory.5 stars, for great batteries that deliver more than they are rated for and are working nicely.

This is a very nice light, I really appreciate the value, in fact I’ll be buying more, but NOT packaged with these terrible batteries.These batteries are rated at 3000 mAh, but when I have cycled them with the BT-C3400 changer, they actually only have about 975 mAh, not even a third of what is claimed.  Why bother with this size of a battery if you’re going to use one that has less capacity than AAA’s.  If that’s the case just yse a 3xAA light.  Crazy because the batteries sold with this package deal devalue the actually very nice light.The charger is ok, it doesn’t actually float up the batteries at the end of the charge so it’s not quite getting their max charge but it does cut off correctly and does work.The flashlight is a really nice light.  I have tested it with several different batteries, both flat top and button types and it works with all of them.  The batteries fit nicely, no slop and the threads are cut well.  I applied lube (petroleum jelly) to keep the threads from fighting you and that works nicely.  The light has a very solid feel to it and can be used as a nice tactical light because after it’s sat for a time, on the first press it always goes to the brightest setting, which is just what you want.  Then you can soft press and get to any one of the 5 press sequence (high-med-low-strobe-SOS).  This light does not focus, it does have a nicely sized beam, not too big, pretty nice for general uses around the house and camping.  It’s very solid and feels good in my hand.  It’ll fit in your pocket too, though a AA light is smaller if that’s what you want.  The clip is well attached and I’ve used to for clipping to backpacks and it stays nicely.I’ve left mine on for a considerable time and while it warms up a little, it isn’t getting hot which I really like.  I’m estimating that the light is about 350 lumens based on relative comparisons to other known light sources.  While it’s not what is claimed in the listing, it is still a very nicely bright light and great for a light of this size with a single battery.4 stars for the overall rating, the light is a 5, the charger a 3-4 and the batteries a 2.

Using the Opus BT-3400 battery analyzer, I tested these batteries and they are delivering slightly more power than the listing claims, which is a refreshing thing given so many batteries don’t deliver anything near what they claim.  When cycling and testing both of the batteries, they are right at 2350 mAh and 2375mAh, very nice for the price.  This gives them more than twice the power of the UltraFire batteries I have that the Analyzer shows only have 975mAh on a good day.  Concerning the disappointing Ultra fire batteries, why bother with this larger form factor if you only get the same power a AAA would have, crazy.The batteries I received are light green, say CGR18650CG on them, and have a very slightly extended button on the top.  One additional and curious thing is that when I use these batteries in a WF-502 light, the light stays cool and does not heat up.  I have other batteries where the same light can get very hot.  These UltraFire® 2pc Ultrafire Wf502b Flashlight Cree Xm-l T6 Led 1000lm 5 Mode Torch(battery Not Included) are realy nice lights for the money and work well with these batteries.To be clear, I ordered these through LED wholesalers and the order was fulfilled by Amazon as a prime order.  I received them in 2 days, not weeks, as they were direct from US stock.  It appears from all of the negative reviews that this might not always be the case so look closely at where your batteries are coming from and who is fulfilling the order.  The batteries I received look exactly like the pictured samples, they are labeled as made in Japan.5 stars, for great batteries that deliver more than they are rated for and are working nicely.

This is a very nice light, especially for the money.  To get right to the point, it has one serious flaw that makes it a poor choice for many usages.  When you first turn this light on, it goes to the state that is one press past where it was when you last used it.  Due to the 5 press sequence (high-med-low-strobe-SOS), this means it advances 1 state with each on/off sequence.  While this may not bother some, for use in an emergency situation, such as a carry light with a weapon, this feature means it’s not acceptable.  Your light MUST turn on to the brightest setting every time, no matter what to be useful as a tactical light.I love flashlights, batteries and trying out many of the different types available and if your purpose for having this light is to use for camping, and general lighting around the house, it’s a very nice solid light.  In fact it has many great qualities; it will run on a 3xAAA batteries, or 1x18650 which is very flexible, though it doesn’t come with a sleeve for the 18650 option.  All sizes fit and work well.  It’s plenty bright (~350lm), tough and the slide mechanism is solid, smooth and holds position.  I like the feel of it in my hand, it’s a very comfortable size.When you leave it on, it’ll warm up over time, but the fins on the telescoping head to a great job of dissipating the heat.  The zoomable feature is nice when you really want to look closely somewhere without lighting up the area around that object.  My light focuses well, so that you can clearly make out the shape of the light emitter on the wall.4 stars, it’s a great light, but the firmware used to control the lighting options needs to default to the brightest state at every power on.

Bought this for my wife who has Celiac disease and is allergic to Gluten.  In her case any Gluten from any source causes irregularity and issues. We have struggled for some time to find products that can help her battle this terrible issue.  It was so bad at one point that the Dr's recommended that she have her lower bowels removed.  Obviously this is a terrible problem so we have reached out to try natural products to resolve this instead.  This Regulate product, along with carefully avoiding gluten has helped keep her regular.  Thanks for this great product.

This tool has become a very used device in my workshop.  I am continually cutting, stripping and soldering wires in the size range of this tool.  For larger wires, I use a different tool and for really small stuff I have one just for those, but for the mid-size wires that I seem to use most often, this tool really does the job.The handles have a wider portion on the outer edge to give you more force when cutting the solid wires, I find it fits my hands well, I wear large size gloves and this tool is not a problem to use, plenty sharp.  It’s designed range is 10-20 AWG for both solid and stranded and that’s what I use it for.On the negative side, there’s no mechanism to lock the tool closed.  While this isn’t necessary, it would be nicer to have when I stuff this in a carry bag to lower the risk of the sharp teeth snagging on and accidentally cutting something.I like that they work well, that they are made in the USA and meet my needs.5 stars, I really love mine and use them weekly.

My trimmer continues to work great after several years now.  I had thought I could run to my local big box store to get a new spool cover when mine finally wore out, but they no longer carry these.  I was very fortunate to find this online, it's better to pay a few bucks and keep using my trimmer than be forced to buy a new one due to a broken lower cost part.This is an exact replacement unit, it fits my Grasshog GH7000 exactly.  Notice that this is the cover only and does not include a spool to wind your line on, you need to keep the spool you have been using and mount it on this spool cover.  When you are looking at these units, there is a similar one that only has one hole on the side for the line to exit, this is the double line unit which is what I needed.  This version was slightly harder to find.I hadn't realized how worn our my previous spool was until it literally exploded one day while spinning.  Thankfully this unit is available, and again I'm very happy with it.  You might consider buying 2 of these which is what I did so that next time I'll have my spare on hand.5 stars, works great and extends the life of a nice trimmer.

This is one of the tools I should have bought many months ago.  I learned the hard way that properly setting up a heli is the key to really allowing me to get past basic flight and move into some of the finer aspects of flying.This tool was used by a master pilot to show me how to fine tune and adjust my heli.  It flew so well and perfectly balanced that it was easy to see that I too needed one.  With the one I purchased I have now been through the setup proves and have completely setup my own helicopter to work and fly in a very balanced fashion.Some have previously mentioned that there are no instructions concerning how to use this.  Well, using this tool is VERY simple.  You turn it on. Hold it level on the surface you are setting the heli up on and press the ZERO button to define that orientation as zero.  From that point on as you measure blade pitch and movement it'll show you in 10ths of a degree what the angle of the blades are.  My batteries arrived working great, no issues there.  My gauge is also accurate and working well.To accurately setup your helicopter right depends on the Flybarless controller you are using.  Some have you go through and tell it what 6 degrees of pitch is and then it uses that as a baseline, others use different values and methods, so it's not really possible for there to be instructions with this tool to tell you that.  Look at your Flybarless controller and determine what it needs.  You will need to follow those instructions exactly to get everything setup as necessary.One hint, when you are tuning up your heli, start at the bottom and move up.  In other words start with the servos, make sure the arms are as level as possible.  Look at the links, make sure they all start the exact same length (I use a Micrometer for that).  Then move up to the Swash and make sure it's level.  Most FBL controllers have a way you can adjust each servo individually to help with this process.  Then you move up and set the pitch on the blade as per your FBL controller and so forth.Once you have your heli tuned, it shouldn't be wobbly or move in a piro, both upright and inverted.  That's a nice way to check your setup.5 stars, this is a great tool and mine is working well, I am very happy with it.  You can spend a lot more and get one that might be accurate to a 100th, but a 10th is plenty enough for me.

I like this so much that I bought a second.  One for home and one for my travel bag.  I'm actually surprised by the negative reviews I see here because this works so well for me.  This is one of those personal grooming things you really want to work well, and this tool does the job.  I was hesitant to get something without a motor.  After using it, I can tell you that it works great, quietly and efficiently.  No pulling or pain involved, though you do need enough coordination to be able to hold it on one hand and twist with the other ;-).There are 2 version here on Amazon, one comes with a carry case, the other doesn't and the cost is slightly less.  For my travel bag I bought the one without a carry case since it'll be in my bag.  They both come with a small brush and a plastic tube if you choose to store it in that. This version arrived in the plastic snaps shut display package, with the unit, in a plastic tube and the cleaning brush.This thing is small and really efficient.  I have a mustache and it really bugs me when a wild hair is tickling my nose, so I keep this hand to trim minor issues like that and I really appreciate how well this works.5 stars, I'm very happy with my purchase and pleased with the quality.  The size and function is optimal, any smaller could be difficult to use.  This is a quality unit, love it.

When I bought my Gaui X5 kit, it came with this VBar FBL controller.  My previous builds used the BeastX controller so learning this one took some time to carefully step through the setup.  Make absolutely certain you go through each step in the setup sequence.  Reversing just one option will cost you deeply in repair parts and time.This is the Mikado controller and uses the Mini vBar express software, or the VStabi Mikado software.  It comes one of those very small CD's and is also available for download from the Mikado site.  In my case I wanted to bind with DSMX satellite receivers and it wasn't an option in the Mini Vbar software as purchased.  I had to buy the $50 upgrade online from Mikado.  I paid in Euros and saved a bit, which you can easily do and have your credit card adjust for you.I play it safe due to all of the carbon on the X5, I use two satellite receivers, one in each of the 2 RX ports that come on the Vbar controller.  The fact that this controller supports DSMX directly, and 2 of them at that, is one of the reasons like this unit so much.There are Pros and Cons to the VStabi software you use to set the system up.  The Pro is that it's got instructions and explanations for the features right there on the screen, just hover over the option and it'll be explained in a pop-up window.  The Con is that you do need a Windows PC to run the software and configure your Helicopter.  That means you either need to use the PC at home, or haul a laptop to the field.  One other thing to consider is that when you mount the Vbar in your helicopter, you need to leave room to get the USB cable to the unit so you can set it up.  It's a little tight in my setup and can be a pain to get the plug in.  To help with this, I found these little adapters which I use to get into the unit: Motorola Right Angle Charger Adapter Mini-USB - SKN6182While the setup takes time to carefully go through all of the options, when flying this unit is rock solid stable in flight and provides an immense range of options including Governor (which I have not used yet).  I have now flown with several different Flybarless controllers (BeastX, VBar and Ikon) and this is the best handling with default options out there.  The interface has less options to worry about and just works how I prefer.  The Ikon has more setup options for example but how many flights are you willing to spend just setting up your Flybarless controller?5 stars for a high end Flybarless controller that works great.

After a recent crash, when I was putting my 450 Pro back together, I noticed that the bearings felt pretty rough.  When turning the main shaft, I could feel it acting "clicky" where instead of a smooth action, it was clicking between indentations.  I had about 150 flights on the helicopter and it felt as if the bearings were worn out.  To keep the bird flying smoother and to help prevent vibration damage to other parts, I went ahead and replaced the main bearings with these.  Instead of ordering new bearing blocks (those come with the bearings pre-installed), I found that these bearings are the exact replacements for the 450 size bearings.  I was able to pop the older bearings out of the blocks using a light tap on them with wooden dowel.  It worked perfectly for seating these new bearings also.Replacing these every 150 or so flights (or after a particularly bad crash) seems a reasonable cost for the enjoyment I get out of all those flights!  I will check my new bearings after 100 flights and perhaps these will last longer since I'm crashing less (don't want to jinx anything by saying that!).5 stars, perfect replacement main bearings for my 450 Align helicopters.

When I decided it was time to step up from a Flybar system and go Flybarless, I had many concerns.  One is the reliability of the gyro in the system (due to experience I know some gyros work better than others), and another was ease of setup and install.  With the many permutations available out there for FBL controllers and receivers, it looked like a real mess for wiring it up and keeping it working.  Then I discovered this combined Flybarless controller and receiver in one.  It really has worked well for me and I have been very happy with how it operates.  Having a clean install really makes a big difference, especially when you crash and end up rebuilding.  A clean install minimizes damage and helps assure you get things back in working order quickly.I will warn you up front, the first time you go through the setup, it's better if you have someone who is an experienced heli pilot go through it and check your work.  If you have someone who has setup a BeastX before, it's even better.  There are some subtle things you really need to watch for.  Not with this unit but with another type I got one setting wrong, started to spin my heli up and boom, it nearly exploded when things were backwards.  A mistake is costly so double check and ask friends if you don't know what one step might be saying.  It's critical that each and every step in the setup process be followed and checked.Ok, enough of the scary talk, this really is a nice unit, and easy to setup and modify.  You can do it at the field, in your house, however you want and simply due to the status lights and how the system works.  This system does not require a computer and connection to setup, it'll work with just your radio.5 stars, I liked it so much that I converted another one of my 450 helicopters to flybarless and went with this setup again.

I have been using these batteries for a dozen flights now to fly my 450 size helicopter (Align TRex 450 DFC).  These batteries are working well and giving me nice flights.  If they can continue to perform at this level after 50 flights, I will be very pleased.  (I'll update the review when I reach that point)  I bought a couple so that I've got a sample of 2 just in case one acts up.The box that these come in says:  HobbyCool Model: YTB4022003S 3S 11.1V 2200mAh 40CThese batteries are doing a great job of delivering full power over the flight.  I get a complete 4 minutes of great 3D flying with these, slightly less power at the end but over all a fairly flat power curve.  They don't bog down like other lower cost batteries under the load and in both time and energy level are working great.  Coming with the Deans connector is a nice bonus for me since that's what I'm using.With heavy 3D flying they are staying cool and that tells me that they are delivering a true 35C as that's what it takes to keep a 3D 450 flying well.  They are delivering without over-heating and without puffing.  They do warm up slightly, which is expected.So, here's how I would rate my batteries currently.#1, Pulse batteries deliver the most power over the entire flight, more raw power the entire time, but at twice the cost, you have to make a choice.#2, Hyperion batteries deliver well and last longer than another of my other batteries so far.  These guys are holding strong, still delivering at 2 years and 75 flights.#3, These batteries are about in the middle of what I am flying, doing well. Big cost advantage!  Only a dozen flights so I need more time with them.#3, Hobby King Zippy Compact, these feel about like the Amazon ZAP batteries and are doing the same at 50 flights now.#4, I've tried many generic batteries and from here down I end up giving them away since they can't handle the 3D flying anymore.  Turnigy, Sky Lipo, Blue copies and others.  While they might be fine in planes or cars, they can't keep up the continuous head speeds needed for 3D heli flying, which really needs to get access to 35C.4 stars, great batteries, not 5 because they aren't quite delivering the same performance as my pricier batteries.

I have been using these batteries for a couple years now to fly my 450 size helicopters.  They are nice in many ways relative to the other 2200, 2250 and 2500 size 3S batteries, but not perfect.On the very positive side these batteries to a great job of delivering full power over the full flight.  I get a complete 4 minutes of great 3D flying with these, slightly less power at the end but over all a fairly flat power curve.  They don't bog down like other lower end batteries under the load and in both time and energy level are working great.  Another nice feature is that I've been able to get over 100 flights per battery and they are still delivering.With heavy 3D flying they warm up and on the negative side, have gotten a little puffy.  At first I was worried about the puffiness, but it's been months now and they continue to fly fine.  It could be that due to flying in Phoenix Arizona where it tends to be hotter they are more puffy here, but I've also heard from friends who use these in cooler climates that they puff for them too.  Some batteries puff, others stay flat, these are the type that get puffy, again not bad but not like when you buy them.  Mainly you need to know this if you have a tight fitting fuse you slip one into.  I have some gliders where if the batteries puff you can't get them in and out anymore.All in all, nice batteries, Hyperions tend to sell for a little more than the off brands but due to their flat power curve and then number of flights you can get out of them, they end up being worth it.If you are still crashing often and destroying your batteries, stick with lower cost ones until you can get past that learning phase ;-)One other thing to know, you'll need to solder on your own connectors.  These do not come with a connector on the power leads.  On the balance port it has the unusual Hyperion wiring, which to me is a negative because most of my other batteries use standard connections, this means you'll need to keep a balance adapter just for Hyperion.4 stars, great batteries, not 5 because they do get puffy and cost a bit more.

If you want to get access to your manuals without having to go the store and buy them, this is the tool you want.You can pick the area, the specific manual and off you go.  It's a very handy way to not only teach but follow along in class too.  It keeps you from having to tote around the paper manual and then there are other nice features like searching for words.  I use it when I know a scripture but can't remember where it is, search for the few words you know are there and boom, it'll find it for you.  Great shortcut.5 stars, great app and the church keeps adding new features too, you'll be very happy you downloaded and installed this one!

This is a heavy duty nicely made L14-30 female receptacle that is designed to handle 30 amps at 240v. Each of the wires slide into an individual tube when you assemble the unit, to keep possible stay wire pieces from arcing. There's also a screw down stress relief section that tightens down on the cord to keep the cord from tugging at the connections if you were to pull on it. Each of the tubes where you insert the wires are clearly marked with W,G,X,Y for the 4 wires usedThis receptacle is well made and doing the job nicely.  I firmly tighten down the #10 wire (which needs to be used to support the 30 possible amps).  It's designed to hold this size wire.I primarily use this to supply power to my welder.  The welder sits on a cart that I built with a power distribution center on it.  I run a cord from the cart over to the wall where I have an L14-30 female to plug this into.  It works well and I really like the locking connection, it keeps things plugged in if there's a little tension on the cords.The main reason for selecting this plug when I designed my welding cart is because it works with most of the 240v generators out there.  Generators use this plug because it can handle 30 amps at 240v for about 7500 watts of power (30 x 240 = 7200)  Use extreme caution if you backfeed info your home with this plug.There are 2 main concerns to watch for if you plan to backfeed power.#1, is that you MUST disconnect the main feed on the house main panel to make sure you are not trying to power up your neighborhood, and that you don't risk shocking a power line worker who might be trying to restore your power.  If the power does come back online and your generator was to be connected, you would fry your generator.#2, is that to back feed a generator with this plug, you end up with a connection setup with 2 male ends.  Those ends can be very dangerous if they have power.  Connect your wires before turning on the power at your generator to keep from having any shock risk.  If your only use for this plug is to backfeed, I suggest using this adapter instead. Reliance Controls PB30 L14-30 30 Amp Generator Power Cord Inlet Box For Up To 7,500 Watt Generators  My reason for selecting this plug is that I use the same power outlet for powering my welder and have it available if I were to need to backfeed the home.This link takes you to the plug I used which is also well made and they work great together.Leviton 2711 30 Amp, 125/250 Volt, NEMA L14-30P, 3P, 4W, Locking Plug, Industrial Grade, Grounding - Black-White  Both of these pieces are available here on Amazon at a significant discount over the local big box stores.5 stars, a well-made lasting design for a great price.

While these staplers do last a lifetime, I've had to buy several now because when my kids moved out and went to college, mine suddenly was no-where to be found!  They knew what they liked and wanted them at college with them.I really like this stapler, a full stick of staples easily slides in and you actually get to use all of them!  The end where you staple has a pivoting base plate where you can change the staples to close in or out as desired.  It also opens up for stapling posters to a wall board for classroom displays.  The rubber base is nice and keeps it securely in place when in use on the desk.  There's a small red indicator on the side to quickly look and see if you need to add staples, though I find I open it up and look inside anyway.It'll easily handle a dozen standard weight pages which is about all I generally staple.5 stars, this is a great stapler with the new models working just as well as my 20 year old one.  My many years older version says Stanley-Bostitch in white lettering at the bottom front, other than that they continue to look about the same.

I got tired of trying to cut through some of the thicker cables I use for my Ham Radio station and decided to break down and buy these.  After using them now for some time, I really should have made this purchase long ago.  These are great cutters, they are strong, sharp and it’s obvious they will last a lifetime.  They make what used to be a tedious chore a simple act.As far as saving time, they do this by simply and quickly cutting my cables.  They save me money because now my cables start off with very clean straight cuts and when I am working to attach the various adapters (which are also expensive) I have a great starting point and don’t have to worry about re-working the ends before making the attachments.5 stars, great tool, great price and if you need to cut any serious cables they are well worth the investment.

I bought this kit to play around with some hardware designs I have in mind for a few projects around the house.  I've been a programmer for many years, I wanted a simple way to get into some hardware projects and needed a platform.  This is just the ticket for what I have wanted to do.The SainSmart board is a copy of the Arduino Mega 2560-R3 and costs considerably less, which enabled me to get this nice kit and have a bunch of fun options for playing around with.  You want the Mega board since it allows much larger programs and has many more options.Warning, for the newbie, this kit does not come with any instructions, only the hardware you see in the pictures in a nice plastic box.  Still, it's a great value and if you are willing to do a little reading online, finding the examples and tools out there is simple, search for Arduino, Learning and Examples. The programming is simple, essentially a subset of the C language.  There are some new words to learn such as a Program is called a Sketch.As far as the hardware goes, everything I have tested so far is working great and having all of the pieces necessary to work through all of the sample apps has been very nice.  Sadly one corner of my box was broken during shipping, but I like the box none the less and a small piece of tape over the hole will keep me from losing the nice yet smaller pieces of the kit.Yes this is a copy, yes this is less expensive than the name brand Arduino board, but the reality is that it's an open source design and this copy lets you get going for less.  The main thing when buying copies is if the instance will work with the IDE, and this SainSmart R3 design works with the main Arduino IDE (integrated Development Environment) from the start, no issues, the drivers auto install.Here's the great part about working directly with the IDE.  There are lessons, steps and examples provided on the main Arduino.cc site and they work exactly with this board.  No worries about trying to decipher the version that is found on the SainSmart site (which I had fun doing too), just go directly to the Arduino site, look for and get that version, those instructions are well done and easy to follow.  The IDE includes the source code built in, just go to File | Examples and you will see hundreds of examples, including the exact lesson samples all typed in for you and ready to build, upload and modify for your learning.Here are some getting started steps, just in case this is your first dive into Arduino like it was for me.  Sorry I can't put links in the instructions, Amazon removes them.Replace the word slash with a backslash and this is a useful link to start with arduino.cc slash en slash Tutorial slash HomePage1: go to the Arduino site, download the IDE for your particular system (there are Win, Mac and Linux versions).  I picked the v1.5.6 version which as of this date is the most current.  Don't mess with the Nightly builds, too much chance for things breaking there.2: install the IDE you just downloaded, which will also install the drivers.3: plug in the Mega to your USB cord (included in the kit) and then into the computer and it should show up on your system and the drivers should auto install.4: now run the Arduino IDE installed in step 2.4.1: In the IDE, select Tools | Board | Arduino Mega or Mega 2560.  Now you have the right board and the IDE knows how to treat it.4.2: Select Tools | Port and notice the ports shown.  Unplug your Arduino.  Now go back and check the ports, the one that the Arduino was plugged into will be missing... make a note of that one, plug back in your Arduino, then go back and select the port it's on.There you go, you can get samples, build projects and upload code to your Arduino Mega.  Pretty quick steps to get you going, but hey this is a review, not a guide ;-)Congrats for your wise choice and good luck building fun projects.4 stars, not 5 simply because some minimal instructions should be included to help the new users figure these basic steps out.  So far, the hardware is all working at 5 stars.

I needed some new fingernail clippers and have found recently that the Trim brand clippers I’ve been using for years have gone downhill.  I really liked the size and function of the older Trim brand and thus I’ve been searching for a suitable low cost yet quality replacement and am pleased to have found these.  These clippers are nearly an exact match for the Trim brand, but they are quality made and functioning very well (at least the 2 I received).  They do not come in any packaging, just 2 in a baggie inside of a shipping package.  They are Asian made, with a character that means Beauty on the top.These have a nice feel and quality cut to them.  The cutting surface is very sharp and lined up well so that you get a smooth quick cut that is accurate and doesn’t leave a frayed edge as the poorer quality clippers can.The tension on the unit gives a very nice feel and I like it.  About the only thing I can see as a bit rough is the file.  The file surface is very rough and can really only be used for a rough file, you need to finish up after using it with something that has a softer feel to give me the smoother finish I like.  The small hole at the end is there like I prefer since I like to put a chain or key ring there.5 stars, I’m really happy with these clippers

I have a Dewalt generator with a Honda GX240 motor that I use occasionally for construction jobs away from grid power, and keep for backup power needs.  Since I want to count on this baby running in case of an emergency or power outage situation, I felt having a spare spark plug was a good idea.  I went ahead and changed my spark plug over to this one and it’s working very well.  Exact fit and no issues at all, starts well and is working great.One additional nice thing for having a spare around is that if you accidentally flood your motor, you can remove the plug, and put a new one in and quickly get back up to speed.Update:  I’ve run a hundred or so hours on this plug with no issues, it continues to run great for me

I have a generator that has a 240v output and I wanted to adapt the power to run my 120v devices using locking connectors for job site needs, that way they don’t pull out when tugging on the cords.  Looking around I found this adapter and it’s very solid and working very well.  As far as my devices (tools, drills, saws, sanders etc) they are all working great and I have not had any problems.Make sure you carefully check your power source and cords to verify that his adapter will fit your needs.  The input side is the L14-20P which is the one where the tab points out (not inward) so make sure you aren’t after the 30 amp version where the tab points into the center.  The description is accurate, and the picture will zoom in to show you the exact details.  Mine looks exactly like the image and is VERY solidly built.  I didn’t expect it to actually weigh as much as it does, this baby is solid at nearly 3 lbs!5 stars, this is one robust heavy duty adapter.

If you have need to use either a plastic or rubber light-weight hammer, this very low cost hammer is working well for me.  I needed to round out a ring and used the sizing stick I also bought at Amazon as a form and it worked great!  This is a very light weight hammer and certainly has limited use for forming lightweight jewelry, wire or sheet-metal, but for those purposes it does work well.4 stars, mine is holding up reasonably well, you can tell the goal here was to be low cost and not highly refined as the fit and finish is mid-range, but hey for a couple bucks, what can you really expect!

Having worked actively in Scouting for most of my life (Woodbadge, camps and many nights in the wild), I was very eager to get this book.  It does a great job of sharing how the 2 organizations, the Boy Scouts of America and the LDS church (The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints aka Mormons) worked together to combine efforts and common goals to build a great program that has been a wonderful benefit to those who are able to join in Scouting.I highly recommend any LDS who are curious how "Scouting" fits into the LDS frameworks and is viewed as the activity arm of the YM program.  This book is now a cherished item on my shelf to occasionally enjoy the pictures reminding me of my lifetime of Scouting and the wonderful friendships built along the way.5 stars, as an LDS Scouter, I really love this book.

I had a hanging garage system installed in my home from a professional installer and wanted to add some hanging hooks.  As a calculated guess I tried these and sure enough they work.  My grid pattern is 3”x4” so they only fit one way, but still, they do work in the 3” grid sizes.  They are a little loose once installed which seems unusual but hey, they work and I can hang thing now.On problem with these is that at least with my grid, the 3” gap has the wires on the top so I can only install these between boxes and such that are in place on the storage unit.  Look at your system from the bottom, measure the spacing to determine which areas have 3” gaps, and then see if those gaps have the bars at the top of bottom and the direction they can go.  If these stick up and interfere with the boxers stored on the unit, they are more difficult to use.  It limits how and where you can use them but they are still useful.4 stars, not because they don’t work but because they don’t fit exactly and you can only use them in places between boxes.

I work with many different tablets and phones and end up using these USB to Micro cables all the time.  I wanted some longer cables and found these to be really useful for my needs.The cables I received are holding up very well, fit tightly and feel solid.  The cable sheath is not too slick, not too soft and feels like it’ll last.  Currently my cables are only a couple weeks old but with daily use they are holding up very well.  I like how nicely they fit in, and the gold connector gives the feel of an expensive cable with a quality hold, which I hope continues being the case many months from how!I have been able to test these cables with Android ADB, and powering my systems from various chargers with various abilities all the way from 5 watts to 25 watts and the cable works well in all of those cases.5 stars, I’ll be buying more for other cabling needs.

Unfortunately I can't write a review outlining the charge current and abilities of this device because mine failed with less than an hour of total time on it.I started by plugging in an iPhone, it showed up, worked and appeared to begin charging.  I left the phone charging for a few minutes and all seemed well.  I plugged in a tablet that needs 25 watts to run (with the battery out) and it wouldn't turn on, so I know that it doesn't put out 25 watts (no surprise, it's only rated at 21, hey but why not check?).I decided it was time to monitor the charger so I plugged in my Samsung Galaxy Tab3 and left it to charge.  Initially it was charging and went up a couple percent.  Checking in roughly 15 minutes I noticed something unusual.  Even though it said it was plugged into a charger (display said it was charging), the power level was going down.  What?  I went back and tested the charger with other devices, including the original iPhone and the charger is no longer recognized and is no longer putting power out at all.  Somehow while charging the Android tablet it failed.Super bummer, I was looking forward to fast charging a couple devices at once.Though I rarely return anything, this one is going back.  It didn't work for more than a few minutes and does nothing at all now.2 stars, I am NOT happy with this.  Not 1 star because, well it did work for a few minutes.*** update: I was contacted by the vendor for a replacement unit.  I'm going to change this to 3 stars for now pending review and validation that my broken unit was an unusual occurrence.

This is a solid and well-built rack  with a nice area for kitchen books or decor! Nicely designed, it goes together very well and is firm and secure. We are very happy with the looks; it's a really nice addition to our kitchen and gives us a nice homey feeling. The color is powder coated and gives a nice antique look, matching our cabinets and hardware very well.  We have darker cherry cabinets with bronze handles and they match this nicely.Besides looking great, a benefit of this rack is how much cabinet space you free up for other things. We like hanging gout pots and lids together (with the lid inserted through the pot handle and then the pot handle hanging.  Some like to hang both pieces separately, that’s up to how you like yours to look, it’ll work either way.  I like to grab a pot and get its lid too.In our home the wall studs are 16” on center, so the 32” spacing that this came pre-drilled for worked perfectly for us.  If you have a wall with 24” centers you’ll need to drill some additional holes on the back side (make sure you drill on the back not the front, the front side has threaded holes for the added supports).  I strongly recommend you firmly attach this directly to studs due to not only the weight of the rack, but the weight of the pots and other items it’ll be holding.  I used a stud finder to assure a direct stud install. It would be sad to drill several holes in your wall.  Make sure it’s level by carefully measuring your first hole to floor distance and matching that on the 2nd hold.5 stars for a very solid and secure rack that performs well and looks great.

As a software professional who spends his days working on Android optimizations, this book was a very exciting find and I enjoyed reading it to gain an insight into another view of this world I spend my life in.  While I reviewed a hard copy, it's an incredible deal as a Kindle download.  Here's my overview followed by my synopsis.Chapters 1-5The first few chapters cover the History and evolution of Android, and some discussion of the chips used to power the systems, along with a market evolution and discussion.  Chapter 5 includes an interesting discussion of Intel x86 vs Arm and then does a nice job of covering x86 architecture.  The practical need to build an x86 version for best performance is discussed along with the mention of a binary translator which assures all ARM code will run on x86 systems (pg 46 for picture and description).Chapter 6 Steps you through installing the Android SDK and covers emulation if you don't have destination hardware for testing your builds.Chapter 7 gets into the main reason for the book, how to create and port an NDK application.  Starting with a discussion of Java and using JNI to call C code, then stepping into NDK application development and the use of the Android NDK tools, Cygwin and steps to build your app and then NDK compiler optimizations, including coverage of the Intel specific switches (great summary to keep handy).Chapter 8 covers debugging and using ADB.  Very briefly there are mentions of the Intel GPA tool, JTAG debugging, device driver debugging, a brief discussion of the differences between ARM and x86 (CISC vs RISC) and one paragraph on hyper threading.Chapter 9 is the largest chapter in the book and where we get to the details performance optimizations.  They cover types of optimization, such as optimizing for speed, code size or power consumption.  Tools are again discussed, including GPA (18 pages) and VTune (10 pages).  Steps are shown for using the tools but little into understanding the data and charts.  There's 40 pages on doing a thread analysis and linking that back to the tools also.Chapter 10 looks at vectorization, IPP and steps through a sample as optimized several ways for comparison.Chapter 11 looks at using HAXM and optimizing your virtual devices.Chapter 12 finished the book by discussing performance testing and profiling apps along with platform turning.The examples and data shown were captured during Medfield timeframe so there's new hardware coming out that dates this now.  It is better than anything I've seen in the public space up to now.5 stars, I highly recommend this book as a great reference for learning and doing performance tuning, for improving your apps and taking advantage of x86 features that can set your program apart from others by superior performance.  As with all things programming wise, you'll have to understand and build on this but it's a great reference and start for your tool box of goodies.

I have pondered just how one could write a review about a book that discusses prophecy and revelation?  I decided to write about how I felt and what the book caused me to ponder as I read it and pondered the information.  I won't be giving any spoiler alerts in this review.  After all, the prophecies have been written for generations, so a spoiler seems unlikely.Reading scriptures is a very personal experience, based on one's own experiences in life, we each seem to interpret things differently and find our own messages while reading.  What I really liked about reading this book is how it opened my eyes to see things in a new way.  Reed has spent considerable time and effort carefully and precisely reading through the scriptures to gather the data that he uses to calculate the numbers and information he presents.  While one can debate an individual prophecy and determine for yourself if you feel that one has or has not happened, it takes some confidence in your research to put up those decisions for thousands and thousands of prophecies!  I admire Reed for this work and appreciated the value gained in his insights.Overall this book presents a new ways to look a prophecies, a new way to view the information, and even a new way to organize your own view of the information.  I found myself referring to the text many times as I go back and see for myself just where on Reeds timeline he has placed things.  There's always room for debate on just where one might place something but the overall theme that they are presented in order of the scriptures presentation gives a solid starting place which can be adapted as you feel for the particular prophecy you are studying.  I enjoyed that the information was presented up front and clearly identified as to how the work was done and felt that this scientific approach adds value to the work.  I have enjoyed my purchase and feel it's a great value given the work involved and the insights it has given me.  Thanks to Reed for his work.As someone who enjoys reading their scriptures, I give this work 5 stars and have really enjoyed the value and insights it has given to me personally.

I'm pretty picky with my cases.  I like the corners of the tablet protected in a drop, and the cover to have a grippy feel so that it's easy to carry and comfortable to hold.  I also like the cover to flip all the way open behind the tablet.  I saw a friend with this case, gave it an evaluation and ordered one.  Upon receiving it, I'm even happier, this is a great case.This listing is for the same case in 3 different sizes, make sure you select the size you need.  The case I ordered is designed specifically for the Galaxy Tab 3 @10"  It fits perfectly snug and has nice corners to protect my tablet in case of a fall.  The texture of the exterior of the case has a nice feel and helps keep it in your hands.  It's not too slick, not too sticky, really just right for my tastes.  It's soft with a slightly rubbery feel, and has a honey comb pattern.  The case top flips up, and you can stand up the tablet in 2 different positions by forming a triangle with the case and the tablet.  You can also flip the cover all the way around to the back and there's a convenient hand hold where you can slip your hand in through the stretchy grip and give yourself an easy way to hold the tablet without fear or dropping it using only one hand.  Freeing your other hand for tapping and using the tablet.While it's thick enough to protect the tablet, and there's a nicely padded side that is against the screen thus not marring it, it's also not too thick.  I don't like covers that are so thick they feel like a big book when I carry my devices.About the only negative with this case, and frankly there's little the case designers could do as this is a design issue w/the tablet, is that with the tablet is standing up for use in the case, you can't change it because the charge port is at the bottom.  Since my battery lasts nicely this hasn't been an issue, but if you like to use yours plugged in, this is something to know.Ok, enough of the praise, I'm really happy with this and give it a full 5 stars.  The balance of design and a nice prices even makes it all the better.  FYI when I ordered mine it wasn't on Prime, now it's an even better price.

We spent the day at Disneyland using our phones to take pictures of our grand-daughter. The cell phone needed a boost and this auxiliary power did the trick. We are very happy with this tool and happy to have it around in a pinch. I've found that it can take a couple hours to fully charge, but it can charge up my iPhone 4S pretty quick.Here are the specifics. There is a micro USB connector used for input. On the input side it's rated at 1.5A (a 1.5A charger will charge it quickest). There's a full USB connector used for output. On the output side it's rated at 2.1A. There are 3 LED's internal to the case that light through the colored back cover right next to the output USB slot. When all 3 are lit, it's fully charged. Each blinks in sequence as charging, representing a third charged each. Very simple and requires no buttons or user actions to operate. The lights operate in reverse to show remaining capacity as you use it to charge your devices.To test the capacity, I ran my iPhone 4S down to 33%. I then plugged my iPhone 4S into the 5 Star America battery to charge it back up. It took about 35 minutes to get my phone back up to 67%, and it took about 90 minutes to get back up to 95%. I was able to use the backup battery to do this twice with my iPhone when I started with a fully charged backup. This is a great option, as I often drain my iPhone when I use it in tethered mode to get my laptop online and send/receive some files, sync mail and so forth. Tethering is one way to quickly drain my battery and having a backup power source really helps.As for using the backup battery, it's convenient that it has a full USB port since I can use it to charge any device that can take power from a USB port. I've tested with an iPhone 4S, and a Samsung Galaxy Tab3. The battery looks like a phone due to the black plastic front and its iPhone shape.4 stars, I am happy with this light, slim, easy to pocket and use battery.  Depending on your needs, you might consider a larger capacity (if you are charging tablets for example), but for a quick boost in a small package this is a nice option.  I was provided a sample for evaluation

This is a nice, medium duty trunk that is a great size for storing misc items in your truck or garage.  These are about the size of an apple box which is perfect for my needs since they will stack on my shelves and fit with my existing storage solution.  The dimensions are: Exterior 24" x 15" x 13"+ Interior 20" x 12" x 11.5".The lid has a grid pattern on the underside to add strength.  The lid works well for supporting my weight, I use them as chairs or tables in camp.  The lid has a grooved U-shaped channel around the entire area where it mates with the base.  This gives a nice dry seal as long as the trunk is kept upright.  One interesting design choice is that the lid has the latch pieces, not the trunk base.  They snap onto the base and hold well.  There is a hole at the side of each latch that can be locked if desired.  To secure lock these would take 4 small locking devices.  A simple screw chain link would work if all you were after was a double check feature.  There are 2 hook shaped extensions on each end of the trunk to allow for securing them during transit with a bungee or rope.  They also have a nice pattern molded into the base and lids that keeps them nicely stacked and secure so they don't slide around.I have been using the Rubbermaid Action Packers for many years, they hold up well but there's a few things I would prefer were different.  When I saw these boxes and realized they addressed my concerns I picked up a couple right away to see how they worked out.  These are more square at the ends than the action packers, which allows for easier packing and loading.  While the material thickness is similar, I feel these Plano trunks are more solid.  The Plano box doesn't have a large grip area, and while it works well and I can get my whole hand in, if they are loaded heavily it'll cut into your fingers some.  Gloves are a good way to deal with that.For placing gear in mine, in particular I can fit a keyboard flat at the bottom of these Plano trunks that would not fit in an action packer.  The allows me to pack up my keyboards, laptops, tablets, stands, USB hubs and various other computer supplies as I work remotely on occasion.5 stars, I'll be getting more of these and improving my garage storage due to these nicely designed units.

I was unable to find this receptacle locally at either Lowes or Home Depot, thankfully Amazon came to the rescue!  This is one sturdy piece of hardware, which is required due to the forces involved in connecting such a large plug to it.  The wires connect to the plug in individual tubes which are then clamped down with a screw that tightens up a plate attached to each terminal.  The tubes are a great way to prevent any flashing or arc inside the unit once it's in place.  I could get a nice #10 wire into each terminal easily.  As an FYI, I tried fitting a #10 and #12 into a hole to see if that would work and I could not get that to fit.  The insulation on the 2 wires caused it to be too wide to slide down into the opening.  Thus, this needs to be at the end of a run, and not in the middle as a junction.The tube design for this receptacle is exactly the same as the design used on the matching L14-30 plug as found here: Leviton 2711 30 Amp, 125/250 Volt, NEMA L14-30P, 3P, 4W, Locking Plug, Industrial Grade, Grounding - Black-White and this female plug Leviton 2713 30 Amp, 125/250 Volt, NEMA L14-30R, 3P, 4W, Locking Connector, Industrial Grade, Grounding - Black-WhiteThe receptacle comes with 3 screws and matching holes for attaching it to a box or surface.  When I bought a cover plate for my 4x4 box, I could not find one with 3 screw holes, but found several options with 2, 1 on each side.  To get what I had available to work, I drilled a hole in the receptacle and it's working well to hold to the cover plate.  I bought the 1" deep rise face plate to get the plug some room in the 4x4 box so that the wires have space in the box.  It fits well and looks nice.  I would upload a picture, but Amazon no longer supports user pictures for whatever reason?  Too bad I really liked that feature.4 stars, the receptacle is working great, but having to drill holes and modify it to get it to work in a standard mounting bracket seems like it shouldn't be necessary.

These finials have an opening on the base that is slightly larger than 5/8" x 5/8", more like 11/16" each way, which gives you plenty of room to slide them onto 5/8" square stock.  They are nicely made but I decided to grind the bottoms just a little more square before using since the halves of the mold on some didn't line up as square as I liked.  These are decorative pieces but made of thin enough cast iron that my guess is a firmly kicked soccer ball would likely break one off.  In fact, one of my 10 arrived broken due to being tossed around during shipping.  Have a spare or two on hand in case one gets broken.  These aren't industrial strength but for the price, it seems a good deal.This particular design is 5.75" tall and 2.5" wide at the base, looking at the design from the wide side.  From the thin side, the tip is about 3/16" thick, and the base just above where it attaches to the square section is 3/8" thick (double the tip thickness) and there's a smooth taper to the change in thickness.I am happy with the look and feel of mine.  I appreciate the assortment of options too.4 stars, great price on a beautiful decorative accent for my garden fencing.  Not 5 due to weak design and 1 arriving broken.

There's some confusion over 6" vs another size for this wheel and I want to clarify that this is in fact a 6" wheel and it does fit on my 6" bench grinder nicely.  I have a Delta 6" grinder and this wheel is working great for me.  I had to mess with the washers when mounting it to get it centered into the space so that it didn't rub on either side.  That is to be expected really and anytime I change out whatever I have in there this is necessary.This wire wheel brush is much stiffer than the previous one I had, and does an amazing job.  The wire bristles are very densely packed in and provide a flat surface to work with.  One really nice benefit is that after I'm done cleaning up my steel, I don't have little metal wire pieces all over because this model does not let them fly as my previous 2 wheels did.  That is really a big thing for me and I also feel causes this wheel to be much safer.  The face of this wheel is considerable wider and flat too.  It looks almost like a stone when once it's spun up it's so flat.  It's different than my previously "softer" wire wheels and took me a bit to get used to, but the bottom line is that I prefer how this one is working.  It does better at cleaning up my edges than my softer wheel did.5 stars, I'm very happy with the fit and durability of this wire grinding wheel.

We enjoy DoTerra essential oils and wanted a nice diffuser to get some of the great benefits into the air in our home.  This diffuser does the job and does it well.  You fill the basin with a little over an ounce of water, add a few drops of the oil you want to diffuse and turn it on.  Presto, a small misty draft will rise from the center column and begin to fill your room with the wonderful smells you desire.  The first press turns on the lights and the diffuser.  The second press turns off the lights, but leaves the diffuser on.  The third press turns it all off.  Nice feature if you don't want the LED lights on.There is an inner cap that covers the water first, and captures droplets and keeps too much vapor from rising up.  Then there's a colored cover placed over that to get the vapor rising.If I fill mine to the indicated level, and turn it on, it'll run until empty just fine.  If I overfill it, it'll turn off sooner for whatever reason?  I would prefer that the reservoir held enough water to last nearly a night's sleep.  The 3 hours isn't enough if you were trying to use it as a vaporizer for example with a child sleeping through the night.4 stars for a great diffuser, but it only holds about 3 hours worth of water.

I bought this meter so that I could compare engines and determine generator setups that would be quiet enough for me to work with.  I didn't want to spend much so I picked this option, and it turns out to be a nice choice.  The meter is very simple to use, it has 2 different modes.  In the primary mode it shows you a constantly updating reading, about once a second.  In the other mode (which you press the Max button to activate), it shows you the max reading since you pressed the Max button.  This gives you the ability to show the loudest over some period of time.There is an auto-shutoff feature which is handy, and you can disable it by pressing and holding the Max button on until UOF displays, then the unit will remain on (presumably until the battery dies).  There is a nice 1/4-20 hole for a tri-pod mount which is on the back side.  Using it keeps the unit level so you can point it in the direction of a stage for example to record a max value over time.There is a very nice auto-backlight feature that works very well.  Just pass your finger over the sensor and the screen lights up.  The backlight has a varying brightness depending on how dark it is, the backlight works great and is turned perfectly for my needs, a dependable brightness when it gets dark.As for the other goodies the seller shows as part of the package, I did not receive those (the radiation and UV testers).My main criticism for this unit is that it would be nice to have some kind of average reading, say the DB average every 10 seconds, vs the constantly updating value.  Even better would be a graphical display showing a time view.  Of course for $25 what can one really expect!?4 stars, it's a handy dependable unit but has no advanced features.

This is a heavy duty nicely made L14-30 female receptacle that is designed to handle 30 amps at 240v.  Each of the wires slide into a slot.  There are 2 slots on each side, they are clearly marked with W,G,X,Y for the 4 wires used.This receptacle is well made and doing the job nicely.  I firmly tighten down the #10 wire (which needs to be used to support the 30 possible amps).  It's designed to hold this size wire.I primarily use this to supply power to my welder.  The welder sits on a cart that I built with a power distribution center on it.  I run a cord from the cart over to the wall where I have an L14-30 female to plug this into.  It works well and I really like the locking connection, it keeps things plugged in if there's a little tension on the cords.The main reason for selecting this plug when I designed my welding cart is because it works with most of the 240v generators out there.  Generators use this plug because it can handle 30 amps at 240v for about 7500 watts of power (30 x 240 = 7200)  Use extreme caution if you backfeed info your home with this plug.There are 2 main concerns to watch for if you plan to backfeed power.#1, is that you MUST disconnect the main feed on the house main panel to make sure you are not trying to power up your neighborhood, and that you don't risk shocking a power line worker who might be trying to restore your power.  If the power does come back online and your generator was to be connected, you would fry your generator.#2, is that to back feed a generator with this plug, you end up with a connection setup with 2 male ends.  Those ends can be very dangerous if they have power.  Connect your wires before turning on the power at your generator to keep from having any shock risk.  If your only use for this plug is to backfeed, I suggest using this adapter instead. Reliance Controls PB30 L14-30 30 Amp Generator Power Cord Inlet Box For Up To 7,500 Watt Generators  My reason for selecting this plug is that I use the same power outlet for powering my welder and have it available if I were to need to backfeed the home.This link takes you to the plug I used which is also well made and they work great together.Leviton 2711 30 Amp, 125/250 Volt, NEMA L14-30P, 3P, 4W, Locking Plug, Industrial Grade, Grounding - Black-White  Both of these pieces are available here on Amazon at a significant discount over the local big box stores.5 stars, a well-made lasting design for a great price.

This is a heavy duty nicely made L14-30 male plug that is designed to handle 30 amps at 240v.  Each of the wires slide into an individual tube when you assemble the unit, to keep possible stay wire pieces from arcing.  There's also a screw down stress relief section that tightens down on the cord to keep the cord from tugging at the connections if you were to pull on it.  Each of the tubes where you insert the wires are clearly marked with W,G,X,Y for the 4 wires used.This plug is well made and doing the job nicely.  I firmly tighten down the #10 wire (which needs to be used to support the 30 possible amps).  It's designed to hold this size wire.  I feed mine with a 10-4 flex cable, feels like an extension cord but much thicker and pretty pricey.I primarily use this to supply power to my welder.  The welder sits on a cart that I built with a power distribution center on it.  I run a cord from the cart over to the wall where I have an L14-30 female to plug this into.  It works well and I really like the locking connection, it keeps things plugged in if there's a little tension on the cords.This link takes you to the plug I used which is also well made and they work great together.Leviton 2710 30 Amp, 125/250 Volt, Flush Mounting Locking Receptacle, Industrial Grade, Grounding, V-0-MAX, Black  Both of these pieces are available here on Amazon at a significant discount over the local big box stores.5 stars, a well-made lasting design for a great price.

My wife wanted to use the larger monitor on the desk instead of looking at the smaller 14" Untrabook screen while working on assignments.  To accomplish this we needed to adapt the DVI cable from the monitor to the Intel Ultrabook mini HDMI.  Using a DVI to HDMI cable worked well connecting to the monitor, then with this adapter I down sized the HDMI connection to the Mini HDMI size that the Ultrabook has.  This adapter works well and now my wife can use the full size monitor and have less eye strain through the day.  To be clear, of all the options that include cable etc, we bought only the mini adapter that adapts from full HDMI to mini HDMI, since we already had HDMI cables.There are other ways to get video from the Ultrabook to the monitor (USB adapters) but this simple and clean solution is working well for us.  You do need to make sure that the mini adapter is fully seated in the Ultrabook, and then due to all of the pressure the longer and heavier cable is exerting we put the Ultrabook aside and don't bump it.  It stays connected fine that way.5 stars for a high quality low cost adapter that had worked well for us for months now.

During the process of building a new home I had the need to run some conduit lines.  I needed a few different sizes due to the places I needed to put the conduit, and the sizes I would be using.  Having used these Dewalt hole saws years ago when building a log home I bought some new sizes and found that yet again they are winners and worked wonderfully.  I love the dual action cutting edges, just in case I end up going through a nail in the framing as I cut a hole.To be clear, these are just the hole saw portion, you will need the proper Dewalt Mandrel to screw them onto and make them useful.There are a couple of tricks to learn when using these hole saws.  The first is; I've found that rocking the drill slowly seems to work very well and keeps the hole smoothly moving along.  I use a larger Dewalt drill with a large enough opening. The standard 7/16" Mandrel used by these won't fit into the smaller 3/8" drills that are typical for hand held drills.  I also found that using a 120v drill made it easier and avoided any bogging as I cut through wall top plates.  My 12v drills just can't handle these.When you get through a piece of 2x4 for example, the hole saw is filled with the small hole you just cut.  You have to get the core piece out before you can drill through another layer of wood.  You can use a screw driver and sort of pry it out from the sides using the slits that are cut into the drill.  Another way is to unscrew the drill from the quick change mandrel and punch it out from the center using a screwdriver and hammer.If there's any negative with these hole saws, it's that sometimes when they are new, they are difficult to get screwed onto the mandrel the first time.  The paint is just enough to make you think you might be cross threading it.  I found that screwing it on a little, backing it off and then blowing the paint residue off and going again worked.  After a few attempts you will finally get it all of the way onto the Mandrel.  It might take a little force the first time.5 stars, I've used these bits to build a log cabin and several homes now and they work great!
