If you like the convenience of these single packs, it will cost a bit more, but if you don't mind sharing your SPAM with a friend, just get a can and share the goodness with everyone.
Perfect for our standup shower, the blue color is darker than on the stock photos, but I do t mind it at all. This is must for showers specially if your flooring is slippery.
This is great, charges the Nikon battery well, if you are like me, I do most of my charging via USB, this will be perfect for you specially when you are traveling.

These towels are great, they are folded to a 2-ply designs so its quick to dry your hands. This also works great for cleaning and drying the kitchen counters and tables, it doesn't break down easily hence not much lint when when damp. Very good absorbent power, great towels overall. Its good to have in the office, but for our use, it will be in the eating area so we can use this for cleaning up after the kids eat.

We haven't seen the movie yet, but he will probably warm up to this toy after we see the movie. This toy is pretty cool, move the head by squeezing the legs and Spot will make chomping sounds. I like it, he's funny to look at but what's almost as funny is how my boy is so scared of this toy, he does look a bit scary.

This is a very cute apron, the wife was very happy to get it. The apron is on the thinner side and have no pockets. No problem, the wife is still very happy with the design and that's all that matters. If you are cooking greasy food, you might want to use a different apron as the Daisy blue is light and will show stains easily.

We have been using the Brica brand rear view mirror, this is definitely a nice upgrade, viewing wise both products are not the best, not super clear but does a well enough job. The nice improvement with the Diono is the light, it helps keep the infant entertained during night time driving. Great car option, must have specially for solo drivers to keep tabs on the little one.

When I first saw a similar item on the Shark Tank, I wanted to get one, the pitch was awesome. However after using this, I found it a bit small specially when working on the back shoulder. Its great with working the legs and the front areas, but I get the same feel with a nice PVC pipe. If they make this a bit longer, it would be perfect, but it feels a bit cramped for a larger guy like me.

This portable bed rail is great, when my parents come to visit no more struggling getting in and out of bed and no need to keep my home made  PVC rail on the bed all the time. The Stander Bed Rail is solidly built, the metal frame feels very sturdy and slightly on the heavier side. The ability to fold this rail is nice so you can keep it under the bed when not in use. The included organizer is also nice to keep the TV remote in.Excellent product, a must have for aging parents!

We tried this with our visiting sick 6 y/o nephew, I believe it helped, he was feeling better and was not coughing as much, so his parents decided to keep our bottle of Hylands. It makes us as parents feel good that we are giving our kids all natural medication. We will have to buy another bottle for kids when they get sick, Tylenol move over.

We like to build cardboard toys, but we like Melissa & Doug toys more! This tabletop puppet theater is another great product that stomped our cardboard toy, we also had a cardboard kitchen that was taken over when we recieved an M&D kitchen.This theater is nice, builds up easily and is great for the kid's imagination. It is amazing some of the things they come up with when performing a puppet show. Great item!

This is a great bag, the feel is solid, holding it and setting it on the table, it almost like a lunch box feel to it. The main pocket is pretty nice and deep, this will work perfectly well for smaller DSLRs. Unfortunately for me, I run with the 5DM3 with 24-70mm and a battery pack. It barely fits in this bag. With the included velcro padding, the camera would not fit, I have to remove all the padding to get the camera to fit. I do wish this had a larger opening, so I can fit the camera using the velcro suspender, but for me to fit it in, the camera had to go in sideways all the way at the bottom.Still a great bag, but if you are looking to fit the same stuff I have, you will need to get a larger bag, for now, this bag will work as a stay at home bag, easy for me to store my camera at home instead of stuffing it into my large camera bag everything after us..
Great cap, looks great, can't even tell its not OEM.

I'm a Niner fan, its horrible what the team has become in the last year... I just have to think of the past and be happy to be a Niner fan again.Oh and its a great stapler too! Heavy duty, staples on demand!

This Gaiam deep tissue roller is no joke. For those who haven't used a roller before, using the roller itself should be considered a workout. We've had our old Gold's Gym foam roller and has done us well, it's great for getting the knots out of muscles, this deep tissue is rough, it's taking a bit of time getting used to, the spikes are hard foam and do flex a bit but not much.What I did find very soothing is in the neck and head, just lightly roll on without putting too much weight and wow! My neck and head area felt great! I will have to experiment more on the other areas, but for now I'm happy to have a plain foam and this deep tissue for the upper back and neck area.

This Fisher Price Roller Blocks toy is nice, its small and simple, the little one just puts the blocks in and the block will drop either to the front or the rear of the zebra. I was hoping it did more, but at this price point its not bad. The zebra however is not very heavy, so if the little one try to stand up with this, it will tip over.

Okay, these balls are small, they are slightly larger than ping pong balls and have a semi hard rubber texture to it, they do flex and go back into shape with no problems.Our use at home currently is not using the balls for hitting but for the little ones who love to throw things as a ball to throw around. These balls will not damage our windows. Good product, the construction of the ball feels solid.
Cool, the goggles barely fits my fat head, but the straps are very adjustable.

These towels are good for the kitchen, the rough side scrubs the hard to remove stuff from the granite counter and the softer microfiber side will help dry the counter. However, the microfiber is not super absorbent as mentioned on the description, its on the thinner side. However it does well with the light drying and cleanup. The rough side mesh is like the same material used for those bath scrubs, it gives a nice abrasion but not rough.Good product, just not that great in drying.

Wow! This Skip Hop light-up surfer bath toys are amazing! The owl and the bee will float and light up in the water. They look very cute and was a hit! These will automatically turn off after several seconds so no worries about draining the batteries too fast (not replaceable). This is probably the only bath toy that has made the bedroom after bath. Very cool toy!

These Ammex heavy duty gloves just what they are, heavy duty, they are white and thicker than your standard latex gloves, even the box itself is about 2x larger than the other 100 piece gloves. These gloves are flexible and comfortable in hand. These would be perfect for working on the yard and anything that is demanding.

We use both Pampers and Huggies diapers, lately it's been a hit or miss with the thickness of the the diapers from both brands, the diapers seem to be thinner lately. Having used both brands , I do like the leak protection of the Huggies brand, it has the rubber stretch on the back and an inside flap to try and help keep things inside. Pampers rubber stretch is on the side of the diaper so the back is just flat.I like Huggies for its protection and the wife prefers Pampers for its softness. You decide what's more important for you.
I got this to use with the Bestway jump house, it's perfect! It has all the 3 adapters needed to pump the jump house. It's very strong and got our jump house refilled with air quickly!

This Boneco Air purifier is great, it's large and fits nicely in our family room which is next to the kitchen, super quiet and I can't even hear it when the TV is on. The machine is also cool to look at. From the picture it looks small but this is fairly large, it can be set on top of a corner table but probably not ideal. Set up is very easy, just remove the bag from the filter and you are good to go! I can already smell the fresh air!One big down side to this is the filter replacement, my machine has the allergy filter, it's currently priced at $99 on AMZN, wow! Hopefully the price goes down when it's time for a replacement.

This came in at a perfect time, really excited to try out this Vicks humidifier, we already use the Crane brand which does a great job but it's not filtered. This Vicks brand come with extra features which we appreciate, being able to add scents is nice, the Vicks vapor smell is always good for stuffy nose. Mist wise, this machine does a great job, I just hope it last as long, only time will tell and I'll update as needed.

This cup holder is great, it comes with 2 attachments so you can use this with the older Britax Boulevard and the current Boulevard. This is a must have, I do wish it was included with the car seat instead of an option.

I was hoping to use this with my Sonicare E-series, I should have known, I've had my E-series for several years now and its still working great, but there's no new items made for that brush. I have always used my Sonicare to brush my tongue for a long time, I have gotten used to it and it works great, so I tried the spray for an extra cleaning power. I would have to say it feels good! My mouth feels fresher with the spray. Specially with Sensodine toothpaste which is fairly bland, the spray does help.

So many negative reviews, this book is actually pretty cool, there's some good ideas in this book at is worth using for parties. I know my 8 y/o niece would go crazy for some of the ideas in this book. I understand you can get plenty of other ideas on the internet, but having a book and have your little girl be inspired by reading and trying out the examples is priceless.Good book overall, good ideas, my favorite and probably the easiest is the Olaf party favor of a doggy bag with drawn up face and clothes hanger.

If your little one is a thrower, this is a must. This fits the iPhone 6 easily and anything smaller, we have our iPhone 5 in there currently. The touch screen is still responsive inside the case. Attaching the tether is simple and feels secure and will keep your device protected. Great product!

I've had the opportunity to try out multiple types and brands of gloves in the last month, this Ammex AINPF indigo gloves and the Ammex X3 blue latex free gloves both feel very good in hand, good grip, and the thickness good for daily use. The medium size fits nicely and is flexible when inserting hand. It's hard to tell the difference in quality between the 2 gloves other than color, both are great!

I've had the opportunity to try out multiple types and brands of gloves in the last month, this Ammex AINPF indigo gloves and the Ammex X3 blue latex free gloves both feel very good in hand, good grip, and the thickness good for daily use. The medium size fits nicely and is flexible when inserting hand. It's hard to tell the difference in quality between the 2 gloves other than color, both are great!

This is great, dress up your favorite wrestler the way you want. This Triple H action figure is awesome, it will go nicely in my toy collection shelves. The quality is pretty good, the details are quite nice on the face and body. This is a must have for all WWE fans!

This toy is great, perfect for my son who likes trains and like to line up his manual train tracks together and let the train slide. This Chuggington train track is powered, this is his first powered train set and he's very happy! Assembly took some time specially with the toddler's "help", but we eventually got the set going. Fun toy, this toy had the privilege to stay in his room.

This STX jogging pants are nice quality, it comes with pockets and have a nice texture and threading. The only issue is the pants are on the skinny side for the length of the pants. It does have a nice elastic waist band, so for a size 5/6, you might need to fold or hem the legs of the pants.

The strength and quality of Hefty cups haven't been the same for awhile now, they are thinner and slightly flimsier than it was several years ago. These Tennessee Volunteers disposable cups are not any different in quality but the design is cool and the print quality is solid. It's a must have for any fan, great for parties! These can probably be washed and reused a couple of times if needed.

These Ammex TLF gloves are the softest and stretchiest set of latex gloves I have used. When inserting on the hand it stretches nicely and it feels very soft on the hand. There is a nice texture on the gloves for a nice solid grip.
Great fit, works well around the house and working on cars. The large size fits well on my hand, good grip, great gloves at a great price!
These Ammex gloves are great, we tried several of these disposable gloves, these fit well, very strong, you can't go wrong with these around the house, working on cars, or in the clinic.

For us it's great, our little one seem to only want to sleep when swaddled, the small size is small and will be outgrown quickly, so use right away. The ZigZag design is nice and will work for both boys and girls. Great product!

Our toddler loves to play cook, we used to have the plastic play food but once we got this, the little guy did not want to play with the plastics anymore. The food is attached with velcro and when chopping it makes a cool cutting sound on the chopping board, its very cool and realistic! Great product by Melissa & Doug!

These SwaddleMe swaddles are great, they are soft and breathable, this set of swaddle is on the thinner side which is perfect for summer. Our NB only sleeps swaddled, so far we are happy she's not turning yet because I don't think we can use this anymore once the baby starts turning. The small size is just right for the newborn, but before you know it they will outgrow these quickly so enjoy your baby while they can still fit in these, next thing you know they are bossing you around :)

Oh after the painful setup (see below) this Bestway Bouncer is super fun for the toddler! He jumps in and out through all sides and jumps until his energy is drained (Good sleep). This bouncy house is pretty big for a miniature size, it's fairly stable, however if there is more than one child in there and they are rough, the walls are not that strong to keep them in. So make sure you monitor them when at play.Now for the painful setup, no pump or adaptor is included with this (bad), also if you don't have a powered pump, don't even try to inflate unless you have the time and energy. On top of that you have to pump each section separately, which is good for leak protection but bad for us because they decided to use different sized fittings for the 3 sections. The base center area needs a small sized adaptor and the base edge needs a super large size adaptor the inflatable bed size. I didn't have that so I used my leaf blower and cupped it with my hand to force the air in, it worked...Once everything was up, the kid was happy and that is all that matter...

Okay this thing is cool, you can carve letters into your crayons, it works and it gets messy so make sure your carpet is covered. I think this is perfect to kids parties, give the guest a crayon with their name on it as a part of the give away. Who wouldn't enjoy that? You do have to go over the letters a couple of times to get a clean carve, still a great crayon engraving tool!

This Sony HTDT9 is an amazing soundbar, the sound quality is excellent, very crisp and clear. Installation is easy, just plug in the HDMI and optical (non needed if you have the latest ARC HDMI which I don't) and you are good to go. The sub is wireless so you can set it anywhere in the room.In comparison to my Bose Cinemate 120, the sound is comparable, however I am not an audiophile I find both bars sound great, full and powerful. The Sony does have more features than the Bose, I like the night feature, I find with little babies at home, the night option is pretty much the norm, less bass to wake the babies. Having Bluetooth is excellent feature my Bose didn't have, however I don't think I'll be dumping my Sonos system for this any time soon. There is a football mode on this system, it's suppose to increase the stadium sound and decease the commentators, I like that. The Sony system is nice because everything is inside the sub and bar, no need for a separate box as the main unit like the Bose.If you have a slim TV you know the sound quality is always what's lost with the beautiful aesthetics, adding this sound bar will give you the minimalist look and still feel like you have speakers all around! At this price point, you will get an excellent sound but if you like to stream your music, I would also consider the Sonos bar and sub combo for its superb streaming service.

These premium swaddle blankets are super soft, in comparison with the standard Muslin blankets Summer Infant sell, the bamboo rayon material just brings it over the top. Gentle on the skin and it is very breathable. These are large enough to that you can use it for plenty of other things. The color and design is perfect for a boy or girl, great product!

Another cute swaddle by SwaddleMe, these swaddles are very easy to use, no need to fold, wrap, and tuck which the littles ones break out off too easily, this uses velcro to secure the swaddle. The material is soft and on the thinner side so this will work perfectly for the summer. This is about 20" long, so your little one will probably grow out of it really quick. We had got to a point with our other baby when we just wrapped this up to his belly. This polka dot and pink set is perfect for the the new baby girl.

Wow, this thing works, but ouch! The wife tried it on her leg and it was intense! She normally waxes and thinks this will work better for her for a follow up after waxing. So I had to give it a try on my chin of all places, wow, its like a torture machine! It did pluck fast and each hair pulled was painful! It also did irritate my skin a bit from the pulling. For my wife, the area on her leg she shaved wasn't irritated but was slightly red from the pulling. She will definitely use it again, but only after she waxes so there will be lesser hair for this machine to pluck.This is not for everyone, if you have a high pain tolerance, this will work, but if you are a weakling like me, you might want to stay away.

New born babies love being swaddled, we have been using SwaddleMe for all our babies, they are easy to use, just insert the legs in the pouch and wrap the Velcro flaps around and the baby stay securely inside, unlike the standard cloth wrap were the baby can break away from.This set is perfect for the summer because it's on the thinner side, very breathable and soft. It is about 20" long, from feet to shoulder so your little one could out grow this quickly.Great product! A must have for all new born!

We love these SwaddleMe blankets, we have several of the non-premium blankets which are 100% cotton but they are not as soft as these Premium Muslin. The bamboo rayon makes a big difference in texture and does not affect the breathability of the fabric. The design is very cute, perfect for baby girls. We use this blankets all over, we hang it in the car to block the sun from the babies, in the stroller to give the baby shade, and for the wife to cover when feeding. Great blankets, but a bit pricy.

This outlet expansion from 360 Electrical is awesome! If you have electronics this is a must have! To install you just have to remove the screw your home outlet cover then attach this to the outlet and screw in the expansion to securely fasten and prevent accidental removal. It's very simple to do, you come from 2 sockets to 6 with 2 USB ports.This works perfectly for our kitchen area that we charge are electronics in. We now have more outlets with surge protection added. Great product!

At this price point, this 16 piece bath kit is great, you get everything you will need to get your bathroom going at a budget. The curtain itself is a good material, it's not flimsy, it should be good for awhile. The other pieces however are lower quality, the hooks are plastic and thin, the cup is a nice size but will probably be better as a tooth brush holder, the lip area looks rough (not a clean cut). If you want a budget bathroom kit, this is great, but don't expect high quality products.

This 6ft iPhone charging cable is the perfect size for the bedside charger. I can charge the iPhone with no issues. Only time will tell how long these things will last, I have purchase other certified cables in the past that broke only after 1 week, so I will update my review once I get some wear and tear on this. For now it's perfect!

I am not a big apron guy (I don't cook much), but I like to grill. This blue apron is nice and large enough to fit me comfortably and fit my small wife just fine. The shoulder strap has a metal adjustable hoop, which is easy to use. The only thing I find odd is the large pocket in the middle, I would rather have 2 size pockets for the hands.I have the blue apron and it hides dirtiness nicely.

I did not know Vita Coco made Coconut Oil... Its amazing how one nut have so much health benefits and uses, I use this on my arms and feet and it it does ease the itching and helps heal the dryness. There is a nice soothing coconut smell on this oil, it reminds me of the Hawaii, ahhh. We have never cooked with coconut oil before, but we will be trying it out soon. The small packets are nice on the go, but the large container would be more economical. This is an excellent product, you must give it a try!

Our toddler loves his dinosaurs, he has 2 that he keeps with him, he just recently started doing the play pretend with his dinosaur with growling sound and eating his Lego characters. So this Dino came at the right time, he can play puppet with his little sibling and keep himself interested for periods of time. The hand puppet is soft and makes cool phrases that initiates play and conversation which we like. Great puppet!

We always just use socks for mittens to prevent scratches, they are always around. However if you are high class and want your baby to look even cuter than just wearing socks on the hand, this is great! These mittens are very soft, the sewing is nice, simple and clean, and they are organic!You get 2 pairs for under $7, I think it's worth the upgrade from sock mittens.

Okay, I got this for the NB, but once the toddler got a hold of it, that became a different story... This VTech bear is cute! The head is super soft and cuddly but the body is a bit hard for the mechanics and electronics of the bear. The bear will crawl and kept our toddler interested and copied the bear (FYI, he can walk), very cute, good songs and sounds, another winner from VTech, this bear will fit nicely with our Scout and Violet dogs.

If you want something instant and larger than the standard label makers this is a good option. You can get a large print that is instantly laminated and be attached to any surface. The laminate is applied by first printing out your design on the paper area of the sheet and folding the laminate over, once folded, you can peal off the backing to attach. It does work, but its a bit pricey. You have to download the template on Avery.com website, which is a template for Microsoft Word that just gives you the outline of where to print your design, no special design is included.

I never knew what Jersey Knit fabrics are until receiving this crib sheet, the material has some stretchiness to it and it feels like a t-shirt. Very soft and breathable for the baby. The fit is perfect for our mini-crib I suggest you use a waterproof lining under this sheet because it is fairly thin and everything will just seep through.Great sheet! Nice, soft and very breathable!

This is a beautiful Lucien Piccard watch, two tone gold and silver with a pearl face. The face is on the larger side, the side to side measurement including the adjustment knob is 1.5" which is good for folks that have difficulty seeing up close. The hands are easy to see in contrast with the background. Great looking watch for the price!

This is a nice bed sheet, it fits nicely in our oval bassinet with the American Baby waterproof pad. The feel of the sheet is soft and looks be be sewn very well. Because our bassinet is oval, we have to tuck the excess sheet on the side of the bassinet to keep it snug. Great product, we are very happy.

We have an oval bassinet that have been around for 5 babies and several hand me down. Its old but it works. It uses an oval bassinet mattress pad, this American Baby Waterproof cover on our oval mattress fits slightly loose but once in the bassinet we can tuck it in to give it a tighter fit. The material is not the softest, but we have an all cotton American Baby bassinet sheet that will go on top. The set works well with our bassinet, its nice because it adds some extra cushion to the mattress.Good product!

We have been using a microfiber type wash cloth for baths which works well but they are small, about 6x6, so we were excited to try out this cute blue and white wash cloth. Soon after opening we found the towel very thin and not as soft. However they are towels and will still find use at home for the baby specially for cleanup after spit ups and spills. For now, we will stay with the microfiber for baths.

If you want a super soft blanket for your baby to lay on, this Sherpa is perfect! This blanket is much thicker than the fleece blankets and also softer. The material is sewn well, the silk edge gives the blanket a nice look.Great blanket!

I don't normally eat Goji by itself, I usually have it in my Acai shake, or bowl, or tea. I do find this Goji a bit on the chewy side, the kind that gets stuck between the teeth. However once it gets a bit wet it gets softer. Flavor is different from what you would expect from the standard sweet berries, the flavor of the Goji is more subtle, not sweet, not sour, just taste like its healthy for you, which is why I eat it.The Healthworks brand is the cheapest I have seen organic Goji sell for, give it a try, the antioxidant benefits is great!

These are good clear cups, they feel durable, but because the sides are straight, they do squeeze in easier than the Solo cups that have grooves. I know at our parties we label the cups with a Sharpie so we can re-use them, having clear cups makes that a bit difficult specially when your drink is dark. This is a good reusable and disposable cup, I do wish they came with lids.

We really like this book toy, it's soft, no pinch points, the little crinkly flaps are nice for the NB to squeeze. The book is like a foldable blanket with images.I knocked off 1 star because when I saw this toy, I thought the sounds were activated by touching the images, but it's not, the images are static and the sound comes from the little stuffed music note attached to the book. Also, the music note is not sewn cleanly, it looks to have a snag. I have attached pics.Still a great toy, just know what you are buying.

This blanket is the softest fleece blanket I have felt. I had to use the Lorax analogy because of it's amazing softness! The blanket is well made, the threading is solid, the lavender color is very easy on the eye, and the silk edging gives the blanket a nice touch.This is a perfect gift for any newborn!

These VTech toys are well made and have plenty of thought into creating them, they are fun and educational. This Smart Animals Grow and Learn is our second Smart Animals, we also have the Tree House. Between the two, this Grow and Learn is larger and have more activities, but also cost slightly higher. The toddler really enjoys playing with slide, the growing carrots, the chatter box rooster, what's not to like. Both toy sets are interchangeable which we really like, but I can get out of control and it has now taken over the coffee table.You can't really go wrong with the VTech Go! Go! toys, once you get one, you will want more.

A very nice album -- I have to disagree with the reviewer who thought it sounded more "early Eagles" than country, for the whole approach to rhythm, not to mention the composition of the accompanying groups, creates what seems to me a different sound altogether.  Henley's voice is still at times that of the singer of "Desperado," but he can adjust the timbre to suit a different mode.  At times, there's a touch of Dylan in the voice (in "Prayin' for Rain" and "Where I am now"),  and the narrative of "Waiting on tables" sounds like it could be a Springsteen song, until the refrain kicks in -- but they all work well.  All but four or five of the songs are by Henley and are new; the oldest one goes back to the '50's (the Louvin Brothers' "When I Stop Dreaming"), there are a couple from the '60s, including "The Brand New Tennessee Waltz," and the disc opens with Tift Merritt's "Bramble Rose."  I don't know that these are classics, but they're good songs, and Henley's own efforts fit right in.  I particularly liked "The Cost Of Living," "Words can Break your Heart," and "Train in the Distance."  The themes are standard -- aging, loss, acceptance of failure, memories of youth -- but none the worse for that.The engineering seems really good to me, with the voice perfectly set against the ensemble and the different expressive mixes in the arrangements coming through clearly.  Guest artists contribute -- Mick Jagger works hard at his county style and accent in "Bramble Rose," and Merle Haggard sounds very good in "The Cost of Living."  Alison Krauss, Trisha Yearwood, Vince Gill, Dolly Parton, and Lucinda Williams all contribute effectively.  This was Don Henley's first solo album in 15 years, and I thought it turned out just fine.

It's always a pleasure to watch Catherine Keener and Liev Schreiber, and here they are, at the beginnings of their respective careers, playing characters who combine likeableness with irritating-ness in about equal proportions -- that's to say, they're representing ordinary folks as Nicole Holofcener sees them.  For Holofcener herself, this was her first feature, and it's like the other two of hers I've seen in its attention to details of middle class life and an eschewal of the kind of melodrama that passes for realism in our current cinematic conventions.  It's quiet, though that's not to say that it's characters aren't a mass of anxieties of the kind that one often reads about in advice columns.  The structure is simple and symmetrical: as Amelia (Keener) has just broken up with Andrew (Schreiber), her best friend Laura (Anne Heche) becomes engaged to her boyfriend  Frank (Todd Field).  No sooner have these changes taken place, but the two young women begin to have second thoughts about them.  Amelia wants connection; Laura and Frank start getting tense with one another.  The two women also become aware of how circumstances seem to be forcing them to see  and consult with one another less as time goes on, so the nature of THEIR relationship also becomes a source of stress.  These are commonplace occurrences, and I think that the popularity of Holofcener's movies has to do with the way in which an audience of a certain age see themselves and all their insecurities in them.  Both women have jobs, and we see them at work, but their work seems to mean less to them than what's going on in their heads about their relationships.Maybe it's unfortunate that I've seen Holofcener's movies in reverse chronological order.  "Enough Said" was an excellent movie, and "Friends with Money" was very good.  This one, from 1996, is less interesting.  The problem, I think, is the writing -- Holofcener writes and directs.  I don't think that the characters are intrinsically less interesting than those in "Friends with Money," but the writing seems less effective.  It's not easy to make credible everyday language dramatically pointed without inflating it into rhetoric, and Holofcener, to her credit, never inflates -- but here it isn't all that pointed and fresh either.  In this respect, it's less successful than her later films and a film like Stillman's "Metropolitan," whose characters are equally mundane folks living largely inside their heads.  The actors are credible, and they do what they can, and they're as engaging as the material allows.  It's nice to know that they and Holofcener went on to better things.

One has to respect the experiences of the author Matthew Quick and the director David O. Russell, who have had experiences within their own lives and families with illnesses like depression and bi-polar disorder, and both have testified to the fact that the book and the movie were undertaken as ways of dealing with, to some extent, the difficulties brought about by such illnesses.  And the movie has been very successful -- Americans seem to love the idea that emotional and mental illness (and of course, cognitive impairment and cancer) can be the bases of uplifting stories.  And sometimes, in "real life," they can be.  More often, of course, they are disturbing, frightening, and financially and emotionally draining, both for the sufferers and those who seek to take care of them.  I sometimes wonder if the desire to see uplift in such stories -- the "silver lining" -- isn't a way of assuring ourselves that we are seeing these sufferers as people like ourselves and that we would never think of marginalizing them.  One would hope that we wouldn't marginalize them, but let's face it: they're not exactly like (and sometimes not at all like) those of us who are lucky enough not to be thus afflicted, and it bothers me to see them turned into occasions for comedy, for these enable in us a covert kind of self-congratulation: we see them as people and covertly congratulate ourselves for empathizing.  But one can't get away from the fact that the conventions of comedy  -- in this case romantic comedy -- blunt or fuzz up the representation of the difficulties of emotional illness.  We can't believe in the suffering of Pat (Bradley Cooper) and Tiffany (Jennifer Lawrence) when they don't seem credibly endangered or a source of danger.  It doesn't help that Pat's doctor is a broadly comic figure or that Tiffany's "normal" sister and brother-in-law seem more out of touch with reality than Tiffany does.  Pat's obsessive-compulsive father (Robert De Niro, wasted) has a fixation with the Philadelphia Eagles that is more a source of comedy than anything else.  To sum up, most of these people (including Danny [Chris Tucker], Pat's friend from the hospital in Baltimore where Pat has spent 8 months) are, in some degree, charming, and charming just doesn't cut it in a movie that purports to take emotional suffering seriously.As most readers will know, Tiffany talks Pat into partnering her in a dance competition, and they practice a lot.  We're to take it that the practice becomes a kind of emotional discipline and, in itself, a source of stability for both.  Fair enough -- and, to the film's credit, in the competition they are (credibly) not very good at all, but they're good enough to bring about a happy conclusion to a rather contrived betting situation that Pat's dad has set up, and -- in best romantic comedy vein -- good enough to discover each other, as each realizes what the other has done for him or her.  I didn't think much of the movie, but the actors are pros, and they give it a whirl -- my quarrel isn't with them.  It's with the whole concept.  I just hope DeSean Jackson was reimbursed for the use (or abuse!) of his name.

As far as Perlman is concerned, for me it's the earlier the better -- not because he started to play badly but rather because in his later DGG recordings, his violin is far too close-up in the aural picture.  This Dvorak disc is from 1974, and I like it.  The orchestra has fine presence, Perlman is in a credible relation to it, and he plays with his usual richness and security.  I have read criticisms of Dvorak's handling of the first movement, but expressively it works well for me, whatever its shortcomings in terms of "correct" sonata form.  The slow movement is beautifully transitioned-into and has a mournful Slavic eloquence to it, which might be less memorable than anything in the Cello Concerto but which is very engaging nonetheless.  There's plenty of life and variety too in the folksy, dance-like finale.  The Romance for Violin and Orchestra is eloquently played too.  I think I marginally prefer the Accardo/Davis recording, from about 1979, with more refined orchestral sound, and with Accardo's more focused tone, but there's nothing at all wrong with this one.  And at the price, in its latest remastering, it's well worth acquiring.

3 1/2 stars -- This was Peter Robinson's second Inspector Banks book, and it's interesting how much less polished it is than his later efforts in this very good series.  I found it less interesting than "Gallows View," the first book in the series.  In this one the "dedicated man" is the murder victim, Harry Steadman, an academic historian with interests in Roman technology.  He has been the beneficiary of his father's estate, and that has enabled him to retire from academic work and pursue his studies in his own way from a base in Helmthorpe, a village 15 miles from Eastvale.  He and his wife are childless, but Harry has developed friendships there because he has been coming to Helmthorpe on vacation for over a decade prior to his retirement.  A shepherd discovers his body up on the moors, and Banks is called in to investigate.  In some ways, it's a very traditional mystery -- a small village, a small group of acquaintances, relations that go back for a decade or so -- and the victim a man about whom no one has anything bad to say, a man dedicated to his field of study . . .Banks flails around a good deal.  He has a feeling that the solution to the murder lies in the past and that it was not just a random killing.  At one point, one character comments, as they talk around the possibilities, that it's all a bit like the blind men and the elephant: they all probably have a part of it, but no one knows exactly which part or how it all might hang together.  Robinson plays with this idea in an interesting way -- he has two of the surrounding characters, who are not in communication with one another, come to believe that they have the answer to the puzzle, and they set out to take action to resolve the matter without informing Banks or anyone else about their conclusions.  In taking action, they put themselves at risk without really knowing what they're doing so . . . cue the suspense.  I think that that's a really smart idea to bring in to a story like this.  Unfortunately, Robinson can't find a narrative strategy for pulling it off interestingly, so he falls back on what was, by 1988 when the book was published. the hoariest of resolutions: after the dust has cleared, Banks sits everybody down and explains it all, pretty much like Hercule Poirot or Miss Marple.  Robinson's idea is good -- too bad the ending had to be handled so unimaginatively..There are some other problems.  For example, he has a group of teenage girls who converse on a number of occasions.  The dialogue just isn't right.  He also has neighbors and villagers commenting on the situation is a kind of standard issue local yokel cliched kind of language.  Banks's family do not come to life here as they do in later books -- his wife, Sandra,is a cipher whose main function is to provide a piece of vital information unknowingly.  In other words, Robinson tend to fall back on stereotypes, and in this respect this book is less effective than many of his later ones, in which dialogue, characterization, and resolution are much more deftly handled.  Still, there are things to enjoy, and shocks and surprises -- but Robinson became a much more assured writer as he went on, in the handling of both the writing and the narrative organization. .

When I was young, I loved the "1812" and the "William Tell" overtures -- this was back in the late 1950s -- when they would come on the radio.  As time has gone on, I find that, for me, the "William Tell" has worn better, and I've come to like Tchaikovsky's ballet scores better than the overture.  But never mind!  If you want a performance with plenty of pizzazz, in good early-digital sound (from around 1981), this will do very well.  Muti's rhythmic grip, and his attention to the orchestral textures, serve, along with the nice sound picture, to give this music with a directness that is most appealing.  The piece has its own inflation, so to speak, and Muti doesn't gild the lily -- if it IS a lily to start with!  Liszt's tone poem "Les Preludes" is given its own distinctive, more somber, "tinta" here, and it makes a good "middle movement" to three pieces the first and third of which are pretty spectacular.  Like "Bolero," it works with limited thematic material, cunningly transformed.  There are other tone poems by Liszt that I like better, but this performance seems fine.  The Ravel "Bolero" opens the program and is given a very fine performance.  It always surprises me how it holds the attention for 17 minutes, with all the repetitiveness, but it does, and Muti builds the crescendo unerringly.  The orchestral color throughout is outstandingly caught by the recording.  All in all, it's my favorite piece on this disc.  I would just add that on a CD, there was room for more.  "William Tell" maybe?

The reviewers who complain that this movie doesn't really help us understand the extent and the intractability of the immigration crisis in the age of "national security" are right -- but I'm not sure that any movie could do that and I'm pretty sure that this movie wasn't attempting anything so ambitious.  Rather, the movie wants to remind us of a simple fact: among all the numbers that are thrown at us, and in spite of the polarized and under-informed ideological posturing, and in the face of the impersonal bureaucratic machinery established to deal with these problems, individuals' and families' lives are being impacted in quite horrifying ways.  You might think that that kind of focus is an invitation to a sentimental response to circumstances that require really hard thinking and really detailed knowledge -- and, again, you would be right.  Sentiment is the name of the game.  I would just say that there is a place for it, even as we need much, much more.  But on its own terms, this works pretty well.  It combines a number of stories of immigrants and "illegal" residents from the Iran, Korea, Mexico, Australia, sub-Saharan Africa and takes us through some of their encounters with "the system."  This being a movie, it's no surprise that some representatives of the system use it to exercise their own power or seek satisfaction for their own desires -- the characters played by Ray Liotta and Jacqueline Obradors -- while others try to bend the rules as far as they can to humanize the system and preserve families whose breakup is threatened by the deportation of one member -- Harrison Ford and Ashley Judd play the sympathetic characters who do so -- but sentimental though the movie might be, not all the benevolent interventions are successful, and there are harrowing moments.  When a teenage Iranian-American girl is deported on suspicion of supporting terror (on the basis of a report she gave in class). her mother goes with her, leaving her father and sister behind.  The scene at the airport is painful to watch, and very well acted.  The immigrants aren't the only sufferers:  Ashley Judd plays an advocate for immigrant children, while Liotta, her husband, is an immigration officer willing to trade green cards for sexual favors.  Harrison Ford plays a weary honest officer, who tries to keep a young Mexican mother and her son together, and he effectively conveys the fatigue that inevitably accompanies the constant battle to help people live with dignity.  Ford's character'spartner belongs to an immigrant Pakistani family whose older members are about to be naturalized and yet who are trying to impose traditional codes of conduct on the younger generation, not all of whom are interested.  That situation leads to the most melodramatic confrontation in the movie, a scene in a convenience store that involves a Korean kid.  The final scenes -- one at the naturalization ceremony and one out on the Mexican-American border wasteland are tense and effective.  So yes -- it's sentimental and it's not analytical -- but it's alive to human costs, and that's something that a movie can get across perfectly well.

After seeing John Ford's "My Darling Clementine" (1947), I decided to see the three following "OK Corral" movies in chronological order.  The next two were "Gunfight at the OK Corral" (1957, with Burt Lancaster and Kirk Douglas) and "Tombstone" (1993, with Kurt Russell and Val Kilmer), with "Wyatt Earp" coming a year later, in 1994.  I'm sorry to say that at 3+hours "Wyatt Earp" is the least satisfying of the four.  It's ponderous, a bit disjointed, and, finally, repetitive, for all the decent cast and the nice photography.  The whole second half of the movie, it seems, is just a matter of the Earp brothers moving from place to place, ending up as lawmen wherever thy go, while their wives constantly object to the upheavals.  There are gunfights in different locales, but we never get much sense of the people that the Earps are fighting (the Clantons et. al.) as characters, and in fact, with the exception of Wyatt, we don't get very strong senses of the Earp brothers either.  They seem pretty much interchangeable after a while.  The fault in these cases of underdeveloped characterization has to lie with the writers.  They don't do much with Wyatt's love Josie Marcus either -- in "Tombstone," Dana Delaney was a much more vivid presence than Joanna Goings.  In fact, the memorable characters here are those we see least of -- Isabella Rossellini as Big Nose Kate, Bill Pullman as Ed Masterson, Mark Harmon as Sheriff Behan -- and that's partly because we get to know Wyatt relatively early -- after his recovery from his wife's death, he doesn't change much at all and he isn't all that interestingly characterized to begin with.There is Dennis Quaid as Doc Holliday to give the movie a lift.  Doc is fatally consumptive and has no illusions about his future.  It's not altogether clear why he befriends Wyatt, but he sticks by him to the end.  Quaid's Doc is a kind of blend of Val Kilmer's dandyism and Kirk Douglas's volatility and fatalism, and he makes it work.  He's less outlandishly effete than Kilmer, but he is given a curious formality of speech that marks him.  In all four movies, the Holliday figure is strongly cast, and in the last two perhaps steals the show -- as, I think, Victor Mature did in "My Darling Clementine."  I have to say that I didn't like the focus on Wyatt's early years -- that part of the movie seems to exist only to let Gene Hackman, as the Earp brothers' father, make rather stilted speeches that are, in effect, thematic markers -- he talks about "blood" (i. e. family) and "the law" as being all-important, and he declares that the Earps are temperamentally itinerant.  And, of course, that's what the movie delivers on, rather predictably.  I'm not sure we needed Gene Hackman to spell all that out for us: just tell the story and SHOW us the Earps in action!  We, the audience, will get the point.What about Wyatt's character?  I wondered, on reflection, if Kasdan, the director, and Costner didn't model him to some extent on John Wayne's obsessives in "The Searchers" and "Red River".  He's single minded and stubborn -- but we don't need the better part of three hours to see that, especially when the dialogue isn't all that strong.  While on the trail of influences, I came to wonder if the ending might recall the ending of "The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance," for the question arrives, for Earp, later in life, if he really did all the things attributed to him.  Viewers can decide that one for themselves.

This novel follows from the end of "The Burning Room," and I think that it's another good, solid Connelly procedural.  It's set up in an interestingly different way from "The Burning Room," and I don't mean only that we have a cooperation between ex-detective Harry Bosch and his half-brother, the pragmatic and flamboyant Mickey Haller, the "Lincoln Lawyer."  Fans of Bosch and Connelly will remember that in "The Burning Room" Bosch is the only character to whose consciousness we have access.  All we hear and know about his new sidekick Lucy Soto comes from dialogue, description, and Bosch's thoughts, not Lucy's.  And this is so even when the novel develops two stories, one of which is Lucy's and becomes Bosch's too -- it's all channelled for us readers through Bosch -- and it worked very well.  In that novel, we readers are always where Bosch is. Here in "The Crossing," however, we have only a single story -- of the effort to clear the name of Haller's client D'Quan Foster, who has been accused of a particularly violent murder -- but we have access to three centers of narrative focus -- Bosch's, Mickey's, and that of two cops who (it's clear from the start) are up to no good, although what their stake is in the failure of Haller's and Bosch's efforts to free D'Quan doesn't become fully evident until later.Bosch is retired now, but he's suing the LAPD for mishandling his retirement (see end of "The Burning Room"), and he needs money to help his daughter afford college next year.  Haller suggests that Bosch work on the case for him, his usual assistant having been taken out of commission in the first chapter.  Bosch is concerned throughout the novel about his working for "the other side" -- the idea that he's a cop outlives his actual professional life as one -- or the "dark side" as some of his old colleagues disparagingly put it.  He makes Haller agree that if the evidence and his investigation conclusively demonstrate D'Quan's guilt, then Bosch will be free to make that known to the prosecutor.  The evidence at the scene is very damning, so Bosch has to explore the likelihood that it was in some way planted or manufactured.  What follows is an excellent account of the procedures by which Bosch goes about finding the truth of the matter, and suspense is generated by the fact that we readers see (while Bosch for a long time does not) that his efforts are being observed and undercut by some bad cops.  We also see that there are still cops in LAPD with whom Bosch has credit -- his old partner Lucy is one of them -- so it's not totally a matter of Bosch v. a corrupt machine.The contrast between Bosch's and Haller's temperaments is established early, and their disagreements as a result become a bit predictable.  However, that's not enough to spoil our pleasure in Bosch's intelligent and diligent approach to the investigation or to Haller's courtroom theatrics at the end.  I think I preferred the tightness of "The Burning Room," but this one is very enjoyable too.

A rock-solid procedural that I found very enjoyable: Harry Bosch is on the road to retirement, working cold cases, with his pension plan worked out, and his main concern seems to be whether or not the LAPD might dump him early and thus save something on his premiums. Then a man dies, ten years after being shot and paralyzed by a never-found assailant, the bullet that paralyzed him having remained in him all these years. Now it is extracted post-mortem, the death is ruled a homicide -- so Harry's on the trail of a murderer, well aware that after all these years it will be tough to track him with only the bullet to go on. Harry, of course, goes back over the paperwork, finds things to ask questions about, and in very short order, the game is afoot. The victim has connections to a rising local politician who is Hispanic, as is the young partner assigned to Harry -- "Lucky" Lucy Soto, a pin-up girl for the LAPD because of some heroics in a gunfight. She has been promoted early, a cause of some backbiting among jealous older officers whose track has been slower, and the question is -- will she prove her mettle with Harry?It turns out that Lucy has a reason for wanting to be assigned to cold cases, and soon enough we have in effect two separate investigations. I'll give no more plot details. In both, careful procedural work is done, a lot of it unglamorous but rendered interesting by Connelly's eye for detail and ear for dialogue. Harry's vulnerability as a near-to-retiring officer who tends to irritate his superiors by not bothering much about the PR concerns of the LAPD forms a kind of under-plot as the main stories develop. The tense moments and the revelatory discoveries are all made to fit plausibly with the procedural aspects of the story as well as with the characterizations of Bosch and Lucy. It's a tight piece of work -- one of Connelly's best, I think.

I wasn't surprised that I liked this account of the Brahms First much better than Bernstein's later digital account from Vienna for DGG. The latter I found mannered, with Bernstein always intervening with the tempo and dynamics and seeming not to want the music to speak for itself. I know . . . other reviewers I respect take a kinder view, but for me this earlier recording has a directness and a freshness that are winning, and the re-mastering of an originally 1960 recording has been very well done (as seems typical of Sony's re-mastering for this "Bernstein Century" series). I WAS surprised to find that I liked this recording better than I did Szell's, also from CBS/Sony, at around the same time. Szell has a tense energy and propulsion, but the sound is more homogenized and less airy than what we have here. The "filler" here is the Serenade No.2 -- like its predecessor written before Brahms began to write symphonies. It's not music I know well, but it receives an attractive performance here, in sound that is a little less appealing than that for the symphony -- they were recorded six years apart in different venues. The symphony is the earlier -- so venue matters! All in all, a very fine disc.

This is a very fine account of the Schubert Ninth in what is as good digital sound as I've heard from DGG.  The quality of timbre from the different instrumental groups, as well as the solo instruments, and their relation to each other in the aural space, just couldn't be better judged.  The concert hall at the Ravinia Festival (where I assume this was recorded back in 1983) must have great acoustics.  Levine's Brahms with this orchestra, recorded by Sony in Chicago, isn't in the same league, considered purely as sound.  The performance itself is fine -- it has a nice, unaffected forward thrust that avoids the rush (exciting though it may be) of Munch's Boston recording but still conveys an attractive energy.  Levine also understands that "allegro ma non troppo" and "andante con moto" aren't all that far apart, and so the first two movements, considered together, have an almost cumulative sweep.  My only reservation is that they are a bit straight-faced, and the final two movements, by contrast, have a life and variety as well as energy, that make them, for me, the source of real distinction in this performance.  The finale is simply outstandingly shaped and communicated, and the ending is thrilling, as it should be.  It's odd that this recording (and its later re-issue with "Rosamunde" as pairing) isn't easy to find nowadays.  Time for DGG to give Levine a "big box" of his fine recordings for the label.  This one wouldn't need re-mastering!This is such great music that I'm open to many different interpretive stances, if the music is well-played.  Krips, Furtwangler, and especially Giulini all get high marks from me too, with Giulini being perhaps the most different from Levine in approach -- but still great.  You need more than one recording of this music anyway -- but Levine should be on your list.

This is so different from the other, later, Fellini movies that I've seen -- "Amarcord" and "La Dolce Vita" -- that I was quite surprised.  The later two are satirical exposes of the shortcomings of post-war Italian masculinity; this earlier one, although set in post-war Italy too, strikes me as much more humanely involving and, at the same time, almost mythic in its clear schematic structuring.  The bare bones of the story are of a rather brutish itinerant entertainer called Zampano (Anthony Quinn), who travels around the countryside giving displays of strength to small crowds in provincial towns who are willing to see him break iron chains by flexing his pectoral muscles.  He's a bit like Canio in "Pagliacci" in his volatility and potential for violence.  At times, he hooks up with small circuses and does his act as part of the circus's entertainment.  His female partner has died (we learn as the story opens), and Zampano in effect buys her sister Gelsomina (Guilietta Masini) from their mother as a replacement.  This is the first hint of the economic stringencies of post-war Italy, looked at from the point of view of a class well below what we see in the later films mentioned above, and it is to that class that Zampano and the small circuses that he joins with appeal.  Gelsomina is simple-minded, to use an old-fashioned phrase that seems right for the time of the film, but she's sweet, and she discovers, as she travels around, a talent for attracting and appealing to audiences with what seems like almost a Chaplinesque, "little tramp" kind of shtick.  Zampano needs that talent -- for she is, in effect, his way of attracting a paying audience -- and yet seems to resent the easy rapport that Gelsomina establishes, and he treats her brusquely and sometimes cruelly.  Things come to a head when Gelsomina attracts the attention of "Il Matto," -- a clown or "fool" played by Richard Baseheart -- who combines jesting with tightrope-walking and violin-playing.  He is associated in the film with a poignant little musical phrase that he teaches Gelsomina to play and which becomes associated with her.  Matto, unfortunately for him, constantly pokes fun at Zampano, and Zampano doesn't take it well.  For all that, it becomes clear that, much as Gelsomina likes Matto and shares his whimsy, she has come to care for Zampano, and given chances to leave him, she does not.  I'll say no more in the interests of not spoiling plot developments for readers who might not have seen the film.What's striking about all this is the economy of the script and the fact that most of what I've described above is communicated through movement and gesture.  These are NOT articulate characters -- they emphatically don't "talk through" their problems, and one doubts that they even could, and Gelsomina is simple anyway.  But beyond the dynamics of character interaction, there's a sense of Gelsomina's responsiveness to the natural and even spiritual dimensions of life.  She is associated with the sea -- and the movie opens and closes with sea images -- and she's also responsive to not just Matto's violin but to the simple ceremony of a religious parade that she encounters in one of the villages.  Her responsiveness to these things is communicated largely wordlessly, but Fellini's attention to Masini's look and gestures makes it clear.  It would be going too far to simply allegorize Zampano and Gelsomina as body and spirit respectively, but in the film's schematization, the contrast trends in that direction, and Gelsomina's unselfconscious playfulness is connected to this hint of the "holy fool" that is part of the way she's represented.  Anthony Quinn's Zampano isn't a graceful mover, as Gelsomina is, but the ways of movement, their ways of using their physical resources, push the film in the direction of dance as an expressive medium, especially given the deliberate paucity of the language.  The performances seem to me outstanding -- Quinn, Masini, and Baseheart seem to give themselves completely to Fellini's conception, and the conclusion is very affecting.  The filming in black-and-white seems apt too for the scheme, and it looks very good, even when what it's looking at is painful to contemplate.  Great film!

I'm glad to have heard this, but to be honest, this recording has some serious limitations.  I'll deal with these first, then touch on what I liked about it.  First, the sound isn't great, and it deteriorates as it goes on.  The throat-clearing and coughing, from the love duet on (i. e. on CD2), is irritating, and it doesn't let up.  The singers sound a bit more "present" on CD1, but I don't know if that reflects a change in position of the recorder or not. (Was it Lord Harewood himself, one wonders?) It's hard to judge the conducting under these circumstances.  Often, the pacing seems fine, but the concerted passages throughout seem a bit frenetic, and the chorus, when singing loudly, gets blurry and indistinct.  When we get to the solo performances, there are some things to like.  Amy Shuard, the Amelia, seems quite at home in the stellar company here.  The microphones don't always do her justice, but it's hard to see that she puts a foot wrong -- she has power, tenderness, and alert expression throughout.  The same could be said of Jon Vickers in a role that one doesn't really associate with him.  But his voice, for all its size, has a airiness, almost a lightness to its timbre, which he uses to good effect here.  What he lacks is elegance, and that counts for something in this opera -- Carlo Bergonzi's accounts set the standard, in my eyes, for the role of Gustavo -- and Vickers is far from that.  His death scene goes for veristic effects -- Bergonzi, in contrast, never loses the aristocratic dignity of the character.  That said, Vickers and Shuard give a fine account of the love duet, marred only by the recorded sound.  In "La rivedra," though, Vickers is far too free with the line and the expressive effects.  Resnik is a solid Ulrica, Joan Carlyle a blessedly un-chirpy Oscar with nice tone, and then there's Bastianini.  He was a great di Luna in a "Trovatore" recorded around the time of this recording.  Here, he starts strong but sounds more ordinary by the time he gets to his big confrontation -- the "Eri tu" part.  He doesn't sound nearly implacable enough in the recitative ("Alzati!" etc.) -- compare Merrill here -- nor does he quite bring off richly the lovely cantilena after "O dolcezze memorie."  He's not bad -- no vibrato or strain -- but rather ordinary.  Still, these are all singers that I'm glad I heard in these roles.

It just so happened that the movie I watched on DVD prior to this one was "Enemy at the Gates," which also featured Rachel Weisz.  She is an actress I find appealing to watch, for she credibly communicates intelligence as well as intensity, and here, as a biologist with expertise in genetics she sounds as credible as she needs to when discussing the (fictional) phenomenon of "viraling out."  You'll have to watch the movie to find out what that means!  If you do so, you'll get caught up, as with the earlier "Bourne" movies, in CIA skulduggery -- generally, an intelligence operation that is carried on as far as possible beyond the ken of the people or their elected officials.  The Bourne series (of which this is the fourth), has been all about keeping the lid on wider knowledge of what is clearly a rogue operation.  In this movie Edward Norton is the chief rogue, and Jeremy Renner plays Aaron Cross, a Bourne surrogate (Matt Damon having bowed out) and an operative who, like Bourne in the first movie, is out to discover just what his employers have done to him.  It involves genetic tampering, hence the presence of Rachel Weisz, who also, she claims (and we believe her because she's Rachel Weisz), doesn't fully know the extent of the nefarious uses to which her research has been put.When Norton realizes that Renner's character is looking for answers, he decides to eliminate him.  Easier said than done, of course -- and the chase is on -- at which point this movie becomes like all the others, a chase-movie.  Cars, planes, boats and motorcycles all feature, and the locale for the climax this time is Manila, and the final chase seems a partial homage to "Terminator 2."  That's all that needs to be said.  Renner is as effective as Damon was as a hunted man and, bearded, looks remarkably like the young Kenneth Branagh. Weisz is fine as the biologist who helps him, and Ed Norton is suitably chilly -- but this is a movie that doesn't really call for the full deployment of acting skills that Renner, Norton, or Weisz are capable of.  The same was true of Damon, of course.  The bottom line is -- if you like fast chases and exotic locales, go for it.  It's smoothly done.  My own tolerance for this stuff is limited, so I tend to think it's maybe time to put this franchise out to pasture (excuse the incoherent metaphor!).

In one of the "special features" accompanying this DVD, the director Jean-Jacques Annaud talks of the fascination of the "rhythm" of a slow, intimate story (the sniper v. sniper slow dance) set against the world-historical, densely-populated, "action-oriented" story of the Battle of Stalingrad in 1942-43, the battle in which the Red Army, taking horrific losses, managed to stop the eastward movement of Hitler's Nazi war machine.  The movie actually starts with an old-fashioned visual device -- the map of Europe with the black stain of Nazism spreading out from Germany in all directions, until it comes, in the east, to the Volga . . . I liked that.  It reminded me of old war movies I had enjoyed.  And the "rhythm" idea is kind of neat too, although it's pretty much an aesthetic indulgence on Annaud's part -- for it isn't totally credible, for all of rhetoric of the Russian propagandist commissar Danilov (Joseph Fiennes) and Nikita Khrushchev (Bob Hoskins), that victory at Stalingrad depends on the outcome of the sniper war between the Russian Vassily Zaitsev and the German master-sniper Konig (Ed Harris).  One has to give some credit to the set-designers -- the ruined Stalingrad is well presented and at times spectacularly filmed, whether in its details or in  the wider picture.  But that's it -- for the film is hollow at the core:  these cast members have done very good work in other movies, and they go at it like true professionals here, but they're given nothing to work on in terms of character.  Such back-stories as we get are very sketchy, and it's as if they have no lives beyond the exigencies of the plot.  The spicing up of a degree of rivalry between Danilov and Zaitsev, erstwhile friends, because of the presence of Rachel Weisz as a fetching woman soldier looks like a desperate attempt to inject "human interest," but it doesn't go anywhere except a rather stereotyped reconciliation near the end.  Rachel Weisz is capable of really engaging characterization (like Harris and Hoskins), but she too is given little to work with.  Hoskins's Khrushchev is a very broad caricature -- basically, "I've come to Stalingrad to kick ass, take names, and in so doing turn back the Nazis" -- and the timeworn contrast between the heroic common soldiers and the brutal officers is played out once again.  I think we see more Russians killed by Russians than by Nazis.  Even allowing for some truth to that, it seems over-the-top here, and one can understand why the Russians found the movie offensive.  Just about all the close-up brutality in the movie is committed by them.  In the German scenes, it's pretty much Ed Harris with his boss or alone.  I see the movie as really wasting the talents of some good character-actors.  Moment by moment, it isn't boring -- but when one reflects back on it, there's not much there.

A lovely recording from the late 1970's, in very good analogue sound.  It's possible to imagine a more refined sound picture, but who needs it?  This is graceful and spirited playing of two pieces that go well together on a CD.  The Octet is very early Mendelssohn, and it isn't quite as magical as the Midsummer Night's Dream Overture, but it seems to have an energy and sparkle that remind one of Rossini and a formal elegance that is Mozartian.  That's a potent mix.  The later Quintet is equally approachable.  The fast movements are fizzing, and the slow movements are elegant rather than profound, in a Beethovenian way, but they're none the worse for that.  As another reviewer reminds us -- the disc is a fine testimony to the artistry of the violinist Iona Brown, who succeeded Neville Marriner as leader of the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields and who died far too young.  If you have or acquire this CD of this music, that's all you need.

There's a lot going on in this engaging, entertaining, and, at times, affecting version of the Earp family's involvement in the "gunfight at the OK Corral."  It tells a rather different and more complicated story than "My Darling Clementine" (1946) and "The Gunfight at the OK Corral" (1957), making the story less a family feud story (Clantons v. Earps) and more a story of the Earps' battles as lawmen against a gang of feral outlaw types called "The Cowboys," who terrorize Tombstone, own the local sheriff, and require the establishment of the Earps as federal lawmen as they try to bring peace and security to a wild gambling town.  Complicating things are the families of the Earps, not least Wyatt's opium-addicted wife -- but we're made aware here, more than in the earlier movies of the cost to families whose men are lawmen in a pretty lawless time.  Unhappy in a deteriorating marriage, Wyatt is drawn to a visiting actress, played by Dana Delaney, who seems to stand for a free and easy life (with "room service") while Wyatt seems almost paralyzed by a sense of various duties -- but she's in there at the end.  The other interesting element is Wyatt's friendship with the gunman and gambler Doc Holliday, whom his brothers don't trust -- but Wyatt sees Doc's essential honesty with him and stands by him -- just as well, as we find out near the end.The portrayal of Doc by Val Kilmer is an amazing performance, even more baroque than Victor Mature's in "My Darling Clementine" and a world away from Kirk Douglas's self-torturing and agonized Doc.  Holliday seems to be the character that writers, directors, and actors seem to feel free to exercise their ingenuities upon, to the point of fantasy.  Kilmer's Doc is apparently, but only apparently, effete and mannered.  Kilmer plays him as more seriously consumptive than the earlier movies do, and with his waxen skin and long black coat and natty clothes, he looks like an avenging vampire at times.  There is in fact an odd mythic-supernatural vibe that plays over parts of the movie.  There's a lot of talk of death, the afterlife, heaven, and hell, and justice is made to seem important in relation to these concepts, and they seem to be rendered at crucial points in the settings -- in the luxurious interiors or in thunderstorm, at times of intense feeling.  The sense of Wyatt as avenging angel is strong, although, as played by Kurt Russell, he's always credibly human, and, at times, vulnerable, too.  Finally, I don't think it's spoiling anything to say that the OK Corral gunfight isn't the end of things . . . All in all, though, this is a carefully thought out and oddly involving movie, and Val Kilmer, I think, just has to be seen.

It must have been difficult for the directors of "Tombstone" (1993) and "Wyatt Earp" (1994) to come up with new takes on the story of Wyatt Earp, Doc Holliday and the gunfight at the OK Corral in Tombstone in Arizona.  Behind them were this John Sturges movie of 1957 and John Ford's "My Darling Clementine" from 1946.  The two later versions bring the Earps and Holliday into conflict with what is in effect a lawless gang, the Cowboys, who are terrorizing Tombstone.  The two earlier versions, by Ford and Sturges, pose the Clanton family against the Earps in a much less complicated scenario.  "My Darling Clementine" was very unusual, with Henry Fonda (Earp) and Victor Mature (Holliday) strongly distinguished -- Fonda consistently quiet, efficient, almost unimpassioned, and Mature, in a great histrionic performance, is flamboyant.  In "Gunfight at the OK Corral," Burt Lancaster is Earp, and he's a much more obviously pro-active character than Fonda's Earp, even though he ostensibly wants to get away from being a lawman and settle down.  The plot calls for his brother Morgan to be gunned down in the dark, mistaken for him, and his guilt over this injustice fuels his revenge.  Lancaster plays the intensity convincingly, as he also plays the humor earlier in the movie in his interactions with Holliday (Kirk Douglas).  Douglas's Holliday is a completely different kind of character from Mature's -- an educated, self-hating man, a compulsive drinker and gambler (and consumptive, of course) who is conscious of having disgraced his family and who takes his self-hatred out on his girlfriend Kate -- we would now say that he abuses her.  This drives her to seek temporary refuge withe the Clantons and their sidekick Johnny Ringo (John Ireland) and that helps set up the gunfight, which, after Morgan's death and Kate's alienation, has less to do with law enforcement than with personal vendetta.  Lancaster and Douglas are very good as a team -- you might have enjoyed them in "The Devil's Disciple" too -- and Rhonda Fleming enters as Laura Denbow, a lady gambler who attracts Wyatt's attention.  She looks fabulous.  Other familiar faces in the cast include DeForest Kelly (later to be on "Star Trek") as Virgil Earp and the young Dennis Hopper as the youngest Clanton brother, who senses that his family is going off the rails but who can't deny family loyalty when the crunch comes.  It's a thoroughly entertaining movie, and it blends a variety of tones -- comic, romantic, something close to tragic -- very well, and the credit for that goes to a decent script (Leon Uris) and to the performances of the two male leads.  The whole thing, I should add, is cast as a kind of Ballad.  Frankie Laine sings a somewhat cheesy song over the opening credits, and we hear him again at transitional points in the action, moving things along.  Good stuff!

I bought this along with the Solti "Rigoletto," and somewhat to my surprise found that this is much better.  Cillario doesn't set the world on fire, but he's steady, keeps a good pulse, trusts his singers to be expressive in the conversational passages, and coaxes a nice sound from the 1973 LPO that is well caught in the remastering.  But the question with "Norma" is -- how does it measure up to Callas?  Well, it's better cast than the two early EMI Callas recordings (studio with Filippeschi, and live with Picchi), and in much better sound too.  The 1960 Callas, with Corelli and Ludwig is stiffer competition.  Even so, this one holds its own.  Limitations first: in 1960, Callas and Corelli were old hands at "Norma," and they had besides expressive resources and vocal qualities that neither Domingo nor Caballe possessed, and one result is that what I call the conversational passages are projected with much more nuance and dramatic awareness than we find in this recording.  It's the case too, I believe, that Cossotto, well as she sings, has a voice that's a bit too unyielding for Adalgisa, where Ludwig and Marilyn Horne are both more vulnerable-sounding; so good though the singing is -- and it always is -- some scenes aren't as engaging as one would ideally like.  Ralph Moore talks of an "assembly-line" quality, but I think that's a tad harsh -- rather, I think, these singers just hadn't thought or felt their ways into their roles -- had they even sung them on stage much, if at all? -- and that accounts for the lower dramatic temperature.However, a real virtue of this recording is that the final scene is given with great emotional power.  Caballe conceives it on a more intimate scale than Callas, and she sings absolutely beautifully.  Even without the spine-chilling baritonal tinges of Callas's "In mia man," that final confrontation with Pollione is powerful and moving, and Domingo is at his best there too.  The singing, simply as singing, is of very high quality -- but there is much more than singing going on in that final scene.  Corelli and Callas are great there too, but Caballe and Domingo are a match, in their different approach. As for another "big moment," I have to say that I thought "Mira, O Norma" was really well done, and if "Si, fin all'ora" sounded too much like two healthy hockey-playing girls, well . . . that's Bellini's fault.  I've always found that cabaletta to be a misjudgment on Bellini's part.  Of the other singers, Elizabeth Bainbridge is a very positive Clotilde, Kenneth Collins a very fine Flavio, and Ruggero Raimondi (whose name is mis-spelled on the front of the box) has a perfect voice for Oroveso and sings very beautifully.  Has there been a better "Norma" on CD since 1973? Scotto? Sutherland 2.0?  I don't think so.  I thought this was just fine and, where it mattered, much better than that.

Charlton Heston wasn't convincing in "Major Dundee," the only other western I had seen him in, but he seems totally at home in "Will Penny," which he has said was one of his favorite roles.  He plays an aging, illiterate cowboy, who seems itinerant, and goes around seeking work as a cattle-herder from whomever will hire him.  He's good at his job, but touchy about his age and his illiteracy, and he'll fight if he's ribbed hard enough by younger cowpokes.  The basic story here is how Penny helps and is helped by a woman and her son who have been forced to winter in a cow-minder's shack up in the Montana hills.  The conventional aspects of the story deal with the threat to Penny and, eventually the woman and her son, from a feral family of rawhiders headed by Donald Pleasance, in full-out, eyes-bugging-crazy mode (the young Bruce Dern plays one of his sons).  As some reviewers have noted, these characters seem to belong to a horror movie rather than a western, so over-the-top is their conception -- but, of course, they give old Will a chance to show his mettle, and I'll avoid spoilers by revealing no further details about that.  The real power of the movie, for me, was in the leisurely build-up to the violent action, where the movie takes time to give us something of the texture of the cattleman's life (filmed beautifully in northern California, with the Sierras as backdrop) and the difficulties of domestic life in hard winters in a small cabin in close quarters -- getting firewood, water, milk, stopping up chinks in the log walls, etc. etc.The human interest lies in the developing affection between Penny and the woman (played very well by Joan Hackett) and her boy.  She's a married woman, traveling to join her husband in Oregon, and she has been deserted by the guide that her husband supposedly paid in St. Louis to get them to Oregon.  Up in the Montana hills, they live a kind of domestic life, and the itinerant Penny is drawn to it.
