Heston is totally persuasive as an older man, habituated to a hard life, who finds himself uncertain and afraid of the love that he feels.  Hackett's character offers herself to him -- for a life together and not just sex -- and the scene in which that offer is discussed is very well done.  The sexual element in the relationship is forcibly communicated too, and the ending is very engaging dramatically.  This isn't the Charlton Heston that you might expect from "Ben-Hur," and it shows him to have been an actor capable of range and growth.  So don't let the cheesy elements put you off -- this is a good one.

The cast is strong from top to bottom, Solti is in charge, and the RCA engineers are on the job.  What could possibly go wrong?  Seriously, this recording should have been much better than it is.  I found almost constantly distracting features to it, despite secure singing and basically good remastered sound.  Much of the blame has to be Solti's.  At times, he's fast and metronomic and brutally loud, while at other times, he seems just to let the singers do what they please.  At the beginning of Act 2, for example, the orchestral lead-in to "Ella mi fu rapita" is unnecessarily driven and tense, but by the time he gets to "Parmi veder," he seems to be letting Alfredo Kraus play all sorts of dynamic tricks, and then he goes to tense and driven again.  Kraus's singing of "Parmi veder" is impressive as vocalism, but seems to me expressively mannered.  In "La Donna e mobile," on the other hand, he's fine.  Also notice how in the final act, the quartet begins nicely, but becomes rushed and over-metrical in the middle.  As a "reading" of the opera, Solti's seems bitty and incoherent -- something I would never say about his Wagner or "Elektra" or even his fine "Don Carlo," just a few years later.  And Robert Merrill -- the beautiful voice is on display, but the drama requires phrasing and attention to words, and all we get is an outpouring of golden tone.  Another American baritone, Cornell McNeill, in his recording with Sutherland is much more musically and dramatically involved.  A few years later, Merrill recorded a Renato for RCA (with Bergonzi and Price) which is as good as any, but here it's all too monochrome.  Moffo makes up for the dramatic shortcomings of Merrill to some extent -- in the lower and middle voice her phrasing is expressively appropriate and her feel for words welcome.  Higher up, at the very top, the voice can sound a bit forced and unsupported, but like the others, she doesn't make an ugly sound.  I enjoyed hearing Kraus -- a great singer who was under-used by the recording companies during his peak years -- even if at times he gilded the lily.  Among the smaller roles, Piero di Palma (Borsa), Robert Kern (Marullo), David Ward (Monterone), and Ezio Flagello (Sparafucile) did fine work.  I once heard Ward in the theater as Wotan, no less -- the man could sing.An added irritation was what I would call instability in the aural picture.  A voice would be well forward, then suddenly it would be moved back.  Listen to Merrill, for example, right before the "Si Vendetta" section in Act Two -- then when "Si Vendetta" begins, he's in a different aural space altogether.  Was all this fiddling with voice placement an effort to reproduce the impression of movement on a stage?  If it was, it didn't work -- I found it ubiquitous and distracting.  Along with Solti's erratic direction, it pulled my mind from engagement with the drama to the problems with the presentation and the medium.

Unlike his great older contemporary Claudio Abbado, Riccardo Muti seems to have felt no necessity to have three tries at the Beethoven symphonies.  This "Eroica" is from his only set, recorded in the late 1980s, in Philadelphia., and the recorded sound is very good.  What's striking about the performance to me is the extent to which it builds to the last movement, which is just splendidly performed here, with a mixture of delicacy, power, energy, and humor that is altogether winning.  The final movement begins by reminding me of Rossini, but by the end, it seems pure Beethoven without having dispensed with the Rossinian warmth and humor.  There's a lot going on in the orchestra in that movement, and the EMI sound catches it all, so that Muti's control of the whole developing narrative is just laid out for you to enjoy.  The third movement is a success too, with the scherzo and trio beautifully integrated and the playing just superb.I suspect that for most listeners, and maybe for me too, the emotional heart of the piece is the great slow movement.  Muti establishes here and in the first movement, like Klemperer, a pulse that never falters and gives great integrity to these two movements.  Klemperer -- my standard for the slow movement -- digs in to the accents a bit more sharply, with the effect of a craggy, tragic solemnity.  Muti doesn't go for that; rather he goes, it seems to me, for a more restrained and dignified but nonetheless human expression, and it works perfectly on its own terms -- and one effect of his way of handling it is to make the final movement a real climax and not a disappointment after the "depths" of the second.  So -- I think this is a really fine account, in beautiful sound, and I can understand why Muti might have felt no need to improve on it.  This well-filled disc ends with nice accounts of a couple of overtures -- "Fidelio" and "The Consecration of the House."  No reason to hesitate if you like Muti or Beethoven.

I think that Santa Fe Listener's account of the strengths and weaknesses of this recording are just about dead right -- the 1974 Israel Philharmonic sounds "scrappy," the tenor Rene Kollo is sorely taxed at times, and the overall sound is unrefined -- though in the latter case the orchestra might be as much to blame as the engineers.  I assume that the recording was made in Tel Aviv, but there's no information on my copy.  Still, I give it four stars, and maybe partly for sentimental reasons -- Kollo and Ludwig were the soloists in the only performance of this music that I heard live in the concert hall -- in 1969, at the Edinburgh Festival, with Karajan and the Berlin Philharmonic.  But it's not just sentiment.  I think Bernstein's pacing and expression here are faultless, for all the shortcomings of the orchestra.  And Kollo catches, as no other singer quite does on record, the underlying desperation and bitterness of the "Trunkene."  I would call his singing, as singing, uneven, rather than downright bad.  There are some very strenuous patches that he sings very well, only to let one down with pitch problems in places where one doesn't expect it.  And, I would say, he sings less well as the piece goes on, so that his last song is the least surely sung.  BUT he knows what the words and music are about, and he is fearless in expression, singing with good power, a good line, and good diction, for all the flaws.  To a degree not realized in her fine recording with Klemperer, Christa Ludwig catches a sadness beyond gravity in her singing throughout.  It's simply a great performance.  No one does gravity and acceptance quite as well as Janet Baker, for Haitink -- but Bernstein and Ludwig get at an extra degree of sadness, and they do so without exaggeration -- for I agree with Santa Fe Listener that Bernstein's "classic" interpretation for Decca in 1966 (with King and Fischer-Dieskau and the VPO) is made to sound inflated and ponderous by both Culshaw's sound production values as well as Bernstein's and F-D's more highly-inflected and interventionist phrasing.  So -- there's a downside to this recording, but for me it remains a very moving account.

For all the opulence of the sound -- the almost preternatural unanimity of the strings in particular --  these are surprisingly lively performances, and the solo instruments that require to be highlighted are not made to stand out in too artificial a way.  I was surprised, because I had read some reviews of Karajan's Haydn that weren't complimentary, and perhaps I gave them too much credence because I was enjoying at that time some period instrument recordings (Kuijken's Paris symphonies, with the OAE, also from the EMI stable) and so Karajan didn't sound too appetizing by comparison.  But I was unfair -- the rhythms are good, the inner movements aren't over-romanticized, and the finales are aptly high-spirited.  I should have remembered that Karajan's recording of "The Creation" speaks to his feeling for Haydn!  Here, we have one of the Paris Symphonies and two of the very late London set.  If you can resist the humor of the Hen in No. 83, you're soberer than I am.  Overall, I like better the orchestral presence in Colin Davis's set for Philips of the London Symphonies, but you can't go wrong with this well-filled disc.

Beautiful sound and great playing from a 50th anniversary release of the music from the original Beaux Arts Trio's first recording.  Amazingly, the original pianist, Menahem Pressler. is still there, and still playing with energy and limpid beauty as required.  The music is great too, of course -- Mendelssohn's First Trio marries a classical form with what we think of as "romantic" robustness memorably here.  The first two movements are eloquent and dramatic; the last two start with the skittishly humorous scherzo, the spirit of which returns several times to haunt -- in a charming way -- the lively finale.  Pressler's playing in the opening of the slow movement is very beautiful, and Daniel Hope, the violinist, is superb throughout.  The cellist Antonio Meneses gets more chance to show his quality in the "Dumky" Trio of Dvorak.  It isn't a big overpowering cello sound, but it's lovely, focused, and characterful.  The Dumky is a winning piece, with its alternations of melancholy Bohemianism and lively dance-music.  With six movements, all of which play with contrasts of tempo, dynamics, and timbre, Dvorak nonetheless holds it all together.  It's not formal in a "theme-and-variations" way, but there is a development and repetition of motifs that unifies the piece musically and expressively.  I should add that in this piece, Daniel Hope makes his violin sound like a very different instrument from its Mendelssohnian self -- in fact, he coaxes at least three different kinds of timbres out of it, depending on the music.  Clearly, these performances have been very carefully thought out -- but the execution sounds as spontaneous and alive as you could wish.

It takes a special magic to conduct the first movement of this symphony at the pace that Alsop adopts here -- Giulini with the LAPO (who is even slower!) has that magic, but Alsop can't quite captivate us to the same degree.  Bernstein with the VPO couldn't either, but Bernstein's much quicker 1960 NYPO recording is enchanting.  Somewhere between 1960 Bernstein and Alsop are Bohm and Abbado, and they both do very well.  The later movements bother me less -- but first impressions are important if one is to stay the course, and I can't get away from a sense of ponderous tidiness here.  The recording (which some reviewers don't like) seems not bad at all to my ears (better than Abbado's, in fact), and the playing throughout is never less than highly competent -- but when Haitink, Klemperer, Giulini, and the young Bernstein are all in the field (not to mention Walter, Bohm, Karajan, and Abbado), then there are plenty of more compelling choices.

Fans of Jon Vickers -- and I'm one -- will know that when his singing in Wagner and "Fidelio," for example, is compared to that of his contemporary, the American tenor James King, there's an easy power, and magic, and charisma to his singing that are not King's to command.  But listen to King, with Haitink and Janet Baker, in "Das Lied von der Erde" and you have to admit that King is better in almost every way -- he sings firmly, he caresses the vocal line, he knows what the words mean and how to weigh them with no compromising of the musical line.  It's tempting to say that he believes in what he's singing -- and on this disc Jon Vickers sings as if he has no idea what is expressively required.  He's not a singer one associates with Mahler, nor is Davis a noted Mahler conductor, and this well-played, quite brisk traversal of the music doesn't suggest that Davis had any useful advice to give Vickers about expression.  Isn't the thrill of the great, distinctive voice enough? Not in this case -- the singing is powerful but perfunctory to a degree where the German vowels sound very odd indeed.  That leaves Jessye Norman.  She has a better sense of the words, and she phrases expressively, and while she has the low notes for the part, she doesn't have them with the ease and roundness and warmth of a Baker or a Christa Ludwig, true mezzos both.  So . . . two great voices and great singers here, but it's just the wrong place for them.

This is disappointing.  The Decca sound (from 1986) is very good, but Solti's conducting leaves much to be desired.  It's weighty and rich, but it's rhythmically spineless and a bit slow, which might not matter if the accenting was crisper.  This means that in an opera that should be tense in all sorts of ways, it's sluggish and inexpressive.  There are problems with the principals too. Aragall was an attractive Alfredo twenty years earlier; here the singing is firm and he works to maintain a good line, but it's tonally monochrome and in important places (like the Act 1 duet) the words go for nothing.  There's no charm or sexual charisma or humor in the duet -- and all of these things matter.  He does a little better at moments in Act 3, but even so, "Amaro sol per te" is really almost bawled, and while O dolce mani" is better, Solti drags it out to a point where it becomes shapeless.  Te Kanawa has the notes for Tosca but she lacks the amplitude of Price or Caballe.  To her credit, she tries to give the words their due, but in "Vissi d'arte" she's undone by Solti's sluggishness.  That leaves Nucci and Piero di Palma to rescue the dramatic singing in this performance -- and they know what they're doing.  Nucci never had the prettiest voice, but he can phrase and sing expressively, and he can accommodate better than the others to Solti's pacing.  Di Palma was an old hand by 1986 at Spoleta, and he sounds lovely and characterizes well.  It's easy to think that "Tosca" should be a "can't miss" kind of opera, but good singers have foundered on it.  Freni, with Sinopoli, comes to mind.  I think the Caballe/Carreras/Colin Davis recording is really good, and so is the Karajan/Price/Di Stefano.  Then there's the first Callas recording, which is outstanding, though the sound is getting old.  But even the second Callas (with Bergonzi and Gobbi) has something that this one of Solti's doesn't.

Predictable kinds of pleasures here -- the malefactors in the novel keep thinking of ways to eradicate Jack Reacher as he zeroes in on their criminal operation, and they always underestimate his resourcefulness of body and mind, and there comes a point where Jack begins to predict the kinds of things that they will get up to and take action even before any threats materialize -- so that, when they do, he's more than ready.  Lee Child's Reacher novels all work like this, so the fun is all in the different specific ways and sets of circumstances that he dreams up to challenge Reacher.  I can imagine a certain kind of reader thinking that there's a sameness about Child's novels and beginning to seek writers who are less formulaic.  I'm not quite ready to join them, maybe partly because the writing is vivid and usually economical and partly because I recognize that at least the formula is Child's own and not a tired reworking of someone else's.  In this novel, it works very well for the first 80% of the novel, and its climax for me comes in the part that is set in Phoenix, Arizona.  (it's not giving away too much to identify it thus).  The last 100 pages or so, however, are a bit anti-climactic, mainly because (in my judgment) the plan that Reacher works out to deal with the main malefactors is very elaborate, and the action is slowed down to an unacceptable extent as that plan works itself out in the plot.  We need to keep reading, however, because it's only in the last 100 pages that the full extent of the evildoers' evil is revealed -- and it's horrible enough, so more's the pity that the tension sags so much in the course of that section.In this novel, Reacher finds himself getting off a train in the middle of the Oklahoma prairie at Mother's Rest, a small town that seems on its face to be a collecting point for grain storage and shipment.  As he does so, he meets Michelle Chang, a PI who is expecting her partner, Keever, to also be arriving on that train.  Even before Reacher arrives, we know that Keever won't be on the train -- a very effective opening section makes that clear -- and Reacher and Chang join forces to try to find out what has happened to Keever -- as a number of townspeople realize what they are trying to find out and take steps to form a plan to thwart them.  Good procedural detective work is done, and a number of American cities are visited as Chang and Reacher pursue their investigation: Oklahoma City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Phoenix, San Francisco.  We're led from the rural heartland to the dark depths of the internet -- so there's a virtual as well as a geographical sweep to the novel that is attractive -- and it so happens that the geographical location of Mother's Rest itself poses challenges that require the complicated plan that slows down the narration in the last section of the book.  It's in these pages that we realize that that geographical situation has been carefully set up from the very beginning to provide the difficulties that Reacher and Chang (and their ally, an LA investigative journalist) face at the end.  To complicate matters further, Reacher seems in these last pages to be suffering from concussion, although that seems to me to be tacked on a bit gratuitously to heighten suspense.Chang is one of Child's very attractive, very competent, and sexy women -- ex-FBI, and therefore with a developed set of skills -- and she and Reacher are attracted to one another with predictable results, although, as always, Child's romantic scenes are quite chastely and understatedly handled, and none the worse for that.  Reacher amazes her with his capacity for coffee as much as for his forensic skills and physical prowess, and these again are familiar pleasures.  I enjoyed the novel, and, like our heroes, I had to find out what the bad guys were up to -- but that over-elaboration at the end wore on me.

Now and again, you come across a recording that you didn't know had been made.  This one is 20 years old, and I just found it, remaindered, in my local store.  I picked it up because it's great music, and I admire the performers, and there's nothing at all wrong with it.  One reviewer speaks of its "noble restraint," and that gets at a quality in the performances, I think.  My tastes run to something a bit more explicitly soulful, so I prefer the recent recording with Kavakos and Wang, which has two added advantages that aren't just a matter of taste: Kavakos and Wang have a couple of interesting and well-played "fillers," AND the Decca sound is even better than the good sound on this EMI recording.  There's also a 1967 Decca recording with Josef Suk and Julius Katchen -- older but still good analogue sound, and just beautifully played.  Still -- this is very good too, and some might prefer its relative restraint.

Both of these recordings were made in 1969, and clearly EMI wanted to make the most of Oistrakh, Rostropovich, and Richter -- the Soviet "big three" at the time.  They had Oistrakh record the Brahms concerto with Szell in Cleveland at the same time as the Double.  It's interesting to hear all three in the Beethoven's Triple Concerto, recorded in Berlin, but I wish that the sound were a little less homogeneously massive and that Karajan had a bit more spring in his step.  It's impressive, but a bit marmoreal.  I prefer Masur's airier sound with the Beaux Arts Trio in their digital recording with the NYPO from the 1990s.  In both of the pieces here, the soloists are well forward, so there's no pretense to a "natural" sound picture.  I think that we just have to accept that as a solution to the problem of posing a chamber group in relation to a big orchestra, and if we can -- and I have no problem with it -- then there's a lot of pleasure to be had.  I think though, that the Brahms Double is the gem here.  There's a little bit more open-ness to the sound from Cleveland, and Szell conducts with fire.  His timings aren't all that different from Haitink's 1979 recording (with Rostropovich and Perlman) but my sense is that in the long first movement, where it counts, he drives the faster music hard and relaxes  a bit more than Haitink in the tender moments.  This brings an element of drama to the movement that is absolutely gripping.  Add to that that Rostropovich's sound is caught with more focus here, and that Oistrakh plays his heart out, making a stronger impression than Perlman (or Stern with Ma and Abbado).  The second movement is eloquently phrased in its lovely first subject, and there's liveliness and charm in the third.  And although the soloists ARE out front, the sound overall is better (and the conducting more dramatic) than with Haitink's 1979 recording.  I'm happy to have both -- but this one is special.

The recordings on this disc come from 1979 (the Brahms) and 1983 (Mendelssohn).  They were brought together by EMI in 1988, in recognition of the 100th anniversary of the opening of the Concertgebouw, whose orchestra, conducted with fire by Bernard Haitink, accompanies the soloists in both works.  I didn't even know this pairing existed until I picked it up second-hand, and I'm very glad I did, because it's quite wonderful.  The Brahms Double Concerto must be the very devil to balance on a recording, and EMI here has both soloists, Perlman and Rostropovich, well to the fore -- too much so, in fact, as Santa Fe Listener says.  So there is a touch of artificiality about the sound balance, but the orchestra nonetheless is given more than adequate presence, with the lower instruments getting their due.  The orchestral sound -- it's late analogue -- isn't as refined as some Concertgebouw sound I've heard on Philips, but it's fine, and Haitink brings weight and drive to the music.  It's very enjoyable -- not the most emotionally engaging of Brahms's big works, but one in which the two soloists cooperate genially, and the slow movement's first motif has the lovely quality of a folk song.  In the last movement, a good time is being had by all.  If you can live with the forward sound, you should like this.No reservations about the Mendelssohn -- the balance of Perlman and the orchestra is well-judged, and I like it better than the more forward balance of many of Perlman's later DGG discs.  The sound -- early digital this time -- is more refined than in the Brahms, though it isn't in the Telarc class.  It's a robust performance that nonetheless doesn't lack elegance.  Haitink brings an almost Brahmsian weight to the music without sounding sluggish, and Perlman's playing seems to me beyond reproach.  The lovely slow movement is done with restrained elegance, and the hell-for-leather stuff in the finale is invigorating.  All in all, a disc I'm very happy to have.

In 1990, for good commercial reasons, Sony put together on one disc recordings of two Tchaikovsky concertos by two of the great Russian soloists of the mid-20th Century.  Emil Gilels, in a live 1980 performance of the Piano Concerto No. 1 with Mehta and the NYPO (in good early digital sound) and, from back in the catalogue, a 1959 studio recording of the Violin Concerto, with David Oistrakh and Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra.  There's 70+minutes of music here, and you wouldn't be disappointed with this disc.  Oistrakh is a bit too forward in the aural picture in his recording, but his playing is so beautiful and secure that one almost doesn't mind it.  Only the slow movement suffers a bit -- not from the playing per se but from the balance, which robs the music of some of its raptness.  In the outer movements, the violin part is so invigoratingly entertaining that one doesn't mind the closeness.  Oistrakh conveys the sheer fun and wit of much of the music, and the close-up sound at least enables one to marvel all the more at the deftness and security of the playing.  It's really amazing.  I always feel that this is a concerto that ends with its scherzo, and the qualities associated with a scherzo -- the humor and high spirits -- are fully in evidence here.  And in the coda, the Philadelphia strings show that they are no slouches either, and play with tremendous panache.The Piano Concerto, I think, is a more engaging performance -- but maybe that's just to say that I like the music better.  The recording is very good, the balance fine (though slightly favoring the piano), and Mehta moves this along very well.  Gilels gives an open-hearted, grandly rhetorical account of the piano part -- even in the slow movement, he doesn't go for delicacy, though the playing and phrasing are by no means insensitive, and in the outer movement there's a kind of Olympian gravity to it that is very compelling.  The interpretation seems to me all of a piece, and Mehta and Gilels seem to be in accord on it.  It's a very distinguished account, as good as anything in the catalogue.  Some reviewers were bothered by some audience noise -- coughs and creaks here and there.  With playing like this, I found it easy not to be bothered.

Santa Fe Listener, whose reviews I always find interesting and informative, is really down on this one -- and I just have to say that my reaction was totally different.  I thought that these were lively, spirited, and genial performances.  I don't know many other recordings of this music, but I remember thinking that Arrau/Starker/Szerying (with Inbal) was a bit staid and thinking that Oistrakh/Rostropovich/Richter (with Karajan) was compromised by sound that was a bit muddy and a balance that might have been better -- though, to be fair, it has been a long time since I heard these versions and I haven't heard the latest remasterings.  Here, the sound is very open and airy, and only occasionally did I feel that the piano in particular was a bit too much to the fore.  The playing seemed very good to me, with the Beaux Arts cellist Peter Wiley eloquent in the brief slow movement, but the others doing very well too.  This is mid-period Beethoven (c. 1808), and the atmosphere is relaxed and sociable, and the music not all that demanding for the listener.  It's not one of his greatest works, but it never failed to give pleasure in this recording.  The near-contemporary Choral Fantasia is an odd piece, starting with a piano solo, going into a section of the finale where the orchestra joins the piano in a fantasia-like movement, and ending with a choral section, with soloists, praising the power of music, that it's tempting to see as a dry run for parts of the finale of the Ninth Symphony, which, of course, was very far from Beethoven's mind at the time.  I have heard one other recording -- Brendel's -- and I prefer Brendel's playing to Pressler's, but I didn't find anything very wrong with Pressler's.  Again, the sound and balance are good, the music is enjoyable, and, as with the Concerto, Masur drives his Leipzig orchestra along in an appropriately lively manner.  A good time seems to be being had by all, and I enjoyed it.

Dvorak's Eighth Symphony is perhaps his most immediately likeable -- it was the first Dvorak work I ever bought, on vinyl, back around 1968, and I immediately was taken with it.  That was Karajan's Vienna recording (also on Decca), and good as it was, the sound can't really compare with this great Dohnanyi account from Cleveland.  There is an airiness and bloom to the sound, and the individual instruments and groupings come through with wonderful texture, and at the same time the sense of rhythmic solidity and forward progress in the music isn't compromised.  There's a lovely rustic folkishness to much of the thematic material -- a sense of folk-song and dance -- that is immediately appealing and that couldn't be more different from the Brahmsian good manners of the Seventh Symphony (also beautifully recorded by Dohnanyi, by the way).  Dohnanyi savors the melodies and textures, never seeming to hurry but never losing the thread.  It's a great recording of a very enjoyable work.  The "filler" is the Scherzo Capriccioso, a work whose expressive quality is very much in keeping with the symphony -- good natured, and coming across like a cross between a slavonic dance and a Johann Strauss concoction.I picked up this disc cheap and used.  Buyers considering this music would be best served by the "Decca Double" release that includes Symphonies 7 and 9 along with 8, all with Dohnanyi and the Clevelanders and at a good price.

Yes, I like it -- but the trouble is that other Decca recordings of this music are more compelling and in some cases better-recorded too.  That said, this late analogue recording (c.1980) is lively and well-played, even if the sound isn't as refined as it could be for Decca (the "Argo" imprint was a Decca label), and on the whole, I think the Italian comes off a bit better than the Scottish.  Perhaps I'm used to a larger orchestra with a richer sound in the Scottish -- something like Dohnanyi's Vienna Philharmonic on a slightly earlier Decca recording, which combines energy and weight of lovely sound in a most engaging way.  Then, a few years after this recording, Solti produced a lovely account -- beautifully sprung, not over-driven -- with the Chicago Symphony -- on Decca too!.  The best Scottish of all is Maag's, from 1957, also on Decca, and marvelously remastered.  Maag's has weight, energy, and a kind of rustic quality that is altogether winning.  If one goes outside Decca, there's Karajan from the early 1970's and Klemperer from a decade earlier.  You'll notice that I've ended up talking about OTHER recordings rather than Marriner's -- and that's the problem: the better and the best are the enemy of the good.  The music is always a pleasure to hear, though -- and the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields is never less than reliable.

About a dozen or so years before making his Schumann symphony recordings in Zurich for Arte Nova, David Zinman, in 1989, made a set in Baltimore for Telarc, and if you want Zinman's Schumann, these Telarc recordings are the ones to get.  The Telarc digital sound in the 1980s and early '90s was one of the wonders of the world, and I'm not sure that it has been surpassed to date.  There's nothing wrong with Zinman's Zurich performances, and the sound isn't bad at all -- it's just not in the Telarc class.  And what of the performances of the symphonies on this disc?  Generally, I agree with John Kwok's more detailed earlier review -- they are just superb.  There are other really fine Schumann recordings, of course -- if you think of Schumann as an heir of Beethoven, then Szell's 1960 recordings are the ones to go for.  They're purposeful, energetic, and very excitingly played.  If you see Schumann as the precursor of his great mentor, Brahms, then go for Sawallisch, with the Dresden Staatskapelle, from around 1973 -- they have a weight and thrust reminiscent of Karl Bohm's fine recordings, plenty of energy, and excellent analogue sound.  But if you remember that Schumann was a friend and contemporary of Mendelssohn, then these Zinman recordings should please you.  The sound is airy and spacious, the textures of the instrumental groups are beautifully caught, there's and an attractive impression of "depth of field" in the excellently balanced sound.  The Second Symphony sounds intriguing and quirky rather than unsettling (as Sawallisch's account is) in Zinman's interpretation, but it works well.  The Third, of course, is almost always invigorating in any decent performance, and here the drive is both elegant and forward-moving, and the brass instruments are well-differentiated and thrilling to hear.  The moral of this review is that you really should have ALL the recordings mentioned -- great music in great performances.

Andrea Rost has worked with some of the most prestigious conductors of the last twenty years, so clearly she's an estimable artist, but this recording (made in 1997, when Rost was 35) does her no favors.  For a start, when I played it at the volume that I usually employ for vocal recitals, the voice sounded far back in the aural picture, and the orchestra even further back -- and the overall acoustic seemed, for want of a better word, "boomy."  Turning up the volume didn't really help -- it still sounded boomy, and the voice seemed to spread,  To make matters worse, there were times when the orchestra seemed to come out of nowhere and almost overwhelm the voice -- so that, for example, the climax of "Mi chiamano Mimi" went for nothing.  None of this was the fault of the singer.  Guessing a bit, I would say that she had a voice of good size, with a nice combination of warmth and coloratura flexibility.  Her natural vibrato seemed not excessive, though turning up the volume on it made it perhaps more troubling than it is in the theater.  Her program encompasses Verdi (Gilda, Violetta), Puccini (Mimi, Musetta, Lauretta), and Donizetti (Adina, Lucia, Norina) -- and perhaps inevitably, given the circumstances of recitals and the anonymizing acoustic, they all sounded pretty alike.  Whatever vocal "acting" was going on didn't really come through -- which I wouldn't have minded if the acoustic had been better.  Mackerras, a fine conductor, sounded languid here -- though the acoustic did the orchestra no favors either.  Sony sonics are usually pretty reliable, but they let down the show here.

First of all, the sound on this disc is first-rate.  I bought it because I had been impressed by both the sound AND the performance on Andrew Davis's disc of the Vaughan Williams Sixth, and the sound certainly lived up to my expectations.  Listen to the Introduction and Allegro for Strings, Op. 47 -- to me, the highlight of this disc.  The way the recording catches the textures of the whole range of strings, from high to low, from loud to soft, just couldn't be better.  The balance of the string quartet in relation to the concertante orchestral sections is just right, and the playing by all concerned, to my ears, is beautiful.  The earlier Serenade for String Orchestra is also beautifully done, though it's a simpler and less engaging piece.  I have to confess a bias, however -- even well-played, Elgar never gets my pulses racing, much as I appreciate the skill of the orchestration and harmony.  I came to this recording having been listening to a lot of Schumann and Dvorak, and these two can get you out of your chair, so to speak.  And it's not just a matter of a degree of reticence in the climaxes -- compared with Tchaikovsky, for example, or even Vaughan Williams.  Elgar seems to be unwilling or unable to commit himself wholeheartedly to melody.  No sooner does a promising motif present itself than it's worked on or worked over before it has a chance to make an emotional impact.  Is this a fear of vulgarity on Elgar's part -- his textures can be very refined -- or does he just have a different conception of symphonic development from Dvorak or Vaughan Williams?  I'm a very unsophisticated listener -- I like music that hews close to bodily sensation -- the march, the dance, the song -- and yet I suspect that, though I like Vaughan Williams better, Elgar is perhaps the greater composer.  It's a bit like preferring Dickens to Henry James, even as you know that James is masterly in a way that Dickens can't be (and isn't interested in being).Anyway . . . enough about me.  I enjoyed this disc, with the reservations noted above.  It opens with a spirited Cockaigne Overture, and ends with the "Enigma" Variations.  My overall impression of the Enigma performance is, again of refinement, and the sound is, again, beautiful.  I've heard tauter accounts, though.  Still, much to appreciate here.

I have read quite a few of the Inspector Banks series, and out of order too -- not that that bothered me -- so I thought I would take a stepback and see what I thought of Robinson's first novel in the series.  Banks, we are to understand, has left high-pressure policing in London to come up to the Yorkshire town of Eastvale, where he expects to find the pace a bit less hectic.  Of course, it isn't really . . . and in this novel Banks finds himself dealing with three separate cases -- one of which comes uncomfortably close to home -- while dealing with his feelings for an attractive psychologist/profiler type who has been foisted on him by his boss to help solve one of the cases.  The three cases involve a peeping Tom, a series of break-ins and thefts, and the murder of an old lady who lives up in the area of Eastvale that gives the book its title.  Banks has to sort out whether or not there are any connections among these crimes -- no spoilers from me! -- before he gets down to solving them.  Followers of this series won't be surprised to know that the plotting is very well worked out, although in later novels Robinson seems at pains to stress how cooperative an enterprise police work is, whereas here, the focus is kept more on Banks than on other detectives in his team.  That's not a big deal, but the greater attention to teamwork in the later novels -- and it isn't altogether absent here, by any means -- adds considerably to their plausibility and attractiveness for me.  Also in the later novels, Robinson's handling of dialogue gets better.  Here, the interactions of Banks and the pretty profiler aren't convincing, and the effect is to make the profiler less of a character and more of a standard-issue temptation for Banks than she (a professional, intelligent person) deserves to be.The novel features an interesting narrative set-up that shows, I think, how alive Robinson is to the technical challenges and opportunities of his craft.  With one crime -- the Peeping Tom -- we actually get the criminal's point of view at places in the novel without his being identified to us.  In the break-in story, we know who the perpetrators are -- but Banks doesn't, until he solves the case.  And in the murder story, we get the victim's view briefly, but no more (again, until the end), putting Banks and the reader in the same boat.  Robinson has to be careful to keep these narrative threads distinct and consistent -- and he succeeds very well.  That's one of the delights of the novel: it plays with generic expectations very deftly.  A good start, then, to the series -- and I think he got better.

Good Trouts are plentiful -- I have the Ax/Ma/Frank et. al.  and the Schiff/Hagen Quartet digital ones -- and they're fine, but when this showed up, used and very cheap, at my local store, I couldn't resist -- it had Rudolf Serkin, Jaime Laredo, and others, from the late 1960s at Marlboro, and since all my other Serkin recordings were concertos or piano solo, I wanted to hear him with a chamber group.  And it's delightful.  The sound doesn't really need any apologies, and the balance is excellent, and it's very mellow and charming music.  The opening is less tense than Ma/Ax, and it's in the opening variations of the fourth movement that one gets a touch of sentimental melancholy in the expression, as if the circumstances of the Schubert song "Die Forelle" are being alluded to.  Otherwise, there's wit and sparkle and charm -- a nice performance, even if, strictly speaking, I didn't need it!The filler is a soulful performance of Mozart's "Stadler" Quintet for Clarinet and Strings.  Harold Wright is the excellent clarinetist, and Alexander Schneider (Budapest Quartet), Isidore Cohen (Beaux Arts Trio), Samuel Rhodes (Juilliard Quartet), and Leslie Parnas are the string players.  Schneider plays beautifully and eloquently too, in those passages where the first violin is given its head.  Again, the sound is well-balanced, and together with the Trout, it all adds up to 70 minutes of very pleasant listening.

In all my recent listening to Schumann symphonies -- Harnoncourt, Szell, Zinman, Klemperer, Haitink, Kubelik -- I forgot that I owned this disc and that when it was released in 1988, it was very highly thought of.  And rightly so, it turns out!  It was recorded in the Lucaskirche, Dresden in 1973 for EMI by a group of engineers and producers whose names meant nothing to me, and with a conductor whose work I didn't know.  There was a great orchestra, the Dresden Staatskapelle, to look forward to, but it turned out that these recordings were outstanding in every way. Sawallisch conducts with great fire and great refinement, the orchestra is outstanding, and the production team has come up with a sound that has an airy three-dimensional quality of a kind that I associate with the best digital recordings -- and this was a decade prior to the digital revolution.  Go figure, as they say!  When I talk of a 3-D quality, I mean that you can hear the parts of the varied orchestral groupings in sound that is clear, true, and well-balanced to create a sound picture that, if you like, gives much more information than, say, Kubelik's recordings or even Szell's -- and when the Rhenish here has an energy that is close to Szell's, it's clear that you have a really outstanding recording AND performance.  The strings get their due -- as they don't quite with Szell or Kubelik -- and the brass is thrilling, but the subtlety of the wind textures can also be appreciated to a degree that they can't in these other analogue recordings.The Third Symphony, the Rhenish, gets a tremendous performance here, but that's one I was fairly familiar with.  However, thanks to the recording quality, I was able to appreciate the eeriness of much of the writing in the Second Symphony -- a work that sounds like no other and that makes one realize what an original symphonist Schumann could be.  The textures are refined and varied, and thus arresting, but the thematic material often seems unpromising, with odd stops and starts in its forward movement, and then, amazingly, Schumann develops out of it powerful and exciting climaxes.  The overall feel of the piece is unsettled and unsettling, but out of that eventually is built something affirmative and even joyful.  But even at the end, with all the affirmation, it's hard to forget the  almost weird lyricism of the slow movement, some of which re-appears transformed in the fourth, in the build-up to the finale.  A great recording then -- up there with Szell, which is high praise in this music.

This is a beautiful-sounding account from the mid-1980s of some great music.  The sound has great warmth, and yet clarity that enables one to hear the individual instruments isn't sacrificed.  The Gabrieli Quartet had been together for 20 years prior to this recording, which must have been one of the last that featured its founding first violinist, Kenneth Sillito, and he plays here with fine feeling and lovely tone.  (He would move on to lead the ASMF Chamber Ensemble.)  The other players are excellent too.  I have a couple of reservations -- the Takacs Quartet, recording just a year later for Decca (and with ITS original first violin) plays the first movement repeats, and in music of this quality, I prefer to hear them.  The Takacs Decca sound is also excellent, and the playing has a bit more pace to it and a nice airy texture, without any compromise in weight.  In addition, the Takacs accounts of these Op. 51 Quartets comes in a Double Decca twofer release with the Third Quartet (Op. 67) and an excellent performance of the Op. 34 Piano Quintet, with then-young Andras Schiff.  All in all, it's a much better bargain.  However, this Gabrieli disc gives much pleasure, and if you can, as I did, pick it up for two or three dollars, you won't be disappointed.

I would very much second the judgment of Mr Giles in his excellent earlier review.  The recordings, 1960 for the Concerto and 1965 for the Fantasia, have come up well in remastered sound (my pressing is from 1988), and is perhaps a bit better than the CBS/Sony recording of the same vintage with Stern and Ormandy -- a lovely disc too, as is the rather better-sounding Accardo recording on Philips, with Colin Davis and the Concertgebouw Orchestra.  All of these recordings seem to me worth having, and I don't feel the need for more recent digital versions!  The Supraphon sound for Suk has the violin advantageously placed, as was typical of the time, but not overbearingly so, and Suk's tone has a tight focus and a wiry sweetness to it that is most attractive.  The orchestra, a little back in the picture, isn't just a homogeneous blur -- it has some body, and the woodwind and timpani can be heard when they count.  The Suk Fantasia was new to me, and while it has a loose, improvisatory quality to it, the lyrical passages are beautiful and affecting, and the more energetic moments are charming.  Dvorak's Concerto is a tighter construction, and finally a more interesting piece, but it has the same qualities of dance contrasted to a somber lyricism that makes this pairing apt and effective.  That Josef Suk, the violinist, is the composer Suk's grandson and Dvorak's great grandson gives a historical interest to this disc too -- one feels that the music must be in the blood, in some sense!  It's such a nice performance that it's easy to think so.

I have to agree with Mr Giles and Santa Fe Listener here -- although I award four stars for sentimental reasons.  I'm softer-hearted than SFL, and Kubelik's Schumann Third was one of the first classical discs I owned, back in the vinyl days.  And Kubelik's Schumann isn't bad at all -- but it's true that Karajan, Bernstein, and (especially) Szell bring a bit more pizzazz to the task.  On its own terms, though, this set is perfectly listenable.  I agree with Giles too that there isn't a whole lot of difference between Kubelik here in 1964 and his Bavarian set from fifteen years later.  In terms of sound, the 1979 BRSO set does more justice to the strings, which sound a bit whistly in the 1964 Berlin recording -- but the overall orchestral picture is a bit more immediate or present in this 1964 recording, at least as I hear it via my Bose headphones.  I would characterize the sound of both as "warm," and there isn't a lot of orchestral detail that comes through -- though the brass does get its due, and in the Third, for example, is quite thrilling.  Szell is still the best choice here, I think  -- his 1960 sound isn't perfect, but the performances pretty much are.  For all that, I have taken Kubelik off the shelves and listened with pleasure to both his Berlin and Bavarian sets.  And by the way, if you must have digital, I find Harnoncourt on Teldec preferable to Zinman on Arte Nova.

Harnoncourt can be irritating and overly interventionist -- though pretty rarely -- in some of his interpretations, but I have to say I really liked these.  In fact, they are the best digital recordings of Schumann I've heard.  I tested them head to head, as far as just sound is concerned, with Zinman (2003) and Giulini (1981), and this Teldec sound is clearly superior, via my pretty good Bose headphones.  Haitink's early digital recording is good, but still it's less airy than this.  Harnoncourt's orchestra is the Chamber Orchestra of Europe, and they don't sound too heavy or muddy.  It's about as transparent as I've heard Schumann recorded.  It also has a spring in it's step -- even more than Zinman and Giulini, the rhythms are strongly marked, though I don't hear the ponderousness that one reviewer complains of.  There's a kind of Landler-ish feel to these performances, which I like.  Perhaps my favorite in these symphonies remains Szell's Cleveland accounts from around 1960 -- in the Masterworks Heritage pressings, the sound has come up well, and the propulsiveness of the performances is infectious.  Still, this is, I think, a smaller band, and that's all to the good.  The recording of the Fourth is the original version -- I don't really know enough to judge it vis-a-vis Schumann's revision, but on its own terms,  it sounds very engaging.  These recordings were from live performances in Graz -- Teldec did a great job in making them so sonically appealing.

Cohen's seventh studio album, and again one marvels at his verbal resourcefulness and his careful deployment of musical means that nonetheless keep the challenging lyrics to the fore.  There is indeed a tinge of C&W to the arrangements, but the songs seem to deal with existential themes to an extent that goes well beyond typical C&W subject matter, even when it is gospel-inflected.  A concern with masculine authority, violence, and spirituality seems to underpin this album -- that's a very broad characterization, I know, but to get any more specific, one would have to get into the weeds of textual interpretation to an extent that wouldn't be appropriate in a review.  Suffice it to say that the affirmative songs, like the famous "Hallelujah," and "Dance Me to the End of Love" are never uncomplicatedly affirmative -- confusion and a consciousness of finitude (of life, of love) give them weight and contrarian texture, and the blending of the spiritual and the political -- in songs like "The Captain," Hunter's Lullaby," and "Night Comes On" -- is striking and effective.  I don't have a clear "favorite song" from this album, and there's nothing quite as engaging as "Alexandra Leaving" (from "Ten New Songs"), perhaps Cohen's most beautiful song, but they are all thought-provoking and satisfying musically in the moment.Note: I've found the Wikipedia pages on Cohen's albums very informative, usually giving more information than the program notes on the reissued CDs and usefully contextualizing the album in relation to what was going on creatively in Cohen's life at the time.

A terrific bargain here -- I was lucky enough to get it on a half-price sale (!), but even at list price, you can't go wrong.  Yo Yo Ma is never disappointing, although in some cases he isn't my first choice for some of the music here.  He has no technical limitations at all, but as an interpreter, I tend to find him too uniformly mellow -- but that's a problem only where some more deeply expressive music is concerned.  Thus, his Dvorak Concerto (here with Masur) doesn't impress me as much as Wallfisch's does, but there is other music in which his performances are as good as any.  Thus the discs here with Maazel -- The Saint-Saens/Lalo disc is superb, as is the Prokofiev/Tchaikovsky.  Indeed, his "Rococo"-Variations are as good as any I've heard.  The chamber discs are very appealing too -- the Brahms sonatas (with Emanuel Ax) are rock-solid, and the Schubert disc, including the Trout Quintet has a very attractive energy in the Quintet and some eloquent playing, with Ax, in the Arpeggione sonata.  Likewise, the "Belle Epoque" arrangements, with the excellent Kathryn Stott on piano, are winning -- a really lovely disc.Ma is famous for expanding his horizons beyond the category of "classical" music, but in this box he pushes the limits of the familiar classical, with accounts of the Schoenberg concerto (with Ozawa), concertos by New York composers (with Zinman), which includes an arrangement for cello of the Bartok Viola Concerto, and, also with Zinman, a recording of the not-too-often heard Barber and Britten Concertos.  I don't know any of that stuff well at all -- most of it just by name -- but I'm glad to have it all so cheap and in performances that are persuasive and good-sounding.  There are also two discs of Ma's solo Bach suites (not necessarily a first choice, but very well played) and, surprisingly, only one disc of Beethoven -- the Fourth Sonata and some shorter pieces, with Ax.  I don't know why Sony didn't expand the box a little to include all the Beethoven.  Again, these wouldn't necessarily be the most compelling accounts, but they are estimable and in good sound.  I recommend the box -- if you don't have much of this music or just want to add an excellent cellist to your collection, you won't go wrong.  I should just add that the remastered sound is very good to excellent.

I own three digital recordings of the Dvorak Cello Concerto, and this is the most satisfactory one.  The solo playing on the others is fine -- Weilerstein with Belohlavek, and Ma with Masur -- but the combination of Wallfisch, Mackerras, and Chandos's engineering carry the day.  Ma plays beautifully, but as often with him, in my judgment, the effect is mellow, and this is a piece of music of deep pathos, if not tragedy.  Masur and the NYPO sound good, but the movement is not particularly propulsive.  In Weilerstein's case, the engineering is the problem.  Her rich, warm sound is foregrounded in the aural picture (and very well caught by the recording), and her interactions with the winds and brass are also spotlit and, again, sound great, but the listener's attention is directed away from the forward movement of the music as a whole and leaves us savoring the details.  Wallfisch has a leaner, grainier tone than either Ma or Weilerstein, but that sounds right for the way he phrases here, and he is very well balanced with the orchestra, the LSO, which Mackerras pushes to very forward-moving and eloquently inflected phrasing.  His feel for dynamic adjustment -- the outburst in the soulful second movement is harrowing -- and tempo modification is impeccable, and he and Wallfisch seem to be in total accord about what this music is getting at.  It's a very moving account.There's an excellent and substantial filler too -- the Dohnanyi Konzertstuck, which I wasn't familiar with and am very glad to have in such a well-played and good-sounding performance.  There are other Dvorak Cello Concerto recordings that I like from the pre-digital era -- Rostropovich with Karajan is justly famous, and Lynn Harrell has a lovely account with Levine.  I'm particularly fond of Heinrich Schiff's account, with Colin Davis, but the sound on Wallfisch/Mackerras is even better, and the performance certainly isn't inferior.  Great music, great performances!

One of the great bargain CDs -- a compilation from two or three Decca/London sessions of the early 1980s that brings together Carlos Bonnell and Charles Dutoit and his Montreal Symphony in Rodrigo's "Concierto d'Aranjuez," in as fine a performance as any on record (and there are many very good ones, I hasten to add: Bream, Williams, Romero . . .). But that's not all -- Dutoit's "El Amor Brujo" is very fine, with plenty of energy in the loud fast stuff and real feeling, with an undertone of melancholy, even desperation, in the slower music. Huguette Tourangeau sings the songs with the right edge of rawness, and shows off the bottom of her voice to fine effect. The sound quality and balance are excellent. And to top it all off, there's "Nights in the Gardens of Spain," with de Larrocha and Fruhbeck de Burgos, this time with the London Symphony. Again, the sound, from 1983, is lovely and warm, though the energy and power are there as needed, and Fruhbeck's control of dynamics and transitional movement is exemplary. De Larrocha's pianism is very distinguished here -- the piano sound has warmth and the playing is tender or spirited, as the occasion requires. She can make the piano sound like castanets or a guitar at times -- it's really quite remarkable. This isn't world-shaking music, but for what it is, this is an indispensable disc.

I have to agree with the earlier reviewer: I would describe the sound as unrefined, although it has plenty of presence, but there's none of the airiness that one gets from, say, Telarc discs of the same vintage, i. e. 1980-90.  I was less bothered by this in the "Amor Brujo," where the slower sections are played with great feeling and where Sarah Walker, the distinguished British mezzo, shows her lower range and her temperament to fine effect.  The louder music is a bit too raw and in-your-face, however, and this is particularly damaging in "Nights in the Gardens of Spain."  The pianist, Margaret Fingerhut, is miked a bit too closely, so overall the charm and sense of mystery doesn't come across as effectively as it should.  A better bet are the performances on Decca/London from the early 1980s, with Dutoit capturing the magic and the energy of "El Amor Brujo," and Fruhbeck de Burgos conducting a wonderful "Nights in the Gardens," where Alicia de Larrocha gives a remarkable performance of the piano part, seeming to be imitate at times castanets and a guitar as well as being pianistic when it counts.  Her sound is warmer than Fingerhut's, and the balance is better.  Fruhbeck's grasp of the dynamics and phrasal adjustments brings it all to life.  As more than a bonus, there's also a great performance of Rodrigo's Concierto d'Aranjuez, with Carlos Bonnell, conducted by Dutoit.

Teldec gave Andrew Davis and the BBC Symphony Orchestra beautiful sound here (in 1990) -- it's particularly striking how well it catches the dynamic variety in the creepy, quiet music that makes up the final movement.  That's music that sounds like the wind passing over the waste land of post-World War 2 Europe, both desolate and beautiful.  Santa Fe Listener commented on how difficult it was to get a volume setting that did justice to the loud stuff and the very quiet stuff.  On my Bose headphones, I was able to hear it all, with nice presence.  The earlier movements are brutal, at times recalling Mahler or reminding one of Shostakovich, and Andrew Davis drives it all home effectively.  Nothing could be further from the Vaughan Williams of English folksong-inspired pastoral lyricism, and I would guess that there isn't likely with music like this to be much room for differences that matter in interpretive nuance.  Previn's and Haitink's accounts are both very good too (I haven't heard Boult's or Slatkin's).  There is a lovely Holstian moment or two of repose late in the first movement, but it seems to be there only to NOT be taken up or sustained in what follows in this bleak and compelling work.The Tallis Fantasia makes for one nice filler -- it's a piece that I like but feel that if I could hear it live in an appropriate acoustic I would like it better.  And "The Lark Ascending" rounds out the disc.  It's hard to believe that Tasmin Little has been before the public for 25 years now.  She has just recorded "The Lark" again for Chandos (with the Moeran concerto), and very nice it is.  This early performance seems equally fine to me, though it's not a piece I spend a lot of time thinking about.  The sound in the "Lark" and the Fantasia" is excellent too.  Fine disc.

I found this a better movie to think about after the fact than it was to see.  Clearly, it's very thoughtfully put together, and visually it is consistently striking, though the experience of seeing it made me think that the three genres that are being blended here perhaps don't hang together very well.  The genres are action thriller, futuristic cautionary tale, and fairy tale.  The first has been better done in the Bourne movies; in the second, "Blade Runner" stands out; and in third, maybe Cocteau's 1946 "La Belle et la Bete" is a good example.  But of course, these movies aren't exactly trying to put things together in the way "Hanna" is.  I don't much care for action thrillers, so that aspect of the story bored me -- but that's just me.  Many people like this genre, and the director of "Hanna," Joe Wright, has every right to make the movie he wants to make -- and I've found it worth reflecting on.In the back story, Erik Heller (Eric Bana) is an ex-CIA operative who had been engaged in a program to genetically alter infants so that they would grow up to be killing machines -- "perfect soldiers" is his phrase.  The program seems to have been shut down by an upper-level CIA administrator, Marissa Wiegler (Cate Blanchett) and the infants involved have been eliminated -- all except Hanna, whose mother is killed by Wiegler, who can't however, prevent Erik from escaping with Hanna (Saoirse Ronan).  He raises Hanna according to his program, and his goal is to have her kill Wiegler.  In fairy story terms, Wiegler comes across as a kind of wicked witch here, but Heller isn't benevolent -- he seems not to be Hanna's biological father.  I would call him a "mad scientist" figure.  He brings Hanna up in the woods of Finland, and while they are in a sense attached to one another, it's obviously a perverse relationship.  Hanna's skill in unarmed combat with Heller is what wins his approval.  So ironically, it's possible to see the wicked witch as being in the right here -- except that Wiegler's determination to stop Hanna and Heller seems to be driven less by principle ("genetic experiments on human subjects are ethically dubious") than by jealousy.  Hanna's dying mother's last words, addressed to Wiegler, are "You'll never have her."  It sounds like a jibe at Wiegler's childlessness and perhaps sterility, and I wondered if at some point in the past Heller and Wiegler hadn't been lovers as well as colleagues.  The idea of sterility seems to me to be the dominating trope of the movie -- all the settings, Finland in winter, the Moroccan desert in summer, the panopticon at the CIA black site, the glass and steel of Berlin, and the infantilizing Grimm-themed funhouse all say that Hanna has been denatured.  The geo-political aspects of these places hardly register; it's the visual presentation that carries the message.  All that means too that Hanna has no future.  The story comes to a satisfactory action thriller close -- but what then?  The closest Hanna has come to relatively normal human contact is when she travels for a while, after her escape from the panopticon, with a neo-hippie family and their two children.  These scenes afford some humor and some recognizable emotional connections -- but that's it.  It doesn't last.  The cautionary aspect of the story has to do, I think, with the exploitation of technology to manipulate human beings by other human beings driven by ambition, jealousy, hatred, power, or whatever.  The old "essential" human tendencies -- and fairy tales seem to me to be almost by definition essentialist -- in a technologically sophisticated age, given free play, threaten to dehumanize our interactions.  We (the audience) are made to feel the pathos of Hanna's situation in a way that Hanna can't and perhaps never will.

Since this particular issue of Klemperer's recordings, EMI/Warner has issued a remastered 4-disc box, which I noted in a March 2013 review.  I own separate discs of the symphonies in a 1989 remastering, and the box reviewed here includes remasterings from 1999.  At around $3.00 a disc (used) from my local indie store, I couldn't resist, so I'm going to replace my 1989 versions with this box -- which helps with my space/storage issues too!  These recordings, from the late 1950's, were superbly engineered and produced to begin with by Walter Legge.  They are still as compelling as any other accounts of the symphonies on the market.  The word sometimes applied to Klemperer's Brahms is "craggy" -- and I think that is partly because the sound, though present, clear, and well-balanced, isn't glamorous. Also, it's because Klemperer's rhythmic alertness doesn't let you want to linger as you listen -- he moves along with great cogency, and yet each symphony emerges with its own character, because Klemperer trusts the music and trusts his orchestra and his instincts. In some more recent digital versions, you'll hear more of the inner voices of the piece, and that's very nice, but the heartbeat has to be there, and Klemperer gets you to it.  The First Symphony is gloriously rendered, and the Second and Third are great too. For me, the Fourth is the touchstone: this is the Fourth by which I measure the others I hear, and it's simply amazing that it was recorded in 1956 and 1957. The sound shows its age a bit -- the strings a little whistle-y -- but the whole thing is perfectly balanced, and the sound is airy and present. I'm reminded of Maag's great Mendelssohn Third (on Decca) from the same year. So credit Walter Legge and Douglas Larter, his sound man, for getting the sound right. But even more credit to Klemperer, whose pacing of the symphony makes it more engaging and even exciting than any other I've heard so far. Although often criticized for taking things too slowly, Klemperer here is faster than other conductors, and in the first movement that gives it a sense of both momentum and coherence: the transitions seem just right, because Klemperer convinces you that he knows where he's going. If I'm not mistaken, he picks up the pace just a bit at the end of the movement, and he drives it home excitingly. The two inner movements have an almost Mendelssohnian flavor to them -- the little dance-figure with a kick in the scherzo, and the phrasing of the first theme in the slow movement. The slow movement has two gorgeous melodies that are related to each other, and Klemperer realizes that he doesn't have to convince his hearer that they're beautiful -- so he trusts them and doesn't linger, and the effect is enlivening. The final movement is, like the first, taken at a good pace, and the variations seem to grow out of one another very naturally. There are times when we're reminded of the third movement in some of the brass figures, and the "slow" variations are grippingly done, before Klemperer moves confidently to the end. This is a Fourth to cherish in a set to cherish.

A tightly-constructed, atmospherically-shot, and very well paced independent film, "Frozen River" reveals the full extent of the talent of an actress I had previously seen in small parts: Melissa Leo. She plays Ray Eddy, a woman living in a small mobile-home in upstate New York, near the Canadian border and near an Indian Reservation that spans the border and that therefore has become a place from which people can be smuggled into the United States.  Ray gets into smuggling because she's desperate -- the money she had been saving to make a downpayment on a double-wide has been taken by her husband, a gambling addict, and one of the first shots in the movie shows us a close-up of Ray, weeping in her car outside her home, with the empty glove-compartment testifying to her husband's theft of the money.  It's just before Christmas, and  she has to go in and tell her five-year-old son that they won't be moving to a new home after all.  She finds her husband's car, which has been appropriated by a Native American woman, Lila Littlewolf (Misty Upham), who has troubles of her own -- she has been widowed as a result of her husband's having taken her place on a smuggling run late in her pregnancy, and her child has been taken by her mother-in-law.  She wants the child back, and she's trying to use smuggling to raise the money to be able to take and keep him.  It's Lila who tells Ray that she saw her husband abandon the car -- leaving the keys -- and get on a bus.  Ray assumes he headed for Atlantic City.The story tells how the women start to work together as smugglers to make what they need.  There's nothing glamorous about the operation: it involves driving over the frozen St. Lawrence River, and the Highway Patrol is on the watch when their car gets off the reservation (where the HP has no jurisdiction).  Meanwhile, Ray is dealing with her elder son, T. J., who is 15 and is willing to drop out of school and get a job to help out.  His mother resists this plan, and the dynamic between the deserted woman and the abandoned boy is beautifully and plausibly played by Leo and Charlie McDermott.  There comes a point -- avoiding details to avoid spoilers -- where one last run (so both women hope) has to be made to garner the money they need, and it doesn't go well.  Again, the circumstances are plausibly handled, and the suspense that is built up is achieved without resort to melodrama or special effects.  Near the end, Ray has to make a choice -- or, rather, she makes a choice that she doesn't have to make, and the way that she makes it is beautifully consonant with the way that we have seen the relationship between the women developing.  The ending is touching, without being implausibly optimistic.Misty Upham, who died tragically about six years after the film was made, is memorable as Lila.  The focus of sympathy and emotional interest has to be evenly balanced if the film is going to work.  These are two strong women -- not a plucky white woman taking care of a hapless Native American.  There is in fact something like a power-struggle early in their dealings with one another, but then the relationship settles.  Each comes to understand the family dynamic of the other, so this is a movie about "family values," if you can detach from that term all the sentimental accretions it has undergone in the last 30 years.  Doing the wrong thing to do the right thing is an old story in movies, but it's very effectively employed here.

It's hard to dislike such an obviously well-meaning movie, with its attractive cast, nice camera work, and sensible message, but there's something maybe too low-key about it for it to be totally compelling dramatically.  That might be because it seems not sure whether the drama or the message should come to the fore.  The message is two-part: first, it's that international multi-billion dollar corporations are ruthless in protecting their bottom lines; second is the point that in some cases, the people that they seek to make deals with are in impossible situations and often the promised deal is the best they can hope to get. That latter message is what Steve Butler (Matt Damon), representing Global Energy, is telling the small farmers of McKinley, PA who can't make good livings from their land and are being offered large sums and other incentives to lease their land for hydraulic fracturing, "fracking," for natural gas. He believes it -- his pitch is that when his family's Iowa town went under when Caterpillar left, he saw the impossibility of making small farming work.  He can't guarantee that fracking won't have some adverse environmental consequences, but these aren't inevitable, he argues, and besides -- where else would you get money to enable you to live a decent life and give the kids a decent education?Steve and his sales partner Sue (Frances McDormand) are making progress, but two complications arise: a crusty local schoolteacher, Frank Yates (Hal Holbrook), reveals a good deal of expertise about the physics and hydraulics of fracking -- and he has enough standing in the town to be able to persuade the local board to allow a town-wide vote on whether or not to allow fracking in McKinley. Yates acknowledges Steve's point about the economics of the local situation, but he worries about possible unforeseen impacts as well as the tendency among anxious townspeople to reduce all problems to economics.  The other complication is the arrival of an environmental activist, Dustin Noble (John Krasinski), who makes a strong pitch against Steve, with posters of dead cows and the message "Stop Global" -- and who also seems to attract some interest from Alice (Rosemarie DeWitt), a schoolteacher whom Steve is attracted to.  The drama, such as it is, resides in the conflict between Steve and Dustin for the soul of the town and the love, perhaps, of Alice -- but that dimension of the story is all very low-key, and the thematic issues tend to dominate.  The relation between Steve and Sue, including their different attitudes to their job, is interesting too, and I can't quite decide whether the dynamic between them suffers from being under-written or whether enough is given to let us see the relationship as more complicated than we had at first thought.There's a twist at the end -- nothing I've said so far constitutes a spoiler -- that changes our perceptions about a number of things, so the movie is worth sticking with.  The predicaments of the farmers are real enough, and the movie isn't too long, and it has a nice screenplay by Damon and Krasinski.  Gus Van Sant directs without calling attention to himself.  You won't find here the goofy and at times anarchic humor of "Local Hero," a great movie on a similar situation, but on the other hand, you won't find the broad drama and button-holing moralizing of "Erin Brokovich," enjoyable too in its way.  "Promised Land" might be low-key, but there's something attractively unassuming about it too.

Let me get an unkind thought out of the way: would Natalie Wood's teeth really be as white and regular as they are in this movie if she had been living out in the wild for years with the Comanches?  Ah well . . . luckily, the movie prompts us to more substantive reflection too, and Wood's character, Debbie, is not so much a character (for no acting is required of her here) as an icon, the object of the search, and it's what motivates the searchers Ethan Edwards (John Wayne) and Martin Pawley (Jeffrey Hunter) that comes to matter as much as the rigors of the search itself.  The setting, ostensibly West Texas, but actually filmed largely around Monument Valley in Utah, as so many of John Ford's movies were, is 1868, and Ethan Edwards has been gone from home for eight years.  What has he been doing since the end of the Civil War (in which he fought on the Confederate side)?  He seems to have been a mercenary in Mexico, and it's hinted that he might even have some criminal activity in his past, but his old friend Samuel Johnson Clayton (Ward Bond) doesn't push it.  What becomes clear early is that his long absence might have to do with his affections for his brother's wife, which is made clear in an understated way, and that he has returned a racist, as we would now say.  Perhaps he always has been, but now the idea of miscegenation between Indian (Comanches in this part of the world) and white folks deeply disturbs him, and when his niece, Debby, is taken after an Indian attack that leaves his brother and family dead, the search for her becomes a search to purify her by killing her --- for Ethan assumes, correctly as it turns out, that Debbie has grown up to become a wife of the raiding Comanche chief, Scar.  John Wayne gives a performance here that matches at least his great performance as another kind of obsessive in "Red River."  We tended to think, late in Wayne's life, that he simply played versions of himself, but that does him an injustice.  Parts were written for him of a certain kind, and he played them as a professional actor should, but he was capable of doing more than he was often given to do, and a movie like this shows it.Fortunately for Debbie, Ethan is accompanied by Martin, whom Ethan tends to look down on both for his youth and for the fact that Martin -- in effect an adoptive brother to Debbie -- is himself eighth-Indian.  And when the final confrontations come, Martin rises to the occasion . . . and, eventually, Ethan does too, but when he gets Debbie back to the settlement where she grew up, he seems himself to feel that it is no place for him.  The final shot is iconic, and by that time we realize that what Ford and Wayne have given us not just a stereotypical portrait of a "loner" but a nuanced account of a man who might realize that his attitudes can't survive in the nascent "civilization" that West Texas represents here -- it's a place that has a place for a person of mixed blood, like Martin, and it's a place where crazy folks like Mose Harper (Hank Worden) and "foreigners" like the Scandinavian settlers the Jorgensons, have a place too.  It's to the credit of Ford and his screenwriter Frank Nugent that they allow most of our grasp of the dynamics of the settlement to be conveyed more by image and gesture than by explicit dialogue and explanation -- which would be a problem for plausibility, given that we don't seem to be among very articulate people here.The movie was made in 1955, and it seems reasonable to assume that Ford is touching on the fears of many Southern whites especially at a time when the Civil Rights movement was taking off.  Brown v. Board of Education had been decided the previous year, and Dr. King was in Montgomery around the time of the filming.  Things were stirring, and Ford seems willing to keep them stirred.  The odd sub-plot of Martin's comic courtship of the Jorgensons' daughter Laurie (Vera Miles, not totally convincing) interwoven with the uncomfortable comedy, if comedy it is, of Martin's acquiring an Indian wife, whom he calls "Look," in the course of the search is important.  Ethan finds it humorous -- so when the Indian maiden is the ostensible sexual object, he clearly has no qualms.  Laurie, on hearing about it in the labored single letter she gets from Martin, is obviously disturbed and becomes open to being courted by Charlie McCorry (Ken Curtis), a musician and a largely comic and non-sexual figure.  Martin and Ethan get back on Laurie's wedding day -- and the ending of that strand of the plot devolves into "Seven Brides for Seven Brothers"-type comedy, but given what has gone before, we can't just sit back and enjoy it -- especially with Ethan and Debby in the picture.  The bottom line for me is that the movie still has the power to disturb, though whether in 2015 we're disturbed in the way that the audiences were sixty years ago seems questionable.  But where issues of race, justice, and empathy are concerned, any disturbance that prompts reflection is salutary.  So see this if you haven't already.

This is a movie of small pleasures.  Released in 1985, and set in the late 1970s, it resists the temptation to be politically rhetorical and keeps the focus on characters who seem too dim (in one case) and immature (in the other) to be doing what they're doing.  The opening credits set the scene: a montage of newsreel footage, all of which, with its focus on wars, scandals, and assassinations, reminds us of the reasons to be disaffected about politics by the late 1970s.  In the very comfortable middle-class setting of the story, Chris Boyce (Timothy Hutton) seems to like spending time with is falcon more than he does thinking about his future, and he clearly is uneasy with his father's pulling strings to get him a start with a contractor that processes intelligence for the government.  But he lacks the force of personality to stand up to his father, who works for the FBI, and goes along, while clearly resenting his father's power over him.  The contractor's office is sloppily run, and Chris discovers just how much the US government is committed to interfering in the politics of other countries, like Australia.  This gives Chris the reason he needs to stick it to the government, and by association his father, and think about selling information to the Russians.His means of doing so is Daulton Lee (Sean Penn), his aimless, air-headed, drug-dealing best friend, who once was an altar boy with Chris and who, on hearing of Chris's disaffection with the government, offers to be the man who delivers the intelligence on Chris's behalf.  He frequently travels to Mexico, and it's his idea just to walk into the Soviet Embassy and do what has to be done.
