There's a mixture of comedy and pathos in this, for Daulton has no idea how seriously the Soviets or the Americans take spying, and his contact Alex (David Suchet, in an understated, essentially comic performance) is by turns amused, irritated, frustrated, and empathetic with this strange creature who claims to have important information about US spying, satellites, etc.  Daulton talks a good game at the embassy, but he really has no idea what he's talking about or what exactly he is or isn't getting from Chris to deliver.  Sean Penn's breakout performance a couple of years earlier was as the stoner Spicoli, in "Fast Times at Ridgemont High," and there's just enough Spicoli in his characterization of Daulton to make him both richly amusing and (because we're in different circumstances from Ridgemont High) finally pathetic.  Like Chris, he's at odds with his family -- but they have no idea what to do about his sloppiness and drug-dealing, which is all they know about.  Richard Dysart effectively portrays Daulton's ineffective Dad.Penn and Hutton must have been only 24 when they made this movie with the director John Schlesinger, best known to me as the director of "Midnight Cowboy."  Their performances as not-fully-grown-up young men are very good.  If Schlesinger is hinting at a connection between anti-government activism and immaturity -- a sense that the idea of it attracts a certain kind of immature temperament from young men of a class that perhaps encourages them to overconfidently overvalue their abilities -- he doesn't rub our noses in it.  He just lets the story make its points, and the writing in Steven Zaillian's screenplay is good enough to enable the actors to round out their characters.  I won't give away plot details but just say that it isn't a comedy, for all its comic moments, but "tragi-comedy" doesn't seem quite right either.

Five stars is supposed to say, "I love it!" but that doesn't seem an appropriate response to a movie about such harrowing events and circumstances.  It's hard to shake the notion nowadays -- especially in the age of Pixar and bromances -- of movies as anything but entertainment, but you have to do that as best you can with a film like this.  Poldek Socha (Robert Wi'ckiewicz) is no Oskar Schindler, with his wealth and social connections to the Nazis.  Socha is a sewer inspector in Lvov, who discovers a group of Jews -- and extended family, in effect -- during an inspection.  They have created an entrance to the sewers from their house, and escape into them just as a round-up is beginning in the ghetto.  Basically, he allows himself to be bribed by them, but when they run out of money, he doesn't cease to help them.  There are risks for him, of course, for the Polish authorities are cooperating with the Nazis and suspect that the sewers are being used.  Luckily, they don't suspect Socha -- at least not until it's too late.  Visually, the movie does a superb job of creating a sense of the dank filth and claustrophobia of the sewers.  There are Hollywood-ish moments -- the big rainstorm that pulls Socha away from his daughter's first communion because he realizes the threat it poses to the Jews is perhaps the most obvious one, and very suspenseful it is.  The cost to Socha is suggested powerfully, especially in the wake of his killing of a German soldier, but most engagingly in the representation of the relationship between Socha and his wife, Wanda (Kinga Preis), who instinctively feels for the Jewish victims of the Nazi occupation but is frightened and worried by her husband's growing commitment to them.  After the rainstorm, Wanda, angry at Socha's leaving the communion service, walks out -- the house is empty when Socha returns, tired and stressed.  The scene between them when she walks in is wonderfully and credibly played, testimony to the way the characters have been represented throughout.Underground, the early bickering and tensions related to status among the Jews soon gives way to a serious focus on survival.  There's a love interest that develops, there are children who get lost, and a baby is born. And if rats in the slimy dark freak you out, prepare to be freaked.  As plot elements, some of these might strike the viewer as standard narrative shaping that is perhaps more a matter of convention rather than truth, but visually none of it is glamorized, and such scenes create focuses of empathy that perhaps a more documentary treatment could not manage.  The alternations of stoic endurance, near-hysteria, depression, sexual frustration -- it's all there.  And in Socha and Wanda, we have characters who just do the right things without theorizing about it -- they just keep on doing, for when they stop to reflect, they tend to tell themselves they're crazy, so they stop reflecting.  On the Jews' side, there is a developing of trust with Socha that takes time, and there are interpersonal tensions among themselves that aren't sentimentally resolved in every case.  All in all, I found it moving, absorbing, and very well put together by Agnieska Holland.  The filming in the sewers, which seeks to do justice to the literal darkness while still letting us see enough, is very well managed.  Jolanta Dylewska was the cinematographer and deserves great credit for her work.

The earliest Western I remember seeing, when I was about 12 -- and the scene with James Stewart getting his hand shot has stayed with me for the past 58 years.  I saw this again right after seeing the original "3:10 to Yuma," and it's a very different kind of movie.  There's a whole different kind of suspense (that is shared with "whodunits"), and there is too in effect a double-plot: the main one is the effort by Will Lockhart (James Stewart), the "man" of the title, to find out who was responsible for his brother's death in the massacre of a troop of cavalry in New Mexico; the other plot is the story of Alec Waggoman and his family as they seek to extend their cattle ranch to take in more land and put smaller farmers out of business.  Alec (Donald Crisp) depends on his foreman Vic Hansbro (Arthur Kennedy) to keep his out-of-control and violent son Dave (Alex Nicol) out of too much trouble and to try to educate him in the qualities needed to run the ranch.  Vic has the qualities Alec would like to see in his son, and he has made vague promises that when he dies, Vic will inherit at least part of the ranch.  At other times, he seems to wobble on this promise (if promise it was), so the situation is fraught for both Dave and Vic.  It's into this family dynamic that Lockhart comes, and he's almost immediately attracted to Barbara Waggoman, Alec's niece (Cathy O'Donnell), who runs a store in the town of Coronado.  Barbara is sort of engaged to Vic, which is a complication, and Lockhart is also befriended by Kate Canaday (Aline MacMahon). a small rancher who was jilted by Alec decades earlier.  Lockhart is very soon made aware that he's not welcome in Coronado, with some of the pressure coming from Dave, but it isn't clear immediately whether Dave is acting only on his own behalf.  Be that as it may, even the sheriff seems to do pretty much what Alec wants -- money is power in Coronado.  Lockhart soon comes to see that somebody is selling guns to the local Apaches -- another mystery he has to solve . . .I'll avoid plot details in the interest of avoiding spoilers, so let me just say that the problem with the movie lies in some casting choices.  James Stewart is very good as a man whose obsession for revenge is kept under wraps most of the time, though when it breaks out, it's scary.  Arthur Kennedy is fine as Vic, though it's an oddly conceived part, I think.  But Crisp and Nicol -- and especially the former -- seem in a different movie altogether.  Dave is a bit of a stereotype, and Nicol brings some intense moments to him, but he's not all that interesting.  Donald Crisp should seem formidable on some level as Alec, but it's a flat performance.  MacMahon brings some pizzazz to the older woman, Kate, but Cathy O'Donnell just isn't a credible object of desire as Barbara, even though she plays the role of an apparently independent, resourceful woman -- she doesn't convince, though.For all these limitations, there's plenty to enjoy.  Good pacing, nice attention to the arroyos and plains of New Mexico, and a double-plot that is well-integrated, despite the casting limitations.  I enjoyed seeing it again.

I was 13 when this movie came out.  I saw "Shane," "High Noon," and "The Man from Laramie" (and a bunch of less-distinguished but enjoyable Westerns), but I missed this one, and I'm glad to have seen it now, in the excellent print by Criterion, with interesting "special feature" interviews with Elmore Leonard (on whose early story the movie is based) and Glenn Ford's son, who was about 12 when Glenn was working on the film.  Leonard, interviewed in 2013, not long before he died, looks frail but is full of pep and information.  It's a charming and useful addition.  Ford's son is more gossipy, but there's an enjoyment of his dad in his remarks that doesn't preclude his seeing Ford's weaknesses as a husband and father very clearly.  The essay included in the booklet, by Kent Jones, maybe states the case for Delmer Daves's immortality a bit too much . . . but it also has good, contextualizing information.The movie, beautifully shot (by Charles Lawton, Jr) and very effectively paced by Delmer Daves, is now considered a "classic" of the genre, and I'm going to say nothing of the plot, just in case there are a few younger fans of the genre who might not have seen it yet.  It has a more psychological focus than Zinnemann's "High Noon" (where the focus is ethical), and it also is less claustrophobically zeroed in on place than Zinnemann's movie (and that isn't a criticism of Zinnemann).  Rather, it connects the psychological pressure on Dan Evans (Van Heflin) to the economics of his situation as a small rancher in drought-stricken Arizona and to his pained consciousness of perhaps failing as a husband and a father in part because of the economic pressures on him.  Heflin, who was wonderful in "Shane," where his masculinity was also in question, is superb here with a character more richly connected to his inner life.  If the pressures on Dan are quite transparent -- and they are transparent too to Ben Wade (Glenn Ford), the outlaw whom Dan has undertaken (for $200.00) to get safely on to the 3:10 train to Yuma and to prison -- Wade himself is less transparent.  He seems a mysterious mixture of impulses, and Glenn Ford gives a winning performance of this complicated man.  Apparently, Ford was initially offered the Evans character but turned it down, seeing something in Wade that he wanted to have a go at -- a good choice on his part!  Felicia Farr, Henry Jones , and Robert Emhardt are very good in supporting roles, while the members of Wade's gang are less sharply individualized -- which makes Wade's charisma all the more compelling.  The movie runs at 90 minutes, with plenty of time given to crisply written scenes in a variety of locations (the range, the hotel in town, Evans's farm, the train station), and the combination of adequately dramatized lead-up and the growing suspense of the two hours before 3:10 are really very efficiently and concisely handled.  It's a must-see.

Why is it that I'm happy to own multiple recordings of Beethoven's, Brahms', and Mozart's major works but that I don't feel the need to have as much Haydn? As I cull my CD collection to make room for new purchases, I'm finding that I can readily give up the recordings of Haydn's twelve "London" symphonies by Jochum and Szell and be content to keep Colin Davis's two Philips Duo sets. There's nothing wrong with the performances by Jochum (DGG) and Szell (CBS/Sony), but I don't find their differences from Davis's -- which seem to me minor -- makes up for the superiority in sound on the Philips discs. Davis brings plenty of energy to his accounts, but the sound is warmer and overall more transparent in what it enables us to hear of solo instruments and the different sections of the orchestra. These recordings are from the late 1970s-early 1980's, with the later ones being digital. The analogue recordings are fine, though. Jochum's accounts are 8-10 years earlier, and their sound can be a bit bright or glaring in the loud, high writing, while Szell's 1960's recordings are drier in sound and a bit more homogenous. I stress, though, that neither Jochum's nor Szell's sound is terrible, and I wouldn't be without Szell in Beethoven and Brahms or Jochum in Beethoven and Bruckner. It's just that I feel that I don't need all that Haydn.I like historically-informed performances, and I own the Veritas set of the six Paris symphonies of Haydn, with the Orchestra of the Age of the Enlightenment, in nice digital sound, conducted by Kuijken. Haydn's fertility of invention never ceases to delight me, but somehow I don't feel the need of a lot of different points of view on it.

4 1/2 stars -- I haven't heard all the recordings of the Brahms Second Piano Concerto (Pollini's most recent, or Hamelin's, for example), but of the many I've heard, this is certainly the best sounding.  In the 1990's, Haitink was making some excellent recordings in Boston, mostly for Philips, and this is another beauty.  The orchestral sound is tonally lovely, well-balanced, and transparent, and, as always, Haitink's grasp of an evolving musical narrative is compelling.  The piano is beautifully balanced with the orchestra too, and I have never heard Ax sound better.  His playing too is distinguished for its coherence and variety in phrasing and dynamics.  The final two movements are as good as any on record, with the playfulness of the final movement especially noteworthy.  The lovely slow movement is taken at a nice moderate pace -- faster than Katsaris and Kovacevich -- but never sounding rushed and always poised and eloquent.  The gentle lead-in to the return of the cello late in the movement has just the right hushed expectancy to it.  If I have one reservation, it's that the expressive contrasts and sense of drama could be a bit more heightened in the first two movements.  Fleisher and Serkin (both with Szell) are gripping in these movements, and so is Arrau, with both Guilini (1960) and Haitink (1969), with the later account being very well recorded for its time, though the piano is more to the fore than I would ideally like.  For all that, Ax has an idea about these movements that he executes beautifully, and I can see some listeners preferring his account to the more stormy or troubled ones.  This one's a keeper for me.The filler is a transcription for cello and piano of a violin sonata.  It's beautifully played by Ax and Yo-Yo Ma, though I'll confess to preferring the original combination of instruments (in the excellent Suk/Katchen version, for example).  But it makes this a well filled as well as a well-played CD.

3 1/2 stars --  It isn't easy to keep a mystery/cop series going when you're trying to deepen your readers' understanding of the characters (as opposed to just constructing different plots  a la Lee Child and not worrying too much about the characters' lives going forward in time).  If Ace Atkins succeeds (so far), it's at least in part because of the voices -- Quinn Colson, the sheriff, himself, and his second-in-command Lillie Virgil, as outspoken and profane as they come.  There's a double-plot going here -- one of them is a cold case, from 36 years earlier, involving a rape and murder, and the other a story of Quinn's efforts to deal with the crooked County Commissioner Stagg, who wants Quinn either in his pocket or out of a job.  A recent tornado in the town of Jericho, Mississippi, has enabled Stagg to present himself as the savior of the town, as he manipulates contracts for rebuilding and infrastructure from his office in the Booby Tap strip club.  But Stagg has reason to fear: a man who was jailed twenty years earlier is close to release, and Stagg knows that this man, the biker leader Chains LeDoux, will be coming for him.  Going for double insurance, Stagg hires a bodyguard/enforcer type, the ex-military man Ringold, to watch his back, and he prods Colson to solve the long-ago cold case, which involved LeDoux and his biker gang and perhaps thus put LeDoux out of harm's way again.  In return, Stagg makes it clear that he has the power to get the DA to drop a trumped-up charge against Quinn and Lillie -- a charge that Stagg trumped up in order to give him leverage over Quinn.  And that's just the background . . . .Along with all this, we have Quinn worrying about his ex-addict sister Caddy and her son, his girlfriend Ophelia Bundren (the local embalmer), his mother Jean and his absent father (who were in Jericho as young lovers at the time of the rape-murder that Quinn is trying to solve), and Diane Tull, raped and left for dead 36 years earlier, but now back in town and running a farm supply store.  Nobody wants the past dug up, except Diane, Quinn and Lillie (for a good reason) and Stagg (for a self-serving one).The complicated past-present structure is well-handled, the center of consciousness for the past scenes being Diane and Quinn's dad.  Their points of view have short italicized chapters.  The "present" chapters (by far the greater part of the book) has us moving among Quinn's, Stagg's, Diane's, LeDoux's and Lillie's viewpoints.  The issues are Quinn's integrity and the question of whether anyone will be forthcoming with information that will help with the cold case.  It's all worked out quite well, though Stagg's getting involved in the cold case seems a bit implausible, and then at the end, in a climactic scene, we begin to see that things aren't quite what they seemed.  Individual readers will have to judge for themselves whether or not they think Atkins plays fair with them.  I was reminded a bit of reservations I had about the last of Peter May's "Lewis" trilogy -- the longer it went on, the more complicated the treatment of the past in relation to the present became.  This novel doesn't strain credibility quite to the same extent, but there are times when the plotting seems more clever than convincing.  Lots to like though -- Quinn and Lillie are a lively pair, and Jean and Ophelia aren't far behind.  I don't think it's spoiling things to say that Stagg is alive if not quite kicking at the end -- so the saga will continue.

The movies here deserve separate review, which I will give them in due course, but I do want to give a general recommendation to this boxed collection from the late 1950's and very early 1960's in Britain.  These are four tales of suspense, with one of them -- "The League of Gentlemen" -- being comic, though far from saccharine, and the others touching on attitudes to race and homosexuality at a time when the latter was still criminalized and when the beginnings of recovery from World War 2 marked a return to prosperity that made Britain an attractive place for immigrants who were at that time mainly people of color from the Caribbean and South Asia.  Although not devoid of stereotyping, the movies make an effort to treat the attitudes and characters with an appropriate degree of complexity and understanding.  The narratives in all four movies are all very efficiently told, the prints are very good, and the only complaint that one might have is that the amount of documentation and special feature supplementary material (including subtitles) is lacking, compared to the usual Criterion issues.  However, you'll note that the price is extremely reasonable, and all in all, this is a fine bargain.  The gem of the collection, for me, is Dirk Bogarde's performance in "The Victim" -- a movie that took some courage to make and act in in 1960 and that, while it might seem a bit tame today, was thought dangerous enough in its time not to be approved for American release.  Close behind, and in a different tone altogether, is Jack Hawkins in "The League of Gentlemen," the opening shot of which is almost worth the price of the box and which anticipated some similar moments in the early James Bond movies.  The movies deserve to be seen, then, both for their own sakes and for what they show of the culture of their times.  An excellent bargain.

Somewhere inside this amiable bloated monster is a straightforward story that would fit neatly into a 50-minute TV episode.  It would look a bit like a brief "Wrath of Khan," but it would be fine.  Unlike the original "Khan," where Kirk and Kahn are the antagonists, here it's primarily Spock (Zachary Quinto) versus Nero (Eric Bana, tattooed), the crazed Romulan commander of a space ship that resembles a giant bug -- very far from the classic lines of a Federation starship.  Bana doesn't quite have the panache that Ricardo Montalban brought to Khan, but Quinto is a credible younger Spock.  Chris Pine, for his sins, is forced to play Kirk as a kind of frat-boy smart-ass, and it's difficult to believe that he would grow into the wry and witty Kirk of William Shatner -- but that how he's written, and so I don't blame Pine, who was good in "Unstoppable."  The cause of the bloat here is the attention paid to the young lives of Spock and Kirk, and their meeting and initial mutual dislike at Starfleet Academy.  I'm afraid that I couldn't get too interested in that -- it seemed to smack of a fairly predictable plot-formula in which two temperamentally different soldiers learn to respect and trust one another, and not all the paraphernalia about Starfleet rules and the Kobayashi Maru simulation could do much to spice it up.  I also found the young Kirk's apparent interest in young female cadets a bit tiresome -- the jock-frat boy stereotype again.I have to say too that the plot device used to get Leonard Nimoy into the picture seemed very forced to me -- was it dumb luck that he happened to be on that icy planet when Kirk crashed there?  And how convenient that Scottie (Simon Pegg) was there too, to help effect transportation back to the Enterprise.  And how come that almost immediately Scottie is put in charge of the dilithium energy system for the ship?  Is it just so that he can say lines that are familiar from earlier shows -- "Im not sure she can take any more, Captain!" -- which chimes nicely with "Live long and prosper," which is also trotted out a couple of times.  No -- it's all a bit too forced for me.  I liked "The Wrath of Khan," and I liked "The Voyage Home," the one with the whales, best of all.  This 2009 revival is all pace and no wit.  There was the revelation that Uhura had the hots for Spock, though.  I did not know that.

It bothers me that I gave "The Counselor" only two stars and give three to "A Walk among the Tombstones" when it seems clear that the former is a much more thoughtful and multifaceted piece of work.  But I didn't like it, and this much more modest, predictable movie seems better of its rather ordinary kind than the hyper-intellectualised kind that "The Counselor" belongs to.  All that said, "A Walk" is not a great movie by any standards -- we have the familiar ex-cop-and-recovering-alcoholic-turned-PI, and the fact that Liam Neeson takes the part and lavishes his solid professionalism on it keeps us watching.  It seems that the wives and daughters of drug dealers are being singled out for kidnapping, mutilation, and murder, and Kenny Kristo, the husband of one of the victims (Dan Stevens, playing sullenly against type) hires Matt Scudder (Neeson) to find out the perpetrators, with an eye to taking his revenge on them.  The police are out of the question because Kenny is a drug trafficker (NOT a mere dealer, he wants Scudder to know).  Meanwhile Matt is attending AA meetings and coming to terms with the circumstances that caused him to leave the NYPD and also forming a relationship with TJ (the appealing Brian Bradley), a black homeless teenager who seems to hang out in libraries and has read a whole lot of crime fiction.  Suffice it to say here that he's instrumental in resolving the case and that his moment of triumph comes when Scudder introduces him to Kenny and others as "my associate."  The others include Kenny's brother Peter (Boyd Holbrook) who is fighting a gallant losing battle with his addiction, and Yuri Landau (Sebastian Roche), a drug-dealing acquaintance of Kenny's, whose young teenaged daughter is kidnapped late in the movie.  The stakes for the audience are now higher, because a child is in danger -- director and screenwriter Scott Frank is clearly pushing our buttons here.  The suspense throughout involves our awareness of the strategies and targets of the kidnappers, and their van always appears cued by ominous music.The tombstones of the title refer to a cemetery in which the body parts of one victim were scattered and which figure again late in the movie.  I'll avoid spoilers and just say that much, though not all of the procedural work that Scudder does is plausibly presented, though the part involving Jonas (Olafur Olafsson) I found not convincing -- and that's a weakness since it does point Scudder in the direction of the perps.  The tombstones might also be Scudder's now-dead past that he can't quite get away from.  The ending will strike viewers as meeting the requirements of rough justice, but the last narrative section seems clumsily handled to me.  On the plus side, we see Neeson here as credibly human and sympathetic and not the implausible superman of the exploitive "Taken" series.  Be thankful for that, and enjoy the moments of creepiness.

Credit where credit is due -- if you are going to act in a farce (I'm referring to the genre), then you must never, even at the silliest moments, seem to be tipping off your audience that you're aware that you're in a certain kind of play.  The humor depends on the actors seeming to be dead serious, even when, to the audience, the events on stage are at their silliest or most outrageous.  So the actors in "The Counselor" deserve a lot of credit.  They play it dead straight.  So, you might ask -- are you saying that this movie is, generically, a farce?  I am saying that, for if it isn't, it's a total mess.  But there's reason to think that Cormac McCarthy, who wrote the screenplay, and the director Ridley Scott knew exactly what they were doing.  Any screenplay for what looks like a "thriller" that alludes to the death of Socrates and Christopher Marlowe's "The Jew of Malta" (and probably some other things I've missed) obviously has something going on, and the nearest analogue I can find to the kind of drama this is is the hyper-sensationalized early 17th-Century morality plays that used to be referred to as "Jacobean Tragedy" and that were associated with names like Cyril Tourneur and John Webster.  Marlowe's "Jew of Malta" might be thought of as a kind of prototype of such drama, and elements of it can be found in Shakespeare's tragedies -- obviously in "Titus Andronicus," and maybe less obviously in "King Lear" and "Macbeth."  The 17 Century critic Thomas Rhymer referred to "Othello" as "a bloody farce," and that's not a bad description of "The Counselor" too, as long as we remember that heavy-handed moralism goes along with it.The mixture of power, greed, and sex, along with characters who think they can control events after having made some very sketchy decisions -- it's all there, just as it was in the Jacobean predecessors.  You might be tempted to think of it as a kind of "film noir," because there is in this film also a sense of its characters becoming more and more entrapped, the atmosphere becoming more claustrophobic.  But in a "noir," entrapment and claustrophobia are expressed through visual style.  Here the visual style is much more realist, and it's in the dialogue that the sense of entrapment and ever-more-limited choices comes across.  It does so because the characters talk all the time about choices and consequences.  Westray (Brad Pitt) advises the counselor (Michael Fassbender) not to get "in" to the drug deal that Reiner (Javier Bardem) is involved with.  Even Reiner is cautioning the counselor -- don't get in.  But the counselor (who, for reasons that aren't explicit, needs money) thinks he CAN get in, just this once, pick up his share of $20 million, and get out again.  It's not accidental that people lose their heads in this movie -- for when greed, power, and sex get to work, clear thinking goes out the window, so losing one's head seems an apt trope, all things considered.Once you're in, getting out is difficult, especially when, to bring off the deal, you have to run afoul of "the cartel."  Let's just say that the Borgias, as popularly imagined, have nothing on the cartel.  Of the characters who are willing to take their chances, only the coolest can have a chance at success.  In this case, that's Marika (Cameron Diaz), and it helps that she lacks a soul and is willing to do whatever it takes with her body.  At the end of the movie, she's still on the playing field, so to speak, though whether she will ultimately prevail is an open question.  Suffice it to say here that thieves have fallen out, and some of the mayhem in the movie derives from that fact and not just the cartel.  But what might strike you most about the movie -- and all the characters are unlikeable -- is the talk.  Everybody's a kind of pseudo-philosopher, and on and on they go about choices, consequences, freedom, guilt, weaknesses.  In case you don't get the point, think about the scene in which Cameron Diaz tries to get a priest to listen to her confession.  It's rare to find such hyper-articulateness yoked to a modern "thriller" plot, and it's one of the features that clues the audience to the kind of farce that this is.  I think that the movie is exactly what Scott and McCarthy had in mind, and clearly a bunch of very talented actors are all on board.  One could even say that it's very good of its kind -- but I don't much like the kind.  I haven't been tempted to re-read "The White Devil" or "The Revenger's Tragedy," and I doubt that I'll be revisiting this -- although there is that scene of Cameron Diaz having sex with an expensive car . . .

1980's Telarc sound was one of the wonders of the world, and here it is again, from 1984, in a performance that almost matches Janssons' great Chandos account.  Janssons is just a tad quicker, and there's a touch of rawness to the sound that is expressively apt, but Previn matches him in sound that is warmer and truer throughout a wide dynamic range and that has what I can only call a kind of three-dimensional quality to the aural picture.  Add to that the tonal distinctiveness of the sections of the orchestra that the recording manages to capture -- and the playing is beautiful throughout -- without diminishing the impression of a coherent orchestral sound.  It's quite miraculous, really.  And Previn is clearly totally engaged.  He builds the climaxes within the movements unerringly, with dynamic and phrasal variation beautifully judged, and he has enough in reserve to make sure that the climax of the final movement is the climax of the whole.  I would just add that the slow movement is as beautifully played and recorded here as I have ever heard it -- and all in all, it's just a very distinguished account of a great Romantic symphony.  The March from Rimsky-Korsakov's "Tsar Saltan" is a lively and delicate palate-cleanser to end the disc.  Don't miss this one.

This excellent recording of a live performance from 1983 has been re-issued in a pairing with the Double Concerto, and that issue is obviously better value for money. I picked this up used for $4.00, so I'm not complaining! It's gratifying to hear Bernstein and the Vienna Philharmonic in what seems to me much better form (AND more warmly recorded) than was the case with their disappointing (to me) Brahms First Symphony from around the same time. My only previous exposure to the Latvian violinist Gidon Kremer was in his set of the Beethoven sonatas with Argerich, that I thought were splendid. He's splendid again here. The first movement has an ideal blend of muscularity, playfulness, and grace, and unusually (and one good reason to own this recording) he uses a Reger Prelude, all four minutes worth, as the cadenza. He really digs into it, and it fits the spirit of his first-movement playing perfectly. (Oddly, the liner notes make no mention of this choice). The second movement, surely one of the loveliest there is, is done with great tenderness and chamber-like delicacy in places. It's ravishing, and the uncredited oboist who opens the movement plays very eloquently too. Kremer leaps into the last movement as if determined to establish the contrast with the previous one in the starkest terms. There's no messing around with refinement -- it's just invigorating gypsy fiddling, and Kremer and Bernstein have great fun in the coda. The orchestra sounds great -- the strings especially get their due, with warmth and presence, and there's no dawdling from Bernstein -- he's much faster than, say, Tennstedt in his fine recording with Kennedy. But you can't have too many Brahms Violin Concertos . . .

Great sound from the Philadelphia Orchestra here, with Sarah Chang, aged around 13 at the time, just a bit more forward in the aural picture -- and that's my main reservation.  It's just a bit too close-up.  That's no criticism of Ms Chang, who plays with great spirit and lovely tone, but I already had Accardo in the Paganini and Kyung-Wha Chung in the Saint-Saens items, and this isn't music that I feel the need to have multiple recordings of.  I can't get all that interested in the Paganini fireworks -- sorry! -- but I do like the Spanish-inflected Saint-Saens pieces, and if you don't have them, you would be very happy to have such a rich-sounding recording.  It's tempting to say, "Nice going for a 13-year-old," but no condescension or apologies are needed.  This is fine playing, well recorded.

The Criterion issue on 2 discs -- DVD in my case -- is excellent, with a fine print of the movie on Disc One and some very interesting "special features" on the second disc.  If you can, you might try to see it in relation to John Ford's "The Informer," also set in Ireland at a time (though a different one) of political trouble.  Reed's 1947 movie owes a good bit stylistically and thematically to Ford's 1935 one.  There are also debts to French and German movies of the 1930's that are addressed in the special features commentary.  The basic similarity is that in both movies, the protagonist, not long out of jail, takes action that causes a death, and one could argue that, different as the circumstances are, in both cases the protagonist causes the death to meet some basic needs of his own and not for any ideological or political reason.  The actions result in both men going on the run, so to speak, and trying to avoid capture, while at the same time being psychologically and maybe ethically disturbed by what they have done.  Stylistic similarities are the representation of the city, especially in nocturnal images, with lots of shadows, deep back-and-white contrast, and a sense of the city as a kind of warren or maze, almost a trap, from which the protagonist tries to escape.  Reed's film, to an even greater extent than Ford's, I think, makes the audience aware of its style -- every shot seems very deliberately framed, and engrossingly, I might add.  However, to the credit of Reed and his actors, the awareness of style doesn't get in the way of the reader's engagements with the characters and their plights.  Sometimes, it's desperation that draws us in; at others, it's an odd, almost absurd kind of humor.  The ostensible issue that the plot engages us in, again like "The Informer," is a simple one -- can the protagonist get out of the city and away from his pursuers?  But the plot, like that of any good film noir, is just the excuse on which to hang issues of psychological breakup and existential threat.It's odd, however, that the political dimension of the story is played down.  Johnny McQueen (James Mason) is the head of what in the movie is referred to merely as "The Organization," and nothing in the movie makes it certain that the organization isn't a criminal enterprise as opposed to a political one.  It has usually been taken to refer to the IRA, but there's nothing in the movie about Irish politics and history to warrant that identification.  I wondered if the "depoliticizing" of the story was a sop to the British censors -- but there's no way that the organization, whatever it is, is glorified or its violence endorsed.  In fact, Johnny, we learn right from the start, has begun while in prison to have doubts about violence -- it's ironic that he's strapping on his gun around the time that he reveals this to his girl, Kathleen (Kathleen Ryan).  But he doesn't come across as a tough guy -- he's reflective and even sentimental, and that's partly his undoing, and Kathleen's attraction to him has none of the dangerous allure of the bad boy for the tough girl.  Be all that as it may, the absence of politics throws all the interest on the existential aspects of the story and serves to suggest that Johnny's situation has a kind of universal human interest.  His conscience is focused on his having killed, with no attention given to the context of or possible reasons for the killing or the robbery that was the occasion of the killing.  The effect is to make Johnny's consciousness seem almost inhumanly "pure" -- or, if you're historically minded, implausibly limited.  For myself, that's where I have to suspend my disbelief where this movie is concerned.  Once you start thinking about the complex history that lies behind an event like the robbery in the context ( a divided Ireland, c. 1940), the film can lose its purchase on you and seem oversimple.  If you head down that road, all you're left with is style.  But partly as a response to style, I DON'T head down that road, and then my interest in what the style is there to express reawakens.The oddest feature of the movie is the part where Johnny finds himself in the studio of the artist Lukie (Robert Newton), who wants to paint him.  Lukie is such an extravagant character, and Newton (remember his Long John Silver?) is himself an extravagant actor, that he almost seems to belong to a different kind of movie.  Still, the idea of the artist as the medium required for penetrating the soul of man in extremis has thematic plausibility here, and it's in that scene that Mason delivers HIS most histrionic moment -- a surprise in a movie in which the protagonist, up to that point, hasn't had much to say at all.  And that's another odd feature of the film -- Johnny, once he is wounded, is remarkably passive.  It's not clear that he cares about being saved, though he doesn't want to be found by the police.  Rather, he just seems not to want to be a burden to anybody.  Is he paralyzed by guilt?  Is he weak through loss of blood?  Both, perhaps?  Kathleen wants to save him and is scouring Belfast looking for him, but it's not clear that he wants any more than Kathleen's presence -- and at the end of the day (literally -- the movie is about the events of a single day and ends at midnight), it's not clear that Kathleen wants any more than just to be in Johnny's presence.  The ineffectiveness of Father Tom (W. G. Fay) gives the ending a very different character from the ending of "The Informer," where Gyppo (Victor McGlaglen) ends up in a church asking for forgiveness.  And yet Frankie's mother's absolution of Gyppo ("Sure, you didn't know what you were doin' ") perhaps applies to Johnny too.Anyway -- if you've read this far! -- good performances all round, not only from Mason but from a stable of good Irish actors including the young Cyril Cusack, Dan O' Herlihy, and W. G. Fay himself.  This was Fay's last movie, for he died in 1947, having been involved forty years earlier with Yeats, Synge, and Lady Gregory in the establishment of the Irish National Theater (later, the Abbey).  Take a look too at the proprietor of the bar.  I thought I recognized him from long ago.  I wondered, was it Peter Cushing?  But no.  He's William Hartnett, who went on to become the original Doctor Who.

I'm very partial to Mackerras's digital recording of Brahms's First Symphony, on Telarc, with excellent sound, but it is something of a special case -- it has been recorded with an orchestra with a much smaller complement of strings than the typical modern symphony orchestra, and Mackerras would have us believe that Brahms's preference, as a conductor, was for such reduced forces.  Is there a digital recording with a full orchestra that is sonically appealing and yet employs all the resources of the modern symphony orchestra?  I would say that this one -- recorded in the late 1980's by Haitink and the Boston Symphony -- gets the job done.  As sound, it is superior to Abbado's Berlin recordings from the early 1990's.  As a performance, it is superior to Bernstein's rather inflated performance of 1983 with the Vienna Philharmonic.  The sound has presence, clarity, and warmth, and Haitink's control of the outer movements especially seems exceptional to me.  The danger in the first is failing to avoid (for 16 minutes or so) a sense of sameness, as limited motivic material is worked over.  Haitink's sense of phrasal and dynamic variation, with no loss of forward motion, is exemplary.  In the fourth movement, the problem is to make coherent a great variety of motivic and harmonic material -- and again Haitink succeeds -- as do, I should add, Bohm, Karajan, and Klemperer on their respective analogue versions.  Middle movements are lovely too, with the trio of the third movement given an appealing lilt.  The filler is the choral work "Nanie" --nicely done too, but the symphony's the thing.Note: for a slower version that, to my ears, avoids Bernstein's dragginess AND has superior sound, there's Guilini and the LA Philharmonic.  I haven't heard the more recent Rattle (Berlin) and Zinman (Zurich) accounts.

Hearing this digital recording of a live performance from the early 1980's makes me want to hear Bernstein's 1960's account of this symphony with the NY Philharmonic.  His CBS (now Sony) recordings were generally fresh and full of life, but this one is a bit of a drag (even reviewers who like it admit that it's slow).  I think the outer movements suffer most.  There doesn't seem to be a consistent pulse or feeling of propulsion that carries through the whole, long movements, and they come across to my ears as sectionalized or "bitty."  There are moments when the music seems to come to a complete stop, and that undermines any sense of effective transition. Individual passages might be strikingly phrased or lovingly cherished, but overall the trees get in the way of the forest.  Brahms reportedly liked to walk -- I like to hear a spring in the step in his symphonies.  The sound has presence but is a bit bottom-heavy and not very refined.  In Abbado's recording, the studio sound isn't great, but the pacing and coherence are better.  Better still is Haitink's digital First from Boston -- here, the individual sections of the orchestra and the solo instruments come through with clarity and warmth, and Haitink's shaping of the long outer movements is much superior to Bernstein's, to my ears.  And if you like even more spring in the step, Haitink's Concertgebouw recording (analogue, early 1970's) really moves along, especially in the first movement.I like Bernstein a lot, but I find that in general I prefer his earlier recordings on CBS/Sony to the relatively few digital DGG ones I've heard.  I should just add that in this recording, the Vienna Philharmonic is with him all the way, so I'm not saying the playing is sub-par.  It's just the concept I don't like.  Also, The Vienna Philharmonic gets a better deal from the engineers with Bohm, in his rich and rhythmically alert performance of this symphony, now available in a bargain box and well worth the outlay.

In the 1980's, Richard Goode made some fine Mozart concerto recordings with the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, and it was on the strength of these that I picked up his recording of these three Beethoven sonatas (Nos. 16, 17, and 18), from the same period of Goode's recording career.  I already owned, and liked, Kovacevich's recording, and I had Brendel too, in a box set of the complete sonatas, also very fine.  These recordings are in that league.  The Nonesuch/Elektra sound is lovely, and the piano is perfectly placed in relation to the microphones.  In fact, I prefer the Nonesuch sound to the EMI sound for Kovacevich, and it's a bit more rounded than Brendel's fine analogue sound.  But it's the performances that matter, and they're full of life.  "The Tempest," No. 17, is perhaps the best-known of these sonatas, and it gets a fine reading here, but I'm especially partial to No. 18, which is as charming a sonata as you could wish to hear, with a presto con fuoco finale that's a delight.  It also oddly has a scherzo AND a minuet, the latter serving as the slow movement, and very lovely it is.  The first movement, with its odd peremptory chords followed by sprightly figures, keeps the listener on his toes, so to speak.  Goode doesn't over-pedal, and the fortes are never banged out -- the music seems to unfold very naturally.  If you have other recordings that you like, I don't know that this is indispensable, but you wouldn't regret getting it.

3 1/2 stars -- there's a lot to like about this debut novel that introduces an intriguing protagonist, Gregor Reinhardt, the man of the title.  He's a decorated WW1 veteran of the trenches, with a hard won Iron Cross to show for it, who went to work in the Berlin Police Force after the war.  With the rise of the Nazis, however, he witnessed with disgust the politicization of the Force and the kinds of compromises he had to make in order to continue work as a policeman.  Finally, after it all gets too much for him, to the point of his feeling suicidally self-hating, he joins the Abwehr, the intelligence arm of the German military, thinking that there, at least, he can be more in touch with the honorable soldier he once was.  However, Hitler has taken Germany into WW2, and Reinhardt finds that his military life now, basically doing interrogations, with colleagues who are often brutal and compromised themselves, is not satisfying, and the book opens with Reinhardt in Sarajevo, suicidally depressed again, wanting to serve his country but to do so honorably, in an environment where honor seems to mean nothing.Then he is tasked with a job that calls on his skills as a detective -- a double murder of a woman, a popular Croatian journalist, and a German officer under circumstances that, given the sexual history and reputation of the journalist, are suspicious and yet maddeningly unclear.  The woman has been stabbed to death, the officer shot.  The Abwehr has an obvious interest in finding the killer of the German officer, but the local police in Sarajevo are only interested in the woman's death and clearly want a quick arrest, trial, and execution, even if they get the wrong person.  Reinhardt is paired with a Croat policeman, Padelin, who is as much a hindrance as a help in the enquiries and whose brutal methods disgust Reinhardt.  Complicating matters is the fact that it becomes clear that there are elements of the German army -- military police and SS among them -- whose interest in the case is not the same as Reinhardt's and who make their contempt for Reinhardt quite clear.  Complicating things further is the fact that Yugoslavia has a civil war going on.  Croats, Serbs, Muslims, and communist "Partisans" are all at one another's throats, with the German army basically trying to work with what seems to be the dominant local faction, the Croat-dominated Ustasa, to keep sufficient order to enable them and their Italian allies to keep Yugoslavia under German control following the failure at Stalingrad, which had stopped German advances in the East.  Also lurking in the background are the problems of Jews and Gypsies in fraught circumstances where both the Germans and the Yugoslavians see them as dirt.Luke McCallin does a good job of enabling the reader to understand the pressures that this complicated situation puts on Reinhardt, as he finds out more about the victims of the murder and their connection to high-ranking elements in the German Army, and the procedural elements in the novel are deftly and clearly handled.  In the interest of avoiding spoilers, I'll spare you details.  Reinhardt's depressed, near-alcoholic character is also compelling -- a culturally and historically grounded variant on the "burned-out" cops like Rebus and Banks, but the more plausible because of the grounding; he's a man who wants to serve his country but doesn't know that he can honorably serve what his county has become.  McCallin also knows Sarajevo and the surrounding countryside, though he perhaps overdoes the street names (or at least might have supplied a frontispiece map).  But the atmosphere of a tense city at the mercy of rival groups AND an occupying force of supposed allies is well caught, and, of course, navigating the murky local politics is challenging for a foreign detective who often feels that he has no business being there.Why only 3 1/2 stars?  Mainly because the ending is awkwardly handled -- too talky and stretched far too long.  Reinhardt's own meditations on his situation are old stuff by this point, and the late introduction of an important character who then has to do a LOT of explaining on his own behalf gets in the way of the pace and excitement of the best of the the earlier parts of the novel.  For all that, it's a book worth reading -- a first novel, so therefore the clumsiness at the end, which includes some implausible moments, might be understandable.  I'll be willing to give the sequel a try.

If you saw "The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada" (TBME), the previous movie that Tommy Lee Jones directed and starred in, then the odd and arresting quality of this movie -- an even better one, I think -- won't altogether surprise you.  It's absorbing to watch, for all its leisurely pace, and it stays in the mind and prompts reflection afterward.  As with TBME, it's about madness and absurdity, but in "The Homesman," that absurdity is tied to a specific time and place and enterprise that, one feels, has not been done justice to in American film before.  In the mid-19th Century, in Nebraska Territory, the whole enterprise of establishing civilization, initially in the form of viable economic activity, is seen as involving costs to the sanity of the women who were made part of it.  There's a stereotype, of course, of the plucky and resourceful frontier woman, but this film is having none of it.  The resourceful woman here -- and a number of less resourceful ones -- pay a terrible price for trying to make it on the plains of Nebraska.  The place is so inhospitable that anything "normal" that survives seems to do so as much by luck as anything else.  Families are necessary to secure work, succession, and division of labor even before one thinks of the refinements of civilized life -- and yet the establishment of stable families is seen as a hit-or-miss affair.  Women have children, and they die; their husbands are more concerned with heritage than affection, so sex is more perfunctory than romantic; marriages are economic arrangements first and foremost, and sometimes marriages just can't be arranged . . . .The story, as all readers will know by now, is how Mary Bea Cuddy (Hilary Swank) undertakes to take three women who have been driven insane by their circumstances back to Iowa, from where they can be perhaps reunited with their kinfolk.  A lot of the early part of the movie shows us these women and their circumstances, and it's not a pretty sight.  Mary Bea's sympathy for them and tenderness with them are palpable, and poignant too, for she's a single woman trying to work her own claim and hoping to ally herself in marriage with a man who will help her.  Her "courtship" scene is both funny and painful, but it goes nowhere, and her disappointment, it would seem, is partly what drives her to undertake the quixotic task of relocating the mad women.  Her feeling for them -- and she is, as they say, a God-fearing woman -- makes one wonder about her own psychological condition, and that's something that we continue to wonder about throughout the movie.  I'll say nothing about the events that prompt reflection about this in the interest of avoiding spoilers.  However, Mary Bea's journey isn't the only quixotic enterprise in the movie.  The speculative hotel building of Aloysius Duffy (James Spader) that is encountered on the journey back east is a visible symbol of the absurdity of attempts to "normalize" the frontier, and that encounter produces some of the most memorable action and images in the movie.Mary Bea saves the life of a man who has been left to hang for claim-jumping in an oddly comic scene -- he's George Briggs (Tommy Lee Jones) -- who seems to have no clear idea or direction about his life, but agrees to help Mary Bea on the journey because she has saved his life and, perhaps more important to George, offers him $300.00.  There's an obvious "odd-couple" appeal to the idea of the Christian woman and the pragmatic and unprincipled rascal, and their journey is a mixture of the painful, the tender, and the humorous.  The mad women don't regain their sanity en route, but they become quiet and reasonably co-operative.  One does wander off and fall in with a wandering and dubious cowboy (Tim Blake Nelson, in a very brief cameo), and there is an encounter with Pawnees, in which George proves his worth -- but there are disturbing things too.  Food runs short, a desecrated grave that the party comes upon causes a major upheaval.  The sense of the environment as unfriendly and hostile and empty is made manifest, thanks to the leisurely pacing of the story.  The psychological effects of the journey on both Mary Bea and George become increasingly interesting to us, and again, we wonder about costs . . .I don't think it's giving too much away to say that the movie has two climaxes -- one for each of the main characters.  There's horror and humor and pathos all mixed in here.  We know, of course, that "the west was won,"  but this movie shows us aspects of that process (if that's the word) that we haven't seen on the screen before.  It's this breadth of interest -- what does it take? what does it mean? to "win" a life from this land -- that distinguishes the movie from something like "True Grit" or even TBME, which are also demythologizing but have a narrower focus.  I should add that Tommy Lee Jones here gives as fine and nuanced a performance as I've ever seen from him, and Hilary Swank is deeply affecting as a woman of real resource who might have over-estimated her capacities.  This is a very fine movie.

I picked up this recording -- an original first run issue from the mid-1980's -- on sale, used, and I have to report that my reaction is very much like Santa Fe Listener's original reaction: it seems to me (with one reservation) very good.  To my ears, the sound is very good, maybe not quite in the mid-'80's Telarc class, but close.  There's an airiness and transparency to it that is especially welcome in the "Wunderhorn"-like passages in the first three movements.  The Philharmonia, Sinopoli's orchestra at the time, plays beautifully, and the texture of the lighter passages and the timbre of individual instruments is ravishingly caught.  Nothing could be further from the rather harsh and dubiously balanced sound that I hear, for example, in Abbado's Brahms, also, strangely, a DG production.  Sinopoli's tenderness in the folk-like Wunderhorn material is winning, and that makes the brutal massed brass eruptions all the more threatening and powerful.  The scherzo material isn't at all light-hearted, and that's in keeping with the dramatic narrative that the symphony enacts over its 80+ minutes -- a narrative of innocence and beauty threatened and seemingly defeated, until the "resurrection" music asserts itself in the last 20 minutes or so.  And that's where my reservation is: the opening choral section is beautifully sung (after Fassbaender's powerful "Urlicht" section), but for the later, louder choral music, the engineers seem to have taken a step back, as it were, and there's some loss of immediacy.  Apart from that -- and it's not the fault of the musicians -- this is a beautiful and affecting reading.Fassbaender and Bernd Weikl provide some extras -- the Wayfarer songs and some early songs.  Nobody will buy a 2-disc set for these alone, but be assured that they are very well done.

I really enjoyed this first installment of PUNISHING MISS PRIMROSE.  I thoroughly enjoyed it; although I would to say that I would have been much, much happier had it been a complete story.  That's not a complain, merely an observation.  In any event, I found the book to be very well written, with a storyline that is fairly unique...at least in my experience.  The story that unfolds is tantalizingly erotic.  Spencer finds himself unwillingly drawn to Beatrice, despite the fact that he believes her to be a villainous female who used and abused his younger brother.  It will be interesting to see how the story unfolds and how these two mule-headed people finally achieve their HEA.  Happy reading!

I wish I could give this piece of crap zero stars. I bought it a few months ago from BJ's Wholesale; it's one of the worst purchases I've ever made! This thing overloads whenever I use it...EVERY. SINGLE. TIME!!!! When I say it overloads, I'm not talking about when I try to shred several pages simultaneously. I mean even when shredding ONE SHEET of letter size paper the blasted thing will become stuck...the overload indicator lights up...and I have to continuously depress the forward button to get the sheet to go through. The first time I used the machine I had a bunch of paper to shred because it had been a while since my previous shredder died. Consequently, I attributed overheating and overloading problems to the volume of documents I was shredding. However, when I next used the machine I experienced the exact same problem, and it's not like I have any heavy duty shredding to do. I shred any mail with my family's name/address on it, any documents with personal information, and the like, stuff that you find in a regular household. I am not a business. Unfortunately by the time I used the machine the second time, and figured out that it really was a piece of s***, it was too late to return it. As much as I hate to do it, and as opposed as I am to wasting money, I fully intend to toss this crap out with the trash. It is just way too aggravating to use!!!! So make a note, if you're looking for a shredder DO NOT BUY THIS ONE!!!! I really wish that I had checked reviews before I forked out my $50. UGH!

This story encompasses a really, really sweet romance.  If you're in the mood for a quick, sweet story with a hero that is totally dedicated to the heroine, then this book just might fit the bill--it did for me!  While it's true that everything in this story seemed to move at a really quick pace--it's only about 70 pages after all--yet still, the author was able to sell me on the couple's instant connection with one another and when the H told the h that he loved her, I totally believed it!  Nate and Tessa meet when she waits on him at the restaurant where she works part-time.  They have an instant connection, but Tessa is a bit hesitant because of her recent breakup with a long-term boyfriend that left her broken hearted.  Nate, on the other hand, is all about Tessa almost from the very beginning.  Despite her reservations Tessa decides to enjoy the moment and not overthink the situation.The story depicts the couple's first two dates then it jumps ahead to a few weeks later; by this time their feelings have grown, but Tessa is still not quite believing that Nate can really be serious about her; although she doesn't spend time thinking about it.  The couple do suffer a setback and end up separated for a short period of time, but I really liked that fact because, IMO, it solidified the couple's relationship.  Tessa resolves her feelings for her ex, so it took away any feeling like she might have been rebounding with Nate.  Consequently, when the couple finally do get their HEA I was totally on board--I found it completely believable.  Yes, it went back very quickly; I wish we could have had more time with them once they reconciled, but that's often the case with books that are this short.  You can only get so much story into 70 pages.  In any event, I really enjoyed Ms. Goldman's writing style and I will definitely be reading more of her books in the future.  As a matter of fact, I have her Vacation With a Star (Contemporary Romance) ready to go next!  FYI, this isn't a clean romance; there is sex, but IMO it's not graphic and it's easily skipped.  Happy reading!

I absolutely love this Jasmine cartridge.  The font is absolutely beautiful.  In addition to the alphabet, numbers, and symbols, the cartridge also prints the following words and phrases:  "I love you"; "Warmest Wishes", "With Sympathy", "Seasons Greetings", "My Friend", "Many Thanks", "and", "to", "from", and "the".  It also has 6 Creative Features: Oval, Diamond, Charm, Italic, Shadow, and Shadow Blackout.

I purchased this M&D Slice and Bake Cookie Set for my daughter back in 2011 when she was only four.  As with all the Melissa & Doug products that I've purchased over the years, this set is extremely well made and durable; we still have it and it's still in excellent condition.  My daughter loves playing with it now, just as much as she did when I first bought it for her.  She and her five year old brother love pretending that they are baking.  LOL  This is one toy that I would highly recommend; it is perfect for creative play!!

This set of magnetic wooden dolls are fabulous.  As with all the other Melissa & Doug products that I've purchased in the past, they are made of real wood and are of a superior quality...they are extremely well made and durable!  There are two dolls, Emma and Abby, and 56 pieces of clothing that allows you to make hundreds of different outfits!  I purchased this for my daughter back when she was only four and she loved it.  Now that she's almost eight, she still loves playing with them...and the set is still in like new condition!  I too have spent many fun hours playing dress-up with these dolls.  They are far superior to the cardboard dolls they had back when I was a girl.  LOL

These cardstocks are awesome!  I love the quality they are a perfect thickness for use with my Cricut Create, and the colors are positively beautiful!  As a matter of fact, I love the way these cardstocks perform with my Cricut better than other cardstock that is sold specifically for use with the machine.  These cardstocks are 12x12 and my Cricut uses size 6x6 paper, so I just cut these in two for each use with my machine.  I love it!

I purchased this Beast Wars DVD set as a birthday present for my ten year old nephew.  He absolutely loved it.  His parents tell me that he spent hours watching the shows one after the other when he first received it, and since then he's re-watched the DVDs several times.  They thanked me for the hours of peace.  I recently went to visit and watched a few of the programs myself.  The computer animation is pretty amazing; both the video and audio quality are excellent.  The set consists of 8 discs; all three seasons; fifty two episodes in all.

My daughter loves the Ladybug Girl storybooks, ever since she received her first one, Ladybug Girl, as a birthday present when she was three.  She's almost eight now, and over the years we've collected several Ladybug Girl storybooks.  Even though she's now in Second Grade and has pretty much graduated to chapter books, she still enjoys reading these books to her five year old brother--who is another Ladybug Girl fan.  So when he needed to buy a present for one of his female classmates, he quickly selected this Ladybug Girl story as the perfect gift to give her.  LOLIn this particular story Ladybug Girl, aka Lulu, and her best bud, Bingo, go camping for the first time.  When Lulu has a hard time keeping Bingo on his leash and by her side, she realizes that that is a job for Ladybug Girl.  LOL  As with all the Ladybug Girl stories, this one is well written, and is beautifully illustrated.  The recommended age is 4 and higher, but we've been reading them to my daughter since she was three, and continued to do so when my son was born, so he's pretty much been listening to and loving Ladybug Girl since he was only a few months old.

This set of People at Work is fantastic.  The set consists of six people, each of a different profession.  There is a police officer, a doctor, a mail carrier, a firefighter, a business woman and a business man.  Each piece is made of solid wood, is exceptionally well crafted, and measures approximately 3 inches tall and is a 1/2 inch thick.  I purchased this set for my five year old son just over two years ago when he was almost 3.  Despite the fact that he's had it for a significant amount of time, and plays with it constantly, the set is still in like new condition.  My son loves playing with this set.  Typically he uses it with his wooden railway set, pretending the people are riding the trains, or he creates towns with his M&D Town Block Set, and has the people moving around the town.  I too love this set because it has provided my son with endless hours of funtastic, imaginative play!  You just can' beat that!

I purchased this 3 pack of Word World DVDs back in 2011 when my daughter was three.  She absolutely loved the series; so much so that I ended up buying her several other Word World DVDs.  Her five year old brother has now inherited, not only her DVDs, but also her love of the show.  The DVDs included in this box set are; Boppin' with the Bug Band, Bear's Masterpiece, and Flying Ant.  Each DVD consists of four episodes.  The episodes included on each DVD are as follows:FLYING ANT:  Flying Ant, Catch that C!, Shuffleboard, and Play Ball!BEAR'S MASTERPIECE:  Back on Track, Ride 'em CowBEAR, M is for Map, and NightlightBOPPIN' WITH THE BUG BAND:  Boppin' with the Bug Band, Pl-Pl-Plane, Get Your Coat, and WaterloggedIf you've never watched any of the Word World programs, you're really missing out.  :-)  I've watched several over the years; with both my daughter and my son.  The program is very educational and helps children with identifying letters, letter sounds, and spelling.  Each episode is unique, fun, and entertaining.  As I said earlier, both my children love these shows; yes, even my daughter who has technically outgrown the program still enjoys watching them with her brother.  As a parent, I can't say enough good things about Word World!

I loved all three books in this box set.  It consists of the first three books in Ms. Harris' HOT series.  The HOT team consists of eight members.  Each member gets his own story.  So far there are seven books published, and an eighth is due out this sometime this year.  The books are interconnected, but each can be read a standalone.  FYI, of the books in this set, only the first book is a full length novel; books two and three are novellas, each around 100 pages in length...actually book 2 is listed at 136 pages.  I rated all three books 4 1/2 stars.HOT PURSUITWow!  I absolutely LOVED this book!  LRH is one fabulous writer!  And what an imagination!  Wow!  The story that unfolds in this book is, in a word, riveting!  I read the entire book in two days--well actually one, considering I didn't start reading it until Friday night, and finished it by Saturday afternoon.  The hero, Matt "Richie Rich" Girard is the leader of his H.O.T. team, and he's pretty freaking hot to boot!  LOL  Anyhow, the Hostile Operations Team unit is a secret branch of the military whose members undertake deep covert operations.  In the prologue we meet Matt and his team while they are out on a mission.  Subsequently, the mission goes badly and Matt loses two of his team members, but not before the entire team is taken captive.  Two months later, Matt is back in his hometown for his sister's wedding, while awaiting a hearing to determine his future with HOT.  Matt is from a wealthy, privileged family; his family owns an oil company, and his father is a state senator...hence the team name "Richie Rich."  LOLEvie is back in town since going bankrupt and losing her restaurant, after all her money was embezzled by her accountant/lover.  Nowadays Evie works as a shampoo girl in her mother's salon while sending out resumes in the hopes of getting a chef position--preferably somewhere far away from Rochambeau.  Evie and Matt were childhood friends, ever since they met when Evie was six and Matt seven.  Over the years the two hung out, until they hit their teen years when things started to change between them.  Eventually the two drifted apart, but right before he left for West Point, Evie asked Matt to be her first, and he took her virginity.  When Matt bragged about sleeping with Evie then departed for college, he left Evie's reputation in tatters, which made her senior year in High School pretty horrendous.  I have to say that the more I heard about Matt as a teenager, the less I liked him...as a teenager that is.  As a man I love him!  Anyway, I wish Evie had called him to account for his bad behavior when they were teenagers.  When she first lays eyes on Matt, for the first time in ten years, she thinks to herself that he had been "a self-centered, arrogant jerk with a giant sense of entitlement..."  Yet when she does come face to face with him and he tries to apologize, she downplays his selfish behavior, even taking part of the blame onto herself!  She tells him it was partially her fault because she shouldn't have asked him to be her first!  I didn't like that.  I wanted her to tell him he'd been a a$$hole.  That's what she really thought, so that's what she should have told him.  In any event, that was all in the past, and wasn't significant to the story.The first time Evie and Matt come face to face, things are a bit awkward between them.  Evie tries to keep Matt at a distance, but he's drawn to her and can't stay away.  That first night, the two find themselves at the same party by the lake, which is where the action gets started.  The book is chock full of excitement, what with shootings, a house bombing, high speed chases, a kidnapping, and organized crime.  Wow!  All the events take place over an intense 48 hour period, so as you might expect, the story moves at a really fast pace.  Developing side by side with the organized crime aspect of the story is the relationship between Evie and Matt.  Matt is determined to walk away from Evie after he helps her get her sister back and makes sure Evie is safe; he doesn't believe that his job is conducive to having a long-term relationship.  There is also the fact that Matt's future is uncertain, as he has no idea what will happen when he attends the hearing regarding his career...there is the possibility that a court martial will be recommended, which could mean time spent in Leavenworth.  And even if he is reinstated, Matt doesn't think it would be fair to ask Evie to live with all the uncertainty associated with his job every time he went out on a mission; not knowing where he was going, how long he'd be gone, and when or IF he'd be coming back.My favorite part of the story is the end, where Matt finally claims Evie as his.  I thought it was so romantic.  I loved the fact that Matt came to the realization that no matter what, Evie was number one in his life.  He realized it; he accepted it; he made it abundantly clear to Evie.  Sigh!  I read a few reviews where readers were annoyed by Evie's constant refusal to follow Matt's directions.  Usually I too am annoyed by the idiotic female who is going to "save" the hero, even though she has no special training, not even in self-defense.  However, in this book, for some reason, Evie's actions didn't bother me.  Oh there was a time or two when I told her she really needed to stay put, but I could see her point.  It was HER sister that was in trouble, and Matt was putting his life on the line to help her.  I could understand why sometimes she'd go off half-cocked to make sure he was okay.  When you're sitting around waiting, without any clue as to what is happening, five minutes can oftentimes seem like 50 or more.  So even though there were times when I thought she was crazy, and maybe even a little annoying, I found her behavior realistic.As much as I loved the story, though, there were a few times when I thought it tended to be a overly dramatic...one such example is the scene by the lake where the shooting takes place.  Matt and Evie both thought it was just some crazy redneck that was probably drunk and shooting off his gun, yet Matt went into full blown covert operative mode.  I had to laugh when he was smearing dirt over his face and arms--because he had no grease--and he was thinking that he should have rubbed dirt on Evie too.  That was a mite crazy.  I also couldn't understand why the house was blown up.  That never made any sense to me...I figured it was just to add more drama to the story.  It also got a little tiresome listening to Matt's inner dialogue about all the crazy things that were second nature to him because of his training as a Special Forces soldier.  After a while I was like, "enough already!  I get it!  He's a well-trained military machine!"  SheeshNonetheless, aside from a few moments that seemed over the top--at least to me they did--and getting a little tired of hearing about how well trained Matt was, I really liked this book.  I loved it, actually.  The series is so darn HOT that it's got me hooked!  Speaking of hot, the love scenes are hot and graphic; furthermore there is some crude language in the story, for instance the f bomb is used quite a bit.  Anyhow, that's my take on the story, it wasn't perfect, but I loved it, and I definitely recommend it as a worthwhile read.  FYI, there are eight members on the HOT team, each of whom gets their own story.  There are seven books in the series right now, and the eight book is due out some time this year.  Hoo-ah!HOT MESSThis is the second book in the Hostile Operations Team series.  In book one, team leader, Captain Girard, got his lady love.  In that book, we are introduced to HOT in the prologue, while they were out on an op, during which two members were killed.  By the end of that book those two positions remained to be filled.  The hero in this book, Sam "Knight Rider" McKnight is one of the replacements.  In this book, Sam has been newly recruited to the HOT team, and the events in his story take place several weeks after the events in book one.Sam and Georgie are childhood friends; her big brother is Sam's best friend.  Georgie is from a wealthy, privileged background and Sam is from the wrong side of the tracks.  Georgie has pretty much been "in crush" with Sam ever since she was thirteen years old, but as far as Sam is concerned, she is strictly off limits.  When Rick, Georgie's brother, asks Sam to check on his sister, Sam and Georgie meet again for the first time in six years.  The last time they saw each other was at Georgie's wedding.  Georgie lives in Maryland, where she teaches college courses to Army personnel.  One of her top students has missed several classes, and the Army won't give her any information.  When Sam goes to see Georgie, she asks him if he could find out what happened to her student.  Subsequently, Georgie's life is threatened, and Sam discovers that Georgie's student has been murdered and that he was involved in illegal activities.  These illegal activities are linked to the threat against Georgie, and the HOT team is mobilized to neutralize that threat.  In order to safeguard Georgie, Sam takes Georgie to a safehouse.While the two are sequestered together, sparks begin to fly between them, and old feelings are brought forth.  Sam is determined to keep Georgie at arm's length, but he's fighting a losing battle, and Georgie certainly isn't making it easy for him.  LOL  I LOVED Georgie.  She may be from the elite, country club set, but that woman is REAL!  Sam sees her as some kind of princess; he thinks she deserves the best; diamonds, silk sheets, and fancy clothes, all things that he cannot give her.  In reality Georgie is no such thing.  She's as down to earth as they come, and she has her own issues.  Georgie went through a divorce almost a year ago, after her husband cheated on her for several months, before finally leaving her for the other woman.  Her self-esteem took quite a beating, and since then Georgie hasn't felt really attractive.  She wants Sam, has always wanted him, and she doesn't hold back in letting him know that.  I admit that when I read the reviews that said that Georgie went after Sam, I was concerned, as I don't like heroines who are willing to throw away their pride all in the name of love.  I usually don't respect them.  However, that is absolutely not the case with Georgie.  Georgie is strong.  She tells Sam she wants him, and she thinks he's an idiot for thinking he's not good enough for her.  But she doesn't beg, and she absolutely doesn't demean herself in order to get him.  What I love is the way she talks--what a mouth!  She's certainly doesn't talk like a princess.  LOLSome reviewers complained that Sam's hot and cold attitude towards Georgie was annoying, but I found it completely realistic.  Sam was fighting a battle on two levels; on the one hand, his job is not conducive to a committed relationship.  He can be deployed at a moments notice, heading to parts unknown, for an indeterminate period of time, with no guarantee that he will return.  He didn't think it was fair to ask Georgie to have to live with that constant uncertainty.  Furthermore, his assignment to HOT was brand new, having a new relationship so quickly after being assigned to such a high level, stressful job, I think, would make anyone think twice.  Then there was the more personal reason; Sam didn't think he was good enough for Georgie.  He had demons stemming not only from the fact that he didn't come from Georgie's world, but also from the mental abuse he suffered at the hands of his parents.  Under those circumstances, it was no wonder Sam blew hot and cold.  His heart was at constant war with his mind, and when you add in the intense sexual attraction that existed between the two, let's just say he doesn't stand a chance.In some ways, this story is similar to that of the first book; the hero and heroine have been friends since childhood, with the heroine having a crush on the H since she was a teenager; Georgie asked Sam to be her first lover just like Evie in book one had asked Matt, although in this case that situation turned out completely different.  Then there is the fact that Sam, like Matt, doesn't think he can have a committed relationship with his job, and tries to push Georgie away.  However, for the most part, this is a very different story.  Book one was action-packed with high speed chases, a kidnapping, shootings, a house bombing, and more.
