The balls also have hollow indents on some sides to allow for stacking of the blocks.  I love the fact that this little twist provided grandson with a real challenge that he persisted in mastering.Another great challenge for this 18 month old was placing the block in the front corner and using the block itself to rotate the little holder and make a great clacking noise.There is a "catapult" on the other front side of the wagon and that was MY favorite thing about the toy.  I used the catapult to launch blocks at duplo creations and other stacked towers we built.  The catapult will launch those blocks a good distance (far past the rear of the toy) so don't teach your kiddo this move in front of a glass cabinet/tv etc (as the blocks are substantial in weight and are a rigid plastic).  Once grandson saw me doing this he really focused on learning to do this himself and laughed with great gusto every time he succeeded.  We used pillows to "shield" ourselves from his barbarian attacks and that really had him rolling.The rolling side of the blocks means that little hands can roll the blocks in the same way they would a push car...meaning just that much more fun.On to the wagon itself.  The rocking motion seemed like a weird idea in the written description but turns out to be a fabulous idea in reality.  Grandson is fascinated by the motion and the movement and noise of the blocks as he pulls his wagon around house.  He threw in a bunch of duplo blocks and some small tupperware containers and other miscellaneous small stuff and had a grand time hauling things all around and sharing his bounty with everyone he passed.The rear liftgate drops down if you want to leave a trail of blocks and duplos rocking out the wagon as your toddler rolls along.  It is a manual and simple maneuver.Lastly, there is a lever on the side of the wagon that makes "silly sounds and music."  Our grandson is silly, loves music and dancing so this is a big attraction for him.

It isn't clear if the quantity of each strain is listed in order of highest proportion either.You could be getting 208 mg of the first strain and 1 mg of each of the other 9 strains for all we know.  If the quantity of each strain isn't available in the amount needed to provide benefits, then all those listed strains are just marketing hype.The mens and womens formulas have the same strains listed in different order on the labels.  The mens says it is 217 mg and the womens says 248mg.If I find that there are only "token" quantities of most of the strains, this review goes to zero stars.  I've written to the company to find out this information and will post if company responds.In the meantime, we continue to take this probiotic on faith that Dr. Perlmutter values his integrity and our health and has created a good quality product.

Love that this company is offering up not only an organic infant cereal, but one made with healthy quinoa.Before giving it to "number one grandson" I made a small batch for myself to try.Upon opening the bag, I got an immediate dose of earthy quinoa scent.  The color was a pale sandy tan (package says can be gray to tan in coloring).  The texture was very fine as you would desire in an infant cereal.I prepared with a one part cereal, two part water formulation as most reviewers mention cereal being too thick.  It turned out to be a perfect texture, just the right thickness and smoothness.  Interestingly, you could smell a bit of the apple once the warm water hit the cereal.  The cereal hydrated fully very quickly.Drumroll, the taste test...earthy, sweet, apple essence-y is my first impression.  Checked label for sugar it tasted so sweet....no sugar, good.A few minutes after consuming the cereal I felt a headache coming one.  Once again I check the label looking for stevia perhaps (migraine trigger for me).  Instead, underneath the amazon vine label which I had to peel off to read bottom half of ingredient list, I found holy basil as an ingredient.  Holy basil is another migraine trigger for me.  Even with what was probably a miniscule quantity of Holy Basil I am sitting here with a pounding headache.I have decided not to give this cereal to number one grandson.  I wish the manufacturer had kept this simple; cereal and apples, and they would have had a winner.  I can't think of any reason why I would give my grandson or anyone else any herbs, vitamins, supplements, additives that he didn't NEED for his good health.  Our goal is to maintain the good health he is in, largely a result of his mom breastfeeding him thus far.

I have used a TENS unit for over a decade for pain management and have had good success so I was intrigued by using the Slendertone Muscle Toner to tone my aging stomach muscles.I went into this with an open mind and didn't do any research (because I knew I would read rabid reviews both for and against both the technology and the product).  I've been losing weight steadily for the past few months and am happy with my reduced size, but boy oh boy am I ever aware of how much I need to stregthen and tone my body as well.I'm taking an exercise class focused on core strength as well as using a pilates reformer for same reason.  Progress is slow.  I figure if this Slendertone helps AT ALL, I'm a happy camper.The instructions are simple, and with the pads being same as a TENS unit, figuring this out is simple.  It is worth your while to take care of your pads so they last as long as possible.I only used the Slendertone two weeks before an emergency room visit in which I found out I have electrical problems with my heart.  That said my doctor felt like using the Slendertone was probably not worth any potential gain I might have (it turns out the Slendertone booklet has the first "warning" related to pacemakers and heart issues).During the two weeks of use I could feel the effects of the Slendertone and felt good after using it.  Whether it would have made a visible difference over time I will not know.I hope it works well for those who are able to use it.

My husband has a high stress job and is also showing some signs of early cognitive decline.  We have been addressing these issues largely through dietary changes and supplements and we read constantly in hopes of helping him through this challenging chapter of life.We have had very good look with Jarrow supplements and tend to start with their brand when trying something new.I was happy to get this PS-PA for my husband to try.As with any supplement/drug, results may be subtle and take time.  He is three weeks into this supplement and we can only judge results by his overall behavior and observations.I would love to say the results have been miraculous, but they haven't.  However, he is feeling less anxious and more focused and that is worth something.I have started taking it as well and am pleased with noticeable results.  I've got some big bookkeeping projects going and feel much more on-the-ball taking the PS-PA three times a day.  Overall I feel it has helped with my stress levels as well (in the questionnaire from the book "the Mood Cure" I tested as being pretty spent in the realm of adrenals, so perhaps this is helping.  I sure hope so!We tend to give any new supplement a three month trial at minimum and will do so with this.At that time my review will be amended with any new observations.Best of luck to all who need this supplement.

We are long-time users of Goody's Powders because they WORK, are easy to carry in your purse/pocket, and they work quickly.The biggest downsides of Goody's Powders are the bitter taste of the medicines on your tongue.I was optimistic that the fruit flavoring would help the "spoonful of medicine go down in a delightful way," but such was not the case.The fruit flavoring simply can't do much to override the strong and bitter taste of the actual medicine.Once this package is finished we will go back to using regular Goody's as I see no need to take any more unnecessary ingredients (colorings/flavorings,etc) than necessary to get the job done.Thanks for trying, Goody's!

If you're a fan of beautiful hardware you're going to really enjoy this Hydrorail.  NOTE:  you are buying ONLY the rail, you have to provide your own shower head and hand sprayer.  The chrome finish is immaculate and the rail is very solid.We wound up using this in our second home, which doesn't have a terribly beautiful shower, so while this Kohler system looks great, it makes our cheapo shower stall look beastly.My husband has worked in remodeling and is a primo handyman.  He said the instructions were clear and installation was easy.  I heard no banging or fowl language while he was doing this so I believe him.  I wouldn't call the installation "quick" nor "easy" for someone who has never done something like this; however the average mr/mrs fixit will get this installed smoothly.Our biggest challenge was that our shower has a built in seat near the front where the shower head is.  We would have liked it if there were a system available that has a longer extension so the rainshower head clears the seat better.  Again, our problem is the shower, not this shower head.

This is a servicable average quality mark and snorkel combo.  It is perfect for taking on a vacation where you don't want to rent questionable used equipment.  We have a house in Florida and we leave this there for guests to use as our other mark and snorkels are far superior to this one.I have a narrow face and have had problems with masks not fitting properly.  The Phantom Cancun seems to fit well on my facial shape.  However, I had tiny leaks in the mask no matter how I adjusted it.  Very irritating.The snorkel stayed dry but didn't have a good ergonomic design (due to my facial shape perhaps...who knows?) and made my jaw hurt.My husband has a large head and round face and the mask didn't work at all for him.

I think most of us would love to have a friendship with someone like Sister Augustine.  And if we were so lucky to have such a relationship for an extended period of time, I think we'd want to share our good fortune at finding such a lovely and wise companion along life's journey.The few Benedictines I've met, along with those whose works I've read, strike me as solid and steady folk living simple lives (not easy--SIMPLE).The lavish language/sentences in this book somehow take away from the simple truths of Sister Augustine.I have a deep love of words and beautiful sentences, but the author hasn't fully mastered the ability to consistently hit his mark in this regard.  I would have enjoyed the book more with less flourish and more substance, spiritual insights, etc.

This is a tough book for me to review.  I really like the premise and back story of this book.  I like the authors writing and character development.  I cared about each of them, flaws and all.I can't put my finger on the exact problem, but something about the entirety of the book just didn't "flow" for me.  There was no obvious disjointedness, it was more like rafting on a river that had very few bends and twists or rapids.  Perhaps there was a lack of depth to characters and situations, in spite of the sorrow and tragedy that is a strong undercurrent through the book.I like a happy ending as much as the next person but I felt like the ending of this book was so improbable as to be ridiculous.  I WANT things to turn out improbably good, but they just don't in the real world.

This is a nice looking towel and I like the pawprint so there is no doubt as to which towel is your dogs.I don't care much for the fabric, nor do I care much for most microfiber products.This product specifically doesn't dry particularly well, nor does it launder well.It comes out of the washer/dryer with tons of beaded lint/fiber balls all over it and looks nasty (this is my complaint against most microfiber--don't launder well).In addition, the towel is small if you have a larger breed dog.  I also think the price is a bit high at $9.99 ($6.99 feels about right)

This story is proof that a great book doesn't have to be a literary masterpiece to bless us.What a SWEET, easy to read, encouraging story Mr. Kraus has written.While the story is a work of fiction, dog lovers will know that there are things in this world that are truer than truth.The book would have earned five stars from me with tighter editing and less words...a perfect short story is embedded in the cover of this book.Recommend for dog lovers everywhere!

I'm always happy to try supplements that help with stress reduction.  After receiving this product I looked up ingredients and found that ashwagandha can cause flare ups in people with autoimmune diseases due to increased immune system activity.That rules out my ability to properly test this product.There is no choice of "N/A" for reviews so I'm giving Sundown the benefit of the doubt with 3 stars.

I am a beginner table tennis player and was happy to grab this racket when it came up on amazon vine.I would love to tell you that my game has really improved as a result of this racket, but alas, it isn't true.My COMFORT however, has improved as this is a nice, lightweight racket, with a comfortable grip.This has helped me with some of the challenges I face due to carpal tunnel and other old injuries that make gripping and most arm movements a challenge.

this is a very simple placemat sized piece of fabric.it is only suitable for very small bowls (as in for toy/mini pets or cat bowls)we have a 20# dog with smallish bowls that were too big to use properly on this mat.because her bowls take up the whole mat the water that is slopped out doesn't land on the mat.

My first order of these bathmats (for a rental property) arrived with two of the 6 have flaws.  Amazon, as always, was great about making right on the order and promptly shipped another set in time to launder before guests arrived.They have been well used since and launder like a dream.  A touch of bleach and borax in the wash and they come out clean, bright, and most important; still rectangular in shape with no loose threads.

We rescued a scruffy little terrier mix that has a very low tolerance for cold and/or damp weather.  I'm not a fan of dressing up pets so I wanted something that looked dignified.I am VERY happy with the price, quality, fit, finish and durability of this great little jacket.Even more important LibbyLuLu actually LIKES wearing it so much that I leave it on her until bedtime.  The funny thing is it fits her like it was custom made for her.  She already had a kiwi collar and leash and I've gotta say she sure looks sporty now and she seems to know it.  She has an extra spring in her step when we're out walking in the woods and she hasn't done any disgusting "rolling in gross things" while wearing it either.  That's worth $20 right there!

I have been enjoying Mountain House freeze dried foods since I started back country camping in Colorado in the early 70s.  I have tried many other companies that sell freeze dried food and have yet to find one that has such consistent and delicious offerings.I normally get their entrees and vegetables and was happy to try these apple slices.We opened the can upon arrival and promptly did some serious damage to these amazing treats.  The taste is divine and the mouth feel/texture is absolutely perfect.  The can says to freeze or refrigerate unused open product if not consumed within a week.Per the label there are six servings which consist of 35 slices (~210 slices per can).  Both my husband and I find 20 slices to be a very filling and delicious snack.  We are eating them every day so this can didn't last a week.  You can tell that very good quality, fresh, crunchy apples were used as the full flavor and crispy texture of these apples is amazing.  And unlike a lot of cinnamon seasoned foods, these apples have a subtly sweet cinnamon essence that doesn't overpower the apples.  These will be a new pantry staple.If I were going to have unused apples after a week, I've found with other freeze dried food that the best way to keep it crisp is to put the remainder in mason jars and vacuum seal with my FoodSaver jar attachment.  When I open other large cans I do this immediately because I know I'm not eating a #10 can of corn in a week so why wait until the product has started picking up humidity to save?

Confession: I've only used false eyelashes once and that was back in the 70s.That makes this a review from a newbie perspective.Menopause has been unkind to my eyelashes (and ever so much more) so I decided to try out these false eyelashes.I am certain the comedy that was my first attempt was solely due to my inexperience so I won't comment on ease of use but will say I am grateful for youtube!I have short, sparse, blond eyelashes and these were just way too much for me as delivered.I felt like I looked like Tammy Faye Baker in them and husband and I had a good laugh.I trimmed the lashes considerably and gave them another try--MUCH better.  The lashes are nice and wispy which looks good with the shorter length.On to the glue that was included...it is latex and has a synthetic fragrance: two strikes.  A friend loaned me a latex/fragrance/formaldehyde free glue and that did the trick.The case is very well made--quite elegant and sturdy.I am taking off one star for the price and one for the glue

I haven't read a single review that has commented on the ingenious hot handle sleeve built into one side of the pot holder.  For that matter, almost all the vine reviews seem to be cut and paste copying/editing of prior reviews.This is a very well made pot holder--nice heavy weight fabric, quality stitching and finish seams, nice silicone ribbing and outstanding heat resistance.On one side of the pot holder the silicone ribs extend all the way across.  On the other side there is a pocket sewn into the full length of the pot holder that slips over the handle of your pots.  What a great, practical idea!The potholder protected my hand when pulling a cast iron skillet out of a 400 degree oven--one of my biggest challenges to a pot holder.I also used it to remove baking sheets full of roasted veggies and found that this particular pot holder isn't well suited for grabbing shallow baking sheets.  It is too thick, long, bulky and/or just shaped wrong for that purpose and the fabric gets all over the food.  It excels on pot handles and on pulling casserole dishes out of the oven.  I will be getting a second one as I would feel more secure pulling larger/heavier dishes out of the oven with two.Note to manufacturer if they read reviews:  Use a fully sewn on tag/care instructions.  The loose/dangling fabric tag is a fire hazard for those of us with gas ranges.

I've had several occasions these past few weeks where we have been able to test this products efficacy.My husband and I walk at least once per day in the woods next to our home.  Once the ticks and chiggers come out in spring we absolutely have to use repellent or we are in big trouble.  In addition, we have a home in Florida and the mosquitoes are already out in force as of this month.We normally use deep woods off and have good success but are always looking for the perfect repellent as we spend so much time outdoors in hot, humid, buggy places.We're very happy with the Cutter Sport Repellent effectiveness on the ticks and chiggers.  It isn't as effective on the Florida mosquitoes though.The scent is very strong and I don't care for it at all so I'm not using it anymore, but my husband doesn't mind it and will use til the container is empty.

I've been using Miracle-Gro Liquafeed Fertlizers with the Liquafeed Feeder for several seasons now.  I had never seen the QuickStart product at any of my local stores and was happy to give this product a try.I used the QuickStart on all of my flower transplants this past month and they are doing fabulous!  I like the ease and convenience of the Liquafeed Feeder and already had it so using the Quick Start product was a piece of cake.The transplants have settled in well and have vibrant full green foliage and several are budding out now.I'm a fan!

I got these for my husband for when we travel, but wound up claiming them for myself.I have fine, sparse hair and dry, sensitive skin.  I am always looking for the perfect disposable razor (which I still haven't found).The Flex 5 is a nice razor.  I like how it feels in my hand (a flimsy disposable inevitably winds up with me losing control of it and cutting myself) with an adequate heft, balance and control.The blades deliver a nice close shave and I can get at least 5 shaves out of each razor.The price is just a tad high to me.

I had never seen or heard of dehydrated pet food before seeing the Honest Kitchen Halcyon food.  We are downsizing to a smaller home in our retirement and have been talking about how we need to pare down the amount/quantity and size of items we store.I tend to keep a large pantry because I loathe shopping.So, along comes Honest Kitchen with this fabulous food.I was surprised by how small the box is! Very compact.  There is a nice weight, good quality ziplock bag inside with the food.On opening the food I was happy to see it looked and smelled good and fresh.Instructions were easy to read and follow:  Serve up just how much you need, add warm water, stir well and let soak a few minutes.The food is very green when hydrated and smells kind of "earthy" so I was interested to see if our picky terrier would even try it.SHE LOVES IT!  It hasn't caused her any gastric distress.I'm pleased with the sourcing and attention to ingredients this company has chosen.LuLu is a rescue girl who came to us in poor condition and is wrapping up her heartworm treatment now.  She needs all of the goodness she can get.The Honest Kitchen Halcyon has earned a permanent place in our pared down pantry.

Not a book. Has a beginning but no ending.  More junk fiction and not even a complete story at that.The writing in this book was dismal enough (the poor character building, the nonexistent plot, the embarrassingly juvenile formulaic writing in general)  that I was embarrassed for the author.  When I realized I wasn't even getting a full story I felt genuinely duped.

My husband is a handyman extraordinaire and our house and landscaping project give him plenty of material to work with.  He is a fan of craftsman quality tools and already had some Irwin tools in his tool chest.He was VERY happy to receive these and quickly set about using them on various projects.As with all Irwin tools he owns, these are of very high quality, fit and finish and are a pleasure to use.  They came with a well-made and very handy lanyard.While he liked this tool and said it is great for specific tasks, it is not as versatile and overall as useful to him as his Irwin PowerSlot Diagonal Pliers.The cutter has a max. gap of ” which spreads the handles too wide to get leverage.  The max. wire size is 1/8” or 10 gauge to get a grip with the pliers.Comfortable design, good leverage in the right range, “handy” lanyard.One reviewer said it opened 1 1/2”, must have been a different tool.

I'm always open to better ways to keep my trunk organized and carry groceries from warehouse stores and farmers market into the house.I had high hopes that this would be the perfect storage solution.My first box arrived broken, leading me to believe the plastic used in this box is fragile.  Amazon, quickly replaced it with a new box which arrived in perfect condition.I love the colors and the fact that the box stores flat so it doesn't take up space in your trunk until you need it.  It was easy to go from flat to box and no need to read instructions--intuitive design.  I can't carry as many pounds as this box is said to hold by manufacturer.  However, I did take it to Costco and load it up to my personal max (probably 40#).When I went to lift the full box up and over the back of my car and into the trunk the sides wanted to fold in.  This is not as sturdy as a fixed sided crate that you could tilt, angle and manipulate to get exactly where you want.  I also don't think I would have trusted $200+ dollars worth of wines, oils, etc in this crate hauling over any distance...just didn't feel like it was secure enough.Lastly, I feel that this is priced higher than design/construction warrants.  I'd say $10-12 max price point.In summary, I will keep this in my car to corral my grocery bags on smaller runs to the store or for farmers market where the open crate design helps keep produce from getting funky from trapped heat/moisture.

I've recently had to switch from carrying shoulder bags to carrying crossbody bags due to neck/shoulder issues.I've tried more purses than I care to remember in my search for a simple, stylish, leather, lightweight, well-made bag.Of all the bags I've tried, the Tignanellos have consistently been the best. I've purchased this style along with 4 others and love them all.This particular bag gets the most use as I can fit my kindle (in a leather case), reading glasses, coupon folder and assorted items like makeup, mints, pocketknife etc in the main compartment and it's pockets. My smart phone is too big for the pocket designed for phone so I slip it into the inside zippered pocket and leave it unzipped. I would take off a 1/2 star for that glaring design fault if possible as I place a high premium on easy access to phone.I rarely need to use the long zippered outer compartment, but it is very roomy if you need extra space--great spot for checkbook if you carry one.The primary reason I love these Tignanello crossbody purses is because of the EXCELLENT zippered "wallet" that is part of all 4 styles I've purchased. This particular version has the roomiest wallet compartment with drivers license window slot, a plethora of regular card slots, and a zippered compartment for your cash.I have this style in 3 colors and my favorite is the "Peacock"--a rich, deep teal blue. The "Brown" is a rich, deep espresso brown that goes with everything.The construction on all 3 is excellent, from leather quality, dye, construction/seaming details, heavy weight interior fabric with very tidy finish. The strap is very comfortable and doesn't cut into my neck. It can be configured several ways if you don't care to go crossbody all the time.HIGHLY recommend this bag.

My husband loves this razor (but not the price) so here is the review in his own words:I've been an electric razor user for almost 40 years and am a fan of the original "triple header."I've also used Braun and Panasonic shavers.The Norelco S9721 was well packaged and included a good manual.The initial charge lasted two weeks.The shaver head comes apart easily for cleaning.Shaving area feels much larger than it needs to be.  Low speed works well for my face, does not take any longer to shave than the higher speeds.  Manual recommends 3 weeks for your face to adjust to this shaver.  It did work better after a couple of weeks.The 9700 is much quieter than any shaver I've used and is a big plus.It is easy to switch between the shaver and trimmer head, but highlighting the alignment tab on both head and shaver would make it easier to see and align for assembly.Nice bonus:  The travel lock feature prevents the shaver from accidentally coming on while traveling or storage.The hard case provided also protects the shaver from damage during travel.Biggest downside (but certainly not a deal-breaker) is that there isn't any place on the stand to store the trimmer head. It either lays on counter, adding to unsightly clutter, or gets put in a drawer for possible damage or even loss.The Smart Clean System works well to clean and lubricate shaver.  Manual cleaning the shaver between shaves lets the system do a better job and extends the fluid and filter life.  The system alerts you when the filter is dirty.  Anticipated fluid cartridge life is 3 months, which I think is reasonable.I do not see an Amazon listing for replacement JC302 cleaning solution cartridges.  They are available in a 2-pack from the Philips website for $11.99 which includes free shipping.  That seems reasonable for the preventative care and maintenance of such a nice shaver.Overall I think this is a very good shaver, but it is definitely not worth the $350 price tag.  He feels like the difference in performance between his $250 shaver and this one is negligible.

I've had this mouse for a couple of years and have reached a point where I just can't justify the batteries it consumes.It is ergonomically good, tracks well and survives drops/falls and travel abuses.BUT, it eats a battery every month and I'm over the cost.The search for a new mouse begins...

As a lover of all things "frog," I was happy to choose this toy for my grandson.Upon receiving the frog I was even happier.  He is even cuter in person than in the images on amazon--frog goodness to be sure.The toy is very well packaged (in other words, it is going to take you some time to get it apart, but all the pieces are in perfect shape).  This is one of those items that might be nice for amazon to offer "Frustration Free Packaging" option.This is definitely geared toward young babies (9+ month) and won't offer enough variety/stimulation for most older babies/toddlers.The toy comes with 3 balls.  When a ball is placed in the frog's mouth he "ribbits" and his cheeks light up and a tune plays.  This particular tune is only 'ok,' not annoying but not enjoyable either.  Bonus points for including starter batteries with the toy.There is a button on the bottom that releases balls from the chute and plays much better music selections (and lights up the cheeks again)--some with kind of a Caribbean/reggae/island vibe that makes me happy.  I LOVE that the music is happy, sweet music set at a very nice volume and encourages dancing around with your child/grandchild.  I don't allow many toys in my home that make noise/music because it grates my nerves.THIS toy can stay permanently at grammys house :>).

Pairing was easy and straight forward.Having used many headsets over the years, and comparing this to others; the Jabra Stealth is louder and clearer.Listeners can’t tell you are on headset. Volume is adjusted on phone, not headset like others, which is a plus to me.The headset comes with multiple ear inserts and ear hooks, to pick a comfortable combination for individual ear shapes.  This was very important to me as I evidently have small and odd ears (I base this on how hard it is to find any headset that works for me).  I was able to get a comfortable fit for this set.Ear inserts are a sporty red and black which kind of kills the "stealth" factor.  I prefer a headset that is unobtrusive, which red is not.The headset holds a charge well but does not give a warning of a low battery, just voice quality goes down.  It would be nice if there was some type of warning so you can make sure its charged before a day of heavy usage.The short USB charging cable is OK for a laptop but takes longer and the laptop has to be on.  The little cover door for the charging port is weak and doubt it will be there for long.The on-off switch is easy to use with thumb while headset is in ear.The call answer/end touch button works as expected.The voice button looks up inquiries on Google +, but I could not get it to dial a number.  It would find a restaurant, but you have to press send from the phone.One time the headset disconnected from the phone, but the Bluetooth still showed enabled on the phone and could not use the phone.  Tried to reconnect and it would not.  Had to reset the phone to use.I rate this headset 4-1/2 stars (because of the disconnect issue above and a few other collective things I'd like to see functioning better).

Having been a fan of model cars when I was a youngster I looked forward to building this fabulous looking Dark Knight model for my grandson.  He is too young to assemble this himself.The box says ages 8+, but I don't believe most 8 year old children could put this together without the help of an adult.  The pieces are very tiny and there are a lot of them to keep up with.  I'm thinking 10+ to build this solo.If I were going to allow a child to try this on their own, I'd put all the pieces in a nice big baking sheet with edges so they could keep track of everything (and make sure they don't throw anything from the package away until completely assembled).  The pieces themselves aren't numbered so don't detach them from the sprue until ready to use.  The pieces assemble kind of like pop beads and assembly took about an hour. Unlike a lot of models, the individual pieces on this kit were smooth edged with no points or barbs where they detached from sprue.The cape was chintzy and very disappointing.  Would have been very cool if they had included a moody, billowing fabric cape.Assembly was straight forward and logical using included directions (I had to use a magnifier to see some of the pieces to connect them so not only need to be able to handle tiny pieces but to see them :>).  The instructions are actually a huge colored diagram printed on nice glossy paper that provides strictly graphic instructions on how to assemble.  It breaks the project down into parts (head, torso, arms, legs, etc).  I much prefer written instructions but imagine most people would like the graphics (like legos) more.Once assembled, other than the cape and a lack of eyes and/or even eye slits in the mask, the overall effect of the model is definitely that of the Dark Knight himself.My favorite thing about this is that this crosses the line from model into action figure with nicely articulating joints which gives this toy much more playability.  Oh, and he has multiple left and right hand options so that he can use his weapons or fists as needed (for a child who is careful with toys this is great but for the average kid these are tiny pieces to keep up with).I think for the $20 price tag there should definitely be an awesome super cape so that when a child (or adult) is playing with Batman his cape is doing that awesome whooshy cape thing it does when he swoops in to save the day or kick some bad guy booty.

My grandson uses Latch bottles and likes them.  He sleeps with low level white noise in his room during naps.  He loves his pacifier.For these three reasons I thought this Latch pacifier with heartbeat clip would be a perfect match (a latch match perhaps?)Alas, it wasn't to be.Number One Grandson has used a different brand of pacifier from birth and we couldn't get him to adjust to the Latch even though he likes the Latch bottles--KIDS!!!The strap is very high quality and the clip holds very well.  It is durable and better made than most we've tried, but the strap needs to be a little bit longer.Rather than lulling him to sleep the "heartbeat" sound actually keeps him awake and leaves him with a confused face.  It sounds nothing like a heartbeat and should be replaced either with a more natural, soothing heartbeat sound or a GENTLE white noise.This has the potential to be another great Latch product with a few minor improvements.

WOW! These placemats far exceed my expectations and are much more beautiful than the images on amazon.com.I'm a bit of a table linen addict and currently have 9 sets of placemats along with even more beautiful linen tablecloths.  My table never goes naked :>) and I consider myself well qualified to review table coverings.The color is a warm color that reads more of a golden toasty/straw tone than traditionally cooler/grayer toned taupe to me (I've never met a neutral I don't like so that isn't a problem for me!).  My walls are painted with Sherwin-Williams "Latte" and these mats look like they were custom made to complement the paint :>).What most impresses me is unlike many "made in India" woven products, the weave on these placemats is nice and tight and the finished edges are nice and even (not lumpy, uneven, unraveled like many).  The fibers themselves have a very soft, smooth, substantial feel and the woven mats lay nice and flat (again, not a given with many imported fiber products).Others have commented on the uneven knots on the fringes and/or the size of the knots.  I like the knots and fringe a lot.  The knotting is a proper size for such a large placemat and the variations in knot sizing give the mats a nice overall look.Speaking of size, these mats are HUGE, which is great!  I have a very large table, and oversized dishes.  It is very hard to find a placemat that will hold my dinner plates and glass, much less dinner plate, bread plate and glass.My set measured 23" x 13-1/4" and all six mats were within 1/8" of those dimensions (another unusual quality "plus" for a made in India set).  The fringe was 1-1/2" on each side leaving the body of the placemat at 20".

-----------------OVERVIEW-----------------When I purchased an iPhone 6 and was looking into getting a ballistic glass protector. Two days before I received my sample for review from I dropped my iPhone at the gym and the screen cracked. Was this a joke? I didn't think it was funny... I almost cried (not literally). The crack was a hairline crack and thankfully Apple replaced my entire iPhone for free since the crack was so thin/small. After getting a replacement iPhone 6, I immediately put on the iPhone 6 HD Tempered Glass Screen Protector by Tauri for protection.---------------------------PROTECTION---------------------------I could say it in one sentence, AMAZING protection for a minimal cost. A MUST HAVE! When I installed the iPhone 6 HD Tempered Glass Screen Protector by Tauri, I immediately grabbed a small marble, a quarter and a 50 Cent piece and was gutsy enough to drop them on to my iPhone (roughly 3 feet above my iPhone) with the iPhone 6 HD Tempered Glass Screen Protector by Tauri installed. My result? Glass didn't break or scratch. I was extremely impressed. While I wasn't gutsy enough to drop my iPhone on concrete or a hard floor, I was confident that even if I did (accidentally) the iPhone 6 HD Tempered Glass Screen Protector by Tauri would hold up, if not give me piece of mind that my iPhone 6 screen wouldn't break/crack with it installed.Also has very good fitment and its of near perfect size if placed correctly on your phone. I do wish it were a little bigger though.---------------------------SLICK/SLIPPERY---------------------------The ballistic glass is slick/slippery and can slide out of your hand fairly easily if you aren't paying attention, but then again, the iPhone 6 is regardless, that is a moot point. Be careful and pay attention.---------------------------PROS---------------------------- Protection from high impact drops- Protection from chipping and scratches- High display clarity- Great touch screen accuracy- Bubble Free Application- Great Build Quality- Amazing Clarity- Amazing Protection- Price---------------------------CONS---------------------------- Although "slim" still adds bulk/depth to the iPhone and it's screen- Glass is slicker than the the non-glass style screen protectors---------------------------DISCLOSURE---------------------------I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promised that my review is fair and honest with no bias.

Upgraded from a SB6121 to the SB6183 - NOT WORTH WHILE ATM - But Great Modem Nonetheless!Overall great modem, but not worth the upgrade from a 6141 or even 6121 for that matter unless you're on a 500 MBP/s or better which MANY Americans are NOT on, but it is worth while if you're lucky enough to have a GIGABIT connection but unlikely to take advantage of even a GIGABIT connection as these modems would be the bottleneck, especially because all of them have only 4 upload channels.I have a 100 MBPS Comcast connection in, SLC, UTAH. L-THEANINE is an amino acid analogue of the proteinogenic amino acids L-glutamate and L-glutamine and is found primarily in particular plant and fungal species. It was discovered as a constituent of green tea in 1949 and in 1950 was isolated from gyokuro leaves, which have high theanine content.[3] Appearance of the name "theanine" without a prefix is understood to imply the L-enantiomer, which is the form found in fresh teas and in some, but not all dietary supplements. The opposite D-enantiomer has far less studied pharmacologic properties, but is present in racemic chemical preparations, and substantially in some studied theanine supplements.As an analogue of glutamate and glutamine, the theanine in common preparations (teas, enantiomer supplements, etc.) is absorbed in the small intestine after oral ingestion; its hydrolysis is to L-glutamate and ethylamine and occurs both in the intestine and liver. It can also cross the blood–brain barrier intact, and register pharmacological effects directly.As for me, did I like the product? I did! All BRI products I have tested are of quality and have worked well for me. It helps relax me at night and get me to bed at a decent time.---------------------------DISCLOSURE---------------------------I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promised that my review is fair and honest with no bias.

-------------------------------REVIEW-------------------------------I've been been a big Netgear router fanboy for a long time, simply because they make quality stuff, but at a premium. I recently got the opportunity to review the TP-LINK AC3200 router, and I must admit I was thoroughly impressed on ever level, so much in fact that I gave away my Netgear Nighthawk R7000 router and kept the TP-LINK AC3200 router for my home.I've always loved the Netgear UI as its cleanly laid out, easy to navigate and just overall easy to use. I've used a lot of other brand routers from Cisco/Linksys, ASUS, DLINK, Ubiquiti, Netgear and now TP-LINK. The TP-LINK UI easily rivals Netgears for the #1 UI for a router that I have used, keep in mind that is a subjective opinion and nothing more. The TP-LINK UI is extremely clean, more so than Netgear in my opinion, it's very easy to navigate and use.The initial setup is very easy and it offers the more advanced setup for the more tech savvy individuals. With the 1GHz CPU the UI is very fast and powerful, no lag that I experienced. One of my favorite features of the AC3200 router is that it is TRI-BAND, you can have 3 simultaneous bands running, one 2.4GHz, and two 5GHz bands, they also have a "Smart Connect" feature which is awesome as it intelligently load balances each band and combines the SSIDs into one for a more seamless experience. It has 6 external antennas that actually work and provide very adequate range for medium to larger homes.I also like that this router offers a smaller footprint than I expected for an AC3200 router, much smaller than the Netgear Nighthawks series routers. The only real complaint that I have is that it doesn't have individual LEDs for each LAN port to let you know which individual LAN ports are connected, it only has one LAN LED so it lights up if one, two, three, or four ports are in use and doesn't light up if none of the ports are in use. I would much prefer individual LAN LED port lights myself.-------------------------------PRODUCT FEATURES-------------------------------- Tri-Band technology creates 3 separate Wi-Fi bands for connecting more devices to your network- Smart Connect helps devices run faster by assigning them to the best available channel- Combined 3200Mbps Wi-Fi for lag-free 4K video streaming and gaming across multiple devices- 6 high-performance antennas with Beamforming maximize coverage area and stability- 1GHz dual-core CPU and 3 co-processors handle simultaneous connections without interruption- Intuitive interface and Tether app for easy installation and network management- Industry-leading 2-year warranty and unlimited 24/7 technical support-------------------------------PROS-------------------------------- Awesome Range- Fast & Clean UI- Smart Connect- Good Warranty (2yrs)- 6 External Antennas- Smaller Footprint-------------------------------CONS-------------------------------- No Individual LED LAN Lights-------------------DISCLOSURE-------------------I was supplied a sample for test and evaluation, and I promised that my review is fair and honest with no bias.

---------------------------OVERVIEW---------------------------A large bottle, with 240 capsules is value, good for 120 days or 4 months if taken as directed per the instructions on the bottle.If you have bone and/or joint issues, I highly recommend taking Viva Labs TRIPLE STRENGTH Glucosamine, Chondroitin and MSM. I recently fractured my anterior tibial plateau, very painful and I cannot put any weight on my left leg for 6-8 weeks. My Orthopedist recommended me getting some Glucosamine/Chondroitin to use in conjunction with recovery and some Aleve. I've been taking the Viva Labs TRIPLE STRENGTH Glucosamine, Chondroitin and MSM for about 2 weeks now and my while my leg/joint is feeling better, while I cannot validate if the Viva Labs TRIPLE STRENGTH Glucosamine, Chondroitin and MSM is making and difference, I do believe it is.A recent study published in the Journal of Rheumatology, found glucosamine sulfate to have greater therapeutic effects on joint health than non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). I thought Madden 15 was bad, well Madden 16 is far worse for so many reasons it's sad. First, given it's a new game it's very buggy/glitches. The run game is virtually impossible due to the snail's pace that the Offense is in, it's like in some slow-mo, it's odd. The animations are far worse in 16 than 15 and they are executed extremely slow for some reason. Makes the game virtually unplayable.With the new catch modes, Possession Catch, YAC Catch, Aggressive catch, more and more pathetically, ridiculous improbable catches are made much more often (we can thank ODB JR for this).The game often crashes, loses sync, disconnects from servers.It's bad, keep playing Madden 15 for a few months until this fix all the pathetic issues this game is plagued with.**************************************UPDATED #1 - -9.14.2015**************************************I played Madden 16 this weekend and it had a patch (I assume) to download, it was over 700mb and it has fixed some issues, the running game has improved SOME, but the O-Line is still very slow, and the handoff is slower than it should be IMO. It's definitely better, The game is more playable at this moment, from last time I played, but still has some patching.**************************************UPDATED #2 - 10.23.2015**************************************The game has become better and more enjoyable with the new patches, roster updates, likeness updates, etc but ONLINE play is still plagued with issues, crashes, glitches, and cheaters which make it very frustrating to play online. I have attached pics of the most common online issues.STILL SEARCHING:When looking for an online game, it gives you a predicted time measurement it will take until it can place you into a game. RARELY is it accurate, I tend to wait much longer than expected, and YES MY NAT IS OPEN!STILL WAITING...:FAILED TO START GAMES:This happens a lot when trying to play, game just crashes.**************************************UPDATED #3 - 11.17.2015**************************************I still get a lot of FAILED TO START GAMES errors when I play online, which is what I mainly do, but after a few tries or rebooting the game, it usually works. Its rather annoying and I wish it was not an issue but it is, but nothing that completely ruins the game like the issues in the beginning.The game overall has improved since the patches and weekly (it seems) roster updates. Much more enjoyable and playable as well. I am increasing my review to a 4-STAR review as of Nov. 17th 2015.

I am reviewing a paperback edition. Most/all of the other reviews seem to refer to the Kindle digital version. I got my hardcopy free at a Poetic Review event in Chinatown Los Angeles in June 2014. Thanks!The narrative is a dystopic view. Set in Shanghai, but not confined to it. A backdrop of news references trickles throughout the story, telling us of dire straits elsewhere in the world. The authors allude to a global recession brought on by a rampant capitalism. No doubt inspired by the recent and some would say ongoing Great Recession.Whether you agree or not with this, the story still makes compelling attention. The minimalist nature of the drawings and dialog leave much (if not most) to your imagination. Fill in by necessity. This style perhaps would not appeal to those used to the much richer illustrasting content of conventional cartoon magazines. But it seems to enhance the Shanghai noir.

The book looks at a hitherto neglected field of architecture. Commercial buildings, and particularly for Los Angeles up to 1941. Nothing in the book is about the grand artistic buildings most often admired. But instead at how the utilitarian needs of retail merged with the rise of the car. In Los Angeles, the easy mild climate led to innovations in what was called a drive-in. Which is not the drive in of later years for showing movies.Instead, the drive-in was the mini-mall of its time. For a new mobile working and middle class to easily shop. The book has many photos of key buildings. The narrative explains how the drive-in was then succeeded by the supermarket. Fundamentally, by the 1940s, the new supermarkets were essentially the format we know them as today.If you live in LA, you may especially find neat the descriptions in words and images of intersections and neighbourhoods. The photos of buildings are all accompanied with a remark as to whether the buildings are still extent.There is a peccadillo. Many of the photos were taken by a person called "Dick" Wittington. But the photo credits keep repeating this, including his nickname. Tedious. Couldn't the author have shortened the credits, for clarity?

A massive effort that can aid someone working in a Spanish and English chemistry context. I don't know Spanish. But I took chemistry as an undergrad. Neat how when I look at an English word listed here, its Spanish equivalent makes sense. And vice versa. In general, showing a common Latin root in the technical sphere.Note also that it is not just single words that you can look up. Common chemistry phrases are listed as keys also.What is strange is when I looked up English phrases related to semiconductor, I found entries for both 'semiconductor' and 'semi-conductor'. And for 'semiconductor laser' and 'semi-conductor laser'. Why list both with and without the hyphen? In English, the hyphen was largely discarded by the 1970s. It tends to appear only in articles prior.

This volume has a stupendous amount of background on Heinlein and the science fiction culture he inhabited, and indeed helped craft. For this, you should be always grateful. We see that even for a successful writer, bills always loomed in an eternal treadmill.What is neat is some flesh on the backstories of the stories. Like how Tunnel in the Sky was originally called School in the Sky. But Heinlein acceeded to an editor's request to amend the title because few students would buy the original title. There is also a neat and by now well known anecdote that the main character is a Negro !! Not in so many words, but if you parse the narrative carefully, this becomes clear. Heinlein's way of tweaking the system.The paths of other major authors cross the pages. Apparently, one of the best known Star Trek episodes, The Trouble with Tribbles by David Gerrold, was a blatant imitation of an earlier Heinlein story. The biography says that Heinlein graciously declined to sue Gerrold, but makes clear that he had a strong case. What may grate is when Gerrold then goes on to exploit his Tribbles story with toy tribbles etc. In this, Heinlein comes off as perhaps a little too indulgent.Another anecdote is about The Mote in God's Eye by Niven and Pournelle. Perhaps their first major joint success. The book relates that they sent Heinlein a preprint. Which he then copiously critiqued, suggesting that they discard the first 30 pages or so and use a more gripping start to hold the reader's attention. Heinlein did commend that the Moties seemed like a genuinely alien race. He did not expect Niven and Pournelle to actually abide by his advice, based on his earlier extensive experience with other writers. But amazingly they did, to the extent of withdrawing their book from publication and doing a large rewrite.

The tone (spirit) of this book differs markedly from that of other technical books I commonly get. The author uses a very informal means of introducing the topic. Which is appropriate because Prezi is a very distinctive way of visually presenting material, where the latter can be text or graphics. In general, as you can see from the book, the material will have many instances of both.Prezi is shown as an infinite canvas. But you are advised to start by just focusing on 3 top level tasks - define the goal, message and audience. In itself, without recourse to using any computer package, thinking this way can be a great help when you start out and want to write down a talk that you will later give. Of course, this is not new to Prezi. Similar advice was available decades ago, when you might have had to do all this by hand, having no computer in sight.In a way, this is the power of Prezi. It takes you back to essentials. The computer is just a secondary tool. But using Prezi arrays the top level ideas and the lower level topics into a spatial arrangement on the canvas that is quick to grasp.A key aspect of Prezi is what they call frames. Where you can group the topics on the canvas into clusters. And then move these around, treating all the topics enclosed in a frame as one entity. This is a natural top down decomposition. Then when enough frames have been defined, you can make a path through these frames. The path is the presentation order.Scattered throughout the narrative are good pieces of advice for presentations. Like 'avoid large blocks of text'. Use images if possible, to engage the audience. And if you use drawings, keep them simple.

It mostly works. But the fundamental limitation is the small size of the embedded antenna. When I use it in my laptop, and start moving away from a Wifi hotspot, the bandwidth can fall markedly. By comparison, an antenna embedded into the laptop can take advantage of the much larger size of the laptop.The limitation is due to the basic physical properties of any antenna.That said, maybe if your computer will be close to a hotspot, then this adapter may be suitable.

Don't take the 'anime' in the title too literally. It is not restricted to the anime style of cartoons from Japan. Rather, Anime Studio is a simple framework within which to draw most any style of cartoons. The book can be used as a guide for the rank beginner in the basics. From writing down a first draft, which the text warns you is likely to be terrible, to making a storyboard. And these days, to providing audio sound track if your characters will speak.So it has to be noted that the cartoons here are typically not destined for celluloid, as in the 20th century. But more often meant for display in a web page. A major attraction is that the book shows how you as a beginner can affordably put together a professional looking composition.Anime Studio is stuffed with many easily learnt tools accessed via a rich GUI. Drawing of figures has been made as simple as perhaps possible.If you come from a background in graphics, especially with Photoshop, then many concepts will be familiar. Including the idea of layers. Anime Studio fully supports layers, with specialised tools like Transform Layer and Follow Path. Great time savers, and that is really what layering is all about.But the most important aspect of Anime Studio might be bone animation. So instead of a character being a raw set of pixels, it is a set of graphics with an underlying skeleton. By manipulating its bones, you can rapidly and intuitively animate the character. Looks easy to use.

Very neat that the book immediately commences with a non-trivial real world application of two factor authentication. Stringer shows the reader that a useful technique for verifying a user can be easily done with your website ringing her phone. The most important context is for purchasing, when actual money is meant to change hands. The source code is only a few pages and you should probably read it carefully to see how Twilio's libraries enable the entire operation. The point is that the example will present the user with a form on the browser where she types in a username and phone number, presumably of a cellphone though it could also be a nearby landline. The browser is assumed to be showing on her laptop or desktop. The example makes a one time password which is then sent as a text message to the phone. She reads it and then types it into the browser.The second example of the first chapter is showing how to record a phone call. Where the recorded message can then be sent to an email address you designate. As with the first example, this leads to a foray into the Twilio Helper Library for PHP.Later chapters give other examples of course. But Stringer made good and I am sure very deliberate choices in the opening chapter to grab your attention. The early examples will be a propos to many sysadmins and developers of commercial websites. Overall, you can use this book to make a rudimentary but practical IVR [Interactive Voice Response] system. Essentially free in terms of software running on generic hardware. Whereas if you bought a commercial IVR hardware package, the cost can easily run into thousands of dollars. Granted, the vendors of those will affirm that their systems offer more options. True. But if you only need the basics, this book and Twilio might suffice.

At first I thought Ouya [I'm not going to capitalise it all] was a software engine; not being a hardcore gameboy. But it is hardware! Wow! So used to reviewing books on software that this makes a refreshing change. What the text suggests is that getting the Ouya gives you a leg up in developing games of professional quality. A hardware IDE. On top of this sits the Unity3D engine and the book takes you into coding with C#.The first chapter is really more important than in some other books, because it orients you in the Ouya environment. Where the store that you can browse for games does not list prices! Quickly the book explains that for a game to make it into the store, it needs at least one free element. Like free play credits.There is an immediate dynamic tension here. You after all are likely reading the book to want to code successful games. That people will pay money to play. So really seeing the game store with no prices is not exactly encouraging.Now for the game store, the book cautions that "the games are often smaller and less expensive... because of the abundant indie presence". What this translates to is that a typical game is simply not as impressive. The book does not come right out and say this, but reading between the lines, that is what you get. The indie developers [and you aspire to be one of them] just don't have the financial wherewithal to underwrite a sophisticated and complex game.The book is somewhat pitched towards a new programmer. Because in part it introduces object oriented programming as a new concept. And I am not really sure why they chose C# instead of java or C++. But that's not a big deal. If indeed you don't know any of those languages, learning C# will certainly help you if you have to migrate to the others.The game development environment explicated later in the book looks simple enough. Like using the IDE to pick a shader and then having the means via a GUI to vary the shininess and specular colour. Very easy and intuitive. Plus, learning Unity's classes greatly speeds up the coding of your game.The text takes you all the way through to submitting a game to the Ouya store. What it does not discuss is the top level decision about whether you want to deal with Ouya in the first place. Professionally, Ouya is likely not where the money is; not where the big time is. Just be aware of that, once you parse thru all the book.

This book might not serve well anyone seriously trying to get into the finance world by programming applications in Python. On a more optimistic note, the book might be better directed at an undergraduate who has read about topics like Black Scholes pricing of options. And who wants to quickly code some simple test programs. The back of the book says it is useful for practitioners. Nonsense. Practitioners in finance already have scads of far more complex programs for modelling.Each chapter of the book basically is a simple rendition of code for the chapter topic. Somewhat superficial. As another reviewer perhaps accurately observed, it is as though the author just went through Wikipedia and dragged out several finance topics and the starting equations. And then coded those into chapters.One good aspect is that the text describes how to use two standard Python modules, NumPy and SciPy. For numerical scientific and financial contexts. If you do end up using this book, you should absolutely learn how to use the routines in those modules. First, the modules have been extensively debugged and are being freely maintained. Second, you add more value for yourself by starting there rather than wasting your time recoding their routines. Though granted, an exception could be where you explicitly want to recode some of their routines as a learning experience for yourself.

Is this a cautionary tale, a foray into the mind of a stalker? Or a reminder of the explosive nature of social media? The type of novel that becomes a guilty secret, You is compulsively readable until the great flood of voyeurism turns brackish and tainted, as irritating as a young woman’s careless neglect of her personal belongings or obliviousness to the smell of the garbage in the shoebox-sized apartment in which she lives, everything strewn with the detritus of a shamelessly narcissistic existence. This is the world of Guinevere Beck (who prefers to be called “Beck”), a college graduate living in school-sponsored housing while she pursues a writing program in New York City.It all begins when Beck walks into an East Village bookstore managed by Joe Goldberg, an attractive autodidact who has never gone to college, but easily holds his own in a literate, bantering conversation with Beck. Joe is an unapologetic sociopath who fixates on Beck, a flirt thriving on the attention of men that can’t help but flaunt her sexuality before a willing audience. Just another encounter with an attractive man becomes the catalyst of an obsession for Joe, whose interest, at first innocent, escalates into a pattern of behavior that grows from voyeurism to the infiltration of Beck’s social media, emails, tweets, Face Book posts, every aspect of her life available to the insatiably curious would-be lover. Joe knows they belong together, that it is just a matter of time, and carefully managed synchronicity, that will turn them into a couple.It is a sly and detailed seduction, a manipulation of people and circumstances to bring Beck and Joe together as lovers, Joe endlessly forgiving and understanding of Beck’s many flaws, the object of his passion yet to realize how perfectly suited they are for one another. Though Beck’s pursuit of an unworthy boyfriend tests the patience of her closest friends, Joe has contingency plans; when Beck’s wealthy, possessive girlfriend intrudes, Joe is prepared to wait for Beck to come to her senses. Joe can afford to be patient. He now has access to every minute detail of Beck’s life.In point of fact, the couple may be well matched, author Kepnes balancing Joe’s pathology with Beck’s overweening narcissism, social media the vehicle of their fated, albeit unhealthy love affair. As events accelerate and Beck moves closer to the circle of Joe’s arms, there are disturbing echoes of American Psycho, unburdened by the heavy-handed misogyny that marks that novel, Joe a predator strolling through a city of women enamored of technology, the land of “selfies” and self-obsession. This landscape is peopled with the young, no place for the elderly, save the retired owner of the bookstore Joe manages. Haunting, shocking or repellant, this is a tale for the times. In the words of T.S. Eliot in “The Hollow Men: “This is the way the world ends. Not with a bang but a whimper.” Luan Gaines/2014.

The latest must-have for little shoppers-in-training, the Shopkins “Small Mart” has all the touches of a real supermarket experience for children 3 years and up. There’s a little shopping cart that rolls to the check stand, a check stand complete with basket storage, with moving parts and a chute to slide merchandise down before check out.One of a series, the Small Mart is made of bright colored plastic with the appropriate signage to make the experience as authentic as that in the grown-up supermarket. These toys are made for tiny fingers to play with, enjoy and maybe save in a plastic storage box to keep all the small parts together. Given the primary colors, this set is not just for girls, but can be used for boys as well, the perfect opportunity to teach little ones the etiquette of shopping and suggest ways to assist the adult shopper while becoming acquainted with the experience. While some might think such toys are too gender specific or limiting, they are wonderfully useful in training toddlers for new experiences, teaching desirable behavior when out in public and including them in the various aspects of shopping expeditions. Luan Gaines/2014.

I am really impressed with the power of the Black & Decker 3-Cup Ergo Chopper, one of the most efficient little kitchen gadgets I have ever had the pleasure to use. Well-designed and easy to clean, the bottom of the mechanism is dishwasher safe, easy to empty- and has the added advantage of use for storage of the chopped item when some is left over. The chopper makes cooking easier and faster. It is recommended to start with the slow speed before using the faster one, to get the feel of the chopper and how quickly it reduces an item to the desired amount, whether chopped onions or fresh fruit for a smoothie. I have been waiting for just such an item to add to my kitchen, compact, handy and able to do the little jobs I need in meal preparation. I heartily recommend this Black & Decker Chopper to anyone looking for that handy kitchen helper. Luan Gaines/2014.

In Alaska, the remote village of Keelut is suffering famine that has turned the wilderness savage, children stolen from outside their cabins to slake the hunger of wolves. The winds howl with the mourning voices of those who cannot reclaim what has been taken in nature’s cruel order: “When kids are killed, the future dies.” Authorities avoid the village, knowing they will find no answers from those who resist intruders, take care of their own. All the more surprising then, when grieving mother Medora Sloane begs author Russell Core to help her find her six-year-old son, Bailey, or at least his bones for burial. Having written a book on wolves, Core has a deep affinity for their ways, their intelligence, unsure why this woman might think he could help, yet drawn by her need and his own flirtation with a place where death might come easily to a weary traveler.Knowing nothing of this place or these people, Core finds Medora a surprise, bright-haired and white-skinned, certainly an anomaly among the others. Sleeping on the couch in a tiny cabin where the boy’s empty boots are a reminder of his absence, Core cannot but be aware of the mother’s murmuring at night, her vigil by the window, her incantations to the moon. Medora’s husband, Vernon, is due to return any day from a tour of duty in the Middle East, his brutal reality in the shifting sands across the globe in stark contrast to the blinding snow that covers Keelut, portending a difficult, if impossible search, Russell dressed in Vernon’s hunting garb and boots.As anticipated, the journey proves fruitless, though Core barely escapes the snarling wolves he tracks in search of the boy. Near-frozen, exhausted, he returns to the village to find Medora missing, a shocking discovery at hand, one that brings the authorities streaming into Keelut, Vernon come home to a nightmare worse than the one he has lived on foreign soil. Not yet acclimated to the ways of civilization, Sloane’s reaction initiates a violent, brutal series of events, revealing a great chasm of fury, inconsolable grief and rage. Yet amid the chaos, the death, the author’s prose is stark, often arresting and compelling, capturing the unapologetic cruelty, the relentless demands of life and death in a place where the flesh of children fills the bellies of starving animals, where compassion is trampled under the boots of men.It is Giraldi’s ability to balance the extremes of place and emotion that imbues his novel with unexpected allegiances, from Russell’s courting of death in a land where it is easy to die to Medora’s motivation in asking for help, from Vernon’s friend Cheeon’s last stand against the breach of his fortress home to the love between Vernon and Medora and the death of their son. It is a tapestry woven tightly with ragged threads, the knotted string of impropriety and outrage, the blood red of carnage and the still-white of a snowstorm, a land that embraces the aberrant, the desperate and the brave, my own twisted hope joining the tangled mess, a hope that the guilty might escape, survive the devastation left behind. Luan Gaines/2014.

Though perhaps the least mysterious of French’s novels thus far, The Secret Place explores an unexpected complexity of character and theme, beginning with the anonymous postings by teenage girls on “The Secret Place”, a message board supplied by the exclusive St. Kilda’s Girls’ Academy. Though hopelessly archaic and rigid, the school is making an effort to circumvent the distraction and mischief of social media, replete with a strict headmistress, pious nuns and school uniforms. Certainly, the unsolved death of a young man from a neighboring academy, discovered on St. Kilda’s campus, has proven that crime can intrude even in the most controlled environment.During the summer break, angst over the tragic and brutal murder of Chris Harper has seemed to dissipate, only to erupt once more when fifteen-year-old Holly Mackey, marches into Dublin’s Cold Case squad room and hands a photograph she found posted on “The Secret Place” directly to Detective Stephen Moran, who treated her with dignity on a former case when Holly was a witness. The picture is made more cryptic by the cut-out words around the dead boy’s image: “I know who killed him.” The fact that Holly’s father is an established detective adds yet another level of complication as the novel unfolds over the course of one long, grueling day.French sets the stage for drama with two scenarios: a renewed police investigation by Dublin’s Murder Squad led by Detective Antoinette Conway; and the events at St. Kilda’s that lead to Chris’ death. In alternating chapters, past and present, the investigation- during which Detective Moran makes his play for a place on the Murder Squad- and the evolution of a murder, the author creates a contrast between the relentless push to force the girls to reveal the truth and the slower, often claustrophobic examination of the intricacies of friendship among four students, Holly, Selena, Julia and Rebecca and their nemesis, popular and powerful Joanna Heffernan and her clique (nicknamed “the Daleks”), a conflict of values and character in which Chris Harper becomes a central figure.Equally fascinating is the relationship of Moran to the only female on the Murder Squad, a prickly, tough detective who demands the best from him and challenges his private ambitions in unexpected ways. The juxtaposition of these diverse elements, the renewed and more rigorous investigation and the truth behind the murder is brilliantly facilitated, the reader intent on learning the secrets behind Harper’s death, then thrust into the agonizing territory of teen loyalties, friendships and betrayals, the inevitable, shattering cracks when life intrudes. French never misses a beat. Luan Gaines/2014.

As jewel-like as the exquisitely made rooms of a miniature house replicating the townhouse where Nella Brandt has come to live with her new husband in 1896 Amsterdam, Burton captures the claustrophobic atmosphere of a marriage rife with secrets in a city where “the austerity and oppressiveness of Calvinism converges with an obsession of wealth and acquisition”. While the marriage of successful merchant Johannes Brandt and Petronella Oortman has yet to be consummated, the new bride has left all behind in her rural village, prepared to make a new life with a husband she has yet to know. And in the same manner that hypocrisy is veiled behind the fine mannerisms of successful people, Nella learns the extent of the subterfuges hidden behind the closed door of the townhouse, the urgency of showing a placid face to society while riddled with uncertainty and fear.Having learned well the danger of having nothing to do, Johannes gifts his new bride with the cabinet-sized replica, hoping she will be content filling its rooms, albeit sleeping alone while Johannes works in his study or at the office, learning that “her husband speaks in all tongues but that of love.” Left to her own devices, Nella faces daily the other inhabitants of the house: Marin, her strict, disdainful sister-in-law, a spinster who abhors frivolity and waste; Cornelia, an overly-familiar maid; and most shocking, Otto, Johannes’ manservant and the first dark-skinned man Nella has ever met. The strange trio keeps the house running smoothly so that Johannes is free to add to their fortune with his trading skills, all of them adept at keeping secrets and sweeping scandal into corners. But eventually Nella stumbles upon a scenario that rips the blinders from her eyes. Meanwhile small, tidy packages arrive from a miniaturist Nella has contracted to make items for the doll’s house in a small rebellion against Marin’s rules and the abject loneliness of her daily existence.As Nella’s innocence is stripped away and Johannes travels abroad, pursuing buyers for a warehouse full of sugar threatening to rot, she cannot decide if the craftsman of these tiny replicas is a prophet of the future of a sorcerer intent on the destruction of the family, occurrences at home replicated with eerie prescience as though they are all being watched. Confined behind the walls of an unhappy, even disastrous marriage, an uncertain fate looms over this small group, the bustling world around them intolerant of weakness, sin or financial ruin. Nella learns that everything she thinks is based in misperception, challenged to face reality, to embrace this strange and broken “family” and move forward. In prose that perfectly captures late 17th century Amsterdam, both the tiny, life-like dolls and the human characters confront private weakness, venality, courage and hidden passions, The Miniaturist is a small gem, where insight and compassion animate the lives of characters caught in a dark tide of history, where salvation lurks in the love for one another that illuminates their hearts. Luan Gaines/2014.

Much as I love the trend, fashion scarves present a particular problem when deciding how best to store them. Smooth and unwrinkled when purchased, a few weeks in a drawer can make this easy accessory looking unkempt. There are some scarves that are meant to look scrunchy or wrinkled and for those a drawer is fine, but for the smooth ones with fringe, only hanging will keep them looking fresh. That’s where this product offers a solution to ready-to-wear accessories without taking up a lot of space. Each Interdesign Horizontal Scarf Holder holds at least four long scarves, but is not limited to that number. In addition, the wider hanger keeps the unit from drooping to one side or another, spilling scarves on the closet floor. For those with space issues looking for storage solutions, this product answers the need to keep closets orderly while clothing and accessories remain easy to reach. It may have other uses as well for similar items, but for anyone with too many scarves and no place to hang them, this is a perfect, simple solution.

There is nothing less attractive in a kitchen than a well-used bottle of dish soap and sponge, so  I had great plans for this product. From what I could tell in the onscreen image, this combination soap and sponge holder is perfect for tidying up a messy problem and keeping kitchen clutter to a minimum. I was surprised that the soap dispenser, while as pictured, was larger than expected. And what I thought was a metal lid/dispenser was instead made of plastic. (In my experience, these tops don’t hold up well to daily use, the finish gradually chipping away.) So, contrary to expectations, this dispenser will not suit my needs. That’s not to say someone else won’t like it- it certainly does what it says and is sturdy and well-made (but for the faux-metal top). So overall, this product is quite acceptable and doesn’t put on airs. I guess my kitchen countertop needs are a bit precious, my kitchen harboring pretensions (even with its outdated tile countertops and lack of stainless steel appliances). A wannabe kitchen can dream, can’t it?

At first appearance, this product seems to be a worthwhile purchase. But once the product is plugged in, its poor design is apparent. Without the clip that holds the hair to the barrel, the user must wrap the hair around the barrel and hold it with the “heatproof” glove provided. First surprise: the glove isn’t heatproof! If the fingers burn so readily, what damage might this wand do the hair? Second surprise: the curls are very loose. It would take an hour to do a full head of hair, even medium length.Frankly, I am surprised that a company with Remington’s reputation wouldn’t do more product research before putting this item on the shelf. It is not only unsatisfactory, but below the quality expected from hair styling products currently available to consumers. Big disappointment. I would really like to give this product no stars. Luan Gaines/2014.

The minds of teens are fertile, often given to catastrophic thinking (“If I can’t have a certain boyfriend/ coveted pair of shoes/ tickets to a concert, I’ll die.”) and the need to belong. Girlfriends Gabby, Deenie and Lise, all students at Dryden High, are no exception- until the day when Lise is taken by a strange fit in class. When the others learn that Lise has been taken to the local hospital in critical condition, they eagerly indulge in rampant speculation about the cause of her hospitalization, every opinion exacerbated and embellished on social media. Lise has become a male magnet since morphing into a young woman with the curves to turn admirers’ heads, occasioning much gossip and not a little envy from her peers. Gabby, one of the trio, is so stylish that a loyal following emulates her style of dress and affectations, Deenie’s friend since their first days in grade school.
