Of the three, Deenie Nash is the most level-headed, living with her brother Eli, a hockey star and her father, Tom, a teacher at the school, their mother having left the family for greener pastures, taking her children for random visits, essentially unreliable in a pinch.As Lise’s unknown medical condition becomes the fulcrum for a crisis built of rumor and fear, the school is slowly infected, one by one, other girls falling prey to strange fits, like the one that delivered Lise to an unknown fate. The template is set, the school-and social media- a breeding ground for rumor, the fits feeding on one unsuspecting teen after another, all of them girls. While the school attempts to quell the concerns of parents and students, both medical and police officials arrive to ascertain what exactly has happened at Dryden High, parent meetings a source of conflict and demands for action, Lise’s mother hiring a lawyer, everyone frantic to stop the epidemic that has devastated their town. And while her two best friends have fallen prey to the mysterious ailment, unfortunately Deenie has not, a source of gossip for those who wonder why. Shades of the Salem witch trial, when a group of hysterical young women garnered attention for their antics, claiming possession by the devil and naming witches among them.Clearly, Abbott is mining this hysterical event for her modern day cautionary tale about the susceptibility of teen girls and the dramatic excesses that come so naturally to them. Yet there is more at work than happenstance in this novel, which examines the tenuous relationships of girls at this critical time in their lives, many of those involved coming from fatherless homes and various dysfunctional situations, real malice at the heart of it, albeit with less drastic intentions. Narrated from various perspectives, Deenie’s, Eli’s, Tom Nash’s, etc., much time is spent in that bewildering landscape where girlhood clashes with impending womanhood, betrayals and gossip the tools of the trade. Though it all makes sense as the novel winds to a close, I found the plot tedious and too often overwrought, marketed for a broader audience but clearly most appropriate for young adults, who will find this topic relevant and eerily familiar. For this demographic, the young adult, it makes perfect sense, a chilling tale for the right reader. For others, not so much.Luan Gaines/2014,

Burley’s first thriller starts out with a harrowing chase through the woods of Wintersville, Ohio, a boy pursued by a killer who ravages and mutilates the victim’s body. Beyond the outrage and repulsion of authorities who discover the victim, the town is horrified that such a thing could happen in their community. Given the brutality of the attack, officials are determined to find the monster that would inflict such damage on another human being before more victims suffer the same fate. Without knowing the identity of the victim, anguished parents await the return of their students from local schools, frantic to have their children safe at home. Among them are medical examiner Ben Stevenson and his wife Susan, who have moved their boys, Joel and Thomas, from Pittsburgh to avoid the stresses of big city life. Grateful to know their older son, Thomas wasn’t the body found in the bloody snow, the grateful couple cannot help but imagine the grief facing the parents of the dead boy. After a call from the Chief of Police, Sam Garston, Ben heads to the coroner’s office to receive the tattered remains of the killer’s prey.Burley sets the tenor of his mystery from the start, the savage brutality of the crime, the medical examiner’s empathy for both victims and those left to mourn them, a father relieved that his family is saved and a member of a community shocked to the core. With only a few peeks into the mind of the killer, the author focuses primarily on Stevenson’s reactions and how the case impacts his wife and family, the grueling examination causing haunting nightmares as he struggles to imagine the savagery of the perpetrator. His fear affects the family, as Ben tries to limit Thomas’s nighttime excursions, causing rebellion and resentment on the home front. But when Monica Dressler is attacked after a local party, a member of Thomas’s own social group, the horror strikes closer to home. Authorities are obsessed with finding the perpetrator, Ben in the middle of the investigation and noticing cracks in the domestic harmony he has counted on at home.Between the details of the investigation and Ben’s concerns at home, Burley creates a picture of a beleaguered town and its fearful inhabitants, a man surrounded by the realities of mortality and the problems of parenting two boys with a suddenly less communicative wife. From one clue to another, one suspect to another, the search is futile for the overworked detectives, the tension more palpable over time. Burley finishes off his tale with an unexpected turn of events that is both unpredictable and nearly as horrifying as the murder in the opening pages. He doesn’t pull any punches, either in detail or his protagonist’s depth of emotion and distress, from the first autopsy to the final pages. For a first novel, Burley has written a fearless foray into the stuff of nightmares, the kind that never end. Luan Gaines/2013.

Stone's drama revolves around the impetuous behavior of the brilliant and beautiful Maud Stack, a student and a New England college who is deep in the throes of a love affair with her mentor, Professor Steven Brookman. Unused to rebuffs, Maud has thrown herself at the man who is in thrall to her intelligence and hubris, her unique combination of brains and beauty irresistible to a man who has dabbled in infidelity with other professors, but never tasted of the forbidden fruit, a student. Oblivious to Brookman's warnings of the imminent return of his wife and daughter from a visit to family in Canada, Maud has fashioned a future for them, shutting out reality in her determination. Flitting through campus from one class to another, Maud and her roommate Shelby, navigate the throngs of homeless who wander the campus, detour around the haranguing pro-life picketers waving placards of dead babies. Infuriated, Maud writes an article for the college newspaper, excoriating the picketers, annihilating their beliefs with vicious irony, Maud leaves her article to Brookman's critique, which never happens, in spite of frequent calls from Maud.Maud's calls go unanswered while Brookman ruminates on how best to end the affair, preoccupied with his wife's return and rationalizing his behavior. Furious at his refusal to answer his calls, Maud demands an answer, only to learn the truth that Brookman wants the romance to end. Brokenhearted, Maud escapes to New York, where her widower father, ex-cop Eddie, faces a daily struggle with emphysema and a lifetime of regrets, Maud the only star in his heaven. Burying her sorrows in drunkenness, Maud is in an agony of rage, returning to campus in the midst of the furor that has arisen from her article, including death threats. But all is a blur as Maud stakes out Brookman's home, intent on calling him out. Pain and outrage begets tragedy as the confrontation escalates, a crowd gathers and a young woman's life is extinguished. Deceptively simple, the central drama is infused with the broader complications of a society compromised by intolerance, the supporting characters adding more layers to what becomes a microcosm of the larger world: the abundance of the homeless and mentally ill; the ideals of youth clashing with the inflamed passions of pro-life activists; a father's helpless outrage at the loss of his daughter; an unfaithful man's useless guilt after the fact.Stone's supporting characters allow the broader discussion of events, from an historical, practical and cultural perspective, the weight of religion in public controversy, the tendency to extremes instead of compromise, the certainty (sanctity) of beliefs in conflict with those who reject ideology, from contemporary Roman Catholic scandals to a mission in South America that slid into fanaticism, terror and blood sacrifice, atavistic urges still simmering years later. Pulling all of this into a cohesive narrative is one of Stone's particular skills, his work delving beyond the surface of events to cause and effect, the impact of religious belief in the course of history, the conflict between changing mores and morality. Maud's short life and ugly death, her ill-fated romance, are but a moment in the vast canvas of a society unable to make peace with its differences, a thoughtful and provocative novel reminding me why I have missed his writing. Luan Gaines/2013.

Detective Chief Inspector Andy Gilchrist of Scotland's St. Andrews Division of the Constabulatory's Crime Management Department, is consumed by a mystery that melds past and present in a cycle of imminent threat and long-buried secrets when the skeleton of a long-dead young woman is discovered in an excavated grave. Dated thirty-five years earlier, the time frame coincides with the death of Gilchrist's brother, the victim of a never-solved hit and run accident. Mourning the death of his remarried ex-wife and struggling with difficult relationships with both his children, Andy avoids the problems of his personal life through a case that taxes both memory and instincts. Given the macabre circumstances of the discovery, the unidentified remains create a high-profile nightmare for authorities, the pressure building on Andy as he interviews familiar faces from the past and tries to recreate the conditions of the murder. At the same time, an unexpected- and unwelcome- clue leads Gilchrist to look into his brother's death, fearful that the two are somehow related.Muir captures the essence of time and place, a society inevitably changed by the passage of time, old secrets long-buried and threatening to undo the reputations of those who once knew the young woman. The bones identified as belonging to Kelly Roberts, Gilchrist travels to America to interview the girl's mother. But he is working against time, in the sights of a nemesis that would use any misstep to bring Andy down. Then there is the bizarre appearance of author/psychic Gina Belli, who pushes her way into the care in the guise of writing a book about Andy's cases, hovering on the periphery with insights and dire warnings that serve to unnerve an already overburdened detective. The plot moves forward, potential suspects falling into place, though time has muddied critical evidence and Andy's pursuit of the hit-and-run driver puts him in further jeopardy. A believable and empathetic character, Muir's Andy Gilchrist has all the right instincts and just enough human flaws to make him an interesting and effective protagonist. Luan Gaines/2013.

In an ongoing experiment with alternative history, Anderson posits the scenario of a son born to Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn, William (Henry IX), who has recently attained the age of eighteen. Chafing against his advisors, particularly the heavy hand of his uncle George Boleyn, Duke of Rochford, who bears the title of Lord Protector, William seeks to prove himself equal to the demands of kingship. As in the first book of the trilogy (The Boleyn King), political intrigue is rife, from those who seek to replace William on the throne with Mary Tudor and provide proof of his less-than-royal birth to the usual strife between Protestant and Catholic factions in England. The characters are familiar, their dramas exacerbated by William's willfulness and refusal to listen to advice, even from his best friend, Dominic. The foursome of the first novel is still intact" William, his sister Elizabeth, Dominic and Minuette, who was raised with the Tudor children and nurtures a secret love for Dominic. Robert Dudley hovers around the periphery of the group, enamored of Elizabeth, albeit burdened by the accusation of treason against his father.Complicit in a dangerous plot to unseat William in The Boleyn King, Minuette is privy to the plots afoot, unafraid to pursue her own investigations, even though her behavior puts her in danger. Unfortunately, a situation has developed among the four friends, William planning behind closed doors what he dare not admit in public, drawing both Dominic and Minuette into complicity despite their advise to pursue the expected course for the good of the kingdom. Once more, Minuette is caught up in the unfolding political drama, as Anderson expands the political landscape with new characters that reflect historical reality. Though well-plotted and fluidly written, it is difficult to acclimate to the alternative circumstances of the author's premise, or to invest fully in a novel that has no basis in fact. For lovers of historical fiction, it is an entertaining diversion, though built on a what-if that didn't. Luan Gaines/2013

The AmazonBasics Laptop Backpack is relatively inexpensive, but certainly meets the need for which it is designed. The design is functional, durable and attractive. For the reasonable price, the material is adequate for regular use. The main compartment is spacious enough to securely hold a laptop and other necessary items (files, notebooks, etc.) There are two outside zippered compartments, each with space for carrying extra materials and an open mesh pockets on each side, straps to go over the wearer's shoulders. The laptop is well-protected inside the main compartment, secure while transporting. While ideally used for laptop transport, this backpack can work just as well for carrying papers and books, plenty of room allowed inside and in the exterior zippered pockets, with the reinforced section for adding a laptop when needed. Lightweight, the backpack provides protection for a computer without the extra burden of heavy fabrication. In gray and black, the look is contemporary and stylish. As the primary means of laptop transport (for students and travelers) or for use in lieu of more expensive products, the backpack is a good investment and a great gift idea for a student. Luan Gaines/2013.

This Genius Energy Mouse delivers what it promises, both portable and effective, whether charging my iPhone or in use with my laptop. Although it is a bit large for my hand, the design is comfortable and presents no real problem once I have gotten used to it. I like the dual battery feature and the ease with which it tracks. It's certainly a bonus for travelers, even those who only go short distances, but need to schlep their devices from place to place. It seems such a simple idea-  that is the beauty of this mouse, a practical solution for charging up a phone, yet also effective, scrolling easily on a variety of surfaces. Now that I am used to a wireless mouse, I have no intention of going back. I like the freedom of movement the wireless one offers, even on my home computer. I'm not particularly tech savvy in terms of its power and adaptability, but any new item that makes my life easier on the go is a welcome addition. I am very happy with The Genius Energy Mouse and will recommend it to others who are looking for items in a reasonable price range. Luan Gaines/2013.

Trivia for one reader is a feast for another. Nissley's A Reader's Book of Days is filled with the arcane and the fascinating, a dreamer's treasure hunt to inspire a return to a favorite author in this literary companion. Nissey- eight-time Jeopardy! champion and former bookseller- captures the lives of authors in diaries and letters, quotations and details, an almanac that expands beyond the usual boundaries to encompass personalities, events and human reactions. An example: "April 15th wasn't just the day that Robinson Crusoe was published, Henry James was born and Edward Gorey died. It's also the day that Walt Whitman mourned the death of Lincoln...and Thomas Higginson received four poems from a woman named Emily Dickenson..." Such is the charm and fascination of this remarkable collection of days, ideas, accomplishments, thoughts, memories and anecdotes. The joy of discovery is experienced in the manner an individual reader approaches the book, whether at random, seeking a particular date, say a birthday, or choosing a favorite name from the index "the historic and the humdrum".Nissley harbors another ambition in this tome, stories from the fictional lives of characters along with their writers, a mix of fact and fiction, where actual events occur, as do fictional events in novels, an ambitious undertaking, but one that adds yet another layer to the collection. Nissey's careful attention to the details of writer's lives- and those of their characters- is a paean to the rich world of writing, "private moments behind public triumphs", the beginnings of our favorite novels, each month introduced with appropriate comments and a list of recommended readings, peppered with black and white illustrations and an expansive index. Luan Gaines/2013.

What do you get when you mix wealth, opportunity, the pressure to excel and the labyrinthine corridors of new technology? Sometimes, murder. When middle school dean and ex-cop Raymond Donne attends the funeral of Douglas Lee, found fatally stabbed under a bridge in Brooklyn, he is at a loss to explain the tragic trajectory of this student's short life, the case currently being treated as a drug-related killing, not a high priority in Williamsburg. Sympathetic to the boy's distraught mother, who begs him to do an article on his former student to keep the pressure on law enforcement, he agrees. With a high-profile uncle in an important position in the department, Donne's recent exploits in another case have inspired a warning not to interfere in police business since he's no longer on the force. Meeting with reporter Allison Rogers at the crime scene the next day, Donne is surprised to see Detective Dennis Murcer there as well, a cop with whom he has some personal history. Murcer is cordial, but guarded, reiterating that Raymond should leave the investigation to the authorities.Donne has two problems at this point: an inability to say no to the dead boy's grieving mother and the innate curiosity of a detective no longer on the force after a serious injury. Despite Murcer's warning, Allison and Raymond are sympathetic to Mrs. Lee, who continues to ask Donne for more favors, all of which draw him deeper into the mystery of Dougie's death, Allison a willing co-conspirator. Frustrated with the lack of progress, Donne does exactly what he was told not to, with predictable results, unanswered questions which he pursues when he's not putting out fires for his students as dean of the middle school. O'Mara has created a believable character, sympathetic toward his Williamsburg students, easily integrating with a community often at odds with law enforcement, habitué of a local cop bar and attracted to reporter Allison Rogers. At odds with Lee's attorney uncle and his own uncle on the force, Raymond persists on Mrs. Lee's behalf because he doesn't believe Dougie is guilty of any crime, especially when another classmate dies.O'Mara drives his novel toward an unexpected conclusion, with a denouement that goes far beyond Raymond's expectations, a contemporary take on events that adds another level of menace to an already thrilling ride, tightly-plotted, with unexpected twists and well-developed characters. Raymond Donne is likely to cross the divide between new career and the old again, regardless of consequences in the right circumstances, a protagonist with a lot of adventures ahead. I look forward to enjoying them all. Luan Gaines/2013.

Phillips has performed an extraordinary feat in Quiet Dell, the reimagining of a horrific murder spree in 1931 West Virginia that begins in the Chicago home of widow Asta Eicher and her three children, Annabel, Hart, and Grethe, literally inhabiting her characters through the Chicago-based reporter, Emily Thornhill, who follows the arrest of the killer, Harry Powers (AKA Cornelius Pierce) through his arrest, trial and eventual hanging. The story takes on the ambiance of a Depression-era tragedy, from the outraged reactions of the public to the actions of law enforcement, the prevailing style of journalism and the values that define acceptable social behavior. Certainly, Mrs. Eicher has few options after his husband’s premature death. Despite the generous intentions of her boarder and friend, Charles O’Boyle, Asta corresponds with a gentleman of means, Cornelius O. Pierce, who offers marriage and a home in West Virginia with her children. Within weeks, the little family is dead. The case comes to light after a similar disappearance, that of Dorothy Lemke, all the bodies gruesomely discovered, the murderer apprehended.Phillips skillfully describes the desperation of a widow with three children to raise and no resources; O’Boyle, the boarder who loves the family; Annabel, the fanciful youngest girl who writes plays and draws pictures; and the family dog, Duty, silent witness to the tragedy.  She imagines the appeal of a chivalrous man met through lonely-hearts correspondence, the children gathered from the home in haste to join their mother; the struggle on a rain-soaked country road, a cruel and violent ending. Emily Thornhill is assigned the shocking case for her newspaper, joined by journalist Eric Lindstrom, expenses paid by banker William Malone. These characters come together in another plotline, one inextricably tied to the Eichers and Harry Powers, from his arraignment to the trial that examines the fate of the family and that of Dorothy Lemke, Powers posturing and adamant, claiming his innocence.Of another time and place, these murders could have easily been exploited, details milked for avid consumption by a curious public, but the author creates such a sympathetic scenario, couched in the sensibilities and particularities of the 1930s, that Asta Eicher’s emotional state, her childish belief in the promises of a stranger is believable, as are the obedient children who follow the directions of a man their mother has told then to trust. Believable as well, is the relentless trajectory of Emily Thornhill as she follows her story to the end, speaking for the dead, battling with her own reactions to the nightmare that unfolds in the courtroom. Emily is a modern woman who will face daunting challenges, embrace the opportunities that come her way and confront the killer, clutching the little dog that belonged to the children in her arms. Phillips captures the essence of the era perfectly, from the emotional tenor of the principal characters to the historic details that bring the events to life, nuanced social commentary adding sophistication to the novel, Thornhill bridging the territory between a lonely widow’s foolish expectations and the demands of the journalistic community for accurate reporting, as well as interacting with law enforcement as sources for material. Phillips enters the dark landscape of the murders, yet fashions beauty from that ugliness, empathy for the lost and hope for those left to find a place in a world sometimes filled with monsters. Luan Gaines/2013.

"Back in the day", girls with curly hair had to resort to an ironing board and an iron to achieve what we take for granted to day. That said, the Andis Titanium 450 Flat Iron is a modern-day answer to an age-old dilemma, a good starter item, described as safe to use without burning or damaging the hair. Though it is not a top-of-the-line item in terms of expense, it provides the expected features, and a few more: titanium to preserve the integrity of the hair and seal the hair cuticle: 20 heat settings, up to 450 degrees; a clamp style to hold hair tightly; a swivel cord to avoid tangling; dual voltage; and an automatic shut-off.The titanium plates are flat, not curved, so there is a possibility that hair can get caught along the sides of the plates. And while the heat dial can be raised or lowered, the numbers on the dial do not indicate the degrees of heat, nor is the dial lighted. Because of this, an automatic shut-off feature is even more critical. This product is serviceable, but like other such styling aids, an acquired skill, to avoid over-heating or burning the hair. (I would suggest a styling spray to protect the hair when using any heated styling aid.) A bit clumsy for smaller hands, it will take some practice to become adept at using this flat iron, to become familiar with its weight and ease of handling- or not. While this flat iron is acceptable overall, I am not impressed with its quality or design features. It has no great flaws, but neither is it an item I will use daily. Luan Gaines/2013.

Provocative playwright Neil LaBute brings brother and sister, Bobby and Betty, together on a stormy night at a remote cabin, where Betty is cleaning out a tenant's effects before the place can be rented again. Despite the acrimony that has plagued both their youth and adult years, it is Bobby that Betty turns to for help, rather than her husband, Bruce. The tension between the siblings is clear from the moment Bobby arrives at the cabin, unable to resist the barbed jabs that have defined their relationship. While Betty is now a professional, a successful college professor, her teen-aged reputation was both sordid and memorable. Bobby, a carpenter, has accomplished little, a shabby history of two divorces tainted by domestic violence, his chronic use of expletives in conversation reflecting his general disillusionment with life. Sporadically attending the task at hand, sorting books and other items, brother and sister engage in repartee that segues from sarcastic to contentious, the years falling away in shared remembrance of past issues, the crux of Betty's present endeavor revealed as Bobby feints and parries, pushing his sister to finally tell the unembellished truth.With a surgeon's precision, LeBute ushers this modern-day Hansel and Gretel into the dark center of the forest, a masterful dance between characters who share a history but not the same values, the scars of youth exposed as the younger brother demands a quality of honesty that Betty, a practiced liar, energetically resists. There are moments of sincerity, of empathy, others of rage and frustration, the weather outside accentuating the storm inside, a visceral tension that can only be resolved when all pretenses are stripped away. LeBute's Preface is fascinating and informative, for his remarks on character and the plot device that injects the story with its particular sense of intimacy, an intuitive quest for truth: "Sometimes I can't tell if I'm running towards the safety of the forest's edge or deeper into its center." This is, indeed, a forest dark and deep, the harboring of secrets and lies and the bright light of truth. Luan Gaines/2013.

Sanford brings Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension agent Virgil Flowers back for another adventure, this time with the added flavor of international intrigue: a precious artifact has been stolen from a dig in Israel, the thief returning home to Mankato, Minnesota, to conduct a bidding war, the stolen item, an inscripted stele, to go to the highest bidder. Elijah Jones, dying from terminal cancer, has carefully planned his crime, returning safely home only to be followed by the converging interested parties, none of whom plans to leave without the bounty. Busy on site in tracking down a counterfeit limber ring headed by the curvaceous and intriguing "Ma" Nobles and her sons. With more than a passing interest in Ma, Virgil, a bit of a ladies' man, is not thrilled when his boss, Lucas Davenport assigns him the case, beginning with meeting a representative of the Israel Antiquities Authority who has come to return the artifact to its rightful home.An eclectic cast of characters assembles in search of the artifact, Rev. Jones managing to stay off the radar of anyone hoping to confront him or take the stele, though his daughter, Ellen is strongly suspected of abetting her father's movements. Virgil, meanwhile, is busy running down various leads and the interested parties who have suddenly arrived in Mankato, from Tag Bauer, a TV journalist, to a Texan interested in documenting the find, not to mention a renegade Mossad agent, Faraj Awad, a young Lebanese Arab with dreams of becoming a pilot, the fearsome "Turk", agents of Hezbollah and assorted thugs hired to act as muscle. Not to be outdone, Ma Nobles manages to insert herself into the drama. The chase continues, Jones always one step ahead of the pack on his tail, Flowers attempting to arrest Jones before lives are lost. He is not entirely successful.While Flowers seems a more light-hearted reincarnation of the iconic Lucas Davenport, Sandford isn't as demanding of this protagonist, except in matters relating to the job. In that respect, Flowers is a dedicated agent, albeit a bit of a rule breaker, like his mentor. Considerable tongue-in-cheek humor abounds, as with the charming, if misguided Faraj Awad, including a plethora of references to Ma Nobles' physical attributes, blunting the potential for edge-of-your seat thrills in the crime drama. Good `ol boy Virgil Flowers, ladies' man and dedicated agent, lopes more easily through mayhem and periodic violence, but the novel loses the momentum of Davenport's hard-edged approach to cases. Luan Gaines/2013.

McFarland has penned a truly frightening novel set in Australia, where Ruth Field, seventy-five, is spending her waning years at the seaside cottage where her husband Harry retired and died five years ago. Ruth is content in her isolation, save for the occasional nightmare she has of a tiger prowling her home. She realizes the tiger is a figment of her imagination, but considers it her "consequential visitor", perhaps a portent of something to come. Whole afternoons drift by in the contemplation of the ocean; her actions habitually ritualized, a task begun after four waves crest, for example. To be sure, her mind is not as acute as it once was, but she is proudly independent, content in her solitude. Raised in Fiji as the daughter of missionaries, Ruth is a product of her upbringing, unassuming, reluctant to make demands of others. Change arrives in the larger-than-life person of Frieda Young, who greets Ruth in the Fijian manner, announcing she has been sent by the government as a carer on a temporary basis, to assess Ruth's needs.Frieda invades Ruth's solitude with brash energy and an air of inevitability, making subtle changes in routines, sometimes beneficent and wildly enterprising, others cajoling and bullying to gain Ruth's cooperation. By turns affronted by the stranger's presence and happy for the company, Ruth adapts to Frieda's moods, which change as rapidly as her hair color. Dropped off each morning by her brother, George, in his taxi, Frieda's hours expand to three, as she takes over Ruth's shopping, cleaning, preparing meals. Soon Ruth cannot imagine her home without Frieda in it, the carer consistently unpredictable, either solicitous or punishing. It is at this point that Ruth's nightmare seems significant, her private world invaded by a woman who is either helper or predator, their symbiotic relationship impossible to deconstruct, though there are moments of clarity in Ruth's confusion. McFarlane captures perfectly the terrain of aging, the weaknesses of the body and the vulnerabilities of an elderly woman living alone. Ruth is often confused, needing assistance, grateful for Frieda's strong arms and fearlessness. McFarland perfectly contrasts Ruth's interior life, the graceful unfolding from youth to old age, replete with memories and future hopes with the terror that commences with Frieda's arrival and the recurrence of the nightmare. It will leave you reeling. Luan Gaines/2013.

The world literally seems to turn on its axis for those caught in the maelstrom of the Mississippi Flood of 1927, when the great river overruns its banks, decimates man-made levees and inundates homeowners with floodwater. It is a massive disaster on a scale the federal government has yet to significantly alleviate for those suffering the loss of homes, lives and futures. But beyond the expected trauma of the disaster, there are saboteurs who, for financial or political reasons, create further chaos, dynamiting vulnerable areas of the levees. Hohnob, Mississippi, is on the path of destruction, a hotspot for bootleggers, who profit handily from the Volstead Act as government agents roam the countryside in search of illegal stills. The land already filled with homeless folks scavenging for supplies and teams of people sandbagging against the river's rise, special agents Ted Ingersoll and Ham Johnson are assigned by none less than Commerce Secretary Herbert Hoover to pose as engineers while trying to locate two missing revenuers last seen near Hobnob.Against this chaotic setting, the team of Franklin and Fennelly posit a two-pronged drama of characters on a collision course. After finding an orphaned baby at a crime scene, the soft-hearted Ingersoll decides to find the child a home. To that end, when the partners separate near Hobnob, he trusts the advice of a local woman, delivering the infant to Dixie Clay Holliver, a young woman who has lost her firstborn. Relieved of his precious burden, Ingersoll has more trouble forgetting his encounter with Dixie Clay, a circumstance that causes him no end of complications, both in the investigation and establishing his priorities. Dixie's husband, Jesse, is the man behind the most successful moonshine in the region, a man with no scruples and a plan to move on to bigger and better things.It's always tricky when authors combine efforts: Franklin has a solid reputation as a novelist; Fennelly as a poet. The transitions between the two points of view are sometimes successful, sometimes not, but the authors use the impetus of the plot to keep the action moving forward, filling in the backgrounds of the primary characters as events unfold. Whatever the intentions at the start, from the search for the missing agents to Dixie Clay's embrace of the orphaned baby, from bootlegger Jesse Holliver's manipulation of people and circumstances to the massive flooding that sweeps away homesteads and hope, the surging water puts everyone in jeopardy, Dixie Clay facing the consequences of her hasty marriage to Holliver and Ingersoll on the cusp of a life-changing decision. Too many easy resolutions here, but the authors capture the essence of the drama during an infamous disaster too many have forgotten. Luan Gaines/2013.

Although her novel is historical fiction, Cullen's Mrs. Poe breathes fresh air into the mythology of Edgar Allen Poe. Popular lore paints Poe as an addict, a madman, a nascent criminal and a bitter critic of his contemporaries. What a revelation, then, to view Poe through the eyes of poet Frances Osgood in 1845 New York City. A struggling poet hoping to make a profit with her writing, Osgood scribbles children's tales and feminine verses, desperate to provide for her two young daughters, Vinnie and Ellen. Frances and the girls presently reside at the home of her good friend Eliza Bartlett. Samuel Osgood, a popular portraitist, has abandoned the family to pursue his art. An incorrigible philanderer, Samuel has an eye for the ladies and a pronounced lack of concern for his wife and daughters. Having published some of her work, Frances is a habitué of a local literary salon, where she hopes to attract the attention of a publisher.Emotions run high in this novel, a city sensing its importance on the world stage, life fragile in an era where children are frequently lost to disease, the distance between security and poverty too easily breached, as Frances Osgood well understands, a woman in a man's world. The salon Frances attends is filled with popular writers and those chasing fame and fortune, among them the newly celebrated Mr. Poe, with his shocking poem, "The Raven". The subject of much speculation and jealousy, Poe is adored by women, an object of fascination to all for his bizarre ideas, his rabid criticism of other writers agitating the literary community. Among Poe's most damning critics is Reverend Rufus Griswold, publisher of "The Poets and Poetry of America" (the very man entrusted with writing Poe's biography after his death). It is at the salon that Frances first encounters Poe, who arrives with the beautiful Virginia his arm, fragile cousin and wife. Neither is seeking a connection, but once drawn together, the attraction is unmistakable. Of course they are doomed, by circumstance, by society and by fate.It is here that Cullen shines, capturing Frances's desperate circumstances and the shame of her tenuous position in a judgmental society, the honesty with which she approaches every encounter with the talented, sometimes temperamental poet. Frances is an innocent in every respect, Edgar resisting what he recognizes is an impossible attachment, until the fragile Virginia begs to have Frances visit their home. Beyond the glittering ambiance of New York society, what Frances discovers in Poe's home is the heart of the novel, a complex relationship between a poet and his ill, child-like wife. The tension of the chase is exquisite, the agony of certain consequences heartbreaking. Yet there is a sense of menace as well that Frances cannot understand, torn between her desire to be kind to a dying woman and the growing love for Edgar she harbors in her heart. Cullen writes this romance with such acute awareness of the risk for both, tempered by the relief of finding solace with a beloved, albeit painfully temporary, that it is impossible to view Poe from the jaded perspective of the myth that has become his legacy. This no monster, no evil villain with a twisted psyche, but a man bedeviled by his past, his genius and the marriage that binds him to one woman when he loves another. Luan Gaines/2013.

Kent changes her focus from previous works of fiction- set in Puritan New England- for the wild west of Texas post-Civil War. There Nate Cannon, an ex-veteran and new Texas lawman, joins forces with two men who will have a profound impact on his life as they all pursue brutal killer Bill McGill, who has cut a swath of death through Texas. As Nate struggles to adapt his moral compass to the actions of the two lawmen, Captain George Deerling and "Doctor" Tom Goddard, he learns of the killer's past and his new partners' determination to run this man to ground. Faced with the tough realities of life on the road, including decisions that require pragmatism over strict legality, Nate holds to his values, often in conflict with Deerling, who demands loyalty and a willingness to take direction.In a parallel storyline, Lucinda Carter slips out of a Fort Worth brothel on a mission to meet her partner and lover, the only one who has made her feel secure in a world that has offered little in the way of protection. Harboring her own secrets, Lucinda is headed for Middle Bayou on the Gulf Coast, there to bide her time and await further directions, meanwhile fitting into a role that affords her some anonymity. Lucinda is a complex character, by turns sympathetic and others deeply flawed, the product of a harsh upbringing. Masquerading as a woman of good character is no problem for one who has made her living giving others what they want, Lucinda obsessed only with the promises of the man who will come to claim her and enact the plan they have constructed to secure the future.Both elements of the novel converge as the lawmen and the killer draw closer, Lucinda a pivotal part of a plot that proves Kent's skills as a storyteller and an observer of human nature, from Nate's awakening to the nature of the daunting task ahead to Lucinda's devotion to a man who will push her beyond her means to survive, lawmen Deerling and Goddard providing the colorful historical background that is the setting for the conflict, Nate absorbing harsh lessons while traveling through unfamiliar terrain, both physically and emotionally. Post- Civil War Texas is filled with renegades, crooked lawmen, recovering, war-weary towns and the slow return of sanity, with just enough room for a killer like McGill to escape undetected from one scene of death to another.As in her Puritan-era New England scenarios, Kent builds a believable landscape for her protagonists, people and places with a sense of historical accuracy and the temperament of the times. Each scene brings the action vividly to life, whether a deadly ambush at a campsite, the disposition of inconvenient prisoners meant for hanging, the taming of a wild horse or Lucinda's retreat to the elegant mathematics of geometry for distraction. There is no shortage of violence or retribution, good and evil at odds on the streets of Texas, the Gulf Coast and New Orleans. Some will die, others survive, all touched by the quest to end McGill's reign of terror, strange bedfellows on opposite sides of the moral divide. Luan Gaines/2013.

Daly strikes a chord of truth with her novel set in the English Lake District. Overworked, overtired and overextended, Lisa Kallisto finds herself at the center of a shattering event- the disappearance of her best friend's daughter, Lucinda Riverty. Friend of Lisa's own thirteen-year-old teen, Sally, Lisa realizes she is responsible for the girl's well-being after a sleepover, a sleepover that never happened. Having trusted one another with each other's children, Lisa realizes, too late, that her busy life has been the cause of unfathomable tragedy should Lucinda not be found. Cloaked in the weight of her guilt, Lisa approaches Kate and her husband only to be rebuffed, Kate in complete shock. Lisa returns home to her own children, Sally and two younger boys, depending on husband, Joe, to help her through the next few harrowing days.In this dramatic scenario, Daly taps into every woman's worst nightmare, the loss of a child, and the aftermath of such an event. While authorities begin their investigation, Kate is suspended in limbo, her sister, Alexa, attacking Lisa on Kate's behalf. Devastated by her part in the drama, Lisa attempts to balance home, work and her increasing need to find Lucinda herself, Daly describing the awkward scenes between Lisa and Kate, revealing the history of a friendship between women from different backgrounds and the contrasts in their lives: "The Lakes has always been littered with two extremes of women: the ones who never work... and the ones who never stop." Lisa is a relatable character caught in a terrible situation, her oversight born of too many details in the busy life of a working mother. Her mistake isn't huge, but the consequences are.Daly inhabits her protagonist with painful accuracy, examining Lisa's missteps and motivation, her eagerness to help her family and friends, her care for others extending even to her work, a charitable organization for placing homeless animals where they might thrive. And while attempts to make right her lapse in judgment, another figure lurks in the background, a predator watching girls like Lucinda, preying on their innocence. Fearing a series of similar abductions in the district, Detective Constable Joanne Aspinall scrambles to make sense of the main players and find Lucinda before another girl is lost. Daly builds the tension to a shocking conclusion, a grim reminder of the secrets that lie behind careful facades of normalcy harsh judgments born of fear and the impossibility of protecting children no matter how well intentioned. Daly's first effort is a winner. Can't wait for the next. Luan Gaines/2013.

Love the concept of a mess free coloring option for toddlers, especially when riding in a car or visiting a place where caryons might be a nuisance. This product is age-specific; its use may be limited as a toddler seraches for more advanced ways to create "art". I like the idea of capturing a small child's attention with the addition of light and sound, but the music could be an aggravation for parents hoping for a few quiet minutes of play. Given the remarks in other reviews about the loud music that accompanies this product could be a deal-breaker, but the instructions include an option for a light-only mode, so what might be a drawback can be controlled by a parent. The gel surface is attractive to small hands and easy to clean, though puncturing might be an issue. The toy is sturdy enough to resist handling and easy to hold. Though it may have a short shelf life in terms of a toddler's interest, this product has much to recommend it.(A caveat: There is a warning on the Amazon product page that there is danger of choking for children under three years of age. This product is advertised for 24 mos. and up.)

As disarming and eerie as a black and white film featuring an iconic "woman gone bad", these tales contain that same disconcerting jolt of a female breaking character in the most sacred of places, the home. Editor Sarah Weinman has selected the stories of fourteen writers in this brilliant anthology, tales with the same elements as those portrayed in 1940s films, a peaceful domestic environment, the jarring dissonance of a female abandoning the role of caretaker for a more harrowing action, murder perhaps. And like the nostalgia for simpler times (when women knew their places), the selections read as familiarly steeped in domestic harmony, well-behaved young women, refined, mannered ladies- each with a fatal flaw running through her psyche. There's something even more sinister about stories set in the home, where families seek comfort and nurturing. Leave it to women writers to expose that notion of security.One of the most fascinating elements of this collection is the manner in which it is presented. Not only does Weinman provide a comprehensive history of the domestic crime novel's evolution in the Introduction, but she prefaces each writer's tale with specific details. All of this serves to give context to a cogent argument for celebrating the work of these literary trailblazers, women contributing to what is essentially a male domain. There is much to be said for these writers and their struggle for a voice in a world that needs their labors during WWII, only to discard them when the men come back to a country is distracted by post-war opportunities. Today, avid readers of crime fiction reap the bounty of the efforts of the "Trailblazers of Domestic Suspense", a generation spanning three decades, from the 1940s to the 1970s. Today our choices are unlimited and without geographic boundaries, from Gillian Flynn to Sue Grafton, Tana French, Louise Penny and Denise Mina.Suspend time for a while. Revisit a pre-digital world, where the face of a monster is masked by loving motherhood or devoted domesticity, where a woman's role is restricted, but not her ability to wreak subtle revenge, where ladylike nannies are hired to care for precious children and elderly ladies too fragile to successfully manage a murder. Some of these writers may be familiar, others not (Patricia Highsmith, Vera Caspary, Charlotte Armstrong), but their stories will both shock and fascinate, early excavators of a rich vein of domestic crime plunging beyond the faade to the more troubled waters beneath. Luan Gaines/2013.

Shameless. Brave. Unflinching. Brutally honest and slyly observant of the roles we play on the stage of life. Post-9/11 New York still in the grip of color-coded terrorist alerts, widowed Celia Cassill has wrapped herself in the sturdy embrace of an apartment building, landlady to George, a gay man; the Braunsteins, a married couple; and Mr. Coughlan, a retired ferry captain. George has asked to sublet his apartment for a short time to write in Europe, though Celia has purposefully constructed her rental agreements to specify no sublets. The burden of sorrow she carries since her husband's losing battle with cancer obscured by the necessary accoutrements of apartment management, Celia feels security slipping away as she agrees (just this once) to allow Hope to move in, unable to resist the lush personage of the new tenant, who is in search of temporary respite after a divorce.Whatever a younger Celia might have imagined for herself, it never included the agonizing loss of a beloved spouse, loneliness in her late thirties or the weighty grief that seems to have settled in her bones. Soon the wonder that is Hope settles into George's tastefully appointed apartment, scattering her flowery scent, emotions and creature comforts everywhere, danger sliding through the cracks along with a bevy of sophisticated friends and well-wishers. And Celia is drawn into a drama both enriching and terrifying, her carefully-constructed interior breached, life demanding a return to the living.Loyd leaves no stone unturned, nor is anything sacred in the exploration of Celia's world without her man, her coping skills, ritualized reapportioning of daily activities, need for control. Her tenants become less abstract, taking shape in a manner she hasn't anticipated, her life laid bare, instincts intact enough to understand that "we were necessary distractions. A jigsaw she was arranging like a hobbyist." Visceral, sometimes violent, literary and utterly without artifice, Loyd explores the wild terrain of love and desire, littered with sorrow, renewal and the endurance of the human spirit: "You could love what you could not foresee, that we are all shape-shifting whether we want to or not." Luan Gaines/2013.

I was pretty excited to get this plush ABC Elmo, my favorite character of all time and a source of much hilarity for both granddaughters. However, when I read the other reviews, I was sorry to hear that the battery cannot be replaced. I love Elmo with or without a voice, but a two-year-old may be pretty disappointed that Elmo loses his voice when the battery fails. In general, I don't believe plush toys have to "do" anything to inspire creative play, so I am hoping Elmo will overcome his problem and hold his value even without a voice. Both girls have had plenty of enjoyment from the smaller Elmo I bought each of them. It doesn't do anything, is just easy to carry and tuck in at bedtime. Since this Elmo won't get his tryout until Christmas, I will try to resist squeezing his hand for my own entertainment. Elmo will always rate five stars for me.Luan Gaines/2013.

The tragically tormented Quirke returns in another mystery, one that strikes to the heart not only of Quirke's childhood traumas as an orphan, but the power wielded by the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland in the mid-50s. The Church effectively censors Ireland's politics, morals and financial institutions, stifling any scandals or questions of impropriety, even when murder is at stake. Murder is certainly the issue in Holy Orders, that of Jimmy Minor, a reporter who is found floating in a Dublin canal, his battered face almost unrecognizable. As a pathologist, it is Quirke's onerous job to perform the autopsy, later to inform his daughter, Phoebe, over tea, of the paucity of clues available to Detective Inspector Hackett, who makes it a habit to investigate crimes with Quirke by his side. The only name that surfaces early in the investigation is that of a popular priest, Father Honan, about to go to Africa as a missionary. Other than Honan, there is only an obscure reference to a band of tinkers visited by the priest to suggest any further avenue of inquiry into Minor's death.Given Quirke's history of aversion toward the church, commitment issues and alcoholism, the usual struggle to interact with others in a meaningful way bedevils the protagonist, as usual, but in this novel, the female characters, particularly Phoebe and on-and-off lover, Isabel, illustrate the grist of the conflict raging in side Quirke, his realization that these women are important to his humanity, yet unbearably threatening in their proximity. He cannot tolerate the emotional stresses of true intimacy. At the same time, both women understand Quirke (Phoebe less generously), though they remain powerless to reach him. Isabel, in particular, suffers for her love of this unlovable man, able at last to question her role in remaining with him. Certainly, Isabel serves as an alter ego, the voice of humanity calling Quirke back from the abyss where he straddles the worlds of the dead and the living. And while Jimmy is the link between Quirke and Phoebe in this novel, the late-to-be-acknowledged daughter has yet to claim her own identity, conscious of the personality traits shared with her father, unsure of the nature of her relationship with his assistant, David Sinclair and even more confused after an encounter with Jimmy's sister, Sally Minor.From Quirke's uncomfortable visit with Hackett to Honan's superior at the rectory- where he is assaulted by near-crippling memories of the orphanage- to a dangerous nocturnal visit to the tinker's camp, Quirke seems more lost than usual in pursuing the murderer, unraveling the threads of his past and the secrets surrounding Jimmy's death, avoiding Isabel, worried for Phoebe and helpless to find justice in the face of the truth. Even the resolution leaves some confusion as to Quirke's future, Black cloaking his protagonist in the shadows of the past, the irresolution of the present and a yet to be faced future. Luan Gaines/2013.

While this product may, in fact, remove redness, I don't believe I would use it. It's a matter of consistency. When I finally got the pump to work- during which it squirted all over me- I noticed the green tint the product mentions, but was not pleased with the consistency of the lotion. It feels a little dry, even after application on the skin. I would be hesitant to use with makeup because of the consistency. Luan Gaines/2013.

I expected great things from this product but was disappointed with the results as well as the consistency of the cream. Eucerin has always been a reliable product and I have been satisfied with whatever items I have purchased in the past. However, when a cream is tagged for such things as eczema, I expect it to have some beneficial effect. I had no relief from this cream. Beyond that, the application was so greasy that it felt quite unpleasant on the skin, not cooling as I expected. Would not use this product in the future. Luan Gaines/2013.

Heartbreaking. Absolutely heartbreaking. The depth of the novel is apparent from the beginning, when two adolescents become friends in Brewster, New York in the "summer of love" (1968), forced into manhood by circumstances beyond their control or their ability to manage. The lanky Jon Mosher is a loner, his German-Jewish immigrant parents unable to recover from the loss of the first-born son, Jon painfully invisible in his own home. Ray Cappicciano is Jon's polar opposite, the consummate bad boy who marches to a different drummer, has a reputation as a fighter and lives in scarcity with his ex-cop father and brother. There are others: schoolmate Frank, who finds security in the rigidity of his fundamentalist religious beliefs; the teacher-coach who prods Jon into joining the track team and learn the limits of physical endurance; and the luminous Karen Dorsey, an outspoken new student who befriends Jon but falls in love with Ray at first sight, her exuberance for life an unexpected bounty, equal parts unconditional love and wisdom. And there is Gene, Ray's baby brother, who makes his struggles bearable, but at the same time tethers him to the dark violence of a drunken father.Between Jon's revelations while running, a relationship with Ray that ameliorates his invisibility at home and Ray's battered-but-charming campus mystique, Slouka probes beyond the faade of 1960s adolescence, young men about to face real world consequences, a future defined by war and the draft, the fate of a star-crossed romance and a young man's life-and-death conundrum, innocence colliding with reality in a heart-stopping denouement. Whether describing Jon's excruciatingly difficult relationship with his mother, his discovery of running as emotional catharsis, or Ray's battered bonhomie and reservoirs of courage, Slouka keeps his finger on the pulse of two unlikely friends bound by deep affection. It isn't often that beauty and violence are so exquisitely rendered: "You didn't punch me in the chest. I trapped your fist with my heart." Slouka caught me with the first page and leaves me in tears. Luan Gaines/2013.

The voice of fifteen-year-old Anais Hendricks carries the reader through the harrowing bureaucracy of Scotland's foster care system, a child who has been in the revolving door of that care since infancy, currently waiting on the disposition of a case that could remand her to a locked facility until the age of eighteen. Accused of bludgeoning a now comatose policewoman, Anais awaits a decision on her fate at the Panopticon, a home for chronic young offenders in Midlothian, Scotland. Though she has denied the attack on the victim, the stern faces of those who interrogate her at the police station suggest guilt or innocence is irrelevant. Anais is seen as a lost cause, a habitual troublemaker and petty criminal. No fool, she has long ago learned to read the judgments of others, a litany of failures: "Fifty-one placements (twenty-three before she reached seven), drug problems, violence, dead adopted mum, no biological links, constant offending."In scathing prose, Fagan riddles her protagonist's language with the vocabulary of the helpless in the face of authority. Anais escapes the theater of the unbearable through drugs- of which there are a surplus- and what she calls "the birthday game', imagining her parentage, extended family members and location, haunted by not having ever known her mother, worried she was created in a test tube as an experiment. For comfort, she turns to drugs (acid, uppers, downers), the affection of predators and the generosity of the street savvy people who have peppered her short existence. As a newcomer in the Panopticon, Anais proves herself through confrontation, bonding with Shortie, Isla Tash, John and Dylan, each with their own painful story. In spite of her rage, frustration, fear and crushing loneliness, Anais is bright, curious, inventive and street wise often enough to have survived her life thus far.This is not a novel for the faint of heart, it is brutal, unapologetically honest and memorable. Fagan indicts the foster care system and its inhumane bureaucracy with her characters, its institutional mentality, revolving door of college graduates, social workers and do-gooders. The Panopticon is a place for the nowhere kids, those who have fallen through the cracks, who shuffle from one place to another: "I... understand that I am just a human being that nobody is interested in." At the Panopticon, the young people in care create their own society, subversive by its very nature, one that operates below the radar of the social workers and caretakers, with its own system of checks and balances. The intimate society of the unwanted takes on a life of its own in a drama that reflects the needs, emotions and frustrations of those who create a family, who aid and protect one another and who howl in protest when any of their number are lost. The beautiful, damaged Anais speaks for all. Luan Gaines/2013.

Evil is indeed pervasive in Burke's latest novel, set in Montana, where longtime pals, the infamous "Bobbsey twins from Homicide", Dave Robicheaux and Clete Purcel, are spending the summer at the ranch of English professor and environmental activist Albert Hollister, along with Dave's wife Molly, adopted daughter, Alafair and the soon-to-arrive Gretchen Hollister, Clete's daughter, about whose existence he only recently learned (Creole Belle, 2012). Though Montana doesn't provide the history-laden ambiance of New Iberia, where fans first fell in love with Robicheaux, it has its own raw beauty, besieged by the usual controversies between environmentalists and oil men, in this case personified by the wealthy Love Younger and his son, Caspian. There's nothing on the visitors' minds but fishing, until Alafair has a run-in with an arrow that barely misses her ear and an ensuing argument with a cantankerous ex-rodeo rider, Wyatt Dixon, who disavows any attack with bow and arrow.One thing leads to another, as they usually do in Robicheaux novels, culminating in an adversarial relationship between Dave, Clete and the local sheriff, Elvis Bisbee, Detective Bill Pepper's vendetta against Gretchen Horowitz (who is, after all, a reformed mob assassin), the disappearance of Angel Deer Heart, the adopted Indian daughter of Love Younger and Felicity Louviere and Purcel's impulsive infatuation with the wife of another man. None of this is as sinister or ratchets up the danger as much as Alafair's declaration that she has seen serial murderer Asa Surette following her in town. Believed killed in a fiery accident en route to prison, Surette is the face of evil, a man who carries the very stench of death wherever he goes, Alafair in his sights since an interview and the articles she published about him. Though out of their jurisdiction, Dave and Clete first get involved in the Indian girl's disappearance, questionable connections fueling their suspicions, a trail that leads straight to the mouth of hell and an encounter with a man who will not die.Burke's prose is colored by the expected and provocative philosophical musings of a man who has seen too much and lived to ponder the wisdom of his actions, but the atmosphere of unrelenting menace casts a pall on each day under the bright Montana sky, nature's beauty at odds with the casual brutality, heinous murders and greed of a wealthy opportunist. Against the backdrop of a sadistic activities of a sadistic serial killer on the prowl, the weary Bobbsey twins from Homicide have nearly met their match this time, Alafair and Gretchen refusing to be left behind, Clete exhausted by his usual self-destructive tendencies, Robicheaux haunted by otherworldly visions and an intuition of a reckoning between the dark forces and the light. Burke's worldview has always been painted with equal parts joy and grief, wisdom and horror, but there is a fainter glow in Light of the World, a fatal wound for a man who has perpetuated  a message of hope, regardless of man's inhumanity to man. Luan Gaines/2013.

The Tudor dynasty is born on the back of Richard III's defeat at Bosworth Field, a pyrrhic victory it seems, with the specter of the Princes in the Tower bedeviling the new king, Henry Tudor. Whether real or carefully staged by Yorkist supporters, the threat casts a pall over Henry VII's reign, diminishing his power and his peace of mind. The major players are larger-than-life: Henry VII; his domineering and fanatical mother, Margaret Beaufort; bride Elizabeth of York, former lover of Richard III; Elizabeth's mother, Elizabeth Woodville, keeper of secrets and spinner of spells; and the "pretender", whomever he might be, waiting to unseat Henry and return the throne to the Yorks.The lines are drawn from the first days, king and mother on one side, everyone else on the other, Beaufort managing the court as though she is queen, usurping the queen's quarters, penning strict rules for court behavior (meant to marginalize Elizabeth), building an elaborate network of spies. For his part, Henry is the fruit of his mother's  ambition, a ruler lacking the accoutrements of princes, exile robbing him of the intuitions of a natural ruler: "What matters is that you have not made your boy the beloved of England." At its best historical fiction breathes life into desiccated facts. This is Gregory's métier, an author who inhabits the personalities of her characters with trenchant wit, ever cognizant of the ironies of fate, particularly in her rendering of Elizabeth of York, trapped in a marriage with the man who killed her beloved, bearing the Tudor children, witness to Henry's weakness and the fanaticism of his mother, who would bend God's will her to own.Loathing turns to pity, even affection ("On the contrary, it makes me tender towards him") as Elizabeth observes the true nature of the Tudor king, his inability to bond with his subjects, his fear of the pretender by whatever name (Henry's "looking-glass king"), her own mother's secret cooperation on behalf of the York cause (even after the birth of an heir) and the tantalizing possibility that her younger brother is alive, albeit in hiding. The paranoia is pervasive, Henry besieged by rumors and rebellions, Beaufort often white-knuckled with fear, prostate to the God who has delivered her son to his destiny: "Nobody in the world could be more sure than my mother that her son should be king." This dynastic marriage of York and Tudor sets the stage for the future of England's game of princes and their heirs, murders and prophecies lingering for centuries, the mystery of the Princes in the Tower unresolved, yet perhaps made clearer by Gregory's keen and informed blend of history and fiction. Luan Gaines/2013.

Set in post-Katrina New Orleans, journalist Nola Cespedes of the Times-Picayune is back (Hell or High Water) in a new novel, the feisty reporter first to discover a body on her regular run through Audubon Park. Nola is horrified when she realizes she knows the victim, Judith Taffner, her former journalism professor at Tulane University. Not one to let an opportunity go to waste, Nola sprints over to Tulane before the authorities lock everything down, copying the contents of Taffner's computer on a thumb drive for later examination. On the move, Nola heads for Judith's home, able to snag an interview with the dead woman's husband by virtue of her former association, the stunned widower left with a small daughter and no comprehension of how radically his life has changed. By end of day, Nola has already put her stamp on the story, checking in with the NOPD detectives, but on her own mission, inspired by two explosive stories Taffner was working on when she was killed.Castro writes with energy, her protagonist propelled from one idea to another, instinctively looking for connections, whether sleuthing her former professor's activities and contacts or interacting with her best girlfriends, each with a distinctive personality, as colorful as the city they inhabit. Make no mistake, this is a murder mystery, but Nola Cespedes is an engaging character with boundless enthusiasm for life and a dedication to her craft that sometimes gets her into hot water. From her first interview with Taffner's husband to touring the lush estate where a senator's wife breeds thoroughbred horses, Nola is always keyed into the appropriate emotional pitch for her subject, whether pursuing the professor's stories or touring the New Orleans Jazz Fest with her Little Sister in tow. Castro has created a lively, interesting character, fearless, inquisitive and impulsive, New Orleans the perfect background for the mayhem, mischief and misdeeds of those who fall under her scrutiny.  If there's murder afoot, Cespedes will not only break the story, but run the killer to ground. Luan Gaines/2013.

In Dorion's Massacre Pond, Game warden Mike Bowditch is caught in the middle of the most heinous slaughter in Maine history, ten moose when the count is finished. From the start, it's all about politics, a developing drama between environmentalists and sportsmen and the internal politics of the Maine Warden Service, where Bowditch has been warned to keep a low profile if he wants to move up in the ranks. The conflict originates with the prime hunting land purchased by Mrs. Betty Morse, property she plans to turn into a national park, envisioning an unspoiled landscape where wildlife can roam free. Unfortunately, this grand scheme will have a profound effect on the local economy, alienating those who make a living from that very land. Her enemies have been enthusiastic in voicing their opinions, including threatening letters to "Queen Elizabeth", as her adversaries call Mrs. Morse. Outraged since discovering the dead animals with his friend, Billy Cronk, Bowditch wants to catch the culprit, but understands the law and his own limitations.Thanks to an ambitious Lieutenant heading the investigation, Mike is assigned to peripheral duties that make it unlikely he will steal any of Lt. Marc Rivard's thunder, though Bowditch is chronically unable to resist immersing himself in the case, reluctant to embrace obvious suspects without further information. There are conflicts for Bowditch at every turn, with Rivard and the other wardens, with Mrs. Morse, who chooses him as liaison over Rivard, with Morse's daughter, Briar, who finds him attractive, with his friend Billy, who is hiding a secret he refuses to share. Meanwhile, the media demands answers and his superiors demand arrests. Even Bowditch's personal life is tangled up in the unfolding events, his strong attraction to the daughter of retired chief warden Charley Stevens (though she is engaged to another), anxiety over the frequent calls from his mother, from whom Mike has kept his distance over the years and a realization of his part in the failures of his relationships.Dorian captures the essence of the Maine wilderness and passions of those who live there, his protagonist beset by the demands of a horrific case, a domineering, wealthy woman determined to do things her way, the internal politics of the Warden's Service and a personal life gone off track. Peopled with strong personalities, from Morse's constituency of fanatical visionaries and a rebellious daughter, to angry sportsmen who resist Morse's intrusion on their way of life and an abundance of eccentrics, petty criminals and regular folks caught up in a conflict between ideologies. In a microcosm of human conflict, the larger debate is acted out in real time, the animal carcasses a grim reminder of collateral damage in the wake of progress and the high price of legacy. Luan Gaines/2013.

This thing is great for when you are transporting dirty items or just have a full vehicle.  I primarily use it for transporting stuff like bags of dirt and gravel/cement items that I do not want in my car.  This allows dirty items not to dirty up my vehicle which is great, I also have found it useful when I need to transport some additional items that will not fit in my car (car too full).I have found it able to hold a lot of weight (not sure how much I put on it, but it was not close to the 500 pound limit it states), although the bottom steel grate is not super strong, so it cannot take a lot of weight in one place, maybe it could handle it, but it looked like it started to push in when a heavy thin heavy item was put in one location (weight could not be distributed).It is easy to move and lift so I just store it in the garage and put it on the car when I need it (I drive a 2014 Ford Escape with Tow package), having it upright will block the tailgate so I do not leave it in the upright position.  It fits great in my car's 2" hitch and a regular hitch lock fit it perfectly (the unit does not include the bolt to hook it to the hitch).In the end this is really nice for keeping the car clean and giving some extra space when traveling, I can use standard bungee cords and it holds up with no problem.  It is light enough that I can lift it out of the car and just lean it against the garage in the wall.  I am very happy with this and find it a great addition to my vehicle.

This conditioner is really nice, and helps add some shine to my hair and helps avoid dry scalp (mainly flakes).  It goes in smooth and is easy to wash out without leaving any residue.  I have been using this with hot water and have had no problem with flakes while using it since my scalp does not get that dry feeling.  I also do not get a greasy hair feeling that some other conditioners leave.  This was really nice and gives my hair a nice shine and not that crisp ends that I get when it gets dry

This vacuum is great!  It is small enough to go in the corner of the closet without taking up much room and is so light I can clean without trying to fight with my canister vacuum.  The battery is great since I do not have to deal with cords and it holds a charge long enough for me to do the entire house.The vacuum is light and easy to carry.  I have hardwood floors and carpet in the bedrooms.  I can drive this right off the carpet onto the hardwood floors and just change it to floor mode which turns off the spinners.  It is great especially in the bathrooms picking up hair.  For such a small vacuum it does a great job picking everything up, I have actually found that I clean more with this since I do not dread getting the canister vacuum up the stairs (it is so large I could only find a place for it in a closet downstairs; this is a townhouse so downstairs is really nothing and everything is upstairs).The handheld part comes out and is great for cleaning the stairs and the edge piece is very useful  I have not had much use for the small spinner part (I do not have curtains in this house, and in the past I used these for curtains).  This makes cleaning the stairs much easier and I also use the handheld for cleaning the car which is a nice bonus.  The no cord is also a plus in cleaning the car and stairs!I really like the dumping out vs bags since I will save money on bags and this makes life easier since I can just clean and dump it in the trash (every once in a while I wash out the filter).In the end this is a great vacuum!  It is super lightweight and easy to use and does a great job cleaning!  I find it quite beneficial to keep this upstairs and only get out the canister vacuum for large messes (which is rare).  I have just been using this whenever I see a need for vacuuming and just keep the battery on the charger in the office.  This allows for quick use whenever I need to vacuum!  I highly recommend this!

I got these solely to be legal when going through the mountains.  I have a 2014 Ford Escape (Titanium with 18" wheels).  This vehicle is more than capable of getting through these areas without tire chains, however, in California it is law that in some areas you must have tire chains (or it is like a $500 fine...).  So I got these.  They were cheap and fit my car.  I was nervous at first since Ford explicitly says NO TIRE CHAINS on the 18 and 19" wheels.  However, I do not think "My car manufacture said I couldn't" is a viable excuse for getting out of a ticket.These are cheap and fit my car.  I put them on at home to make sure they fit and they went on easily fit snuggly (it took a few tries to get the connector in the right place to get both sides even (for me it was 4 notches, so I wrote that down on the instructions)).  This way if I get to an area with a sign saying "TIRE CHAINS REQUIRED" I can put these on and be legal!If you are looking for super heavy duty tire chains these are not for you, but if you just want basic tire chains that do the job of giving a little extra traction and allowing you to drive in tire chain areas these are a great choice!!I am happy with these and highly recommend them for those wanting to take a weekend trip skiing and concerned about tire chain restrictions.  My only complaint is that I wish the carrying case was a little bigger (although I am glad it came with one), but it takes a little effort to get the chains back in.

Miracle Gro is my go to choice for plant food.  It works wonders and this is no different.  I have been using this on some roses (got them as just the cut off branches) and this has gotten this to leafy and almost ready to bloom in about a month!The actual feeder is great and my plants seem to love it.  The hose adapter is a neat concept, but my hose connection is in the garage and I do not like leaving it on when not using it, so I take it off between uses which is not great.  The hose kit allows me to simply water my plants using my hose and having this plugged into the faucet.  I am not sure what the ratio is that is being used, but it does not seem to be too much since after a few uses the feeder is still pretty full, I assume the main purpose of this is to ensure a nice proper amount of feed per water.  This does make it easier and if you had a faucet outside that you could leave this on all the time it would be idea.  In the past I have used the crystals that you mix with water which works nicely, and this seems to have the same level of growth with less work.  Putting it on and off is a bit annoying, but this is just because of the space limit I have in the garage, if you have an outside faucet this will work great!In the end this works great and my roses love it!  They are almost ready to bloom and I only planted them a month ago (as root/stick).  The water hose attachment makes this simple since I do not have to measure and can just spray them down.

I am not sure why they call this topper.  To me a topper is what I put on a cheap mattress to make it feel like a memory foam mattress.  To me this is more of a 'guest' or second bed.My main use for this is as an available bed for when guests are over (or if we go out and do not plan to stay at a hotel).  I use the third bedroom for a office, but if we have guests it is nice to let them use that bedroom.  This was perfect for this.  This mattress is foldable and takes up a small amount of room in the garage and when someone is over we can toss this on the floor in the third bedroom and put a pillow and a sheet/blanket on it and they are good!It is surprisingly light (when you first see the box it looks like it will be heavy), but it is light and the carrying case has a nice handle on it for easy carrying.  I put it down and laid on it and it is super comfortable.  It feels like a regular memory foam bed and it wide enough for one person to sleep comfortably.  It is also longer than me, allowing for a comfortable sleep without hanging off (I am 5'10" and it has about another .5-1 foot length).  I weigh about 190 lbs and this holds up nicely, I do not sink through any part of it and it forms around nicely.The carrying case is nice, but this is the only thing I do not love, they made the zipper only go about a quarter down on each side, which makes it hard to get in and out.  I really wish it opened all the way, it took two people to get this in and out of the case (difficult due to the bulk and flexibility of the mattress).  While this is not a big enough deal to affect the item, it would have just been nice to have a full zipper to get it in and out easier.In the end this is great for keeping in the garage and using in the office for guests.  It is good for one person and super comfortable.  I do not know about it as a topper, as all we have is a queen and king bed, so this would hardly cover half of it.  However, for a guest bed this is great!!!  Keep out of sight and be ready when you have guests!

I got this to help get some sun on my arms.  I ride almost daily so no reason not to work on a tan.  This was very solid feeling and felt well made.  It is a thin material and was very cool.  The orange color is really good looking and stands out (bright color that cars will see).  It is only a half zip, which is normal in cheaper jerseys, but that is OK, for the cost I can live with a half zip.The size is odd.  I am 5'10" and about 180 pounds and I got the small (I always want cycling clothe to be form fitting), but even the small was a tad loose.  So you may want to get a smaller size then normal.
