Maybe they made this with the idea it would be loose, even in the photo the jersey looks loose.The jersey has back pockets which is useful and the back of the jersey itself is longer than the front so you get more backside coverage which is great!For a great affordable jersey this was a perfect choice!  I am very happy with the quality and feel of the material and love this for getting my arms a little darker (lower arms are dark, top or arms are white... now we need to balance it out!

I got these as a gift for someone who loves Fireballs.  I got this selection since it was the actual 'regular' size ones that you would get in convenience  stores.  This was perfect!  It was 150 of the regular size ones and they are identical to the ones you used to get at the convenience stores.These have a great taste and are identical to the ones from the store for a great price!  Very happy!

These are super high quality staples in numerous sizes that makes hanging stuff way easier.  My main use for staples is hanging wires or other items outside the house.  I find this much easier than trying to use screws and I can pull these out without big holes in the walls.  My recent use for these was running a cable down the side of the house and stapling the cable (to keep it organized) against the wood.  The staples went in easily and they felt high quality like they would not rust (only time will tell, but they felt high quality).  The different sizes were great as I started using the super long ones and all of the sudden they would not go in all the way (apparently some metal plate behind the plywood), so I put in the smaller ones and continued and it worked perfect, this ensures they were all snug to the wire.I really like these for around the house jobs as I can quickly staple them into the wall and be done, no more trying to run wire along screws or leaving wires hanging and when I do remove them it leaves such a small hole it is unnoticeable.  These are great for around the house chores!

I used to have a rice cooker, but I sold it when I moved since it only did rice and took forever...  When I saw this it looked pretty awesome, so I gave it a shot.  First off, it looks way more expensive than it actually is, essentially the design does not look cheap and looks pretty modern.  So I read over the instructions (which could have been better), and added the water to the base and put some broccoli in the bottom container to test.  I turned it on and pressed the time to the chart's recommendation in the book.  I hit start and waited.  After about 3 minutes you could already here the water bubbling and after about 8 minutes it was steaming.  After it beeped so I knew it was done I went back to the kitchen (the beep is not too loud, so if you are like me and go back to the living room to watch TV you do not have to worry too much, since it goes into warming mode).  I tried some of the broccoli and it was delicious!  This was frozen broccoli from those big bags you get at the store.  The broccoli stem was even soft and good and it tasted amazingly!So I love rice, and was excited to cook rice the right way (not a steamer bag); rice just tastes better when cooked this way.  I was not sure from the instructions but it seemed like I should not use the second tray when cooking rice...  Well being the rebel without a cause but wanting rice and veggies I did it anyway (maybe it was accepted to do this, but I could not get a clear answer from the instructions).  I put the rice in the black bowl and put it on the bottom tray and put broccoli and snow peas on the top tray.  I added a little bit of water to the rice bowl and little bit of chicken bouillon (this is not needed, but I like the chicken flavor it gives to rice).  I set the timer to the recommended time for the rice (which was greater than the veggies) and waited.  After about 3/4 of the time I stirred the rice.  Well it went off and I was ready to try it.  I took the rice out and plated it (it was super, it was plain long grain white rice and it had puffed out nicely and tasted amazingly), I then forked the veggies and they were also perfect.  I poured them together and served them on the rice.  The broccoli was cooked perfectly and was tender and soft making even the stems taste amazingly.  The snow peas were still a whole (in shell) and the peas were cooked amazingly (you could bite through the shell and the peas and all were just perfect.I also could not figure out from the insturctions what was dishwasher safe, it stated some items were but I did not know what those items were (they used names that they would recognize but I did not know it).  So i just put it all except the unit and the part that covers the water (since it was not dirty; I just rinsed it in the sink with some soap) in the dishwasher.  After the cycle (I always use heat dry) everything was fine and it was all perfect and clean!I am very happy with this unit and find veggies cooked in this taste amazing!  I love being able to cook rice and veggies at the same time and cleanup is a breeze.  This can cook so many different things that I look forward to trying other items.  I will note the only thing I do not love is the display on the unit is set into the unit (not flat against the edge), so when on the counter I have to lean way down to see it (I am only 5'10"), this is sort of annoying, but not the end of the world. In the end this unit is quick and cook my food fast and make it delicious.  It is easy to use and a breeze to clean!  I am very happy with this!!!

I will state that the locking mechanism was really nice and I had high hopes for this.  However, the inside compartment is very tiny and hardly holds anything.  I wanted to put a little key fob in and the measurements online looked like it would fit, but the locking mechanism takes up so much room with a slanting effect that very few items fit (I guess their measurements included the space behind the slanting of the lock).  If you want to only put regular metal keys or maybe one car key (with no fob or built on fob) this should work.  I am still looking for a nice locking box that will hold a fob, this was just too small.

Sunglasses are ridiculously expensive, and when my last bike glasses fell out of my pocket I was not looking forward to finding new ones.  The last pair were just sport glasses that were like $20 for basic glasses.  So when I saw these for about $15 I was willing to give them a try.  They are surprisingly awesome for being a brand I never heard of.First they lack instructions.  Had no idea what all the stuff was for.  I figured out how to change the lenses and understood the piece that hooked to ear rest to keep them on your face, but I was not sure what the last strap was for.  I later (a few days) realized the black button on the side pops out the ear rests and allows for the item to be hooked into that hole.  I was also not sure what the plastic glass frame looking thing was for.  I assume you can put prescription lenses in it and pop into the holder in the sunglasses?  I wear contacts so this is not an issue for me, but if that is what it is for that is pretty neat.The lenses are nice and I mainly use the one in the picture (not too dark but keeps the sun out).  I will say it is odd how screens look through this glass, it adds a strange filter over digital screens (like looking at an iPhone is tougher).  However, I can see my Garmin head unit fine.  So it is not a big deal.I like the clear lenses for night riding since the wind dries my eyes out (which causes the contacts to become an irritant).  I have not had much use for the other lenses but it came with several, so you are bound to find one you like.The nose piece is adjustable and fits nicely on my nose.  The glasses are a little away from my face (quarter of an inch), but I can still see fine when looking to my side since they wrap around.The lenses are easy to change and while yes everything does feel like cheap plastic, they all pop together nicely and does the job for little price.  The package included a real nice hard carrying case and loads of accessories and lenses (like I mentioned). They all go in the case nicely.I am very happy with these and they were about the cheapest glasses you can find and even more amazing considering what is included.  I actually like these much better than my old sport glasses as they have this little ridge above the lenses (soft rubber/plastic material) that keeps sweat from going down the lenses as much and since they are away from your face a tiny amount I have not had as much problem with sweat getting on the lenses.

Works well.  I already have relatively long eye lashes and this did a good job of keeping them out and adding some body to them.  This gave them a darker, thicker look that holds all day.  It does not make them any longer looking, but like I said I already have relatively long lashes and this just makes them darker and bolder.  My only complaint is that you have to make sure they get through the brush, otherwise they seem to leave clumps (this stuff is sort of thick and likes to clump), other than that it works great, I just have to make sure that the eyelashes go through the brush.

I love tennis, however, I do not get to plat that often since it is hard to find a free tennis court...  I got this to be able to have some tennis like fun at home.  The first thing you have to do is not expect to play tennis with this.  However, it is still fun and great practice for eye-ball coordination.First it is in a smallish carrying case that is small enough and light enough to carry easily.  It took me about 5 minutes to assemble it; it is just push in the metal pin and push the poles together, it is pretty basic and easy to understand, even without the instructions.  The net slid on nicely; I did have to put one side on a small amount and than the other side to get it on all the way.The tennis rackets that it includes are not full tennis rackets, they are a tad smaller and are more similar to a racquetball racket (except these have a tennis like rounded top).  They are surprisingly high quality rackets and are really well made!  I figured they would be cheap in a kit like this, but they are top notch, they had a good feel (good weight balance) and were easy in the hand (they did just electrical tape for the handle wrapping, but it works fine for a racket of this size).  The rackets are really high quality!!The balls are foam and feel like heavy Nerf balls.  They are solid (unlike a tennis ball), but work well with this game.I live in the city and finding a place where I can setup this is challenging, I could not find a place had a concrete base that I could use for this (they were all shared with bikes or cars).  So I setup in the grass in a park.  This surprisingly worked well!  The balls actually had a bit of bounce on the grass (I would say they bounced better on concrete, but the grass still worked well), and we could play on the grass with no issue.  The net went up and we went back and forth for a while.  It was surprisingly fun and challenging.  For a foam ball you could get some power behind it and spike it!  It had a real tennis feel, just without the first bounce.  We played keeping it in the air, but sometimes it would bounce and we could still play off of it since it would bounce up about a foot or two.When we were done we put it in the bag (everything just unlocked and snapped apart) and zipped it all up!  It went away nicely.I will say this was surprisingly fun and worked well on grass, when summer comes, I plan to take this to the beach and play on the sand, this is a great small game and was really fun!  I highly recommend for anyone wanting a fun playful game that is quick to setup and can be played nearly anywhere (as long as you do not get in anyone's way).  I cannot wait to play again later with it!

I am always skeptical about these types of products.  However, this was pretty nice.  I am embarrassed to admit, but it actually took a bit for me to figure out how to use this.  Once I figured it out, I was happy with the odd applicator as it actually avoided losing any (like on your hands).  I have been using it for about a week now and my skin is more 'radiant', wrinkles are still their (without pulling the skin, I do not see those going) but the small wrinkles (like around the eyes) are not as noticeable.  They seem to be smoothing out and the skin has a more healthy glow to it (could be a sheen).  I am very happy with this and it is easy to apply without losing any and the results seem to be on parr with expectations, small wrinkles are not as noticeable (large wrinkles are still there, but that is part of being old).  If you have just slight wrinkles (around lips and eyes) this is a great choice and will smooth them out.

I got these to keep my rug from slipping on the hard wood floor.  I quickly found the rug just kept moving around and that was dangerous and annoying.  It is a full size floor rug and I was fearful that putting this on would be difficult, but it was surprisingly easy.  I lined up the rug with a line of wood panels and did one half at a time.  Just flipping the edge over and applying the tape (it was not super sticky so I had to carefully remove the backing as it kept attempting to pull off the rug.  I then just gently applied it to the floor and voila, it was staying in place.  It has not moved since.I am very happy with this and this was the best option (money and use wise) that I found.  I just did a line around each edge and I still have half a roll left for other carpets.  The rug stays in place and since it was not a real sticky substance, I am not worried about it leaving a residue on the floor.  Highly recommend!!

We usually get these for using when going on a run.  We find that sometimes a little leakage is found when running and these help keep it off of running clothe and underwear.  These are great and fit nicely and do their job.  While we mainly use these just for runs they are great for when traveling and going on a long hike.  It prevents any issues and keeps everything dry which avoids any rash or other issues when out moving.  These are my must for running!

I got this to light up a dark trail when riding home.  I quickly found out that I needed a powerful light that did not just allow others to see me but allowed me to see.  I found my cheap strap around light was worthless when in the dark.  After a 1 hour, 5mph ride home trying to see the road ahead to avoid debris, potholes and those polls that they put up to keep cars off trails, I started looking for a bike light.  I tried a bike light that I found that seemed like a good buy (it is odd that NiteRider does not appear in searches for Bike Light, maybe they should work on their keywords?) but did not work right when I got it.I was desperate for a light so I went to Performance Bicycles and got this light (I later found it on Amazon and it is a great price for a light of this quality).  I got home and loved the fact that it used 2 AA batteries, super simple and after mounting it on my handlebars (aimed slightly out and down) and it was amazing!  It was super bright and lights up the path ahead for a good 20 feet (15 feet is the focal point of the light and than there is about 5 feet of a radial effect around it).It has three settings which is nice, the super bright setting, the dim setting (never use this) and the flashing (use this to be seen).  It also comes off easily (slides off the mount) so you can pocket it when going in for coffee or leaving the bike.This light is great!  It is small and does not take up the entire handlebars and is one item (no battery pack to run to it or anything) and offers a great level of light that makes it easy to see the road ahead and definitely be seen by cars.I am very happy with this and it works great!  It is a great price for a bike light with this power and is a name brand!  Highly recommend!  I just wish this showed up in Amazon searches for Bike Light and it could have saved me a lot of time searching for  a light.

I got this for my Mom's car (2014 Ford Focus); this is the camera and the display.  We live in the city and parallel parking is a must and having a backup camera makes life so much easier (I have one in my Escape and it constantly amazes me how close a car looks in the mirrors compared to the actual distance (as seen in the camera).).Installation was as expected, not fun!  I will say that I was proud of myself the camera on the car itself looks great!  It looks professional, I included some photos!  I knew that it would be near impossible to get a professional (native) look for the screen.  so I do not love it, but it does the job.I used the hardware of the trunk's closing mechanism to run the wire and it worked really well (I did have to take the right side of the trunk off of its connector (not loving that), but it did allow me to run the cable in the opening arm which resulted in a clean install).  I also was able to use the button for the trunk release and the lip of the trunk to run the cable and hook in the camera without having to drill into the car (which I was happy about).  I put the camera right above the license place under the Ford emblem, which is where the camera is on my Escape, this made the camera look native to the car.I used those splicer cables locks (that go around existing cables and splices into them; they have them at auto places and Walmart and probably online, but they are really cheap so a real store may be a better option) this allowed me to splice into the hot cable of the reverse light for power.You will need to run power to the display, I find it much easier (in my opinion) to splice into stuff like the reverse light than into anything under the dash; so I ran a cable from the reverse light splice to the monitor for power; I also had to run the video one as well.I got the camera installed and put the back seat down and ran the video cable under the plastic moulding along the side of the car all the way along the driver's side.  I than ran the power cable along the same route (I ran the video first since it is fatter).I put the monitor on the left side of the dash, as I have a GPS unit in the center (would life not be great if I could just use that for the monitor...).  The monitor has two video inputs which means more cabling that has to go behind the screen (it is too short to run under the dash and make the connections their (you can see this in the photo I added).The monitor is lightweight and holds on nicely using a sticky pad.  The arm is very flexible and with a large radius of tuning so you can mount it in multiple ways.I got everything hooked up and it worked!  I do not love having a few cables behind the display, but they are too short to run anywhere else, you do not see them from within the car the way I have them.  So I guess it is will work.The camera has lines on it to help with distance and this makes backing up out of parking lots easier since you can see in both directions pretty far and this makes parallel parking much easier since you can easily see how far you got before you hit the other car.I am very happy this, I got it for about $40 and it works great!  I was able to install it myself (I consider myself pretty mechanical) and it was not super expensive!For an affordable solution to having a backup camera this is great choice!

UPDATEI wanted to share the battery life.  After using this about every other day (just for my back) with it on the Power Burst it lasted from Christmas to the beginning of February before I had to recharge it.  This was great battery life!!I am hairy.  So freaking hairy....  With this I am no longer!!!  I have tried so many body groomers to shave my back, I use a razor for my upper arms, chest and stomach, but I can only reach the lower back with a razor.  The upper back has been a problem.  I have tried several other ones (like Phillips) and they just do not work for me.  The heads often pop off when pulling up around the shoulder blade or I cannot reach parts and go against the grain (I look like I am doing Yoga in the shower).  I got this as a Christmas present and after the first use I am amazed.  The handle and head all lock, so no popping off when the shoulder blade gets between the head and the handle, I can get a smooth stroke all over those rough terrains.  I use the head with the foil on it as that seemed to do the best job and left the back smooth!The wide head makes it a quick job and the handle expands to any length so I can get really low and all the way to my neck.  I use it with power boost on every time and I can shave my back in under 3 minutes!After I am done you cannot see any hair, it is smooth!  In the past other shavers have left a tiny bit of hair that is noticeable when you have black hair and white skin...  This gets it all and does it quicker and easier than any other shaver.It is not waterproof so I shave in the shower (with no water) and than put it away and than shower off and shave the rest with a razor.  The unit's head is easy to clean and I can just rinse it under some water in the sink and it folds to a small size that I can easily put in the medicine cabinet.I am so happy with this and wish I had received this sooner, it is has made shaving much quicker and gives a better result.  This is a must for anyone shaving their back!!

I got these as a Christmas present for my Mom.  Whenever she goes out for a run she has her shoes come untie.  I am not sure, they look tight but they always come undone (I on the other hand, have never had a shoe lace come undone...).  Since she kept having problems I went to find a solution.  I came across these and figured they would make a great present.  I was right, she loved them!First off, they were easy to put on, you just lace the shoe with these like normal laces (they are elastic, so do not pull them too tight when lacing, she found it better to keep them loose when lacing; than the foot expanded them).  You than just put the lock on, cut to the excess you want (we did about 1.5 inches, due to her short feet) and clinch them together.They come with super long laces, so they should fit about any size shoe, I held them next to my shoes and they would fit my size 11 Nikes, and since you cut off excess they would fit my Mom's size 6 Nikes.We got Orange since he shoes are grey and orange, so I like that they have a range of colors.  The nice part is you can reuse them on future shoes since the plastic caps can be opened and you can relace them on other shoes when you wear through your current.She has gone on a few runs since getting them and loves them!  She has not had to stop (and lose her pace) since getting these and she actually said that they give her a better run as they let the foot move slightly when running (I guess the elastic) which gives her a more powerful push off and no restraints from tight shoes (I might have to get a pair for myself).She loves these and she no longer has to worry about shoe laces coming undone.  She said she is going to get some more for her other shoes (hiking/trail shoes) so she no longer has to worry and stop when running or outside!

I got these for cycling and they do a great job!  They kept my arms warm and if I got too hot I can slide them down.  This is a great option over maintaining a closet full of long and short sleeve jerseys.  They stretch over your arm and for me went from my wrist to the center of my upper arm.  This was perfect coverage!  They kept me warm (where I live our lows are only about high 30s [rare] and mostly high 40s and low 50s) and did a great job!  They are cottonish so if you sweat they will get wet, but they seemed to a pretty good job at getting the sweat away from the skin.For cycling or running these are a great choice, they are cheap (money wise) and work great!  I am very happy with these, highly recommend!!!

I had my doubts on this, but this thing is great!I got this for a Christmas present, and this was a great buy online, I will note that the price on these have dropped since their initial release.  However, they are great, so do not think otherwise from the price drop.I always get the lowest fat content burrito grande size tortillas I can find (has to be 4g or less Total Fat), so that is the type of tortilla I use, I sometimes get different brands, but always the low fat ones.I got the pans and put them in the dishwasher to clean them (I always wash things before using them), plus these are dishwasher safe!  I preheated the oven to 400 and put the shelf in the center (it did not state this, but I did to keep the tops from burning).  I took the burrito grande size tortilla and pushed it in.  Surprisingly it went straight in and held its shape (I was fearful it would just keep trying to slide up, but it did not). I will note that I keep my tortillas in the fridge until use so they were cold, in case that is what helped.I baked it for about 7 minutes and the tops were starting to get a little dark, so I took them out (I baked two of them).  I turned them over the counter and they fell right out (pan was just as clean).  The tortillas had a bowl shape and maintained it!  The tops were more done than the bottom, so I just put them back in the oven and turned it off while I finished making the stuff to go in it (about 7 more minutes with no pan).  This was my trick, it made them all over a golden crisp that was great!I got all the toppings ready (chicken grilled in the skillet, onions pinto beans, salsa, cheese) and took them out of the oven, they were very hot (which also ensured they were warm when I was done and served them).  I put the pinto beans in followed by the chicken/onion, then cheese and finally salsa and sour cream (I kept it healthy, by using Fat Free Cheese, Fat Free Sour Cream and canned chicken; I grilled them in the skillet with no oil, so my high end non stick pans had to do their job)!Surprisingly, it was delicious!  It tasted like the ones that you get at restaurants, but without the oiliness.  I could break off pieces at the top and dip into the salsa and chicken and it was liked a nice chip and when I got to the bottom it had held its shape and texture and the beans did not soak through so I could pick it up and eat it.I am very happy with these and highly recommend them!  They were super easy to use and created a great tasting dinner that did not take long to make but looked and tasted amazing!

I went for a ride to work on a beautiful day, when I got off work, it started to pour down rain...  I was not prepared and was not dressed appropriately (I now have a rain coat for future).  However, not concerning my clothe getting wet, I quickly found that my feet got soaked.  I guess all the water goes down my leg into my shoes and inside the shoes becomes a slushy mess.  The worst part is that the feeling of wet feet in shoes is one of my nastiest feelings; like sticking your feet in mud or something; it is just a nasty feeling.The shoes are Giro road shoes with Speedplay cleats.  They feel like leather or some type of faux leather and they do a good job of keeping water out that lands on them, but they are breathable so that lets water in when there is  a lot of water.  Plus the socks seem to soak it in from the top and that fills up the bottom and makes the padding like a squishy nasty feeling.The shoes are a EU 45 and US 11.  I got the XX-Large shoe covers as that seemed too large at first, since an 11 is about average in US and many are above that.  But from reviews they said go larger so I did.  The shoe covers fit tightly around my shoes and it does require some pulling to get them on (I am fearful of their longevity with this pull).  However, I fear that a larger size could result in the top being open or them getting loose and sliding over the cleat.  I think EU45 is in the middle of xx-xxx size.They do a great job and go up my leg a bit and have velcro to get a tight snug hold, which keeps water from sliding down.  They cover the shoe nicely and after a few uses they are easier to get on/off.  They do stretch and cover the shoe nicely.  The whole in the cleat is a perfect fit for my Speedplay cleats and they fit in nicely (so SPD and Look will fit even better since Speedplay has a large cleat).I am very happy with these and they do their job of keeping my feet dry during wet rides (and when it is cold having wet feet make me feel even worse).  They are easy to walk in and move in and do not interfere with any walking or use and I got the white which are easy to see (truthfully, I wanted to the black, but they were sold out; however, there is no reflective strips on these so the white is more visible, so I am happy now).I highly recommend these if you plan to ride in the rain or in the fog or in the after rain (throwback from the water on ground).  These are amazing and do a great job!  They also were a great price and are a brand I know and like (love my Pearl Izumi gloves).

I got this after a terrible ride where it got dark early and I had to get home going about 5 mph since I could not see the path.  When I first opened this it looked great and well made.  I turned it on and wow, it was bright and lit up the whole garage (tried it in the garage before taking it on the road).  I was excited to get this at a great price (around $30).  Well to make sure it was on secure I bounced the front wheel a little bit and the case did not come off, but the light flickered...  I opened it up and checked the battery holder and made sure the back and front was super tight.  It was all good.  I quickly realized this was not a great light (glad I found out early).  I could turn it on and it was bright, later I could turn it on again and it was dim (I knew about the focus beam part, put that was not the problem).  I know some lights have a bright/dim setting, so I assumed it was just skipping for some reason. I tried a few times and it would either be bright for about a minute and turn dim or would just randomly turn off.  I tried checking everything and trying new batteries, but still had problems.  It just kept randomly dimming itself (which was super dim and worthless) or would start to flicker dimly, or just go off.For something related to safety, I was not going to take a chance with this on the bike (going down the Bay Trail light goes off, and I wind up riding right into the ocean...).  I ride on the San Francisco Bay trail to and from work and at night that trail is pitch black, and you have to be able to see debris and those poles that they put up to stop cars...I returned this item, it is possible that I got a defective unit, but the fact that it worked fine, just would not stay on made me think cheaply made and at around $30 this is not that cheap in my opinion.  I went to Performance Bicycles and got a Nite Rider light they had on sale for $25 and it works great and is brighter than this one and actually stays on.  For safety, I recommend a name brand; as I cannot risk losing light when riding.

This case does feel very rugged and should do a good job protecting your phone.  I cannot say if it can protect from drops as I try to not drop my phone, but this case does feel very solid and gives the Note a rugged outdoor feeling.  I find the case to have good padding around the corners that might help in the dreaded spider crack that is the norm when dropping and hitting a corner.  The screen protector included is nice and feels very thick (I will see how it holds up, as in the past thick screen protectors have started to peel prematurely (maybe with the case always on it will be good)).This is a good case for anyone wanting a little more protection, it does make the Note a tad large and bulkier than it already is, however, if you frequently have to get to your phone in odd places that present a drop risk this would not be bad to have.  It is not a great choice for outdoor living, as water and other elements are still an issue, but for in the city and on the go it is a good choice.  I keep an outdoor case that I use when hiking or anything that is waterproof so this is great when riding my bike in the city.

This is a neat idea and looks like a winner.  However, I was disappointed.SetupSetting up is easy and gives promise, I really wish the volume was initially louder, since when I turned it on I could not hear what the speaker said and she did not want to repeat herself, after unplugging it and leaving it for a while she said it again (I could not hear the URL).  I followed the instructions and it forced me to create a Rdio account (not happy about that, as I do not use Rdio; I am a Pandora person).  I used my iPhone to setup the account and it was easy and I cannot complain.  I finally got it setup and it was working (took me to NPR; I can now sound intelligent in conversations and hint that I have listened to NPR...)UseThe controls are cool and the turn fast for next station and turn once for next song was nice (although the turning is a bit tough; it is stiff, maybe after some time it will be a little easier for one handed operation).I was excited and I got ready to tell it a song to play "Play L.A. Love by Fergie", waited, and got some message about if I wanted to hear a specific song I needed a Premium Rdio (get use to this message).  It started to play some song I never heard of...I tried a band, and did play the Beatles, it took about 4 times before it actually played something by the Beatles.  Not a great start.I downloaded the iPhone app for the Cone, and it is very basic and not very useful (which makes me surprised they do not have Android yet).  It essentially shows you what is playing and gives basic controls.Here is my big issue, I cannot specify a song; and saying play artists plays a station for that artist which includes other artists that are 'similar'.  So if I want to hear a certain song I cannot do it from the device, I have to use AirPlay.I cannot use other sources in the Cone, mainly Pandora, which already has my stations, my favorite songs and everything I like.I also, never know (unless I get my iPhone and look at the app) if it successfully heard me and is playing what I want, I say Cee Lo Green and kept getting the message about not playing songs; finally it went through and started playing some hardcore rap (I am an adult and OK with adult content, but the hardcore rap it started playing was very sexual, and not appropriate for the living room...); not even close to Cee Lo Green; but I did not know if that was part of its station or what...What this showed me was that it is possible for it to misunderstand and start playing some real filth, that you would never listen to.  I like uncensored music, so I would not want to limit it, but I also never play extreme rock/rap that is sexual; even if there was parental control in Rdio (might be, did not look) I would not want to be limited to censored, but do not want really filthy music...Also, turning the dial to switch stations takes me to a random place, I have to wait and try to recognize the song to see what I am listening to.I am not sure the target idea of this speaker...  Is it suppose to be a speaker that learns what I like (Pandora already knows), will it start learning the time of day I listen to certain things, maybe in the morning I listen to Techno and in the evening I listen to local news?  I am not sure, but I will say for radios I listen to about the same thing all the time (Today's Hits or Calvin Harris Radio) and if I want talk/news I turn on the TV.It is a good speaker and has a  good sound.  I can stream from my iPhone which is nice, but now a days what WiFi speaker cannot do that?  The talking concept is neat, but without being able to specify a song, or know for certain that I am getting the station I want (I do not have a wide change in what I listen to) I would not recommend this.This thing is more of just a promotion for Rdio Premium (I have heard that message so many times and it is a long message).  I do not use Rdio and do not plan to.  If this had a wider support for different services (primarily Pandora), but others have their personal preference in online radio, this would be nice, the touch is nice, but something like "Pandora Calvin Harris" or "Rdio San Francisco News" would be nice.As it is, I would not recommend it.  Which is a shame as it is a nice speaker and looks and sounds amazing.  It is useful sometimes to quickly hear a band (assuming it hears you right), and it does a pretty good job of getting it.  I think if it had outside sources (other than Rdio) it would be much better.  I have to say that parental controls might need to be enabled if you like to scroll between channels, scrolling through I went from Goo Goo Dolls to Drake; which was not family friendly...  I did not ask for it, I guess it just picks random stations...--Also, the packaging is nice, but you could have shaved some costs off this by cutting down the packaging, that was a lot of cardboard, I kept looking to see if there was more stuff hidden in it...

I recently moved to the city and I want to start using my bike more for my general getting around and not just exercise.  This basket was great as I can use it shop in the store (easily comes off) and can simple hook it to the holder on the front of the bike and go.  The mechanics are ridiculously easy which makes using this basket simple.  The basket locks on when the handles are down and unlocks when they are up so you can tilt it out).  It is a good size so you can hold about two reusable bags of groceries (or one if you really pack it in).  It is deep enough not to allow items to fall out and if you are not using a bag the bottom is mesh so small items will not fall out.  The basket is also very lightweight making it easy to carry on the bike (without adding weight).  and is very productive (although, on a race bike it does take away from the race look...) :)I am really happy with this and it is a great thing to have when you go to the store (no more bulky book bags for me!) and while not a sexy addition to the bike, is very productive and useful!!!

To start with I should mention that I personally prefer high arch faucets. Therefore this is the idea faucet for me, I always find high arch and pull down are the best looking and the easiest to use in the kitchen.  This one is true on both fronts plus the bonus of being able to touch it to turn it on (very useful when your hands are covered with chicken juice or hamburger meat and you need to wash up).First off, the look is amazing!  This is a sharp looking kitchen faucet that adds to any kitchen.  Luckily my new place has a single hole kitchen sink, so this fit perfectly.  If you have an older three hole sink you will need a plate to cover the two other holes (or in the past, I have utilized those for putting dish detergent and hand soap around, but that depends on you and the setup (room)).  This does not come with a cover for the three hole setups.  The faucet is seamless where the pull down meets and with the weight in the perfect position goes in smoothly.Installation:Installation was on par with other sinks (and like other sinks, you will spend most of your time removing the old one).  Getting this one in was not that hard.  However, the extra hookup of the electrical stuff for touch was a little tougher.  As far as installation it is like all other sinks until you get to the electrical part.  It was simple to install and the use of the above the sink tightener made getting this straight and tight a breeze!When I got to the part of installing the touch electrical components it was straight forward, but I realized if you want hot water when you touch it you need another item (not included).  I was kind bummed, since I prefer to wash in hot water.  However, after reviewing the diagrams and reading on that item, I realized the item was just to make the water warm (mix in some cold).  So I just hooked up the touch to the Hot water supply, which works perfect!I finally got it installed.  I realized that when I turned on the faucet (from handle) it would not turn off.  Turned out the touch was activating.  I found out after reading through (the instructions were very lacking; mostly diagrams).  That I could adjust the sensitivity.  I went through each option (1-5) and found 2 to be the best for me.  It detected a brief pause of my skin on the faucet, but did not activate when touching the pull down or the handle.A strange problem I ran into was that when the battery cover was on it would keep resetting the sensitivity, I think the battery cover would cause the button to press inside and trigger the change.  So I just left the battery cover off.In the end this was easy to install (took me about 2 hours; removing old and putting in new and than fine tuning and dealing with problems) and looks amazing.  The touch is super useful and makes life much easier when you do no have to touch a handle with nasty hands and than have to clean your sink after you wash your hands.  For looks and use this is a great choice!!  Very happy!

My old quesadilla maker started to lose its non stick finish after several years of use (I love these, I get the low fat grande tortillas fill with non fat cheese (Kraft) and a little bit of Taco Seasoning and onions.  If I am feeling deserving, I also add some black beans and grilled chicken).  So I use it a lot!Well, I through the old one out when I moved since it was losing its non stick coating (scratched away from use); that was a mistake.  Iw went to all the stores looking for a new one and could not find it!  The only one I could find was a tiny 8" one at Sears.So, I came online, which honestly, was also limiting.  I found this one which was an 11 inch (great for my grande tortillas) and got it!  It was a low price and was an actual quesadilla size.I made some last night and they came out perfect and had a nice toasted color to the top and bottom, cheese melted properly (I use Kraft Fat Free shredded cheese, so it does not get as melty as others, which works better here since it is less prone to coming out) and it tasted great!  I cut it up into the triangles (it leaves a mark/indent in it, and I use a knife or pizza cutter to cut it completely).  I find that I can half it (take three pieces) and some beans on the side and have a great dinner!  I also usually dip it in a little fat free sour cream.The package comes with the maker and a drip tray (never needed it; but if you use really wet fruits or soggy meats, you might).  You want to be sure not to use a knife or metal item to get it out as that will scratch the non stick.  I use the 'George Foreman' spatula that comes with the cooker, and also heat resistant plastic spatulas (be careful some spatulas are not heat resistant and will melt).I am very happy with this and find this is a great item to have to make quick and delicious dinners.  I am not sure why it was so hard to find, used to they were always around during Christmas for presents, but this year I could not find one.  However, I got this one and it is great!!!

To get it out of the way: I love this Immortalitea tea cup. It solves so many issues I have with making tea:1.) The mess.2.) The holding a cup awkwardly so I don't burn myself.3.) Being able to see the tea while it brews to the perfect color.It's definitely peculiar having an insulated "warm cup" of (very hot!) tea that will burn your mouth if you're not careful, so don't be fooled by the cup temperature - the tea will be boiling hot!My only complaint with this tea cup is that the infuser holes to let the tea through can definitely trap tiny particles of tea debris, and it's a little tricky to remove them. Not a huge deal, and you certainly won't die from a rogue tea particle, but it's something to bear in mind.Overall, though, I love this thing. Easy to make tea, easy to clean up (caveat aside), and fun to drink from.4.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.*Sample received for objective review*

Amcrest really is on a winning streak with these HD dome-style cameras. I'm fortunate enough to have this 720p model's bigger brother, the Amcrest ProHD 1080P WiFi Wireless IP Security Camera - 1080P (1920TVL), IP2M-841 (Black), and while this 720p model is still excellent, it doesn't quite have the resolving of fine detail as the above model.Pretty much all of the pluses and minuses of the 1080p model are applicable here. That means a little barrel distortion (solved by digitally zooming just a hair), and a still-imperfect app in iOS that's not been updated to support the 6, 6s, 6 Plus or 6s Plus (the app is scaled on those devices, but does work). This is especially a downer with the 1080p model camera, since the app is designed for the 1136x640 resolution of the iPhone 5, so 1080p playback on the 6 Plus or 6s Plus isn't... well... 1080p!Anyway, the 720p model puts out a great picture, but it's not quite as sharp as the 1080p model, even at a sub-optimal resolution in the iPhone app.Setup over wifi was a piece of cake on my iPhone 6s Plus. The included quick-instruction card runs you through this absolutely perfectly, and I had this camera set up within 60 seconds. The camera connected to my wireless ac Time Capsule over the 2.4GHz network (no 5GHz support) without any trouble, and two floors up it maintained a very good connection. Control from the Amcrest app from my iPhone is flawless, and I'm still incredibly impressed by the smooth playback and controls in the Amcrest app, even if the rest of the app is a bit of a letdown. It pans left/right/up/down extremely smoothly, and motion captured from the camera is equally smooth and lag-free over even half-decent connections. I also like being able to see both the 1080p and 720p cameras at the same time in the overview screen in the app, and being able to switch between camera feed with a single swipe (see, not all is bad in the app!).Overall, app aside (again!), Amcrest has another superb camera on the market. I'd still say if you can swing it, get the 1080p model if you'd like that slightly better camera system. But really, you can't go wrong either way. Another winner from Amcrest.4.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.

This really is a well-made and relatively compact Yoga-accessory bag. I'll get that out of the way first! I can easily fit my yoga brick and cloths inside without any trouble. I really like how it zips down the side, because it means the bag opening is much large than if it just opened like a "regular" backpack at the top.However, and this is a big one for me - my yoga mat is simply too thick when rolled up for the Gecko Active's mat straps to get around. They just won't make it around the entire mat. I accept that part of the problem is me: I'm 6'5" tall, and thus my mat is longer - and rolls up thicker - than the "average" mat.However, for ME that's a downer. For my wife who is 5'4", this is no issue since her mat is a lot shorter. So now she's taken the bag as her own... *cries*.So there you go. This is a great yoga accessory as long as you're not stupidly tall. I guess being able to see over everyone has its downsides after all...4 stars out of 5. Recommended with the above caveat.*Sample received for objective review*

The Vorbana Vertical Stand is... OK. Yep, that's probably the highest praise I can heap on it.But, it's only just "OK" for one big reason, - but first - the good things!1.) Very simple to set up. The PS4 fits perfectly into the PS4-shaped cutout on the right. It's then easy to plug the USB cable into the front.2. The two controller slots will also charge the Dualshock 4 controllers. They will also charge the controllers while the system is in standby, as long as you have USB power set to ON in the Playstation 4 power-save settings.But now... the bad things. Or, should I say - the one bad thing:1.) The fan noise. It's ugly. A nasty, grinding-sounding fan noise from both of the fans in the unit. I'm guessing these aren't brushless fans (not easy to tell since I can't read the labels on the fans to see the brand). The system itself does vent well, and the fans are pointing away from the PS4 and out the bottom, but the noise is just far too annoying for my liking. Don't get me wrong - the fans do work, - they just sound terrible while doing so.Bottom line: If your PS4 is nowhere (and I mean nowhere) near where you sit, - perhaps hidden away in a cabinet, -  you could certainly do a lot worse than the Vorbana Vertical Stand. But.., if the PS4 is out in the open, your mileage may vary as to how annoying you find the unit's dual-fan noise. For me, it was a deal killer.3.5 stars out of 5. Certainly this is for someone, - just not for me.*Sample provided for objective review*

The VcTsing CD/DVD-RW burner is exactly that, but it does come at a cost (or is it a lack of cost?)It burns CDs and it burns DVDs. I had no issues burning either when connected to my Elgato Thunderbolt 2 dock via a USB 3.0 port, or via the USB 3.0 ports on my 2014 5K iMac.However, the device feels cheap. No, scrap that - it SCREAMS cheap. First, the very plastic exterior is bound to get trashed if you throw it into a bag with "other stuff," so may want to a small case to go with this if you're a laptop traveler. Plastic isn't always bad, but this definitely feels like the non-quality type of plastic. The same goes for the USB end.Second, the mechanism to eject doesn't feel altogether very solid. And, for some reason, there's an eject symbol on the right of the drive, but the actual eject button is further to the left of it. Huh?Third, there are several screws on the inside of the tray, and while they're supposed to be a silver color, one of the screws inside my drive is a little....how should I put it... brown? It looks like a slight rust sheen to the screw. Not exactly inspiring.Lastly the USB cable is connected directly to the drive, and there's no way to replace it. While this is reminiscent of Apple's own SuperDrive, it wasn't an ideal design there and it's still not an ideal design. If you put too much pressure on the cable where it attaches to the drive (both in the case of Apple's and VicTsing's here), the cable will fray/snap, and you'll be left with a dead drive.Overall, though, in terms of performance, the drive does indeed work. I'm not sure USB 3.0 was necessary for this burner, as I have several other drives with similar/the same specifications, and all of them work just as quickly over USB 2.0. If it were Blu-ray, the need for USB 3.0 is more obvious, but for a DVD burner? I'd have perhaps like to see that extra cost of USB 3.0 channelled into a slightly more premium feel to the drive.As an aside, I wanted to call into question the following from the description:"CLASSIC APPEARANCE. With exterior silvery aluminum grinding surface finish, this CD/DVD writer/burner is fashionable and scratch-proof."OK, so classic appearance and fashionable are subjective. But scratch-proof? I took some keys and pretty gently rubbed them over the top of the unit (in the interest of science!). Nope, NOT scratch proof. This WILL get scratched up to all heck if you travel with it unprotected.So, the VicTsing does work fine. But, for less money you can certainly get a more premium-feeling drive from LG or Samsung on Amazon...3 stars out of 5. OK.*Sample provided for objective review*

Anyone who drinks wine should have an aerator of some sort. This is just simple Wine-Drinking 101.This Anear wine aerator does many things right. First, it makes pouring wine that much simpler because it provides a nice spout. Second, it does a great job aerating, putting beautiful, temporary oxygenated bubbles in the wine you pour out.Cleanup is simple, requiring just pouring warm water over it to clean out any wine.Downside? Just one of note, really. There's a straw that goes down into the bottle, so when the bottle is nearly empty, you'll need to remove the aerator and pour directly from the bottle. Not the end of the world, but worth noting.Overall, 4.75 out of 5. Highly recommended.*Sample provided for objective review*

This Dead Sea Essentials shower soap/bubble bath set is nice. It feels very "fresh" on your skin, and my overall experience with the shower gel is quite positive.However, there are a few issues:1.) As bubble bath it's pretty weak. Not many bubbles, - more of a bubble slick on the surface of the water. You can do MUCH better in this space.2.) The lid is just a screw top, which means it's a little more awkward than it should be when used as shower gel, since you have to take the top clean off to dispense liquid.Overall, I like the smells and feel of this soap (especially the hibiscus - love it), but it's more of a jack of all trades set. The bubble bath-ability is the standout disappointment.3.75 out of 5. Recommended with caveats.

You know it's a good sign when your pet makes a beeline for a new carrier and curls straight up in it - and goes to sleep.And that's what happened here. Barely had I zipped up one end before my 9lb Shih Tzu clambered into it, sighed, and dozed off.For a toy breed like a smaller Shih Tzu, this is definitely a roomy carrier. It will certainly fit under plane seats, but you may need to wedge it slightly - height-wise. Given the huge head-room available here, that shouldn't be an issue.I'm impressed with the build quality here. Double zippers on both ends, and it stays rigid and upright when zipped up. My old carrier (similar style) just sort of collapses on itself so it was due to be replaced anyway. This Geega-Pet model looks like it will hold up a lot better over time.Overall, there's nothing to dislike here, and my Shih Tzu loves it, so there's a double recommendation for you.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.*Sample received for objective review*

You know, reviewing eau de toilette is not an easy task. It's one of those things you generally really need to smell for yourself to decide if you like it.Helpful, I know.I could just say that if you like this Burberry Brit Rhythm smell, then you should buy it, and if you don't like this smell, then... you probably shouldn't buy it.No, still not helpful.I'll say this (trying to be helpful, truly) that it's a very pleasant smell. Some people tell me they can smell the cardamom, but I just give them a blank stare. I'm a guy, I admit it, so blank stares come often when it comes to describing odors. It's a very inoffensive smell in terms of the Annoying Everyone Around You scale, though. It's certainly classy, - but don't overspray it. Even one press on the snazzy-looking bottle can be enough, and the smell does stay with you for several hours.Overall, I've really enjoyed using Brit Rhythm (and being British, it feels just slightly better - for no tangible reason of course). It works for a casual event, or for business use. And unless you go completely crazy with it, the 3oz bottle will last an extremely long time.5 out of 5 stars. Highly recommended (...for me. For you? Who knows...? Chances are good you'll like it, though, given other reviews here...).

The Logitech K380 solves a problem I'm sure many of us have. We have multiple devices like iPads or Playstations or Macs/PCs, but we don't use them all at the same time, and it would be nice not to have so many keyboards lying around.Enter the K380, a very solid (literally) keyboard from Logitech.The first thing you notice when you pick up K380 in it is that it's surprisingly heavy. That's because despite being not the largest keyboard in the world, it's got a great heft to it. It's certainly not cheap feeling.Setting up the keyboard is simple. Open up battery compartment, put in the 2x AAA batteries (included), and then hold down one of the three yellow Bluetooth pairing buttons to put the keyboard into pair mode for that particular memory preset. Yes, you can pair with three different systems, and switch between those systems with just a tap of the same yellow button assigned to that preset.I have been successfully using the K380 with my 2014 iMac, my 2010 Sony Vaio laptop, and my Sony Playstation 4, without any issues. I'm very happy that all the shortcut keys for volume//mute/play/pause/skip track etc work great on Windows/Mac, but adjusting screen brightness doesn't work on the Mac since those keys are the Bluetooth pairing keys on the K380. No great problem, since I'm mainly using this keyboard for Windows and Playstation 4.In terms of key feel, I'm impressed. The keys don't "clack" very much, and have a solid feel to them. If I have one criticism, it's that I'd prefer if the keys were square instead of round, but I accept that this is a personal choice, and others may be quite happy with the keys here. At least they are about full-size!Overall, this is a great keyboard. With a claimed 2-year battery life from 2x AAA batteries, a low price, and an easy set up and switching between devices, it's really hard not to recommend this keyboard.4.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.

Given that you can buy Lightning cables for quite cheap these days (even Apple MFi cables), a dock needs to be a bit more than just a cable with a bit of plastic around it - to be worth this sort of money.The OZAI O!tool (what a name!) is well made, for sure, but there's nothing here that screams must buy, especially with a few issues it has.1.) The "amplification" is just essentially a channel for the audio from your phone to travel and out to the left. It's not electronic amplification, and it's just essentially channelling the audio to "focus" it. Yes, it's a bit louder than using the iPhone by itself, but it's still not that great. It's not recommended for music, but it does work fine as a slightly louder speakerphone on your desk.2.) You can't use this with a case that protects the bottom of the phone, no matter how thin said case is. That said, if you're using an Apple case that leaves that bottom edge exposed, it will work fine here.The build quality of this IS really good, though. Very solid, nice weight to it, but it's just not a must-buy, and for the money, that means a bit disappointing.3 stars out of 5. OK.*Sample received for objective review*

Maybe I set my expectations just a little too high, but this Panasonic trimmer isn't quite as good I'd have liked. But it's certainly a solid option.I like a 5mm trim for my head shave. I found I had to set the trimmer to be 4.5mm to attain a 5mm length that my other trimmers hit. I suppose there's no harm in being conservative. In terms of trimming, it did so pretty consistently across my head, so no real complaints there. The trimmer guard is easy to attach and remove, and there's basically no danger of accidentally switching the trimmer settings by mistake. The pop-up trimmer did a decent job, but did not give as close a cut as my Braun Cruzer 6 Body Shaver, which has been soldiering on for about 4 years now without complaints.I do not particularly like having to oil the blade so often on this Panasonic, and the manual is very insistent that you do, so... bleh.On the plus side, I was surprised to see a world-wide 100-240V charger included. It's always best to check *your* charger, but if it's like the one I received, it's good to be used worldwide (you'll just need a cheap end-piece to convert US 2-prong to... whatever end you need). I can't think of a time I've had a trimmer with this sort of charger, so kudos, Panasonic.Overall, this is a decent trimmer. Perfect for travel with the world-wide charger. There's nothing particularly standout about it, but it certainly does the job.3.75 out of 5.

This is an "OK" case. Not amazing, not terrible. VERY minimalist, scratched pretty easily with a fingernail. But it does the job of protecting the phone with minimal bulk. Just bear in mind the whole bottom is exposed except for the corners. I'm generally not a fan of this layout..The included screen protectors (two - one for a black iPhone face and one for a white iPhone face) are quite difficult to put on without getting dust under them. I'd say if you're VERY particular about bubbles due to dust etc, don't bother with them.Overall, a solid product. If you want extremely light, minimalist protection, this is a good case. If you need something a bit tougher than minimalist, go elsewhere.3.75 out of 5. Decent.(As is usual for OZAKI, the packaging is sensational. The clear box feels like it's designed for a high-end piece of electronics.)*Sample provided for objective review*

The Jabra ECLIPSE (why the caps?) is teetering dangerously close to form over functionality, but there's no questioning its design aesthetic. The headset itself has no straight edges. Everything curves delightfully, and it feels wonderful in the hand.The packaging is smart, and I'm happy to see that no power adapter is provided. Given the ubiquitousness of micro USB, grab one of the thousand of those cables you have (or use the tiny one in the box) and charge away via your computer, iPhone plug etc.The headset comes with four different size inserts for your ears (extra small, small, medium, and large), and I found the medium size one already installed was perfect for my ears. Experiment to find the one most comfortable. It's very comfortable in my ear, and very solid - it's not falling out. However, because of the design, it does give that slight ear-plugged feeling. On the plus side, it's easier to hear the person on the other end when there's lots of background noise due to the slight isolating nature of the insert itself.1.) Call quality is excellent. In a bathroom, the echo is reduced significantly, and people over FaceTime audio said I sounded extremely clear and "full." Background noise is reduced dramatically outside, and overall, this is a very pleasing Bluetooth experience with my iPhone 6s Plus. With the Jabra Assist app on the Apple App Store, I was able to bump the call quality to add a little bass, as the standard setting was just a little too thin for my liking.There are some problems, though:1.) Three hours of battery life. Jabra tries to get away with this by outfitting the charger/dock (which the headsets docks delightfully in, magnetically) with an internal battery as well - giving you an extra 7 hours for a total of 10 hours of battery life, but.. the bottom line is you're getting three hours of battery life from the headset at any one time. If you want more, you'll need to wait the two hours for a full charge in the charger before you can use the headset again. This is a real downer, especially when competing headsets have 7-10 hours of battery life all in the headset. The price of delicious aesthetics... 3 hours of battery life from 2 hours of charging. Oh the humanity...Yes, you can pop the headset in the dock/charger while you're out and about. Jabra even touts you can charge it in your pocket, but while small - it's not exactly tiny. I personally wouldn't want to have to charge the thing in my pocket.2.) If you lose the charging dock, you're out of luck. There's no way to charge the headset except in the dock.3.) There are no physical buttons on the headset. You can tap the headset (I find it easiest to do that where it goes into your ear) to enable Siri etc. However, it's extremely fiddly to use this touch method, and I suspect many of us will end up tapping at our headsets trying to get the feature to work. Yes, there's a learning curve, but it's still too fiddly. Ending calls to another person might end up with them deafened as you tap away at what is essentially a microphone with an earpiece. I would have preferred to see a little button above the word "Jabra" on the top of the headset to answer/end calls. Yes, it would have taken away from those delicious aesthetics, but usability is important, at SOME point!4.) Volume control is handled entirely on your phone. This is a bit annoying since my phone is often in my pocket. The Jabra assist will adjust volume (with the option on) depending on ambient noise, but I prefer to change volume myself.5.) The only way to turn off the headset is to put it in the dock. So, if you leave your fully-charged headset in the car, without the dock, it's just going to drain its standby time (7 days, according to Jabra) and its available talk time, of course, as a result.6.) Right ears only. You can get away with it in your left ear if you must, but it doesn't fit quite as nicely.7.) NFC/Bluetooth pairing is only available while the headset is in the dock, so if you're looking to pair your headset with a different phone while out and about without the dock, you're out of luck.8.) To check the battery status, you can tap the headset once and there's a green LED that lights up. You can also press the button on the underside of the dock/charger to see the same thing. However, it will show either a green light or a red light. A green light means the headset has over 20%, and a red light means under 20%. A green light for over 20% battery is not my idea of helpful... at all. When the the dock itself is charged (three white LEDs solidly on), there's no indicator at all of how charged the headset itself is, though. You'll need to take the headset out of the dock (which turns it on) and see in the Jabra Assist app the actual battery life (or the icon at the top of your iPhone screen).Overall, I do really like this headset. However, I feel it's better served for occasional outdoor use, or as a nice headset around the home. It means you can leave the dock/charger plugged in to your computer at all times, and when you're done calling someone, you just place it right back in there, ready for use later on. A perfect use-in-one-place companion.As an out-and-about headset for the on-the-go users among us, this really isn't your headset. No on/off button, poor continuous battery life, and just general user interface issues means you should probably look elsewhere.3.75 stars out of 5. Recommended with quite a few caveats.

This Luxury SPA Bath Pillow isn't particularly luxury, but it certainly is a very nice pillow, especially for its low price. It suctions extremely well to my tub, is super easy to clean, is extremely comfortable, and... uh... yep that's probably about it.I thought about posting some pictures of me enjoying this in the tub, but someone already beat me to it, - which is further proof I've never had an original thought in my entire life. I suppose that's pretty depressing now that I think about it.Anyway, 5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.*Sample provided for objective review*

There's not a huge amount to say that hasn't been said before. This is a great infusion pitcher, but I'm not loving it for sangria. The problem with is that you will end up with fruit high-up in the center fruit-holder, so much of the fruit is suspended ABOVE the liquid. D'oh! You can put more liquid in, but then your sangria is diluted too much. Most recipes for sangria call for 2-3 whole fruits per bottle of wine. You simply can't make that work here.But, for lemon/orange-infused water etc, this is a great product. I've really enjoyed drinking naturally-flavored (in the sense of real fruit!) water this way.Bearing in mind the sangria deficiency, it's definitely a great pitcher.4 stars out of 5. Recommended.*Sample received for objective review*

I've gone through more of these cameras than I like to admit. I'd been using a Foscam FI9821P for a while, and not been happy with it. Focus is poor, and the color at night under house lighting is a dingy orange (see picture!). I'd already exchanged one, but the replacement was no better, so I just gave up.Given the above, the chance to review the Amcrest ProHD couldn't have come at a better time. However, the setup procedure wasn't quite as smooth as I'd have liked it to be. If it had been just a LITTLE clearer, I'd have been happier. But let's start at the beginning..First, the box it comes in is excellent. Well-packaged, feels high-end, and overall is a positive unboxing experience. Unlike some other dome-camera systems, the wifi antenna is built in. There's no external antenna to connect, and in my experience checking signals in the desktop browser app, it hasn't needed it.I plugged the power cord in to the camera/wall, and then the included ethernet cable from the camera to my Apple Airport Time Capsule ac model.I'm an iPhone user, and setting up with my iPhone 6s Plus in iOS 9 was a little more confusing than I'd like. The setup card included in the box directed me to download the Amcrest Viewer (the free one is all you need if you're not needing push notifications etc). No issue, - downloaded in seconds.. Adding the camera was very simple by scanning the QR code at the bottom of the camera itself. At this point, it asked me to input my WiFi SSID and password to connect to the network. But... but... I don't want to use WiFi, because I connected the camera via an ethernet cable!Turns out, you don't need to worry. I entered in a network SSID the camera couldn't see (my 5Ghz network, for example, or you could use an entirely made-up network. Either way, the camera is not 5Ghz compatible). Type in a fake password, and hit connect. Voila, it will say "Done," but really it's just using wired ethernet at this time because it didn't connect to WiFi. It's a bit odd you can't just pick wired and skip WiFi setup, but there you go.., you're done!For reference, more fine-tuning of things (like adding day/date stamps to your video or adjusting hue/contrast/night vision) can be done in the desktop browser, so log in to the camera and make changes there. This is pretty simple, following the setup card instructions. You can also completely disable the WiFi chip from the browser app on your computer, which I did. No need to even have it on if you're using a wired connection. This worked on my iMac running El Capitan, in the Safari browser, - no issues.At this point, on my iPhone and via the desktop browser, - I was very impressed with the image quality. It absolutely DESTROYS the Foscam FI9821P (see comparison picture). For one, the orange cast to the image under regular house lights is now gone. Second, the image is much wider, fitting more of the room into the image. Unfortunately, there is some barrel distortion on the edges, but this is to be expected at such a wide angle. The center of the image looks great, with very little distortion. To "solve" this, you can always zoom in just a hair in the app. Yes, it's digitally zoomed, but it makes very little image-quality difference, and does remove the barrel distortion on the edges.Moving the camera left/right/up/down is also very simple, and VERY smooth in the iPhone app, over both WiFi and LTE.One unfortunate thing, though, is that there's no native iPhone 6/6s support (including Plus models). I'm hoping Amcrest updates their app to properly support these devices. The app works fine in iOS 9 on those iPhones, but you can tell it's not optimized for their resolutions. The app is definitely a bit of a letdown, but it's not too far off the mark. It does the job, though, and is free.I'm very impressed with the camera quality. It's the best I've used. The colors, especially under house lighting at night, are surprisingly accurate. The room the camera is located in actually looks like this in real life in comparison to the video feed. Automatic switching to night vision works great, and the resultant image is also excellent. While out this evening, I was able to do a test run over LTE, enabling the speaker/microphone in the Amcrest Viewer app and having a conversation with my wife. It worked just great.Overall, this is a superb camera. With a few tweaks, the app could be great, which is my only minor complaint.4.75 out of 5. A gold-standard dome camera.*Sample received for objective review*

LifeStraw definitely have their game on with their Gravity-Fed water purifier.First, there's really not that much to setting it up. While the instructions are a tad confusing as to what EXACTLY the back-wash bulb is doing, the video on the product page makes it much simpler to understand, so I recommend spending the two minutes watching that video to give you a better sense of the product (over the tiny manual).It's very easy to use and very easy to clean. I admit, I don't travel all that much into the great outdoors. On the other hand, it's so easy to take running, clean water for granted, and so why not be prepared?To use the water purifier, it's as simple as this:1.) Fill with water (only to white line), roll over the top of the bag, throw strap over tree (or something else that will suspend it vertically), and snap around the bag. Connect stay to bag (making sure that both levers are in the horizontal position).2.) Turn red lever to either vertical position to let UN-treated water out for 10 seconds.3.) Turn red lever horizontally to stop UN-treated water flow.4.) Turn blue/green lever vertical to let clean water flow (it does so much slower than the red outlet as it's being filtered simultaneously).I do recommend, if you're able to while camping etc, let the untreated water out nowhere near where you'll actually be filling your drinking containers. You want to avoid cross contamination if possible!Overall, it would be impossible not to recommend the LifeStraw. If anything, it's a reminder of how lucky many of us are with running water.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.*sample provided for objective review*

The Spigen Apple Watch Stand works really well. Let's get that out of the way. I have very few complaints, so since it works so well, I'll just address the couple of niggles I have.1.) I do wish there were a way for the charging cable to come straight out of the back, rather than the sides. This would tidy things up a little, though this will depend on your bedroom/desk setup.2.) the 38mm adapter piece it comes with is a little tricky to get straight since it sticks down very easily. I suggest using a credit card to line things up against it as you stick the piece down. The nice thing is that in my experience the 42mm Watch works fine with the 38mm piece installed, too.Overall, this is an excellent stand. It does a much better job than several others I've tried, and the way it sticks to your desk is very smart. If you're looking at other stands currently, be aware if there's no lip like the Spigen, the Apple Watch will sag due to the strap weight, and I was getting obsessive about trying to balance it to get it rotated straight with a competing stand. Gaaa! I'm glad with the Spigen not to have to do this anymore.Overall, 4.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended, especially at this low price point.

These are great batteries, and I've been really happy with their performance and longevity when paired with this head-lamp, the LiteXim Hands free Outdoor Ultra Bright 3 Modes 400 Lumen Q5 Zoomable LED Headlamp Camping Hiking Fishing Headlight.For high-drain devices, these come highly recommended.5 stars out of 5.*Sample received for objective review*

This is a pretty solid light, and it's also useful indoors, despite being marketed as an outdoor light.The battery compartment is easily accessed via the rubber housing (no tools required like some other head-lamps out there).Only two modes are really useful, the bright, and not-quite-as-bright settings. I don't really see the point of the strobe-light setting.My only real complaint is that it takes 2 x 18650 batteries, which are not common. I picked up EXCELLENT 3.7V 18650 Li-Ion Rechargeable Batteries (2-Pack), and they work just great. There's a charging port on the side of the headlamp, but no charger is included.Overall, this is a solid product. It's pretty comfortable, and I've used it around the house and working on fixing small electronics, happily!4.5 stars out of 5. Highly recommended.*Sample provided for objective review*

I have a small Shih Tzu, and he has a bit of a beard (OK, he has a substantial beard). Whenever he drinks, he drips water off his beard for the next few minutes. It's especially bad right by his drinking bowl on the wood floor...Solution? A silicone pet feeding mat. It collects the most heavy of the water drippage, while still providing room for his food bowl next to it. Oh, and it's easy to clean? Win.Overall, 5 stars out of 5. Recommended.*Sample received for objective review*

I was really hoping that for the money this Premium Ice Ball Maker would really make a whiskey-drinking experience that much better. But, alas, it really didn't. It just mostly annoyed me.First, the procedure of getting the water into the contraption is just one giant pain. You have to have finesse, a steady hand, and try to avoid over-filling or getting too much water in the top part. Inevitably, you won't be able to do all these things and so you'll suffer from one or a combination of the following:1.) Great difficulty removing the top part from the bottom after freezing, because the water on the top has frozen.2.) Cutting yourself on shards of ice that you try to remove from the top section.3.) Balls that aren't completely solid and are attached to each other by the swimming pool of water that froze around them in the bottom tray. (trying to separate the balls from the additional water that froze is really annoying).4.) Balls of ice that just aren't very attractive, with seams and cloudy parts where it froze unevenly. They fall apart too quickly in a glass of whiskey, too, because of the lack of solidity.I was mostly just annoyed by all of this. The balls aren't very attractive when chunks of additional ice are attached to them, and trying to get the water in without making a mess was for me more trouble than it was worth.2.5 stars out of 5. Not a good experience.*Sample provided for objective review*

This is a really odd product, and I'm not really sure I *get it*.It's shatterproof, but only because it's essentially two bottles in one. The inner glass bottle (which is most certainly not shatter-proof in of itself), and then the outer plastic bottle which the glass one sits inside to make it "shatter proof." Yes, you fill only the glass part, but it makes me wonder what the point is? Your lips touch the plastic when you're drinking, and you're only really aware that it's glass because it weighs so darn much. The rest of the time you're just holding a plastic bottle. So why not just use a plastic bottle?Also, the drinking area is pretty rudimentary stuff, certainly nothing like the clever Contigo bottle caps out there. Doesn't feel great at your mouth, and I can't say I expect it to last as long my Contigos either.So there you have it. A rather bewildering bottle, that's interesting just because of its novelty factor, but in my eyes it's certainly not a must-buy.3 stars out of 5. Ho hum...*Sample provided for objective review*

I really like these adapters over straight-up HDMI to DisplayPort cables because the adapter gives you the flexibility to use HDMI cables of varying lengths depending on your needs.I used this with a 2011 MacBook Air and a 2013 13" MacBook Pro and had no issues, so it's certainly recommended with either of those systems (I was outputting at 1080p).Overall, there's little to dislike here. It's a solid device with gold-plated connectors, and the HDMI cable doesn't feel loose when plugged into it.5 stars out of 5. Recommended.*Sample provided for objective review*

MYOHO has a nice line of accessories, and this Micro USB 2.0 cable does the job decently, too. It's a crowded USB market out there, so don't expect anything mind-blowing here, but this does the trick.A couple of things. The connectors are solid, but the cable itself isn't going to stand up to huge amounts of abuse.
