I would take another star off for the marketing hype. There is nothing innovative here. The word "dynamic" should read "elastic" and the term "progressive resistance" as "you can pick one, two or three straps". The exercise guide is nothing that is not obvious from the pictures you see on the offering page here.  I did not take off the other star because the above is normal when dealing with a simple product imported from China. It works as one would expect, so it gets four stars.To get five stars, all that would have been necessary would have been to include a couple of other sets of bands marked with their resistance value. That way, you could have a nicer gradation of resistance. That way, you could choose to have a more effective workout depending upon the demands of each exercise, and whether you were going for maximum stress or longer sets of repetitions. Obviously you could also have a finer gradation as your strength increases, if that is your goal.As it is, one strap is a good way to do the exercise pictured where she stretches both arms out, and doing several sets of, say, ten repetitions. Or as the picture where he is stretching one arm with the other stationary at his sternum, using all three is not difficult. Just remember that when two straps is chosen, take out the middle strap to maintain balance. The straps are removed easily and replaced securely with this design.

Makes sense Hall would start his selection of old poems with "My Son the Executioner", since he is living it out some sixty years later. Seems he still agrees with what he wrote about an instrument of immortality. Makes sense that many of his selections are on aging and some deaths.No preface or introduction, he pitches lines strait at us. He poses more questions than he answers. Besides that immortality, why does he say that most gunslingers are left handed? Is that a symbol for sinister? No matter, he is fun to read when he lets out the sun.  I like his "unfriendly birds (they really are, you know) -- and out comes his little nods to Poe.For a kid that went to a bunch of snooty schools, Exeter, Harvard and Oxford, he emerged awake and aware. He has not been not afeared of poetic form and structure. Early on he punched above his weight landing combinations of meter and of rhyme. Must have been all those good years at Michigan. A few baseball selections are here. "Old Timer's Day" is one; his dad had taken him to see Ted Williams in his prime. But the stinker leaves out his brilliant nine stanza, "Baseball". He figures those who like that stuff will go buy a copy of "Museum of Clear Ideas, where it is the lead-off poem.Not to give the idea at all that the subject is overdone with him, baseball is hard to write poetry about, as if any subject were easy. He does it without any of that phone George Will boyish, cuts-pie drivel. He wrote a book of essays on sports, too. Late in this slim collection, Hall returns to baseball, but as a means to his long dead love, Jane, and with a few other ingredients into "Meatloaf".Finally, a brief Afterword. Like Milton, he decided on poetry early. If this book is your first, it may well lead you to others. For myself, I am glad I caught and killed an already dead metaphor with my red rubber bullet.Thank you for your patience.

I remember my lengthy time reading Heidegger ("not the man, but the matter of his thinking") as a protracted mental hernia.The memory of that pain, because it is a memory, nostalgic and rose, returned in some part of its true agony as soon as I started Trawny's splendid little volume. Early on he remembers Junger's characterizing Heidegger's home as the forest -- the untrodden and the uncertain. Great; back to a place where home means its own opposite. Again a queasy guest at Heidegger's home, I was home again.Heidegger rode Nietzsche's horse into the end of the 19th century and came flying out the other side in an airplane. His horrible style, knotty language, is the torture of creation. The horror is his unbearable butchery of a dozen millennia of pleasant error. Syntax and etymology are his flashing cleavers.Truth is nothing out there just waiting for discovery. His hacking, slashing and gutting blows are what eventuate truth or meaning. Plato's Idealism, Kant and Hegel's Absolute, any eternal truth is a mug's game. Even the more durable truths like mathematics or physics are in the ruins of incoherence and incompleteness, those jaws of Godel's Kerberos. [ I think Heidegger is blown into the swamp here because he errs in being forced by the sheer gale of his own thought into taking math to be objective and therefore not truly true.]Trawny throws himself into this muck like the old anarchist (brilliantly rendered by Fernando Rey) in Wertmuller's "Seven Beauties", when the concentration camp inmate hurls himself into the cess pool. Hmm, movies can eventuate truths where no mere language alone can. Trawny dances around Heidegger's ashes to conjure his truths of the Schwarze Hefte for us.But what is there for Trawny to do about the elephant in the lebensraum? What good is any of this in the face of anti-semitic National Socialism? His already slender volume shrunk further still in my hands. Trawny attempts to pull a rabbit out of Heidegger's hat. He wills to be the magician he has shown Heidegger to have been. To shut down his philosophy in this conclusive guilt is to join the guilty. Trials reach conclusions, but philosophy cannot, even in madness. Anti-semitism, in full flame of evil cannot be proscribed because no proscribing can be legitimate a priori.Sophistry? Yes says Trawny. Guilty again.  Old Marty was a sophist, an alchemist and a true devil worshiping theology. But what of Hanna and her testimony of his greatness? Nothing. No thing. Nothing? Still guilty and still concluded. So just how is one to disentangle thought and action? For ten thousand years the brain followed the hand. Then and more and more the hand began to follow the mind -- for good and for ill."When Thales, contemplating the sky, fell into the well, the Thracian girl laughed"So might all our thinking be the proper object for ridicule. My book-burned fingers can draw no conclusion but to urge on...Read! Think! Write! and Talk...rinse and repeat...Thank you for your patience

This is a handy pry bar to get good leverage in hard to fit tight spaces. It offers superior range of motion from fixed bars. I will include photographs that show the extreme ranges allowed. It was exactly what I needed to replace my car’s serpentine belt, a very light duty job.In my opinion this pry bar is suited for light and medium duty.  I personally would not trust the adjustable indexing gear for extended heavy duty use and depending on what I was lifting, I might be concerned about safety. But that’s just me. To my feel the indexing gear appears to be the stress point on the tool. The company has a very good video on YouTube and I recommend viewing before purchasing to help you visualize and answer questions you might not think of. The video demonstration shows removal the indexing gear from the metal bar and handle which makes me think that the gear is designed to be able to be replaced.The handle is not padded and does not have a comfort grip. I prefer the steel grip handle because it allows me to be brutal. The GearWrench is manufactured in China for Apex Tools.I like the tool. It’s a good addition to my tool box. And its cheaper than having to pay to have simple DIY work performed for me. At the time of this review, this pry bar is priced on Amazon half of the retail price on GearWrench's website.

This toy is pretty cute to look at, but I wish there were a few adjustments. The concept is basic: baby stacks blocks onto the head, or drops one in the mouth. A dropped block will make arms move, and then exit either the left or right foot, so it's a surprise for baby.Con 1: The drop is almost instant, and even I don't have time to really notice the arms move or the block fall. I wish it were designed with more resistance in the arms, so the movement was slower and baby could actually watch the path of the block fall. This would give a better sense of cause and effect: how the moving blocks move the arms, and how the arms change the path of the block.Con 2: There's no way to store the blocks inside or with the zebra (they are designed to always fall out), so that I can put the toy away and easily keep all the parts together.These are biggest points. But, like I said, the design is cute, and it's also sturdy. The blocks are good for stacking or rolling on their own. Maybe I can find a way to gum up the arms, so the toy is more fun.

Pretty simple. Plug into your Mac USB and sit your iPhone on top. Fast and easy to use while docked.Better for my desktop than having to lay the phone in some awkward spot to using more space to lay flat.One star loss because it will not change on all USBs, the way a simple cable will.

I started working out with a personal trainer after a hospitalization a few years back. Patrick has done a world of good for me but he can’t be there all the time. He’s not there while I’m stuck all day at the computer on conference calls, writing, creating reports and managing project workflows.  I focus on work and forget that my body needs attention too; I simply forget to move until its too late and everything hurts.The gentle reminder of the Pivotal Living Band keeps monitors my movement and inactivity.  It is an easy, painless way of keeping my needs in alignment even when I’m under stress.Yes, I could schedule more time each week with Patrick. But the band costs less than one additional session and its with me always, even monitoring my sleep. Patrick agrees, this wearable monitor is an important addition to caring for my health. I can use the Pivotal Living App to graph for Patrick my last few days so he has a better idea of what my workout should include.The only potential concern that I can see is personal security. You register and use the app from your phone or tablet. After that I don't control  my data and for what I can tell, have no user privacy. The phone and tablet point back directly to me with no filtering of identity. I do not have control or assurance  that HIPAA protections are being observed to keep my identity and health monitoring records confidential, non-discoverable and away from anyone to whom I don't care to divulge. I don't know how my records may be used. This may be a concern for only a few but it is a concern that each person should consciously decide if it's important.The Pivotal Living Band has significant potential advantages for improving health. I would just prefer if Pivotal Living gave me greater assurance and control of personal data.

Our daughter rolled in the night and falling out of bed was a problem.  We never needed a trip to the emergency room but I worried about it. We used a hard plastic bed rail and that solved the problem but it was ackward removing the rail each morning.This bed rail is mesh around an aluminum frame; instructions describe how to fit the bottom straps under the mattress box spring or platform to hold the rail in place against the side of the bed. The rail becomes part of the bed fixture.The mesh center is soft and will hold a child’s weight but with enough give to encourages her movements back into bed, or so I believe. A hard, firm rail gives the illusion of permanent edge support; I suspect registering in the child’s mind that the side of the bed is safe. The mesh is removable and machine washable.I like that when you depress two buttons at adult’s arms reach, the hinge folds to allow the rail to fold down out of the way so our child can get in and out of bed comfortably. Since the rail fits twin, full and queen size mattresses, I would feel comfortable with an infant co-sleeping and nursing in bed at night as mom rotates with her infant.Grey is a nice neutral, soothing color.

I love these Merino Kids Sleep Bags and have bought several at different sizes.  I researched heavily before ordering and purchased along with Merino Kids infant line, Cocooi Baby, a Winter Schlummersack and a Kangapouch Down Sleepsack. We like to keep our house cool for night time sleeping and all these allow us that continued small treat without worry that our baby will get too cool because she kicked off covers.My favorites of all the bags are the Merino Kids. Yes they are expensive and they last years. They are not as expensive as the Canadian Kangapouch. They are more expensive than Schlummersack’s winter down. I eliminated many competitors that were less expensive because I think Merino Kids are better quality and durable for both winter and summer wear. We made these purchases early with our first child and will be able to take full use of their value. I expect these will last through several children.Merino Kids is an award winning New Zealand company. They have a US website which gives greater detail on their Sleepsacks.I really like the design. The winter-weight sleep bag has a merino wool lining with an organic cotton outer layer. The merino superfine wool lining is soft and thin, but not too thin. Stitching is well done. I love wool because it is very breathable, absorbs and releases moisture, and regulates baby’s body temperature. Merino Kids colors are pretty and make it attractive. Arm snaps are used to make the torso and arms smaller for use with an infant. Shoulder snaps are on one arm to keep the sack from accidently coming off a standing child. Snaps and bottom round zipper are solid quality and makes it easy to get the sack on and off or to change diapers. Front and back slit openings are handy for checking to see if diapers need changing and for easy placement through a car seat carrier or stroller. The zipper is designed for parents, easy to slide and easy to open to change a sleeping child (without having the fabric all bunch up) yet harder for exploring fingers to figure out. The generous bottom size and design helps me feel like our daughter is comfortable while sleeping.We will co-sleep with our daughter. I expect to careful place her on top of our covers and blankets where she is less likely to be hurt by night time rolling or falling out of bed. Cocooned in a sleep sack she doesn’t need the additional warmth from our covers and blankets. I'm sure to check sleeping arrangements carefully with the pediatrician for specific suggestions.This sleep bag is washable (special care instructions) and dry-cleanable. To keep the wool soft and not scratchy, I mix well a  teaspoon of Lanolin in a warm solution of Eucalan soap until it is cloudy with no visible strands of lanolin, before adding to my wool laundry in a delicate/hand wash. Be sure to mix well or the lanolin may leave stain spots. I’ll consider dry cleaning at end of season hoping that can extend the life of the sleeping bag for our next child

When our family travels, we prefer to listen and share audiobooks or watch movies. In public places listening has been unavailable both because we need low volume to not disturb others and the volume needs to be loud enough to hear. Sharing simply has been more difficult than it needed to be.Now my wife and I can listen with good sound and we can share with our kids when the mood suits them. Getting stuck at airports, long flights, drives or long waits at the doctors offices no longer means boring, lost hours. Our test of the splitter adding different headphones found no discernable problems.  We are ready for our next trip and Belkin Splitter will find a permanent home in the carry-on bag.Nicely, an extender cord is included so one listener can be 2 feet further from the source. Good job Belkin!

I researched heavily before ordering several wool Cocooi Baby and Merino Kids Sleep Bags, a Winter Schlummersack and a Kangapouch Down Sleepsack. We like to keep our house cool for night time sleeping and all these allow us that continued small treat without worry that baby will get too cool or come undone from covers.My favorites are the Merino Kids. Cocooi is their infant line. Not as expensive as the Kangapouch. More expensive than Schlummersack’s winter down. I eliminated many competitors that were less expensive because I think Merino Kids are better quality and durable for both winter and summer wear.  I expect the Merino Kids Sleep Bags will last through at least two or three children. I’m glad we made this purchase early and will be able to take full use of its value.Merino Kids is an award winning New Zealand company. They have a US website which gives greater detail on their seasonal Sleepsacks.I really like the design. The Cocooi Merino Sleep Bag for infants is make of soft superfine merino wool. It is soft and thin, but not too thin almost a midweight and to my feel, about the thickness of a good quality cotton kitchen towel, except in wool. Stitching is well done. This style for infant is perfect for day or night time wear. Its good for day wear because you don't need an extra blanket. We can move our child from room to room easily and unencumbered by extra stuff.Cocooi line colors are earthtone.  I believe the colors are attractive and neutral even in our raspberry or Honey Oat, for either girl or boy. The Kimono style wrap top makes it easy to go on and off through the bottom round zipper. It’s easy to get the sack open to change diapers on a sleeping baby. Front and back slit openings are handy for checking to see if diapers need changing and for easy placement through a car seat carrier or stroller. The zipper is designed for parents, reasonable to slide open to change a sleeping child (without having the fabric all bunch up).We will co-sleep with our child. I expect to place her in a basket for the first couple of months and then to careful place our child on top of our covers and blankets where she is less likely to be hurt by night time rolling or falling out of bed.  We’ll check with her pediatrician for suggestions. What I like is that the child will still be warm cocooned in this sleep bag on top of our covers and I don't need to worry that baby will get over heated during nighttime feedings.I love wool because it is very breathable, absorbs and releases moisture, and regulates body temperature. This sleep bag is washable with special care instructions. It also may be dry-cleaned. To keep wool soft I will use an approved wool washing liquid with lanolin. And I’ll probably consider dry cleaning at end of season to save it for our next child.The only con for me is:The cost for 3 months of wear for a single child. But as I’ve written, I do expect that this Cocooi Infant sleep bag will last for several children.

I researched heavily before ordering several wool Merino Kids Sleep Bags, a Winter Schlummersack and a Kangapouch Down Sleepsack. We like to keep our house cool for night time sleeping and all these allow us that continued small treat without worry that baby will get too cool or kick off covers.My favorites are the Merino Kids. Not as expensive as the Kangapouch. More expensive than Schlummersack’s winter down. I eliminated many competitors that were less expensive because I think Merino Kids are better quality and durable for both winter and summer wear.  I expect the Merino Kids Sleep Bags will last through at least two or three children. I’m glad we made this purchase early and will be able to take full use of its value.Merino Kids is an award winning New Zealand company. They have a US website which gives greater detail on their seasonal Sleepsacks.I really like the design. The winter-weight sleep bag has a merino wool lining with an organic cotton outer layer. The merino superfine wool lining is soft and thin, but not too thin. Stitching is well done. I love wool because it is very breathable, absorbs and releases moisture, and regulates body temperature. Merino Kids colors are pretty and make it attractive. Arm snaps on the 0-2 size are used to make the torso and arms smaller for use with an infant. Shoulder snaps are on one arm to keep the sack from accidently coming off a child as she stands. Snaps and bottom round zipper are solid quality and makes it easy to get the sack on and off or to change diapers. Front and back slit openings are handy for checking to see if diapers need changing and for easy placement through a car seat carrier or stroller. The zipper is designed for parents, easy to slide and easy to open to change a sleeping child (without having the fabric all bunch up) yet harder for exploring fingers to figure out.We co-sleep with our child. I expect to careful place our child on top of our covers and blankets where she is less likely to be hurt by night time rolling or falling out of bed.  What I like is that the child will still be warm in his/her own cocoon on top of our covers and I don't need to worry that baby will get over heated  during any nighttime feedings.This sleep bag is washable with special care instructions. It also may be dry-cleaned. To keep wool soft I will use an approved wool washing liquid with lanolin. And I’ll probably consider dry cleaning at end of season to save it for next season and later for the next child. The generous bottom size and design are perfect for our needs.

I purchased the 3.5 Tog Winter Slumbersac along with a Kangapouch Down Sleepsack, several Cocooi Baby and Merino Kids Sleep bags.On price to quality Schlummersack was the best buy. The build quality is all there. Stiching is well done. Cotton cover is pretty and appears down proof. Snaps and zipper are good solid quality. Easy to zipper design going down and around to change baby on the back side of the sack without bunching it up and contorting baby for diaper changes. Baby can continue to lie peacefully and hopefully sleeping.The down sleeping bags mean that baby will stay warm without any extra covers even on cold nights even dressed in a cotton long sleeve t-shirt for easy changing.  Parents can keep house temperatures moderate to cool at night. In my opinion, baby could carefully co-sleep with parents on top of their covers.I am very happy with my Schlummersack and recommend it highly.Yes you can wash it in the washing machine as you would a down blanket.  I'll probably suggest that the parents consider dry cleaning at end of season to save it for next season and later for the next child.

I have been concerned about how to keep our coming Thanksgiving grand baby warm this winter. I ordered the 3.5 Tog Winter 6-18 months Slumbersac along with a Kangapouch Down Sleepsack, several Cocooi Baby and Merino Kids Sleep bags.On price to quality Schlummersack was the best buy. The build quality is all there. Stiching is well done. Cotton cover is pretty and appears down proof. Snaps and zipper are good solid quality. Easy to zipper design going down and around to change baby on the back side of the sack without bunching it up and contorting baby for diaper changes. Baby can continue to lie peacefully and hopefully sleeping.The down sleeping bags mean that baby will stay warm without any extra covers even on cold nights even dressed in a cotton long sleeve t-shirt for easy changing.  Parents can keep house temperatures moderate to cool at night. In my opinion, baby could carefully co-sleep with parents on top of their covers or in a nighttime basket so less likely to be hurt by night time rolling.  I'm sure they will check sleeping arrangements carefully with their pediatrician. And I don't need to worry that baby will  get over heated as she feeds. I am very happy with my Schlummersack and recommend it highly.Yes you can wash it in the washing machine as you would a down blanket.  I'll probably suggest that the parents consider dry cleaning at end of season to save it for next season and later for the next child. The generous bottom size and design gives me hope that the baby will be able to get 2 seasons from this.

Omega 3 is thought to be important for babies’ brain development and mom’s mood. But I find it difficult to eat enough fish that is low in Mercury, high in Omega 3 and tasty.Even though I'm taking prenatal vitamins not all prenatal contain DHA. I have have an easy time swallowing these soft gels. If your pregnancy pills don’t contain DHA you probably also need to supplement and should ask your doctor.I read in WebMD that a baby’s developing brain, is designed to accumulate large amounts of DHA during gestation and the first two years of life. Interesting to me, this two years corresponds to WebMD reporting that researchers found that babies born to mothers with higher levels of Omega-3s and especially DHA in their blood at delivery have higher levels of attention span into the babies’ 2nd year.So taking DHA and Omega-3s is thought to help my gestating baby’s brain and eye development and concentration.I have my doctor’s approval. I am in late stage pregnancy and mixing with the supplements I current take will not cause overdosing. My doctor cautioned that many women unintentionally overdose all sorts of vitamins and he emphasized with me that overdosing could hurt baby and mom. I am going to continue taking through pregnancy and breast feeding because DHA is transmitted through mothers milk.

Finally I don't have to charge or sync devises right next to each other. I can move and have room in front me to work. Apple certified means no worries about proper connectivity. I am quite pleased. I can think of no cons.Beyond 10ft., you might start getting signal degradation and distortion, especially for cables that are not properly certified to perform to spec.

I received in the mail a 1-month HP “SmartFriend Complete Plan” tech support card, good for a single PC or tablet. Service must be registered within 6-months of purchase, so it’s a good idea to keep a record; I wrote the date on the front of the card with a permanent Sharpie and plan to save for immediate use in the event of a malware issue.It looks like a credit card or gift card. I will register by calling a toll free number, give them the card pin and use as needed. The techs offer the choice of walking you through the problems or with my authorization, log onto my computer and solve the problem by remotely looking at and having access to my computer screen and programs while I look on. Once we sign out of the session, the tech cannot get reauthorized to back into my computer without new input from me. I’ve done remote tech service before and I highly recommend it.Since I’m saving the card for potential future malware / virus issues, if our daughter were to develop a problem I could conference a call with her and tech support and activate the 1-month service on her computer across country.Services listed on the website for 1-computer include:➢24/7 phone support with remote login assistance➢Virus, spyware and malware removal➢Help with software problems and error messages➢Software installation and setup➢Learn how to protect and back up your photos and documents➢Setup and troubleshooting of wireless network or printer➢Performance optimization for slow-running or non-booting PC➢Help with managing your smartphone, tablet or other device from your PC➢Protection from online threats and social media privacy exposure➢Assistance setting up parental controls➢General how-to’s, tips and tricksHP defines average sessions as lasting for a several minutes to an hour depending on the scope of the problem. The month service lasts one month. I can call multiple times for help with the same computer. HP warns that if “excessive or abuse is detected, customer will be notified and access to service may be restricted or terminated.” Therefore it is also a good idea at registration to ask the tech to define “excess” and “abuse”. My smartphone allows me to video so I will ask permission to video the registration process and if approved, I will keep a temporary record of answers for my protection.HP Subcriptions Plans include SmartFriend Complete Plan for a single computer, SmartFriend Family Plan for up to 4 devises or a SmartFriend Tutor Plan for a single devise.I appreciate the ability to start service on my terms for my defined problem. If lucky, I need only 2 pops a year for piece of mind.

This humidifier is super easy and intuitive to set up, works well, and it's nice and small. But ours has a constant dripping sound, which is worse with the higher level. It's not the worst sound, but is pretty annoying when trying to fall asleep. Pretty sure it's not normal since an advertised feature is its "whisper quiet operation".We will keep trying to adjust and if we can remedy, we'll report back.

Nice to see. Nice depth. I do not know how convincing those two birds will be. Me, I could do without. Chances are that the other birds do not need the hype, especially here in the desert.It loses a star for having a small base for no reason. In fact, it lists placement, depending on how level your pad is. No reason not to make it nearly as big as the bowl.

This is a book for beginner, or for an experienced cook.I have followed Ruhlman for decades now. He is an expert journalist with superb style. He was a plodding, digging dirty hands journalist that came to the CIA, the real one. He followed what Joe Campbell would call "his bliss". Now he is an instructor himself. I just buy anything he writes.But this is a good one for you to work through. No particular theme, no cuisine. But if you just work through it, you will be successful and have solid results with each adventure you will share with those who are important.

There’s a lot I like with HP’s premium new ENVY 13.3-Inch notebook. HP made its laptop lighter, more portable, thin (less than 1"), built it with solid state storage, three 3.0 USB ports, and Touch Gestures! HP included an SD card slot, glass display -- solid graphics, HD webcam, an HDMI-out; got rid of extra keyboard key largess, enlarged the touch pad, and accessorized.Let me say up front that the product" instructions" included in the box refers buyers to HPs web pages. So, I thought, might as well have a look before hitting the remorse button. When I went to the pages a message appeared explaining that the pages have not yet been loaded. I could not verify which features are upgradable or which accessories are available. The web link states “Coming Soon. Information about this product is not yet available but will be added shortly.”IN THE BOX:HP ENVY 13-d010nrAC adapter and plugSetup InstructionsHP Worldwide Limited Warranty and Technical Support printed in grey in what appears to be 4pt font (unreadable)THE COMPLETE LIST OF FEATURES in the “Quick Tour” of the Setup Instructions are:Wireless antennasInternal microphones (2)Webcam light and WebcamMute key and lightPower buttonCaps lock key and lightSpeakers (2) BANG & OLAFSEN hey-hey!Windows key: displays the Start menuTouchPadFingerprint readerAirplane mode keyMemory card readerUSB ports (3)Audio-in (microphone)/audio-out (headphone) combo jackPower lightHDMI portAC adapter and battery lightPower connectorI’ll describe details that are important to me for professional and personal use. THINGS I DON’T LIKE are not major so I list them first.CONS:' 30 G of the hard drive is reserved for the system recovery software. Before a single document was created or software subscription applied, 33.4 GB out of 118 GB is registered as “used”. Wow. I’m going to need external storage.' Back-ups to external spinning drives are important because SSD are more susceptible to melt downs. Having solid state drives makes things like surge protection more important and it makes the computer more vulnerable to some high tech security malware.' The external optical drive is so handy it’s a shame it wasn’t included and has to be bought separately. Especially nice to have the USB hub to connect a mouse, monitor or other devises.' I read that intensive memory game graphics will need to be played on low-medium setting with 720p resolution for smoother frame transition.' Ethernet connectivity is not available.' Requires a deliberate push to connect and pull to disconnect the charger; the charging port doesn’t magnetically attract and connect the charger; magnetic connections like on Apple devices are nice but no biggie for me.' Annual subscriptions to Windows 10 and McAffee Live Safe software are required.' Box disclaimer states: “Not all features are available in all editions of Windows 10. Systems may require upgraded and/or separately purchased hardware, drivers and/or software to take full advantage of Windows 10 functionality.”I list other disclaimers printed on the box that I consider impactful for purchase decisions:1 “GHz refers to internal clock speed of the processor. Other factors besides clock speed may impact system and application performance.”2 “This system requires a separately purchased 64-bit operating system and 64-bit software products to take advantage of the 64-bit processing capabilities. Given the wide range of software applications available, performance of a system including a 64-bit operating system will vary.”3 High-Definition content (eg WMD HD files) is required to view high definition images. Most current DVDs do not provide high-definition images. In some applications the colors displayed will appear to be similar to the actual colors, but not exact renditions, due to RGBW4 color subpixel design.”THINGS I LIKEPROS' An internal battery life of between 6 and the advertised 7.5 hours.' 6th Generation Intel Core, i5-6200U Processor (2.3 GHz)' USB 3.0.--10x faster then USB 2.0, this has been the standard for several years now, but, because of the increased cost, the 3.0s are not always included. USB 3.0 is backward compatible; but not all 3.0s are created equal. The fastest drive seems to achieve its speed by using “four channels of flash” memory instead of one. SEE: Howtogeek's article on usb-2.0-vs.-usb-3.0-should-you-upgrade-your-flash-drives. Again without HPs web pages for this ENVY, I cannot locate any information on the USBs.' High Resolution 3200x1800 13 inch screen. Color resolution, brightness and viewing angles appear nicely. The display gives a bright, clear, crisp resolution. It appears to enhance color with richness and graphic detail for front and side viewing angles. Pictures from digital camera show nice detail on this screen and when displayed on our large screen TV. You cannot fully appreciate the screen unless you get the 17"+. But nice it is even notebook size.' 128GB solid-state hard drive (SSD!). I love solid state storage because it is faster, and does not crash like spinners. In solid state, important files stay put. I’ll store my programs on the SSD. It’s good to have both types of drives so I’ll use an external spin drive for documents and back-ups. If it gets too hot, SSD can melt or fry circuits (SEE: Pros).' Wireless WLAN and Bluetooth connectivity only.' Audio output uses Bang & Olufsen audio system! I won’t need additional computer speakers to listen to high fidelity music while I work.' Appearance: All metal aluminum and magnesium-alloy chasse; the magnesium shell reduces the weight. Smooth, clean brushed metal on both sides of the enlarged touchpad; nice and soothing for resting fingers while I’m thinking. Glass display panel. Keyboard is angled up for more comfortable typing.' Infrequently used buttons, are half normal size; this shrinks the overall size of the keyboard area and it looks less cluttered. I am neutral about ENVY having added both the back and delete keys on keyboard; I don’t mind using one key for both.' Smaller AC adapter; easier to transport.' Large Touch track pad with right and left click and center turns on/off and top left corner to turn touchpad on/off. Touch pad supports gestures tap/double tap, two-finger pinch zoom. When the ENVY is in TouchPad mode, then two-finger click and two-finger scroll and in touch screen mode, one-finger slide is supported.As an aside, other reports state that the track pad on ENVY can be frustratingly unreliable especially if you are use to Apple and do a lot of scrolling. Reports say it is not as reliable and responsive as Mac’s Trackpad. Scrolling gets stuck and sometimes does not register as a scroll. If it should become an obstacle, we will need to turn the Touch pad off and connect a Bluetooth or wireless mouse to the small USB hub on an External optical drive. We would need to purchase the external drive separately as an accessory. This has not happened to us so it is only a rumor. This ENVY model is so new that the problem could even be fixed. So I’ll leave this comment here with the pros but I mention it because I believe in being aware and watchful. If it does happen to us, we will report back.' The compatible External optical drive (Blu-ray or DVD) is rumored to have a small USB hub on back so you can connect keyboard and desktop. We have not seen nor ordered an optical drive; again because with HP’s webpages under construction, we're not sure which to order. If rumors are true, I like it because while the ENVY is portable, I won’t always need the optical drive with me. I can leave the drive on my desk and when I return plug in to devises is fast and easy.' ENVY has a standard HDMI out port; nice and convenient for displaying onto a large monitors or TV in a hotel room to watch Netflix or other movie subscriptions.' Adding our printers and scanners was as easy as clicking a button; it was nearly automatic.' I like that I can set up to use the ENVY in “tablet mode”. I can even select to make Windows more “touch friendly”. I have the option to download maps to search for places or get directions even when not connected to the internet.' I like that I can turn off shared connections and pushouts to Outlook, Skype contacts and FaceBook friends.' I like that the “Network + Internet” page tells me my data usage for the last 30 days.' Built in front facing HD Webcam with dual microphones for Skyping or video recording. I find iPad’s dual facing cameras and mics surprisingly useful.' HP ENVY notebook comes with temporary Windows 10 and McAfee LiveSafe software.I want to consider buying HP’s 3yr Service Care Pack for $190 or 3 yr Amazon protection for $160. These service agreements give me piece of mind and allow me to better control purchases so that I’m upgrading at the same time.I see HP’s advertised comparisons to Apple’s MacBook Air; I suspect because of the ease of portability, a better comparison for me might be November’s release of the iPad Pro. Once released, I’ll make that comparison. My local Costco sells the 15” ENVY and I was able to physically view it there for comparison before I received it in the mail. Amazon Prime gives me free shipping and depending on whether the vendor has brick and mortar in my state, my Amazon taxes may be less than my local Costco.In all, I'm VeRy happy with this ENVY. It gives me all the functionality I need in a Windows environment, in a small package and at an attractive price.

This is a 1st quality dish from (American made) Lenox with the only visible imperfection being the gold border is slightly askew but it doesn't detract from the beauty. The 6x6 inch square plate is perfect for displaying holiday cookies, candies or buffet sandwiches for the kids. It dresses up my living room table for winter and is perfect display on my dining room table making regular meals festive.I love porcelain because of its brilliance and durability; porcelain doesn’t break easily. It the comes out of my dishwasher gleaming and I have not noticed any loss of gold trim, fading or dishwater removal to the holly or red cardinal decoration so I expect our family will enjoy these for years to come.I have gotten both the Lenox Holiday Square and the Winter Greetings Square dishes. When I unpacked the plate I thought it could make a nice Christmas gift.  I toyed with keeping both as my extra presents on hand under the tree in case I’m caught short. But I decided that I like these. The Cardinal plate is nice enough for Christmas but can be used all winter long. I want our family to enjoy them.

My wife and I use disposable gloves when handling harsh household, pool or hazardous chemicals. These work fine and are comfortable. They are thin but quite suitable for protecting hands from much of everything from cutting up and handling chicken or pork, cleaning cat litter, using pesticides or pouring pool chemicals. There is no powder inside yet they are easy to put on and take off unlike the latex disposables I generally buy from Costco. They are a little less expensive to and with Prime, I don’t have to worry that my local store has them in stock or spend more time than I need to in a big box store.

I do not want all my towels to be super absorbent. I have thirsty terry for that. Flour sack towels are hard to come by these days. I had taken to buying Blue Bird Flour because they still come in these.What I do like is polishing my crystal and other glassware. These are quite good. No lint.And, I pour my yogurt into a double layer to get the water out. Same deal with quick cheese, the kind you want to make for same day use to capture the flower of high quality super fresh milk.

The scent is of sweet watermelon. It pours and feels thin and covers well, but not exceptionally. It takes time to absorb on my skin and after 10 minutes, still feels tacky. The ingredient list is written on the box in hard to read, light grey lettering.If I didn’t know the manufacturer, didn’t see the advertising, was given a blind sample and told a 7 oz tube would cost me $43 and then asked, would I buy it? My answer would be a simple, no. There are other products I like better, absorb better, at the same price or less.I love body creams and body lotions. For me, this is not above average; nor are the ingredients organic, exceptional or high quality; mostly they appear to be synthesized. It’s a personal preference; for me it's simply, "okay."

Let's start with the positives. This baby monitor provides sufficient quality video and audio directly to your smartphone or tablet. Yeah, I've seen higher frame rates--but it is a baby monitor after all. Babies don't move that quickly. The camera automatically determines whether the video streams in color or black-and-white (for night vision), but the image is clear in both. I operated the camera from my Droid Moto X. The interface wasn't pretty, but it was functional and intuitive. The interface also allows you to take pictures and video of your sleeping baby. Also, I'll note that set up with my phone and WiFi was pretty easy.Physically, the baby monitor is attractive with a small footprint. The camera is mounted to a swivel base. It is very lightweight (this is good or bad, depending on how concerned you are with stability.) I wish the power cord were longer, but this isn't a major issue.A neat feature of the baby monitor is that it has a speaker. You can talk into your smartphone and the baby monitor will relay your voice to baby. It also has a nice selection of lullabies and other soothing classical pieces that it can play for baby. (Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata sounds too sinister to play to an infant, but maybe that's just me.)My complaints? First, I downloaded the firmware update required to get push notifications delivered to your smartphone. (That is, you can set certain motion and volume thresholds, such that if the camera detects high levels of motion or sound your phone chirps or vibrates or displays an icon, much as it would when you receive a text.) However, I have never received a push notification, despite checking that I have the settings correct multiple times. Could I be doing something wrong? Possibly. But I still fault the manufacturers because setting up push notifications shouldn't be this hard.So what do you do without push notifications? Well, you leave the app open with the speaker on. First, this is annoying because it means you will be exposed to white noise. (If you mute it, you won't hear your baby.) Secondly, it is a real drain on the batteries. My phone went from fully charged to drained within 3 hours.Finally, I really wish you could use your laptop to interface with the baby monitor. Why limit it to smartphones? I'm more likely to be near a plug for my laptop than my phone, and I am generally less concerned with my laptop's charge than with my phone's charge. I'd say over 50% of the time, I'd rather use my laptop than my phone.So, I have a few reservations about this product. But let's look on the bright side: firmware updates, software updates, and a new app for laptops would address all of my concerns. If the manufacturer's continue to support this product, I would up my review to 5 stars.

Babies are slippery when lathered. Bath time makes me nervous that my infant can slip from my hands. Slipping in a hard bathtub or our step down jetted bathtub could be dangerous and it’s a concern.Muchkin’s Cradle Tub makes bathing less stressful because bathing is safer and rinsing easy.  We are expecting our daughter next month.  I like that we will be able to wash her from our sink countertop. The cradle fits securely and did not slip or slide in our test even when the countertop surface was damp.  Since our daughter will be born in the winter, room temperature is a concern. Our kitchen probably has the most comfortable temperature in our house and is most easily adjusted.The design and use in a standing position, helps in control of our infant should she wiggle around. It is a great saver for my husband’s and especially, my back after a long pregnancy and back pain.I am confident that the design of high side walls and cradle will support our baby and help insure that our daughter is comfortable and secure as she’s lathered, rinsed and dried. I intend to place a Motherhood bamboo washcloth behind her as I wash her because it is soft and will wash her back at the same time. The washcloth is easy to remove before rinsing and drying.The single recline position helps protect that baby does not accidently become submerged in a shallow filled tub or get water in her face or ears. On the counter-top, she can see my face and I can wash and rinse her head, ears and face as I comfort her. Bath time can be relaxing for baby and me.I especially like that rinse water drains directly in the sink for easy clean-up. So when she’s ready to be dried, I can dry her front torso, legs, arms and head before moving her. Because these are dried and I’m only reaching to dry her back, I feel more comfortable that there is less chance she will slip and fall as I pick her up.I also like that the Muchkin Cradle means I do not have to buy 2 products, an infant bathtub and a separate sling hammock for an infant; with the Muskin, I have no problem about drying the cradle tub nor concern for mildew or rust.Eventually, when our baby is able to sit up independently, I can move to the tub and use a Bath tub ring chair for older infants and toddlers. While she is an infant, this is an ingenious solution for bath time and I appreciate the simplicity.Problem Solved.

Perfect ultra soft washcloths for anyone with sensitive skin. Holds soap and rinses clean.I was hoping that these would be as soft as my favorite bamboo socks that I found years ago. The socks were cushy and soft to walk in, felt like cashmere at a fraction of the cost. I am not disappointed. These washcloths are everything I was hoping for, perfect for new granddaughter's baby skin. A pack of 5 is a nice collection, 3 would have been too small.

I’m happy to rid myself of my clunky docking station and replace it with this much more easily connected, sleeker vertical docking stand. For me, it is a lot easier maneuver.  I don’t have to contort to get behind my older horizontal station as I try to figure out which slot to use. I can pick this up and look. This unit was designed to use the 2 front 3.0 USB standard ports for new quick external storage devices and flash drives, and the 3 rear USB 2.0 ports for existing peripherals like keyboard, mouse, printer, and 2 HD displays. It has 2-way audio support with an audio headphone port on the front side.This appears to have been made for Windows users with Mac as an afterthought. It is compatible ONLY to Mac OS 10.9; this is annoying to those Mac users like us with OS X Yosemite v 10.10.5+ that we have on all of our Macs say nothing about upgrades to OS X El Capitan. The website does not have updated Mac drivers as of this review. It cannot be used as a charging station. It has a 2-year limited warranty.  What’s in the box? TU3-DS2 unit, CD-ROM with drivers and guide, Quick Installation Guide, power cord adapter and 35 inch USB3.0 cable and a VGA to DVI adapter.I originally intended to hook this up in our living room to our Toshiba widescreen, printer, Windows, Mac and Oppo components. However, for now I’m better off connecting in my office with my simple, basic Office Windows used for work and Mac so I can have better access to a larger Windows display. It’s nice to have the added features of TreadNet’s Universal USB 3.0 Docking Station but I’ll need to wait until the upgrades to get the power out of this that I had hoped for. My recommendation? If you are heavily a Mac user, wait for the upgraded software.I’ve purposely kept this as an overview. I would like to recognize and applaud those reviewers before me who have given solid technical reviews.I will update this review and note any glitches after I have significant experience using the devise.

It is that time of year in the great American desert -- monsoon. That means the cycle of bugs in my flour. Sure, I have been building my bastions of plastic flour containers and such. But come they still. Flags unfurled and an appetite that would make Wall Street proud.Set-up is easy and progress is clearly seen. The little bugs lie on the faces of these pyramids.

Why cannot these products we need cut the hype? No renewal at all. A good therapy with my manual treatments. But nothing near these wild claims. I continue to use this good product, but with open eyes.

Finest finishing sander I ever had.  I just finished a big block of ebony every step from after planing to final finish. The control is superb for a light touch. I can even sculpt a bit as I shape. The oscillation is the most rapid I have felt.  I wish I had not waited so long.There are comparable finishing sanders that are pneumatic.

Oh, man, I like dig these cards. They let me see all the hands I do not have. These are prescriptive cards, medically speaking. They deal like I wish my dealer would.They are great performers, to deal, fan and shuffle.

Danged if I know how they get in. But they do. Well, I do know they wait around the outside of the kitchen door like it was the Times Square subway stop. Then I tote this light little killer into my kitchen. But at night it goes in the bathroom where them skeeters find their way towards my blood.The bugs find this Zapper's light before they find my breath. Even if one does get through ( I count none so far), it will then go to the light and find something more like rupture.It runs cool and light on the light bill.

Writers and critics love to hate old J.D. Even dead, he is a threat because they are hunting for his unpublished stuff. But readers have loved that same stuff for 50 years now. Junk writers may sell a million (small by Salinger standards) but they fade. These stories may have some unfamiliar turns of phrase. Good and thoughtful stories they remain.He came back from WWII, and had seen enough. He stopped writing and became a New England recluse. He died just a couple of years ago.

Everything about this file is right. It has an aggressive cut, yet easily controlled by hand speed. No need to use any pressure. The attenuating surface means that I can take long strokes along the missile surface while having just the right width for a particular job.The plastic handle, with a nice disc for your finger, will fail before you do much damage, so do not blame the fail-safe for too much needed and damaging pressure. Let it do the work.The steel is high grade, so it will not degrade for decades.

All the ABC products seem solid, though not luxurious. Their jersey port-crib sheet are soft and nicer to the touch. Nice basic, lightweight jersey, stretchy soft at a good price. Close examination of the stichings is good and seems to indicate this is well made. I rate it 4 stars for Amazon's "I like it!".
This is what my hospital used on me and was used by their staff. It has low viscosity, so it flows well. Now I keep it at home, not to use all the time and everywhere, but for a minor cut or scrape.

This is a good quality waterproof cotton over poly fill mattress pad that works as advertised: It protects our baby mattress from diaper wettings. Our bassinet mattress was more expensive than I thought it would be and I’d like not to replace it. Here’s good insurance that it stays clean and prestine. A second pad allows me to air-dry after wash. The vinyl waterproof backing is layered over with a cushy quilted poly fill and 100% cotton overlay; my cotton sheets insure baby is in comfort.  I’ve tried several American Baby linens now and I’ll say that I believe they represent good value for a good product.

This mobile is designed to visually stimulate an infant during development. The instructions clearly lay out how this mobile is supposed to be used, and how to tell if a baby is interested. As the baby needs something new to look at, or gets older and more developed, you can switch out the pictures.Because the mobile is meant for infants, who are only beginning to  develop sight, it may be much less appealing to you or me, as adults with more or less fully developed sight. The design is a little utilitarian: plastic parts, no motorized movement, and designs that are more about high-contrast than being cute. So not typically what we think of for a baby's room. But, since infants have better peripheral vision than center vision and poor resolution, the high contrast images are theoretically better at capturing a baby's attention.This is a rare instance when the user is first, unlike so many things that mean to sell to the parent to the pet owner. As a PhD neuroscience  mom--That's Five smart stars!

If you are familiar with the Wrangler brand, this is the quality that you have come to expect. If you are not familiar with the brand the quality exceeds expectations of durability, cost and quality. This is no exception.My only complaint is the size in the X series appears to run small. I normally wear a 2X. This did not fit my wide shoulders.But let me describe the shirt. This feels like Indian madras fabric which is a cotton summer weight with looser weave.  Good for work clothes outside or casual wear on a hot summer day. Made in Bangladesh it is 100% Cotton. The collar, neck and button column along the front do not have a reinforced inner core like more expensive dress shirts; the shirt doesn’t take collar stays. The neck and collar will not have that crisp finished look even if starched. It’s a casual shirt. It does have two front pockets, stitched on the outside for extra durability. The length is good. Meant to fit into a pair of jeans. The buttons appear to be a durable plastic like most shirt buttons these days. The buttons are sewn on for extra durability, not just a couple of stitches but beefy attachment. All the stiching is what you might expect from a more expensive shirt. The plaid box weave is attractive and understated with grey, rust and white.If you need to look good while you are working, this is the shirt to throw on. Only get the right size. I’m disappointed that the X-series runs small and appears tapered, because it’s a good quality shirt.

I was disappointed when I first opened the frustration laden package to eventually crack open a rather cheap looking device of questionable moral standing. I was feeling more than normally stupid until the battery insulation shield fell from the battery/Brinks twist cap. NOW the thing turns on.But I was really crestfallen when I fitted the coarse attachment and threw the switch to high. With my footsies, I was hoping for a few horsepower rig that tore threw my foot debris like a belt sander running 60 grit bark stripper.Instead I got a gentle persistent hum that efficiently made its way around my nail, and then took down the Continental Divide that was left after a charming  bout of nail fungus.You see, I am the kind of impatient nit-wit (a nit is the egg of a louse) who wants enough power to bloody my toes after blasting through whatever is in my way.Instead I got a well designed gadget that shapes, smooth's and polishes my tootsies.  Restraint is the greater part of courage. Besides it gets easier as you progress.

There is a lot to like about this stroller and car seat combination. First, the stroller is attractive. Assembly was a breeze, especially compared to some other baby-related accessories I've had to assemble lately. The toddler stroller frame has two positions, it reclines good enough for a snooze but not for lying flat. Forth, it steers reasonably well and seems to handle Philadelphia’s uneven pavement around our house. Fifth, it has a nice unfoldable hood for shading.I'll single out a few features for special notice. I love the stroller's folding mechanism. It's a quick twist with the wrist and the stroller collapses. As the stroller folds, a latch automatically catches so that the stroller won't accidentally reopen while you're trying to carry it. The stroller is light, fortunately, though slightly ungainly. (What stroller isn't?)The stroller also good wheel locks. The rear wheels lock so that they are incapable of rolling, while the pivot on which the front wheels are mounted locks. This disables the steering. This is important to us because we've noticed how many new parents around our neighborhood dine at restaurants outdoors with their baby in a stroller parked next to them. Having a good wheel lock system means that we'll be able to join them.The wheels are just big enough to negotiate easily though they are not wheel bearing for smooth turning. The frame took a lot of stress and torque from me with no ill effect.As for the car seat, there is less to say. It lifts in and out of its base well. I like the big handle you use to carry it (which also has a nice lock system). The shell itself is strong enough and has a nice cushion insert to cradle my infant’s head. The most confusing thing for us was figuring out how to dock the car seat in the stroller. It wasn't intuitive, and we're still a little clumsy doing it, but we're sure it will be second nature soon. This is of course a wonderful feature, as you can transfer a sleeping baby from car to stroller seamlessly. Also, there is a nice hood on the car seat, so that when the car seat is in the stroller both hoods can be fully extended to almost entirely shelter baby from the elements. Very nice.The manufacturer's instructions say the parent carrying tray can carry 3 pounds and the underneath tray 10. That's enough to carry a purse on top and a baby bag underneath. We are warned not to attach bags to the push rail so although the Graco Literider satisfies basic transportation, it is not really as well suited for carrying groceries or purchases like I need in an urban city. Not a baby SUV, but priced cheaply enough and easy to have around and about.The largest negative to our mind is Graco's record with flame retardants. Consumer Reports and other public watchdogs have picked up on studies of carcinogenic flame retardant use in car seats. Unfortunately, Graco rates worse than other companies according to this study. We wish that in the future Graco would switch to fewer and safer chemicals in their products for children.

If you are familiar with the Wrangler brand, this is the quality that you have come to expect. If you are not familiar with the brand the quality exceeds expectations of durability, cost and quality. This is no exception.My only complaint is the size in the X series appears to run small. I normally wear a 2X. This did not fit.But let me describe the shirt. This feels like chambray fabric which is a double-ply cotton with tight weave but since this fabric does not have a white filler woven thread, this Wrangler fabric is probably closer to a light weight denim. It is rugged but light. Good for work clothes outside or casual wear. Made in Bangladesh it is 100% Cotton. The collar, neck and button column along the front do not have a reinforced inner core like more expensive dress shirts; the shirt doesn’t take collar stays. The neck and collar will not have that crisp finished look even if starched. It’s a casual shirt. It does have two front pockets, stitched on the outside for extra durability. The length is good. Meant to fit into a pair of jeans. The buttons appear to be a durable plastic like most shirt buttons these days. The buttons are sewn on for extra durability, not just a couple of stitches but beefy attachment. All the stiching is tight and what you would expect from a more expensive shirt.If you need to look good while you are working, this is the shirt to throw on. Only get the right size. I’m disappointed that the X-series runs small and appears tapered, because it’s a great quality shirt.

We recently removed the glass enclosure to our tub so I've spent the last week looking at shower curtains. This DII Oceanique compares to the cloth shower curtains I found at Bed, Bath and Beyond where the range, even on clearance was still $20-60. I did not find any that I thought were great. All are pretty basic and the pattern provides the color. This pattern works for us because of the darker lines become lighter as the eye moves up the pattern so the curtain does not appear fatiguing in our opposite full glass mirror.  The mauve color is soothing. In my opinion the fabric weight is light, not exceeding light, but still light.We have a white Restoration Hardware bath rug and the two compliment. I installed a curved shower rod pretty high up the wall. The length of this DII Oceanique falls about where you see in the advertised picture which suits. $20 at the time of this review and Prime Shipping would make this  an easy choice for me since I couldn't find any that I liked a lot.  I  feel fortunate to have received this in exchange of a fair review.

I have taken my old three way torch away from my desk. It is in the back of my home office, where it does what it does best, bounce light off the ceiling. This not-so-little replacement now sits atop my desk, lighting up everything with a nice warm white.My desk is 4x3 feet so it takes a lot to cover well. I need to read several open books and three keyboards. The other, lower setting are just right for less intense work sessions.The nice cantilever design gives broad coverage because of the way the LED light falls away along the arm. You can easily finger down the end of the arm to keep your eyes out of any glare.

I can't decide whether I like the light on this better or the portable charger better...but the five stars is because I do not need to choose. The quality and intensity of the light is better than any of my old ones. The charger works fast on my iPhone. The size is just right, small enough for my bag or my pocket but big enough to handle easily.The shock case has a nice feel to it. As another reviewer pointed out, you cannot charge and use at the same time, if that matters to you.

Nice looking, not expensive looking, evening wear. I see no flaws in the pearls even under a magnifying glass.The larger cubic zirconia gems, at the pinnacle and the lower connection point give nice sparkle to the earrings. The smaller zirconia surrounding the top surface of the lines and the petals which attach to the pearl, provides nice elegance. These smaller zirconia are more visible to others  when your face is at side profile.The metal, more prominent from the small silhouette of sides of the earrings which someone looking directly at your face is likely to see at a glance, does not look like white gold, platinum or silver.  Although when I reread the description, I read the metal is sterling silver, it does not appear so to me. To my eyes, it is an unidentifiable metal and looks more similar to chrome. My wife and I assume there is some stealing with the metal alloy, but silver is not what our eyes see. I assume that the instructions not to spray perfume and void contact with lotions, hairspray and other chemicals is meant to protect the metal as much as the stones.The earrings are a comfortable weight for my wife who does not like heavy earrings and she says they do not have an over pull on her lobes. She does mention that if someone is allergic to metals there may be a concern.I am trying to be more critical in this review because these are difficult to see in a picture and I am trying to accurately describe what my eyes see close up.  I go back to my first comment, these are lovely earrings for evening wear but they are not meant to impress the discriminating person who knows their jewels. My wife and I are not one of those persons, nor are we overly discriminating in jewelry.This set of earrings is a nice finishing touch for evenings out for dinner and concert.

I particularly like the bunny decals on this MAM white bottle. The 5 oz size is perfect for nursing mothers like my daughter who need to express and leave newborn a feeding for dad or even granddad.I also like the bottle design for 3 big reasons.1. The ventilated bottom is supposed to reduce colic (just remove the silicone bottom). Our neice is pretty gassy. While I can't definitely tell if she's doing better on these bottles (we aren't using them exclusively), her mom and I believe there are fewer bubbles in the milk while she feeds and she seems to have less gas and spit up at burping. This is a nice observation for me because we are expecting our baby this fall.2. The bottle is self sterilizing. Which means not having to carry around extra stuff when dropping her off with family, or worrying if it will fit into narrow hotel microwaves.3. The orthodontic nipple promotes proper sucking and tooth placement in oral development. The flat nipple design with the hole at the top allows milk to hit the roof of baby’s mouth rather than the back of the throat. Less air is needed for swallowing; milk mixes with saliva and helps with baby’s digestion.I am happy that Silicone has no BPA. I am somewhat concerned about D4 and D5 siloxanes, compounds generally found in silicone, which theoretically can migrate and accumulate in baby’s delicate human tissue. I do not find any reference to these compounds in MAM’s literature. But in other literature, I learn that these two compounds don’t break down or decompose. I repeat and emphasize, somewhat concerned or at least aware, because the compounds tend to remain stable at temperatures up to 300 degrees. But because the compounds can migrate at higher temperatures and when combined with fat, I will not wash the silicone nipples in the dishwasher or boil for extended periods even though I know that our newer model Miele dishwasher heats well below the threshold at only to 156.8F on SaniWash and 164.4F on Pots and Pan Scrub. I also will throw away any that become discolored or show signs of white and I will replace silicon nipples every 2 months regardless of wear. If this is a concern for you, please rely on your own research.I am so appreciative for high quality design in the MAM bottle, and I think the ventilation and self-sterilization are great additions.

Before I start describing the cat tree itself, first let me point out that while all humans are dumb, my male human is particularly stupid when it comes to assembly.  He is an idiot that has not yet found something he can't install backwards or in the wrong direction!  You have to forgive him a bit with this one though.  The instructions were a bit more idiot prone than others: just a sheet with an exploded diagram and some numbers. Here's a hint!  Put the #1s in first, then the #2s, then the #3s, then the #4s.  You are going to end up building it upside down.  The poor instructions almost knocked this down to a 4-star review, since it took him a while to figure that part out, but he seems to have been able to assemble it reasonably quickly without much cursing or injury to himself.  That said, he did install the hammock incorrectly four times.  FOUR TIMES!!!  It only goes two ways.Typically, I don't like cat trees...or any toys the human gets for me.  This one's different: it's definitely high quality, and very heavy.  While he was assembling it, I assumed it was a trap from the vet, but as soon as he went in the other room to get catnip and treats, I had already started exploring.First, I love the carpet.  It's really soft, which feels great on my tummy, and light colored so I can see when I get cat hair all over it.Second, there are all sorts of interesting ares for me to explore.  The little house is great for me since I can get in there, but my big fat sister doesn't have a chance.  The sisal covered scratching posts are okay, but they're all vertical, which is good for me, but my sister prefers horizontal things like Cosmic Pet Double Wide Scratcher, or even better, the ottoman and couch.Lastly, the hammocks and other moving parts must seem appealing to humans, but as we've already covered, humans are dumb.  No way would I get in one of those things, no matter what treats you put on it.  I'm avoiding those things like the plague!  That said, this is still a great cat tree, and who knows, maybe I'll try one of them one of these days...Please note the size was surprising to my female human, even though she's generally smarter than my other one.  It is quite clearly labeled as 23.4"W x 31.3"D x 46.5"H, so you should definitely make sure you have room BEFORE ordering, because this could be an expensive mistake.

We bought our Xbox One because of Just Dance 2014, and Just Dance 2015 is pretty much the only thing we use the Xbox One for nowadays.  From the technical point of view, this even better: it does a much better job of recognizing little kids, and the ability to select avatars definitely appealed to both my kids.  The one downside is that by putting actual Disney stars, instead of blanked out people shapes, made my daughter only want to play about a third of the songs: just those with a female lead.That said, the music is really bad.  Maybe kids who watch Disney more than my kids do will enjoy these songs more than I did, but I sure didn't.  My kids didn't seem to mind, but they definitely didn't recognize any of the songs even though they do occasionally watch shows such as Austin & Ally.The dance routines were easy enough to follow, which was great, but be careful of arm flailing with these party games.  It's easy to whack someone by accident.

This is a great printer for average household use.  It is easy to set up, though there is a lot of pressure to sign up for the HP E-ink automatic delivery.  Personally, I like that feature, since I am constantly running out of ink at the wrong time.It's also very small, which is great since my office/computer/guest room does not have a lot of spare space.My one complaint is that this model does not have an automatic sheet feeder for easily scanning multiple pages.The HP companion app for the e-all-in-one printers is great and frankly obviates the need for a scanner 99% of the timeThe box claims to have lab quality photo printing.  My wife is a pro photographer, and feels that claim is a bit of marketing, but they're quite decent for a home printer!It is worth noting that I used to have a HP Envy 5530 printer, which I was quite happy with, but it randomly conked out one day and just wouldn't connect to my network.

This is a much easier install than TED, Sense, or similar products because you can install this yourself without an electrician, and don't even have to open your electric panel.  On the other hand, it's harder to try to track down exactly which appliance is causing the power consumption: you basically have to go around turning everything off, then turning on one appliance at a time.  Furthermore, the website sort of indicates there is a way to track the usage of individual appliances like, say, the dishwasher, over time, but they tell me that's with a Bidgely partner app that they no longer integrate to.I had a tougher install than most because I had a bum unit, but even then, it's definitely not an iPhone level ease of use.  They have a really good and responsive support organization.The app and website also have a lot of room for growth, shall we say.  That said, it's much easier for them to upgrade the app and website than it is to swap out the device, so they actually have the basics already in place!  I have high hopes for seeing more.I also bought the LCD display, which I find to be very useful in figuring out where my energy hogs are.

I've use Epson products for years, and in general I associate them with very robust, but lower quality (and lower priced) equipment.  I have an Epson Workforce printer with some cheap plastic buttons that I could probably drop out the window and would still be able to print (the scan ability would probably be impacted since the screen is made of glass, but honestly I use my smartphone for virtually all my scan and fax functions now).  This printer completely breaks that mold.  It feels very high end, with tonnes of bells and whistles, including an output drawer that automatically opens and closes, a high resolution touch screen, and even the touch screen automatically angles out...BUT, I see a ton of stuff that can break.  I'm seriously concerned about it's longevity.  Given the price (full disclosure: mine was provided gratis through the Vine program) I would be very hesitant before I laid out the cash for this if it was going to be at the curb 6-9 months later.Some other concerns:1) This sucker is HUGE.  Seriously, check out the dimensions before buying because the pictures don't really convey the size properly.2) The six cartridges of ink strikes me as costly.  They're small too, so if you are printing out large photos on a regular basis, I expect you will be hurting.  Go price out the cost of ink for this sucker before you lay out the cash: would a color laser printer make more sense?3) Epson has this amazing, huge touch screen but still has a very clunky user interface.  For instance, it still makes me type in the WIfi password using a keypad so that the number 2 means I have to press 7 times (ABCabc7).The biggest point of this review that I hope to convey is that this is NOT meant for the casual user.  There are many other printers out there for a fraction of this cost: check out Epson WorkForce WF-2630 Wireless Business AIO Color Inkjet, Print, Copy, Scan, Fax, Mobile Printing, AirPrint, Compact Size  So why do you want this printer?  Easy: the photo quality.  I happen to be in that market because my wife is a professional photographer.  That means she won't even use Snapfish because the color isn't exact enough for her.  I hope that the money that Epson sank into the touch screen didn't come out of their "photo quality" bucket!  Also, even though the advertising says "professional quality," I have to see how well it does printing out 25 or even 50 prints at a time, on a regular basis (see my longevity concerns above).[Update 15Nov2015] Wow, we just printed out the photos.  The HP (on the left) wasn't even close.  It's way too yellow, and there are lines introduced by the printer.  The Epson XP-960 on the right is legitimately pro quality: the colors are right on, and the image is perfect.  We're confused that there doesn't seem to be a way to calibrate it...  but it appears to be calibrated already.  I *had* been prepared to not let this review go above 4-stars, but the photo quality is so good that I actually upped it to five stars.  I'll revisit the review in a few months to update the longevity, but if you don't see anything below, no news is good news!
These are exactly as you would hope them to be.  They're good toothbrushes, and more importantly, they get my kid to brush his teeth!

Dutailier is the best glider brand I've found, and this is amazingly smooth motion.  It was also easy assembly.  With my first kid, we spent twice this on a Dutailier and it is still my favorite chair in the house.  For the second, I bought a SherMag from a local Baby store and that was a waste of money.  For our third kid, we tried to split the difference: get a Dutailier, just a less expensive one.  From what I can tell, the chair and gliding mechanism are pretty much the same, but the cushion is way less comfortable.Also, if you have a baby, get the ottoman.  I basically bought the wrong item...

With our other babies, we had found that Huggies led to blowouts and Pampers were the only ones that fit properly, but with #3, we're rather happy with these Huggies so far.  The umbilical cord cutout is making us happy (I think with the other two, the cords fell off earlier).  So far, no blow outs!The one thing that we would have preferred is if Huggies offered a sensitive version. The little guy's butt is SO small and he has such delicate skin that we're very worried about giving him a rash or other irritation.  None yet, but you know the anxieties of "new" parents...[Update 29 October 2015] Okay, looks like we're seeing blowouts.  YUCK.  So we're torn between the Pampers that irritates his belly button (even after we fold it down) and the Huggies that doesn't hold the #2.

This set is amazing from the get-go.  Even the packaging was amazingly designed, with my only quibble being around the thick plastic that holds the tracks: it was surprisingly tough to open those!This is totally amazing:the technology is first class, and puts it squarely in five-star territory.  The re-configurable track keeps it there, especially given that there are expansion sets.  The only technical thing missing is a camera to give a first person perspective, which I think would be very helpful.The track is a bit of a mixed blessing: it's HUGE, so you need a large area of bare floor space; I'm pretty sure that carpeted floor is not the optimal surface, but a table is even worse since the cars could fly off and get damaged.  The issue with keeping it on the floor, though, is pets: my cat thinks this is an awesome thing to sit on, which I'm pretty sure is bad for the track.The cars CAN fly off the track, and go under beds, cabinets, etc.  I wish there was something that could help with that.Surprisingly, there is a single player mode that allows you to compete against an AI driver.  That's pretty awesome.However, my biggest gripe is really around the app.  There are some parts of it that are really slick, but it's also really confusing.  Without going into massive details, it feels like the game designers took a lot of great ideas and then threw them together in a complicated mish-mash.  It's absolutely amazing that Anki pushed this into five star territory by taking this beyond just a racing game and adding weaponry and strategy to it, but my son and I just want to race cars.  The nice thing is that this is easily fixable with a software update, and I will gladly update the review if they introduce - or I discover - a basic mode that makes simple multiplayer racing easy (without any levels).Also, regarding the recommended age, my now 6-year old son had added Anki Drive (the first generation) to his Amazon wishlist two years ago, when he was just 4....  but obviously it's too sophisticated for that age.
