I had hoped that as a 6-year old he might be close enough to the 8-year old minimum recommended age, but he's definitely struggling with it.  Hopefully with practice he will improve, but I think this may end up being something that really should wait until 8.
My 3-1/2 yo daughter LOVES this!!!

My little girl (3-1/2) immediately fell in love with this doll, and will tell anyone that listen that this doll goes #2.  She has been having fun feeding her, while I have been impressed that you can take off he back of the baby's head to get objects that may have been fed to the babyThat said, first this doll is MUCH bigger than we expected.  My daughter loves it, but we are the ones who have to make spaceAlso, the wrist button is a little hard for my daughter to push, which distresses her greatly.  Hopefully she'll build up strength and technique quickly

Amazing sound.  Absolutely amazing.  The gimmicky fit doesn't really add anything for me.Two negatives: first, the mic is really bad.  I have to manually hold it in front of my mouth for people to understand me. Second, there needs to be some sort of clip!  When I am not using it, and it is just hanging around my neck, it has fallen off.  This one happens to be free from the vine, but I previously owned an older model Jaybird and lost it after three daysNormally I would have put three stars, but the sound is that good

I have my doubts about the "odor detection," but it does seem to work pretty well.  I have it on top of a cat litter box ( Merry Pet Cat Washroom / Night Stand Pet House ) and my house does not smell like cat!  That said, I'm not a huge fan of the scents Air Wick has: right now I use Snuggle.

My 3-1/2 year old daughter loved this from the get-go.  Even the bin fascinated her.  She was off making cookies within minutes, and no mention of the iPad.My wife loves the fact that it's easy to store.I just received this the other day, so I can't comment on the longevity, but this falls into the category of "good, creative fun, for not that much $"

I'm a big fan of Legos, but these are not Legos.  These are actually nearly identical to MegaBlocks, but with a light.  I'm not a fan of Megablocks for the same reason I'm not a fan of these: it's too hard to get the bricks to stick together.  The light feature is neat, but there's definitely some false advertising going on: the light does not get all the way up to the helicopter blades.It's also way too hard for 5.  My son is 6 and is struggling.  I am way older than 5 and *I* was struggling a bit.That said, my son is enjoying them, and the light feature is entertaining him

My cat doesn't like Frontline, but he needs it because he goes outside.  He's smart enough now to recognize the little container and run.  Usually when I catch him and pin him down, he usually just accepts his fate, then runs off to sulk and give me the evil eye (and sometimes goes #1 where he's not supposed to, the passive-aggressive jerk).This product seemed like it could be a less expensive alternative, but when I was giving him the medicine he FREAKED.  I couldn't even give him the whole dose.  He got out of my hold and is hissing and acting WAY worse than he usually does.  Not sure exactly what's going on here, but he is definitely voting for 1-star!!!

My 3-year old daughter LOVES this stamp set, and we love it because it's "mess-free."  Someone was really thinking with this one: the stamps are also big and easy for little ones to hold.  It's gender neutral, and compatible with other color wonder products.The batteries, wire (it's short, so no risk of strangulation - as I said, someone was really thinking!!!), and special paper are a little annoying for me, but my daughter isn't negatively affected at all.

This is advertised as a keychain remote.  It's only a keychain remote for someone who walks around saying "Fee Fi Fo Fum," and I am not a giant.  For me, this is a car remote.Also, the one I received from seller KCC was ADT branded, not unbranded like the photo above.

I had never previously heard of Symmons, but had an opportunity to get one free from the Amazon Vine right when I was redoing my bathroom.  After having the chance to inspect the product, I bought a second one, out of pocket, as well.  This is obviously a much higher quality product than Delta faucets (with chrome-painted plastic), and I'd put it on par with my contractor's favorite brand: Moen.  My sense is that Symmons is more commercial than Moen: it seems to have fewer styles, and those styles tend to be more "classic."  Functionally, just like Moen, it has a lifetime warranty (for homeowners), and if you happen to like the styling, you're in luck!  This is actually really similar to the Moen Weymouth, which I love, but for half the price.
It looked good and felt good, but the clasp wouldn't stay shutAlso, the LROO logo etched into the edge of the band is a bit garish
Everything was just perfect!  Exactly as expected.

We were really interested in this toy (as opposed to Lego or Lego Junior) because it's a brain-building toy that would be good for my 3-year old and maybe even my 5-year old, but would also be safe to be around a baby.  The colors are gender neutral, and there's a decent variety of pieces.My three year old daughter was very interested in building a castle for her princesses with this toy.  It was a good size, and she was able to build pretty well, though she did get frustrated her inability to build exactly what she wanted.My five year old refused to play with it because it didn't have superheroes.Just to make it very clear, the bag is a really nice feature since it makes it easy to transport and clean up.
These fit great and are very heat resistant.  I picked up a cast iron grill with no issue whatsoever.They don't look exactly like the picture but who cares.

These are SO amazingly soft!  I'll update this review once I wash them; hopefully they'll stay just as soft.My only issue is with the color, and mostly as it relates to the Amazon listing: "natural" color is actually just as I expected, sort of a linen colored off-white.  But it is WAY more orange in real life than in the photo.  If they fix the listing, I'd definitely up this to 5-stars.I wish they had these in white, which matches my baby's room and décor, but that probably means bleaching the material and ruining the softness as well as being worse for the environment.

Day 1: maybe I drink too much coffee on a regular basis, but I never got the jitters from this...  I never even got an energy boost!  I took a pill at 4pm and at 11pm I'm tired.I'll update this over the next month as I observe - or don't observe - any weight loss.

Hasbro really got EVERYTHING right in this game.  First, the princess figurines are awesome just on their own.  My 3 year old daughter was playing with them in a Little People castle playset and just having a grand old time.  She LOVED looking at the board and spotting all the characters she knew, and telling me everything about the castle.Regarding the gameplay, there are a bunch of cards to pop out, and possibly to make a mess and/or lose, but it's very clear to a little kid who can't count well or read numbers yet (she actually is pretty good at both, but this is much easier), and doesn't have any dice or spinners which can be tough for a little kid's dexterity.There are also modified rules for younger kids, which is awesome and makes gameplay simple.The only issue is that this is SO princess oriented that her big brother (5yo) will not even touch it.  I would have suggested throwing princes in as well, but that would have ruined some of the draw for her, so I guess you have to use your best judgment.  She doesn't like playing Marvel Superhero Chutes & Ladders with him, so maybe they can switch off or something, I don't know!  Minion Trouble, they both like.The box keeps talking about an app, but I haven't investigated that yet.  I like the fact that this is "real," even if there was an electronic version as well.
This Polyester is totally not breathable.  I sweat like crazy wearing this robe, and it doesn't absorb anything after a shower

The pail is nicely constructed, and both my wife and I were impressed at the metal.  That's really the big draw to this, actually.  That and the fact you can use your own bags.I did also like the fact that we could go with whatever bag we wanted, but the pail is so small that my big Glad bags are mostly wasted, and frankly the diaper genie rolls can come on Subscribe & Save here on Amazon for a not horrible price.  In fact, Ubbi also sells their own bags for this, which I'm sure I would end up getting.Just to reiterate: the pail is quite small.  The size is really a disadvantage.  You can say "it's full of diapers, you're not going to let it fill up, are you?" but with my other two,we did in fact let the Diaper Genie XL fill up quite a bit.  Little ones go through 7-10 diapers a day, and a lot of those are #1.  If the pail contains the smell, letting it sit there for the whole day - or even two or three - isn't going to have a huge effect.  And when they're little and you're waking up every three hours....  you start to get behind on chores, shall we say?Also, you have to bend down if it's on the floor.  I think this is a countertop device, but my wife disagrees, and the picture does depict it on the floor next to the changer.The slide function and lock work okay, but there is no foot pedal so if you're holding a baby in one hand and a diaper in the other, this is hard to access.  It's actually not the easiest thing to open one-handed; maybe some WD-40 would help, but I've been using both hands to open this.Not sure how well the smell is contained.  That may cause the review to be adjusted!

My grill arrived fully intact, even though it actually fell once or twice while still in the box.  It's definitely made of cheap material, especially compared to a Weber at relatively the same price point.  The Weber doesn't have any electronics associated with it though.Assembly was not too hard, but pictures would have been nice.  I had a particularly tough time figuring out how to screw the main tube together, but the rest of it seemed to be pretty straightforward.What's so funny is that this is really just a large George Foreman Grill with a fancy stand.  You can unclip it and bring it inside and put it on the counter (if you have enough space).  It's actually decent to cook on, and could come in handy to augment my regular grill.

Bought this a few days ago at a local big box store.  First, the picture doesn't really convey the size of this thing.  I've set it up in my basement at 45% humidity, and it definitely is drier down there than the rest of the house on a warm humid summer day.  It feels a bit warmer, but I haven't checked a thermometer.No leakage whatsoever from what I can tell.  The pump seems to be working just fine.I did have an instance where this machine was on even though the basement registered 38% humidity.  I've been checking periodically, and that hasn't happened since... but I've got 30 days to return this to the retailer, and I will if it doesn't do its job properly!!!One discovery: even though this is Energy Star, it is sucking up Electricity like nobody's business, at an average of 590W!  That means it costs me roughly $3/day to run...  about $100/mo.  This may only be an issue during the summer months, but $300/yr is a pretty hefty bill!!!
It's a small puff with a ninja turtle.  Nothing special to a grown up, but gets my kid to wash!

This turned out to be a great game for my kids (3 and 5-1/2) since they both like the minions (who doesn't?) and Trouble is an appropriate level of dexterity for both of them.  My little one has some difficulty pushing the bubble hard enough, but is usually able to do it with no help.  She likes moving the pieces, and it helps her counting.I agree with all the comments about the low quality materials, but I've sort of come to expect it.  They're paying for the character licensing, so either the customer has to pay more (I got this free through the Amazon Vine program) or they have to cut back on construction cost.  Thus far, the game hasn't broken and the cardboard hasn't gotten messed up, so it's really just the "feel."

This nail hardener dries fast and leaves a nice shine on nails.  It really seems to work, similar to Nailtiques Formula 2 but for half the price!  (I got the first as a sample free through the Amazon Vine program, but will be switching to this.)

The pellets spread well, and I haven't seen any ticks or grubs this season.  There was a slight odor for the first few days, but it faded quickly and wasn't unpleasant at all.  My only issue was that it seemed to cover a little less area than advertised: for 10,000 sq feet, I used three bags

We can't get over the cuteness here.  My daughter is in LOVE with this dolly: she smells like lavender (for calming my daughter while she sleeps), and she has a magnetic binky and bottle.  My daughter loves the fact that "it sticks!"  The baby has a lovey, as well!!!  A rubber band will keep the lovey on the baby's hand.It appears to be well constructed (with soft, infant friendly eyes), the clothes are easy to take on and off, and there are accessories sold separately as well.

The birds don't like these.  I bought these because supposedly all types of birds preferred them, but that's not how it's working out.  They come to the feeder, wrinkle their beaks in distaste (metaphorically, at least), and then fly off...
I thought this rug was a soft shag, but it's more like the texture of mopstrings.  My daughter likes it (which is what counts) for the color, but I dislike the texture.

My first reaction upon unboxing was that this feeder was MUCH smaller than I thought it looked in the picture, but just as cute.  Check the measurements first so you're not surprised: it's only about 8 or 9 inches tall.  The mushroom cap is awesome since it theoretically will keep the squirrels out, but it's so small that I'm not sure it will be effective.  I have very determined squirrels around here, so I will watch them and update the review.A lot of folks have complained about the mesh letting the sunflower seed out.  That's sort of a design flaw, isn't it?  The mesh has to be large enough to let the birds get the seed out, but at the same time the mesh has to be small enough to hold the bird seed in.  My experience was that this made a complete mess when I was trying to fill it.  A bottom platform would ruin the mushroom theme but would probably make this much more effective.A bottom cap would also lure a better variety of birds.  I love cardinals but they need some sort of hopper.  This only attracts clinging birds like finches and goldfinches.[Update 12 May 2015] As feared, the mushroom cap is a bit too small for my incredibly acrobatic squirrel population.  Check out this squirrel that is hanging upside down by his claws and *just* making it to the feeder.  I'm going to try relocating the feeder.

The included chain is very thin and not adjustable, but this is a GORGEOUS pendant (esp for the price - full disclosure, I got this free from the Vine program) and would be a great present from young children to mom.  My daughter loves butterflies, so if it was only a pink or purple stone, this would have been perfect.The packaging was a nice presentation with a black cardboard box covering a black felt jewelry box.  Not Tiffany's, but way more than a cheap plastic bag.

This is sort of the gold standard for lawn seed, isn't it?  Looking at the reviews, it's interesting that some people love it, some people hate it.  I had good luck with this seed on a bare patch.  I *did* put down fertilizer first and also covered the patch with peat moss to keep in the moisture and protect from the birds, so I'm not sure if that helped.  Personally, for a patch, I prefer the EZ Seed, which includes fertilizer and paper mulch (instead of peat moss), and has a mix of fescues, ryegrass, and bluegrass.  It's less work, though more bags.It had a nice color, but not the crazy deep green I've seen with some seed.  For reseeding my existing lawn, I couldn't really tell how well this grew.  Again, I didn't follow the instructions, instead I used a seeder machine (not just a spreader) to put this down.The big question is if you want the Kentucky Bluegrass variety or more of a turf type tall fescue.  The Bluegrass is a bit more heat resistant even with short roots, whereas the TTTF needs to have long roots.

As I was reading through Sucker, I was reminded of the very popular movie, Sin City. It has the same kind of feel as that, but this one is even better in my opinion. Author Mark Lingane did an excellent job with Book 1 of this series, and I am extremely interested in reading what's next to come. This is a true detective novel, which reminded me a lot of how good detective books used to be. What's even better is that a supernatural twist is thrown right into this one, which really helped to peak my interest. Lingane does an excellent job of describing each scene very vividly, so you feel as if you are a part of the story with all of the characters. It's an extremely fast paced read that's going to be over with before you know it. It's definitely heart pumping, and will literally "suck you" right in. Great job overall, can't wait for the next ones. Good job Lingane, you have gained a fan in me.

It's extremely rare when a book comes along and truly touches me in such a way that I think about it days after I finish reading it. That's exactly what Bowl of Fruit, by Panayotis Cacoyannis, has done to me. I finished it a few days ago, and had no words to describe it immediately after finishing it. However, I have been thinking about it ever since, and feel compelled to post a review, due to how touching it was to me. Cacoyannis clearly has a lot of talent, and has blown me away in words that I can't even describe. Between the amazing character development, unique plot line, and excellent imagery, I just couldn't seem to get enough.Leon and Anna are two completely different people - It's hard to see where they may fit together. However, as the story moves along, we see that there are many hidden secrets intertwined, as they both go backwards in their lives. Anna is a ghostwriter, who knows way more about Leon's history than even he does. Leon agrees to meet with her, even though he is extremely unsure about it. As they trace their pasts backwards, many secrets get revealed; some of them devastating, some of them uplifting. They soon figure out that their paths aren't as different as they originally would of thought.I don't want to give too much away, as this is one that I feel any avid should pick up and read. Cacoyannis has a lot of talent, and it really shows through in this work. I can't wait to see what this author has in store for us next.

If you're looking for a good read that contains war, romance, action, suspense, etc., then The Butcher's Daughter is a definite must. Written by Mr. Mark M. McMillin, this story will have you on the edge of your seat wanting more and more. It's based on true Historical Events as well, which made it even more interesting. Being a teacher, I do already know a lot about history and I know that the events in this book were pretty spot on to factual events. However, the characters and the overall fiction aspect of it really kept it interesting for me.The King of Spain is currently creating one of the most powerful armada's that the world has even dreamed to be possible. His main goal is to evade England and depose of the Queen. In order for England to stand a chance, they need to think up a powerful way to stop it. Queen Elizabeth decides to spare Mary from the headman's axe in exchange of her men, ships, and loyalty.This book kept me on my toes, and left me wanting more. Kudos to McMilin for an excellent story. I can't wait to see what he has in store for us next. Highly recommend.

Super Daddy Bedtime Questions, by Nicolas Pavlou, is such a great children's book! Not only have I read it to my nephew, but I've been reading it in my classroom as well and the kids absolutely adore it. It's funny and sweet, and filled with common questions that kids ask. What I LOVE about this one is that it focuses on "Daddy", more than it does on Mommy. I feel as if a lot of children's books are catered more towards the mom, and It's refreshing to come across one that goes the other way. The kids always get a kick out of as well, which is really what It's all about.Kid's LOVE Superheroes (yes, girls TOO!), which is really what gets my classroom kids so excited whenever they see the cover. It's written in the form of a poem, and each Daddy response is a rhyme, which is amazing. It also teaches kids that their Dad doesn't have to be a superhero in order to be a super dad, which is an excellent concept for all children to know and understand.My students make me read this story to them at least once a week - they just can't get enough. I HIGHLY recommend it for It's originality and humor as well.

Eterlimus, by Azis Hamza, is an excellent read that I'm really happy I decided to check out. Hamza is a new author to me; I hadn't heard of him before this one, by the storyline was so interesting, I had to jump right in. It's also a short read, at around only 100 pages. That allows readers to have a good idea of what kind of writing style Hamza has, which is what I appreciate. By the end of the book, I was hoping it was longer, though. It was so exciting and engrossing, I didn't want to put it down.This book focuses on the Roman History, in a less confusing way than normal. I am a big fan of Roman times, and felt as if this was pretty spot on. Imagery was excellent as well, and at times I felt like I was back in time with the characters. Main character Eterlimus is one of the few who survived King Tarquinius. Flavius rescued him, and the two of them bonded very well. I loved the character of Eterlimus, and feel as if he was well written and full of life. Such a great hero to have around.Overall, this was an excellent read and one that I would definitely recommend. Five stars all the way.

Sons of Abraham is a complete Sci-fi trilogy written by Joseph Ray. I remember reading just Volume 1 not so long ago, and being blown away by it. When I saw that the entire set was now up for grabs, I immediately purchased and read right through them all. It's a massive collection, but one that you won't be sorry for reading.. There is so much action and suspense involved, with such intricate storylines, you won't ever want it to come to an end.Set in 3026, things have changed dramatically. Somewhere around the 2500s, mankind as we know it struggled to sustain life on earth, due to limited resources and billions upon billions of new population. People were left starving, with no real way to cope. When the powers to be can't figure out a solution, the next best thing is to build the greatest mind. This is when the Cybers were invented. They were extremely hard to solve every complex issue, in order to help mankind. And help is what they did. However, 500 years later, mankind still has a ton of issues to contend with. The Cybers are now in their third generation, and they are called upon to help out once again. However, certain people aren't thrilled with the way they are operating, and take it upon themselves to harness their power. It is now up to Nathan to David to help the world, and stop the terrorism in order to save mankind.There is SO much more to these stories than I can ever get into. All I can say is, I'm blown away by the writing of Joseph Ray, and I truly feel as if this is the best Sci-fi trilogy out there today. It is filled with action and adventure, and will definitely keep you wanting more. Highly recommend, you won't be sorry.

Flatlander and the Rise and Fall of Mike and the Ravens, by Peter F. Young, really appealed to me. I did not grow up in the Rock N Roll era, but my Father did. This meant that growing up, I would constantly hear about all things Rock N Roll; between the music, the great artists, and the rise and fall of some of the big celebrities during that time period. This book touches on that subject, in a very interesting kind of way.In this memoir, Young recalls his time between the small towns of rural Vermont and Northern New York State. Like other young boys during that generation, he dreamed of being a rock star himself - and it almost happened for him. Mike & the Ravens were almost a huge hit in New York State, but didnt quite make it. They did, however, get signed by a record company, which made them regionally famous. With any hardcore Rock N Roll, there also comes a bit of trouble, which they got themselves into, landing themselves in jail.This was a very enjoyable read, with a lot of humorous moments thrown it. I found it to be exciting and interesting, and glad that I got to peek into Youngs past. Five stars all the way for originality and good storytelling.

When Water Flows Uphill, by Beryl Shaw, is definitely a different kind of a read. There are a lot of elements to it, which are sure to keep you hooked. There is suspense, romance, and twists and turns along the way. What really got me interested, though, was the fact that I learned a lot more about water than I thought I would from a book like this.Main character Dr. Armand Croft wakes up with no idea who he is; he's suffering from amnesia. The only thing he remembers is that he's currently working on a water project in Las Vegas. There is a shortage of water in the city, The water is going to be drained out in the ranches in order to get enough supply for the people. This causes many problems in itself; one of which being, making the ranchers angry. Croft is confused on which way he's supposed to go, but he has no problem falling in love with lovely Stephanie. This is a dangerous move though, which may cost the both of them their lives.I loved the character development involved here, and the vivid descriptions of Las Vegas, along with water. This is one that definitely held my interest from beginning to end, and I would nott hesitate to recommend it.

DEEP EARTH, by R Julian Cox, is Book 2 in The Hanford Chronicles series. I must admit, I have not read book 1 yet, but this one is easy enough to follow along with without having to read the first one. This was an extremely different type of read for me, and I wasn't sure how I would feel about it. However, I was drawn in by the 3rd page, and did not come back to my own reality until I was finished reading. '49 days remain, that pretty much sets up the tone for this book. A remote British Past and an American Present are still at it. The deadline is quickly approaching to a project that is set to save thousands of American lives. Just when they believe the problem has been solved, another terrorist cell is threatening to strike once more. A Scientist is trying to find his way back from the past into the present, but this proves to be extremely challenging. The race against time is approaching, and the main question is, can the terrorists be stopped?I don't want to give too much away, but this is a very deep read but one that you will quickly be able to pick up on and follow just fine. I would highly recommend it, due to all of the intense action involved, and the wonderful writing. I am definitely going to work backwards and pick up book 1 to read. Five stars all the way.

Brett Matthew Williams has done a great job with Time is Relative for a Knight of Time. It did start out a little slow so I was unsure about it in the beginning, but it quickly picked up and became almost addicting to read. Poor Rolland Wright is a seventeen year old boy who is having an extremely difficult life. First, his mother was murdered. Then his father the alcoholic decided to abandon him, and now he's sleeping/living in his car. One night he makes an amazing discovery; he's able to slow down the flow of time, which sets him on a journey. He ends up in the early 19th Century to fight General Andrew Jackson. He comes across the Knights of Time, who help him to discover the mystery of his mothers murder. This was actually a very interesting concept that I couldn't seem to get enough of. I was pleasantly surprised that there is going to be a 2nd installment of this book; I truly can't wait to read it. Highly recommend Time is Relative, It's one worth reading.

There was a lot going on in One Stick and a Waco, by J.M. Taylor, and I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of it. This is a shorter read, so it didn't take me very long to get through it. It's pretty close to factual, so I can appreciate that. I love all things World War II; I am actually fascinated by that point in history, especially in Europe. There is a lot of clipart in this book, along with several maps and references. I have read many WWII books since I am so intrigued, but I must say, this was one of the better ones. Even though the characters in this novel are not factual, the storyline's surrounding them definitely were. J.M. Taylor's biography truly blew me away, and It's no surprise that this book was so well written. He has extensive knowledge on this subject matter, and it shows through. A lot of things written in this book I did not know about before, so that was refreshing and also eye opening.Overall, I am extremely impressed by not only this book, but also by the author. I definitely look forward to what else he has to offer in the future. Five stars all the way.

Who doesn't love a good time travel novel? Especially when It's mixed in with Vampires? This is probably my favorite book this year, due to all of the exciting aspects of it. We not only have a great time travel novel here, but we also have an incredible love triangle that will leave you wanting more as you keep reading. I love the fact that there are twists and turns involved in this one. Everytime I thought I knew what was about to happen, I found myself completely wrong. I love the character of Roxanna, and I also enjoyed both Philip and Darren. Obviously I was rooting for one over the other, but I liked them both equally as much. I also enjoyed the fact that Roxanna had her own hopes/dreams/desires, and would not let anything come in her way. The characters were extremely well developed, and I almost felt as if I knew them all. The descriptions were vivid, and the overall plot was just fantastic. I would highly recommend this one.

A Ladder In The Dark, by Alan Eisenberg, really pulled at my heart strings. It made me extremely sad, but also enlightened at the same time. Bullying is such a major issue in today's world and as an educator, I take the subject matter very seriously. It breaks my heart to read stories written by those who have been bullied, but It's a reality that we face in the world. I give Alan Eisenberg so much credit for putting his story out there, and for not being ashamed. Eisenberg does a great job in stressing the fact that being bullied is something that stays with us our entire lives; it doesn't go away just because the bullying stopped. It's an extremely traumatizing and emotional thing, one that a person can't simply just escape. I love the fact that he also talks about his own faults as well. As time goes by, Eisenberg does begin to grow a self acceptance overall, which is a wonderful thing. His story being out there will hopefully serve as an inspirational guide to those of us who have been bullied in any time of our lives. It was very well written, and definitely an eye opener. I would highly recommend this one to anyone.

I just got finished reading Legends of the Collective and I must say, I'm very impressed. It was definitely better than I expected, and most certainly not what I expected going into it. When they say don't judge a book by It's cover, this is a true example of that. Author Michael Kirk has a lot of talent, and It's evident in this book. If you enjoyed The Hunger Games, then you definitely can't pass this one up.This story is set in the future; year 5847 to be exact. Jaden and William are two brothers who have had an extremely difficult life. Joanna and Alicia are two sisters, who are looking for a journey. They decide to join the boys into the forbidden forest, on an illegal type of journey. Joanna ends up getting maimed, and Jaden and William are sentenced to prison (death). When a series plague hits the land, the only real solution is to get the antidote out of the Diggers bellies - but they isn't an easy feat.Every character in this book was enjoyable, and I couldn't put it down until I reached the very last page. I couldn't help but to root for the brothers, and felt very badly of them. If you are a fan of The Hunger Games, or Sci/Fi in general, than I would highly recommend Legends of the Collective. Great read overall!

Girl On a Dolphin, by Vic Warren, is the second book in The Neptune Chronicles series. It is a two part series, both being equally as good. This is such a refreshing read, that will make you feel good by the end of it. I thoroughly enjoyed the writing, and would definitely be interested in reading Vic Warren's other works.In Girl On a Dolphin, main characters Jamie and Mercy have been living on a small island for the past 5 years. They have a daughter named Saffron, who seeks adventure. One day she runs in to tell her parents that she just saw Neptune's on a dolphin! Their goal is to travel on both sides of the globe in order to stop the Dolphin War. The main purpose is to get the Neptunes and the humans to come together in peace and harmony.I loved the characters in these two books; they definitely did seem to come alive. This book had a lot of character, and I almost felt as if I was in the story alongside them. Would definitely recommend, especially if you are looking for something light and amusing.

WOW, is all that I have to say after finishing A Simple Soul, by Vadim Babenko. So much went on in this novel, it was impossible not to be completely captivated by it. This is definitely a different type of storyline from your average romance novel.Elizaveta is a very attractive Muscovite who gets sucked into something that she wasn't prepared for. She gets followed, receives strange gifts and calls. These are all coming from Timofey, who is her ex lover. He now lives far away, but feels threatened when a local mafia boss wants him to marry his daughter. His only way out of that is to get married, and who better to marry than Elizaveta? Soon enough he manipulates her, and the two of them find themselves in some serious danger.I enjoyed this story, and found the relationship between Timofey and Elizaveta to be refreshing and unique. I would highly recommend this one; It's better than your average romance novel!

Having just read a very similar book by the same author and falling in love with it, I was excited to come across Love in a cala. I wasn't sure that I would enjoy it as much as the first one, but it took me by surprise. This is not really a sequel as the characters are different, but I enjoyed these characters just as much as the ones in the previous novel. These are such wonderfully written books, you can't help but to be engrossed by them and wanting to come back for more.In Love in a cala, Tessa is completely fed up with men. Her bad experiences have made her want to wash her hands clean and be done. In comes Luke, who is everything that Tessa doesn't want in a man. Luke likes casual relationships, with no strings attached and no commitments. When Tess gets hurts swimming and Luke's dog comes to her rescue, It's inevitable that the two of them will meet and sparks will fly. I couldn't help but to root for the two of them to be together, as the sparks were literally flying off the pages.I love how the author makes the reader feel like they are a part of the story, right in the middle of the Mediterranean. Can't wait to see what she's going to come out with next.

Love in a boat, by Carla Prince, really did surprise me. While at the beach I was browsing through different books, and came across this one. From the cover, I knew it was going to be a fun read so I gave it a shot. I got absolutely HOOKED into it! I ended up staying on the beach for an extra 2 hours just because I was so engrossed in this one, I couldn't get up. It's a romance novel, which is right up my alley.This book takes place on a yacht and a pier; both locations I adore. I almost felt like I was there with the characters, that's how clear the imagery was. Main characters Flynn and Kate were priceless! Obviously I was rooting for them to be together very early on. Kate has absolutely no experience with men, which makes her pretty clueless. Flynn just purchased a luxury yacht, and never had imagined getting involved with a woman who was so inexperienced, such as Kate. The two of them come together, and magic happens. Obviously there are obstacles in between, but it wouldn't be a good romance book without that.This is a pretty light hearted read, but definitely a lot of fun! I would highly recommend.

Semmant, by Vadim Babenko, is a book for this generation. It is definitely unique, and the storyline isn't something that I have seen touched on many times before. I was pulled in from the very beginning, and did not get pulled out until the very last page. This is an extremely well written piece of fiction, filled with characters and plot development that fascinated me.When you start out reading Semmant, you feel as if the storyline is going to be simple, overall. However, as you continue turning the pages, the storyline becomes more detailed, complex, and very interesting. Main character, Bogdan Bogdanov, is a cyber geek, as you may say. He develops a robot, named Semmant, that is the most intelligent robot known to man. In Bogdan's eyes, Semmant is perfect in every way possible. The two of them team up together to start working on the stock market together, and they quickly become a success. With such a brilliant team, how can they possibly fail?Sure enough, a woman begins to cause a wedge in between them. Her name is Lidia, and Bogdan quickly falls in love with her. The only issue is, Semmant was built in a way that he begins to have feelings of his own, and his feelings develop towards Lidia as well. He is starting to become almost humans, with real emotions and thoughts of his own. Semmant is no longer your typical robot; he is now fully capable of true human experience, which becomes extremely unpredictable for all of the characters.I felt the character of Bogdan to be extremely relatable. He definitely has a unique personality, and you can say that he is a genius. His mind process is not the same as an average person, as he is far beyond, but he still manages to feel the emotions of life just the same as everyone else.What I like most about Semmant is that the plot is complex and makes you think and ponder, long after you have finished reading it, due to the many underlying meanings involved. At the same time, the author writes in a way that is still simple and easy to read and follow along with.I was truly engrossed, and felt as if I was transformed to another world, a world that is a possibility of our future with the way technology is developing. I feel as if there truly could be a "Semmant" one day, and this book had me wondering what it would be like to be in the same place as both Bogdan and Semmant. Highly recommend.

Words To Die By, by Jeanne Lamb-Carlin, is Book 2 in the Allison Taylor series. I am absolutely loving this series so far! I find the storylines to be intense, thrilling, with a nice mystery element to them. The characters in these books also suck me in, and make me feel as if I'm a part of the story with them. There is also some romance in this particular story, which is something that I like even better.Allison Taylor is having some serious trust issues going on in her life. A woman from Mark Ryan's past pops up in Spring Hollow, and she makes no secret about the fact that she may want him back. Elizabeth Meade is writing a murder mystery at the same time, which ties in nicely. The issue is, people in real life are dying just like in the novel. Mark Ryan doesn't want Allison involved in too much investigation; instead, he wants her to leave that to him. Instead of listening, Ally decides to enlist her friends to help her figure out the mystery.I loved this one, and look forward to reading the next series in this collection. Jeanne Lamb-Carlin has a lot of talent, and It's evident in her works.

I found Swimming With Sharks, by Jeanne Lamb-Carlin, to be refreshing and full of life. I thoroughly enjoyed the introductions of a large amount of characters at the very beginning; I find this kind of thing to be exciting, and keeps me wanting to read more to figure out who everyone is. I also enjoyed and appreciated all the background information that was provided; it helped me to understand what was going on. There are quite a few twists and turns in this one, sometimes very unexpected.Main character Ally has some issues going on. Her ex-husband, Jack Doretta, shows up and tells her he has some money issues. These money issues have put a major strain on his new marriage, and begs Ally to let him crash at her house for a few days. She doesn't really want to, but she ends up giving in anyway. However, she soon begins to regret this as nothing but trouble arises since allowing him to stay. Suddenly strange men are coming to town, and her life gets threatened. She is desperate to figure out what he's hiding, and enlists the help of her bestfriends, Elizabeth Meade and Larry Jones, to figure out what's really going on.A good mystery all in all, one that I thoroughly enjoyed. Highly recommend.

Eye of the Storm, by Ray Williams, is a masterpiece in my opinion. A definite must read for anyone who is in a leadership position, or an entrepreneur. Williams goes into detail on how to improve your business and those who work for you, in order to make it a more peaceful and pleasant environment. It's a known fact that when you have a positive work environment, your business does better due to higher quality employee work ethics. Most leaders face a lot of troubles and difficulties when it comes to managing their workers and keeping things running smoothly. I myself have worked for several people who had no leadership skills whatsoever, and I'm pretty tempted to forward this one to them.This is a well written book, that has easy to follow instructions on how to turn things around. I love that Williams writes in such a way that everyone is able to understand, without getting confused. It's obvious that this author has a lot of knowledge, and I'm truly grateful that I stumbled upon this book. Would highly recommend.

I have read some of Thomas Drago's other books, and have been extremely impressed by his writing style and unique storylines. Queensboro is no exception. This is such a thrilling suspense/mystery/horror novel that keeps getting better as you turn the page. It's filled with so many twists and turns, I was constantly surprised by it The storyline was intriguing, and as a reader, I couldn't help but to feel sorry for poor Ashley Smith who got taken off of a school bus. She had everything going for her, and was heading in a great direction. As local natives turn up dead in the woods, we must figure out what's happening and why. More importantly, where is Ashley and who has her? If you enjoy reading vampire books, you will love this one! Especially since it involves the classic spin on vampire/supernatural type of stories. Thomas Drago is an excellent author, and I truly can't wait to read more of his work.

Wow, Dana Alexander really took me by surprise with this one! Beyond A Darkened Sky is Book 1 in this trilogy, and the author is off to a great start. For a debut novel, this was beyond my expectations. I was sucked in from the very beginning, and not let go until I reached the last page. I am now anxiously awaiting the next one to be released, that's how good it was.New York psychiatrist Dr. Sara Forrester finds herself in an interesting predicament. She's torn between the life she knows, and another one that seems to be a dream, or a nightmare. She receives a task; she has to retrieve three keys, but in order to find the keys, she must unlock the gateways to each one. The only way to do this is by finding three different medallions.This novel has different elements to it. It has mystery involved, sci/fi, along with thrill. I loved it, and truly can't wait for Book 2 to be released. I recommend to everyone.

Finally, a self help book that actually makes sense! Matti Dobbs has a Ph.D., and has committed her life to helping others, so It's obvious that this book would be filled with useful information. In Soaring, readers are given helpful ways to help live a better life; joyful, and empowered. There are twelve flight plans involved that a person should follow in order to achieve that goal. I have been in need for quite some time to achieve personal and professional growth and success in my own life. When I came across this book and read the description, I knew that I had to have it. I have been reading it for a few days now, and have been practicing the steps involved for a few days, and I do really feel as if this is going to help me. It's well written, easy to understand, and gives clear direction. Five stars all the way for a wonderfully written self help book.

The Crash Between Heaven and Hell, by Michael Edmonds, really did take me by surprise. When I started reading the prologue, I was extremely confused as it contained a lot of violence and erotica as well. I wasn't sure what kind of book this was that I got myself into, but I decided to keep reading them anyway. I was intrigued by how vivid the entire chapter seemed to be, and it continued that way throughout the duration of the book. Each chapter starts out with a very descriptive, vivid illustrations. What I found as I continued reading this book was something so much more than just erotica. This is a pretty intense storyline that sucks you in and doesn't let you go until the end.The apocalypse has devastated humanity, leaving only a few survivors behind. However, there is some hope left. The angels have been sent out to save the world from the evil It's being faced with, but they are going to need a lot of help from the pure-hearts. There are seven people who are the key; all seven come from different places in the world and different cultures as well. Even though they don't know each other, they are thrown together to reach their common goal.A lot is happening in this book, which makes it as exciting as it is. I would highly recommend it.

If you enjoy romance reads, then you absolutely must read Love Out of Time, by Joyce Zeller. Not only is this a romance read, but there are also some parts of History thrown into it as well. This was very well written, with an interesting concept surrounding divorce. Divorce is extremely common in today's world, so this book is going to be relatable to a lot of people. I enjoyed the characters and the concept very well.Main character Sara Burkhart is suffering from a divorce, and decides that she needs an escape. She rents a beach house in New Kensington, which is located on the Jersey Shore. Her main goal is to re invent herself as a single woman, and find herself again. The problem is, the house is haunted by two ghosts; Thomas and Caleb. They were sea captains from 1860s. On top of that, she gets sent back in time, to 1865. The weird part about that is, the people she meets there resemble the people in her current time period. She finds herself meeting Caleb, and suddenly realizes that he's the man she was always destined to be with. The problem is, in present time, he is no longer alive. She finally realizes that in the town she's staying in, everyone is a time traveler and they get killed by Hurricanes every year. Now her main goal is to find Caleb in a time period where they are both alive at the same time.It's been awhile since I've read a romance novel this compelling and good. I highly recommend it.

Having read two prior Franklin Bean books to my classroom and loving them, I couldn't wait for Book 3 to come out. Franklin Bean and Bubbie's Bullies is just as interesting and intriguing as the first two, and once again, the kids just ate it right up. I love the illustration of these books, and the storylines are amazing. These books have a huge focus on bullying, which is so important in today's world where bullying is a major issue. What I love most is that I'm able to read these books, and then give a mini lesson on bullying and why it shouldn't be happening. It really helps to drill it into the children's minds that bullying is a bad thing. Emmy Swain has so much talent.John and Franklin Bean are back again. In this book, John is finally settled into his new home life, and has a good friend, Addie. Before a dog rescue charity event, Franklin Bean goes missing yet again. His bullying problems may be a bit different now than before, but they are still happening. This is where the superhero Pancho Frijole comes into play yet again, saving the day.I can't wait to see what new and exciting things John, Franklin Bean and Pancho Frijole have in store for us next! Great read for children.

Franklin Bean Secret of the Bay, by Emmy Swain, is Book 2 in the Franklin Bean series. Having purchased and read Book 1 not too long ago, I knew that I had to get the 2nd installment. The kids absolutely love the illustrations and storylines, and Franklin Bean is becoming a real character in my classroom. I am impressed by the lessons that are taught in these books, and I think that Emmy Swain has a real gift of engaging children while teaching them something at the same time.In Book 2, Franklin Bean is back again! John is in a new school, and being the new kid isn't easy for him. The bullies are really harassing him and Addie, his new friend. Franklin Bean keeps disappearing, and this causes John even more stress. He has to solve the mystery of where Franklin Bean is going, and why. Even though he's desperate to find out, the bullies won't stop bugging him long enough to figure it out. Pancho Frijole is the only superhero who can save the day.I love that this book focuses on bullying, because that's such a major issue for the classroom in general. Kids all of ages will appreciate it, and the illustrations are beautiful! Can't wait for Book 3 to come out.

Being an educator, I am always on the lookout for new and refreshing books to read to my students. I'm tired of the storylines always being the same, and It's been difficult finding originality these days. When I came across Meet Franklin Bean, I was instantly attracted to the cover of it. I knew the kids would like it, so I decided to purchase it and give it a chance. I was pleasantly surprised, and this book is adorably cute, with a great concept of a storyline and wonderful characters.Ten year old John and his mother move to a new city where they are a lot of financial worries and bullies hanging around. They adopt a Boston Terrier named Franklin Bean, who helps him out in more ways that one would ever imagine. Franklin Bean teaches him how to deal with bullies, but even with that skill, there are always other dangers. A real superhero is needed to tackle some of these bigger issues, and Franklin Bean may just be the one to do it.What I loved most about this book is the fact that it deals with real world issues that a lot of children are facing today. There are lessons to be learned in this one, and the kids truly get the message across without realizing that they are being taught certain lessons. Great illustrations as well, very cute! Definitely recommend.

Vengeance Always Delivers, by Geoffrey Sleight, may be my favorite book so far this summer. I was instantly drawn in to the interesting storyline and plot development taking place. I found (some) of this book to be extremely relatable, and thoroughly enjoyed the main character of Steve. As I do agree that the delivery was a bit too fast paced, I found the story so interesting that it didn't really make much of a difference to me. The writing was excellent, and the dialogues were realistic.Steve Holland is an average man who just happens to have terrible luck in his life. His wife left him, his company went under, and his financial state is not looking good at all. Steve is never happy with anything in his life, and is convinced that most other people have it much better than he does. He pretty much gives up on this changing anytime soon, until fortune hits him. He meets a stranger randomly, who offers to help him change his luck around. Steve's life is suddenly turned right away, when he's given fortune that he never dreamed that he would have. However, what Steve doesn't know is, he will have a price to pay and it will be a hefty one. Revenge is approaching him, far worse than he would of ever possibly imagined. I don't want to give too much away, but I will just say that It's an extremely compelling read.Five stars for originality and interesting storyline. Can't wait to see what else Sleight will have to offer.

I was in the mood for a good mystery/thriller type novel, and came across The Lies that Bind. It is Book 1 in the Allison Taylor series, and it definitely started out strong. Jeanne Lamb-Carlin has a lot of talent, and it shows through with this one. Interesting storyline that just sucked me right in from the beginning, and didn't let me go until the end. I can't wait for Book 2 to come out.Main character Allison Taylor suffers through a pretty terrible divorce, and change is needed in her life. She takes her daughter Melanie, and they move away together to the town that she spent summers in as a child. While there, she is reunited not only with her old friends, but also with her surrogate mother, Frannie. Another twist happens when she finally meets up with a long lost love who she hasn't seen in over 12 years (who also happens to be a cop). She believes that she's finally on the path to rebuilding her life, when suddenly a murder occurs in the town. Many secrets are let out, and Allison is once again at a loss of who to trust, and what decisions to make in her life.All of the relationships that were displayed in this book were extremely realistic, and all tied into each other nicely. Especially the relationship between the three friends. Many people can relate to the character of Allison Taylor, which is probably why I enjoyed this one so much. Would highly recommend, and I can't wait for Book 2 to come out.

The Dazzling Darkness, by Paula Cappa, definitely did It's job in dazzling me. This is a unique twist on a pretty common story; a little boy gets lost on his way home from school. The biggest question is, where is he, and can they get him back, safe and sound? A definite nail biter almost from the beginning, and kept me hooked until the very end. Excellent storyline and plot, great characters, and a lot of emotion.When two parents lose their son, Henry, they have no idea where to even begin looking. It's every parents nightmare. They are sure he's been kidnapped, but there is way more to it than that. Henry has somehow gotten behind the locked gates of the cemetery, and Elias Hatch is protecting the secret power that's buried inside. Detective Mike Balducci comes to the rescue, and discovers the crystal sculpture buried inside Old Willow. Secrets will come to light, and It's up to Mike to figure out what it all means.A kidnapping mystery novel with a twist, who wouldn't love that? I give this book five stars for excellent plot and intriguing storyline that kept me engrossed from start to finish. Highly recommend.

Before I start out my review, I just want to say how impressed I am with Donald D. Allan. His writing style blew me away. His attention to detail, engaging plot, and interesting character development really had me hooked on this one. DUILLEOG is the first book in this series, and I have no doubt that there will be many more books to follow after this one. I was drawn into this from the very beginning pages, and simply couldn't believe how well Allan did on this particular subject matter.Not much is known about the ancient druids; there wasn't much left behind about them during that time period, and most people just speculate what they were all about. Because of those reasons, many people don't bring them up, or they are forgotten about completely. When I saw that the druids was the topic of this book, I was immediately intrigued because It's not a subject matter you see done every day.This particular novel is about a man named Will Arbor, who is the last of the druids. Once he realizes that he has certain healing powers, he goes on a journey in order to find himself. A lot is going on during his journey, and the action packed feel you get from it keeps you wanting more. There is conflict with the Church of the New Order, who desires to destroy the last of the druids. They also want to remove the Lord Protector, and regain control over the people of the Realm. Will Arbor is there for all of this, witnessing the greed happening all around him. His main goal is to change the world, and he will stop at nothing to make this happen.Definite must read. It's a story that is a bit out of the box, but will definitely keep you entertained. Can't wait for the next one.

I thoroughly enjoyed Looking Glass Killer, by Floyd Merrell. I believe that you need to have a certain type of mind frame in order to enjoy this one, and truly appreciate the storyline. I found it to be intense at times, along with fast paced and somewhat original. The writing was excellent, so much so that I was glued to it from beginning to end pretty much. There is a mix of suspense/mystery/thrill all in one, something that I personally can appreciate.There is a dangerous serial killer on the loose; one who likes to play all sorts of games; word games, puzzles, rhymes. At each murder scene, this killer leaves a note behind with a new puzzle attached to it. Detectives Lucia Viera and Mike Ramsey are the ones in charge of solving these crimes and bringing the killer to justice, but they are constantly being toyed with and it makes their job that much harder. On top of it all, someone in the force is leaking information to the press. The only way Mike and Lucia can solve this case is by putting their thinking caps on, and going back to the Lewis Carroll novel, "Through the Looking Glass", for clues. I absolutely loved the incorporation of that.Excellent read overall, one that I thoroughly enjoyed. Floyd Merrell has an abundance amount of talent, and I can't wait to see what he comes up with next.

Jessika Klide did an excellent job with UNSTOPPABLE; which is Book 2 in the series. I was able to really feel the unbelievable chemistry between Siri and Aurelius throughout the novel. There are so many explicit sex scenes involved in this book, which really helped to spice it up quite a bit. But there is more than just sex involved; there is also love and deep feelings. The two of them fall hard for each other, and can't seem to keep their hands off one another, either. The only real issue is, Aurelius has some pretty deep, dark secrets, and if they stand a chance at being together, these secrets need to be known and accepted by Siri. She had plenty of secrets of her own, but they got through it and they'll now have to get through his. It's not an easy road, but love isn't always easy. Can't wait for Book 3.

What do you do when you finally meet the man of your dreams, but he's already attached to someone else? That's exactly what happened to Lacey, after walking away from a destructive relationship and moving to a whole new town on her own. She knows no one, until she meets Ben. Ben is a successful lawyer, who is extremely good looking and has a lot to offer. He befriends Lacey instantly, and they hit it off right away. But he's about to be engaged, which means that the two of them can ever only be friends. As the story develops, the reader can't help but to root for them to finally get together. Their chemistry is off the charts, which is obvious. Ben is torn, between right and wrong. I can't wait for Book 2 to come out, I really enjoyed Book 1 so much. Great job for a debut novel.

I just finished reading this collection, and I am so impressed that I felt compelled to write a review. NR Bates is an excellent author, who truly knows how to draw readers in and not let go until they reach the last page. The Fall of Icarus contains three short stories; each one with a different premise, all equally as enjoyable as the next. What I love most is how each of these stories are set up; you know what to expect but at the same time, you really have no idea. There are no "real" endings to any of these stories, but I feel as if that was done on purpose, in order to evoke some thought into the reader. You kind of have to use your imagination with these, as to what you think may happen next. That's something that I found so enjoyable about these stories. Can't wait to see what NR Bates has in store for us next.

A fun mystery novel with delicious recipes included? Who wouldn't enjoy that? I really couldn't put The Heir to Villa Buschi down. This particular book is part of a series, and after reading this one, I am definitely going to go on the search for the others. It was fun, fast paced, and action packed as well.Lily Bilbury has a lot going on in her life. Not only is her current boy off filming a movie in the jungles, but she also has to deal with raising her kids, getting divorced, and now solving a mystery in Villa Buschi. When the ex-owner died, he leaves behind a ton of mysteries that Lily has no choice but to solve. She enlists the help of her friends Rupa Brunetti and Francesca di Campo, who all come together to solve the mysteries. A lot of lessons are to be learned by Lily in this one, all of which I found to be extremely enlightening.Five stars to this novel, I loved every second of it.

A Science Fiction novel mixed in with environmental issues? I was instantly sold as soon as I read this description. Brilliant writing, great character descriptions, and excellent imagery is portrayed in A Benwarian Fix, by L.W. Samuelson. This is a story about a different species from a different planet, wanting to help and protect planet Earth from suffering the same faith as their own planet did. I loved it, and found it to be an extremely interesting concept.Once their planet has gotten destroyed, the Benwarians get on their spaceship and begin searching for a new place to call home. Once they find earth, they quickly figure out that It's in the same kind of shape as where they once came from. They decide that earth is worth saving, and will do everything in their power to make this happen; including decreasing the human population. The leader of the pact is more humanized, and does feel extremely emotional and guilty about this, especially after meeting with three scientists from earth. The question being posed in this book is, will human population be wiped out completely, or will the Benwarian leader figure out another plan to save earth?I deeply enjoyed this one, and would highly recommend it to any Sci Fi fan.

If you are a fan of science fiction novels, than you will definitely enjoy Exile. This book is filled with action, drama and suspense that will keep you on the edge of your seat. I have read the first two and enjoyed them a lot, so I had to purchase this one as well. I finished it within two days, so you know that it had to be good.The two main characters in this book are Guy Erma and Teodor, both with something in common. One is trying to return home, while the other is trying to run away. When their paths cross, they form a bond unlike any other. However, bonds and trust can both be broken just as easily as they begun. They are in for a wild run with one another.The target audience for these books is Young Adult, but even as an adult I enjoyed it just as much. Sometimes YA novels are even more fun for adults than those written specifically for adults. The authors imagination just blew my mind, which is not the easiest task in the world. Very well written, great character development/description, and good storyline. Don't miss out on these.

EPIPHANY - The Silvering, by Sonya Deanna Terry, is the second story in this series. Having read the first one and thoroughly enjoying it, I just had to pick up this one as soon as I saw it was released. I absolutely ADORE this author and her writing style, so I knew I wouldn't be disappointed by this one and I wasn't.The first book in this series is mostly mystery/fantasy based. It is about a tarot card reader who is also reading a story from the 1770s. Both stories collide, which I found absolutely fascinating because I never saw this happen before. There was a certain cliff hanger in that one, which the author picked right up in this one.Terry did a wonderful job tying up all the loose ends in this one. The great writing style/mystery/fantasy was more present than ever in EPIPHANY - The Silvering, and I actually enjoyed this one better than the first. I love the characters involved in this book; they came alive and had a certain flare to them. There is so much positivity in this novel, you can't help but to feel good.I would highly recommend this one - It's a worthwhile read and a GREAT conclusion to the first.

I wasnt really sure what to expect when I read, "The Butterfly Room", by Saurav Dutt. I read the book description and was extremely intrigued by it, so I decided to give it a chance. Im happy that I did, as Its written well and the storyline is so intense I was drawn in from the very beginning. Its a sad story and definitely does not contain a happy ending, but thats what makes it so realistic I believe.This story revolves around a family. Rohan, husband and father, is not the greatest person in the world. His wife and children all fear him, for good reasons. Lakshmi is Rohans wife and also the mother of his children. Her main goal is to keep her children safe from him, and acts as a buffer on many occasions. Her storyline is extremely sad; she is abused by her husband, and attends a support group to help her with her grief. Her biggest fear is that her children will head down the same path as shes in, and thats the last thing she wants to happen.Her son, Vikram, is set for an arranged marriage. Anita is the oldest daughter, and in an abusive relationship herself. She is forced to stay in this marriage, due to the fact that she has a child. Sunita is the youngest daughter, and Lakshmis favorite in my opinion. Both Sunita and Lakshmi do not want her heading down that path, and will do anything to avoid that from happening.This book is extremely realistic, as these situations do happen often in real life, unfortunately. I thoroughly enjoyed it, even though some parts of it were depressing. I was sucked in and reminded that life is not all peaches and creams as some people would like to pretend that it is. Highly recommend this one, Its worth the read.

Author John Anthony Miller has created an action packed novel entitled, "To Parts Unknown". I knew that this was going to be an exciting read from the beginning; Miller has a way of sucking the reader in and not letting go until the very end. This is unlike any novel that Ive read so far this year, making this one of my top favorites so far.Main character George Adams has a lot going wrong in his life. He is a journalist from England, who lost his wife and gets rejected from all the branches of the military. He goes to Singapore to cover what is happening there in terms of the war threats from Japan. While there, he meets Lady Jane Carrington, who is an English aristocrat from India, along with Thomas Montclair, who is a French spy. When Japan starts to invade, the three of them must escape from Singapore in order to stay safe. All three characters have their own back stories and own reasons for wanting to escape, which I thoroughly enjoyed. The storyline between George and Jane definitely had me hooked.Being a teacher, I always enjoy reading a good Historical Fiction War Story, and this one did not disappoint. The author has a very unique writing style, and the storyline flows very nicely. I would highly recommend this one, as Its a worthwhile read that will keep you hooked. Five stars all the way.

Monday, Sunday, by Fenton Grace, is a book that I wasnt able to put down. The plot itself is a bit disturbing, but something about it just sucked me in. The authors writing style is unique, and Its obvious that she posseses a great amount of talent. The story had a nice flow to it, and I was pretty intrigued.Main character Laney is a beautiful 32 year old woman who just loss her husband. Being a single mom is not an easy task by any means, and she isnt handling it well. She blames herself for his death, and doesnt quite know how to cope with it. Almost out of nowhere, she meets 16 year old Christopher, who changes her life. He pursues her hard, and even though she knows Its wrong, her temptation overpowers her.Eventually, she succeeds at pushing his away and decides to date his father instead, who is more age appropropriate. As much as she wants to feel that connection, she just doesnt.Even though this book borders unconventional ideas, Its interesitng to see what grief can truly do to a person. We get to see Laneys struggle between right and wrong, and how the choices she makes can have real consequences.Overall, this was an excellent read that I found to be intriguing. Five stars all the way, would definitely recommend it.

I am a huge fan of historical Paranormal fiction novels, but feel as if a lot of authors just dont fully get the concept. C. C. Spivey hit the nail right on the head with, "Reborn". This book has so many different elements to it, Its hard to exactly describe how I felt after reading it - aside from blown away.Reborn has a little of everything in it - from extreme horror (I admit I was frightened at times), to romance, to erotica and suspense. Main character Mayan was born into a difficult life of slavery. Unlike other African Americans, Mayan is fair skilled with beautiful bright eyes. Soon enough, Tytarion finds Mayan hiding under a rock and immediately takes her under his wing. His main goal is to bring her into immortality, and have his vampire baby. It gets a little sick and twisted at times, but thats what I enjoyed most of time.The writing for these characters, along with the dark storyline, makes this a must read. I have not enjoyed a paranormal novel like this in quite some time, and it definitely surpasses the more popular ones on the market today. I highly recommend this one to any fan of this specific genre.

The Bed, by Nikos Vlachos, truly pulled at my heart strings and reminded me that relationships arent always easy. The story of Joe and Sara is not only well written, but extremely relatable as well. I was hooked from beginning to end, not wanting to put this one down for even a second.The story starts out in 1983 in Chicago. Joe was a struggling artist, while Sara was a nurse. They meet each other and fall instantly in love, and end up getting married. Soon enough, however, they find out that marriage isnt as easy as they might of thought it would be. They face challenge after challenge with one another, but Its the strength of their love that keeps them fighting to hold on to one another.The love between Sara and Joe reminded me of one thing; marriage, or relationships in general, are not easy. However, it doesnt mean we give up. Instead, we must work through with each other to come out stronger on the other side. Author Nikos Vlachos does an excellent job at portraying this message, and has really written an inspirational and heart warming story.Five stars all the way! This is truly a book that everyone should read.

This set is awesome, because the chairs rock! You really can't get any better than that. It's so comforting to be able to sit outdoors and rock yourself back and forth. This set is also weather resistant, which makes it even better. It's classy looking and definitely unlike what most people have in their outdoor spaces. I can sit in these chairs for hours on end without ever getting uncomfortable. I recommend to everyone.

First of all, the beige color of this set is perfect, especially since It's an outdoor set. The color is UV protected, so I don't have to worry about it losing It's essence after awhile. The chairs themselves are comfortable to sit on. There are seat cushions as well, which the photos don't show but they are soft. Sturdy set, glad I bought it.

This poolside lounge chair is pretty simple, yet super convenient to have. I have other lounge chairs but they have cushions, and who wants to sit on a cushion when you're all wet? This chair is perfect for after swimming, when you want to dry off. I also lay in it to tan, and It's great for that purpose as well. I'm happy with it.

After seeing a similar chair as this as my sister in laws house, I just had to have one of my room for my backyard. I found this one, and really liked it. I wasn't sure it would be the same, but bought it anyway. I'm pleased to say that It's even NICER than hers. It's also softer, and way more comfortable in my opinion. The back changes position as well, which is such a nice touch. I'm going to be sitting outdoors all summer long on my lounge chair!

I fell in love with this set as soon as I saw it, but my fiance really didn't like it when looking at the pictures. There was just something about it that bothered him. Luckily I won that fight, and we purchased it. He was pleasantly surprised when it arrived, because It's 10x nicer in person than in the picture. The wicker is perfect for an outdoor set, and the table is a nice little touch to it. Glad that I won!

This is one of the last pieces I needed to complete my sons bedroom. I didn't think it was that necessary to have, but once putting it in the room, I see that it is. It's a small piece, but makes a big impact. My son stores a lot of his school books in it, papers in the drawer, and pens/markers on top of it with a little lamp. Really convenient to have, and now officially makes his bedroom perfect!

I recently got a bed set that is the exact same color as this dresser, so It's perfect. I put it next to my window and it doesn't take up much space at all. I love that on the top of it I was able to put my little figurine that had nowhere else to go for so long. The drawers are pretty big, and allow me to finally organize myself. I am pleased.

First of all, the Cappuccino finish of this drawer dresser is breathtaking; I couldn't be any happier. My room has been cluttered with clothing for the past year or so now; my closets definitely aren't big enough. With this dresser, I'm finally able to take some stuff out of my closets and organize it neatly into this. I'm so amazed that I can actually find things again. Don't hesitate, this one is a must have buy if you're looking for a dresser.

I'm simply in love with the contemporary style of this nightstand. I've always been against getting one because I thought it takes up too much space, but this one is perfect because It's small. The Cappuccino finish is breath taking. Assembly only takes a little while as well, since there isn't too much to put together. Affordable price, and super fast shipping!

This canopy bed makes my bedroom look extremely classy and elegant! The metal frame construction of it is extremely sturdy, so I know It's going to last for a long time. My fiance loves it as well and he's usually extremely picky about these things, so It's a win/win for the both of us. All it needs is a queen mattress, so no need for a box spring (I hate those). I'm so glad that I picked this one.

I literally turn this app on every single day! I wouldn't be able to start my mornings or end my nights without it. I love the fact that you can change the music selection on it; also, the picture is high resolution which is the ultimate plus. I put the sleep timer feature on it every night so that it doesn't stay on, and that works out excellent as well. Five stars all the way for this one.

My Fiance and I are currently in the process of looking for our own home together. It's my first time buying a house, and obviously I've been a little concerned about not doing it correctly. I have been doing google research on what to avoid/red flags to look out for, and I came across this book by Thomas K. Lutz on Amazon. The Smart First-Time Home Buyer's Guide was affordable, so I decided I had nothing to lose by going ahead and purchasing it. I'm so glad I did! It's filled with a wealth of well written research on how to go about buying your first home. There are so many mistakes that first time home buyer's make, and this book helps you to avoid those. I'm pleased that I am well informed and well educated, thanks to this book, so that me and my Fiance don't make these mistakes. I have sent it to him as well and he's currently in the process of reading it, and so far he's appreciating it equally as much. Five stars all the way, excellent read.

Such a good idea. Works very well on my Mercedes C-class.Normally after about 2-3 weeks on not driving my car, the battery flattens. Now it's kept trickle charged all day. As the instructions say, do not drive with it connected!

Fifteen short years after he became Lakewood Church’s senior minister, Joel Osteen had become the embodiment and achieved the fulfillment of his own message—positive thinking, self-encouragement, and belief that God’s consequential blessings inevitably bring progress and advancement—the story of salvation with a smile, according to Phillip Sinitiere in this book.The book starts with the story of John Osteen’s background, his transition from Southern Baptist into neopentecostalism, and his philosophy of ministry at Lakewood. It then goes on to describe how Joel stepped into the senior pastor position upon his father’s death in 1999, and his own distinctive philosophy of ministry.Based on analysis of Joel’s sermons, the author says that Joel’s prosperity gospel has four parts: positive thinking, positive confession, positive providence, and the promotion of the Christian body as a site of improvement. It seems to me that there are parts of the Bible which can be used to support each of those themes, but those themes are not an accurate representation of the message of the Bible.The author did not have access to Joel Osteen or other key people while writing the book, and as a result the book often feels like an academic analysis of writings and sermons rather than a lively personal story. Nonetheless, it does provide some interesting insights into the senior pastor of the largest church in North America.

Faced with the emergence and speed of growth in the information economy, organizations have an urgent need to adopt IT governance best practice, according to Alan Calder and Steve Watkins in this book.
