This hat is one size fits all, I have a smaller head with short hair and it fits great.  I like that there is already a nice curve to the brim.  Often I have to work on curving the brim myself with some hats.  It seems constructed well and the stitching appears well done.  And it had all of the appropriate NFL hologram stickers so you can tell it is genuine.  The clasp, is a buckle type and there is a slot to tuck in the extra strap left over.  I got this on sale and am very happy with it for the price I got it at.  I'll include some pics for you as well!

I'm extremely impressed with this case.  It is so well made compared to some of the ones out there.  I like how there is a cutout for the logo.  Between the logo cutout and the multi-color aspect this case actually looks like it is the phone. Very classy looking, even the side button bumpout for the button is a different color which continues to make it look like an actual phone instead of a case.  I couldn't be happier with this case.  I did receive a complimentary sample of this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.  But, don't let that deter you, this is a very nice case and I would let you know if it wasn't.  As a bonus it also comes with a screen protector.  I have included a few extra pics for you as well.

As soon as these were delivered the dogs knew this box must be for them.  There was a lot of anticipation on their part as they could smell them!  I tried to take some photos, they may be a bit blurry as the dogs were quite frantic and moving pretty fast.  The manufacturer says these are very wholesome snacks and I would say they are right.  They appeared well made, and clearly the dogs loved them.  One of our dogs is very picky, there are many treats she will turn her nose to and walk away from without touching them.  She actually looks offended in those situations when I offer them to her.  Makes me wonder what she knows that I don't know about those treats.  But, we didn't have problems at all with these.  As you can see, both dogs give a glowing review even the picky dog!  I was given a sample of the product for a fair and honest review, but the dogs didn't know that and they clearly loved them!

This is a nice case for the money.  What I really like about it is how it protects so much of the phone.  It feels like your phone is very protected with this case on your phone. It includes all of the pieces you need to put this together with the screen protector so you really are protected.  The only negative is that your home button is buried in there a bit, but that is an issue with most of these type of cases.  One major benefit to this case is that it is quite thin compared to some other cases.  My sister has a really heavy duty one for her iPhone, but it is so huge it looks like she is carrying a brick around.  This seems like a much more reasonable balance between phone safety and usability.  I was given this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.  I see no issues or problems with the one I was sent.  I have attached a few additional pics for you as well.It also comes with instructions that includes photos which is very nice.  It also says in the manual that it comes with a Lifetime Defect Warranty.

This my first bluetooth speaker, and so far I am very impressed.  I didn't know if it would be hard to pair, but it was incredibly easy in fact I didn't even need to read the included instructions.  I simply charged it up for several hours to be safe.  Then I turned it on and the bluetooth light was blinking.  I figured that meant it was in pairing mode.  I simply went into my Android phone settings for the bluetooth and scanned for new devices.  It showed up almost immediately, I clicked the button in my phone settings to connect, and the speaker played audio that said "Connected".  Couldn't have been any easier!It also comes with an audio cord so you can plug devices in manually, but I didn't test that as I only plan to use this as an bluetooth speaker not as a wired one.The sound is really good for such a small speaker.  It of course does not have booming bass, but the sound is much better than I expected and is quite rich sounding. It also can crank pretty loud for its size.  Currently I have it playing in a different room from which I am writing this review, and I can hear it great even though I do not have the volume turned up all of the way.  I can use this and hear it throughout our single story 1400 foot house without issue.In terms of the bluetooth signal strength this is really good.  I put the speaker in the center of the house and took my phone to the far corners of the house and it still kept playing the music.The case is made very well and doesn't feel cheap at all to me. All in all I am quite pleased with this speaker!This product was given to me in exchange for a fair and honest review.  I have included some extra pics for you to check out.

I am really happy with the quality of this.  It fit in our 2010 Chevy Cobalt just fine since it has wide vents.  But, at first I couldn't get it to work because there are back left and right adjustable vents as well as the front up and down ones.  I had to adjust the back left and right ones to be centered so I could pop it in.  After I figured that out it fit great.  If you have round, or really small vents you might have issues.I'm impressed with how it is made.  It didn't feel cheap at all and held the wife's iphone 5s without issue.  But, it would also fit much bigger phones as there was much more play in the adjustment left.This unit is well made and if it fits your type of vent I highly recommend it.  I was given a sample of this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.I have attached some photos as well.

I was skeptical that this long cable would work properly and it did.  I measured the cable and it may have been a few inches short of 10ft but it was hard to tell because I couldn't pull it completely tight and measure it at the same time.  Either way it is at least very close to 10 ft, if not 10 ft.  And, the good news is that it actually works.  I tested it on the wife's Iphone 5s and it not only charged the phone properly without errors, but it also worked great for transferring her photos off of the phone.  There isn't much else to say except it is a nice long cable that actually works at a fraction of a cost compared to the name brand cable.I was given this product in exchange for a fair and partial review.

Having only used the smooth loop type wrenches I really like this type of tool instead.  It is easier to get a better grip I think on the filter.  Of course you do have to be careful to not press too much on the handles as you could dent, or tear the metal as you remove the old filter.  Normally that isn't a problem as it is the old one, but if you tear the metal too much it may be hard to remove.  If you use this with the correct amount of force it works great.  I like that it is adjustable with three different adjustments.  I have the 12 inch one which works great on my cobalt and cruiser.  If you have a large truck you may need the larger size.

These stickers appear to be made well and stick great to the windshield without any residue.  I expect they will hold up well with time.  It seems like a fair price for what you get especially with the prime shipping availability.  I would purchase these again.

I really wanted to like this because of it's extremely small size.  First off keep in mind if you get the 2500mAh like I have it will add some juice to your phone battery but likely won't be able to charge it completely to 100%.This system does work on my android phone and the wife's iphone(using the adapter).  My unit came with no directions and it isn't super obvious how it works out of the box.  The cable for charging the unit is pretty obvious at least.  I simply pressed the tabs on each side and pulled on the loop which pulled out the two cable ends to charge the unit.What I found more confusing was how to charge a phone without any instructions in the box.  I finally figured out to pull the blue cable out which at first I thought was just for decorations.  But, then I didn't know that the white part inside the unit was the adapter for lightning iphones.  It looked like it was part of the unit since it wouldn't move and was flush.  I had to read other reviews here on amazon to determine that adapter needed to come out.  But, mine was completely stuck inside of the unit.  I couldn't get it out.  Finally I had to use a small screw driver and pop the casing loose so the adapter would slide out.  I popped the case back together and tried putting the adapter back in/out and it got stuck again.So, the unit does work, but the case/adapter holder portion of it needs some work.  I have had to keep the adapter out of the unit so it doesn't get stuck in there again, but that probably means it will get lost.I was given this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.

The graphic is really nice looking and does appear like marble.  It is a very shiny of a finish which should be good for keeping it clean.  The design is very minimalist and thin yet it seems to fit fine.  All in all I have no issues with this case.  I have included some pics for you to check out as well.I was given this product to review for a fair and honest opinion.

These are great cable management sleeves. I had only used velcro ties in the past which still showed a lot of unsightly cable.  This however is great, as it hides the cables much more thoroughly.  There is enough room inside of the sleeve to bundle up a very reasonable amount of cables.  Plus the Neoprene stretches a bit so you can really fill it up.  The stitching seems well done and the zippers work great.  Overall I am very happy with the quality.  I will include pictures of the product next to a measuring tape so you can verify the size of the product.I was given a sample of this product for an honest review.

It is so handy to have a longer cable.  But I often don't trust the longer ones as I have had some bad experiences in the past with longer ones.  So, I immediately tested this and not only did it charge the phone, but it also was able to transfer data without any issues.  So, I'm quite happy with this.  As you can see from my measurement with the tape measure (see pic) my cable actually seemed to be a few inches longer than 6 feet.  All and all this is a great cable and I verified that it works properly on our phone.I was given this cable to give an honest review of the product.

I'm impressed with the quality of the these straps as well as how extremely adjustable they are.  The straps are much longer than I had envisioned when I ordered them.  The included Carabiners are heavy duty and sturdy.  I also love that it comes with a bag and drawstring.  Everything fits nicely in the bag which will be really nice for camping.  In the past when camping it was rare that I could find trees that were the right distance apart for our hammock.  However with these straps there is so much adjustment that it will be much more likely we can use our hammock now.  I also like that these straps are gentle on the trees.I was given a pair of these straps for a fair and honest review.

I'm pretty happy with this lense kit so far. I've never had one before so this is my first and I can't compare it to other kits out there. I'll include some pics, but keep in mind I'm using a phone model which is notorious for having a terrible camera. So, don't judge the kit to harshly because of my phone camera.I had a little trouble figuring out how to remove the wide ange/macro lenses which is a two unit setup. I thought they were supposed to pull apart, but that didn't work. Then I realized they screw on, so I simply did "lefty loosy" then they came apart no problem. I removed my case and the various lenses clip on quite nicely.The pictures of my back yard without the bench are the fisheye vs non fisheye. I didn't have the lense centered quite right so there are some dark corners in the top. Also, my phone didn't autofocus well so it was a bit out of focus for that shot. Not a problem with the lense though, as my autofocus is terrible.The pictures of the yard with the bench are wide angle vs no wide angle.But, the one that really stood out to me was the Macro lense! I didn't hold out any hope with my bad phone camera. But, check out the flower, these are very small flowers but you wouldn't know it from the pic! You can see the drops of dew on it and everything. This would not have been possible at all without the macro lense. My camera is terrible about taking close up shots of things, this lense will be a life saver for that!Anyhow, here are the pics for you to check out.

The leash is well made.  The clasp is strong, the material feels strong as well.  The main handle is padded and very comfortable.  The second handle is not padded but that is good so it isn't too bulky/heavy down there when the lower handle is not in use.  Let me get to the nitty gritty as to why this is way better than my other two handle leash.  We have another two handle leash, but the lower second handle comes out much further from the leash on our other leash.  Which means that when you aren't using that second handle the dog often trips on it since we use a front harness.  However, with this leash it is sewed up much tighter to the main leash, so when you aren't using it the handle pretty much just becomes part of the leash with no danger of the dog tripping.One problem with all of these two handle leashes though is that if you use it with a front harness, the handle will be pretty low and more difficult to grab.  It would be cool is someone would make one someday specifically designed for front harnesses that is further up the leash.  But, that is not an issue for most people as most people use collars or standard harnesses.  We only use front harnesses because our local humane society has a very strong opinion that the front harnesses are by far the best for controlling the dog without causing them discomfort.Anyhow, even if you have a standard harness this is the best two handle leash because you don't want the second lower handle flopping around.  I'm quite happy with this leash.I have included some pics as well.

I'm quite happy with this.  It gets around 5 hours of run time when your power is interrupted.  The instructions didn't seem to explain the switch very well though.  If you don't have the switch set right it won't work as an emergency light.  So, make sure to check the switch!!Here is what I learned by playing around with the switch which has three settings.  If it is in the middle setting and you interrupt power it will not come on, that seems to be charge only option and will produce no light.  My unit came in the box set to the middle setting, this is probably necessary so the unit won't run in the box and wear down the battery.  The switch has to be set to the top or bottom setting to function as an emergency light.  One is a low light feature even when it has power, the other is no light when it has power, but both will turn on when you interrupt power.I have mine set in a darker room to always illuminate a small amount of light, then if the power is interrupted it will automatically turn on full brightness.  It works great!To test yours you do not need to flip a breaker switch, simply unplug it from the outlet to interrupt the power.I have included some pics for you to check it out further.

I got this on sale so it was a great deal at the time.  This hoodie is well made and fits as expected.  It does have a large pocket in the front which is great.  I like the thickness of the fabric.  It isn't an overly thick kind that will make you too hot, but it doesn't feel to thin. I would call it a medium thickness which is exactly what I was looking for!  I can recommend this hoodie, especially if you can get it on sale like I did!

I got this to oil the foam filter for my new Yamaha generator.  But, keep in mind it will work with any foam filter that needs oiling not just Yamaha's.  I was impressed with the oil, it was a thin enough consistency that it was quite easy to oil the filter.  I removed the filter from the generator first then I just dribbled some on the filter.  It is then thin enough to penetrate immediately down into the filter.  Then I simply patted out the excess oil with a clean paper towel.  The Yamaha manual warns not wring the filter as it may tear.  It has a bluish/purplish color which makes it easier to see where you have put it depending on the color of your filter.  But, it was also nice when patting with a white paper towel because I could easily see how much I was getting out.  I poked a small hole in the foil cover opening so I didn't have to worry about accidentally pouring more than I meant.For some reason the bottle I was sent did not have a lid and it was no where in the box.  But, I think that was a fluke and a problem with the shipper not the product itself.  Luckily the foil safety cover kept it from leaking.  I simply store it with a plastic bag over it secured by a rubber band.I will attach some pics as well.

After doing some research I definitely wanted a dual sensor smoke alarm which this is.  My understanding is that it is more likely to catch different types of fires like open flame vs slow smoldering.  We bought an older house that only had one alarm.  I decided that wasn't good enough in case that one ever failed we would be in trouble if we ever had a fire.  So, I got three of these to add to the house.  Installation and battery insertion is very easy.  The other question is... do they work?  Yes, they do... we were cooking in the oven and food bubbled out onto the oven elements causing smoke.  They did there job and went off.  But, once I took them outside they immediately stopped beeping.  So, they definitely work!

This tablet does not come with a charger, but does include a USB cable for charging from the USB port on your computer or you can of course plug it into any USB charger for other devices.  I used my phone USB charger without any issues.Form Factor: It is similar in shape to my Nexus 7  tablet with the main difference being thickness and weight.  This being a budget tablet is a bit thicker and heavier than the more expensive tablets.  But it isn’t overly thick, so for the price I don’t think the thickness is an issue for most people.Internal Storage: I have the 16Gb Tablet, and out of the box with no new apps installed yet I have 12.32 GB of space available to use.  I will post this review for both the 8gb and the 16gb tablet as the internals are identical except for the amount of storage.  I assume the 8 gb tablet would have around 4.32gb f space available to use.  For the minor difference in price I would recommend the 16gb tablet instead of the 8gb one.External Storage: It has a Micro SD card slot, I put my Lexar 32GB card in the slot and was able to access all of my files without any problems.Sound  The External speaker is one single small speaker in the back.  Sound is very hard to make out if listening to music or videos through the external speaker.  It is better to use headphones or earbuds.Sound: With my Earbuds connected the sound was pretty good and was quite usable.  It has a standard 3.5mm headphone port.Display: Small text was definitely grainy, and at times it looked a bit washed out.  But surprisingly watching youtube videos on it actually looked pretty good.  It’s not comparable to a high end flagship tablet of course, but it is very reasonable for the price.  You do have to look at it pretty straight on, it can be hard to see the screen from an angle.Touchscreen:  The touch screen can be a bit erratic.  In fact I thought there was a problem with the wifi card when I setup the tablet because it wouldn’t connect to my wifi.  But, then I checked “show password” and I saw that strange characters were being added when I would type in the password.  It took many attempts before I could get the password right.  Interestingly enough after the setup was done, it seems that the touchscreen is less finicky and is working a bit better.  But, I still don’t think it is perfect at always registering touches properly.  It is however usable(just slow down when typing), and of course you can always attach the external keyboard as well.Processor/Speed: I watched several youtube videos without any stuttering.  It was very fluid with no problems.  If I started doing lots of multitasking it would slow down, like if I was downloading apps then tried to do something else at the same time.  But, even my Nexus 7 slows down a little with multitasking so that is to be expected.  I tested a few basic games and here is what I found: I installed Brickies a simple arcade game for knocking out bricks (Kind of like Breakout back in the day).  It was a little slow to load but once the game loaded it ran pretty well.  I also tested Angry Birds 1,  It played well without stuttering or excessive heat.WIFI: I couldn’t access my 5ghz wireless network, but could access my 2.4ghz network without any issues. In terms of speed, I just ran a test from speedtest.net and got 39.78mbps download and 12.93 upload with this tablet.  I then ran the same test on my Nexus 7 Android tablet and got 81.30mbps download and 12.67mbps upload.  But, it isn’t a fair fight since this tablet can’t see a faster 5ghz wifi access point like my Nexus tablet can.  So, all in all the wifi performance of this tablet is pretty good considering it doesn’t support 5ghz networks.Battery:  The battery was better than I expected for a budget tablet.  I was watching youtube and playing games.  It took about 1 hour and 15 minutes to go from 100% battery down to 75%.  So, I would expect to get up to 5 hours of usage out of the battery.  You may get even more out of it if you aren’t using it as heavily as I was.Camera: There is a front and back camera which is nice.  The quality of the pictures is pretty grainy, but for a budget tablet that is to be expected.  The camera did however work.  The camera does not have flash.External keyboard: It is small and cramped, but it has to be to fit with a 7 inch tablet.  So, I couldn’t type with much speed.  But, the keys felt good.  It is a plug in keyboard, so unfortunately you can’t charge it and use the keyboard at the same time since they both use the same port.Case:  The case that it comes with is very well made, the materials and workmanship are very nice.Overall impression:  To be honest I didn’t have much hope for such an inexpensive budget tablet.  But, if you have a tight budget and can’t afford a high end tablet this one will definitely do the job if you have realistic expectations.  I’m actually quite amazed that for the money you get a tablet that works as well as it does, plus includes an external keyboard and a case.  It is a great option for those in the market for a budget tablet.From "About Tablet” in SettingsProcessor type: Quadcore-A33Android Version: 4.4.2Firmware Version: 2.0Kernel Version 3.4.39I checked for updates it said none were available on 9/8/15PS.  I will also upload some pictures of the device as well.

I used my phone USB charger without any issues.Form Factor: It is similar in shape to my Nexus 7  tablet with the main difference being thickness and weight. I will also upload some pictures of the device as well.From "About Tablet” in SettingsProcessor type: Quadcore-A33Android Version: 4.4.2Firmware Version: 2.0Kernel Version 3.4.39I checked for updates it said none were available on 9/8/15

I got a couple of these for my generator.  I decided it would be good to have some backups as it would be terrible to have the spark plug go out in the middle of a storm/power outage.  Gives me some cheap peace of mind!

Some generators like my Yamaha EF2000IS have a small oil tube at a strange angle.  It would be really difficult to add oil with a normal funnel. This one with the flexible tube worked great, and made a frustrating process much simpler and easier.  I spilled very little oil using this.  The main problem was I couldn't tell when it was getting full, but that isn't a problem with this funnel.  I'm very happy with this purchase.

This worked well with my wife's iphone 5s without having to make any changes to the phone settings.  The directions are a bit unclear, we weren't sure at first how to clamp the phone on.  But, you simply pull back on the end, there is a spring loaded part.  Then it snuggly held the phone in place.  I plugged in the cable to the headphone jack.  But, we couldn't get it to snap the pictures.  Then I realized it wasn't quite plugged in tight.  So, if you have the same problem make sure the cable is actually in the port all the way.I did not test this stick with an Android device, but the instructions say it will work on most android phones.  But, you have to change the settings so that the volume button can be used as a camera button for the stick to work.  So, before buying this for your android device I would recommend that you make sure your phone has that capability.  But, it sounds like it should work if your android phone has that ability.I like that it is not bluetooth, so there is no need to pair the stick with your phone or keep batteries in the stick.  It also folds down really small which is nice for carrying around.Now, keep in mind this is a budget selfie stick.  It isn't super high quality, and the telescoping seems a little flimsy, and I wish there was more angle options in the phone hinge area.  But, because it is such a reasonable price, I'm giving this 5 stars since it does function as advertised, and works at an extremely reasonable price.  So, if you are looking for a budget selfie stick, this would be a good choice.I'll also include a few pictures for you as well.

So far I am quite impressed with the Yellowknife branded cables.  I recently got their braided one as well as this one.  They both are great.  This one is very soft and pliable which is nice and makes it less likely to tangle. The connectors feel solid and well made.  I used this with an Iphone 5s and it worked well for charging as well as transferring files.  It was also packaged very nicely.  I can definitely recommend this brand of lightning cables as so far I am pleased.  I have also attached some pics as well.

I am a big fan of the braided cables.  They don't tangle as bad and seem to last longer.  I am very impressed with this Yellowknife braided cable.  It worked well on my Iphone 5s.  It charged and transferred data without issue.  The construction seems to be high quality and the ends fit well like they should.  I am very happy with this and have included a few photos for you as well.

This is just what I was looking for when hiking.  The camera bag holds way more than it looks like it should.  It has lots of pockets, and plenty of adjustable dividers, and small holders for SD cards etc.  And that it comes with a rain proof cover is just icing on the cake for an already wonderful bag.  The bag also does a good job of not getting too hot up against your body when hiking.The shoulder strap is padded and comfortable.  All of the zippers, velcro, and buckles seem to be very high quality.  I'm also impressed with the fabrics used and stitching.  This bag seems to be made of premium materials and has excellent workmanship.  I am very happy with it so far.  I have attached a few pics so you can get more of an idea of how it is made.

Just received this and tested it on our Iphone 5s, it worked great.  It charged the phone properly, and I also tested hooking it up to the laptop and transferring photos from the phone to the laptop using this cable and that worked great as well.  While only time can tell how long it will hold up over the years, it seems to be constructed well.  The connectors fit tight into the charger and the phone, they are not loose or sloppy.  It seems to be constructed very well, and I am quite happy with this cable so far.  I have uploaded a few pics of the cable and it's packaging as well.

We have two black labs that get hot on their walks. So, we have a sling that goes over our shoulders and carries a water bottle and has a pouch with a small fold-able fabric bowl. That works ok, except the fabric bowl can collapse in, plus it is too small so it is hard for them to drink from.So, instead we now use these larger non fabric collapsible bowls.  While these would work great for food or water, we plan to use them mainly for water and walks or for travel. These are the perfect size. We clip one to the leash loop with the supplied clip and it works much better for the dogs to drink from on their walks than the fabric kind. It isn't too large and bulky but large enough that a Lab can drink easily from it.They collapse easily and pop back up great as well. The material claims to be FDA and doesn't have any weird smells so I suspect that the material is high quality. We are very happy with them so far as are the dogs. I have attached some photos of the product as well.

I was given a free copy of the Kindle book in exchange for a fair an honest review.  I can tell Debra is a wonderful person and cherishes pets as I do.  So, I give this two stars for her love of pets and kind heart!I wouldn't be able to recommend paying for this book unfortunately and am knocking off stars for my findings below.  It was incredibly short, I'd say it took me about 3 minutes to read the captions and look at the pictures for the entire book.  Maybe it has something to do with the kindle version vs the paper version, but some of the pictures were very grainy and low quality in the kindle version.  Most of the pictures appeared to be taken with an amateur home camera or Iphone.I so wanted to give a 5 star review like most of the other people that were given a free copy, but can't in good conscious recommend that people pay any money for this.  It is an excellent attempt though from a wonderful lady.

I used old crimpers and cable cutter tools back in the day that were a pain to use.  I hadn't crimped coax for a few decades since then.  I bought this because I needed to rewire my newly purchased old house, but was dreading having to crimp since I used to hate doing that.  Man, things have gotten better over the years, this tool and the supplied ends were so easy to crimp.  And the tool for stripping the wire was adjusted perfectly and just worked right the first time.  I did have to buy extra ends though as this didn't come with enough.  The tester also worked great and said all of my lines were correct.  Sure enough when comcast came and hooked up my service all of the outlets in the house started working immediately without issue, so the tester was spot on.  For such a cheap price I'm very happy with this kit for the average "Do It Yourself" home owner!

This was a great price, and the cable is really good.  I bought a house that needed the cable completely re-ran and I used this to do that.  I bought a tool for crimping on the ends and ran it under the house and up the walls to new outlets.  When comcast came out to hook up the service to my house they said this cable was perfect for HD TV and Internet.  My Internet speeds are blazing fast(I have 100mbps service and get over my advertised speed), so this works good for cable tv and for cable internet.  I considered paying extra for quad shielding but this did the job just fine so I'm glad I didn't spend the extra money on quad cable plus I read somewhere that the quad is really thick and harder to run up the walls.

I really like this low profile flash drive.  It is much faster than I thought. I figured it must be pretty slow to fit it in such a small profile.  But, while I haven't bench marked it, it seems comparable in speed to my other larger USB 3 flash drives.  I also really like that even though it is so tiny it does come with a hole in it so you can attach a lanyard to put it around your neck if you want.  I liked this so much I got three when they were on sale.  I am using two in my chromebook for additional low profile storage.  And, I use the third on a lanyard around my neck at work.  I need to have my files with me and used to have a huge flash drive hanging from my neck.  But, this is barely noticeable and much lighter.I am extremely happy with this.  The only reason I knocked off one star is because it gets really hot.  If you have it in your computer for a few minutes and pull it out, it will almost burn your hand.  That said it seems reliable so far, and has not degraded from the heat, but I'm a bit worried about the long term reliability because it always runs so hot.  I still highly recommend this though as none of my three have failed yet.  I have attached some photos so you can see how it small it is, and how far it sticks out from my chromebook.

As more and more newer computers start to include the new smaller USB-C ports we need a way to adapt our old USB devices so we can still use them.  This adapter works perfect for that.  Simply plug in your old standard USB device into this adapter then you can plug it in to a computer that has the newer type C port and still use your old devices on your newer computer.  I got the blue one and the black one.  They seem to be well made.  The ports on the adapter were tight so there was no sloppiness when using this.  I used an old usb flash drive and could access it just fine with this adapter, and it seemed to perform well.  I have attached some pictures of the adapters to this review for you to check out as well.  I am quite happy with these so far.

I'm very happy with this belt.  The stitching seems strong, the belt itself feels strong yet pliable enough.  One of the things I was really impressed with is that the holes in the belt for adjustment are reinforced on the back side (see my attached pics).  This should mean the holes will be less likely to rip over the years.  I expect this belt will last many years.This is a fairly wide/fat belt.  So, it should be sturdy.  I measured the width of the belt and it is: 1 3/4 inchesI wear waist size 34 jeans right now and I purchased the belt as size 36.  However I have to use the belt on the largest setting.  I wish I had ordered a 38 belt, but it works for me.  I just have to watch what I eat is all going forward, but that isn't a bad thing!Overall this is a very nice belt for the price.

I got this on a major sale, to replace a broken name brand one.  Because it was a huge sale at the time, I'm happy enough with it.  It does the job and sharpens my knives fine.  However, it seems to have a very weak motor.  It will often stop because I guess I have applied a bit too much pressure to it and I have to pull the knife out to get the motor spinning again.  The case is very light and cheaply made as well.  But, that said.  I got this on sale for 1/6th the cost of a name brand basic model.  So, I just take my time and go slow when sharpening my knives.  I'm happy enough with it because it was dirt cheap, but the quality is definitely lower than the high end brands.

My wife has an iPhone 5. The remote worked perfectly to initiate calls or other commands through Siri and to end calls. The call quality was comparable to the Apple original manufacturer provided earbuds and they are way more comfortable than the Apple ones. The noise cancelling properties are very good and the sound quality is great for listening to music, podcasts, videos, or calls. She is short and the microphone hangs very low on her, but this does not seem to interfere with its ability to pick up her voice. The only thing lacking in these earbuds is the ability to adjust volume via the inline remote. This is not a deal breaker, as it is not too inconvenient to handle adjustments using the device. The cord is good quality and seems resistant to tangling and does not produce any audible noise interference when it rubs against clothing, as can be the case with some earbuds.When she calls me with them I can hear her just as well if not better than when she used to use the stock apple headset.  I couldn't hear excessive background noise, or wind.  The sound is much better than a Sony aftermarket headset she tried.  I could rarely hear her with that set.  But, with this set I have no problems hearing her when she is calling me with them.All in all we are both very happy with them, with the only downside being the lack of volume control... but to us that is not a deal breaker since it has such good sound and microphone capabilities plus it is very comfortable in our ears.It also came in nice packaging.  I will attach a few photos for you.

Both my wife and I tried this.  It felt nice and 'tingly' to the scalp.  It smelled to me like Tea Tree Oil and a hint of mint.  It smelled nice without being overpowering which is important.  The shampoo seemed to clean my hair nicely and the conditioner left it soft but not greasy.  The bottles that it comes in are very stylish and the pumps seem very sturdy and work well.  They were packaged well, and taped shut to reduce the chance of leakage during delivery. Over all I was very happy with the shampoo and the conditioner.My wife also tried the shampoo and conditioner and provided feedback. She has naturally curly/naturally dry hair. She was pleased with the way her hair felt afterwards; very clean, but still soft.Overall we are both very happy with this product.  I have included pictures of the bottles and pictures of the ingredients.

I like that I can fold this out of the way when I don't need it.  This lamp is very bright and is perfect for using at my desk.  It is also very adjustable so you can get the light where you need it.  It also has a great range of brightness/dimmable options, and you can select whiter/blue colors or more relaxing yellowish colors.  The usb port works great for charging devices.The lumens seems quite bright on this lamp which is great, some of the cheaper ones sound good on paper but I read reviews that said they weren't bright enough.  But, this one is plenty bright for my needs.I don't use it for a bed lamp, but if you are interested in it for that, it does have a light on the power button so you can find it at night, and it has a sleep timer which is great.This light also has 'memory' so it remembers the last brightness and color temperature you picked which is very nice.  Some of the other models do not have this feature.I am quite happy with this lamp and can recommend it with only one possible hesitation.  The top hinge seems kind of flimsy to me, so I'm not sure how long that will last.  But, I didn't knock of a star because it does function just fine and only time will tell how well it holds up.  But, so far I can't fault it.I do really enjoy how bright this light is and it has really helped my productivity as a result.  I have attached a few pictures so you can see it in action.  Two are with it turned on and at the brightest setting.  The other pic is what it looks like folded up.

Works great with my Garmin Vivofit 2.  It was easy to setup and seems accurate.  I don't like the strap quite as well as my polar soft strap, this one is a little harder to adjust the size.  But, once you have it adjusted it is comfortable.  I'm happy I got this to use with my Vivofit 2.  If you have a Vivofit 2, I'd recommend this.The main thing if you have a Vivofit 2 is to make sure you go into the software, or app and check the box to add the 'heart' function to your menu items otherwise you won't see it.  At first I missed the second check box to add it to your 'activity' menu though.  I could see my heart rate just fine, until I would start my activity then it would go away.  So, I hunted around and realized I hadn't clicked both check boxes.I did read other reviews that said they had stuck screws and couldn't change the battery.  I haven't tested that, and plan to cross that bridge when the battery runs out someday.  For now I'm happy with it and will hope my screws come out well when the time comes

This is my favorite fertilizer.  I use to fertilize all of our outdoor plants and trees.  It works great!  One warning though, don't make the mistake I did and try to use this indoors.  The house was pretty stinky for several days!  But this stuff works wonders outside!

I was very impressed with this lamp.  I was looking for a night stand light, this works well for that purpose.  It has blue LED light that is always on so at night you can find the power button.  I definitely wanted a light with multiple color temperatures and this does that.  At night I prefer the less harsh yellow light temperature.  Then I use a 'whiter' one if I want to read or something.  I also like to turn it's brightness down at night.This lamp also has memory so that it remembers your latest brightness and color temperature choice.  This was important to me as well since at night I don't want it forgetting its setting if I have to turn it on in the middle of the night.  Some of the other models I looked at would default back to a bright setting so a memory feature was very important to me for use as a bed lamp.I tested the 'timer' mode and that worked great, so the light properly shut off once the timer was up.  All you have to do is hold the power button for a few seconds to turn the timer on, the blue LED will blink to let you know the timer is on which I appreciate.The goose neck is very flexible and doesn't feel too loose.  The base is weighted so it won't fall over, and I love the rubber coating this lamp has.Really the only possible negative I see is that the plastic coating on top of the buttons seems to have a few bubbles in it, but I haven't investigated it closely yet.  It may be a protective plastic sheet for shipping that needs to be removed but like I said I haven't investigated that closely yet as it is barely noticeable.The usb port charges my phone well.  I do wish they made this with a 2a USB port for those that want to plug in a higher amperage tablet.The light quality is great and the brightness is just right for a night stand lamp as well as reading if you are close to it.  I wouldn't expect this to light the entire room well, but it will light your desk or night stand well.

This is the size I needed for my  GreenWorks 20012 9 Amp 14-Inch Corded Chainsaw, works great and keeps the chain in good working order.  It gets dull pretty fast, so I found out pretty quickly it was important to keep things sharpened!

Seems good so far, I knocked off a star because the instructions aren't very complete and are confusing.  I needed an always on outlet, and needed the switch to also control a 'load' line, but it needed to be GFCI protected too.  The instructional diagram in the printed instructions warn you that if you follow their directions the switch will not be GFCI protected(only the outlet), but that there are many other ways to wire it.  However, they don't actually give you the "many other ways" to wire it instructions.  I spent hours trying to figure out how to do it properly and was close but couldn't quite figure it out.  There were no good youtube videos for this device, so I did a standard web search and found a link to Leviton forum, with a very good diagram.  It is for a slightly different version, but the concept is still the same as long as you keep in mind which is your 'line" and which is your 'load'.  Then it is very easy to hook it up with this diagram.  Once I had this diagram it only took me about 15 minutes to complete it and everything worked.  One warning though, I hooked everything up and flipped the breaker but things didn't work.  So, I thought I wired it wrong, then a light bulb came on in my mind, duh.... I had to press the 'reset' switch, then everything started working properly.  The outlet was always on and the line I wired to the switch was GFCI protected and turned on and off when flipping the switch.  Phew!Here is a link to the forum I found with the diagram.  http://communities.leviton.com/thread/2950In case they ever move things on their website I will also upload the diagram directly here on Amazon.  I hope this helps some of you that want to wire yours the same way as I did.  Without it I don't think I would have got it working right.

The flavor is great, and you can make a lot from this can.  This is way cheaper than buying the premade bottles of gatorade.  I was doing work in the attic so it was over 115 degrees in there, drinking 16 oz of this every 45 minutes was the only thing that kept me from passing out as I was soaking wet from sweat.  Water alone would not have been enough.  For work or fun with major sweat involved, I'd highly recommend this.  If you have a cost co membership you may find it cheaper there though.  I've started getting it there.

Most people dissatisfied and tortured by lives gone wrong, hopes unrealized and a dull emptiness throbbing in some inexplicable place will probably turn to some form of coping mechanism. Some may find escape in such innocuous pleasures as surfing the internet for people to look down on. Others may start coin collections and lose themselves forever in the endless minutiae of minting errors or die variations. Or why not dress up and channel your favorite super hero? Some people may even look awesome since most superheroes just happen to dress in alluringly scanty, skin tight clothing. Hopefully, none will go to the extremes shown in the now legendary novel "Fight Club." In it, the hero, or more likely anti-hero, fed up with his seemingly pointless life of paralyzing consumerism drifts into an insomnia induced schizophrenia and literally plays out his revenge fantasies. These intensify gradually until the inevitable occurs. After all, one typically comes cheek to cheek with one's own unchecked demons, or at least swollen cheek to gun barrel."Fight Club" reads like a supersonic roller coaster. An all out assault on the brain's syntactic pleasure centers generates so much tension that peeking ahead a few paragraphs or pages in helpless suspense becomes pathological. The sentence variety ranges appropriately from run-on to fragment, with plenty of well placed contrast for tension, novelty and intrigue. The well-crafted dialogue showcases the blessings and curses of many post television and movie novels that understandably share the ambition of appearing on film. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it has shaped the modern novel arguably more than any other factor. "Fight Club" definitely qualifies as a "film-able" novel, and so it was. A dream realized. Nonetheless, it still manages to remain a great novel with great tight writing throughout. No need to get into puerile arguments about "the movie is better than the book" or "the book is better than the movie" because that's turtles all the way down. In any case, the book would stand well on its own without a movie incarnation, though it may have missed out on a felicitous sales boost.Similar to many thrillers, the story uses the well-known and highly effective technique of opening on the climax, then rewinding time and gradually resolving the story back to that same climax. As such, Tyler Durden appears immediately, shoving a gun into the mouth of the nameless anti-hero. They stand atop the Parker-Morris building which will apparently explode any minute. A few floors down, anonymous obsequious henchman throw furniture onto the crowd below. This curious situation demands explanation, so rewind to scene one. The first person narrative catapults back to the first coping mechanism: support groups for the dying. Here, for the narrator, life reveals itself in its own resolution of death. He feigns illness and engages in hugs, sobbing and consoling asphyxiating physical smothering. A woman, Marla, appears one day and he immediately takes her for a fraud. She ruins his own fake experience for him, so he tries to convince her to stop coming. It doesn't work. Things soon turn up a notch and Tyler Durden makes his entrance. Fight Club begins with a narrator-Tyler sock-em fest. People gather. Rules form. Associated mantras also form, the best known remains "The first rule about fight club is you don't talk about fight club." Tyler and Marla begin a fling. The narrator's apartment, full of prized consumer goodies, suddenly explodes. Chemical burns in the shape of kisses appear on hands. Soap gets made, possibly out of the fat of Marla's mother. Subliminal glimpses of genitalia appear unknowingly in family movies. Gourmet food gets peed in. Notes about urine in expensive fragrance cause a breakdown. A defiant boss finds fight club notes on the company's printer. He backs off in horror after his confrontation with the narrator ends in a psychotic rant. All of this happens, pretty coincidentally, wherever the narrator and Tyler show their now disfigured beaten swollen blood caked faces. Fight club catches on and sweeps bar basements across the nation. Ferocious beatings occur weekly almost everywhere.Then the volume ratchets up. Project Mayhem, a sort of a spin-off from fight club, initiates a new dangerous level of mass chaos. Led again by Tyler and the narrator they apparently want to "fix civilization." They go about it by recruiting a small army of self-deprecating recruits complete with required hand burns. The narrator reflects that, before his life changed, he was going to name his future dog "Entourage" and concludes "This is how bad your life can get." Now a team of devotees scours distant medical waste dumps for liposuction fat to use in products sold by the very profitable Paper Street Soap Company. Sometimes they also drive like Mr. Toad. Terrifying "human sacrifices" occur that, though they may change lives, they do it through hideous psychological terror. What a way to enter veterinary school. An office explodes. The narrator's office. Did someone inject gasoline in a computer's CRT? Suddenly, the narrator can't find Tyler. But when he asks others, also battle scarred by fight club, they tell him they haven't seen Tyler, wink at him and treat him with embarrassing and militaristic deference. People even call him "sir." Tyler suddenly appears in dreams, in visions and the narrator has a hideous Jekyll and Hyde revelation. He has to stop everything, but the tsunami momentum may prove too much. He becomes a wanted man, loves Marla and finds himself once again atop the Parker-Morris building teething a gun barrel with the clock ticking. He ends up in "heaven" with a premonition that everything has ended - and another haunting premonition that it hasn't. Can one ever really escape one's demons?"Fight Club" manages to remain shocking and edgy almost two decades after its release. Its dramatic progression of dissatisfaction building up to violence that ends in regret may even hold a lesson for our increasingly volatile times. Though often disturbing and jarring it also manages a good amount of laugh out loud humor. It also contains some outright stunning passages, such as "we are the middle children of history, raised by television to believe that someday we'll be millionaires and movie stars and rock stars, but we won't. And we're just learning this fact." This chilling quote occurs while a gang from Project Mayhem prepares to castrate a police commissioner. One of their many "homework" assignments. Ultimately, the book sends a warning about reacting violently or vengefully to one's internal malcontent. Consumerism may leave many people feeling empty and purposeless, but that doesn't mean a worse monster needs to get created. "Fight Club" thus ends up providing a critique both of modern life and of a typical knee-jerk reaction one may have to it, namely, a fervent desire to "fix" it through some kind of armed revolution. Obviously, interpretations of fiction will differ wildly, but "Fight Club" seems to tell the middle class disaffected, or at least people without problems who think they have problems, to "cool it." So should they?

Those of modest means, or most people, who find themselves pursued and bitten by a fervent numismatic bug may find the hobby's emphasis on pricey rarities a barrier larger than a carbonized steel wall extending past the thermosphere. The few and inaccessibly expensive precious planchets that grace the numismatic press seem accessible only to those possessing pedigrees extending back to Charlemagne. But fret not. Alternatives exist. Apart from numerous modestly priced coins dispersed across bourse floors throughout the globe, one can borrow inspiration from Marcel Duchamp, that old champion of autographed urinals, and accumulate and appreciate found objects. Coins abound in the real world, often hidden in plain sight. Just gaze into streets, gutters, flaps of siding, between tire treads, in the digestive tracts of animals, beneath snowplows and in countless other surprising niches and crevices. Not beautiful or valuable specimens that will have Sotheby's ramming down your door Viking style, of course, but pieces full of curious historical fascination all their own. Not everything exciting or interesting is expensive."Keep the Change," a modestly sized and extremely enjoyable book priced well below a Saint-Gaudens Double Eagle, passionately embraces the finding and collecting of mutilated money. Burgeoning with interesting monetary tidbits, bursting with plenty of full color photos of coins and bills damaged beyond hope and infused with a slightly necessary Quixotic spirit of adventure, the book highlights very underrated aspects of the life of physical cash. It's rough out there, even for metal. With a fresh albeit askew perspective the book turns the numismatic field, if not on its head, then at least on its rib cage. It exchanges perfect MS-70 museum pieces with cents and quarters splattered with inexplicable goo, dollar bills saturated with coffee, dye or noxious chemicals, deeply counter marked copper, loudly rubber stamped cotton and coins tortured beyond recognition by heavy industrial equipment or disemboweled by household tools. And it sees it all as beautiful. And, arguably, it is.Along the way, some may even learn what "fungible" means. Points for educational value.Those who don't appreciate quarters flipped over like tacos should at least enjoy exploding some money busting, or money defacing, myths. Many children, during those long lazy days of aimless youth, become possessed with the uncontrollable urge to rip something apart from the inside out. Some of us may have direct experience with this, but finger pointing is never productive. How many children saw a cent in half, subject a quarter to intense heat or simply deface currency in the name of boredom resolution only to have friends with shrill voices begin brandishing endless excoriations for destroying government property? The book deals with this timeless topic by citing 18 U.S.C. 333. This clearly states the utter illegality of defacing currency, but many of our childish selves would mercifully be spared the hoosegow by the loophole of difficult to prove intent. The book points out that even a Treasury Secretary once personally signed a banknote, which technically qualifies as defacement. So unless one's acts of currency mutilation appear excessively gratuitous or indignantly rebellious, most of us probably have little to create ulcers over concerning this topic. Though to be clear, the book by no means supports or recommends the intentional defacing of currency, only the finding, collecting and appreciation of already mutilated currency. Hey, back off, he didn't do it!Some of the book's most amusing material involves the alteration of money for artistic or political purposes. Some conceptual artists have stamped circulating bills with messages such as "Free Money," "I am voting" or anti-consumer aphorisms such as "What if you only had what you needed?" One of the more impressive projects involved a Turkish artist taking ten years of creating a "new" twenty dollar bill out of strips of already circulating currency, aptly titled "How to Make a Buck." A piece entitled "Wrong" showcases poorly conceived counterfeiting schemes. Money as art. Art as money. Other chapters discuss the endlessly fascinating security features on currency, including the fluorescent variations of embedded ultraviolet strips that vary by denomination and magnetic ink. Voluminous other topics spill over the sides of this tiny book, including perfectly legal money-gami, a lucky windfall of error notes, a bank manger who literally throws away $1,000 a year, lovely verdigris, star notes, Issac Newton's numismatic contributions, coin clipping, a slew of nicknames for money, a public money burning on Wall Street, the ups and downs of submitting damaged money to the Treasury, the mystery of red quarters, and a final taxonomic dictionary categorizing the many ways money gets morphed and mangled - everything from advertising to irradiation to "Vegas Coins." Readers will glean more about mutilation than they ever thought possible."Keep the Change" expands the concepts of numismatics in directions accessible to anyone. It also excites an admiration for the unimaginable stress that money endures in circulation. Perhaps tumbled worn seemingly valueless money has more to communicate historically than valuable pristine and untouched money? Smooth featureless and even damaged coins have definitely done their job out in the great big world. Perhaps they deserve more credit than rotting at the bottom of dusty discount bins? "Keep the Change" helps redress this imbalance and fosters gratitude for the beaten culls and the ugly slugs that have driven everyday commerce since the appearance of our now ubiquitous money. Now go find a maimed coin and give it the attention it deserves.

In a late filmed interview, author Paul Bowles said that he had never worked unless he really wanted to. Not only that, others who knew him claimed he was the "most free" person that they had ever known. Perhaps this accounts for his relatively uneven literary output, scattered as it was across multiple decades. Perhaps he didn't need to write to make a living, but remained lucky enough to write only when inspiration or urges bubbled up beyond breaking point. Following the 1970s, a decade in which he released very little material, the 1980s saw a resurgence of interest in the reclusive expatriate who wrote mainly about the murky and disturbing side of human nature. A few small new works appeared, including a tiny experimental work encompassing a periodic multiple perspective history of Morocco called "Points in Time," a new collection of short stories, a format he mastered, called "Midnight Mass" and an equally diminutive collection called "Unwelcome Words." The final collection appeared in 1988 and remains among the last original work he released before his death in 1999. It shows that his powers and experimentation had not diminished even in his final years."Unwelcome Words" contains seven very short stories, all of which deal with familiar Bowles themes. Three of them stand out by using a stream of consciousness or "language of thought" approach that eschews all punctuation and reads like a continuous and interminably anxious inhale. This may disarm some readers at first, but its pleasantly unpleasant effect works given these stories' mostly sinister subject matter. The remaining stories have a journalistic feel except for the final epistolary story in which Bowles himself appears."Julien Vreden," the first story, deals with the sudden deaths of two parents and their bitterly vengeful son. "New York 1965" introduces the experimental style through a relentless barrage of thoughts of a woman who harshly judges a friend whose life and values veer drastically from her own and who can't tolerate "people who refuse to abide by the rules of the game." The story leaves lasting thoughts about who remains the most repulsive, the judge or the judged? Or perhaps neither? Maybe some moralizing ends merely in an unresolvable stalemate? "Hugh Harper" tells the sordid tale of a man who acquires a taste for human blood and finds himself exiled from one culture after another. The reasons why each culture exiles him provide intriguing contrasts. "Massachusetts 1932" once again provides an onslaught of chained sentences lacking punctuation. This time the deluge appears in second person, told by the owner of a secluded cabin in which two women, both his estranged wives, committed suicide in a suspiciously similar manner. The shotguns on the book's cover may take on a deeper meaning. "Dinner at Sir Nigel's" relates a bizarre tale of an eccentric aristocrat who invites a group of journalists to his house. They witness a macabre performance featuring beautiful young women. Soon everyone knew why he keeps only a very small house staff well out of proportion to his fortune. "Tangier 1975" features yet another uneasy circumstance in which a young poor couple take up residence on a rich woman's estate. Following a large party in which the couple are asked to monitor guests, the sounds of nearby peacocks screeching come to sound more and more like screams of tortured humans. Or do they? This story leaves a lingering dread.The book's longest, and final, story, "Unwelcome Words," finds Paul Bowles himself communicating with a seemingly bitter man confined to his room and a wheelchair after experiencing a stroke. Only Bowles' letters appear so readers must deduce the debilitated man's words. Little by little Bowles becomes increasingly impatient with the hopelessness expressed by the unseen other side of the correspondence. Bowles relates ghastly stories of plotting to kill noisy dogs in his neighborhood, the murder of an old woman, the attack on two old Americans who lived on a mountain, a practical joke in which someone reveals that Bowles has died, theories on the sources of the suffering man's stroke, mainly his insufferable ex-wife, strange song lyrics, the highly chemicalized ingredients of "Home Fashioned" American chocolate and "Huckleberry Finn" as a "ruined masterpiece." When Bowles begins to address the gradual unread accusations of his grieving pen-pal, he essentially gives up and hopes his friend will remember his kindness in his final moments. A one-sided dissolution of a lifelong friendship unfolds. The reasons why Bowles personalized this story to such an extent will probably remain a subject for speculation. One could also argue that he doesn't depict himself as the most sympathetic of human beings here, but this piece also appears in a collection of fiction. Theories could abound. In any case, the story will likely haunt readers well beyond closing the book.This small collection demonstrates Bowles lasting literary power. Its bold experimentation works and its themes drill deep into human psychology without drawing any facile conclusions or wallowing in needless moralizing. They seem to depict life in all of its polymorphous indeterminacy, as does all of Bowles' best work. Situations unfold, humans provide counter arguments and justifications while violence or its premonitions lurks mysteriously beneath the surface. Bowles' work brings humanity face to face with itself and some may find the experience relentless, but never boring, trite or gratuitous. It never shuns the depths of human experience and attempts to embrace and expose an aspect of existence that many would probably rather sweep under a carpet of platitudes. Though Bowles never found great fame as a writer, his work will nonetheless continue to impact those lucky enough to stumble across it.

Published continuously since 1947, the famous "Red Book" retains its status as the preeminent reference book for United States coins. Its legendary status has even  promoted the red book itself to a collectible. Original early editions can capture hefty premiums, as the book itself unabashedly admits. This 69th edition continues the tradition of delineating all US coin types, including colonials, commemoratives, patterns, territorial releases and even some samplings of tokens. It even includes annual silver, gold and platinum bullion releases, such as the Eagles, Buffaloes and First Spouse series. Just about any nanoparticle of metal that the US has ever deemed official currency shows up in these pages. Better yet, they appear in color and in actual size.Beginning with the intriguing and rare Sommer Islands' issues aptly named "Hogge Money" from 1616 an accessible and manageable monetary history of the US unfolds. Even items unobtainable to those lacking aristocratic incomes appear, such as Brasher Doubloons, Continental Currency and the 1792 "Dismes" and "Half Dismes," all of which easily fetch 6 or 7 figures at auction. The included lovely but inevitably inadequate paper reproductions remain the closest many will come to experiencing such deified rarities. Special sections also exist for the 1804 dollar and Gobrecht Dollars, but the equally celebrated 1913 Liberty Nickel receives only a cursory mention. Following an almost dizzying but fascinating parade of colonial and post-colonial issues, the book lists coins by denomination starting with the now enigmatic and very obsolete copper half cent. Alongside very familiar issues, such as the Lincoln Cent, Roosevelt dime and the Washington Quarter, other long lost denominations crop up like lion fish amongst tuna, many of which were probably good ideas at the time. Thankfully, short historical footnotes accompany most sections and help illuminate these now seemingly puzzling coins. The two-cent and three cent piece both had practical 19th century applications. Half dimes were basically nickels clothed in silver and the very strange and extremely short lived twenty cent piece probably remains one of the US mint's most beguiling blunders. Its size proximity to the quarter dollar created confusion similar to the ill-fated Susan B. Anthony dollar released over a century later. The lesson: don't release new coins that are nearly identical to coins already in circulation, especially if they differ in purchasing power. Additional lesser known coins also receive attention, such as confederate, Hawaiian, Puerto Rican, and the early 20th century standard and commemorative releases of the Philippines. Many of these also command exorbitant prices.Though the book often revels in rarities, it doesn't neglect recent clad issues and their special variations, such as the well-known and well circulated Statehood and America the Beautiful quarters, the "Westward Journey" nickels, the Presidential and Native American dollars and the 2009 bicentennial Lincoln cents. Photos of all appear (though this edition appeared too early to include photos of the most recent First Spouse issues, including the much anticipated Jacqueline Kennedy piece). Opinions also vary on the US mint's commemorative program, but the curious, or morbidly curious, will find every commemorative ever issued within these solid red covers. Many of the "classic" commemoratives feature breathtakingly beautiful designs, such as the Oregon Trail Memorial. This era ended with the controversial 1951 - 1954 Carver/Washington issue. The book provides a curious quote claiming that proceeds from the sales of these coins, among the first in the US to picture African-Americans, went "to oppose the spread of communism among Negroes in the interest of national defense." Very interesting, indeed. This apparently dealt such a blow to the program that commemoratives didn't appear again until 1982. Some argue that we're now in an era of commemorative and variety glut that may strangle the hobby. A profusion of limited edition "reverse proofs," special mint marks and limited mint sets fuels a secondary market that can temporarily inflate values and cause collector frustration. And this Red Book edition doesn't yet include the controversial Truman and Kennedy "Coin and Chronicles" sets that sold out almost immediately. Many blame the horrifying decline in stamp collecting, and stamp values, on a similar flooding of the market with endless releases that led to irreversible collector frustration. But not everyone agrees with this ominous warning or decrees the same fate for coin collecting.Many will also notice that the Red Book calls itself a "guide book" and not a "price guide," though it does contain a litany of prices and values. The book itself contains a warning about following the listed prices too closely, as the market fluctuates wildly and unpredictably over the span of a year. That said, few will probably recommend using the Red Book as a guide to pricing. The instantly updatable internet has even started to question the very existence of print price guides and many dealers now use online subscription services to determine values. That said, the Red Book and the accompanying Blue Book can give a rough order of magnitude pricing range for newcomers, not to mention valuable mintage data and crucial historical background information. Not only that, some of the best information in the Red Book has nothing to do with pricing. The introduction provides a fascinating and detailed outline of the history of US coins and famous hoards plus advice on the coin market, detecting counterfeits and the ever elusive topic of grading. A small discussion of errors, values of collectible Red and Blue books, historical bullion prices and the top 250 auction prices and a bibliography close the book. Though most who purchase this book will likely want to own coins of their own, it's completely feasible that someone who never wants to purchase a single physical coin could still derive much useful information from these pages. As such, the Red Book is probably best thought of as a reference book, not as a price guide, and one with a history all its own. It will turn 70 next year and only time will tell if its printed pages will eventually succumb to the digital bits of the internet. Until then, assuming that does happen, it will remain an indelible institution in and of itself for the field of numismatics.

Anyone following Captain Beefheart's career in 1974 probably screeched with delight upon hearing of his upcoming collaboration with longtime associate Frank Zappa. Though far more a Zappa album than a Beefheart one, "Bongo Fury" represents Beefheart's drastic turn away from the brash commercialism of his two uncharacteristic 1974 albums. Here he sounds completely back in his element, gritty sandblasting voice, poetically surreal lyrics and a committed affirmation of everything elliptical and angular. Perhaps Zappa, who had both discovered and provided Beefheart with his often misheard moniker, had saved Don Van Vliet's career from the "Tragic Band" chasm? In any case, the duo sound so great throughout "Bongo Fury" that one wishes they had shared stages more often ("Willie the Pimp" from "Hot Rats" provides another heavenly example of their brilliant collaborations). Sadly, as most people know, this mid 70s album, tour, legal hassles following the "Bat Chain Puller" project and whatever else pretty much drained any desire that these two immense talents had to inhabit the same room. Thankfully, they decided to record their 1975 tour (mostly live) and left "Bongo Fury" behind as testament of their once fruitful relationship.Beefheart growls the album to life on the Zappa-penned "Debra Kadabra." Either Beefheart completely made it his own or Zappa had The Captain in mind when writing this track. Even the lyrics sound right out of Beefheart: "June, a rancho granny, shook her wrinkled fanny" and "Oh debra algebra amnesia kadabra, witch goddess, witch goddess of lankersham boulevard. Cover my entire bodice, with an avon cologna" and "watch the rubber tongue when it comes out from the puffed and flabulent Mexican rubbergoose mask." This opening song leaves a definite impression. It hearkens Beefheart's triumphant return from the abyss and christens the remainder of the amazing set that awaits.Things just get better with the catchy and driving "Carolina Hard-Core Ecstasy" that features Zappa in full form. Supposedly a collage of some of Zappa's own interesting and often humorous experiences, the song tells the tale of a woman who likes a good stomping. Not exactly a topical stretch for Zappa. Those familiar with the era will likely laugh out loud at the "Roger Daltrey cape" reference. It's possibly one of Zappa's best songs and worth the entire album alone.Beefheart's first of two original numbers, "Sam With the Showing Scalp Flat Top," with the unforgettable lines "the music was thud like" and "particular about the point it made," showcases the Captain's always evocative lyrics. The song ends with a variation on "Louie Louie" with Beefheart ominously chanting "Bongo fury." Zappa then announces that the coming USA bicentennial year will feature many products that "maybe you shouldn't ought to buy," which queues the "cowboy" song "Poofter's Froth Wyoming Plans Ahead" sung once again by Beefheart. "200 Years Old" emerges with its slick blues suddenly from the sudden ending of "Poofter's Froth." "Cucamonga" feels like a smooth reminiscence of Zappa and Beefheart's late childhood spent in the yawning California desert. It features an insane vocal transition and plummeting piano fills. Fans of Zappa's legendary guitar solos will melt along with the extended "Advance Romance." Screeching harmonica also joins in, along with some trademark whoops, hollers and gargles from Beefheart's heavily sandblasted throat. Beefheart's second number, "Man With The Woman Head" only encompasses a minute and a half of the album, but it makes the most of that geologic eye blink. Identical to "Scalp Flat top," Beefheart mostly speaks the lyrics over a thick layer of flailing and ethereal musical accompaniment.The album closes on a truly momentous note. It provides an exemplar and culmination of the concept of "concert closer." "Muffin Man" not only showcases Zappa's guitar acrobatics but also makes a passionate plea for the supremacy of muffins over cupcakes. More great lines grace the amazing music: "Girl you thought he was a man but he was a muffin, he hung around till you found that he didn't know nothin'." Beefheart's vocals add very special emphasis. The thundering refrain continues and eventually ends with Zappa's classic pronouncement "Goodnight Austin, Texas, wherever you are!"Zappa and Beefheart went their separate ways following "Bongo Fury." Zappa continued one of the most prolific careers of the twentieth century until his tragic death in 1993. His enormous body of work still stands as an insurmountable achievement in its richness, musical sophistication and evolution. "Bongo Fury" provides a mere nibble of the impressively eclectic and vast Zappa library. Beefheart, perhaps energized by his old friend, experienced a musical renaissance and happily returned to his more dissonant and cacophonous roots. The abortive "Bat Chain Puller" morphed into "Shiny Beast(Bat Chain Puller)" which extended to two more additionally brilliant albums before his retirement into painting in 1982. Van Vliet passed away in 2010. Apparently, he and Zappa resumed communication prior to Zappa's death. "Bongo Fury" shows just what these two 20th century musical giants could accomplish in unison. Sadly, they didn't come together more often.

Jazz pianist Thelonious Monk, who some earlier used to dismiss as "bizarre" or "eccentric," finally found popular success in the 1960s. A string of albums for Columbia, an extensive touring schedule and even an appearance on the cover of Time Magazine in 1964 kept Monk solidly in the limelight as one of jazz's leading figures. In retrospect, this vertiginous ascent also presaged the end of his groundbreaking career. Rumors of failing mental health began to spread and some accused his late recordings of uninventive cyclical rehashing. Though Monk's Columbia recordings definitely contain fewer original compositions than previously recorded songs, they nonetheless have a character all of their own. Given what we now know about Monk's later years, the amount of original material he did manage to create during this phase now seems impressive and inspiring. Regardless of the truth behind some of the criticisms, Monk even managed to make his rehashes seem fresh and revitalized."Straight, No Chaser," released in 1967 following a two year gap in recording, contained almost no new material, but this doesn't really seem to matter almost fifty years after its release. Perhaps those who had followed Monk in his day experienced the repetition more directly as each new album appeared in sequence, but today this album's energy really stands up. Listening to it in a 21st century retrospective context probably makes the stigmas and ethos present in the late 1960s jazz scene seem less relevant. In any case, the album sounds strong all on its own and contains enough of Monk's angularly playful musicality to withstand repeated listenings. It does come very late in his recording career and only a few albums remained before Monk's final studio sessions and retirement from recording."Locomotive" opens the album with an addictive mechanic churn featuring a rhythm that sticks long after the final notes have faded away. As usual, Charlie Rouse channels Monk's musical thoughts and provides a streaming moving sax solo that perfectly accompanies the song's aura. "I Didn't Know About You," composed by Duke Ellington, begins with Monk solo on piano. Rouse's smooth sax eventually emerges, almost surprisingly, over the lilting piano making for another great sonic combination. This album's version of one of Monk's most famous songs, "Straight, No Chaser," runs over 11 minutes and includes a slew of incredible solos by the entire ensemble. The extremely extended "Japanese Folk Song (Kojo no Tsuki)," running at almost 17 minutes, never becomes worn and tired thanks to its intriguing melodic structures. Monk also begins this number solo and the rest of the band gradually joins in. This track doesn't seem to have appeared on any previous Monk his albums. The well-known and heavily covered jazz standard, "Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea," appears here in a lovely solo piano rendition. "We See" highlights Monk's catchy lyricism and provides further evidence that his music represents one of the happiest and most hopeful sounds in all of music.Later CD reissues restored many of the originally reduced LP tracks to their full length. Not only that, three additional tracks continue the show beyond where the 1967 album left off. "This is My Story, This is my Song," shows Monk in a melancholy mood with just enough of his idiosyncrasies infused to keep the song from taking itself too seriously. An earlier take of "I Didn't Know About You" rolls into the boppy "Green Chimneys," a song that would appear on Monk's next album, "Underground". This take, though very listenable, doesn't quite have the drive of that subsequent album's version. In this context it provides a hint of the creative explosion that would soon unfold. "Underground," released the following year, included more original compositions than many previous albums. This makes "Straight, No Chaser" seem less innovative in comparison, but the seeds of "Underground" may have begun to emerge on its predecessor. Monk had not recorded in a few years before "Straight, No Chaser," so perhaps this served as a warm up to one of his last, and arguably one of his best, late albums. But "Straight, No Chaser" still stands up fine today even in comparison to "Underground." It represents Monk, one of the undisputed geniuses of modern music, in full form even in his later years.
