Every Talking Heads album feels equally like an ending and a beginning. With the possible exception of their first and last few albums, none of their releases seem surmountable. How could they top "More Songs About Buildings and Food?" With "Fear of Music." And how could they possibly top that album? With "Remain in Light." They kept re-inventing themselves to such a fervent extreme that no one could possibly predict the next progression. "Remain in Light" seemed like the culmination of aggregating afro-rock and western pop with enlightened stream of consciousness. How would they top that? Some may argue that the follow up to "Remain in Light," arguably their most critcally acclaimed album, doesn't completely measure up. "Speaking in Tongues," released three years later, fully embraced synth pop and the same electrified african rhythms that graced its predecessor. But it contains a different and more subdued kind of energy, not quite as explosive as "Born Under Punches" or "Once in a Lifetime," but a more accessible and subversively quirky aura that feels murkily spontaneous despite its very precise electronic rhythms and sound. It somehow managed to make the Talking Heads a household name while simultaneously solidifying both their artistic and commercial aspirations. Even today it still sounds equally popular and subversive with lines such as "and I don't know what you expect staring into the TV set" and "our president's crazy, did you hear what he said?" "Burning Down the House," a massive hit in its day, now defines the band for the mass of people who tilt their cochleas towards popular music sources. One can still hear the song vibrating air molucules out in the great big world over thirty years later. The elliptical but addictive music video found voluminous play on the then only two years old MTV (which, surprising as it probably seems today, once stood for "Music Television"). At the time, this album felt like the culmination of the band's four previous albums while sounding like yet another re-invention. Its subsequent commercial success seemed well deserved. But cracks began to fracture in the foundations even before this album appeared. Following the equally successful "Stop Making Sense," which filmed the tour that supported this album and the band's final tour, not everyone appreciated what came afterwards or the sometimes puerile and openly public back stabbing between band members that ensued over the next few years."Speaking in Tongues" arose out of improvisation. The band sat in the studio and played together and tightened the lyrics and the music and released an album. It probably sounds far easier than the reality. This also accounts for the change in song writing credits for this album and "Remain in Light." All songs now get credited to every band member rather than just David Byrne. Byrne sang the vocals extemporaneously during the sessions and some of his original ramblings remained on the final mix. The album's title then provides an apt analogy for at least the lyrical methodology. Though the new approach and credits suggest more collaboration, the individual members had gone their separate ways during the three year gap between albums. Byrne had recorded two solo records, Frantz and Weymouth formed "The Tom Tom Club" and scored a hit of their own, and Harrison had even recorded a solo album. They finally came together again to create a fetchingly danceable album."Making Flippy Floppy" contains an ethereal violin solo by Shankar that reaches in and grabs something primordial. Razor slices and gurglings punctuate the incomprehensibly comprehensible lyrics of "Girlfriend is Better." The lines "we're being taken for a ride again" and "nothing was lost, everything's free, I don't care how impossible it seems" still resonate today. They may even prophetically define our current times. "Slippery People," we've all known some, includes an infectious groove and more profoundly dadaist lyrics. The skippy "This Must be the Place (Naive Melody)" seems to provide a rare bittersweet moment of consolation in the Talking Head's catalog, but something sinister bubbles beneath the surface, again revealed by the lyrics, "the less we say about it the better, make it up as we go along" and "It's okay, I know nothing's wrong, nothing." Though some genuinely touching moments peek through, such as "Out of all those kinds of people, you got a face with a view" and "and you love me till my heart stops, love me till I'm dead." A great mellow album closer.Many of these songs received new, sometimes more frenetic, treatments for the concert film "Stop Making Sense," which may make the original albums versions feel slightly more lax for those who experience the concert before the album. The movie also featured a sampling of songs from the album, leaving some truly great tracks slightly obscured. "I Get Wild/Wild Gravity" contains a hearty mix of juicy groove. "Moon Rocks" opens with the classic line "Flying saucers, levitation, yo, I could do that" and doesn't let up through "talkin' transubstantiation, any version will do" and "Moon in the rock, rock in the moon, there's a moon in my throat." Its angular funky beat evokes the rage of "Remain in Light." One wonders just how awesome "Pull Up the Roots" would have sounded in the "Stop Making Sense" set list. The fiery chorus provides one of the most powerful moments on the entire album. Of course immensely evocative stream of consciousness lines permeate the entire number: "Well I have a good time when I go out of my mind," "towns that disappeared completely, pull up the roots, pull up the roots," "I don't mind some slight disorder" and "and I hear beautiful sounds coming outta the ground, gonna take us a while but we'll go hundreds of times.""Stop Making Sense," the film and the soundtrack, re-invented the band yet again, but this time also visually. Sadly, things fell apart and the band never toured again. "Speaking in Tongues," though not the end by any means, does seem like the end of the heightened creative progression and innovation that evolved during their first five albums. The next two albums put Byrne back in the writer's seat exclusively and furthered the band's commercial exposure, though some critics and long time fans found the new "for the people" direction regressive, despite many admittedly strong songs. Regardless of diverse personal opinions, the Talking Heads were never the same after "Speaking in Tongues." The "bad blood" Byrne later spoke of seemed to start during "Stop Making Sense" and then climaxed a few years later as the band members openly defied and betrayed each other. One can feel some of this tension on a 1983 David Letterman appearance (now easily accessible via the new museum of television called "YouTube"). After finishing a rousing live version of "Burning Down the House" only Byrne runs forward to Letterman's desk for an interview. The remaining band members, who share equal writing credits with Byrne, fade into blackness in the background. Then Byrne appeared by himself on the cover of Time Magazine. The other band members appeared almost parenthetically on the inner pages. Then, as if to even the score, a scathing Rolling Stone article featured other band members excoriating Byrne. It was sad. Wounds that apparently won't heal continue to the present day. It happens. Regardless of depressing personal politics, no one can deny the freshness and vitality that the Talking Heads brought to popular music during their insanely provocative run on the pop music scene. Their voluminous contributions still feel unprecedented and unsurpassed today.

Simple stories provide a great way for beginners to a new language to stockpile vocabulary. Though such stories, with their inevitable limitations, don't always provide stunning examples of narrative drama, the Blaine Ray series manages to provide engaging tales despite the small number of words utilized. "Patricia va a California" builds on its predecessors, "Berto y sus buenas ideas" and "Pobre Ana." Though the preterite tense appears only later in the story, the narrative includes compelling themes such as multiculturalism, travel and reconciliation. Though not a literary classic by any means (how could it be?) it provides a far more enticing platform for learning than memorizing vocabulary lists (which, admittedly, doesn't hurt either). Basic grammatical structures give words adequate contextual meaning to help meanings stick. The book even allows for reading without a vast knowledge of verb conjugation since the word list includes translations of the verbs in their conjugated form. This shouldn't encourage anyone to dismiss learning verb conjugations by rote, since extremely few books treat verbs in this simple manner and relying on conjugated word lists will only entrap learners in the beginner level.The story features Patricia, who lives in Panajachel in Lake Atitlan in Guatemala. Similar to Ana in the previous story, her family subsists on limited means. One day an opportunity to live in the United States falls at her feet and her family makes a large sacrifice to allow her to make the journey. She lives with a family in Ventura, California and soon meets the (presumably Caucasian) high school cheerleader Debbie Martin who mistakes Patricia for a Mexican and then loudly expresses her fervent dislike for Mexicans. Patricia's extremely friendly host family tells her to ignore Debbie's racist fulminations, but she can't shake them. One day Patricia sees Debbie cornered in her car by a man with a handgun. Patricia leaps into action and everything changes. This is pretty intense material for a beginner's book.Along the way the book discusses some aspects of Guatemalan culture and lifestyle, such as colorful huipils and some differences between indigenous Guatemalans and ladinos. Morality also plays a large role, including suggestions of anti-racism, anti-materialism and reconciliation. Those who made it through "Pobre Ana" will have little difficulty finishing this equally short book, though, as already said, the preterite appears a little over half way through, as do constructions with verbs and prepositions such as "para comer." So, true to the purpose of the entire series, expect slightly more advanced grammar from "Pobre Ana." The series continues with "Casi se Muere" which still remains at level 1, though also builds on material presented here. Overall, the Blaine Ray series presents great supplemental reading for learning Spanish. It can't take the place of more traditional learning, but it will enhance and enliven the experience of learning another language - and it may make those monotonous but necessary verb drills more meaningful.

Hammered coins contain a certain ineffable something. Perhaps the fact that an actual human hand held a mallet that struck a design into a thin blank planchet provides a direct personal link to an actual historical person? After all, we know at least one person had to have held a hammered coin. Or maybe just their sheer age, which obviously extends far beyond machine stuck coins, conjures up lost eras? Whatever the attraction, hammered coins definitely possess their own distinct and potentially addictive aura. Those coming to these fascinating artifacts from more modern machine made coins will find a dizzying array of types, countries, historic figures and often undecipherable legends. What does "EDW R ANGL DNS HYB" mean anyway? One has to start somewhere, after all, and when it comes to exploring hammered coins for the first time a good strategy remains starting with a limited scope and working slowly outwards. "England's Striking History" provides an excellent starting point for those seeking knowledge of this almost incomprehensible field. Keeping the beginner in mine, it limits itself to silver hammered coins of England. Presumably, those just starting out, especially those with limited budgets, won't begin by bidding on extravagantly expensive gold nobles or crowns. This book simply removes those distracting and pricey relics by showing the reader just what great things exist in more moderately priced English silver struck between 959 and 1663. The coins included in this book alone could keep a hammered coin addict occupied for years, if not for a lifetime. But, as the text itself admits, this book remains a good starting point, not a good ending point.One characteristic that may attract or repel certain readers is that the book presents only illustrations of the coins discussed. Each one contains great detail and many even depict the inevitable flaws that hammered coins possess. Still, the only photo of a coin in the entire volume, apart from a few advertisements, appears on the front cover - a penny of Edward the Confessor. A brief introduction argues that photos often don't help people experience a coin up close, so historical illustrations were instead procured from various sources. Opinions will likely differ on this approach, but many of the illustrations contain an undeniable beauty all their own. Also, most increase the size of the coins by a magnitude or so. A few places do show actual sizes and relative sizes between denominations, but the vast majority display as magnified. In most cases this helps with reading the often unfamiliar letters found on such coins. A early page called "Confusing letters On Hammered Coins" provides some guidance. Along the way, every legend gets spelled out in modern notation at least once along with translations. Soon everyone will know that "EDW R ANGL DNS HYB" means, in very abbreviated medieval Latin, "Edward King of England Lord of Ireland." Though some potentially confusing non-modern pronunciations do slide by. In Anglo-Saxon Old English, characters that look similar to a modern "p" (a "wynn") were pronounced more like a modern "w." The text does not point out that "EADPEARD" should be pronounced as "EADWEARD." Though a small point - this isn't a book about speech - it may nevertheless confuse those with no exposure to Old English.As an added bonus, a brief history of England accompanies the numismatic discussions. Each section gives a short historical background on the respective monarch or era and then goes into further details on the coins, mint marks and sometimes multitudinous variations of that age. The section on Henry I outlines 10 out of 15 groupings associated with his coinage. A page and a half of illustrations show the seemingly endless varieties of William I's coins (also spelled "Pillelm"). Even Charles I's voluminous types receive adequate attention and features the book's largest coin, his silver Pound. Most of the sections list coins in chronological order from higher to lower denominations. The section on Elizabeth I reverses this ordering and begins with the halfpenny and ends with the Crown. Cromwell's Commonwealth receives only a single page and shows all denominations displayed side by side. No base metal coins appear and the section on Charles I even calls out that his farthings remain outside of the book's scope. The main historical section ends with Charles II's adoption of milled coinage. A short discussion on obtaining hammered coins, either in coin shows or by metal detector, ends the book, along with some frightening warnings on using electrolysis to clean hammered coins found in the ground. Other less risky cleaning techniques, such as using tinfoil and spit, also receive coverage.A single book cannot cover every topic, particularly one so vast, but some notable, yet understandable, omissions exist. For example, almost nowhere does it talk of value or pricing. After all, only wealthy beginners will have a prayer of laying their hands on many Anglo-Saxon coins, large denominations, Edward I groats or especially on anything featuring Richard III. The book could have included direction on more accessible coins, such as the often easier to find and relatively more affordable pennies of Henry III and Edward I. Not to mention the vastly different grading standards for hammereds. An XF may represent the absolute peak grade for many types. Apart from that, a few dispersed typos, a couple of illustrations that seem out of place and a note in the section on Henry VIII that ends abruptly don't distract much from the book as a whole. Though not perfect, its pros far outweigh its cons."England's Striking History," complete with punning title, provides a great introduction to the nearly fathomless topic of silver English hammered coins. It won't overwhelm newcomers with quibbling numismatic minutiae. That can come later. The stalwart and enthusiastic may even finish it in a single sitting. Ultimately, everyone will finish this book with their knowledge greatly increased and their brains ready to tackle heftier volumes. Not only that, this small book prepares one for an appreciation of the numerous coins that our ancestors used throughout their daily lives and the messages and images that their leaders wanted to communicate through this once mass dispersed medium. A lifetime of fascination awaits.

As the Magna Carta turns 800 a resurgence of interest in its origins has arisen. At the epicenter of this tale sits a highly derided king, King John, who many have proclaimed, typically without a hint of reservation, as "the worst king in English history." King John's sordid reputation apparently stems from his own actions and reactions to events occurring in his own 12th and 13th century lifetime. These eventually led to outright rebellion and civil war. This antipathy persists to the present day. A commentator on a recent BBC radio show called John "an absolute rotter through and through" and claimed that a subsequent 14th century claimant to the throne, John of Gaunt, was not considered at least partially because he possessed the name "John." King John's inaccurate and ahistorical inclusion in the Robin Hood tales certainly hasn't bolstered his historical standing either, at least in a popular sense. Other pejorative terms commonly thrust upon him include opportunist, womanizer, murderer, narcissist, usurper, inept, among others in a seemingly endless litany of bile. He remains the king that everyone wants to hate. Not only that, his faults often symbolize the weakening of the monarchy and the first glimpses of a more shared and democratic rule in the West. After all, the Magna Carta negotiations began during his reign and John's allowing the situation to degrade so putridly usually emerges as the root cause of this monumental political change. As often happens in history, a great evil somehow gives rise to what many consider a great good. King John's story thus remains a vital piece of the present day.Given that arguably true delineation, some claim that the Magna Carta story doesn't reduce to a simple moral tale of "good versus evil" and its accompanying and inevitable and perhaps preordained outcome. For example, Stephen Church's "King John and the Road to Magna Carta" attempts to retell the events leading up to the now legendary and almost mythical events of June, 1215 in a narrative that does not take the ending for granted. While never denying that the reign of King John remains an abject failure, the book depicts the historical events as an unfolding stream of possibilities. As improbable as it now seems given the patina of time, John's rule could have succeeded at many points. This experiment definitely shows just how encrusted John's reputation remains. Since readers now presumably know the ending, some may have a hard time not shaking their heads in disbelief as the text relates each of John's foibles. They may also show surprise or shock at the moments when John seemed very secure and trusted, even glorified. There were unquestionable successes too. In other words, the book's method may further demonstrate just how difficult it is to abstract away the individual events of a historical figure's life from the perceived outcome of the whole life.A story appears in the book's preface that suggests John did have success in mind from the outset. When warned by St. Hugh in 1199 of the dangers of damnation brought on by personal excess, John pointed out that he should instead focus on emulating the exalted kings who were glorified by the heavens. Once again some may find, contrary to the book's intent, difficulty in suppressing caustic comments such as "well, that certainly didn't work out the way he planned." Nonetheless, the point holds: John thought of himself as an entirely appropriate person to represent God in England. He planned to triumph.The introduction discusses the opening of John's tomb in 1797, some of the history of John's historical desecration and the absolute power obtained by the Angevin kings. Recording of court correspondence also increased during John's time so these artifacts arguably show more of John's intentions and thought than any previous king. The narrative then unfolds in chronological order beginning with his birth to King Henry II and Eleanor of Aquitaine. John first appears in the historical record in 1177, the same year his father gave him Ireland to rule. He had the standard royal education in Latin and French, though Gerald of Wales found him unknightly and "least suitable for martial affairs." An 1185 excursion into Ireland largely failed presumably due to his ignoring experienced advice. Four years later, Henry II died and Richard I, John's older brother, took the throne. John seemed intent on undermining Richard especially when Richard fell into enemy hands while crusading. King Philip of France (later "Philip Augustus") also loomed on the continent waiting for opportunities to strike England. Eleanor of Aquitaine protected John a few times and John miraculously found himself forgiven by his enthroned brother. 1197 saw John somehow chosen as the heirless Richard's successor. John succeeded to the throne following Richard's death from gangrene in 1199. At this point England still ruled large portions of the continent. In 1200 things look good for the young king, though some thought he ceded too much to Philip after he demanded the land of the Vexin. John annulled his first marriage and married Isabella. Her dowry included cities on the continent. By 1201 English barons were growing tired of foreign wars and unrest began to stir. A victory at Mirebeau quelled the unrest and troops captured Arthur of Brittany (though John sapped morale by taking all of the credit). Much brewed around Normandy, Poitou and Anjou as Philip rested his sights on expanding his territory. John's execution of Arthur sullied him in his contemporaries' eyes. Things started to go badly.John only saw the continent a few more times again after his trip there in 1203. Upon his return to England, he started an assault of taxation that greatly undermined the power of the nobility but greatly expanded his own already bulging coffers. The justification was war against the French as crucial parts of Normandy and Anjou and Poitou had fallen to Philip. New perilous drama arose when Pope Innocent III suggested that John appoint Stephen Langton as the new Archbishop of Canterbury. John thought others more appropriate for the title and resisted. The issue dragged on as John hoarded coin to recessionary levels and lived in open luxury. The 1208 William de Briouze affair, in which John jailed his wife and son who later died in prison further boosted John's tyrannical reputation. Trust in him began to falter. He also increased the royal forest, annoying more nobles and the Pope threatened to excommunicate John over Langton. Regardless, by 1210 John controlled England, Scotland, Ireland and Wales. The book marks 1212 as the turning point. Predictions of John's death circulated. Those responsible were hung and any rumors of John's death were dealt with severely. By 1213 Philip prepared to invade England with the Pope's support. The crown would go to his son, Louis. But once again a miraculous defeat of the French fleet at Ghent saved John. Everything now weighed on John reconquering lost territories on the continent. Would all of the misery he inflicted on his own people presumably for this project pay off? Tensions heightened.Everything came crashing down at the Battle of Bouvines in 1214. Philip won decisively and any thoughts John had of conquering the continent ended. John wasn't even present at the battle, allegedly he was dealing with Poitou, which the author sums up as "the most significant moment of his life and he was not there." He found his kingdom in full rebellion. The barons begin talk of imposing a charter similar to that of the 1100 charter agreed to by Henry I. When they demand that he hold to its decrees John stalls and agrees to go on crusade, which sends Innocent III into fits of glee. Innocent, who once supported John's overthrow by Philip, now turns on the barons. By 1215 they find the Henry I charter insufficient and begin drafting a new charter which evolved from "the Unknown Charter" to the "Articles of the Barons" and finally to the first 1215 draft now known as Magna Carta. Proxies likely took the oath on June 15 at Runnymede and the actual parties met and banqueted there on June 18th. The mess seemed fixed, but clause 61, which decreed an unprecedented check on the king and instilled the right for the barons to wage war were the king not to live up the terms supposedly proved too much for Innocent III and he nullified the agreement as illegal in August. Outright rebellion followed. The barons sought John's abdication and replacement by Philip's son Louis. Louis arrived in England in 1216. The Pope excommunicated the rebellious barons and imposed an interdict on their lands. John had some favorable military outcomes but fell ill after a feast at Lynn. His doctors tried bleeding. Innocent III then died and was replaced by Honorius III. John also soon died while trying to make peace with the church that he had thoroughly ransacked. Whatever retribution he made with God, his kingdom lay in absolute disarray. In addition to losing the vast majority of his continental holdings, some of which he had given to his second wife as dowry, he had even lost control of the city of London. It's hard not to see this as an utterly disastrous failure.John's son, Henry III, then 9 years old, was rushed to the throne to keep any French claims at bay. A 70-year guardian was appointed and he amended Magna Carta to the 1216 version, which sealed a new agreement between the boy king and the barons. This version became the Magna Carta known to history. Louis' forces were defeated in 1217 and the civil war started under John's reign officially ended. The book ends with the reflection that John's own son, the same Henry III,  approved the effigy on his father's tomb at Worcester in 1232. This depiction of the then previous king, with drawn sword slightly bent by a lion, suggests unrest and rebellion. John's own son did not try to gloss over the issues of his father's rule, which probably helped solidify the already unfavorable reputation of this last Angevin king for generations to come."King John" does not include a detailed analysis of Magna Carta as the subtitle may suggest. It focuses on the life of King John and the events that led up to at least the first version of that influential document. The events of John's life shaped the future of both England, France and the Holy Roman Empire (Otto IV was overthrown following Bouvines) and eventually saturated the entire political thought of the West. This book, and the interesting narrative experiment it attempts, shows just how tightly his legacy remains indelibly intertwined with that of the document he fought so hard against. Though Magna Carta didn't come to full fruition until the reign of Henry III, the seeds were sown under the king considered by many as the most nefarious ever to hold the English throne. King John and Magna Carta. Magna Carta and King John. 800 years later the association still sticks. It will probably stick as long as humans roam this planet (after all, his name is on the document). "King John and the Road to Magna Carta" presents this important tale in an easily readable and highly enjoyable narrative.

Dogs urinate on landmarks and the acrid scent helps them find their way back from where they came. If rain falls during one of these canine adventures and washes away all of those helpful odors, a dog may find itself lost and wander aimlessly through a world devoid of olfactory guides. Tom Waits considers these lost "rain dogs" an apt analogy for the underclass of human society who similarly find themselves lost, misguided or abandoned in a strange and muddled world. A sort of red light district Woody Guthrie, the portraits Waits paints on his 1985 album "Rain Dogs" resonate with broken dreams, miserable love, seedy greed and incessant transience. As many unforgettable characters and stories permeate this album as musical styles.This album arose out of the shadows of the ineffable and almost miraculous transformation Waits undertook following 1980's "Heartattack and Vine." Everything culminated with "Swordfishtrombones" and this brilliant foundation produced the arguably more brilliant "Rain Dogs." No more a slurpy, haze infested, wise cracking diner denizen, this amazing development represented, to some critics, an artistic leap he didn't previously seem capable of. Waits still hasn't deviated from this mesmerizing direction rife with creepy dissonance, arrhythmic heartbeat skipping percussion, throat ripping half moaned, half hacked vocals and tales right out of dark steamy alleys, foamy clubs and dimly lit bar stools. His songs never moralize, at least not directly, they just paint pictures and allow listeners to draw their own conclusions or to feel cathartically queasy."Rain Dogs" remains one of Waits' best and most accessible collections. Some of his most straightforward rock and pop compositions appear scattered throughout the more angular quirky tracks, creating sonic surprises whenever their relative consonance bursts forth. The first instance occurs after the seventh song. The murky "Diamonds & Gold," which sounds sung through a dilapidated apartment intercom, reflects on greed and futile ambition, then explodes into the opening sonorous chords of "Hang Down Your Head," an almost straight out rock song. One of Waits' most moving ballads, "Time," follows and conjures piles of dead pigeons, anxiety rousing painful procedures, faded calendar girls, cars plummeting into water and bandages covering unknown wounds. Musically, it also feels comparatively straightforward and accessible. It would have made a great hit. Later, "Blind Love" goes all out beer splattered country. Fiddles and slide guitars on the verge of squealing express the passionate, but evidently misguided, love the raspy narrator bemoans.Unlike "Time," "Downtown Train," the last outright pop song on the album, did make the charts, but years later from the mouth of, of all people, Rod Stewart. This song definitely deserved more attention at the time of "Rain Dogs." An expertly crafted number loaded with unforgettable hooks and permanently unfulfilled and unrequited longing, it remains a largely unappreciated masterpiece. Around this time another of Waits' great songs, "Jersey Girl," fell into the hands of Bruce Springsteen. A live version appeared as the final song of his exhaustively encyclopedic 1986 box set "Live/1975-85." With the help of "Jersey Girl," the amazing songs of "Rain Dogs," and various acting roles, Waits gradually emerged into public consciousness in the 1980s.The remainder of "Rain Dogs" wades into more typical Waits territory. "Singapore," the jouncy eliptical opener, sees the narrator falling for a "tawny Moor," sailing on a ship captained by a "one-armed dwarf" and walking the sewers of Paris. Gentle bells, skeleton marimba and a great guitar solo drive the murky "Clap Hands." "Cemetery Polka" features "Uncle Vernon," who is "independent as a hog on ice" and other stingy deviants who claim "there ain't no pretty girls in France." The disturbing refrain "hey little bird, fly away home, the house is on the fire, your children all alone" haunts "Jockey Full of Bourbon." Even more incredible Tango-esque guitar provides the melodious color counter commentary. Wet lonely accordion opens the title track, which finds Waits declaring "for I am a rain dog too." It ends with the ominously poingnant line "you'll never be going back home." "9th & Hennepin" relates a sordid event Waits witnessed in Minneapolis, Minnesota, where "all the rooms smell like diesel" and "all the donuts had names that sound like prostitutes" and a crumbling beauty with a tattooed tear has "nothing wrong with her a hundred dollars can't fix." The final number, "Anywhere I Lay My Head," closes the show a twisted but defiantly inspiring note. For the bellowing narrator, home can appear anywhere. He doesn't need anyone, has grown accustomed to solitude and will seemingly continue to follow his meandering path, declaring his home as his current location. This rain dog lives everywhere and so will never find himself lost. The closing horns echo a New Orleans Dixieland funeral."Rain Dogs" contains an almost overwhelming diversity of styles that magically weave into a cohesive whole. The seeds sown on "Swordfishtrombones" flourish here in astounding ways. The show doesn't end here, of course, as Waits continues to develop his renaissance to the present day. "Frank's Wild Years," released in 1987, completed a trilogy of albums that helped establish Waits as one of the most singular, exciting and inventive composers of his era. And doubtless more is yet to come.

Many great responsive frameworks now exist and some developers may never need, or want, to know what actually goes on beneath the surface of these easy to use platforms. But some will want to go further for customization, fine tuning or merely for curiosity's sake. Anyone wanting to delve into the nitty gritty of how these responsive frameworks perform their magic will want to check out "Mobile ASP.NET MVC 5." "MVC 5" probably appears in the title for marketing reasons only, as the book's main concepts could probably apply to almost any web platform. A few chapters involve opening Visual Studio and creating MVC projects (sometimes MVC 4, sometimes MVC 5), but the emphasis remains largely on responsive techniques and client side code. Even the word "mobile" doesn't completely capture the book's main premise. "Responsive" probably works better. Perhaps "Responsive ASP.NET MVC" would serve as a better title? In any case, the book contains a lot of great information about making responsive sites that all definitely applies to developing for mobile devices.Though the word "Pro" doesn't appear in the title, note that the word "beginner" doesn't appear either. As such, the book assumes a decent familiarity with ASP.NET, MVC, Visual Studio (either 2012 or 2013 work fine), JavaScript and a little HTML5 and CSS. It espouses the now fairly familiar, and very helpful, philosophy that developers have absolutely no control over what devices their sites will appear on, so they should therefore develop sites that can adjust to different screen shapes and sizes. If you can't adjust the screen, adjust the site.A quick introductory chapter covers the main concepts at a brisk pace, but everything receives more detailed coverage later. The book first presents a non-responsive site to show off the many obvious disadvantages of this now aging approach. Then it turns this site into a responsive site using a flexible layout with flexible content, CSS media queries and the now ubiquitous "Viewport" meta tag. Code examples appear everywhere. A deep dive into CSS layout (called "a bootcamp") follows with CSS resets, floats, block and inline display, the box model, columns, menus and more. These early chapters set the stage for the rest of the book. Subsequent chapters cover voluminous topics, such as flexible layouts, flexible navigation, flexible content (with flexible text and flexible tables, images and video), MVC display modes, custom view engines, device and feature detection (both the hard way and the relatively easy way using WURFL), tips on optimization and performance, other tools for mobile development, touch development and finally frameworks.One of the best chapters discusses performance and contains very helpful tips that any developer should know to keep their sites from bogging down in the muck. Using Chrome Developer Tools and Fiddler as guides, it points out often overlooked flaws such as making too many HTTP requests, not using compression or not minifying. These concepts apply doubly to mobile development where bandwidth and storage often remain relatively tight.Some of the chapters just survey their subjects. One such later chapter called "Native APIs, HTML5, and CSS3 on Mobile Today" just provides very high level information on some newer technologies and techniques such as geolocation, web sockets, offline apps, transitions, canvas, etc. Most receive less than a page and very simple code examples. Two of the most challenging chapters involve programming for touch. These may cause some to flee in terror and let some of the popular frameworks do the heavy work. But anyone needing to make slight customized adjustments to a swipe gesture may suddenly find themselves deep in this material. Make sure to read up on JavaScript events before tackling these hefty chapters.Finally, the book discusses frameworks such as Bootstrap, Zurb, FitText, jQuery Mobile and others. Although it only presents a short list with simple examples, the book's website has live demos and allows framework shoppers to get a decent idea of just what each one may offer. Of all the frameworks presented, the author says that he had the hardest time setting up Sencha Touch (and no live demo appears on the website due to "complications"). Though he also admits that it uses a unique approach. After making it through this fairly short technical book, one will have a new appreciation for just how much development time these frameworks can save."Mobile ASP.NET MVC 5" reveals some of the guts of the latest responsive frameworks. It takes readers beyond the frameworks into deep, and sometimes challenging, territory. Absolute beginners should probably familiarize themselves with a framework or two to fully appreciate this book. But anyone desiring a dive into what makes responsive sites tick should read and study this book cover to cover.

Of all the musical transformations that occurred in twentieth century pop music, Talking Heads' "Remain In Light" probably stands as one of the most shocking. Following three albums of highly adventurous and experimental rock the band reinvented themselves almost beyond recognition with sounds and rhythms heavily influenced by African music (Fela Kuti in particular) and mad stream of consciousness ravings. This landmark fourth album had few, if any, precedents in western popular music. Maybe the band's own "I Zimbra," from their previous album, "Fear Of Music," represents the closest, or only,  predecessor. Their fourth album's thick churning stratified rhythms propel the music in very different ways to their relatively more standard previous arrangements. On top of that, lead singer David Byrne, with a host of backing vocalists, shouts and moans lines sounding right out of a passionate pulpit or an angry poetical psychoanalysis session. Feelings of joy, dread, angst, revelation and foot-stomping epiphany permeate the songs. The result sent pop music careening in entirely new directions while simultaneously shooting a bloody rift right through the band that didn't seem to heal. In terms of sheer musical inventiveness and lyrical expressiveness, "Remain in Light" arguably displays the Talking Heads' at the peak of their powers.A few drum thumps and a defiant shout launch a powerful rhythmic machine that manically rolls on for five songs. The album's first lyrics also set the mood. "Take a look at these hands!" Byrne pleads to the drums, the skies and the limbic system. As the layered guitars, effects and the occasional video game-esque sounds glacier their way through the senses, the beautiful refrain "all I want is to breathe" wafts up from the miasma and offers a gasp of relief. "Crosseyed and Painless" remains one of the band's masterpieces with references to shape changing, feeling like an accident, and a rather impressive epistemological rap about the ineffable and murky foundations of facts. Absolutely anyone can relate to the song's fist pounding mantra "I'm still waiting." "The Great Curve" celebrates our ultimate feminine origins. We all came from the curvy hips of women. Adrian Belew's searing guitar adds an otherworldly aura to the song's fading conclusion. These first three songs follow the same format: an almost hypnotic unchanging rhythmic structure lays down a solid foundation and the musicians and vocalists perform various themes over it in a sort of frenetic rhythmic polyphony."Once In A Lifetime" breaks the structure of the first three songs and adds more unforgettable sounds and words. It exhorts people into waking up and acknowledging the incomprehensible patterns and events that led to their respective present moments. Many have doubtlessly shouted "My god! What have I done?!" when faced with such hideous revelations. Many simply don't pay attention and let the days pass. In some ways, this song builds on themes first presented two years earlier in "The Big Country." Yet another masterpiece. "Houses in Motion" features a dreary, and often hilarious, narrator decrying his previous uncouth habit of "wearing shoes with no socks in cold weather." The chorus explodes over Byrne's nearly monotone ramblings. A synthesized blowing wind solo drifts between two choruses and continues to haunt the song's instrumental second half. "Seen and Not Seen," arguably the album's most forgettable song, appears to exist as a framework for the spoken word vocals describing people's attempts to change their facial structures by pure and concentrated thought. Not surprisingly, some people "get half way there" and "change their minds." "Listening Wind" probably ranks as the saddest of all Talking Heads' songs. An incredibly gorgeous and moving piece, it talks of the loss felt by an indigenous man following the European conquest of the Americas. Suggestions of violent and angry retribution weave through the lyrics, but ultimately the wind in Mojique's heart will "drive them away." "The Overload" ends the show with dire disjointed reflections: "A gentle collapsing," "I'm touched by your pleas," "the center is missing." A reverberating bass tone wavers ominously beneath these same observations as they meander just beyond logic. It feels comprehensible and incomprehensible all at once, making for a disturbingly meditative ending.Following "Remain In Light, which apparently had disappointing early sales, the Talking Heads toured, released their first, and lesser-known, live album and essentially went on an extended hiatus. They returned with another great album, but one with a direction notably directed more towards pop music than the bold experimentation of "Remain In Light." During this three year gap, David Byrne released two solo albums, the Tom Tom Club formed and dominated the dance charts with "Genius Of Love," Jerry Harrison released "The Red and the Black" and the band parted ways with producer Brian Eno (who  received a writer's credit for "Remain In Light"; his voice also appears on several tracks). Apparently, the band had philosophical and musical disagreements that seemed to terminate the general path of their first four albums. They would subsequently regroup and find staggering success in the 1980s, but they wouldn't venture down untraveled paths again until their final album. In a way, "Remain In Light" cleaves their work in two. This, their most daring adventure, seemed to split the seams and initiate what Byrne eventually called "bad blood." They managed to hold things upright for eleven more years and through many more tumultuous periods, great music and even through wild commercial success. But likely the Talking Heads will mostly endure in musical memory for the creative heights they reached on "Remain In Light."

Japanese songwriter Tsuji Ayano said she built her career around the ukulele because of her small hands. Their tiny size apparently didn't allow her to hold and play a guitar properly (did she try smaller sized guitars?). So she downsized all the way to the one of the smallest stringed instruments of all. Her trademark quickly became this dainty instrument melded with her melodious and often cute vocals. In her earlier music videos and concerts she often presented an almost catatonically stoic persona, rarely cracking a smile or displaying any hint of physical emotion as she strummed her poignant songs of heartbreak, longing and loss. This exuded an aura of disaffectedness, as though keeping everything in her presence at a great distance. Or did this help her deal with nervousness? In any case, it provided a stark contrast to her very emotional music.Ayano eventually signed to a major label in Japan, but prior to this she recorded a short and somewhat roughly produced independent album called "Uraraka." Containing just six songs, Ayano, her ukulele, a guitarist (supposedly not her due to the previously mentioned hand size issue) and backing vocals (perhaps Ayano overdubbed), it lacks some of the polish of her major label releases, but it still packs plenty of charm. Ayano fans will instantly realize that her writing, performing and lyrical styles all begin with this small album. She still sounds this way overall, but her songwriting has since developed exponentially. On this, her earliest available recording, her voice hasn't quite developed its full strength, some of the playing sounds a little shaky and it doesn't really sound professionally produced. Still, it probably helped her land a recording contract, so it goes way beyond tinny AM radio fidelity and rolls of sea shore tape hiss.Many of the songs appeared on her later major label releases. "Kuloobaa" ("Clover"), easily the most recognizable to long time Ayano fans, begins the album with a guitar introduction. Ukulele soon arrives along with Ayano's vocals. The final song, a beautiful ballad (which also sounds accompanied by guitar), appeared, along with "Clover," on her first full-length album two years later. Snippets of tape-recorded ambient sounds fill some of the gaps between songs. Ayano's voice stands out clearly in these interludes. In one, she strums and sings a few bars of a song that surfaced on a later album. Another features a distant prolonged buzz, similar to a subway or train signal and a jumbled mass of voices. These episodes do provide some variety between the sparsely arranged songs. The CD booklet features photos of a very young Ayano without her now trademark glasses. It almost doesn't look like her. The back cover shows skinny lower legs terminating in sandal-covered feet with toes playfully touching.Ayano never found extreme success, even in her native Japan, but she apparently found enough for someone to re-release this 1998 independent album. The CD lists "Living, Dining and Kitchen Records" ("LD&K") as the label, not her current label Speedstar. LD&K's website gives the appearance of a smaller label and Ayano's "Uraraka" doesn't seem to appear anywhere. So perhaps it now resides in "out of print" status? Ayano continues to record, though her output has slowed considerably in the past few years. Mostly known for her theme song to the Studio Ghibli anime, "The Cat Returns," her Japanese blog shows her giving ukulele workshops, playing music festivals and hanging out with friends (and eating some incredible looking food). "Uraraka" offers a fascinating glimpse of Ayano's beginnings and also demonstrates how far she has come since those early glassless days.

No one can ignore the climate. We're embedded directly in it day by day with no real escape, whether inside or outside. Arguably, we humans emerged from climate itself and our fate and the climate's fate remain forever intertwined. After all, our ancestors, or even most of earth's life, could not have appeared, developed and survived if our global climate hadn't produced conditions amenable to life. Venus and Mars both seem like utter wastelands to our eyes, though either may have held life in the past or possibly will hold life in the future. It all depends on their climates, neither of which look hospitable to life at the present time. Only earth contains all of the elements and climate, that we know of, to help life flourish. Just how long this planet will remain habitable for creatures such as ourselves presents a rather serious question. In any case, our inextricable relation to our world and its climate make even a basic understanding of its workings essential knowledge for anyone residing on this rocky watery ball. It's our life support system, after all, at least for the foreseeable future.Gaining this valuable knowledge doesn't come easy, as anyone who has attempted to read "Climate: A Very Short Introduction" has probably realized. At only some 150 pages, it looks deceptively breezy and light. Begin reading and a density akin to neutron stars billows from its conceptually thick pages. Those with no prior knowledge of this hefty subject may struggle, especially if one's goal involves a detailed understanding. A book of this length can usually only impart knowledge of a higher level, but even considering that this book presents challenges. Still, those up for the challenge will learn so many fascinating and useful things that the effort will pay off in droves. As the information seeps in, it becomes more comprehensible. Prepare to read some chapters two or three times. Take notes. Draw the diagrams out on paper to enhance understanding. Watch supplementary Internet videos on the more difficult topics. Basically, make this book a study project and it will pay off. Even without these extra techniques the book will prove an interesting and informational read, but to really get the most out of it requires a deeper engagement than simply reading the words.The opening chapter, "What is climate?" provides a fairly easy beginning to the book. It points out the ways we rely on climate and how climate determines our lifestyles, clothing and even our cultures. Then it quickly moves into more technical areas, such as earth-sun geography, the creation of seasons and the transfer of heat around the globe, which ultimately creates climate. This heat transfer to address energy imbalance takes place in the atmosphere and in the oceans. Very detailed discussions of each of these mechanisms follows. Greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane and water vapor) create the famous Greenhouse Effect, which, according to most scientists, both nurtures and threatens us. Many physical formations contribute to this effect via their albedo rates. The formation of the Hadley, Ferrell and Polar cells, the jet streams and the earth's desert and rain belts all result from energy transfer in the atmosphere. In the oceans, complicated spiraling motions started by surface winds results in motion modeled by Ekman motion, inertia and geostrophic currents. All of this fuels the circulation of heat through ocean water, which sends the Gulf Stream northwards to warm Europe. Further complications arise from the interaction between ocean water's salinity and water's freezing point. These seemingly simple concepts drive many ocean currents. These first few chapters provide a brain full of information that may take some time to digest fully, but it's worth it.Chapter three addresses one of the major misunderstandings around climate today: the difference between climate and weather. Weather is not climate, weather is localized. Climate determines weather, but climate warming can affect different areas in different ways. Some cool off, some warm up. As usual, it's not completely straight-forward. This leads into chaos theory, El Niño, La Niña and ENSO. Climate modeling, which spurns much current debate, through over twenty independent AOGCMs, and taking into consideration variable greenhouse gas rates, predicts temperature increases from 1.8 to 4 degrees Celsius by 2100. This book appeared before the 2013 IPCC report, so it relies on data from the 2007 report.Subsequent chapters cover voluminous topics, such as: hurricanes, tornadoes, winter storms and monsoons; the effects of plate tectonics on climate (supercontinents do not appear friendly to life); icehouse ("Snowball earth") versus greenhouse earths (and why we don't have either); the general climate of the past 100 million years (derivable from frozen air bubbles in ice cores; the controversial work of Bill Ruddiman; global cooling, which culminated during the Great Ice Ages of the past 2.5 million years; the earth's axis wobble and how it affects climate; Heinrich events; the Holocene and countless other topics that defy summary.Later chapters talk about the strong evidence for human-induced climate change (something that remains heavily debated in the United States media), the misunderstandings of "Climategate" (which resulted in no charges), the ominous effects of climate change (more extreme weather, floods, droughts, sea level rise and water and food insecurity), and potential solutions to the climate problem. Scientific groups have suggested three approaches to "fixing" climate change: reducing carbon emissions, removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and altering the amount of solar radiation the earth absorbs. The book favors investment in alternative energy to reduce carbon dioxide levels, geoengineering in the form of reforestation and Carbon Storage and Capture (CSC) and a huge emphasis on adaptation to current and future climactic conditions. It doesn't ignore the enormous political, social and technological barriers that obviously exist.A sobering final chapter looks at the current science around the fate of the earth and its ability to support life. Anyone desiring a happy ending should stop reading here. A new ice age could apparently happen anytime between now and the next 1,000 years. A new supercontinent, generally bad for life, could form in 50 to 150 million years. A few billion years from now the earth will heat up to the point where the oceans will evaporate. No multi-cellular lifeforms will survive this era. Eventually, even the most robust microorganisms will die off in the extreme heat. In around five billion years the sun, which doesn't have enough mass to supernova, will morph into a massive Red Giant, essentially frying planet earth. Later a nebula will form as what remains of the sun fades into a white dwarf. And that's it.Such a stark ending will probably result in reflections on humanity and our place in this enormous miasma called the Universe. We don't seem to have feasible alternatives to the planet that we inhabit and rely on. Miraculous technological advances need to occur before the idea of inhabiting the recently discovered, and light years distant, exoplanets even becomes a realistic consideration. We have enough trouble reaching the moon. This book will drive home our utter reliance on a life-friendly climate and just how complicated and fragile that climate is. Though densely challenging throughout, the effort pays off in vital knowledge and perspective about some of the most hotly debated issues today. Hopefully we'll do the right thing, but learning must come before decisions. As such, no one can afford ignorance about the complex but critical information contained in this little book.

One could interpret the title of the Beatles' final album, emblazoned in high contrast white on black above iconic images of the defunct band, as an exhortation to "let it go." In other words, the band broke up, they're done, no more, they're an ex-band, in past tense, history, just let it go, let it be already. Of course no one could, not even the band itself. By the time "Let it Be" filled store shelves in May 1970 the once lovable mop tops had entwined each other in angry and puerile accusations and lawsuits that seemed almost satirical. So much so that Monty Python member Eric Idle spoofed this period in his hilarious parodic Beatles tribute called "The Rutles." His mockumentary announces that The Rutles released their final album, called "Let It Rot," as "a record, a film and a lawsuit." One could laugh or cry at such painfully accurate satire. Litigation aside, by the time "Let It Be" arrived everyone sadly knew The Beatles as The ex-Beatles. Paul McCartney's departure announcement and solo album, which had appeared a mere month before "Let It Be," had already trumpeted the most famous and acrimonious breakup in rock history. And no one could let it be.The album itself, by no means the best album the group had produced, almost disappeared behind all of the controversy. Culled and modified by Phil Spector from hours of tireless, and sometimes viscous, 1969 "Get Back" recording sessions, the album manages to still hold together and sound great, though arguably not quite as astounding as the Beatles' actual final recordings that produced the masterpiece "Abbey Road." Nonetheless, "Let It Be" contains some real stunning compositions, including the gorgeous title track, the equally beautiful "The Long and Winding Road," "Across The Universe" and "Get Back." Punctuated by studio chatter, some false starts and a few tiny charming throwaway ditties, the album, especially for a Beatles album, sometimes feels a little uneven. But considering the album's source, hours upon hours of unedited takes, retakes and noodling around, the results approach the miraculous. Of course a few disputes arose. Though Spector's "wall of sound" enhanced Harrison's passionate lament to selfishness, "I Me Mine," controversy surrounded the same treatment applied to "The Long and Winding Road." McCartney openly decried it, though the public didn't seem to care as the single throttled up the charts to number one in 1970. Apart from that, the remainder of the album comprises mostly rock songs, the relatively folk traveling song "Two of Us" and the bluesy "For You Blue," notwithstanding. The Beatles seemed intent on returning to downright rock n'roll, the apparent goal of the abandoned "Get Back" project. "Dig A Pony" has a fabulously wailing chorus drenched with signature rock desire. "I've Got A Feeling" features wildly distorted guitar and a steady rock rhythm. "One After 909" hails from Lennon and McCartney's early days and almost feels rockabilly. The closing track, "Get Back," recorded live from the Beatles' last public performance on a Savile Row rooftop, brings the Beatles to a rollicking close. What better way to end than Lennon's great "I hope we passed the audition" remark? The fading to legend began.That the Beatles never fully reunited probably accounts for their still enduring legacy. They remain the pinnacle of rock success and only the staggering increase in population since the 1960s probably allows others to break their sales records. Like movie stars that retired or died young, they ended at a youthful peak, remembered frozen in time at the moment of their departure. Since they also never returned they also never had an opportunity to fail or to release an embarrassing geriatric dud. As such, the band remains largely untainted, regardless of varying opinions concerning their subsequent, and admittedly sometimes shaky, solo releases. They managed to escalate popular music, once thought only the domain of vacuous bubble gum teenage sentiment, to an art form. The entire culture went with them, at least for a time. As they pushed their boundaries so did popular music itself. Progressive rock, folk rock and even alternative rock followed in their wake. Their influence has arguably begun to wane only within the past decade, and then only slightly. But all things must pass, as Harrison famously titled his first post-Beatles mega-release, maybe as poetic therapy for mourning Beatles fanatics. Individual band members never completely escaped their original quartet personae and the two still surviving members still haven't. How could they? The Beatles were a very big deal that resonated through multiple successive generations. Eventually, a far removed generation, possibly the current one, will no longer comprehend the big bang that the Beatles exploded with onto popular culture. Times change, but many legends endure. The Beatles will likely endure, at the very least as legendary echoes through the eons, as long as humans continue to study twentieth century popular music. When those future historians, now mere wispy indeterminate imaginings, uncover the box of musical wonders left behind by the Fab Four, doubtless they won't be able to let it be either. But who really knows how the distant future will judge or value the current age's artifacts? It's out of our control completely, beyond even our comprehension (as far as we know). So, at the risk of sounding overly repetitive or trite, let's take The Beatles' advice, enjoy what we treasure today, and let it be.

Japanese artist Yoshihiro Tatsumi proves that comics, often associated with puerile adolescent escapism, can explore deep and disturbing elements of human life. He coined the term "gekiga" for a very adult-oriented subgenre of manga that encompasses everything from violence, perversion and alienation to even outright desperation. Often shocking in their portrayal of everyday people lost in the mass, they miraculously never come off as gratuitous or sensationalist. They seem largely realistic and true to human nature, which may explain their penetrating emotional power. Though Tatsumi's books have appeared in many comic book stores, often sitting right next to manga for teens and pre-teens, these remain adult comics through and through. They would without doubt receive at least an "R" rating today, though at the time of their writing many may have argued for "X." Nudity, sex, violence, scenes of death, mutilation and themes situated light years outside of the realm of more youth-targeted escapist manga permeate nearly every story. This work reveals aspects of reality that some would probably rather not consider, but that many know exist regardless of our idealistic wishes for humanity. Tastumi manages to show us pieces of who we really are, an incredible achievement for comic art.Comic publishers Drawn and Quarterly have reissued numerous volumes of Tatsumi's work in English from the 1950s to the present. The third volume, "Good-Bye" features short stories from the early 1970s. A chilling story, "Hell," opens the book and features a horrendously misinterpreted shadow burnt into a building by the Hiroshima atomic bomb. A photographer re-energizes his fame by selling a photograph of this image and all of Japan rejoices and celebrates the humanity of what appears as a son dutifully rubbing his mother's back at the time of the bomb's detonation. One of Tatsumi's best and most disturbing stories, it sears into the conscience and deconstructs the human trait of seeing the best in everything. It also contains this volume's most horrifying imagery in depicting post-war Hiroshima. Not for the morally or visually squeamish. "Woman in the Mirror" challenges notions of masculinity and the pressures it exerts, not to mention the sometimes crushing social isolation of gender roles and expectations. "Night Falls Again" explores social and sexual loneliness in the mass. A young man trapped in a menial job frequents strip clubs and peep shows and finds out that he can't relate to real women. Though he revels in the seediness of Osaka, it also overwhelms him to the point of vomiting. Sex obsesses him to the point of all out entrapment and distraction. Total acquiescence seems his only option, or at least the only one he entertains. "Just a Man" finds an old man finally achieving his dream girl, but this astonishing realization keeps some important things from functioning properly. "Life is so Sad" deals with fickle loyalty. A woman working as a "companion" in a night club awaits the release of her husband following four years of incarceration. The man treats her with contempt when she visits him in prison. She professes deep love though he laughs in her face while accusing her of disloyalty. One night before his release, she breaks down and shatters all expectations. The story's final panel will leave readers pondering the woman's intentions and psychology, though some may disturbingly understand and relate. "Click Click Click" looks at the solitude of fetishism and perversion. An independently wealthy man seeks pleasure through women's boots and heels while simultaneously performing acts of charity. He lives for the clicking sound of women's shoes. "Good-bye," the final story, takes place in post-war Japan. An American soldier woos a poor woman and promises to marry her. Her father comes only to beg for money. Following further betrayals, she disowns her own father in an inconceivable way that the vast majority of daughters wouldn't even acknowledge. "Now he's just another man..." she tells herself. Guilt, loss and the humiliation of losing the war reverberate in the story's recesses.Not for the faint of heart, this volume further testifies to Tatsumi's artistic and literary skills. He flouts the narrative form to great effect, dashing expectations of happy endings, some sort of "life lesson" or conclusive resolution. These stories may hit a little too close to home for some people, causing either cathartic convalescence or rabid disavowals of their categorization as "entertainment." Indifferent reactions seem the most unlikely. Thanks to Drawn and Quarterly, Tatsumi has now found an audience in the United States, though the book's introduction states that he remains almost unknown in Japan. In the book's closing interview, Tatsumi claims that none of his work received much response until a French translation appeared in 1983. His work didn't reach a wide audience until the publication of these collections in English began around 2005. He says he remained fairly poor throughout his artistic career. Thankfully, the relative popularity of these books has led to further releases of his work, including brand new material. Some things apparently take time.

The heyday of Baroque guitar has long passed, of course, though a mild resurgence of interest in this almost obsolete and rarely heard instrument seems to have emerged in the past few decades. It reigned as a dominant European chordophone from roughly 1600 to 1750 and eventually morphed into a primordial modern guitar. Much smaller than its modern namesake, with 5 string courses (each course contains two strings to create a doubling effect, like a modern 12-string guitar), it resembles a rococo ukulele and sounds similar enough to a lute for uninitiated listeners to mistake it for one. Many featured breathtakingly elaborate decorations on their soundholes, bridges and fretboards. Looking fully like delicate and precious museum pieces, most now sit ominously silent and out of reach, as though encased in some form of invisible solemn amber, in those austere temples of cultural preservation. Given that, and other obvious reasons, the musically curious must usually resort to reproductions to hear this instrument. Many incredible reproductions exist, including the one played by Jerry Willard on the collection appropriately titled "The Baroque Guitar."Containing numerous examples from four of the instrument's most celebrated composers (Sanz, Murcia, Logy and Roncalli), this entire album features solo baroque guitar exquisitely played with historically accurate techniques. From the rollicking rasgueado of "Canarios" to the more delicate finger plucking of a Prelude by Roncalli, it covers a vast array of Baroque guitar styles and repertoire. Many will recognize Sanz's gorgeous "Maricapalos," often called one of the most beautiful melodies in all classical music. This and the rousing "Clarines Y Trompetas" that opens the album all come from Sanz's guitar method books, in tabulature, in 1674 and 1675. Murcia's "Folias Gallegas" demonstrates an interesting plucking technique that produces bell-like tones. "Gaitas" would provide an ideal soundtrack for a walk through a lush landscapes with perfect weather. "Paspied Viejo, Paspied Nuebo" contains a regal marching rhythm that probably suited the social class that had access to this music. Requisite dances from suites by both Murcia and Logy display the versatility and range of this small instrument. A reflectively lyrical Passacaglia by Roncalli ends the album and the musical time travel.This collection definitely evokes what we think its era would probably sound like. A general glut of recordings from the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries obviously injects a dose of speculation into interpretation. Nonetheless, this album sounds genuinely historical and features an instrument that arguably fell into unjustified neglect centuries ago. Sadly, the trudging of history, power structures and the endless human fascination for the new can leave even astounding artistic achievements choked in the dust. This album helps resurrect one of those bygone eras filled with music that still remains appealing today.

Many consider the Tiffany Transcriptions the finest recordings made by Bob Wills and His Texas Playboys. They nearly define western swing, which hit its popular peak in the mid twentieth century, and exude an addictive spontaneity that hasn't lost its appeal for over half a century. The group's immense popularity likely derived from its inventive amalgam of country, blues, jazz, swing and even some shades of primordial rock. Churning fiddles, lightly distorted flying guitars, rollicking piano rolls, thumping swing rhythms and Wills' often hilarious vocal intrusions make this music instantly recognizable and timelessly unique. The Tiffany Transcriptions, recorded for a furniture company in 1946 and 1947, feature a fully live ensemble uncut and unaltered. Occasionally notes get missed and, in the days before perfectionist overdubbing, these rare flubs remain intact (recordings of false starts and complete breakdowns also exist). Wills' exhortations manage to crack up the lead vocalist more than a few times. Fun fills the air and everyone joins in. Wills even announces the soloists by name, graciously conceding the floor to some very impressive musicians. Though the initial  collection spans ten albums, many more recordings lurk in vaults awaiting discovery. Some of these lost recordings appeared in a two disc set in April, 2014 called "Riding Your Way, The Lost Transcriptions for Tiffany Music." More will probably arrive.Volume Four of the original ten volume set featured a Texas theme in title and song theme. "You're From Texas" opens with the Playboy's unforgettable theme song based on the excellent "Nancy Jane." The title track starts with a great ad-libbed moment (or at least a very effective scripted moment)  after Wills howls "Texas, our home state," he suddenly says "what you grinnin' about?" and a band member answers "mine too." Without missing a beat, Wills drawls his trademark "yeaaaah!" Wills' commentary on the line "you got a smile like an acre of sunflowers" nearly breaks down vocalist Tommy Duncan. "Beaumont Rag" provides yet another great example of the band's ability to define swing. "Lum & Abner Special" begins with a tribute to fans who wore out 21 copies of Wills' staggeringly popular "San Antonio Rose." They then play an incredible version featuring a rather heavy, chunky and almost jarring guitar part where horns usually play in the song's introduction. Other highlights include the early cowboy "Little Joe the Wrangler," the not so incredibly politically correct, but swinging "Across the Valley From the Alamo," the stirring "Along the Navaho Trail," the yearning ballad, "My Brown Eyed Texas Rose," has Wills poignantly crooning with Duncan and the instantly recognizable "Red River Valley," which the band transforms into a raucous foot stomping swing number. A closing version of The Playboy's theme bookends the album and attains adequate parallelism.Though this fourth volume contains numerous high points and amazing tracks, it doesn't quite have the power and pull of the three preceding volumes. Things get off to a frenzied start and then the energy lapses for a few songs, only to pick up briefly and sag a little again before the set ends. No one would probably call anything here outright awful or even missable, just not precisely up to the band's and the Tiffany Transcriptions' usual stellar standards. It still delivers enough western swing oomph to make more than a few listens worthwhile. The effect may even heighten for those actually from Texas. Texan or not, swing away.

Spastic. That one word may sum up the experience of listening to the almost amazingly hyper Japanese band Polysics. Mix a gallon of potent energy drinks with ripsaw distorted guitar, jackhammer pogo stick rhythms, frenetic half sung half screamed vocals and indescribable electronic treatments, then pour on a layer of mostly Japanese lyrics scattered with English words. Something resembling the Polysics will bubble up from that crackling static electric brew. No one would describe them as relaxing. They affectively simulate a mega caffeine overdose or a near death adrenaline rush. The polymorphic nature of their songs heightens the effect. Some flash from head thrashing rhythms to eerie synthesizer laden interludes, then back again to explosively jarring bursts. Music sounding right out of classic video games often punctuates their beguiling arrangements, almost as if the song had lost a life while gaming only to stand right up and face the world yet again. Until the end of the song, of course. Some may find the effect overwhelming.Their 9th album from 2009, "Absolute Polysics" may qualify as their most aggressively energetic. The assault on the senses never ceases. A short pithy instrumental called simply "P!" launches the album off video game style. Images of Mario bashing his head into blocks and smooshing mushrooms may waft from consciousness. This erupts Krakato style into "Shout Aloud!" a phrase that seems like a laughable understatement when juxtaposed with the wailing music that suddenly flows. Buzzy robotic vocals start it off, followed by triple time hammered aorta bursting drums periodically interrupted by a wall of synth filled with beguiling female vocals. A downright fantastic amalgam of styles and moods. "Young OH! OH!" continues the spaz out drenched with flaming guitar and more earth shattering beats. Guitar thudding like a pile driver in a flanger races through "Hypnotize Go." The intermittent countdowns create the aura of a war zone, with doomsday missles at the ready. Once again, retro video game tunes sprout from "Time Out," another raucous instrumental. "E.L.T.C.C.T," one of the album's best songs, features female lead vocals, an utterly angular and indescribable arrangement and an absolutely unforgettable chorus. This one almost approaches Captain Beefheart. "First Aid" probably qualifies as the album's most abrasive song as its bellowed chorus nearly stretches the envelope to outright speed metal. "Eye Contact," though still a fast driving song, feels like a paranoid 1980s pop song. "Wasabi" ends the album with more female lead vocals, which often sound strangely cute, and esoteric melodic experimentation. All out end of the world chaos erupts a few times followed with the heavily accented lines "just a little bit." One last Armageddon, burgeoning with terrified screams of immanent destruction fade the song, and the album, and possibly all of existence, to conclusion. It probably accurately reproduces the effect of taking a mouth filling bite off a heaping mound of gleaming chartreuse wasabi. One's world probably would end. Screaming would happen, at the very least.Borrowing and deriving sounds and rhythms from western punk, Polysics seem to provide a logical extension of that era's musical exploration. They sound simultaneously historical and current. Futuristic throwbacks, they often dress in outfits that Devo would approve of while pumping out music that can sound straight off XTC's grittier early releases. They also hold the distinction, rare for a Japanese band, of making a significant splash in the west. They have toured the United States and appeared on UK television. Right around the time of "Absolute Polysics," popular keyboardist Kayo left the band. In 2004 she had also recorded a relatively laid back solo EP. She apparently wanted to try having a "normal life." After years in the hyperactive Polysics, her pulse has probably just returned to normal. The band now records and tours as a trio, with no sign of their addictive pep having waned. "Absolute Polysics" showcases the band at their best and may even provide a safer alternative to energy drinks.

Anyone who creates websites, particularly ones requiring security, should know at least the basics of HTTP. This ubiquitous and simple protocol essentially runs the entire Internet using simple text messages transmitted between web servers and other proxies. Beneath all that web application code and ASP.NET session objects, HTTP sends the messages that make the world wide web work. The aptly titled, "What Every Web Developer Should Know About HTTP" will give anyone fundamental knowledge on this critically important protocol. Its main audience remains beginners throughout, so experienced developers likely won't learn a great deal. Regardless, those needing a refresher will find an easy to follow review.This small book covers a slew of topics, including URL structure, "%" encoding, MIME, HTTP request and response messages (focusing on GET and POST), HTTP status codes, numerous HTTP headers, the POST/redirect/GET pattern, connections with TCP and the communication stack layers, parallel and persistent connections, proxy servers (forward and reverse), caching (public and private), cookies, (session and persistent), authentication protocols (basic, digest, windows, forms, OpenId) and HTTPS. Some sections also delve into the trade-offs and issues with choosing one direction over another (everything is a trade-off in the end). Cookies have definite downsides, for example. They can provide an easy built-in state tracking technique, but not handling them correctly could lead to Cross Side Server Scripting vulnerabilities (XSS). Data stored in cookies, again, if not handled efficiently, may actually sit exposed to malicious eyes. HTTPS, though unavoidable in any secure development situation, does have performance ramifications. The book covers all of these topics and more in at least a high-level fashion. Best of all, most will finish it in one or two readings.Developers should quickly move beyond this material as their careers progress. By itself, it doesn't provide enough information to deeply troubleshoot HTTP issues, though it does point to useful tools such as Fiddler and WireShark. It will make more detailed books and websites more accessible. And after inhaling all of the information here, new developers should jump right into more extensive and intricate technical sources.
