The more one knows about HTTP the better one can uncover those annoying and difficult to trace problems that inevitably arise with today's more complex web development frameworks and platforms. Start, but don't end, here.

Understandably, few will likely enjoy, appreciate or understand George Harrison's second solo album, "Electronic Sound." Listening to it cold, especially without any historical context or knowledge of early synthesizers, may give the impression of a random, possibly drug-induced miasma without direction or purpose. Anyone could easily reduce it to "weirdness for weirdness' sake" and drop the whole lot in the nearest rubbish bin. Not only that, even those possessing proper knowledge to comprehend this admittedly unique and bizarre creation may not find much pleasure in it. Parts of it do come across as mere fiddling. Everyone obviously has the right to loathe it. But to simply dismiss it as lunacy or as Harrison's "Yoko Ono collaboration," or as a puerile succession of "electronic burps and farts," as one critic apparently wrote, frames the album unfairly.In 1969 Moog synthesizers had just barely appeared. The previous year Wendy Carlos, then Walter Carlos, released an album of synthesized Bach that sold astonishingly well (Carlos also performed synthesized classics for "Clockwork Orange"). Interest in this new instrument exploded and the Beatles, possessing endless musical curiosity, wanted to explore. Harrison eventually purchased his own Moog. At about the same time, Apple records then inaugurated their experimental, avant-garde and extremely ephemeral label "Zapple." It claimed to embrace "new sounds" and the Moog seemed like an appropriate candidate. So, in the spirit of the avant-garde, "Electronic Music" hit the store shelves.Listeners today probably find the synthesized sounds unimpressive or similar to early annoying video game noises (but perhaps it could spawn a "retro sound" movement). The intention apparently wasn't to write tonal music for the Moog, but maybe to explore the possibilities of the instrument. "No Time or Space," the second track on the album, sounds like a playful Moog showcase. Some sounds on this piece mimic the real world, such as gunshots, fireworks, white noise, wind and bubbling. Others sound nearly otherworldly. It puts the range of the Moog clearly on display, whether one enjoys the show or not. And for 1969 this was probably pretty freaky and edgy stuff. The idea that a keyboard fitted with an intestinal morass of wires plugged into what looked like a miniature phone operator's switch board could produce such a wild array of sounds probably astonished many people (anyone who has played with an actual Moog knows the challenges). Arguably, the Moog at this stage represented the electronic music equivalent of the Atari 2600, apart from the price, of course. The synthesizer, not to mention home video games, have since evolved in shocking ways. "Electronic Sound" sits at the cusp of the electronic music revolution and it remains a historical relic of its pre-digital age. Though it definitely sounds dated to 21st century ears, the fun nonetheless comes through in the episodic pieces.Though few would probably consider "Electronic Sound" a masterpiece - not to mention the fact that George Harrison's name alone likely keeps the album alive - this new reissue and remaster preserves a moment in time towards the very end of the Beatles' reign when things began to change. Their final album, "Abbey Road," featured Moog, which may remain Harrison's album's most important legacy. The reissue includes a booklet - also included with the download, thankfully - that includes all of Harrison's interesting cover artwork and tells the album's entire story, controversies and all. One of the project's collaborators wanted his name obliterated from the album cover. A blotch of silver paint under Harrison's name resulted. Also included are photographs of Harrison, McCartney and an obscured Ringo in front of a Moog. Looking at McCartney, arms folded in the back of the room, one is tempted to think that he wasn't too impressed - or maybe just exhausted. A final photo shows Harrison's ominous and nearly intimidating Moog IIIP today. One can only imagine what it cost in the late 60s. Concerning the unique cover art, Harrison's son Dhani contributes an intriguing story about how he came to possess the original painting. He also relates when his father interpreted the painting for him. Harrison, Neil Aspinall, Mal Evans and even Eric Clapton were portrayed in the artwork's thick childlike strokes. Dhani has nothing to say about the album itself. Lastly, Tom Rowlands of the Chemical Brothers provides an introduction about how he came across the album in a shop in Japan. He immediately bought it and claims that it still provides him voluminous inspiration. So not everyone has gushed hate on this album. Still, "Electronic Sound" will not please everyone and it often gets categorized as a mere historical curiosity. And maybe that's all it is today. Regardless, it showcases George Harrison's vast exploratory scope and, with mind wide open, can even be kind of fun to listen to.

Moments before everyone thought the world would end, circa 1999, the now almost vanished UK band XTC seemed on the brink of an explosive Renaissance. Having wriggled free from a stranglehold recording contract, "Apple Venus, Vol.1" burst forth and coated the brains of happy fans pent up from years of forced abstinence. The band had a new liberating record label, gave numerous interviews suggesting that they now felt unchained from the musical equivalent of Hades and optimism and a new millennium awaited. Onward musical soldiers!But wait. Long time member Dave Gregory then ejected. Apparently it was personal. The new CD only pictured two members and demoted Gregory to the "additional musicians" list. The bane of all optimism is reality. Things suddenly seemed to wobble and crack. And, of course, the world was obviously ending since a year terminating in three noughts approached ominously. It was written. Well, it was written in the collective human psyche fascinated and somewhat deluded by the certainty sometimes promised by numbers.Right around this very moment a curious relic appeared called "A School Guide To XTC." What? School? Wasn't lead singer and songwriter Andy Partridge the self-proclaimed "Mayor of Simpleton" possessing no academic credentials of any kind? It turns out that the school theme did not denote any deconstructionist, phenomenologist, structuralist, existentialist or platypusologistic agenda. No degrees required here. All are welcome. School merely provided an outline for an extended essay on XTC written by Italian critic Massimiano Bucchi for the 21st installment of an Italian series known as "Sonic Books." This series had previously featured Don Van Vliet ("Captain Beefheart") reading poetry, pre-Pink Floyd Syd Barret, Sex Pistols demos and other interesting miscellany untouched by vast distribution. XTC had joined the ranks, complete with a CD containing six tracks recorded by a somewhat primordial XTC under the name "Star Park" dating from 1972. Six years would pass before "White Music" introduced XTC to the world's aural canals. This CD represents some very deep archeology. Think pre-Neolithic.Star Park, as a listen to the CD reveals, had a ways to go. Perhaps that six year gap makes sense. Though by no means wretched, these recordings don't really represent a soon to emerge XTC on the brink of "Making Plans For Nigel" or "Senses Working Overtime." Many more adjustments, tweaks and tightenings would happen before fans and record labels took notice. Though many fans will doubtlessly see some glimmerings of the future in these obscure English basement tapes. Not to mention that such historical dives reveal that brilliance usually doesn't appear instantaneously. Though luck definitely plays a part, knowing that the members of XTC had jammed and fiddled for almost a decade prior to their initial public offering should serve as a dose of reality to those seeking quick success schemes. Still, the performances actually contain enough energy and playfulness to make them worthwhile for XTC fanatics and completists. Most noteworthy, an early rough "Neon Shuffle" appears, showing just how long some of the "White Music" material had incubated in the troposphere. The final song, "Do You Really," with its Who-like power chord intro, includes a hilariously repetitive and desperate plea to a loved one: "Do you really really really really really really love me?" Flawed and slightly awkward, but nonetheless enjoyable.Though the CD may only serve as an enjoyable curiosity, the parallel English-Italian booklet contains the real treasures. Apart from a compact and interesting XTC biography (with some typos), it includes a fascinating 1999 interview with Andy Partridge that ends with his personal album-by-album reflections. Looking back on "White Music," Partridge says, "I now see it as naked baby photographs." He also muses at length on his breakdown that ended XTC's frenetic touring schedule, to the eternal dismay of fans, managers and other band members. "Mummer" was written in the aftermath, with Partridge strumming his guitar in his garden accompanied by sips of beer. The outside world apparently terrified him for some time after. At the nanosecond of the pre-millennial interview, Gregory had left but things still remained chummy with Colin Moulding. "Apple Venus, Vol. 2" was in the works and XTC seemed solid as steel reinforced with reinforced steel, assuming the world survived the coming numeral flop-over apocalypse, of course.This little book and CD set captures a moment of brief optimism in XTC's late period as well as revealing some of the band's deep roots. Soon after, "Wasp Star" appeared in 2000 and things fell apart quickly. Partridge and Moulding experienced a "friendship divorce" and any hopes of an XTC reunion were dashed like baubles on concrete. Some fifteen years later, things haven't changed, though the intervening years have seen Partidge's extensive "Fuzzy Warbles" series and APE records (which occupies itself with XTC reissues on CD and vinyl) and a few extended interviews that bobble with tiny potential of new XTC projects. But sadly all evidence points to nil. As John Lennon said on his first solo album, "the dream is over." The XTC dream seems in a similar state. But perhaps they quit at the right time? Pushing on for the sake of pushing on rarely results in creative, innovative music. So though aging fans may bemoan the dearth of new material, perhaps XTC called it quits before any signs of real decline. Or, as a drop of deluded optimism shimmers, perhaps they just needed a long break? If we knew the future, we'd be bored stiff. In the case of XTC, we can at least enjoy the past.

Today's JPOP has roots directly in Pink Lady. The always smiling leggy synchronized dancing duo Mie and Kei dominated Japanese mainstream music from their first appearance in 1976 to their first breakup in 1981. Their hook-drenched, insanely catchy, upbeat, disco electronica inspired music sold in the millions and their concerts often overstuffed sports arenas into gargantuan mosh pits of desperately screaming and clawing fans. The usual ancillary rewards of mainstream success inevitably followed: they appeared in movies and cartoons, hawked numerous products in television commercials and eventually made their way overseas. They set the standard for massive success in Japan. Tiny leg-baring shorts, peek-a-boo navel tops, mirror image Busby Berkeley-esque choreography, striking exaggerated poses right out of super-hero comics and an innocent playful seductiveness remain necessary elements of JPOP to the present day. The unbelievably popular group Morning Musume, with enough members to fill a clown car, and other groups such as W(Double U) and Puffy Ami Yumi owed an obvious debt to Pink Lady. Numerous other examples are easy to find. As such, no one who studies twentieth century Japanese Pop music can ignore Mie and Kei's influence.Many Pink Lady anthologies exist and most of them are probably identical. Amongst these, one unique collection honoring lyricist Yuu Aku stands out. His name, painted in elegant Kanji calligraphy, dominates the cover. Not only did Aku pen the words for numerous Pink Lady hits, he wrote poems, novels, lyrics for voluminous other pop songs and was considered an icon in the Japanese entertainment industry even after his death in 2007. This special compilation appeared in 2008 and includes sixteen Pink Lady songs featuring his lyrics, which happens to include the vast majority of the group's most popular singles. But it does not include all of them, so those looking for a complete Pink Lady retrospective will only find a partial one here.Still, all of the most familiar songs appear, including their peppy debut "Pepper Keibu," the horn and string driven "S.O.S." (not the Abba song), featuring the often edited morse code signal at the beginning, "Nagisa No Sinbad" with its unforgettable chorus of "Sexy!" and staccato aspirated vocals, "UFO," one of their biggest sellers with creepy 50s space horror leitmotifs, electronic effects and an exhilarating chorus. The song order follows the release dates. 1978 marked the group's peak and their last million selling single, "Monster." Though they remained popular, Pink Lady overall declined and their chart positions fell dramatically in the late 1970s. Consequently, the songs become slightly less and less familiar as time progresses. The album's sole ballad, "OH!" from 1981 marked the group's first breakup. Aku did not write lyrics for Pink Lady following this era, so the disc ends here. But Pink Lady did not.Sadly, many Americans probably know Pink Lady from a disastrous 1980 variety show. Credited with single-handedly destroying the variety show format on television, it featured Mie and Kei with comedian Jeff Altman. It didn't work despite the inclusion of very high profile celebrity guest stars. By this time they had a hit in the US, "Kiss in the Dark" and several US disco albums. To get a general idea of how the US marketed them, one of these albums was titled "We are Sexy." Meanwhile, back in Japan times had changed and they no longer fit Pink Lady's style. After a farewell tour, a considerable hiatus, at least one comeback, and appearing to have barely aged, Pink Lady re-recorded their old hits with only slightly more electronic arrangements in 2010 and toured again. The recordings and concerts apparently sold well in Japan. Will they return again? The pair, though both are now approaching sixty, definitely have plenty of energy left, as their most recent videos show. Whether they strike another major comeback or not, Mei and Kei's, not to mention their famous lyricist's, place in JPOP history will doubtless remain secure for some time to come.

By now, most people know the story. The slightly mysterious man with the yellow hat ("El señor del sombrero amarillo") brings George ("Jorge") to his house from the jungle and the little monkey ("monito") never stops letting his curiosity lead him astray and into trouble. Of course, this trouble never delves into the extremely serious - "Curious George Joins a Gang" doesn't exist, for instance - but it does cause endless annoyance for those unlucky enough to stand in his frenetic wake. In this volume, he files a kite. Not in the dismissive "oh, go fly a kite!!" manner, but with his usual holistic never do anything half-way approach. Or, perhaps a better title would have been "A Kite Flies Curious George." Along the way he meets bunnies, a fisherman, voluminous fish and a very welcome helicopter.This dual language edition includes all of the English and Spanish text together on each page, with the Spanish text in red. Even some of the words in the drawings get translated, such as when a small bird bilingually castigates George from the margins with a scathing "¡monito malo!" Those using this as a Spanish learning tool should know that the translations are not literal and that all verb tenses, even the subjunctive, appear throughout. Given its level of vocabulary and grammar, this book probably best suits those at an intermediate stage. But those looking to break out of beginner's malaise and into more rich structures will find this book a particularly rigorous and satisfying challenge. The parallel language text also facilitates learning vocabulary. Overall, "Jorge el curioso vuela una cometa" serves as a great tool for learning either Spanish or English and remains enjoyable in either language from start to finish. Now go fly a kite.

(original review from December 05, 2010)Sometimes things just don't work out. As Tsuji Ayano's reputation has risen in Asia, it seems to have dribbled into obscurity in America. In her home country of Japan, TV commercials now feature her music (a sure sign of success there, and becoming more so in the US, for better or worse). The venues that book her have vastly increased in size. She once toured coffee houses, parks, and tiny stages. Now her blog (in Japanese) features photos of performances at music festivals and auditoriums. The various You Tube clips that come and go also suggest that she's appearing more on television (You Tube has slowly become the real litmus test for popularity, apparently). Not only that, an official Tsuji Ayano ukulele has recently appeared on the Japanese market (for 69,300 yen, or about $830.00). The ukulele craze of five years ago has apparently not subsided, and Tsuji keeps riding that wave. If that wasn't enough, Tsuji had another "hit" with the theme song for the very popular "Sgt. Frog" movie series. After celebrating her 10th anniversary in 2009 with a double CD, she has now returned to form with her latest album "Niji Iro No Hana Sakihokoru." All the while, the momentum from the 2006 NPR profile, broadcast nationally in the US and still available on their website, has turned up squat. As such, Tsuji remains obscure across the Pacific.Of course much of Japanese culture never "makes it" in the US, popular or not. And vice versa. The language barrier really diminishes true cross-cultural communication. English and Japanese don't even derive from the same linguistic base. Not to mention the prices of CDs. A Japanese CD can easily cost twice as much in the US. In Tsuji's case, most of her work remains available only via import. So expect to pay more. A domestic release would of course solve this issue, but none have surfaced. Add to everything the precarious position of the CD. Its slow death march continues as independent shops close and bands turn to web downloads and touring to make a living. The situation looks just as bleak in Japan. Plus, many downloads don't transfer between nations. What this means for the music industry remains uncertain. For now it suggests a much more difficult exchange of music, at least where download gaps exist. Again, this appears true in Tsuji's case. Hopefully international sites such as Amazon will come to the rescue.Regardless of the music industry's overall condition, Tsuji has once again released a fabulous album, which likely won't quiver any airwaves in the US. The songwriting quality overall retains its usual high standard and most of the songs will hook on a first or second listen. Obvious standout tracks include the lilting ballad "HanaYoHanaYo" and the poppy third track "HanaWo Sakaseru Hito." Videos for both songs appeared on You Tube (in Japanese) prior to the album's release. Track 4, "Asakiyumemishi" features Tsuji at her most dramatic, with burgeoning crescendos. The rest of the album swings along Tsuji-style. Fans of her previous work will also revel in this one. But a few things seem different. The ukulele still serves as Tsuji's signature instrument, but here it seems lost in the mix on many tracks. The liner notes cite a ukulele for most of the songs, but hearing it may prove difficult, especially on the first few tracks.Also, English continues to creep into her lyrics. Three songs have English titles and a few others feature English phrases. So clearly Tsuji's attitude towards has changed since her 2006 NRP profile. There she seemed to disparage too much use of English in Japanese music. Tides change. Regardless of these details, Tsuji still produces some of the most beautiful, melodic, danceable and accessible music in Japan. Sadly, most Americans will probably never hear it.

Most people living westwards from Europe across that massive Atlantic pond know Queen Isabella as the patron of Christopher Columbus who, from the European view, "discovered" the American continent. But many of the vast populations that already inhabited that land saw and continue to see Isabella's most famous protégé as an invader and a brutal conqueror. That now famous (or infamous) western year, 1492, also saw the expulsion of Spain's Jewish population and the final defeat of Granada over the Moors. Isabella played a central role in all three events. Allied with her also famous husband Ferdinand, this royal duo oversaw one of the most influential and controversial reigns in Spanish history. These years also produced incredible music and the Spanish record label Alia Vox has marked this era with the third volume of its "Musicas Reales" series. Similar to the previous installments, "Carlos V" and "Alfons V," this one follows the life, rule and significant historical events of a single monarch. Each song represents an event in the life of Isabella from her birth in 1451 through the tumultuous year of 1492 to her death in 1504. The experience transcends music and introduces a historical dimension. Of course, as with other Alia Vox collections, the musical quality never veers from stupendous.Those looking for historical accuracy may find more than some liberties taken throughout, as many of the arrangements and tempos do seem enhanced for modern audiences. Nonetheless, no one can doubt the incredible power of the albums's first track "Exultet Cealum Laudibus" that begins with an enticing but almost hesitant bell ring. Soon after, the piece explodes into a Cathedral of sound that surrounds the brain in a cloud of ecstatic harmony. This energy never lets up, even when the arrangements become relatively minimal such as on the gorgeously lilting "Pavana (Pues que jamás olvidarlos)" that marks the coronation of Isabella in 1474 and "Bassa & Alta Danza 'Mappa Mundi'" representing Colombus' voyage. The sadly now late Monserrat Figeuras lends her mystical vocals to many tracks, including the melancholic "Paseabase el Rey moro" with its defeated refrain of "Ay mi Alhama!" and the even more tragic "Lavava y suspirava" in memory of the Jews expelled from Spain in 1492. A lighter moment comes later with "Franeses, ¿por qué rrazón?" in which the French army receives a good Spanish taunting for supposed cowardice and drunkenness at the battle of Roussillon. "Patres Nostri Peccaverunt" ominously marches in the Inquisition, which was also established during Isabella's reign. The final song, "Requiem Aeternam," serves as an eulogy for Isabella and almost turns mourning into a tangible and immediate experience. One of the album's starkest arrangements allows the arching vocals to soar and float on a riveting sonic stream that nearly feels discorporate. Indescribable moments like these doubtlessly brings many back to Alia Vox's vast catalog yearning for more. Perfectly accurate historically or not, the music and performances justify themselves all throughout this album's almost seventy-eight minutes. Much of it remains unforgettable."Isabel I Reina De Castilla" continues Alia Vox's solid tradition of great music wrapped in history. As always, the booklet included with the CD contains detailed information in French, English, Spanish, Catalan, German and Italian (including some lyrics in Latin), and photos of historic documents, including illuminated manuscripts and musical scores. The CD's quality hasn't diminished an iota in the ten years since its release. "Musicas Reales" volume four was released in 2009 as a double CD all-instrumental set (with some reruns) entitled "Royal Minstrels." Given the amazing music contained in this series so far, one can only hope for more installments and soon.

Though the deep origins of human music will probably remain forever milkily obscure, no one probably intended it to make civilization seem strange, detached and sometimes alien. Pop music often celebrates or affirms a culture's predominant values and ideals. Rock n' roll embraced its own distracted, alternate ethos, which often resulted more in escapism and hero worship than in any meaningful scrutiny of reality. By stark contrast, The Talking Heads somehow made music that feels and plays like a distorted critical mirror onto their own society. Multi-layered, often highly hip-swinging rhythms, combined with sounds and effects approaching psychedelia provide enough ear candy to deflect the nearly deviant themes of the often twisted lyrics. As such, Talking Heads managed to provide a critical lens onto modern life and popular culture while simultaneously embedding themselves within it. Few have managed to inject so much intellectualism and artistic sensibility into pop music while keeping sales at reasonable levels of self-preservation.The band's second album, "More Songs About Buildings and Food," sounds so refreshing, unique and singular that it seems like another debut. Their first album, "77," sounds musically light years away from the follow-up's thick arrangements and electronically laden atmosphere. Many bands require multiple releases to fully gestate, but Talking Heads miraculously attained it after a single album. Like an infant blue whale, they grew up fast and never sounded the same again. The 1977 version of "Stay Hungry," a bonus track included with the album's 2006 re-release, when juxtaposed with the version included on "Buildings and Food," demonstrates this astonishing transition.Though the music exploded with a new frenetic inventiveness, the lyrics continued their skewed, confused look at human life in an increasingly technological civilization. One obvious standout track in this regard, "The Big Country," fully rejects this growing mass culture with an anthropological literal bird's eye view. From the window of an airplane, the song's narrator looks down on the fields, towns and people, who scurry ant and flea-like between their established institutions and expectations. Though the narrator admits that such a life has some advantages, the song's chorus chimes the harsh conclusion: "I wouldn't live there if you paid me." Paradoxically, one does need to get paid, sometimes heavily, to afford the lifestyle in question. Regardless, the song masterfully lays the average American life starkly bare. Though it doesn't present solutions - a song can only do so much - it does present the often automatic suburban lifestyle as a question rather than an inevitable fate.Other songs also question deep societal norms. The jolting "I'm Not In Love" outright claims that we don't need love and that "I believe someday we'll live in a world without love." Equal to the seemingly deterministic suburban lifestyle, the emotion and value most treasured by that same lifestyle comes under scrutiny as potentially unnecessary. Were such an idea presented in a less musically seductive manner, the devotees of passion may cry heresy. Though one could easily see the song as a simple denial following a failed relationship, the lyrics' scope suggest a wider range of scrutiny."With Our Love" remains painfully relevant today. As many know, the combination of work and love doesn't mix well chemically or socially. The song's repeated cries of "I have to get to work now... set an example for us!" while elastic guitar riffs oscillate in unison heightens these familiar tensions to fever pitch. Modern angst pours from this song and many others on the album. "Warning Sign" needs little explanation following the opening lyric, "warning sign, warning sign I hear it but I pay no mind." "The Girls Want to be with the Girls" probably includes one of pop music's few lyrical instances of "abstract analysis." Is the song a celebration of supposed "female values" or an observation on gender tension? The sometimes vague words, like most good lyrics, leave room for multiple interpretations. "Artists Only," with its wonderfully creepy instrumental refrain, probably satirizes the worst sort of art school student. Since the band formed while in art school, they probably had plenty of experience with people taking themselves too seriously ("pretty soon now, I will be bitter"). And of course the album begins with a frenetic horse gallop into an ecstasy of shaping another person to one's own designs and desires. "Thank You For Sending Me an Angel" seems to explore the psychological dimension of relationships that involves the desire of one person to "improve upon" the other, or at least the trap of seeing one's partner exclusively in light of one's own expectations and needs. The song launches the album off appropriately and the energy never ceases until the first nanosecond of silence following the closing song."More Songs About Buildings And Food" stands amongst the Talking Heads' best work and amongst some of the best rock/pop produced in the late 1970s. The influence of producer Brian Eno stands out saliently and he helped propel the band forwards into increasingly innovative territory. The entire album, even the minor hit, an Eno-treated cover version of Al Green's "Take Me To The River," sounds amazingly fresh some thirty-six years later. Perhaps this is partly because the intervening years have seen an increasing commodification of pop music and a considerable de-emphasis on innovation and exploration. The bucks now seem to reign. Though the Talking Heads would eventually climb the popular charts in the 1980s, in 1978 their sales were by no means stellar. This remained true even up until their universally acclaimed album "Remain in Light." Would this important band have survived for so long in today's money music environment? Or would they have been relegated to Internet obscurity? Of course no one can say, but we can remain happy that these musically curious art students decided to take a different course in life and that they happened to live in a time that welcomed, or at least allowed, their askew questioning and angular perspectives. And 1978 was only the beginning, or maybe the second beginning?

Like a rare colorful fish that nobody ever sees because one has to go out of their way to find it, Robyn Hitchcock has always bubbled deep under the surface of pop music. Almost forty years after the first Soft Boys EP, he still releases albums regularly and many now refer to him as "legendary." Regardless, he remains obscure and nearly locked away in that prickly subsumation of "cult figure." For some this would spell doom: an ephemeral career lit at both ends and in all orifices that more explodes and disappears than fizzles out. But Hitchcock somehow sustains himself on this tenuous but enviable status despite his own observation that his record sales never exceeded a pip's length. But at one time, in the halcyon days of the late 1980s, when what obsessive music categorizers now denote as "jangle pop" reigned, things looked quite prosperous for Hitchcock and his band of Egyptians. The  peak occurred in 1988, when the band signed to the A&M label and released the appropriately Hitchcockian titled album "Globe of Frogs."Those who know Hitchcock at all probably know this album's "hit," "Balloon Man." It barely made a squeak on the mainstream music charts, but reached the heights of the "alternative" and "college" radio charts, then just beginning their longstanding lurking in that new subterranean dominion. "Balloon Man," in terms of 1988, fit none of the weary molds of mainstream music. In a year when George Micheal's "Faith," INXS' "Need You Tonight," Rick Astley's "Never Gonna Give You Up" and the former Beatle George Harrison's final hit "Got My Mind Set On You" set the standards for hot pop music, a song about a fat man vomiting in someone's hands on the street sat doomed from inception. But if Hitchcock courted mass fame and self-absorbed I me mine adulation, he would have never considered the idea of considering releasing "Globe of Frogs." This, along with his addictive musical hooks and often impenetrably surreal lyrics, has likely kept his tiny dominion glued to their seats for decades.As a whole, "Globe of Frogs" presents one of Hitchcock's most consistently strong collections. Aside the jangly fun "Balloon Man," sits the brooding and disturbing "Luminous Rose" with its imagery of fish slowly eating legions of drowned sailors. Some of the rougher numbers, "Sleeping With Your Devil Mask" and "The Shapes Between Us Turn Into Animals" showcase Hitchcock's more driving and distorted side. "Tropical Flesh Mandala" defines catchiness, regardless of its elliptical and oblique lyrics: "Lying out there on the beach, was a pleasant growth," "Feeling so good natured I could drool," and "It was covered in pink scales, lots of tiny feathers. Valves that opened up and closed, very tight together." "Chinese Bones" fits right in with the REM-esque sound that began to dominate "alternative" radio at the time. Appropriately, Peter Buck of REM (then still with IRS) plays guitar on the track. The album closes with one of the most underrated songs in pop history: "Flesh Number One (Beatle Dennis)." Peter Buck appears again and helps provides the jangly sound that should have projectiled this song into the mainstream. Perhaps the rather critical, world weary lyrics kept radio stations from playing it alongside "Sweet Child O'Mine," "Get Outta My Dreams, Get into My Car" and "Pour Some Sugar On Me." Lines such as "everyone worries so much about themselves," "there's nothing happening to you that means anything at all," "everyone wishes so much upon themselves" and "there's a house burning down on the radio, but we're in love, we don't mind" stand in stark contrast to many of the self-indulgent short term Epicurean fantasies promised by so many pop songs at the time (and now). So perhaps never appearing on the charts just adds to its appeal.In recent years, Hitchcock has grown up a bit and moved slowly away from his previously maniacally biologically inspired lyrics. Though "Unsettled" was apparently an intentional experiment in non-meaning, lines such as "in a hollow shoe the mincemeat sees for you" and "got a heart exact tomato flourish on a spike of greedy prongs" and "they are full of leather peas that rattle like a slow disease," "it's all compulsion there's no choice, my mother's second name is Joyce" from "Devil Mask" rarely grace Hitchcock's more recent music. He seems to now favor a more direct approach.The album and CD also included a "Manifesto" that seems to capture the album vis-à-vis human culture. "This album does not deal with the conventional problems of so-called 'real' life," for which "lines of cliché have been devised for and against everything." Continuing, it states "Within the framework of 'civilization' we remain as savage as possible,"  and "beneath our civilized glazing, we are all deviant, all alone, and all peculiar. This flies in the face of mass marketing, but I'm sticking to it. So loosen your spine, bury your television and welcome to a Globe of Frogs..." This pretty much summarizes things. The mainstream didn't embrace Hitchcock and Hitchcock didn't embrace the mainstream. Feelings were apparently mutual. No divorce was necessary because no wedding occurred. End of story.Sadly, "Globe of Frogs" and Hitchcock's other A&M recordings seem suspended in a haze of "out of print." Fans of this album, "Queen Elvis," "Perspex Island" and "Respect" apparently need to rummage in the modern equivalent of the used CD bin: the Internet marketplace. Thankfully, this means all remain readily available, but none of these albums have yet to appear in downloadable format. Some may find this a plus. In any case, "Globe of Frogs," one of Robyn Hitchcock's best albums, will hopefully stay perpetually available to anyone seeking an aesthetic experience of a slightly less consumerist bent. Let's all be trouts next time.

In the 1980s the young country of Somalia found itself stuck between two superpowers and wracked by violence and misery. A few years earlier, Somali General Siad Barre, backed by the Soviet Union, had invaded and claimed lands in neighboring Ethiopia. The Soviet Union then surprisingly switched alliances and supported Ethiopia. Barre called on the United States and Britain for help, but in the end he had to pull out of Ethiopia. Subsequent coup attempts and executions destabilized and divided Somalia into war zones. Famine followed. International food aid couldn't penetrate the region's carnage and corruption and the U.N. sanctioned humanitarian military intervention. An attempt to capture warlord Farrah Aidid, who had attacked Pakistani troops, led to the infamous "Black Hawk Down" incident. American troops were killed and President Clinton ordered the U.S. to leave. All other countries followed suit, leaving a smoldering Somalia behind. With few options remaining, people fled. A particular group of refugees went to Kenya and, following more indescribable hardship, some eventually found their way to San Diego. Lacking opportunities in California, a 1992 help wanted ad for a food processing plant inspired some to move to the considerably more frigid climate of Marshall, Minnesota. They found work almost immediately, encouraging others northward. More and more followed. They established communities in Minnesota's welcoming and relatively tolerant atmosphere. Even more followed. Soon, some relocated to Minneapolis and continued building Somali communities. This continued until Minnesota, particularly the city of Minneapolis, could claim the largest population of Somalis in the United States. The small book "Somalis In Minnesota" tells this inspiring and often heartbreaking story of perseverance in the words of Somalis themselves.Three Somali words appear prominently in this tiny book: "Sahan" (or, roughly, "pioneer"), "war" (meaning "news," not combat) and "Martisoor" (or "hospitality"). Basically, the "Sahans" that made their way to Minnesota spread "war" (news) to others of the "Martisoor" awaiting them in the North Star State. Hospitality in particular remains a central tenet of Somali culture. As the book explains, the word "Somali" means "go milk for yourself," referring to the hospitable practice of allowing guests to help themselves to milkable livestock. Though many Somalis did find hospitality in Minnesota, the book also points out that things were by no means perfect. Many faced discrimination in housing, jobs and education. Language barriers in particular left many vulnerable to fraud or intimidation. Most Somalis also practice Islam, so religious tensions rose, especially following 9/11. Some Somali money-wiring companies were closed by the FBI. Not only that, the 2008 suicide bombing incident in northern Somalia exposed a group of young Minneapolis Somalis training with al-Shabaab. Voluminous FBI investigations followed. Further arrests and convictions in 2011, coupled with media coverage of "Somali Gangs," led to much unwanted attention for the Somali community. Nonetheless, the community and Minnesota seem to have weathered this storm relatively unscathed so far. Tensions didn't rise as far as Somalis feared and outright hate incidents remained isolated and few in number. The book even highlights stories where Minnesotans went out of their way to protect Somalis from backlash, such as a Marshall Police officer personally asking a Somali family if they had faced any harassment and Project 504, which helped Somalis deal with unscrupulous landlords. Despite past and present challenges,  Somalis have overcome and built a solid community in Minnesota complete with Somali doctors, police officers, businesses, malls and community services. A Somali culture and artifact museum is also planned. Through all this and more, Somalis have become a genuine part of Minnesota itself."Somalis In Minnesota" provides a great high-level introduction to Somali culture in Minnesota, but its brevity can leave an aftertaste of "not enough." A breezy reading through its 70 some pages of content feels more like a mere starting point for this voluminous topic. Though some may want more after finishing it, the book was likely intended as an easily accessible general introduction, not as an exhaustive study. At this it excels. As Somalis have now become an intrinsic part of Minnesota, even outside of Minneapolis, everyone should learn something about their story and their culture. "Somalis In Minnesota" is a great place to start.

This is essentially a speed matching game that promotes memory, spatial awareness, and reflexes. It's easy to learn and comes with two suggested difficulty levels. It's a lot of fun and the kids LOVE it.

First, this is an excellent book. Why 4 stars? It presupposes a fair amount of knowledge of R, Python and the analytic techniques used for the data science approach of marketing analytics. Newbies will struggle with the concepts in this book. It dives right into the code, the techniques, and the statistical measures used in the first example of how Miller made the decision of which mobile company to use after a move based on 16 product profiles using linear models and conjoint analysis. (a brief explanation of the sum contrasts and fitted regression coefficient follows with code for R and Python). In many of the chapters, there are appendices that have additional descriptions of statistical techniques and references.That being said, this is an excellent reference for programmers, statisticians, modelers, marketers and data scientists. Props to Miller for calling out in the intro the definition of data science, "the new statistics, a blending of modeling techniques, information technology, and business savvy" while also reminding readers that it doesn't mean abandoning scientific research, surveys, inference, or primary data collection. Not all of the information that we need or want is available.The pros: readers familiar with how to program in R or Python will be able to follow along. All the sample code tested have been correct so far. Python scripts are notoriously problematic in books because of the spacing requirements, but all those tested have worked. Since it's focused on using Python and R (both of which are free and have robust user communities), people who are familiar with the analytic techniques but who want to learn to apply it can do so without having to pay for software.Miller also includes concepts of data visualizations (often done through R, which has a number of great packages he references), data base systems and data preparation, all of which are major components of being able to efficiently answer the question. Data curation is often a huge undertaking that non-database people misunderstand.To get a sense of the comprehensiveness of the appendices, in the marketing data source appendix B, Miller also describes options for sampling (simple random, convenience, probability samples, types of sampling frame, cluster sampling, adaptive sampling, on-line surveys, telephone surveys, random-digit dial, and discusses some of the pros and cons of each (with words, not formulas). He also discusses the concept of a panel sample and the accuracy of the panel in being able to generalize the responses back to the population. The one discussion area that is missed when he asks " How large a ample is needed to obtain useful information?" is a power calculation - looking at what is the smallest needed sample to detect a difference in what measure is being used (improvement on an indicator/survey question; differences between specific populations; or to determine how wide a standard error is around the point estimate to see  what a detectable difference would be.Overall, though, it's got a lot of great information. It's dense and takes time to work through the examples and code (especially for someone like me who is just an R and Python tinkerer without a ton of expertise in those languages), but is a good primer that presents the concepts in a neutral way, allowing the data scientist to make up their own mind about how to approach the situation.

Excellently and conversationally written, Webb combines aspects of behavioral science and how the applications can be actually applied to improve life. There is focus (as is true in most books like this) on priorities and productivity, but the behavioral science tweaks add a lot to the reader's understanding. There are also sections on relationships, resilience (resetting after setbacks), boosting energy, and influence. She includes chapters on "making it stick" and things that improve meetings, emails, and jazzing up the routine.Well researched, annotated, and good to read, Webb has given several suggestions that are influencing the way I'm trying to go about my work life. Highty recommend.

Easy to assemble and really good quality. After assembling this and playing with it, I ordered other Star Wars, The Force Awakens Revell items.Pros:* Snaps tight, with no gaps. My 4.5 year old was able to assemble (granted, it took almost the entire 30 minutes, whereas an adult could do it much faster).* Wings open and close!!!! So does the cockpit.* BB8!* Sound effects from pushing down BB8Cons:* No Poe. Especially with an opening cockpit, this is a little disappointing.* Rear landing gear: the front retracts, but the back need to be removed.Overall: excellent quality, easy assembly.

Easy to assemble - it's a great toy for cats who like to bat the ball around the circle or who enjoy whapping random things with their pays. This is a pretty large toy, so it needs a decent amount of floor space. The fun part is that it can combine with other of the 2.0 versions, allowing for a lot of different set ups. The ball included is just a regular, non-light up ball, but any light-up ball for cat toys fits. All the cats are enjoying it!

Effective? Perhaps. There is some evidence that the effective dose of HCA in garcinia varies per individual body response, from 1500-2500 mg. Jarrow has HCActive  - but it's unclear what makes that different. The bottle says a 3 capsule dose delivers 1,500mg of HCA. The best part is that this is not supposed to have filler. Sometimes the added carbs of filler can have an unintended metabolic effect by accident. Some people may also experience some negative gastric side effects. It tends to wear off after a few days as the body adjusts.

It's unclear to me why this is published as "Grockit" (also a homage to Heinlein's Stranger in a Strange Land - where Grok means to fully grasp something) when it's a Kaplan published book. It's a different format than the Kaplan GRE study guides.This book helps elucidate what you remember, what you need to work on and the concepts you forgot. All the questions I worked through are correct (have had an issue with that for Kaplan books in the past), and explanations are good.There is an on-line component, which is important, as the GRE is administered online and online test taking strategies are different than a paper based version. The feedback from the online component is good - even gives an idea of which ones stumped the user most, with a time spent on questions. Users can see how the difficulty of the questions changes. The downside is that it's just a 6 month free subscription, so be careful in timing the on-line practice with the time you're going to take the test. By comparison, the Kaplan Premiere has 500 fewer questions online than the Grockit version, but has mobile-device study guides, a DVD of resources and a refund if the user doesn't score higher on the GRE. Barron's offers free access, video, and an iPad study app.

This is a brand and formulation we've used and trusted for years. My son likes the taste and never complains about taking it. The one minor issue is that it only seems to be effective for 1-2 hours, and it's not effective for overnight. Otherwise, good product.
A good mix of probiotic strains. Effective at repopulating gut flora, especially after a round of antibiotics. Does not need refrigeration.
Excellent at removing pee and poop stains from a feral cat's homing experience. Worked well in a Bissell cleaner.

Used in a BISSELL PowerLifter PowerBrush Upright Deep Cleaner, 1622 this was effective in removing a ground in spot where one of the ferals from indooring in the winter had chosen as their elimination spot. NatureClean and OxyClean had both failed, as had traditional steam cleaning. This product made a real difference. Will definitely use again.

Pros:* Not as harmful ingredients as conventional treatments* Much more pleasant smell.* Comes with a preventive spray (some schools don't make kids with lice stay home as it's considered a pest but not harmful; preventive spray *may* help prevent reinfestation).Cons:* Long treatment. 4 hours with a showercap is a long time for an active kid to keep it on their head.* Still requires combing with a nit comb* For best results, keep using nit comb until no more nits are seen (keep looking for several days)* The preventive spray might work by keeping people far away from your kid because of the strong smell, so they can't get reinfestedAs tested, it was definitely effective for at least a minor lice situation.

Easy enough directions to follow, and a lot of very cute hairstyles, However, the biggest drawback is in the binding. It's a quality paperback with a waxed outside, but the glue on the inside is likely to break down over time. The book doesn't lie flat when opened to a page, which makes it a challenge to do hair for those of us who need the step-by-step guidance reminders. If it were a hardback that could open and lie flat, this would definitely be a 5 star.Note: hairstyles also work on decent quality wigs too.

Fantastic cover for a medium-sized fire pit. After putting it on to "winterize" the pit, we had a series of heavy downpours and windstorm. Held up really well, repelled the water, and the pit was nice and dry underneath. Easy to put on and to take off.

Great spicy base for Bloody Marys (just add vodka), as a meat marinade (tender slow-roasted steaks in this - YUM!), mix with beer for a michelada, or drink it alone. It's got a great flavor. Like other tomato drinks, it's high in sodium, but it's very tasty.

Play is exactly like traditional Battleship with new Star Wars ships. Each spaceship has a number of hits it can sustain (from 5 to 2). Players place their ships, then start calling out spaces. If hit, a peg goes in; red pegs are for hits and whites are for misses, until one side's starships are all destroyed. As a twist on the classic rules, there is a "Battleship Salvo" that allows multiple strikes on one turn.The ships include new ones from The Force Awakens. The Rebel Fleet consists of Tantive IV (5 hits), Millennium Falcon(4), Resistance X-Wing Fighter (3), and an A-Wing Fighter (2).  The Imperial Fleet consists of a First Order Destroyer (5 hits), Imperial Shuttle(4), Slave I(3), and a First Order Special Forces TIE Fighter(2).Assembly is a bit of a pain, which is where it loses a star. The ships have to come out of the plastic grid and have rough, sharp edges - they aren't super well scored. Then they have to be placed on these pegs, and it was a struggle to get a few of the ships in the right place and everything snapped together. Once assembled, though, it's fun to play and Sith-loving or Jedi-Loving kids of all ages will enjoy the game. The one change I'd make would be to have different colored pegs for the different alliances. (Red for Imperial and Green for Rebel). Overall, though, a big hit for Battleship or Star Wars fans.
Very nice shampoo with a subtle fragrance. It's difficult for hair that tends towards oily, however, as it weighs it down.

High quality, very warm, very comfortable scarf. With a 70% cashmere to wool blend, it's soft and not itchy. It's great for airplane travel, looks elegant, and doubles as a blanket. It also has gotten a lot of use in the office. Tan/camel color exactly as pictured. Will be purchasing more for gifts.

Pure Protein is the favorite meal replacement/enhancement bar in this household. They are filling, contain little sugar, and lots of protein for the calorie ratio (200 cal for 3 g sugars and 20g protein). The variety pack is nice because it gives several different flavors to choose from, rather than having a case of 18 of the same flavor to eat. Out of the 3 flavors in the box, the chocolate peanut butter is a personal favorite. These bars have some bits in them to chew, unlike some other flavors of the Pure Protein bars, which are smooth. People who really like chocolate will like the chocolate deluxe (it's pretty rich). They are great for occasional meal replacement, for people who have had gastric surgery and need to up protein with little sugar and as minimal of calories as possible, and for post-workout recovery. Highly recommend.

Two things would make this a 5 star pair of shorts: pockets and a drawstring waist. The 5/6 is a little more generously sized towards the 6, which makes it hang somewhat loose. A string or small adjustable band would fix that right up (or a tighter elastic). Also, this is the age where they are starting to pick things up and need places to store them. A side pocket or even a small back pocket would be fantastic. Otherwise, good quality fabric, which sustains repeated slidings, hangs to the knee, and is cool to wear.

This is a nice tanner but is definitely dark. You'll want the associated mitt, as it will stain palms and not come off. It was a little too dark for my pale skin, even after using the lighter version of this lotion.

The cats are now almost 14 years old and the activity level has dropped a lot. Finding the right food that sits well on their bellies,doesn't make them gain weight, and that they like can be difficult. This one was met with eager anticipation of filling the bowl, and seems to be a quick favorite. It doesn't have soy or wheat, which seems to result in more upchucking, so that is positive. Will definitely buy again.

With 3 indoor cats, a self scoop litter box is a huge help. The Arm and Hammer is quiet and efficient; quieter than either of the litter maid ones currently in use. Like others, it has a fill line and it is important to pay attention ton that to not cause a malfunction.
The scent is nice but not lasting and needs a second application after any major workout.

This is a pretty awesome book that catalogs all the Minifigures that you didn't manage to find. It might be a difficult book for those collectors with OCD who want every unique type, although it doesn't appear to be the full compilation of each figure.From the 1970s to today, this book has a 1 page spread for the minifigs, with information about when and where it was produced (there are some country-specific minfigs - who knew?) and makes for some fun reading.Definitely recommended for Lego fans of any age.

Fluxx and Adventure Time go hand in hand. The fun and whimsical art are perfect for Adventure Time fans. This plays like most other versions of Fluxx (draw and play, action cards, goals, other rules cards, keepers, and creepers to prevent someone from winning). This adds a "surprise" card which has the potential to actually change rules faster than in some other versions of Fluxx. So it's a nice variation on their basic play. If a player has figured out a way for a slight advantage, this edition will throw that out the window.

Fluxx is a game of randomness and can be quite crazy and enjoyable to play. This expansion game, at close to the same price as a regular Fluxx card set, contains 5  - count 'em, 5 - and two dice. The 5 cards integrate into other Fluxx games.The Meta card also produces a lot of confusion. Some savvy Fluxx gamers have difficulty with interpretation, as there are also dice override cards. Then there are "doubles" - if the play card and the die are the same, that's a double. But does "Play all" = 6? They also reintroduce a creeper card that used to keep you from winning the game, but for some reason, doesn't in the expansion.The dice also don't fit in any of the Fluxx boxes (and the Fluxx cards don't fit in the Dice Expansion box), so it's also another box to take up space.After muddling through several rounds with a few sets of friends, we all decided this wasn't worth it. PSI needs to make the rules much more clear and rethink the edge cases.

This product does not come with the mitt, and you will want to purchase it (or use a different mitt). XEN-TAN Deluxe Tanning Mitt as your palms will be noticeably discolored if you don't. However, with the mitt, it goes on smoothly, with no streaks, and provides a great color and coverage. Don't forget to the backs of your hands once the mitts are off!It didn't run or streak in the shower, didn't leave a color stain or residue on the bed, and looked very real - no orange undertones. I'll be using this product again!

This "Toy Box" is a cart racing expansion for the Disney Infinity 3.0, and is useable across all platforms. It's a definite improvement over the previous Infinity racing games, and delivers a pretty fun cart racing experience (think Mario Kart/arcade racing) using the entire range of Infinity characters, including the ones in the new 3.0 Infinity release. You don't have to be the best driver - just the smartest! Use weapons strategically and get ahead of the pack.Some of the major racing venues range from Sugar Rush Raceway (Wreck-it Ralph), Tatooine Sand Dunes, Frozen, and Monsters Inc. Cars range from a Teacup (yes, it spins and goes upside down), Luke's landspeeder, boats, motorcycles, Cinderella's carriage (how that is as fast as Lightening McQueen is a mystery), motorcycles, boats...it can be a lot of fun to do things like put Sadness (Inside Out) inside the Teacup or put Yoda inside the Incredicar (Incredibles), or Olaf in a Speederbike...there are lots of amusing combos.Also similar to other arcade-style games, it does offer a split screen for 2 player fun on the same console. There are occasionally a few weird hiccups (usually in the beginning of a race) but overall, the gameplay on the tracks is well-balanced, engaging, and enjoyable. What really earns it five stars is the Monsters Inc track, racing along all the moving doors. Kart racing games all have a lot of similarities. However, the door factory with rail jumping is really superbly done and is very unique and definitely makes it worth the extra expenditure to get this add-on.

This party crock is somewhat versatile as it can be used on the stove or oven to cook the food, then kept warm either via the electric base or under a warming stand (with a tealight candle). The heavy cast-iron enamel holds heat well, so the tealight candle actually does keep the food warm if a hot pot is placed on top of the warming core, and it is nice to not need a cord to keep food warm on a buffet. Because it is removable, it's also easy to wash. The biggest downsides are the size (1.5 quarts is pretty small) and the electric base, as the cord isn't very long. In addition, it's not on a timer, and has 3 temperatures: low, medium and high. It comes with a small recipe book with some suggestions. It's great for fondue or warm dips, a bagna cauda, or  a smallish appetizer. It's not a "must have" but is a nice addition for opportunities to keep food warm. It will definitely be getting a lot of use this holiday season.

I've suffered from asthma and allergy for decades, and love to know how well oxygenated I am, so this handy portable oximeter does a wonderful job of helping confirm that I'm getting enough oxygen to my bloodstream. In addition to taking oxygen readings, this oximeter also shows real time pulse rate information, both in visual wave forms and numerical reading on a small digital screen. These are the primary two numbers that show up on the screen when you've inserted a finger to be scanned, and pushed the small button near the readout screen. In addition to the oxygenation and pulse rate, this oximeter also includes some smaller, more mysterious numbers that I had to look up in the written instruction sheet to figure out what they were--such as the PI reading, or "Perfusion Index." The instructions explain that the PI reflects the limb perfusion status, which also provides an indication of the detection precision of the instrument. I noted measurements ranging from just about 3% to up to 11%, and noted the instructions explain, "The PI of a normal human body is 3% or greater." Similar guidelines are provided for the oxygen saturation (94%-100%), and pulse rate (50 to 130).This device stays on for just long enough to note the readings, and also to give you time, if you wish, to get measurements for a finger from your other hand.This oximeter is battery-powered, running on two AAA batteries that can be easily inserted behind a removable back plastic panel on the opposite side from the display screen. It's palm sized, with enough bulk to it that I can almost fully conceal it in my hand when not in its travel case.I really love the protective soft cover carrying case for this oximeter, with its black cord, and I appreciate the small size of this device as well. It's easy to carry in purse, gym bag, or pocket, so it travels with you wherever you go.I received a review sample of this oximeter in exchange for an honest review.

These slightly-snug-for-big-feet copper socks are surprisingly comfortable to wear, thanks to their stretchy knit weave and padded soles. I wear size Men's 10 or Women's 13, so my feet run toward the larger size. I'm sure these socks feel a fair bit tighter on larger feet, but since these are the only feet I have and this is the only size these socks (currently) come in, there's no way to know for sure.The good news is that if you don't mind your socks feeling a bit snug, they're just fine. Think "compression socks" such as are worn to improve circulation for long times being seated, and that's about what these feel like. So if you do have larger feet, you can think of these as bearing both the benefits of copper socks and also compression socks all in one!I love copper socks for their antibacterial nature, preferring them now to other socks--even bamboo socks--that merely wick moisture away. There truly is something marvelous about the feeling of wearing copper socks in terms of having more energy, and feeling generally better overall.I received a complimentary pair of these socks in exchange for an honest review.

Depending on the size of your lingerie, this bag may or may not be adequate. But this having been said, I find it just the ticket for my needs! And I am a larger sized person, who had read a previous review by someone also wearing larger garments. I can easily fit three underwear in the side mesh pouches as well as five underwire brassieres, and still have enough extra room in the main compartment for more lingerie, such as two more pair of underwear! Certainly the primary factor has more to do with the compactness of the brassieres in question. If they fold in half and are not comprised of padding or heavy materials, they'll fit just fine, like mine do.The material and zipper on this bag are sturdy, and look like they will hold up well with moderate to heavy use.I received a complementary review sample of this bag in exchange for a fair and honest review.

This wonderful RFID blocking wallet and passport holder is the perfect travel companion. With risk of identity theft becoming a much more real and present danger, peace of mind comes from having a passport holder one can entrust credit cards and passport to. With one zippered pouch, two inner pockets, one outer pocket, and one inner plastic pocket (perfect for photo ID or credit card), this pocket-sized wallet folds up neatly to either be tucked in a safe location, or worn around the neck by it's drawstring cord.Despite a need for RFID blocking wallets, they're not always easy to find, let alone one as practically designed for travel as this one.Highly recommended!I received a review sample of this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I love the way this bag has two separate zippered side pockets, since I often like to separate some items from the main compartment. There are two more zippered mesh pockets, providing speedy access to those items you'd like to keep in view, and a spacious center section that includes two more elastic mesh side pockets on the inside.This toiletries bag is small enough to pack neatly into any luggage, and flexible enough to be hung by a metal hanger wherever most convenient. This often comes in handy for those situations where counter space is at a premium. When not in use, the metal hanger zips tucked away inside a top pouch, out of the way and out of sight.I like the carrying handle atop this case, as it makes toting it around easy, and the sturdy, water-repelling green fabric make this bag a marvelous practical addition to any organized traveler's luggage suite.I received a review sample of this product in exchange for a fair and honest review.

Peter Russell points out that the proverbial Emperor "has no clothes" in gently pointing out how our current materialistic paradigm with all scientific paradigms under its umbrella are based on the assumption that the physical world is the real world, and that space, time, matter, and energy are the fundamental components of reality. Despite the fact that nothing in Western science predicts that any living creature should be conscious, the only thing any of us can really be certain of is that we are conscious. There exists a paradox of consciousness that Russell describes as "it's existence is undeniable, yet it remains totally inexplicable." Clearly there is trouble in the material realism camp, since it's unclear how any purely material process can ever give rise to consciousness.From Science to God includes reference to German philosopher Immanuel Kant, who proposed that the mind is an active participant, and we construct reality for ourselves in the form of 'phenomenon--that which appears to be' as forms in the world which give rise to the perception of 'noumanon--thing in itself.' Immanuel Kant is now being proven to be correct, as scientists discover how our brains create representations of reality, and the senses we presume to show us 'how reality truly is' are simply interfacing with reality to share something comprehensible to us. Russell points out that there are two realities--the physical 'out there' reality and the personal reconstruction in our minds. Both of these realities can feel very real, and illusion and confusion can arise when we confuse the reality we experience with the physical reality.Beautifully written, and filled with insightful descriptions of scientific discovery and spiritual wisdom, From Science to God deserves a place of honor on every book shelf.Highly recommended!

This is a truly beautiful wedding ring.  The space age Carbon Fiber inlay is stunningly beautiful in contrast to the elegant chamfered rose gold plated band surrounding it. The pictures don't do this ring justice, since there is a sparkle to it that looks even better in real life, and best of all when worn on a ring finger.The enduring, gorgeous, and elegant nature of this ring cannot be overstated in mere words. That this ring is made of super durable Tungsten, with up-to-the-moment Carbon Fiber is a modern wonder. I'm delighted to see the natural outgrowth of centuries of change for the better in this truly beautiful ring.A review sample of this ring was provided in exchange for an honest review.

This ring says:  I mean business!  This stout, sturdy yet elegant ring nestles comfortably between the fingers in understated elegance, yetno one will doubt the gravitas and status that wearing this wonderful ring brings. It's brushed tungsten outer / 14K Rose Gold inner ring is unobtrusive, and easy and comfortable to wear, yet sends its quiet statement whether working out, gardening, or working on the car. Thanks to the near invulnerability of the material, there is need to worry about scratching its tungsten exterior, either. This ring is truly the embodiment of enduring elegance with durability and beauty built in!The plated rose gold lining the interior of this ring provide a smooth sensation of comfort, as well as a lovely glow which flashes occasionally when viewed from the side. Such a subtle indication of understated elegance combined with the strength and durability of brushed tungsten make this ring the very embodiment of enduring elegance.I received a review sample of this ring in exchange for an honest review.

8 LAWS OF CHANGE packs centuries of time-tested wisdom about how to successfully effect long-lasting positive change in the world. Schwartz shares insights from five decades of his personal experiences, starting with the American civil rights movement of the 1960s, and continuing forward to today. Until 8 LAWS OF CHANGE, those of us striving to achieve social goals with small community groups have relied upon good intentions and good luck when bringing together people of different experiences and viewpoints. To say results are not guaranteed is an understatement! I’m grateful to have been involved in a few successful projects involving a small groups of dedicated individuals working in the face of opposition and with limited resources. People working together to improve the world need help holding a consistent vision of long-term goals without individuals pushing their specific beliefs or agendas— and 8 LAWS OF CHANGE serves as the best book I’ve yet seen that provides a guide for accomplishing that. Schwartz’s 8 LAWS OF CHANGE are key success factors responsible for having brought about change in American society in such areas as: civil rights, women’s suffrage, public education, and environmental protection. Schwartz introduces the 8 LAWS OF CHANGE by expressing astonishment that every successful movement for social change he lists began with “a few Quakers joining together in common intention.” Individuals and the group: share a common intention; have goals but not cherished outcomes; accept they may not see change in their lifetime; accept lack of credit or acknowledgement; enjoy fundamental equality; foreswear all violence; make private selves consistent with public postures; and act from the beingness of life-affirming integrity. Choosing my favorite part of this book is challenging, since it’s so well written, and filled with fascinating accounts and people. Some chapters share a successful case history, and others delve into important topics such as: taking the long view, the power of nonviolence, the issue of authority, the power of intentioned awareness, and nonlocal consciousness. I’m especially fond of investigating matters of nonlocal consciousness and intentioned awareness, and was pleased to see that these chapters provided current research findings and useful practical tips. Highly recommended!

Embracing the Wild in Your Dog provides readers with profound insights into some aspects of dog behavior that have become completely disregarded--not just by dog owners and their families, friends, and neighbors but also by many of society's leading 'experts' in dog training and behavior. Embracing the Wild describes how over the past several decades, the relationship between Americans and their dogs has slowly and insidiously been shifting away from a working relationship, in which family dogs had jobs to do, and relished the respect they gained from assisting with household protection and hunting, among other things. Thanks in large part to remarkably successful marketing campaigns by the multi-million dollar pet industry, this relationship has changed. Rather than being seen primarily as wolves-in-dogs-clothing working animals that require obedience training in order to best assist people, dogs are now increasingly viewed as "little-furry-people" and treated as surrogate children, complete with all-positive behavioral conditioning.Bailey's point is that people disregard the "inner wolf" in their dogs at their own peril. Embracing the Wild truly shines when he illuminates the darker side of playing make-believe and imagining that "little-furry-people" can be trained entirely with positive conditioning, in much the same manner that American children are raised today. As a canine behavioral expert, Bailey is often consulted as a trainer of last resort, when all other dog schools and methods have failed, and the worst case scenarios have occurred. Families who can't comprehend how their adorable child-in-a-fur-suit could possibly have mauled another family member when they grew up together typically don't comprehend the basic rules for living that wolves (and dogs) abide by. This is the wisdom that Bailey's wonderful book imparts.I've always loved books about wolves, and I treasure the way each chapter begins with a quote about and picture of wolves, keeping the presence of these fierce wise predators foremost in mind. Bailey was blessed to have received wise counsel and guidance from a wilderness survival expert and mentor, whose teachings are some of my favorite parts of this book. Through experiences with the wild, we gain a sense of both our true inner nature and the genuine nature of dogs--with their wolf nature always present.Bailey writes with passion about a topic he cares deeply about, since he's seen a similar change in the way Americans feel about and work with dogs to what I've also witnessed in these past five decades. It's a wonderful book that casts our own past experiences in a new light, seeing fresh insights and new clues in old events--and Embracing the Wild inspired me to mentally review my numerous past associations with dogs.While I've had few opportunities to learn first-hand about wolves, my experiences with dogs come from having grown up in the 1960s in a California family where dogs were frequently a part of my life, and considered to be outdoor animals who had jobs to do. I do appreciate the dangerous side of dogs, as I have been bitten on two separate occasions by dogs--once as a young child by our next-door-neighbor's German shepherd, and as a college student / teenager while visiting a woman's apartment. I was careful when selecting and bringing a large (75 pound) adopted dog home from our local animal shelter as a pet for my daughter to choose a dog whose eyes I looked into and who met my gaze with mutual trust and acceptance. I knew that finding a dog who communicated the right level of inner knowing when gazing into his eyes was absolutely essential, so I visited numerous shelters over the course of several weeks before finding a dog to show my daughter for her to approve or veto. This large dog was a beloved part of our family for 16 years--far older than most large dogs get to be. In addition to the love we showered him with, we also ensured he always knew he had a job to do, and it was obvious how clearly he thrived on knowing his responsibilities. He kept our garden clear of 'varmints,' and on one occasion caught and killed a rodent we happened to be walking past. While such savagery in a dog can take us aback, these behaviors are clearly part and parcel of living true to the wolf within.I highly recommend this book to anyone seriously interested in genuinely understanding canine behavior.A review copy of this book was provided in exchange for an honest review.

You can't beat this towel for portability when space and speed of drying time matters. This towel and washcloth set comes in a handy mesh carrying bag, which serves as an excellent carrying case to toss into your suitcase or gym bag.The 29" x 60" towel has surprisingly big dimensions, considering how small it becomes in the mesh bag when rolled up (4" diameter x 9" long). I was also surprised at the softness of the towel's textures (except the stitched edges, which feel rough), and how well it absorbs water. It seems like a towel so thin wouldn't have anywhere to soak up water, but this towel does an excellent job of drying my entire body.The remarkable drying success of these cloths are attributable to their being a product of progress in microfiber materials. They are composed of 85% polyester and 15% polyamide, so they are not safe in the clothes dryer, and must be drip dried whenever wet. I heeded the warning to dry these in the dryer, so I don't know what happens if someone forgets and tosses them accidentally for a tumble with heat--but I can imagine the material might shrink or suffer some kind of heat-related damage. On the positive side, these towels dry remarkably fast, especially considering how absorbent they are.The towel comes with a stitched loop that makes it easy to hang it up at gym class or at home or while traveling on a hook, and of course it can also be hung up on a dowel like any other towel just as well.When I first removed the towel and washcloth from the mesh case, I thought to myself, "I'll never get these back in the mesh bag again," but this turned out to be an unnecessary concern. One can easily get them back into the mesh bag simply by tightly rolling them together as one would roll a backpacking tent before easing it back into its case.This is definitely the best travel towel I've ever tried, thanks to its compact size, excellent drying capabilities, and speed in drying back out again so it can be rolled up, returned to its mesh bag, and taken on it's next adventure. Highly recommended.A review sample of this product was sent to me in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I'd hoped this armband would stand the test of time and elements from daily walks and runs, and now several months after purchasing this armband I can vouch for its excellent design, comfort and durability. I appreciate the side velcro strap that helps organize the ear bud wires off to the side, and I like the smooth fit, easy on-again-off-again velcro strips and having an armband big enough to around my upper arm and stay closed. I got this armband months ago and use it almost daily, and it's been a marvelous purchase that I enjoy nearly every day. Highly recommended!

This wok ring is truly superb! It's made of excellent quality material, and it adapts to many gas range stove tops with sturdy grips that prevent the ring from dancing or skipping around when stirring vegetables or whatever you're cooking in the wok. It's a great fit for a 14" wok, and looks like it's something you might find in a professional kitchen. I'm really grateful I found this wok ring here, and it's totally worth spending the money for the quality kitchen ware this is. Highly recommended!

I've enjoyed a number of Targus laptop cases, but this one truly is marvelous, since it has both wheels and backpack straps. It handily accommodates my larger size 17" laptop, carefully protecting it in a compartment large enough to hold items you might wish to bring in a carry-on bag for a flight, an overnight bag, or books and notebooks at school.
