This is hands-down (or should I say, "paws-down") our dog's new favorite dry dog kibble. He does have two other favorites, but if pressed, it seems this is currently his number one choice. I wouldn't have suspected that a dog food with such small pieces would be something he'd adore, since he's a large breed dog, yet taste and smell matter a lot in dog food, as I'm sure he'd tell me if he could write this review himself. I love the thoughtful care IAMS puts into each bag of this senior dry dog food, as older dogs have different nutrition requirements. What a joy to find a dry dog food our dog so looks forward to at dinner time, and how marvelous that this dog food stays his top choice week after week! Highly recommended.

These strings are terrifically easy and fast to install, thanks to their ball-end design. Not only do these strings go on the guitar quickly and easily, but they sound terrific right from the start, which is a welcome surprise. I love the tone of these strings, which somehow seems richer and fuller than the strings I've used previously--including other types of Elixir strings (without the nanoweb design). Not only does my guitar sound better with these strings, but it seems to get and stay in tune just a bit better than ever before. I have no idea why this might be the case, and perhaps it's just my imagination, but it's also possible that the nanoweb strings provide a bit more stability, as well as fuller, deeper, brighter sound.

This is an excellent dry dog food for mature and elderly dogs. The kibble pieces are somewhat small, but our large breed dog doesn't seem to mind at all, devouring every bit of food at mealtime with true gusto. We love knowing that this food contains nutrients designed to keep older dogs like ours looking and feeling their best, and our dog loves the smell and flavor, based on his enthusiastic response when we offer him some in his bowl or as a treat in hand.

Amy Lansky is a most unusual ex-NASA scientist, in that she sought answers to explain how homeopathy could be such an effective system for treating her family's health concerns. As a concerned mother, Lansky put the well-being of her children ahead of cynical cries of "Woo-woo!" and discovered, much to her surprise, some extraordinary healing powers of homeopathy.I love how Lansky cites fascinating studies conducted by homeopathic researchers that associate the ways symptoms of a patient's physical disease often reflects or symbolizes the nature of their psychological issues, or as she puts it, "Thus it may be no accident when emotional irritation leads to a 'pain in the neck,' or being 'pissed off' leads to kidney problems."Active Consciousness does an excellent job of illustrating the ways expanded dimensionality of consciousness might be expected to interact with our 3D conceptualization of the world. In short, higher-dimensional levels of consciousness would be able to easily see connections hidden to us, by virtue of our world being as transparent to them as a 2D world is to us. A resident of such a "Flatland" would be amazed that we could instantly see everything and everyone in that world, which for us is as easy to view as looking at a map.When we recognize that higher levels of order contain more information than we ordinarily consider accessible, we have the means by which we can use consciousness actively. Lansky provides numerous examples of ways we can do this, whether through something akin to homeopathic treatments, or through meditation and visualization exercises she provides throughout this book. As Lansky explains, once we achieve a state of genuine, authentic, deep communication with others, true connection can occur. We also can thus experience who we really and truly are.I especially love the way Lansky includes lots of fun illustrations alongside some of the key points she's making in her book, so you can gain a better idea of how, for example, you can hold in mind a possible future as long as it is possible, and through the process of active consciousness, help ensure that more enjoyable possible future is attained.Packed with numerous exercises, Active Consciousness makes an excellent guidebook for taking your consciousness to the next level. Highly recommended!

Ervin Laszlo's "The Self-Actualizing Cosmos" points out that we humans are part of something much bigger than ourselves. As Laszlo explains, "Entering altered states of consciousness through unusual events or through prayer, meditation, esthetic experience, or the contemplation of nature has a measurable effect on the brain: it synchronizes the left and right hemispheres." Such synchronization is in sharp contrast to regular states of consciousness in which right and left hemispheres function independently of one another, and yet this is just the beginning of something truly amazing; when groups of people enter a deeply meditative state together, coherent synchronization occurs for the entire group of meditators!In the Akasha paradigm presented in this book, such connection and coherence are considered as fundamental features of a unified, holistic, interconnected totality. Quantum physics brings with it a new conceptualization of what it means to be human in an intrinsically nonlocal world. In this new paradigm, evidence of a deeper dimension of information presents itself at the cutting edge of quantum field physics. And yet, as new as this idea may seem, the truth of the matter is that such a concept of basic essential roots of reality has been known for thousands of years in classical Indian philosophy as the Akasha--the fundamental element against which everything in the material universe can be observed.Alas, the coherence attainable by groups of meditators is seldom the norm for human societies. While our biosphere and all natural ecosystems demonstrate how they are networks of supercoherent systems, humans frequently dance dangerously close to marginalizing our own and other species. Laszlo sounds the clarion call to feeling the urgency by which humans must either regain coherence with the natural order of our planet and ecosystems, or accept the fate of all species who refuse to make such harmonious connections.While the situation indeed appears dire on the face of it, Laszlo's book is not depressing. I find a great optimism intrinsic to the notion of an intelligence beyond our ability to quantify or dissect. When we consider the idea that natural order already exists, as do ways of living harmoniously with all plants and animals on Earth, we can envision there will be people willing, motivated, and able to join together as one and experience a prosperous, sustainable, interconnected and harmoniously supportive world.So how, exactly, does this Akasha paradigm work? Two scientific hypotheses are presented: Paul A. LaViolette's hypothesis of the Transmuting Ether, and Peter Jakubowski's theory of The Universal Quantum Field. Since these theories are not readily verifiable, some could argue they are theoretical physics and philosophy more than actual scientific theories we can yet test. Nonetheless, the concepts and ideas presented in The Self-Actualizing Cosmos are essential reading for anyone seriously concerned with the well-being of the human race and life as we know it on Earth.Highly recommended and thought-provoking!

Turmeric is supposed to help with inflammation when taken over the long term. I don't have any great results to report, but I have not been taking this product for very long. I have not had any adverse reactions, and this brand seems to be of good quality. There is some evidence that high doses of turmeric can be harmful for the liver and gall bladder, so do your research, watch your dosage, and check with your doctor if you already have liver or gall bladder problems.

These are fun interactive pieces you use with apps you have to download. They are magnetic and come in 5 pieces for counting 1 to 5. When you set the piece on the screen, it recognizes what number the piece represents and reacts accordingly. It's a great way to make counting and addition fun. The only problem is that sometimes the pieces don't register when you set them on the screen and you have to keep trying till it works. Take the piece off, put it back on, two or three times until the piece is recognized by the app. This doesn't happen with great frequency, but it does happen often enough that it could be frustrating for some kids.

This is a really nice, solid case that provides good protection and is soft on the inside. It is, however, quite heavy, so if you want a case that doesn't add a lot of weight to your iPad, this might not be what you're looking for. This case by itself weighs 13.45 ounces. It's very attractive and fits just right for the iPad Air 2, but is not quite the right size for a first generation iPad Air.

This is a wonderful stroller. It's fairly lightweight, easy to carry, and very easy to set up and fold down. It takes up less space in the back of my station wagon than the other stroller I have. It has great maneuverability, easy to push, easy to turn. It would be really nice if it had a tray or some kind of space on top to stash things, but that would probably add more bulk and make it harder to fold and unfold.Do note that the manufacturers specifically say this stroller is not for jogging. Baby Jogger is the brand name rather than a product description.

I like the convenience of this charger, especially because you can charge several devices using only one outlet. It works great for tablets and phones, and doesn't take up much space. It doesn't come with cables, but you just use the one that came with your device. Definitely recommended.

This was just the right thing to have on hand for a dreary weekend when I was feeling lousy and needed distraction. It has excellent pacing and held my interest throughout. The ending was a little too tidy, with a couple of "Awww, shucks, isn't that sweet?" moments, but I suppose it does help us feel more connected to Stevens and Windermere when we're allowed to see a part of their lives outside of the crime-fighting milieu.The plot involves a situation that is, sadly, not entirely fiction. It deals with human trafficking, wherein young girls from Eastern Europe are smuggled into the U.S. to be sold as sex slaves. We meet two sisters from Romania, Irina and Catalina, who become separated in the U.S. Both are attempting to escape. Kirk Stevens and Carla Windermere team up once again in a nationwide chase to save the girls and capture the thugs.I have been with this series since the first Stevens and Windermere novel. Owen Laukkanen comes up with some wonderfully imaginative plots. He especially excels at creating deliciously evil criminals we love to hate. With this fourth book, I can happily say that the author's skill as a novelist is steadily improving, especially with regard to pacing. Although this is a series, I think each of the novels stands alone well enough that it's not strictly necessary to have read all the others.The one notable flaw in this story is the use of too many obvious coincidences. Of course, all thriller writers have to use them. That's how we move the plot along and keep things exciting. It's just that Laukkanen has perhaps not yet learned how to hide them as well as do some of the more experienced authors.

Having loved Tatjana Soli's first novel, THE LOTUS EATERS, I have gone into her second and third novels with high expectations. Both times I have been disappointed.I was quickly bored at the beginning of this novel when Richard and Ann are introduced and their financial disaster is described. I hung on and became a little more interested when they arrived on the island and the group dynamic among all the characters began to develop. I thought Soli had some interesting things to say about how attached we are to our electronic devices and social media, and how bereft one might feel when suddenly cut off from these connections.Eventually I grew weary of all the anguish over who is, or might be, or wants to be, sleeping with whom, and who might have seen whom naked. Soli is quite skillful at creating detailed back stories for her characters. In this novel, these back stories didn't seem to do enough to further the front story and maintain my interest.As I reflect on the author's ability to get inside the minds and motivations of her characters, I can't help wondering if she is more philosopher than novelist. The portions of the book that border on philosophy were far more interesting to me than was the plot.

This is a well-made product at an excellent price. The bright colors are a great idea. I can't use it, but that is my fault. I thought it was the right one for my phone, and didn't do enough checking prior to ordering this cable. It will fit the connection on my phone, but a message appears on the phone screen saying it is not the appropriate cable.

I'm not an old lady yet, but I am well into middle age. I have very fair skin and it has a lot of weathering, so I look perhaps a little older than I am. This product gives very nice coverage, but is not ideal for mature skin. When I was younger I would have loved it, but on older skin it tends to accentuate the signs of aging. The compact is very nice, with a mirror that is large enough so you can actually see what you're doing when you powder your nose. Recommended for the younger set.

I received both this Sis Toy and the Learning Stages Puppy for review. Aside from the different colors on their bodies, the only real difference between them is their voices. The puppy sounds more like a little boy voice, and the sis toy sounds more like a little girl. They both do basically the same thing, although there may be some variation in the words, phrases, and songs.Sis Toy is adorable, cuddly, and very versatile. You press on the left foot to change stages, and the things she teaches and songs she sings progress from very simple to a little more challenging. Just be aware, as with any toy that makes noise, that the cute voice and music may start to drive you crazy after awhile. On the other hand, there's enough variety here that Sis Toy could keep baby company quite nicely while you get other things accomplished.

I have only been using this oil for about three weeks, so I don't yet have any long-term or miraculous results to report. However, I do enjoy using the oil and have found it to be of very fine quality. When I received the oil I was pleased to see that it is cold pressed, so no chemical extraction processes are used.This oil is quite rich in texture compared to other oils you may be using on your body such as jojoba or sesame. It's less oily than other oils, so it doesn't spread over your skin as easily. The best way to use it is to dampen your skin before use. That way it's easier to rub in and more easily absorbed. It also helps you use less oil, and thus save a little money.So far I've been primarily using the oil on my face, as middle-age dryness calls for rich moisture. What I really like about this oil is that if I use it after a shower in the evening, my face still feels smooth and soft when I wake up in the morning.If you're familiar with other rich, cold-pressed botanical oils such as extra-virgin olive oil, you know they have a distinctive smell. Not unpleasant, just very rich is the only way I can describe it. This oil does not smell like olive oil, but it does have its own smell. It is made from rose hip seeds, so don't expect it to smell like roses.For now I give this oil four stars, to be upgraded in the future if I experience any exceptional results after continued use. A sample bottle was provided to me for review.

A few months ago at a local discount store I purchased over a dozen rolls of some off-brand packing tape for 99 cents per 55 yard roll. In some ways it's similar to this Duck Brand tape. It's 3.0 mil thick, whereas the Duck is 3.1 mil. The cheap stuff is the same width as this tape, and has pretty good stickability for a cheap tape.So far I haven't used the cheap tape for much shipping during the wet season, and I've been concerned about how well it will hold up under rainy and snowy conditions. I use it liberally because it was cheap, and then just to be safe, I reinforce wherever I need to with a higher quality tape. That's where this Duck Brand tape fits in. It has a different texture than the cheap tape, and does not tear as easily. The cheap stuff feels sort of like a thick cellophane, whereas the Duck Brand is acrylic. I did a side-by-side test on a shipping box, and the Duck Brand definitely sticks more easily and is harder to tear off.If you don't mind paying the premium price, this tape might be worth it for you for the peace of mind. Just note that it has less tape per roll than some others. The three rolls together give you 131 yards.

This is a product I should have used on my old Subaru before the interior started cracking and crumbling, but I'm hoping I can prevent further breakdown if I apply it every 3 to 5 weeks as suggested. This is an easy product to use, just be sure to read the very tiny print instructions on the bottle. It doesn't air dry, so be careful not to use too much, or you will spend extra time wiping it away. I thought this was mainly for man-made materials, so I was surprised to see leather and teak mentioned in the list of surfaces it can protect. So far I've only used it on my car, and the interior looks quite a bit nicer after one application. I used to use Armor All quite a lot, and it's a great product, but I think this protectant makes things look prettier than the Armor All.

I'm not much of a girly girl, but I couldn't resist this beautiful design. I wanted the case mostly for the pretty flowers, but I'm very pleased with the overall quality and level of protection. This is a much sturdier, more significant case than another one I was using that cost about the same amount. When I ordered this I was a little concerned about the Trina Turk logo, but it looks better in person than it does in the product photo. It's a shiny gold metal plate, which I hadn't gathered from the picture. Even the packaging and presentation of this case is classy. It comes in a turquoise-colored box, with a window in the front where you can see the phone case. The flap on the box even has a magnetic closure! All very nice if you want to give it as a gift.

I'm just a casual player, so I don't have all the fancy language to describe how guitar strings perform. I had just put different set of Ernie Ball strings on my old Yamaha, and I didn't want to take them off and put these on just for purposes of review. So I put these strings on an old sort of crappy guitar I got in high school. I don't think this guitar even has a name on it, it's that unimpressive. But these strings made it sound pretty nice compared with the old strings that were on it, which I think were nylon. These strings feel good on the fingers, and don't sound as metallic as the other set I tried. Good value.

These are pretty enough, but they don't really have an "antique silver" look, as the name would imply. They're quite a bright metallic silver. I used them with some dark brown linen napkins, and they looked quite nice. Beware of the spikes, though. It's hard to put the napkins in the rings without the cloth catching on the "branches" unless you roll the napkins up tight enough. And then you have to worry about someone at the table being careless and yanking their napkin out of the ring, snagging it on the sharp points.These napkin rings are open on the back side, so I think you might be able to open them up wider if you wanted to. I haven't dared to do that yet because I'm afraid I might bend them out of shape and never be able to get them right again.

I'm not much into gaming, but I was eager to try these because I'd heard they were good for lots of other uses. And they are. They give great sound for music and movies, and you can use them for Skype. They are very comfortable and cushiony, and seem to be lighter in weight than some of the other over-the-ear headphones I've tried. The cord is a little shorter than I'd like, but that seems to be a trend over the years for cords to get shorter and shorter on a lot of items. Other than that, I'm very pleased with the sound and function.

What a great idea! I don't generally keep up with what's new in toys, so I was pleasantly surprised to see how much fun this set is. I've been collecting a few things to have around for short-term visits from little people to our home. When they first see the set, of course they're wowed how by cool it looks with the big shark mouth. Then there are the five cool color-changing Hot Wheels cars that come with the set. It makes for a lot more fun and variety than just racing your cars on a track. This set is also compatible with other sets you may have, for even more fun. For everything you get in this pack, I think it's a good value.

This is a great little ball, because it's soft enough to use indoors, but firm enough that it bounces nicely on our hardwood floors. Of course, this is going to be a lot more fun if you have the little basket that's supposed to go with it, which we don't. But you can improvise with a little garbage can or something else to aim for. Things have come a long way since the Nerf ball days of my youth. This seems like a sturdy ball that should last for quite a while. It's fun the way it's made up to look like a real basketball, except not quite as orange as in the photo.

This is a super slim, lightweight case that does everything it's supposed to do. When I first took it out of the box I thought, is that all? Because it's seemed so much slimmer and lighter than other cases. For me that is a good thing, because I'm not hard on my devices and prefer as little bulk as possible. I think the compromise is that you don't get as much protection, so beware of that if you're rough on your stuff.The cover is a very basic, sleek black, with a nice-looking front made of "Clarino leather." Clarino is not real leather, but a synthetic leather material. If you're a vegan, that will be good news. The back is just the plastic tray where your Kindle sits. It is very easy to install and remove the Kindle, and it remains securely in place.If you're looking for supreme portability, this might be a good case for you. It's a little hard to figure out how to use the stand at first, even with the illustrated sheet of instructions, but once you've got it down, it's easy. I'm a little concerned about the elastic band for closure. It feels like it could easily become too stretched out to remain firmly around the case, but only time will tell.

I've experienced no effects from taking this supplement. No boost to weight loss, no reduction of appetite. Of course, I didn't have myself tested to see if it promoted healthy cholesterol and blood sugar levels as claimed, so I can't comment on that. It's got a long list of highly promising ingredients, and maybe the antioxidants are doing me some good I don't know about, but for weight management it's a bust.

For many years now I've enjoyed carrying dog treats in my pocket when I go out for my walks. It's a fun way for a dog lover like me to make friends with the dogs I meet and get to know their owners, too. I've recently been trying out several varieties of Natural Balance dog snacks , and all but the pickiest of dogs seem to love them, no matter what flavor or variety. These treats are low in calories, so the owners can feel good about letting me share without making the dog fat. This brand is definitely spendy, but you can break the treats into smaller pieces to make them last longer, and the dogs don't really seem to notice. All they know is that they're getting a treat. Yippeeeee, woof woof.My only reservation about these products is that the manufacturers don't seem to want to be forthcoming about where the treats are made or where the ingredients come from. Some other reviewers have contacted the company and received varying levels of reassurance on the matter, but it seems like if the product really was made in the USA, they'd want to announce it boldly on the packaging, which they do not.

I've been looking for some quieter ways to entertain little ones while my sister teaches their older siblings. This barn has turned out to be a pretty popular item because they only get to use it when they come once a week. It's really just a big cardboard wall, and would be best with other things to encourage imaginative play. I found myself wishing I had a little cowboy hat for one particular three-year-old boy.Most kids like to feel like they have a secret place where you can't see them, so sometimes it's fun to throw a small blanket over part of the barn so they can hide. It has to be a very light blanket, though, and herein lies my reason for the three stars. This is pretty flimsy cardboard, and I don't anticipate it holding up for all that long. Somehow I expected something at least as strong as a regular cardboard box, but I guess that might make it harder to assemble.Three stars means "it's okay," and doesn't mean I don't like it. It's a great idea for the tiny ones, ages 3-4 or so. It's very big, about 7 feet long, which means I can only set it up out in the yard. We live in a rainy climate, so once the wet season hits, I'll have to stash it till spring.

For this pad you'll definitely want to have the orbital polisher machine to get the promised results. I do not have the machine, and I was able to see some acceptable results, but it was awkward to handle and really meant for the machine. It seems a bit pricey for what it is, a big round piece of "euro foam," but if you love the process of detailing your car, it's worth a try. It is machine washable, but I wasn't impressed with how it came out of the washer.

This is a nicely put together little set, although I think when I was a kid I would have wanted an eraser on the end of the pencil. The lead in this pencil is thicker than in most mechanical pencils, so it's easier for kids to use it without having the leads break all the time. It comes with about 10 replacement leads, but note that replacement leads are not sold separately, so when these run out you have to buy another whole pencil set.I think a set like this is more a luxury than a necessity, but it does have some features that can make it more fun and easier for kids to master the use of a writing instrument. It has a raised yellow ridge that is meant to help develop the proper habits for finger placement while writing. It works for both lefties and righties, and it's a great add-on item here on Amazon.

I have an electric pencil sharpener I love, but at night when I'm doing pencil puzzles in bed I don't want to have to get up and go to the sharpener every time my pencil gets dull. This little 2-in-1 unit is the perfect solution. Now I always have a good big eraser handy, and a little sharpener that gets pencils very sharp and doesn't make a mess. If you're using it for art work, there's also a larger opening to sharpen oil pastels and big drawing pencils.It would be nice if they would include an extra eraser that is the right shape to fit the space. If there are no replacement erasers available, the coolness factor will drop when the eraser has been used up.

I have a geriatric Subaru that was needing some shine and protection as it ages. I haven't been very consistent over the years about protecting the exterior of my car.  I'm usually more concerned with maintaining the things that keep it running smoothly. So I was very pleased with the results when I used this wax on my car. It gives a nice shine, and I couldn't believe how much better my car looks. I live in a rainy climate, so I was quickly able to see how the wax repelled water. It's very easy to use, and even smells nice. Good price, good product.

This is a very bright bulb meant for industrial use, but it's also good for areas at home that don't get much natural light. It works well in a dark garage when you want a lot of light to clean up and get organized. These bulbs are high quality, energy efficient, and non-polluting, which I have to applaud, but I find that the color of light they put out bothers my eyes a bit. I prefer the warmer light of the old-fashioned light bulbs.

I ordered this with the intention of trying it on some indoor plants, based on a couple of reviews that said it worked great for that purpose. When the bag arrived, it said clearly on the front "for in-ground use." I scouted out some reviews from savvy gardeners and decided against using it with my houseplants. It was too late in the year to use it on what was left of our summer garden, because you have to mix it with the the existing soil. We did mix some in with the soil where we are trying out some cold-weather greens like kale, but it's too soon to know what the effect will be.  I'm looking forward to next spring and summer, when I can find out if it really "grows plants twice as big."

I found it was a bit tedious and awkward to use this on my car without the appropriate machine, so I took a tip from other reviewers and tried it around the house on other surfaces. As promised, the microfiber pad works great on mirrors, computer screens, TVs, and of course, automobiles. If you don't have a machine to use it on your car, be sure to get a hand strap or some other way to grip it, because the diameter is too wide to use it comfortably by itself.

These are single-use gloves, but they're definitely industrial strength. They don't tear or puncture like some cheaper gloves, and they're more comfortable because they don't make my hands feel clammy. These are definitely strong enough that you can re-use them, depending on the task. Sometimes I just use one on one hand when there's something gross I don't want to touch. I can just toss the glove when I'm done.Pay attention to the size when you purchase. I wasn't paying enough attention when I ordered these. I ended up with extra extra large because somehow I missed the second "extra" in the title. I can still use them because I think they tend to run a little small, but they're looser than I'd like. My mistake, and no reflection on the quality of the product. Definitely recommended.

We absolutely love these cases. They are classy looking, lightweight, and provide excellent protection. All of the features work as expected, and I love the auto-sleep function. It's easy to insert and remove the iPad from the case, but secure enough that it's not going to fall out. We've had no problems with the magnetic tab, and the viewing stand is ideal for use at the angle you want. Superior protection in a sleek and stylish case. Highly recommended.

I don't have leather in my car, but I wanted to try this because I'd heard it was good for all kinds of leather. I have an all leather backpack I got second-hand. It wasn't in bad shape, but I figured it could use a little cleaning. This product was easy to use, and worked great for general surface cleaning. It also conditions your leather to keep it supple and protect it from cracking. Of course, it's best to use it regularly from the time your leather is new, because it doesn't take out ground in dirt or old stains. I'm glad I have it around now to use on purses and other things that could use a quick regular cleaning to keep them looking their best.

This is okay for what it is, a fairly small picnic blanket, somewhat water resistant on one side. Mine arrived damaged, as if perhaps it was a return that was repackaged. The water resistant side had two cuts in it, almost like it had been slashed. One cut is about an inch long, the other about a half an inch long. There was also some kind of big oily stain on the edge of the water resistant side.This is a bit small for me, as I am quite tall and have long legs. The measurements given are 57" x 57", but I measured it closer to 55.5" x 56.5". I realize they're going for compactness and portability, but it's hard to fit all your stuff on it plus a couple of people.

I don't remember anyone I knew in school having a Trapper Keeper, but some of my grown-up friends speak fondly with nostalgia of the one they had as a kid. So I was looking forward to seeing what I had missed out on when this modern-day version arrived. Sorry to say, I'm disappointed. The paraphernalia shown in the photo doesn't come with the binder. Apparently it has to be ordered separately. What you get is basically just a binder with a flap closure that snaps on the front. The snap is sturdy, and does not come open easily, so it will keep your binder from flopping open. I think that's the one attractive feature of this item. But the snap is somwhat hard to snap shut, so it's also a bit annoying.The binder does seem to be sturdily made, but only time will tell.

This is a lovely, brightly colored tablecloth, hand printed, so each one is unique. It's not something I'd want on the table for every day use, but it's wonderful for special occasions at a small table or for outdoor dining in your garden. It's square, but looks okay on a small round table as well.The price seems a bit steep, but if you read the information here on the product page about the hand blocking process, it's understandable that they have to ask more for it. I love the vivid colors and variations, but there are some places where there are color smears that look like mistakes. So if you're a perfectionist who demands uniformity, you might be bothered by the little bits of color where they don't belong. It's not noticeable when the cloth is on the table, and sort of adds to the charm in a world where almost everything is mass produced these days.

If I had known something like this existed I would have tried one a long time ago. I've always found the spring-loading toilet paper holders frustrating. If I don't get it put back in just right after changing the roll, the whole thing goes sproinging all over the bathroom floor on the next use.With this gorgeous holder, there's no ridiculous spring and pieces to worry about. Just lift the arm, put the roll on, and put the arm back down. I love it. Be sure to pay close attention to the instructions if you're like me and don't have a lot of experience with installing this sort of thing. It's not difficult, but it does require some care and precision.

I confess I got this for myself and am reluctant to share it. I just couldn't resist the chance to have my own big robot, and having it be the Batman one made it even more irresistible. With a lot of toys there's initial excitement, and then the "is that all?" response kicks in. What I love about this Batbot is that there are so many possibilities for fun. You've got the transformation, the disks it can shoot, the Batman figurine at the helm, the flashing lights and of course the "100+ cool sounds and phrases." I love the bat-shaped remote control, and it's a blast to send the bot cruising around the room to see what he's big enough to knock over.A couple of warnings for parents. Number one, this toy is quite loud, so be prepared for a lot of noise during playtime. Number two, it seems like it eats batteries pretty quickly if you're really having a lot of fun and spending lots of time using it. Still worth it, though, for the fun and the coolness factor.

When I first put this feeder out in the place where my old feeder has been, it seemed like my hummers were not happy with it. They would come by, sniff at it, and fly away. I thought I was going to have to take it down and put the old one back up, because I didn't want my birds to abandon me.I decided to give it one more day, and that's all it took. Apparently it just takes them some time to adjust to change. Today they were finally comfortable with the new feeder, and they seem to like it better than the old one because this one has the places for them to perch while they feed. That was the main reason I wanted to try this feeder, because I'd never had one with the little perches on it. The birds seem so content when they're sitting on those perches. They can rest while they sip, and they're sticking around longer and feeding more than they did with the old feeder.The top fill feature is a definite bonus. My old feeder is also a top filling feeder from Perky-Pet, similar to this one but smaller and with a glass jar rather than plastic. It's easy to fill and fairly easy to take apart and clean. Definitely recommended for purchase.

When I first saw this I thought I'd have no use for it because I don't have babies. But its compact size was so appealing to me that I had to take a closer look. I'm glad I did. This washer isn't just for diapers and baby clothes. It's great for people like me who prefer to do a lot of smaller loads of laundry.If you use the cold or warm water cycles, this washer can be more water and energy efficient than a full-size washer. Probably not so much if you use the sanitize cycles, because it takes a lot of energy and time for the machine to heat the water enough to do the job. If you're going to use the sanitize or super-sanitize cycles, be sure you don't put anything in there that could shrink, because the water gets super hot.Aside from the fact that the unit is quite heavy for a woman like me, set up is not too difficult. Everything you need is included to either hook it up to your sink or connect it with your regular washing machine. Presumably you can also put it in baby's room if you have washer hook-ups in there. The claim is that it's quiet enough for baby to sleep while the washer is running. I've never had babies, so I wouldn't know, but I know I wouldn't be able to sleep through it. It's quieter than our full-size washer, though.So far I love this washer for its great variety of features, both for cleaning and for safety. I adore the compact size, and would love it even more if they could find a way to give it wheels without leading to vibration problems.Samsung is an excellent, reliable brand. If this washer is within your budget, and you have babies, pets, athletic or incontinent family members, or a very small living space, it's definitely worth considering for purchase.

This case is a lot sturdier and less rubbery than some of the silicone cases for adults I've tried recently. I don't know exactly what this case is made of, but it's thick and stiff and made to withstand some rough usage. It does add a bit of bulk, but that bulk also makes it easier for kids to hang on to. The promotional material says it's "made from a lightweight, durable, kid-safe material," but they don't say what that material is. Anyway, it's very nice for kids as well as klutzy moms and aunts. It's not as slippery as some cases, so it's easy for little hands to grip.The case is very basic, and does exactly what it's supposed to do. What you see is what you get. The packaging is minimal, which is nice for our planet. It's not wrapped in plastic, so be prepared for some dust and marks on it when it arrives. Not a problem for us, as we know it's just going to get dirty and scratched anyway.

This is a delightfully scented lightweight lotion that smooths on beautifully and is not overpowering. The description of the scent made me wonder if there would be too many competing undertones, but when it comes to fragrance, all I know is whether I like it or not. This one I love. It's a wonderful youthful scent, and lasts for hours, which makes it worth the cost. You don't have to reapply several times a day like you might with cheaper products. And it comes in a beautiful bottle, which adds to the feeling of feminine luxury.

I've given four stars to the other Five Star products I've reviewed, because the paper they use nowadays seems flimsier than in Five Star notebooks of a few years ago. However, I have to give this notebook the full five stars because I love its other features so much. After discovering how much I liked the one I received to review, I bought another one.Let me first mention that this notebook weighs a little over 2 pounds, so if you don't want to schlep that much in your backpack, maybe you can buy a 3-subject notebook in this same style. I'm not a student, and this notebook remains at home most of the time, so the weight is not a problem for me.I absolutely love having the fabric covering the spiral metal binding. It keeps the metal from getting bent and snagging on things, and gives the notebook a classier look.I also love the sturdy plastic pockets dividing each subject. A lot of notebooks have the papery/cardboardy things in between subjects, with perhaps a little reinforcement at the tops and edges. The ones in this notebook are good quality plastic that will last a lot longer, and they help with organizing because there are actually three pockets to use on each divider. There's a short pocket and a taller pocket on the front, and a short pocket on the back of the divider.The last thing I love about this notebook is that it has a nice thick, sturdy plastic outer cover on both the front and back. Most notebooks I get have plastic on the front and thick cardboard on the back, and the cardboard starts to wear out before the rest of the notebook. On this notebook the back cover feels slightly stronger to me than the front one, although I'm sure they're made of the same material. With this kind of quality, I anticipate some real durability from this notebook.

I knew this would be big because it's a 5-subject notebook, but I was still surprised by the heft of it when it arrived. It's quite heavy, weighing in at just a fraction over 2 pounds, so be sure you really need this much notebook and won't mind schlepping it around in your backpack.I've liked Five Star products for a few years now because they seem to be of a little better quality than other notebooks. This one is quite sturdy, with thick plastic on the front and a much thicker cardboard backing than I've found in other brands. The pockets between subjects are reinforced along the top edge, so they're less likely to tear at the corners.The only reason I can't give this five stars is because the paper seems thinner and more flimsy than the paper I remember from older Five Star notebooks. Still, the paper is better than in other currently available notebooks, and the perforations are stronger, so pages are not as likely to tear out when you don't want them to.The paper attached to the front says "Lasts All Year. Guaranteed." I assume that means all school year, so give it a whirl and test out their guarantee.

I've liked Five Star products for a few years now because they seem to be of a little better quality than other notebooks. This one is quite sturdy, with thick plastic on the front and a much thicker cardboard backing than I've found in other brands. The pockets in the front are reinforced along the top edge, so they're less likely to tear at the corners. The only reason I can't give this five stars is because the paper seems thinner and more flimsy than the paper I remember from older Five Star notebooks. Still, the paper is better than in other currently available notebooks, and the perforations are stronger, so pages are not as likely to tear out when you don't want them to.

When another murder happens in Verity's Sugarland Tennessee home town, it will be up to Verity and her gangster ghost pal Frankie to find the culprit and in the process uncover the secrets of the town's past.I really enjoyed The Skeleton in the Closet (Southern Ghost Hunter Mysteries Book 2). This series has a lighter feel than the authors Demon slayer series, which is sort of surprising since there is a murder mystery at its center. I thought that the murder mystery made good use of Verity's ghost whispering skills.The leading lady Verity is ernest and appealing. and I have great sympathy for her continued struggle to overcome the dire financial straights she's found herself in due to a cheating ex fiance and his vengeful mother. I liked that the way things work out indirectly present an opportunity for some cosmic payback. I also liked the light double touch of romance in the background-I really liked Ellis and hope that they eventually take their relationship public.So another good episode in the Southern Ghost Hunters Mysteries, I'll be keeping an eye out for more.Complementary copy via NetGalley

**Warning this review contains spoilers for previous books**The final book in the House Immortal series by Devon Monk, Crucible Zero, was a great action packed wrap up to a really good series. I have really liked the previous two books which had a bit of a paranormal feel in the Thirteen Galavanized who are 'stitched' ( in sort of a Frankenstein-ish way) but can't die. The world of the first two books is a sort-of-not-quite appocalyptic futuristic one in which governments and national boundaries have given way to 'Houses' that control resources/areas of commerce, a world shaped by the fallout of a time experiment that lead to the creation of the Galvanized. I was a bit afraid to start Crucible Zero since the ending to the last book was such a shakeup to everything in the previous books - everything and everyone that Matilda Case knew is gone as a result of the attempt to repair the Wings of Mercury time experiment and we left Matilda as she discovers that the world and the people she's returned to are very different than the ones she's lost.Even though this is not the world that we came to know in the previous books, Monk has created another interesting one and the counterparts of the people - Abraham, Neds, Quentin and others- retain enough of their core that it is easy to reconnect with them. I really liked the twist to Matilda's 'place' in the new world and that the twist makes it so that Matilda can't just drop in seamlessly. But fortunately Matilda is still a Case and a Case will always get the job done. And even in this new world the job is still stopping Slater Orange who also retains his memories of the world before the attempt to repair time, and who is still trying to take over the world in any of its incarnations - if Slater has his way that world will be one where Matilda and all her friends are dead.I was surprised by the ending to Crucible Zero, not realizing that House Immortal was a trilogy, at about 95% I was mentally girding my loins for a cliffhanger setting up for a fourth book - because really the framework for this story could have easily carried forward to one more book if Monk had decided to put her readers through the wringer one more time. I'm both sad and glad that she didn't. Sad that the series is done, and glad because I'm not all that masochistic as to wish to suffer through the consequences that would have set things up for one more book and also glad because I was satisfied with how things end up for Matilda.Complementary copy via NetGalley - release Sept 1, 2015

Nate Garrett, aka Hellequin, is dangerous as ever, but loyal to those who've won his friendship, as he battles a secret faction looking to take over Avalon. To defeat the Reapers, Nate has to end his hundred year exile and face down Merlin while trying to save old friends and he has to defeat an old foe.Lies Ripped Open was very entertaining with lots of action, both past and present, plus secrets revealed, enemies unmasked, and threads pulled that promise a very interesting future for the series.Complementary copy via NetGalley -release August 24

The last few books of the series have been on the so so side for me but I actually really liked Eighth Grave After Dark. The audio performance of Charlie and Co has finally clicked for me. The cast has really solidified in this and the wedding, the birth, the two mysteries and the 'Reyes Time' were all good. I do still have problems with mentions of Danger and Will Robinson, especially during love scenes -just pulls me out of the moment - but I've built up a tolerance to the rest of Charlie's snark.It will be I interesting to see where the shake up at the end of the story takes us next -Jones has sold three more Charlie books - so I suspect it's going to be quite a ride.My favorite chapter opening quote - probably because I should own this shirt - “ANXIETY GIRL! ABLE TO JUMP TO THE WRONG CONCLUSION IN A SINGLE BOUND. —T-SHIRT”

Served is a collection of five erotic shorts set on the same night in an upscale New Orleans restaurant, Facile. These are all literal and figurative quickies at somewhere around 35 pages with just enough setup to get to the sex and I have to say that some of the patrons are getting extra special service...I picked this up when I saw that Molly Harper was writing as Jacey Conrad paired with Gia Corona. I can see why Harper rebranded herself for this collection because it is waaaay more sexy than her other stuff and there was only one laugh out loud moment in the entire collection.This was more on the okay side for me because I like a bit more romance with my sex. Kudos to the authors though for not trying to force HEAs or even HFNs into stories this short - HWTAL (Happy While the Afterglow Lasts) was much more reasonable.

A new magic player, Dionysus, is in town and has stolen some sex magic potions that he is using to terrorize the town of Babylon which is already ramping up the crazy-scale due to an impending Blue Moon.I enjoyed Cursed Moon in audio for the most part but with two exceptions. First,  one of Dionysus' attacks on Babylon invovles a sorority that has been dosed with a drug that causes sexual aggression forcing  the women to become rapacious and there is an in the moment mass rape scene that is very disturbing. Second, Kate's attitude about potion use and magic in her dealings with her friends and brother irritated me - and the hypocrisy added another level to that irritation. On the plus side, Kate does have an epiphany that allows her to work on mending the damage that attitude has caused. Another plus for the book is that fallout from an encounter for Kate and fellow magical crime task force agent Morales, adds a foundational change to their relationship and it will be interesting to see what builds on that change.So, bottom line is that Cursed Moon left me very interested in seeing what happens next for Kate and Babylon.

This was lightweight werewolf romance  - it's nice to see that a mate bond isn't automatically a done deal HE A for a change in a shifter romance -and got better as it went on. I'd read another of these - especially if Gabriel is in the lead.

This series is one of my audio favorites. I love hopping back into this world and enjoy Alex and crew immensely and am pretty excited about the new wrinkles added by the Keeper angle - Caldera is a good foil for Alex - and Luna's new teacher is promising too.

Alloy of Law was fantasy with a steampunk feel to the magical world. I haven't read the earlier Mistborn trilogy, but the story here stood well enough in it's own - though I do have to admit that I started this in audio and switched to Kindle because the key elements of the world were sort of subtle for a newbie.Still what I loved most about the book were the characters: Wax and Wayne (and it took me about 10 chapters to get that pun). Wax aka Lord Waxillion, was one of my favorite kinds of leading men intelligent, honorable and good in a fight, and Wayne was the perfect side kick, irrepressible, irreverent, and also handy to have around. There is good action to the story, a mystery to solve and a bad guy to take down. The metal based magic idea is sort of odd, but its use is interesting.I liked this a lot and will definitely be reading the next which is out in November, I think.

At long last Nell and Tom's story, and we get to find out what's kept the pair apart even though they've loved each other since the were youngsters. Tom made quite a mess of things, but fate is going to give him a second chance even though Nell's determined not too.I really liked this story. So often in a series there's a pair I've been dying to see get their HEA and when their book finally comes out it doesn't live up to the expectations I've built book after book for the pair - but here I wasn't disappointed at all. Turns out Ether & Elephants not  only makes Tom work to get the HEA his youthful mistake cost him, but it also wraps up the series with a more solid feeling story than the rest of its enjoyable but more lightweight feeling predecessors.I am going to miss these Gaslight Chronicles with their mix of mystery, adventure, magic steam punk and romance - though there's still a slight hope for Pier's story in the future.Complementary copy via NetGalley - release date 7/20

In the past books Linc has been one of the most tortured of the cursed Wing Slayers, fighting against the fallout of bis early life as much as the Witch Hunter bloodlust that is a part of his legacy. Finally, as he feels like he is on the brink of succumbing, he finds the one women who is his only hope of redemption, the women who is the other half of his soul, a woman who is just as broken and unable to trust as he is - but trust is the only thing that will save them both.It's been years since Lyons published a book in this series (I think the publisher dropped it and this was self published), so I've had Caged Magic wishlisted since the day I learned she was picking the series back up.  And even viewing the earlier books through the rosy filter of time, I still think that Caged Magic was actually better than the earlier books. It is still a pretty smexy paranormal romance - since sex is a component of the pair's magic- but the smexy parts had a purpose instead of being filler.Linc is a well done tortured hero, there are good backstories for pair which keep the soul mate aspect from being a slam dunk - even though neither wil survive the events of the story without it.  Plus there's a good background story that also allows for a nice setup for two more pairs - who have insurmountable obstacles to their HEAS - who will get books.I am so happy that Lyon listened to her fans and gave us chance to return to her Wing Slayer world and I am looking forward to more.Complementary copy via NetGalley .

These were lightweight not too smexy shorts. My favorite of the bunch was Random Acts of Violet because Noah was such a sweetie... that one was a solid 'like'The first story, The Gamble was promising, but just a teasing prequel to the pair's bookand the rest were more on the okay side - it's tough to pull off a super engaging short in such a short format. But hey for .99, add a couple of Margaritas and .....

This was an entertaining short little freebie prequel. Sara Wilde is a magical artifact hunter for hire and the story picks up with our heroine naked trying wend her way through an orgy to reach her target in order to relieve her of a magical necklace.I thought that One Wilde Night was pretty fun. Sara's adventure was set in Rio around Carnival time, so the naked chase to the sambadrome was kind of in the 'wild' (pun intended) spirit of the book. The story is a nice little action packed carve out that doesn't do much more than scratch the surface of the mythos of the series. The events do, however, introduce Sara's ability to use Tarot to guide her way and the mysterious 'Magician' who wants to retain Sara's service for his secret organization - he has my interest peaked (and piqued too:)I'm definitely reading the next one, [book:Getting Wilde|26045106].

3.5 stars-First off, I <3 Gargoyles :)  So the Gargoyle gets His Girl appealed to me right from the start. I liked the Gargolye former Army Ranger leading man Nick, he is protective without being domineering, and I liked the Fae jewelry artisan Willa, whose first instinct is to flee when trouble heads her way but who grows a backbone before all is said and done. I liked their relationship because both are lonely and they connect through conversations and actually seem to like each other, outside of their physics attraction. And since there are no open door love scenes there feels like there is a bit more story while they work to overcome the obstacles to their HEA, than similar sexier stories in this genre.So this was cute and light and I liked it even more than the first Nocturne Falls book, but then again Gargoyles Rule and Vampires Drool:)

Wow! This was good, intense and did a great job of setting up the parameters of a world where time travel is possible - if limited to a few minutes. It also did a good job of connecting me to characters Silas -who is in the lead in this story,  it who sounds like a side character in the upcoming series - and to Peri - who will be in the lead. Both of the leads are brilliant in different ways - he's a wiz at the theory and tech - and she's an out of the box thinking.So this short did its job well and has me totally excited for Drafter, book one of the Peri Reed Chronicles due out September 1st.

Leopard Enchantment starts off with a nice amount of intensity to the attraction between Sentinel Ian Scott and Ana Daiku who is a newbie spy for the enemy. I like enemies to lovers stories, but that trope is fairly subtle here since Ian doesn't know that Ana is the enemy and Ana is very sweet and isn't so wrapped up in the propaganda of her 'people' that she can't belp but liking Ian and the other Sentinels that she interacts with - so the 'betrayal' when Ana is outed - and the consequences of that- is the big conflict for the pair.I have been reading the Sentinels since their 'Nocturne' days and I am still hooked on the series. I really liked this pairing. I loved Ian in all of his borderline geekiness and Ana was very likable and I thought it was great that she quickly finds her own strength when she finds out how she's been manipulated by her handler. It was also fun to get some brief cameos of past stars. Now I am wondering how the introduction of a third faction to the ongoing battle between the Sentinels and the Core is going to affect future books. Can't wait to find out.Complementary copy via NetGalley

I liked Smoke on the Water, which wraps up the Sisters of the Craft trilogy.Willow had had the hardest time of all the 'abandoned' sisters in the series who were thrown forward in time by their parents' final act of magic. As a child, Willow's power of seeing visions in watery reflections kept her bouncing around foster homes because no one wanted a child who screamed every time they bathed her or gave her a glass of water. And, as an adult, acting to prevent a vision which showed her gruesome death at the hands of a witch Hunter landed her in an institution and tagged as criminally insane. It is there that she meets the man she's 'seen' herself with - the man who will save her. Unfortunately, Sebastian is the new director/psychiatrist at the institute and the attraction he feels for Willow is both forbidden and illegal.I did like both Willow and Sebastian, but their time 'together' is very limited . The romance  gets the short straw this time around, because there's so much to do to introduce the Willow as the final sister, reunite her with her siblings and significant others, and battle the big bad witch Hunter cult that had caused her family so much harm. While the connection that Willow feels for Sebastian from a lifetime of her visions of them together did help, since Sebastion as a good guy had to fight his inappropriate feelings for a patient, theirs was the thinnest romance-wise of the trilogy. But still he is important and I did really like the twist in how Sebastian saves the sisters. Willow's story does run parallel to the first two books but fortunately it mostly just fills in and doesn't overlap much.So overall,  really enjoyed the series (with the second book being my favorite since it wasn't burdened by the setup/wrap-up of the other books.) And as a fan of Handeland's old Nightcreatures series it was fun to see the mini cameos of characters from that series.Complementary copy courtesy of St Martin's via NetGalley received in exchange for an honest review.

I really really liked Ember. This novella length Cinderella inspired story twists the tale into something very original and very entertaining. Ember is not the sweet lovely victim to her evil step family. The Prince is cursed and not the the cardboard easily smitten man every little girl is supposed to wait for to grant her happily ever after. And, there's a good reason he insists on trying 'the shoe' on every maiden in order to find his real love. Best of all there's a HEA,  it's hard fought and truely feels like an ever after kind of ending.What a wonderful little find for 99 cents.

4.5 stars - Novella length, Brush of Black Wings brings us back to the Master of Crows world of Crow Mage Silhara and his former apprentice, now wife, Martise. I really enjoyed this but the ending felt unfinished until I realised that it looks like this story will tie to Draven's Wraith King series -(and I was wondering how she was going to follow up Radiance and now we have an inkling.)As always, I love Silhara and Martise, him grouchy and her beautiful to him because of his love for her. I also enjoyed seeing Gunn again, and watching him give Silhara a hard time. And I liked the promise of the new characters introduced and I hope that we will get a chance to find out the rest of their stories.

Spinning off from the Knitting in the City series, we return to Ashley's hometown of Greenville Tennessee for the first of her six bearded brothers' HEAs. The first chapter is equal parts quirky and steamy as we meet Jess and watch her rethink her life long antagonistic relationship with Duane Winston  - and Duane has a 'plan' to finally make Jess his, because while she was crushing on his twin, he's been secretly in love with Jess since they were kids.I finished this with a smile on my face.I loved so much about about Truth or Beard, Reed does such an awesome job with her characters and relationships - and not just the romantic ones, there are great friendships and fabulous family ties too.  I really liked that Reid gave us POVs for both Duane and  Jessica, and knowing what they were thinking and feeling heightened the emotional level and the steam level too.I would never have imagined from our first introduction to the Winston brothers in Beauty and the Mustache that any of them would make a great leading man, but I truly loved Duane - and  I am prepared to fall for his brothers as well.

I really enjoyed Give up the Ghost. I loved the friends to lovers romance amidst the Ghost Hunters paranormal trappings. I am a sucker for friends to lovers as a trope despite the fact that I am often disappointed, but this story succeeds where others don't because the friendship is firmly established before the lovin' and smexy times begin.This worked fine without having read the first book, off to do that now:)

This short falls after the first three Scarlet Bernard books and after the first Boundary Witch book-and, as the author warns, has spoilers for all of the above.Malediction does a great job of bringing the two series together when Lex hunts down Jessie and Scarlet to find out the truth about Sam's death. It is sad,  because we get a glimpse of Sam 'before' and her death was quite gruesome, but it was also interesting to see the fallout and to have everyone interacting - the story is told in alternating POVs by Jessie and Lex. It made me look forward to Lex's next book, I think she's shaping to be a great character.

To honor his father's dying wish, devil may care Jovian must team up with his much more serious brother Rhys to find Sebastian, their missing older brother and heir to their father's position on the League (mage)council. But in order to find Sebastian who went missing without a trace five years ago they must employ the aid of the council's best tracker,Skylar, the woman who Jovan loved - the woman who wants nothing more to do with him.  But with others coveting Jovan's father's position and power, throwing stumbling blocks in the way of their search, Jovan will have to make amends for mistakes in his past and repair his relationship with Skylar and Rhys if they hope to succeed.I liked this first book in what I suspect is a trilogy with a book for Jovan and his brothers, but the story is very thin, and all of the conflicts thrown in rakish-rarely-serious Jovan's path are quickly and easily resolved. Additionally, the family's nemesis, Darin, is a bit hard to take seriously after an earlier encounter with his own father - who does not think highly of our bad guy - I spent the whole story thinking of Darin as an incompetent dufus. Since I got this as a kindle ARC I don't have a good idea of the actually length but The League of Illusion: Legacy felt like a short story, though it may have weighed in at novella length.Still it was a fun short read, with a bit of magic, a touch of steam and a smidgeon of steampunky goodness in the background.Complementary copy  via Netgalley - release date 12/31/12

I enjoyed this first Dark Legacy book, it follows the formula of Krentz/Castle's Arcane Society/Harmony books with a Psy-powered leading pair whose 'auras' click connecting them in a forever kind of way while they solve a mystery aided by a special pet-this time a dog. The framework doesn't detract from my enjoy of Castle' s contemporaries,because her leading men may be dangerous but they are always excellent partners to their leading ladies -  not growly alpha males- and her leading ladies are always intelligent.This is my first time trying one of these in audio and it worked exceedingly well in that format, so much so that I'm off to spend another one of my carefully hoarded credits on the next book.

I've really liked the books in this series, and enjoyed seeing just a bit more of the amazing Chance family. I liked this one too as the Doctor sister finds love, but I do wish that this had been just a longer- at least an epilogue would have been nice. This sets up for brother Jack's story and possibly pulls a thread for Marguerite's. I am really looking forward to more.

I liked Singer of Death. This time around it's a Changling/Changling pairing set on post plague Earth. I found the leading man very appealing - he's had a tough life since he's half Fae and plants 'talk' to him but he's unaware of the fae and magic and he was raised by human 'parents' who thought he was delusional or possessed.  We didn't get to see quite as much of the Darkling 'court' as I thought we would, but still enough that I am wondering how Husk is going of pull off a romance for Kellie shifter Kaid.

There was a really good world building to this erotic romance  - the leads are demons and there is a soul mate connection but the connection is not necessarily romantic- so not one of those 'done deal' kind of things where the leads don't have to work for it at all. The leads Knox and Harper were really great. He's powerful, dark and intense and she's no pushover either - smart, resourceful, forthright, and powerful in her own understated way.  Also really good was the background story and the supporting cast - I really want to see the Hellhound and the Hellcat together. My only issues  were with the erotic part of the story. There were way too many smex scenes. I didn't much care for the ones I didn't skim/skip. Knox is just too control freaky dominant in this context for me - yes, I do suppose that it fits his personality - and Harper turns to submissive sensual mush during their encounters - which I didn't think fit hers. This type of sexy times just isn't my thing for multiple reasons including the fact that it feels more like a battle than anything romantic. But on the plus side they were skip-able without losing too much.

I liked A Thousand Pieces of You (Firebird Book 1) Sci fi-ish YA,  at the  heart of the story was an  invention that allowed a person to jump into there counterpart in another dimension - sometimes very similar, some times not. Leading lady Margarite's parents are on the verge of making their invention work when one of their graduate assistants sabotages her father's car, steals the prototype and escapes into another dimension. Margarite and another assistant head off after him determined to extract revenge for her father's death, but of course there's more going on than Margarite realizes...I really liked Margarite and the guys -there was sort of a love triangle ( well maybe a few more side than that...) but not too annoying. It was a bit odd that one of the jumps goes to a present that mirrors imperial Russia - but hey it provides inspiration for the cool cover. I liked that the characters do acknowledge the ethical implications of possessing their alternates - because they  do leave some fallout in their wake.I'm not much of a NA reader - the heroine is eighteen (they guys probably a bit older) but she wasn't super immature -except for the impulsiveness that gets the whole thing rolling at the start. I enjoyed this series starter, it felt original and I will twist my daughter's arm to get her to read it (she loathes love triangles) and I will keep an eye out for more.

Who'd have thought that Broderick deserved a story of his own, of th at he'd have such hidden depths. I like the way that the characters that were not exactly bad but such complete jerks to the leads in previous books make great leads once you get to see behind all of the attitude.Ashley does a great job with her novellas, and even this many books into the series still leaves me wanting more of her shifters.

I love dragon shifters, so I had high hopes for Ivy's Dragons of Eternity series starter... Unfortunately, the setup had me nervous from the start.Our heroine is an Imp who has lived on the run for decades, she finally took chance, settled down,  bought a house and  became a business owner and was finally happy... until he finds her.I really didn't care for the kidnapping/slave/master thing that brings the leads together, there's such an imbalanced of power and he *will* have her, she is *his*. Initially, this skirted the line and I was worried that we might stray into questionable consent territory -nope, his overwhelming sexual mojo makes her forget all her qualms. Still, I wasnt happy that a HEA for them means she has to give up everything she's built. My other issue was that there wasn't much else going on storywise in the background, so at the heart this is just sexy times in a thin story wrapper.So, for me this was just okay.

I read this as part of the Fire & Frost anthology. Set in the Iron Seas world, Elizabeth, who has been on the run from her father (for a very good reason), and hunter Caius, who was supposed to bring her back but failed before, are sweet together and there is a good enough set up for the past history between them to make that part of the story work. The resolution to the main conflict of the story is a bit quick, but that's not really a problem, just a nit and just my greedy nature speaking - I always want more of this world.

An 'X' titled book for my A to Z cheapies (2.99 or less) challenge. This was super short, but that was probably better for me because I'd have been more uncomfortable with the enthrallment vibe if it had been a longer story. On the whole this felt very much like a prequel to another book as the ending was left very open.

Due to his scientist sister's brilliance, EMT Eli and his sister get the opportunity to leave the lawless desserts of Pennsylvania for a new life and new jobs in the canal city of Boston. Eli' s new partner is Cacia Ferry, sister to the Chief and member of the power Ferry family - who carries on her family's sacred duty of leading the recently deceased through the veil to their final destination of either heaven or hell. But when Cacia's father, the head of the family business, is murdered, Cacia suspects that there may be plots afoot.I really liked Marked (Servants of Fate Book 1) it's Urban Fantasy Romance with a good balance of romance, mystery and good world building - dystopian with a myth based foundation. And I really liked both of the leads, especially the hero, Eli, who is a winning mix of fighter and protector, with a touch of 'I am not worthy' - because of the difference in 'station' between him and Cacia and some 'history' - to keep him from being too perfect. The story is told effectively alternating (3rd person pov) chapters which follow Eli and Cacia. And there is good set up for both the larger future story arc and the next starring pair.Marked, was a winner for me and I've already wishlisted the next book, Claimed, which I think is out in March.Complementary copy via NetGalley 1/1/15

Verity is on the verge of losing her ancestral home when she rinses out the dirt in the bottom of an antique vase - a vase which turns out to have been the final resting place for the ashes of a dead gangster.  Now Verity is seeing Frankie's ghost and now that Frankie's ashes are firmly embedded in Verity's rose garden, Frankie is very motivated to help Verity save their home. And with Frankie's help in seeing the spirit world, suddenly Verity has more than a ghost of a chance at getting the money she needs.I actually read a Verity short in one of those little multi-author collections, so I had a pretty good handle on Verity's ghostbusting partnership. Here her relationship with Frankie isn't quite as developed as I thought it would be, but Verity herself is really great - her innate compassion and respect for the ghosts she dealing with makes her very appealing. I also thought the mystery was well done, and I was surprised at how it turned out - the story was fast paced enough that I really didn't spend much time trying to guess the outcome. There was a love interest for Verity, but that didn't work quite as well for me because he starts out pretty jerk-y and the transition into his change of attitude was pretty abrupt.Still, all in all this was pretty fun and I'll be on the look out for the next book.Complementary copy via Netgalley

Lost Chalice, book 3 of the Relic Seekers, was a bit on the slow side and I had a really hard time with the love triangle - especially with alusions to a more famous one steeped in betrayal, heartache and guilt. And this was tough since there isn't a lot of soul searching on Kendall's part on resolving the triangle and as a result didn't leave me with good feelings toward her. Though I still love Nathan, Jake's character is growing on me, he has definitely lost his rough edges and gained a knightlike honor.On the plus side there were lots of revelations in Lost Chalice - almost everyone is actually someone else or multiple someone else's and there's some treasure hunting for an artefact asssociated with Arthurian legend and the crucifixion. As a nit though, everyone is still trying to protect Kendall by leaving her behind - and unguarded - even though it doesn't work out so well (this is something that has bothered me from the first book.)complementary copy Via Netgalley

I like  the Three Fates of Ryan Love. The beginning of the story immediately grabbed me and reeled me and even though the initial hook up is pretty quick between the leads it does take a step back and the story isn't just all smexy times. I really liked Ryan, he's a good guy hero at heart and I liked the leading lady too -she's an interesting mix of naive and not. There's a nice little touch up with previous pair Ryan's sister Roxy and her Reaper. There's also and unanswered questions about what makes the Love siblings so special and I really want to know what that is.

I used to be addicted to these Mammoth books, though I think their niche has been overcome by the cheap Kindle 'box sets '. I really bought this for the shorts by a couple favorite authors in particular and theirs were, for the most part, my favorites in this collection. My favorites were the stories by Kellison, McMaster and the new to me Bonilla. There are a fair number of paranormals in the bunch - which was a plus for me.Shiloh Walker - The Haunted - One place that the dead don't haunt is a graveyard, so two kindred spirits who share the same gift of seeing the dead meet when they go there to get a  little quiet time. I liked this, and was happy that the lead Gabriel was going to be able to keep someone else from his fate.Sonya Bateman - The Devil Went Down - A man determined to start fresh is drawn to a house and a woman and feels as if he knows them both even though he's never seen them before. This was a near miss, not bad, but not great even though the set up was really promising. The transition and wrap up was just too quick, this could have easily been half again as long  - and needed to be in order to pull this off.Dianne Sylvan -Sweet the Sting -A terminally ill woman is doing the faith healer rounds until she hears of the mysterious Beekeeper who heals people but leaves them 'changed' - I liked this, it's a bit oddball and not exactly a romance but there is the promised of a ever after.Erin Kellison - Wylde Magic - A family curse and a reunion between two childhood friends who have longed for 'more'- Kellison does a great job of telling stories in a short space (I am a fan of her Revelers series). And all the elements of the story here are good: the characters, the connection, the curse and the emotion. The ending leaves things open for more and I hope that she picks this story back up soon.Jill Archer -Dream, Interrupted - With dysfunctional sleep/dreams as its focus the story had the right feel, it just wasn't a style that engaged me and I started skipping the song bits at the start of the chapters once the love interest showed up because they were chopping things up too much.Laurie Landon - Enticed by Blood - A vamp encounters the human woman he tried to leave behind, but who he couldn't forget - I haven't read anything else from  this series.  The pre-existing connection  between the pair helps, but this is really still too short to do justice to the big reveal of the vampire world to the heroine and it would have been hard enough to fit in some proper groveling by the hero for the way he's broke her heart.Bec McMaster -The Many Lives of Hadley Monroe - This is really the story that I bought the book for and it was a good one, Hadley makes a deal with Death. I don't know why reaper romances work for me but they just do and in this one Death starts out so other and Hadley humanizes him as she shows him what it is like to truly live. This even brought a few tears to my eyes.Angie Fox - Date with a Demon Slayer- A Haunted anniversary date for the demon slayer and her hubby could be their last, if not for her talking Jack Russell terrier. This was ok, it had all the elements of the series, but it wasn't my favorite of the shorts in this series.Elle Jasper - Return to Me - A woman sets off to a remote island to try ovecome her fears.JD Horn - Pretty Enough to Catch Her - A parolee attracts the eye of a former beauty queen- no actual romance here.Tiffany Trent - Love, Sugar - A woman inherits a family homes but there's an even stranger part of her inheritance - the idea is interesting but she accepts the strange terms to her legacy too quickly and her not being 'special' but just one in a long line didn't feel very romancey to me.Shelli Stevens - Savage Rescue -A shifter gets to play hero to a woman from his past.jessa Slade - If Only Tonight - This was a bit odd because it's southern but southern California and with a Goth girl and an Adobe instead of a Belle and and Antebellum. I liked the ending though.Shawntelle Madison - Cursed - The alpha and his OCD mate head off to renew their vows and run afoul of a curse.
