Get your old tires off, of course. Put just a little air in the tube(s) -- and on slime tubes, turn so the stem is at the top, so you don't get any goop leaking out. The air will give the tube some shape. Put some dish-soap in warm water in an old bowl. Dip the tube in, bit by bit, until it's all wet. This will let it slide inside the tire if you need to do any adjusting. Put the tube inside the tire. Now take the slippery soapy water in hand and wet the tire on both outer sides where it will met the metal rim. Now start to lever the tire onto the rim -- starting with the tube stem placed through the hole in the metal. Get the whole inner bead on the far side (away from you) seated inside the wheel. If you need to, push and pull a little to make sure the stem is still lined up -- you don't want it bent in any way. I managed to do the next bit all by hand, but if you need help, you can use a big blunt flathead screwdriver to help you pry. Just don't pinch the tube! Lever the tire onto the wheel rim. Once in place, inflate the tire. Now you're ready to mount it on the bike.Buying this tire (and the other, plus tubes) and doing the work myself, saved me somewhere between $50 and $100.Recommended!

Good price for a bike headlight and taillight combo. Both take AA batteries, not included. The headlight needs 3, taillight, 2. Both are bright, and will certainly let people know you're coming. I mounted them on my mountain bike (the mounting is simple -- use the supplied rubber strips to cushion the clasps). It probably took me ten minutes, tops. Both give you a variety of patterns of LED lights -- steady, or flashing in a number of sequences. The headlight is small but bright -- but it won't illuminate your path too much. I wouldn't want to be on a difficult trail with it in the middle of the night -- but then, that's not when I ride. I need a headlight mostly for dusk, and in part, so show anyone else around where I am.The taillight, especially on one of the flashing sequences, will let also let anyone behind you know exactly where you are -- on the trail, or a busy street!Good price for the combo, in our opinion.Recommended!

We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on your reviews, so we've written hundreds ourselves. Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for an honest review and this is one of those.Hey, this is a fine little waterproof speaker. Some people want to make phone calls in their shower. LOL! But more power to you if that's what you have to do. We use it mostly to play music in my old Ford F150 pickup, hanging from a convenient spot, jacked into an MP player. The charge lasts longer than most trips -- maybe 6 hours. The sound is great -- and certainly a lot better than the blown out built in speakers. It's also a handy way to get music while camping -- something we do regularly, and this fits right in.Some have said that the speaker will distort at high volume. Well, take a look at the size! This may be a cool thing, but it still comes down to a single small speaker. Considering that, it does play what we think is high fidelity.Recommended!

We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on your reviews, so we've written hundreds ourselves.Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for an honest review and this is one of those.This is a great lightweight little backpack! You can stuff and zip it into what becomes the front pouch for storage -- and pull it out to full size as the picture shows. It would make a great backpack for a kid going to school (or college) who wants to look cool. We use it as a day pack on our hikes.You'll like the detail and all the pockets -- and the quality of the workmanship.Recommended!

We've tried lots of ways to deal with getting compost from the kitchen, to our compost hole about 20 yards from the house, among the trees. (I had an expensive rotating kind of set-up for a time, but have found over a couple of years that a simple hole in the ground, covered over with dirt when it gets full, yields excellent soil in just a few months).But there's still the problem: how do you save up the organic kitchen waste, until there's enough to make the trek to the compost pile? We've had a small step-on-to-open-lid metal canister that matched our larger kitchen can. However, to be frank, that smelled bad and grew fruit flies (and maggots!). Yuck. In addition, the inner plastic bucket gets gunked up. Let's face it, "making" soil can be a messy business! But we have an entire organic veggie garden and orchard. We're not about to give up.We looked at the kind of compost bucket that has a filter in the lid, but the reviews were mixed. A lot of folks still had fly problems with those. Also, we don't want to have to buy and change filters. So -- back to making it simple.We decided we'd use a mixing bowl we could cover with a plate to collect the plant scraps. Every couple of days, we carry that to the patio and dump it into this Tierra pail. Sure, it can smell a little when you open it -- but that stops instantly when you close the tight-fitting lid. When this pail gets about half full every few weeks, then I carry it by the large and sturdy handle to the compost pile and dump it out. I use a garden hose with a jet to wash it out, and dump that sometimes murky water on wild plants in the landscape. I rinse with pressure until the pail is clean (enough), and then set it on the patio to begin again.We're more than satisfied with the compost pail, and like the shape and color of it as well.Recommended!

Wow! We're impressed with the quality of this family "game." You can find lots of product shots of the backboard and hoop set up, so we thought we'd show you how it comes out of the box. First, the ball is not a soft rubber thing -- it's a real rubber basketball, no matter that it's only 5" in diameter. It does come flat, as you see, and requires inflation with the typical needle pump. The "glass" board is high quality, and the ring comes with heavy-duty springs for that slam-dunk shot (but don't try hanging off it!) -- and the string is is made to last as well.Hung over a door in the rec-room, this cool "pro" basketball hoop setup is ready to go -- years of enjoyment to come for the whole family.Recommended!

Remember, for any occasion, hearts say "love"! I got these as a gift for my wife on our anniversary. She put them on for our special dinner at a favorite restaurant and loved them. She has ears that are sensitive to any cheap metal -- especially nickel -- so this gold plated silver was a good hypoallergenic choice for her.We have purchased several things from the Amazon Curated Collection, many of them as gifts for members of our family, and they are always finely made and much appreciated.For any occasion -- recommended!

First of all, look at the price! Then look again! All this for under 50-bucks?? Wow! 8 gigs of onboard memory, upgradeable by inserting a card, to 32. Hard to believe iRulu can give you a Google-equipped Android tablet, with touchscreen, keyboard and case, for this price. Outstanding!We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on your reviews, so we've written hundreds ourselves. Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for an honest review and this is one of those. As you'll see from our photos, the one we got features a black-framed tablet, not the blue one pictured, although the simulated leather case is definitely blue (also nicely crafted, by the way).As I said, we live in a remote area and our Frontier-supplied DSL so-called "high speed" internet is iffy, so it actually took me a few days (trying off and on) to get the product to find our wiffi, and then, to download and install our favorite apps. Most of them work just as well as they do on our much more expensive Samsung Tab3 (at $300+, not really a fair comparison -- but the iRulu stands the comparison much better than you might think). A couple of apps we like on the Samsung wouldn't load on the iRulu -- "not compatible." This includes Google Night Sky -- a way to look at the stars, which we enjoy. However, that said, there are lots of apps to enjoy from the Google Play Store -- or via the iRulu site itself.The keyboard is small, of course, but well designed and sturdy. You could use this little device as a handy notebook at school, college, or work. It's stylish and it would look good on you. Also, the keyboard plugs in with a USB supplied cord. No irritating missed Bluetooth connections here -- a challenge I do have with the Samsung! Plug, and really play.One issue -- the battery is only good for 4 to 6 hrs without recharging -- and then you need to plug it into another USB device through the same port as the keyboard uses. SO it's probably best for limited time away from the home port -- and don't forget to shut it down when not in use to conserve the charge you do have.Overall though, as we said -- wow! All this for under 50-bucks and free Prime shipping?? I got in touch with the company and they said they've done very well on eBay, and now want to try the huge river of sales called Amazon.The tablet itself is about 7.25 inches wide x 4.75" high. The screen within the border, is 6 x 3.3". In the case, which has a stand so you can prop it up (but doesn't work so well on your lap), the whole thing measures 9" across x 5.5, x 1" thick.By the way, you can get the same thing -- with double the memory to 16 gigs (and upgradeable to 32 as well) for only a few dollars more -- so you might want to start there. As we did. iRULU X1S 7" Google Android 4.4 KitKat Tablet PC, GMS Certified by Google, 1024*600 HD Resolution, Quad Core, Dual Cameras, 16GB Nand Flash, Black Tablet with Black Keyboard Case.Whatever version, for this price, you can't beat it! Highly recommended.

First of all, look at the price! You have to keep that in mind when you're evaluating this tablet. Wow! 16 gigs of onboard memory, upgradeable simply by inserting a card, to 32. To provide a fully Google-equipped Android tablet, touchscreen, with a keyboard and case provided, for this price, is just outstanding.We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on your reviews, so we've written hundreds ourselves. Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for an honest review and this is one of those. As you'll see from our photos, the one we got features a black-framed tablet, not the blue one pictured, although the simulated leather case is definitely blue (also nicely crafted, by the way).As I said, we live in a wilderness area and our Frontier-supplied DSL so-called "high speed" internet is iffy, so it actually took me a few days (trying off and on) to get the product to find our wiffi, and then, to download and install our favorite apps. Most of them work just as well as they do on our much more expensive Samsung Tab3 (at $300+, not really a fair comparison -- but the iRulu stands the comparison much better than you might think). A couple of apps we like on the Samsung wouldn't load on the iRulu -- "not compatible." This includes Google Night Sky -- a way to look at the stars, which we enjoy. However, that said, there are lots of apps to enjoy from the Google Play Store -- or via the iRulu site itself.The keyboard is small, of course, but well designed and sturdy. You could use this little device as a handy notebook at school, college, or work. It's stylish and it would look good on you. Also, the keyboard plugs in with a USB supplied cord. No irritating missed Bluetooth connections here -- a challenge I do have with the Samsung! Plug, and really play.One issue -- the battery is only good for 4 to 6 hrs without recharging -- and then you need to plug it into another USB device through the same port as the keyboard uses. SO it's probably best for limited time away from the home port -- and don't forget to shut it down when not in use to conserve the charge you do have.Overall though, as we said -- wow! All this for $52 and free shipping?? I got in touch with the company and they said they've done very well on eBay, and now want to try the huge river of sales called Amazon.The tablet itself is about 7.25 inches wide x 4.75" high. The screen within the border, is 6 x 3.3". In the case, which has a stand so you can prop it up (but doesn't work so well on your lap), the whole thing measures 9" across x 5.5, x 1" thick.You could buy a version with 8 gigs internal instead of the 16 here (also upgradeable to 32 with a card), but for just a few dollars more, why not just go for the 16 gigs to begin with? But here it is for comparison (and it does ship Prime if you're members as we are. But then, this one ships free so...) iRULU X1S 7" Google Android 4.4 KitKat Tablet PC, GMS Certified by Google, 1024*600 HD Resolution, Quad Core, Dual Cameras, 8GB Nand Flash, Blue Tablet with Blue Keyboard Case.For the price, you can't beat it! Highly recommended.

Cute! If you can say that about an outfit for a rough-tough 6 yr old. Size 6 fit him just right, by the way. The shirt and shorts are nicely made -- but the material is definitely summer weight. Pretty thin. We don't know how long it will last, but that's not too important. With the camo, he knows he looks like his Dad, who is an officer in the Army and has been far away on deployment most of this year. It's our young man's favorite outfit.Looks good on him! We recommend it to you.

These are two separate things, connected by a theme: hummingbirds. There's the wind spinner, featuring one of the tiny fast birds feeding, and the "antique" red hummingbird bottle feeder itself. They are both attractive. We get lots of hummingbirds where we live, and even have some that stay right through the winter now, which is somewhat unusual, as they migrate and follow the heat. So we always have at least two feeders out, and they've come to know they can count on us. By the way, once you start feeding hummingbirds in the winter, you need to be faithful because their little lives come to depend on your constant provision of "nectar."The product info says you can actually hook spinner and bottle together, and some other reviewers were disappointed that the linkage wasn't included. However, we aren't so hell-bent on hanging them as one, so we're quite fine to put them in the same tree, but separated by a couple of feet (see photo).These items are both decent quality for the price. Someone else complained that the metal on the feeder was thin and cheap -- but having owned uncounted feeders in our time, we have to say, this is par for the course. You don't actually need thick metal, and unless it splashes, the "nectar" doesn't touch the metal -- glugs directly from the glass into the plastic bottom of the bird feeder portion and stops filling below the metal (or it would drip out around the edge).Some of the cheaper plastic feeders have a ring so the birds can land and sit there while they drink. But hummers don't need this. They're expert at hovering just above the "flowers" while they delicately dip their nectar-sippers into the fluid and extract again, without any need to put down. Because they're such tiny little jewels themselves, they can perch if they want.In the spring, we get bright yellow orioles on the feeders-- they're sugar-water feeders as well -- and being bigger, they can go through a lot of it. There are specialized oriole feeders you can purchase, but at that time of year, we just put out extra plastic feeders with big bottles, the kind with the rings around the edge so the bigger birds can sit, which they need. Both types of birds go for those, but we also provide this specialized hummingbird feeder, so the smaller birds can always hover and feed.The nectar you buy in the store is expensive, and comes red, courtesy of food coloring. You don't need it -- especially not with this red bottle. (But then, you don't need the color red at all. Even in clear glass feeders, the birds find the clear sugar-water just fine without adding food coloring to their diet).The best stuff for your feeder is plain sugar water which you can easily make at your sink. The ideal ratio, according to the experts, is 4 parts water to 1 part sugar. This particular feeder holds comfortably just under 3 cups (let's call it 2.75). SO to do the math, IF you start with a slightly rounded half-cup of sugar, you're just right. We mix ours in a 4-cup Pyrex pitcher. Start with the sugar. Add about a cup and a half of hot water from your tap. Stir until the sugar is totally dissolved. Now top up your water with cold, to your 2.75 cups total. (You can test with a finger -- body temp is fine, you don't want to hang it hot!). Keep stirring -- otherwise adding the cold water may cause the sugar to crystallize in the feeder. Pour your nectar into the bottle and screw on the base -- snug, but not so tight you warp the plastic. Holding it this side up, carry it outside to hang it. We use strands of wire around branches, bent to make hooks. Only now do we invert the bottle in case so that if and when sugar water splashes out, it lands harmlessly on the ground.Hang it and your ready! Step back and watch the action. Once hummingbirds get used to the spot you've selected, you'll sometimes find them buzzing even while you're hanging the bottle! When there are a lot of them on the feeders, we find the best time to replenish the nectar is after sundown, once the birds have quit feeding. They like to top up just before their long night, so wait until they're done.While some people want to sterilize their bottles, we don't like to use any harsh chemicals on our feeders. We simply rinse and scrub clean, and if there's anything nasty growing in the bottle, we'll use a bottle scrubber and some dish soap. Then we make sure to rinse it fully (several times). Hummingbird feeders do grow stuff. Bacteria can be introduced by the birds themselves. They dip their beaks into many a flower, and it's natural for them to "contaminate" your feeder this way. And in the summer, lots of microbes love balmy sugar water.Then there are ants, and wasps, which can swarm your feeders. Not so much you can do about the wasps. We've actually seen them drive away the birds when both species are competing for the nectar. However, they're only really bad in the late summer. The ants are another problem. We've tried many things to deter them, including washing them and the tree off with a hose. However, they're soon back. You can sometimes fool them simply by moving the feeder a few feet to another branch. We have several wire hooks in our favorite feeder tree for this purpose.Hope that helps! This is a nice set, and we think it's better than average quality for commercial hummingbird feeders -- beautiful to look at, and a wonderful focus of entertainment when the hummingbirds are hovering.Recommended.

We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products on Amazon. We write a lot of honest reviews, mostly for things we purchase. Sometimes we get offered products to sample for review, and this is one of those. This comes from the female side of the family.I have very fine "baby" hair. I can't use a lot of products which might work well to moisturize or de-frizz normal hair, because it makes my hair lay flat. However, I was interested to try this Argan oil hair masque or treatment, to see if it would moisturize brutal Arizona sun damaged hair, without making it overall oily. I have applied it according to directions several times now, and then shampooed it out. I'm pleased to tell you, it appears to have repaired my hair, and added healthy luster, without making it sticky or flat!I love the fragrance, and like the fact that this is made from the oil pressed from the nut of the Argan tree, which is found only in exotic Morocco. I was interested to read that the trees, found only in that area, can live to be about 200 years old, and they do not even start producing nuts for up to 50 years. That's a long time for an orchard owner to invest! No wonder that, until recently, argan oil was costly and hard to come by. (It's also an edible oil).I was already a fan of a light pomade or gel, made from organic coconut oil and argan Argan Oil and Coconut Oil Pomade - Medium Hold - Add Volume and Shine to Your Hair Without Weighing It Down. It's been great to add shine, hold and body to my fine hair -- so I was very interested in this argan oil hair masque. Now I have two argan oil hair-care products to protect, treat and feed my hair.I'm delighted with this product!

We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on honest reviews, and we've written hundreds of them ourselves. Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for our opinion and this is one of those.These are great silicone mats -- the food grade revolution continues! They are brightly colored and can be used for a variety of purposes. We use them as oven mitts -- they do protect your hands! We also put hot pots on them to protect counters and the table. The colors add a festive note to the cooking process.They do wash up nicely -- stuff just doesn't like to stick to silicone. However, while we do understand the purpose of the hollow honeycomb pattern -- you wouldn't want them to be solid -- they do fill up with sticky stuff if you spill on them. One point off for that. But then, you can throw 'em in the dishwasher, so that helps.At $12 at the time of this writing, that's only $3 each -- a good deal.Recommended.

We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on honest reviews, and we've written hundreds of them ourselves. Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for an honest review and this is one of those. We love the food grade silicone revolution in the kitchen! We have spatulas and oven mitts made of the stuff, and jumped at the opportunity to get these handy "mats" made of the colorful material. It's hard not to smile just looking at them! We have a set of colorful dishes -- Fiestaware -- and these trivets fit right in.We use them as oven mitts to grab things out of the oven, and as trivets (on which to put hot pans on the counters or table). They work well, are dishwasher safe, and add even more color to our kitchen.At $15 at the time of this writing, that's something under $4 each.Recommended!

This is a well-crafted, light, attractive volleyball. The price is right! It does arrive deflated, so you need the ability to pump it up before use. It is super-responsive to the touch and performs well.As frequent reviewers of sports equipment, we received a sample for review.Recommended!

It's a light, organic hair product. They call it a medium-hold pomade or light gel. According to the company, it's a blend of organic botanicals, featuring argan and coconut oils -- two of our favorites. It feels fine and non-greasy on the fingers, goes easily into the hair, and holds it in place without overkill.Smells wonderful!As frequent reviewers of natural cosmetic and beauty products, we were given a sample for review.Recommended.

We live in a wilderness area and buy thousands of products from Amazon. We count on honest reviews, and we've written hundreds of them ourselves. Sometimes we get offered things at a discount or free in exchange for an honest review and this is one of those. This phone-holder (or other GPS device holder) is easy to put together. The spring-loaded mount squeezes your phone or other smart device between two padded arms, and holds it in place -- either vertically or horizontally. It goes into one of your vehicle air vents -- at least, the one leg does that twists to hold in place. The other two sit on the edge, giving it tripod stability.Easy to use -- solves a problem with what to do with your GPS or phone on a dashboard with no room for it. Hands free while driving!Recommended.

I grew up with Coleman pressure lanterns as the child of missionaries in the South Pacific 3rd World. For years, Coleman pressure lanterns (and a few hurricane lanterns) lit our nights on the other side of the world.These days, as outdoor lovers -- and prepping for emergency power outages, short or long-term -- we decided to add a couple of these lanterns to our equipment. We love the fact that there's been a breakthrough in fuel supply. These also readily burn regular "car" gasoline and that makes them extra useful, and certainly worth a few more bucks. What you save on gasoline by the gallon alone is worth the money (yesterday, the price of a gallon of white gas at my hardware store was $13).In general, with all our equipment, we burn gasoline that is treated with Sea Foam SF-16 Motor Treatment - 16 oz.. This is so much better than the competitors' gasoline treatment-for-storage products, and keeps all your gasoline engines starting and running better. It came to us recommended by a highly experienced small engine mechanic, and our engine headaches largely disappeared after that. We use it regularly in all our equipment, truck and car. Treated gas burns great in this lantern, and I can even leave fuel in the tank, ready to go in an emergency.We bought this with another great "blast from the past" -- the Coleman Guide Series® Powerhouse(TM) Dual Fuel(TM) Stove. It's another classic, now improved by being able to burn gasoline as well.This lanterns comes in a strong hard shell, which makes taking it camping extra-easy. You don't want to break the glass, or shatter the mantles. We have seen the light!Strongly Recommended!

We recently bought this dual fuel Coleman 2-burner stove for camping, and prepping for any catastrophic event. I grew up in the 3rd World and I was delighted to unpack this well-made, large Coleman stove. To me it was like going home. For many years during the 1950s in the South Pacific, my family did a lot of our everyday cooking on one that was not so different from this. When I was at university in the early 70s, I bought one that was virtually identical to the new one, in design and ease of putting together, except the fuel tank was red and it took only Coleman white gas. I cooked on it on camp trips for many years, until it mysteriously disappeared (I bet someone's still using it). In recent times we've gone with throw-away-tank propane stove-tops. However, one tank of fuel with our new Coleman stove is equivalent to 4.5 small propane bottles, so this makes more sense.Some have said they thought the metal on this newer Coleman was flimsier. I don't think so! We also like the "orange peel" textured green paint. The gray tank, that still fits inside the stove while transporting and easily slides into place for use, seems as well designed as ever, and heavy duty.A true breakthrough is that this stove can take regular (unleaded) gasoline, in addition to traditional "white gas" fuel. That white fuel has gone up and up in price. Yesterday, a gallon at my local hardware store was $13! You figure that out, compared to a gallon of gas. To be able to fill the stove with regular gasoline makes this so affordable, and easy to use, with gas you can take from a 5-gallon fuel container, or even siphon from yard equipment or your car.Some people say that regular gas, especially with ethanol in it (which is associated with water in the gas), makes gasoline not as dependable a fuel source. It could foul your stove, they say. However, we treat all our gasoline with Sea Foam SF-16 Motor Treatment - 16 oz., which was recommended to me by a highly experienced small engine mechanic. Using it in my gasoline has gotten rid of the "old gas" and hard-start problems I used to have with our various infernal combustion engines, from weed-wackers to chainsaws, to ride'em lawnmower, compact backhoe, and our vehicles.I've been putting Seafoam-treated gasoline in my new Coleman stove, and it burns like a charm. No problems! We leave treated gas in the tank, ready to go camping, or for emergency cooking in a blackout.Love having a Coleman 2-burner again, and the dual-fuel option is a real bonus! Given an extended power outage, it could even be a lifesaver. It's certainly worth a few extra bucks to us. By the way, we teamed this up with the Coleman Premium Dual Fuel(TM) Lantern with Hard Carry Case, another gasoline-powered product very like one that lit our home in the South Pacific when I was a kid.Highly recommended!

We like alternative medicine, and so are fans of homeopathic treatments -- as contrasted to strong sleepin drugs. Therefore, in order to help get a good night's sleep, we use these Moon Drops just before bed. Just sucking one in the mouth is soothing, and helps get you calm before sleeping.That said, homeopathic traditional remedies are mild by nature. However, they are one of the sleep aids we rely on. You could take the whole box without any ill effects, and the product directions on the box (like a large matchbox that slides open) say you can take one every half hour as needed, for adults and children.We use in combination with the company's Historical Remedies, Lozenge Calm Drops, 30 Lozenges.The Moon Drops contain arsenicum, chamomilla, coffea cruda, gelsemium, ignatia, lycopodium, nat mur, nux vom, and that well known herbal sleep-inducer, valeriana.The lozenges are mildly sweet and do contain organic sugar (with vanilla and tapioca).All that said, when you're having a really difficult night getting to, or staying asleep, it's hard to tell if the Moon Drops are working. Still, we find them soothing and helpful, and they're part of our nightly "getting ready to sleep" ritual. Also nice to suck on if you happen to awake during the night and can't find you're way back to Dreamland!Recommended.

As part of preparing for an upset in the electric grid, or some upheaval that would cause us to be without power and some supplies, we recently bought a Coleman Premium Dual Fuel(TM) Lantern with Hard Carry Case and some other products, including a new dual fuel 2-burner Coleman stove (these both take regular gasoline as well as traditional "white gas" fuel, which makes them extra handy). Of course, a key product to have with a lantern is extra tie mantles. This 2-4 pack gives you 8 extra mantels (if you're having trouble doing the math, lol). These are necessary back-ups for perishable mantles (they turn to a kind of rigid ash once used, and are kind of delicate, although they can last for months if not years, if not poked or disturbed).Recommended!

We like the taste of these and use them in conjunction with the same company's Homeopathic Moon Drops, 30 Count to assist with getting a good sleep at night. They come in a largish slide-out box like an old-fashion matchbox. The write-up says they are for temporary relief of anxiety, tension and irritability. They are based upon traditional homeopathic practice and have not been reviewed by the FDA. Being homeopathic, you could take the whole box and not have a problem. Recommended dosage is one lozenge dissolved in the mouth (for adults or children) every half hour as needed.Active ingredients are aconitum, arsenicum, calcarea, chamomile, ignatia, kali carb, lacheis, natrum, nux vom, phosphoricum, pulsatilla and sepia.They are mildly sweet, and do contain sugar -- although it's good to know, it is organic (with oil of vanilla and tapioca syrup as well).Here's the thing: just the act of sucking a lozenge while going to sleep is soothing. These are not strong drugs, so it's hard to really tell if they're working. If and when you're worried about something, if you're like us, it may affect you going to sleep and staying that way, so it's a difficult to gauge just how effective these mild drops are.However, we find them soothing, and we enjoy them, and that's good enough for us.Recommended!

We have a couple of these, purchased primarily for home protection. This is a decent quality (fighting) machete which could be used in a pinch clearing brush etc. It is shaped, however, as a sword. It has good balance and feels fine in the hand. The handle is made like a traditional Japanese katana -- metal wrapped with cord. In this case, it's nylon, and provides excellent grip. We ran a flame lightly over the material to "weld" it together so it won't unravel (be careful not to set it alight!). Below the sharpened point and blade, there's a wicked serrated edge -- which could be used for sawing sticks etc., but would be deadly as a striking edge.One point off for the fact that the machete arrived with the blade not too sharp. I've used a whetstone on it, and it's got a keen edge now.It comes with a light nylon sheath and shoulder-carrying strap. Great value for around 20-bucks!Recommended!

Handy gear bag -- for the gym, or even as an overnight bag. As frequent buyers of athletic and outdoor gear, we received a sample for review. The straps are strong and handy, with the option to carry by hand or over the shoulder. The the zippers are nylon, heavy duty, with metal tabs. There's a top zip-open flap, and zipper pockets at each end. The bottom is double-stitched waterproof material, and there's a  foam pad sewn in. W have it loaded with beach towels, gear and sunscreen, ready for the river. Great value for the $$!It's an excellent all-round sports duffel.Recommended.

This is a striking necklace, with it's mounted "pearl" and man-made, glittering diamonds. This necklace, plated with 18K white gold, looks like a lot more money than it is! You can wear this with confidence, knowing that you're not risking a lot of money IF it should be lost -- and that it looks like a lot more $$$ than it costs.Good deal -- would make a nice gift as well.Recommended!

Security can be fun! This is a cool "toy" -- a voice-activated safe that responds not only to the child's secret self-chosen password or catch phrase, but to the timbre of their voice and even the inflection. We got this for an 8-yr-old-going-on-18 girl who has a younger brother. You get the drift. She has a hard time keeping anything private. But the Zillionz Safe for our future Zillionaire solves the problem. Now she can secretly program her safe and hide away her diary and "precious" items. But let's not get carried away. The safe is plastic, so it could be busted open with a hammer -- or stolen completely. But that's not the point. This can sit in her room, and with a little help from the parents as to the rules about safe-cracking, it can remain there, protecting her valuables and giving her a fun way to get a little privacy.The voice software built into this "toy" is pretty amazing. It's also easy to use. Press the blue button to get going (batteries, 3 x AAs) come with, so it's ready (unless they've gone flat on the shelf). It's intuitive, and there are spoken instructions (in a female voice). The new owner will be prompted to speak her secret password or phrase. She'll be asked to say it again to make sure. If it's not said exactly the same way again, it will not be accepted. Once the machine is satisfied with the result, it says so. Next time the child presses the same (blue) button, she'll be asked to provide her secret password. She must say it the same way -- believe me, we tried a slightly different phrasing or inflection and did not get a pass! Try again. But get it wrong twice and you're busted! A red light flashes and a siren goes off. At this point, little brother will be scuttling out of his sister's room! Say it correctly, though, and a green light flashes. There's a rumble and ca-ching, the door opens. Inside is a compartment to store bigger things, a little drawer, and a couple of removable shelves for valuables.Although this should not be announced to the entire family, should someone forget their password -- or presumably, each time batteries must be replaced -- the pass phrase will need to be reset. Probably with the help of an adult, the front door is removed by extracting two phillips screws. This reveals the battery compartment beneath -- and a reset hole which can be pressed to erase the former password and start over.Recommended.

For $15+ dollars, we thought this was a pretty good deal -- a number of things you'll probably need for your Sandisk Sansa Clip Plus. They only fit this item, by the way -- too bad SanDisk has stopped making it! We got one recently as we wanted a dedicated MP music player to use in the car, and it really fits the bill -- tons of memory, especially if you add a tiny SanDisk 32gig card, as we did.The main thing we wanted was the 12-v car charger. It's good quality, and is doing the job -- although the SanDisk instructions say you can charge your device while driving in your car and playing music. Not so. As soon as we plug in the charger, the player stops playing and goes into charge mode. Oh well. One of the best things is the silicone sleeve for the SanDisk -- made for it. The other useful things are the AC adaptor for when you're on the go -- or want to charge the device indoors. There's a USB cable you can plug into your computer in order to transfer audio files -- and charges the device as well, by the by. There's a stereo mini-jack cable -- useful to run music and audiobooks in and out of the device.I couldn't figure out what the rubber fish keychain was -- no place to attach it to the Sandisk or silicone sleeve -- until we realized it is something you can wrap you earbud wires around when on the go. Clever.All said, you need this for your SanDisk MP player -- and it's not provided by SanDisk itself. I wonder why not? But then, as I say, I wonder why SanDisk isn't making the Sansa Clip Plus anymore either. Probably knocked out by all the smart phones playing music these days.Recommended.

We call these the "Happy Pig" smoke detectors (because that's what they look like -- see photos below). There are 2 LED lights that flash from time-to-time in the red snouts to let you know the devices are working (they blink constantly when you need to replace the 9-v batteries that power them). Beneath the piggy snouts are the smiling "mouths" you see when you look up at the mounted units. These look to us like cute (and potentially life saving) "Happy Pigs."Reading the other reviews I must say first -- we did NOT get a free sample! We needed smoke detectors, read the specs, and bought 4 of these. With them we have upgraded smoke and fire detection in our entire house. The price of 4 was no big deal -- for what they are, they are cheap cheap!! Our old ones were installed when the home was built nearly twenty years ago. These were the expensive kind -- maybe $60 each, wired to the house power. However, those old detectors started to malfunction and we wondered if they were even working any more. Recently, we had a plumber fixing pipes in one of the bedrooms, churning up a lot of smoke as he soldered pipes, and the detector didn't work. Not even a peep -- although the green circuit light was on. Hmm. Time to make a change.In addition, while it probably seemed like a good idea at the time to wire those units so high, we have vaulted ceilings and without at least a 25-foot step ladder, there's no way to get to several of them. We decided we would only go with battery-powered units, installed where we can reach them, and forget about hardwiring them in.Why did we choose these "Happy Pigs?"- They are cutting edge, with a micro-processor that detects the appearance of smoke, as well as a traditional smoke detector.- The smoke alarm is 85 db -- let me tell you, plenty loud!- They run on long-lasting 9v batteries. In fact, each one comes with its own battery. When you figure the price of these as part of the $10 cost of the unit, The Smiling Pig is also a Very Good Deal.- These units flash very briefly from time to time, letting you know they're awake, doing their job. It is such a brief flash, you don't even see it unless you're looking at the detector. That said, it is still a light that flashes a couple of times a minute, so we decided not to put these in the bedrooms. We've gone to a lot of trouble to make sure these rooms are pitch black -- complete with blackout curtains, and no device that emits light. So we mounted a Smiling Pig high up in the hall outside each bedroom door. We've tested them. They'd pretty much wake the dead. This time, in our great rooms, we mounted units up on walls where we can actually get to them on a standard stepladder. Sure, it might be wiser to have them at the roof for early detection of smoke, but better to have them where we can change batteries -- and of course, turn them OFF if they are set off by burning toast etc., without a major panic.It's easy to mount these as well. It wouldn't really matter which way around they were turned, but there's a natural up and down look to the Smiling Pigs. Grab the back plate between fingers of one hand, and the main part in your other, and turn slightly and they come apart. The plate mounts to the wall with 2 screws (and drywall plastic supports) that also come-with. You can hold the backing plate up so the screw holes are in horizontal line and mark the screw holes with a pencil. Instead of a drill, try using a punch or even a phillips-head screwdriver tapped in with a hammer, to make a hole for the plastic inserts. Twist in your screws through the plates. Fit the detector over the plate and give it a twist -- not even a quarter turn. Voila. You're in business.You can test your unit with the handy little knob on the front. A quick push, and the snout lights blink. That's all you need. Really want to test the sound? Hold down that knob!Our Happy Pigs give us peace of mind -- and when we happen to notice 'em, they put a smile on our faces as well.Recommended.

I got one of these and the plug didn't work -- the blue LED light didn't come on and I returned it for a full refund. Got another. Works perfectly. It plugs right in, and provides a USB input as well for another device. The blue light lets you know it's working. It's easy to figure out. You can tune in any FM station in your area of course, but I don't need it for this as I have a good Honda car radio. What I want, because the vehicle is pre-mini-stereo-jack in the radio for smart phone and MP music players to plug in, is to use this iClever tuner to find a free FM station, and use it to run my Sandisk MP music through it. It's easy to figure out -- intuitive -- and I've readily discovered a batch of "free" (available) FM stations. You leave this tuner on one of those, and then manually set your car radio for the same station. Just plug the comes-with stereo mini-jack into your phone or other device where your tunes are stored, and away you go.One tip: I thought my tuner wasn't working at first because I had everything hooked up right, and couldn't hear my music. First, set your device (phone or player) to play as loudly as it can without distortion -- tested through your earphones etc. Then plug it into the FM tuner. Then crank up your car radio volume. Presto. Mine works like a charm.Recommended.
This is a great-looking and practical shell for the innovative Miche line of shell-purses.Recommended!

This is a priceless record of the thinking and strategy of those in the US Military who make the difficult decision to unleash atomic weapons against Japan. I have heard a great many arguments from those today who think it's their place to decide if the US was right to employ these atomic weapons of mass destruction to end the war against Japan. Personally, I have a deep interest in the time period, the world events, and the unleashing of these weapons. In order to truly understand how the US authorities came to their decisions, and employed the only 2 atomic bombs every used in warfare on our planet, you cannot find a better record than the one in this book.

I have a particular interest in this event and an arresting record of world history, as I write about the period and place myself. Therefore, I've read hundreds of books about WWII in general, and the atomic attack by the US on Japan, in particular.This book is a priceless piece of history, as it is an account by those who were actually there, of the events that took place in Nagasaki around and after the bomb went off on August 9, 1945. It's of special interest that the primary witness was a doctor who lived through the devastation, and dedicated his efforts to helping the survivors.I'm bemused by the reviewers who think theymust take a stand for or against the historical fact that the US employed atomic weapons against Japan, in the only war-time use of such weapons of mass destruction in the history of the planet. I presume it will always be controversial, and although I've read a great deal about it, I don't think it's my place as a student of history to have to take such a stand. Certainly, far more destruction and loss of life in WWII -- including all deaths caused by America and Japan -- were caused by more conventional weapons, including "carpet bombing" employed by both sides.There's a great deal of misinformation out there about what actually happened in Hiroshima and Nagasaki when those man-made "suns" lit up over their cities. Books like this one -- now out of print -- tell it through the priceless historical words of those who were there. IF those eyewitnesses happen to be Japanese, perhaps biased towards their own country's viewpoint, this is not a condemnation of the works. It in fact makes them even more valuable -- an insight, largely forgotten now, of the way people thought. More than 70 years later, those of us with an interest in the world-shaking events of WWII -- from Pearl Harbor to Hiroshima and Nagasaki, can be nothing but grateful for this irreplaceable record.Recommended.

I was a little leery ordering this, because a number of people said the plastic foot on their broke off. Not mine -- but then, I'm reasonably careful. I find the Fiskars does an excellent job of grabbing the weed taproot (the only kind it's really good at pulling out) and removing some very hard to hand-pull plants. The only time it can't do a good job -- and it's fairly often -- is when there are stones around the root, and then the pincers get jammed up with rocks. But that's not the device's fault -- just goes literally with the turf.This weeder has saved my low back a lot of grief! A couple of quibbles: I could have used another 6" on the handle (there's a more expensive version with an adjustable one) -- and yes, I'd feel a little more confident stomping on the "foot" if it was some sort of metal.That said, it does a great job for me.Recommended!
